column2: LONDON, June 18 -- Labor politicians pursued their personal and ideological quarreling today, despite appeals for restraint.

All thirty-three countries in Africa south of the Sahara have pledged participation or expressed interest in a Conference on African Resources to be held at New York University Sept. 19 through Sept. 21.
PARIS, June 18 -- It is doubtful that farmers in Kansas or South Dakota know about it, but a somewhat ominous note for their future was sounded in France this week.

THERE has recently been created a Reinhold Niebuhr Professorship of Social Ethics at Union Theological Seminary in New York City. The list of sponsors of this recognition for nearly half a century of leadership in social, political and religious thought reads like a Who's Who, spanning almost every field of cultural and institutional life, both here and abroad.

AMERICAN student life, on and off the campus and in private and public moments, has been Susan Greenburg's special project ever since she abandoned painting and took up the Leica camera about five years ago.

PROPER equipment and accessories can increase the pleasure and reduce the upkeep of an in-ground swimming pool. New and improved products available now make it possible for the owner to enjoy his pool with very little effort.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- The stage was set this week for a showdown struggle in the use of farm labor in California.
Although New York is usually thought of as a city of shrinking privacy, two cooperative apartment houses are rising by the East River along privately owned streets.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 18 -- Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N.J., drove his birdcage Maserati to an easy victory today in the Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker Trophy race. The event was the first-day feature of a series that will be capped by tomorrow's Vanderbilt Cup race for Formula Junior cars.

LONDON, June 18 -- Princess Margaret and her husband, Antony Armstrong-Jones, returned from their Caribbean honeymoon today to be greeted by the news that a wax effigy of the bridegroom had been stolen from Madame Tussaud's waxworks museum.

In a world which seems to be shrinking in size and exploding in population, it is often forgotten that there are still vast stretches of this globe which remain to be explored and exploited. One of the last unexplored frontiers is the Indian Ocean.

The phrase "sinking fund" is a deadly expression that usually dooms any sentence that makes room for it. On the other hand; "lottery" is a heady word -- one smacking of risk, high stakes and -- in the United States -- illegality.

SEOUL. AS South Koreans prepare to mark the tenth anniversary of a war that for a time seemed to threaten the obliteration of democracy in a struggling republic that was then only two years old, they find themselves again in a period of crisis.

TODAY'S living requires vast amounts of hot water. The average family of four, for example, consumes 44,000 gallons a year. Automatic laundering and dishwashing appliances contribute to the need for heaters that can replenish hot water as fast as it's used.
MILWAUKEE, June 18 (AP) -- Lew Burdette shut out St. Louis on seven hits today as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Cardinals, 5 -- 0, to snap Pitcher Larry Jackson's eight-game winning streak.

THIS is the most devastating study of the people of the United States and their peculiar culture that I have seen in the last twenty minutes. This man, Lord Kinross (Patrick Balfour), has traveled through thirty-four states and has observed our people in their native habitat.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- It anybody is interested in analyzing what is wrong with our diplomacy these days, he might get a clue from reading the dispatches of the reporters who saw President Eisenhower yesterday aboard the cruiser St. Paul.

WHEN, in the recent Botvinnik-Tal match for the world chess championship, Mikhail Botvinnik in effect resigned the match "because he was too old and tired," Raymond Balfe was inspired to compare bridge with other games, athletic and intellectual, and to conclude that bridge is a far better game to age with.
Warren E. Kraemer's head is buzzing with new ideas about the development of jet air travel.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 18 -- Ten meet records were broken and another was tied today as the varsity aspirants for berths on the United States Olympic team concluded their two-day exercises in the thirty-ninth National Collegiate track and field championships.

A colloquy between Justice Charles D. Breitel of the Appeliate Division of the State Supreme Court and an attorney representing the International Maritime Workers Union is stirring comment among maritime lawyers.
A foyer running from the front entrance to the rear stairway is a feature of a two-level model home in brick, stone and hand-split cedar shingles at Oakwood in Lawrence, L.I.
Excavations for new skyscrapers here are providing two amateur mineralogists a rare opportunity to study underground Manhattan.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 18 -- Richard Larkin, a 13-year-old student at Long Lots Junior High School, has been using Long Island Sound as a scientific laboratory for a little more than a year now.
HAVANA, June 18 -- Free enterprise has failed in Cuba and in the future the state will own and operate all industry, Maj. Ernesto Guevara, president of the National Bank of Cuba, said today.
A modern concept of criminal justice and penology, emphasizing rehabilitation rather than punishment, is finding expression in the design of municipal courts and jails.
QUEMOY, June 18 -- The communist guns that pounded the Chinese Nationalist strong-old of Quemoy last night were lent today.

MARIGOT, St. Martin, West Indies -- Travelers who like contrasts in foreign flavor are enjoying double delight these days on this tiny West Indian island, which floats like a bouquet on the Caribbean Sea 110 miles east of St. Thomas.
CAGLIARI, Sardinia -- "Sardinia is lost between Europe and Africa and belongs nowhere," wrote D.H. Lawrence. "It has no history, no date, no race. * * * It lies outside the circuit of civilization."
Next Thursday a six-member health commando team from the United States will establish a beachhead on the northern shore of the peninsula that juts out from the southern coast of Haiti toward Cuba.
ATLANTA, June 18 (AP) -- Billy Lenoir of Sucson beat John Maloney of South Africa today and gained the final of the southern amateur tennis tournament.
HOLLYWOOD LABOR peace returned to the movie industry last week for the first time since Jan. 16, when the screen writers began a strike against seven of the eight major studios.

FREDERIC R. MANN, the energetic Philadelphia business man who has headed that city's Robin Hood Dell concerts since 1949, announces that the six-week Dell season, which opens tomorrow night, will have a new feature.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The downing of the U-2 in Soviet Russia, just as the summit conference of 1960 was preparing to assemble In Paris, exposed an official policy of the United States Government that was precisely what the anti-treaty forces in Japan needed. And this completed the case against what they call the Eisenhower-Nixon Administration that the Democrats plan to put before the voters in the Presidential campaign of 1960.
Alberto Bimboni of 380 Riverside Drive, a conductor, composer and teacher of music, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 77 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- Bill Rigney was released as manager of the Giants today and replaced by Tom Sheehan, who went out ninety minutes later and directed the team to a 7-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
WEST TISBURY, Mass., June 18 -- After nine weeks without ferry service the island of Martha's Vineyard is more determined than ever to resist the unions that have struck the boats.

PHILADELPHIA -- To the roll of drums, the nation's fifty-star flag will be raised officially for the first time at Independence Hall by a Marine Corps color guard in Colonial uniforms at 11 A.M. on the Fourth of July.
The old-time lumberjack, long famous in song and story, is rapidly becoming as imaginary as some of his more fanciful tales about Paul Bunyan and Babe the Blue Ox.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Bishop Lloyd C. Wicke of Pittsburgh was named today Resident Bishop of the New York area of the Methodist Church. He succeeds retired Bishop Frederick Buckley Newell.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 18 -- The Newport-Bermuda ocean race is an exciting evant for this island.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Deeds, not words, appeared this week the better standard for measuring the revived Presidential aspirations of Adali E. Stevenson of Illinois and Governor Rockefeller of New York.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 18 -- The Nassau County Classroom Teachers Association today announced its support for 17-year-old Stephen Bayne, an honor student at Westbury High School who refused a citizenship award from the American Legion last week.
ELKHART LAKE, Wis., June 18 (UPI) -- George Reed of Midlothian, Ill., won the sixty-mile event for big cars at the opening of the international June sprints at the Road America track today.
GOTHAM, Notts., England -- There is no place else on earth like Gotham. That is the considered opinion of all true Gothamites, and they have given the question years of leisurely study?

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 18 -- Ethiopia declared today that the nations of Africa must form a "common African foreign policy based on African unity" but not precluding the attraction of foreign capital.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 18 -- Patrice Lumumba, who was informed officially yesterday that his chance to form the first government of an independent Congo had ended, told a public meeting here today that he was setting up an adminisration anyhow.

AS you lie on a crowded beach on July 4, or grope for a slippery hold on an overpopulated raft in the lake on Labor Day, do you ever dream of having a family swimming pool on the property? If so, don't be frightened by tales of hazards and sky-rocketing costs.
THERE'S a bright and constant star to steer by when looking for a modern gas appliance. It's the Blue Star Seal of Approval. This time-tested guide points the way to satisfaction.
EAST LANSING, Midi., June 18 -- Michigan's Democratic delegation voted overwhelmingly today for Senator John F. Kennedy in an informal poll.

TRENTON, June 18 -- New Jersey's basic property assessment problem -- uniformity of rates -- was solved this week when Gov. Robert B. Meynel signed into law an amendment to the state's century-old statute that requires assessment at 100 per cent of true, or market value.

ABLY translated from a very idiomatic language by Gerald Stillman, this novel is a characteristic work of the principal founder of the modern Yiddish tradition. Like other Yiddish writers, Mendele Mocher Seforim -- whose pen name means Mendele the bookseller -- seems overshadowed by Sholem Aleichem, a later author who was at his best when he wrote short stories.

ONE afternoon in the autumn of 1941, a football team from Southern Methodist University arrived at New York's Polo Grounds to play Fordham. But the game was only a part of the attraction for the crowd that attended.
NAKURU, Kenya, June 10 -- If you have always wanted a castle, there is one for sale just eight miles from here -- in the heart of Africa.
A private export trade promotion program organized by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., one of this country's major steamship companies, will get under way in August.

TELEVISION commentators, newspaper men and politicians traditionally are enamored of the mechanics of politics; they are so close to the firing line that understandably every twist and turn in strategy takes on an absorbing fascination.
WHEN a renowned aeronauticist plans a new home, one might expect it to be "out of this world." This is just what the nearly completed California residence of Dr. Clark B. Millikan promises to be.

Spurred by Father's Day promotions, retail trade in this area last week rose an estimated 4 per cent above the 1959 level, according to leading retailers. There was heavy traffic in men's wear departments. Consumers, apparently in a late buying mood, according to merchants, made up for the light shopping the week before.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- President Franklin D. Roosevelt and other American officials repeatedly prodded the British to speed the granting of independence to India early in World War II, state documents released today showed.
HOW little this country seems to know and can about its own important music is illustrated by the case of the Symphony No. 1 by Roger Sessions.

ONE hundred million Americans can't be wrong! They insist that natural gas is the perfect fuel for homes and schools, churches and hospitals, hotels and restaurants, stores and factories -- everywhere, in fact, that reliability, efficiency, cleanliness and economy are desired.

Freedomland, a 205-acre mixture of nostalgia, science fiction and parking lots, built on a reclaimed swamp in the Bronx, was dedicated yesterday. A throng of 25,000, many of them children, attended the preview showing and parade of costumed employes, which benefited Boys Harbor, the Children's Village Interfaith Chapel and the Sheltering Arms Children's Services.

IF Chekhov thrived on Fourth Street, can Ibsen? This is the question, and listening last week to David Ross, major domo of the Fourth Street Theatre, even the most confirmed non-believer would be hard-pressed to say nay.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 -- An edict by the Archbishop of St. Louis that Roman Catholic students must have written permission to attend secular and other non-Catholic colleges and universities has apparently met calm acceptance among Catholics here.

THE CANCELED VISIT REACTION AT HOME The project was doomed from the start. It could have been at least partially salvaged a couple of weeks ago when Senator Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, made an earnest plea for *** postponement ***.

ON children's records, outer space is the world of the possible. Manned flight already exists. Its launchings seldom sputter, its space stations go in circle's, its moon men take right off to the other planets.

The automobile rally has finally made the big time as a sport in the Communist world. Earlier this month the first international Communist rally took place and won much more publicity in the Russian press than any such event has before.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 18-- The Jewish War Veterans denied today that it intended to demonstrate against George Lincoln Rockwell, a self-styled Nazi, when he speaks in Manhattan's Union Square on July 4.

Why Are Men Timid? "What is it," asks Justice Frankfurter in "Felix Frankfurter Reminisces," a recently published transcript of a series of recorded conversations, "that makes so many men timid creatures?"
Bills that would drastically amend the Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Compensation Act are pending in the House of Representatives.

The splash of a 2,100-ton containership launched at the Maryland Shipbuilding and Drydock Company in Baltimore last week heralded the opening of a new chapter for a shipping line that once ran canalers between Lake Erie and New York.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Scholars and politicians working on the frequently neglected problems of state government have an important new tool -- a massive guide to the constitutions of all fifty states.
ROCKFORD, Ill., June 18 (UPI) -- Bonnie Randolph of Columbus, Ohio, took the lead in the Cosmopolitan women's open golf tourney today with a second-round 68 for a 36-hole total of 138.

In this world of taxes, virtue increasingly must find its own reward. Long ago, investors discovered that a corporation able to show a string of losses could command a premium for its shares in a merger dicker with a profitable concern.

A gradual but significant change in New York City's government set-up in recent years is the rise of professional men who are now getting the top administrative jobs that once were sinecures for professional politicians.
THE heavy industry of thesis writing flourishes much more luxuriantly in the United States than in Great Britain. This is largely a matter of money. American universities are better endowed.

THE phrase, "And this be our Motto, in God is our trust" from Francis Scott Key's "Star - Spangled Banner," features the design of a red and blue on white 4-cent stamp which, as one of the Credo series introduced by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield last January, will be issued on Sept. 14.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 18 -- The third annual Atlantic City predicted-log cruiser contest from Atlantic Highlands to Atlantic City for the Atlantic City Perpetual Trophy was won today by Henry R. Stadler of the Atlantic Highlands Yacht Club in his Philijean with an accuracy score of 99.22 per cent.

FIFTY bulldozers churned the ground; rising clouds of dust choked the small army of workers. Seemingly everywhere were machines and men on the move, as though someone had given the signal to re-stage a Western land rush.

MOST new home owners are faced with two main garden problems -- how to start an attractive landscape planting, and, once started, how to maintain it at reasonable cost. Ordinarily, about 10 per cent of the cost of the house is a fair estimate of the cost of the landscaping, and 10 per cent of this amount must be put aside for yearly maintenance.
MADRID, June 18 -- High Roman Catholic sources in Spain believe that the coining sixth International Catholic Press Congress may spur the Government to act on its long-buried draft press law.
The conditions under which the city will permit double-standing by trucks while making deliveries were announced yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley.

IT'S HARD to beat a bank account that grows larger each year even though your expenditures become increasingly greater. And that's just what has been happening to the nation's supply of natural gas -- the balance on deposit increases despite record withdrawals.
LOS ANGELES. SOMETIME this year, this city, which has become increasingly restive about the esthetic superiority of San Francisco, will begin clearing out some of its cultural smog.
Included in the few art openings of the week are two group shows that should interest summer visitors to the galleries.
Thirty houses are planned for the final section of Central Park, a colony of 420 dwellings at Routes 34 and 9 in Madison Township, N.J.
NAHA, Okinawa, Sunday, June 19 -- President Eisenhower, appearing glum and dejected, emerged today from the office of the chief executive Ryukyu of the Islands, Seisaku Ota.

Arms and the Allies While the effects of the U-2 affair and the Japanese events were still reverberating, the focus in the East-West propaganda contest appeared to be shifting to the field of disarmament. Soviet Premier Khrushchev's proposals in this field have had considerable impact among neutral nations, and last week Western allies of the United States were pressing for a "new look" to counter them.

Six Chileans concerned with providing housing for their country will return home this week from a United States tour to face a problem that has tragically doubled in their absence. Earthquakes and floods have destroyed or heavily damaged about 500,000 homes.
The boundaries have just about disappeared that once divided the marketing areas in which the various Standard Oil companies were permitted to do business in 1911.

What is the function of fashion; what should it do for a woman? NORMAN HARTNELL: Fashion is created to give an aura of romance to women. It should expose or hide, but at all times embellish. A man dresses up order to dominate; a woman dresses up in order to appeal.

AS natural gas moves into your home from sources perhaps a thousand miles away, the final important connecting link is your local gas utility company. As the distribution member of a well-coordinated supply team, the local utility takes over from pipelines at a "town border station" on the edge of your community and completes the journey of "stored sunshine."

WIMBLEDON, England, June 18 (UPI) -- Neale Fraser of Australia and Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, are co-favorites to win the men's singles of what almost certainly will be the amateur Wimbledon lawn tennis championships.
WHEN does an American worker become "too old" to get a new job or win a promotion? The answer is: at a atartlingly early age -- 40, or sometimes even younger.
GOLF Arnold Palmer won the United States Open championship with a 72-hole score of 280 at Denver. He shot a 65 on the final round. Jack Nicklaus, an amateur, was second at 282. Six pros tied at 283.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- When the Yankees left New York last Sunday night, they were determined to be alone in first place by Father's Day. With hours, runs and base-hits to spare, they achieved their objective today.

The teaching of modern foreign languages beginning at the third grade for all children and a ten-year continuous sequence for the academically talented was recommended yesterday by specialists in the field.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A Jewish educator and historian asserted tonight that American Jews "have no right to become tired" of fund-raising efforts for Israel until that nation's people had achieved full economic independence.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18 -- Harvard University is cooperating in a project to uncover the buried city of Shechem, Israel's first capital, and the first city in Palestine to be mentioned in the Bible.

For Ages 9 to 12. COMBINING comedy, philosophy and nature lore, M. M. Osborne Jr., a pediatrician who knows birds as well as children, has written an offbeat fable (handsomely illustrated by Evaline Ness) that reminds me a little of Rumer Godden's "The Mousewife."

FREEDOMLAND RANKS as the world's largest outdoor family entertainment center: situated in a 205-acre arena, the U.S.-shaped park spans 85 acres, with the remainder devoted to parking and service facilities.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. -- This city long has had the reputation of being Florida's original "summer resort," and it is going all-out again this year to uphold that standing. Advance reservations at the beachfront hotels and motels indicate a busy season for the Daytona Beach area, which extends from Ormond Beach to the north to New Smyrna Beach to the south.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 18 -- When Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson step into the ring at the Polo Grounds tomorrow night for their championship fight, a third man will be in a neutral corner with a portable, home-made organ.
LONDON, June 18 -- With a combination of artistry and vitality of stroke production not often seen, Andres Gimeno, added another conquest to his string today at Queen's Club.

The saying in the cocoa circles this year is that no one has been hurt in the cocoa market. The statement is true as far as domestic interests are concerned, but not necessarily so for producing countries.
To U.S. Position The stakes in the East-West struggle in Asia are immense. They involve roughly one-half of the world's population, one-third of its land area and vast untapped resources.

TRENTON -- A massive state park and recreational center is being developed in the heart of the New Jersey pine barrens. The site is known as the Wharton Tract and it sprawls over 96,000 acres of semi-wilderness, an area larger than all of the state's fourteen, other parks combined.
MOSCOW, June 18 -- The Communist party told the Soviet people today that the "American fiasco" in Japan has written the epitaph of President Eisenhower's Administration.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 18 -- Paul Ziffren, California's Democratic National Committeeman since 1853, was retired today by Gov. Edmund G. Brown's favorite-son delegation.

WARRENSBURG, N.Y. -- The Adirondacks area of upper New York State has been drawing visitors for the last 350 years, judging from that fact that both Henry Hudson and Samuel de Champlain dropped anchor there within two months of each other in 1609.

SHORTLY before the copyright began to lapse on the Gilbert and Sullivan operas, an elderly woman in Oxford petitioned Parliament to waive the existing law and allow these works to remain forever outside the public domain.
Russians' questions to Americans visiting the Soviet Union revolve largely around the point: "Where does your money go?"
The mass market in this country's fashions is becoming more entrenched than before.
The first section of play in the International Soccer League ends at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City today with a doubleheader involving four of the loop's strongest teams.

DANVILLE, Va., June 18 -- Plans to establish a privately sponsored library were started here this week after the residents had voted to close the public library rather than to integrate it racially as directed by a Federal court.

SEOUL, Korea, June 18 -- South Korea will seek President Eisenhower's support in solving its critical problems -- including questions of unification and economic and military aid -- during his twenty-eight-hour visit beginning tomorrow.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 18 -- Peter Lorson's Yankee scored a 36-second victory over Dr. Edson Stannard's Frolic in the Manhasset Bay One-Design class in today's Interclub racing sponsored by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

THE home owner who is considering the purchase of a permanent, inground swimming pool has a sizable variety of construction methods and materials from which to choose. Although costs, site problems, size of family and other factors will influence the final choice, each type of pool has its own merits.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector)), June 18 -- The Israeli Government was expecting today to have to stand alone in Wednesday's debate in the United Nations Security Council on the manner in which Adolf Eichmann was captured in Argentina and taken to Israel for trial.
HARTFORD, June 18 -- Connecticut Democrats broke party history today by advocating higher taxes.

The Middle East Technical University in Turkey will enter a new phase of development with the graduation of its first class next month and the start of construction this summer of a $50,000,000 campus near Ankara.

TOKYO, June 18 -- The Communist-instigated disorders that have prevented President Eisenhower from visiting Tokyo on his Far Eastern tour have plunged Japan into the gravest domestic crisis since the end of World War II.

To the Travel Editor: WILLIAM LUCE'S article entitled "How to Rough It With a Touch of Elegance" [June 5] is a true tale of a tenderfoot. I think it should be pointed out to Mr. Luce that what he calls camping is, in reality, nothing more than an adult version of the common practice of eleven-year-old boys, in their own back-yards called "Sleeping Out."

THIS is an elegant run-of-the-mill Western. Harry Brown wrote "A Walk in the Sun," one of the best war novels. He has also written a great deal of verse and won prizes with it. You are reminded of these earlier achievements on every page of "The Stars in Their Courses," though you are seeing unfold nothing more than a standard horse-opera plot.

To THE EDITOR: Professor Fred Rodell's analysis of the "Crux of the Court Hullabaloo" (May 29) makes for better understanding of the functioning of the Supreme Court. It renders clear that the present division among the justices, however sharp the lines are sometimes drawn, is more apparent than real.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A railroad spokesman said today that delays resulting from wage demands had not diminished management's determination to modernize work practices as quickly as possible.
Through plant modernization and belt-tightening, British shipyards are now able to compete in pricing with construction yards in West Europe.

BUENOS AIRES, June 18 -- The first flush of nationalist protest over the disappearance from Argentina of Adolf Eichmann has been followed by a more critical mood asking why the Nazi accused of a key role in the extermination of 6,000,000 Jews was in Argentina at all.
Most people in the Belgian Congo have difficulty grasping what their coming independence means, a panelist of the New York Times Youth Forum said yesterday.

BECAUSE millions of travelers are expected to visit Civil War battlefields next year, when the centennial of the start of that conflict will be observed, and thereafter through 1965, the historyminded tourist might well consider beating the crowds by making his tour this summer.

WHEN he was in Brussels last month Wilfrid Pelletier was in an intellectually stimulating position. He had nearly finished a survey of European conservatories that he had been sent to make by the Montreal Conservatory, and at the finals of the Queen Elisabeth of Belgium contest, he found himself listening to the products of American music schools playing in competition with Students from European schools such as he had studied.
MODERN gas refrigerators, cooled by energy from a tiny blue flame, are making their debut this year wearing the smart new "square look."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- This city's pride has receive a jarring blow. San Francisco, long basking in its role as the financial and cultural cosmopolis of the West, was revealed this week as a city that has lost 60,000 of its residents in the last decade.
Following is the text of a Statement issued yesterday by Commissioner of Purchase Joseph V. Spagna:

PARIS, June 18 (UPI) -- Mrs. Ann Casey Johnstone of Mason City, Iowa, America's only representative in the French women's golf championship, was eliminated today in the semifinals by Brigitte Varangot of France, 3 and 2.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., June 18 (UPI) -- Michael Owen Page of New York was the top scorer today at the start of the Olympic three-day dressage test in trials for the United States equestrian team that will compete in the Rome games.
IF institutions thrive on criticism, the Presidential nominating conventions are guaranteed immortality. For years people have been saying how awful they are.

CHOICE FOR TALENT -- A comprehensive high school in Davenport, Iowa, has taken a leaf from the college catalogues. Students may now enroll in any one of eight different programs designed to fulfill their individual purposes, abilities and aptitudes.

One of the few all-breed shows still held within New York City limits is scheduled for next Sunday when the twenty-first dog show and annual obedience trial of the Staten Island Kennel Club will be staged at Tompkinsville.

A Blessing of the Fleet will be held today in the Jamaica Bay waters off Canarsie principally for the pleasure craft of the Inter-Yacht Council. Commodore Tex Frost and Fleet Capt. Henry Prestidge of the Hudson River Y.C. at Paerdegat Basin, Brooklyn, foot of Avenue U, will be the sponsors.

TO THE EDITOR: Your correspondent Joseph T. McIntyre wrote of me, "To identify, as he does, an aversion to pornography with Puritanism is astonishing." If Mr. McIntyre thinks that "Puritanism" can mean only "an aversion to pornography," he has what educators call a problem in reading comprehension.

A MAN once wrote a letter-to-the-editor bemoaning the fact that, when Father's Day rolls around, the average father is pictured "exclusively as his children's adviser in relation to baseball, fishing tackle and outboard motors."

SUMMER THEATRE, that congenial combination of the rustic, artistic and frantic, is looking forward to a new season with high hopes for success -- the whims of audiences, temperaments of stars and vagaries of weather permitting.
An eight-day strike of Eastern Air Lines pilots against rules of the Federal Aviation Agency spread yesterday to Pan American World Airways.

NOW that the international furor over the execution of Caryl Chessman has had time to die down, it may be possible to discuss Chessman's first (and only) novel strictly on its own merits -- if one can find them.
ABRAHAM LINCOLN used to tell the story of the man who was being ridden out of town on a rail.

Stuart Thomas Saunders is the kind of man who could jump from a small institution such as Roanoke College in Salem, Va. (present faculty, 44; students, 662) to Harvard Law School and make his Ivy League classmates like it.
TALES of desert prospectors and divers for sunken doubloons pale by comparison with one of the greatest treasure hunts of modern times -- the exciting search for gas and oil.
KANSAS CITY, June 18 (UPI) -- Dan Dobbek slammed two home runs and Jim Lemon hit his seventeenth tonight as they paced the Washington Senators to a 7-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

ATLANTA, June 18 -- Another challenge has been raised to the somewhat popular theory that voting rights can be guaranteed by simply passing a new law. The challenge carries added significance because it comes from the Old Plantation Belt, the most intransigent area on the issue.

New York Democrats put the finishing touches yesterday on national platform proposals calling for strong action on civil rights, a coordinated attack on metropolitan problems and a more forceful foreign policy.
ALEGEND that goes back to medieval times has been turned into an opera by Lee Hoiby on commission from Station WAVE-TV in Louisville, Ky.

FOR THIS WEEK: Mulch flower beds and vegetable plots to conserve moisture and keep down weeds. . . . Yellowing leaves and curling twigs on elm trees may indicate Dutch elm disease; consult tree experts for control measures. . . . Use diazinon now, and again in early August, to control lawn chinch bugs. . . .

Checkers fans will have an opportunity to pit their skills against the world's free-style champion, Tom Wiswell, at the recently re-opened Chess and Checkers Club of New York at 2 P.M. on Sunday, June 26.
A move that may take some teachers out of administrative posts at school headquarters and return them to classrooms is under way at the Board of Education.
With the United States contributing three grandmasters -- Bobby Fischer, Samuel Reshevsky and Larry Evans -- another South American International chess tournament will start tomorrow.
With the United States contributing three grandmasters -- Bobby Fischer, Samuel Reshevsky and Larry Evans -- another South American International chess tournament will start tomorrow.

A CIVIL Aeronautics Board announcement last week liberalizing regulations of charter flights points up the steady growth this travel season of such flights. The chartering of airplanes for use by a cohesive group or an organization, thus cutting the cost of air travel about in half, has been growing steadily, and last year it started running away.

HAVANA. SHYING away from the crowded and chaotic center stage of the revolution, but not altogether hiding in its wings, a soft-spoken, Argentinian-born physician with Communist propensities, shoulder-length hair and an indefinably oriental aspect is Cuba's eminence grise.

PARIS. THE newest exhibition in Paris is of 702 pictures, all painted before 1800, from the storerooms of Louvre -- "Les Reserves da walls of seven new galleries. After six months or so, the plan is for these to be removed and an equal number to take their place.

MEXICO is a land that has quickened the imagination of writers, artists and tourists -- more deeply, perhaps, than any other country in this hemisphere. The mixtures of races, the exotic mingling of Christian and pagan traditions, the heat, the history of revolutions and unrest, all have an unforgettable impact on the visitor.
WHEN you were a youngster, did you ever imagine yourself in the midst of the great adventures of America's history?

HE is a quiet child -- too quiet, and too well - behaved. He lacks the "bellyful of fire" that the late William Byron Mowery thought all small boys had -- or should have. Instead, he stands wistfully on the sidelines, unable to wade into the rough and tumble savored by a boy among boys.

THE tremendous majesty of Niagara Falls and its rapids, gorges and whirlpools are, despite their familiarity, sights of the greatest interest. They are spectacularly rewarding, both on the American and Canadian sides.

WASHINGTON -- This is the time of year when the best-seller list down at the Government Printing Office goes through a little shuffling. The run on one of the biggest sellers, "Your Federal Income Tax," is about over for the year.

Ingemar Johansson, a 27-year-old native of Goteborg Sweden, will make the first defense of his world heavyweight championship tomorrow night. He will oppose the previous title-holder, Floyd Patterson of Rockville Centre, L.I., in a fight scheduled for fifteen rounds at the Polo Grounds.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 18 -- On June 30 the Congolese people will become their own masters. This week in the capitals of the six provinces that will make up the new country one third the size of the United States, provincial assemblies met.

THE tourist traveling from Athens into the southern part of Greece normally goes by bus or on one of the new Diesel trains operated by the Peloponnesus Railroad. If he wants to live dangerously, however, and at the same time familiarize himself with every cowpath on the Argive Plain, he can do as this traveler did and take the fabled Athenian steam train.

HARTFORD, Conn. -- This state's new turnpike, a comparative infant in the world of superhighways, was used by 40,356,271 vehicles during 1959, its second year of operation. This followed a lean twelve-month period in which most of the turnpike resembled a deserted runway more than a superhighway.

I CAN'T escape the conclusion that it is the opinion of the powers that be in post-graduate medical schooling that one cannot learn unless one is tired browbesten, or hungry, preferably a combination of all three.

THE nation's airlines flew more people, more goods and more mail in 1959, the first full year of the jet age, than in any previous year, the Air Transport Association of America reported in the 1960 edition of its official publication, Air Transport Facts and Figures.

Two more arrests were made yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in the $25,000 faked hold-up of a Yonkers bank last Monday. The teller who handed over the money and one alleged accomplice were already under arrest.

QUANTICO, Va., June 18 -- Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. opened the door today to abandonment of the principle of service rotation in the appointment of chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

AMONG the members of the Intimate Wilson circle, no one aside from the family group had better opportunity to view and know Woodrow Wilson than did Cary T. Grayson. A Navy doctor attached to the White House during the Taft Administration, Grayson stayed on to serve aa personal physician to President Wilson from his inauguration in 1913 until his death in 1924.

The Yankees announced yesterday that mail orders for the I960 all-star baseball game at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday afternoon, July 13, would be accepted beginning tomorrow. AALBORG, Denmark. WHAT is described as the largest dairy plant in Denmark is only a few miles from Aalborg. Known as Akafa, it is, like most Danish concerns, cooperatively owned. It belongs to 102 dairies, representing some 15,000 farmers.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Furniture makers have stopped trying to be the stars of the Decorating show at home am have switched to the role o mother's helper. VERDI'S second opera, "Un gidrno di regno," sung in English as "King for a Day," had what was said to be its first American, performance at Town Hall Saturday evening. It was performed by the Amato Opera Theatre.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown's displacement this week-end of Paul Zaffren as California's Democratic National Committeeman is regarded by political observers here as a maneuver with mixed implications for the party on both state and national levels.

The lack of summer job opportunities for high school youths has increased the fear of many social workers here that this summer may be a violent one. The job market for young people was described as the tightest in years.

FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, June 19 -- Two rookie race drivers, Chris Bristow and Alan Stacey, crashed to their deaths during the Belgian Grand Prix this warm, sunny afternoon. The race, witnessed by about 100,000 fans, was won by Jack Brabham, the world champion, who drove a Cooper.
THE method of contract bridge scoring known as "Chicago," or more formally as four-deal bridge, is increasingly popular in bridge clubs.

KATONAH, N.Y. June 19 -- What with the British Exhibition the British Tattoo and the British crosscountry walkers, this has certainly been a good month for Anglo-American relations. It was a fine gesture on the part of Caramoor to add a festival of British music.

TOKYO, June 19 -- Japanese Leftists set themselves today for a long struggle to nullify or weaken the new United StatesJapanese mutual security treaty. It was ratified in the Diet (Parliament) automatically last midnight.

Thomas H. Raddall has won the 1959 Doubleday Canadian Prize Novel award for his forthcoming biographical story "The Governor's Lady." The award consists of a prize of $2,500 outright and $7,500 as an advance against the author's earnings.

THIS month the first summer surge of out-of-town visitors has hit New York. By the end of August the total will have reached more than four million, Among them, several thousand women will, unknowingly, deserve the title of the worstdressed in the city.

DETROIT, June 19 (AP) -- Hoyt Wilhelm and Milt Pappas hurled the Baltimore Orioles to a pair of shutouts over the Tigers today, Pappas blanking them on three singles after Wilhelm had pitched a twohitter. The scores were 2-0 and 1-0.

JERSEY CITY, June 19 -- Unbeaten Kilmarnock of Scotland won the first section of play in the International Soccer League today. A crowd of 11,704 saw the Scotsmen beat the New York Americans, 3-1, in the feature of a double-header at Roosevelt Stadium.

At least ninety optimistic school boards in New York State are watching with rising interest as Congress careers its way toward adjournment. Last Wednesday, the Senate Finance Committee voted to allow the 10 per cent Federal tax on local telephone service to lapse on July 1.

Congressional approval of a constitutional amendment to give to citizens of the District of Columbia the right to vote for President and Vice President is only about a century and a half overdue. However, better late than never -- and so we welcome the prospective .Twenty-third Amendment and hope that the Legislatures of New York and the other states will approve it as soon as possible, surely within the requisite seven-year limit.

TOKYO, June 19 -- President Eisenhower's brief visit to Okinawa today gave disaffected residents their first real chance to express their, grievances against the United States in a manner calculated to make a solid impression on the American public.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- Dr. Linus C. Pauling, a Nobel Prize winner, said today he had been subpoenaed to testify tomorrow "on Communist participation in, or support of, a propaganda campaign against nuclear testing."

MOSCOW, June 20 -- Soviet physicians attracted world attention with such advanced experiments as the transplanting of live animal organs. But on a practical level, does the average Russian get adequate medical treatment?
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I read with amazement the letter of William U. Taylor published on June 15, in which he takes you to task for your editorial of June 2, "No Buses on Parkways."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Senate was told today that the Federal Communications Commission had been giving an advantage in television license contests to firms with members of Congress among their stockholders.

Henry Wallitsch, a 24-year-old shipping clerk from Astoria, Queens, scored a technical knockout over Lennart Risberg of Stockholm, Sweden, last night in the scheduled six-round semifinal to the heavyweight title bout.

"The only reason the bill cannot be introduced now," Mr. Lindsay said, "is because there will be no more action this session on excise taxes in the Ways and Means Committee. But the bill will be a major project of mine in the next Congress.
QUEBEC, June 20 -- There is a fresh political wind blowing in Quebec as the provincial election campaign enters its final stage.
Ingrid Bergman and Sir Laurence Olivier, who made their first appearances in dramas on American television this season, last night won the medium's highest award for their portrayals.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- It take a cheap o'dirt to make house a home today. Dr. Sydney J. Levy of Social Research Inc., told the Fashion Group a a luncheon meeting here today that the American home is dirtier, but that the people living in it are happier.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The bottle-nosed dolphin, the playboy of the sea and the age-old friend of mariners, was said today to be at least equal, and perhaps superior, to man in some aspects of brain power.

SEOUL, Korea, June 20 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a toast given by President Eisenhower at a state luncheon in Seoul, a speech by the President at a military review, the joint communique issued by General Eisenhower and Premier Huh Chung, and farewell statement by Premier Huh and the President:
LONDON, June 20 -- Prices retreated sharply in the stock market here today on renewed fears that the Government would take further steps to contain inflation and avoid balance of payments troubles.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A fundamental change in American politics is illustrated by the fact that in 1960 no Governor of a state is a strong contender for the Presidential nomination of either party. Three Senators are the foremost Democratic contestants, and the virtually certain Republican nominee is a former Senator who is still associated with that branch of Congress.

A State Supreme Court justice granted an order yesterday restraining Park Commissioner Newbold Morris from issuing a permit to the American Nazi party to conduct a political rally in Union Square Park July 4.
Floyd Patterson, in winning back the heavyweight championship, achieved a feat that escaped some of the more legendary figures of the ring.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 20 -- Joseph Kasavubu and Patrice Lumumba met tonight with other Congolese leaders. At the end of the session one participant said the formation of a national union Government was imminent.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal District Court might condition an injunction against a railroad strike on the employer's withdrawal of changes in freight runs that had precipiated the labor trouble.
MINOT, N.D., June 20 -- Following is the text of a major farm speech by Vice President Nixon before a Republican rally here tonight:

WARSAW, June 20 -- The East European Communist party chiefs assembled in Bucharest for the Rumanian party congress are determined to support Premier Khruschev against the Chinese and his own opponents at home, according to information available here.

GOLLY! In the prize ring they get to the last act more swiftly than they do in the theatre. More decisively, too. In less than fifteen minutes Floyd Patterson, the challenger, made his point twice with notable conviction and Ingemar Johansson, the king, went down faster than Othello.
Thomas Alva Edison, Henry David Thoreau and Jane Addams are the leading candidates this year for enshrinement in the Hall of Fame for Great Americans.

FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, June 20 -- Much seems proven by yesterday's disastrous Grand Prix of Belgium motor race: That there is much a driver can do after losing control of his car, which may save his life; that no spot bordering a race circuit is really safe; and that race cars must somehow be slowed before the sport destroys itself in some final holocaust.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 20 (AP) -- Lake Erie, the longest shot in the race, wore down the odds-on favorite, Isendu, to win the Kingston Purse today at Monmouth Park. The payoff was $55.60 for $2.

The Jewish Education Committee of New York elected Morris M. Satin of 239 Central Park West as president last night. The committee serves as a board of education for 750 Jewish schools in greater New York.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., June 20 -- Wes Ellis of Mountain Ridge fired rounds of 67 and 65 for 132 -- tying the Green Brook Country Course record with his 65 -- and led the New Jersey qualifiers for the Professional Golfers Association championship today.

EVERYBODY is talking about the problems the next President will face. But no one can know precisely how they will develop or turn out. That is the precedent of the past we see in the two books on our table this morning. They are "Woodrow Wilson, an Intimate Memoir,"* by Cary T. Grayson, and "The Human Side of F. D. R., a Pictorial Biography," by Richard Harrity and Ralph G. Martin.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 20 -- Robert Moses attacked today the efforts of Illinois interests to divert additional Great Lakes water for sanitary, domestic and industrial use.

The farm situation in this country is discussed in a book by the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson. Doubleday will publish it July 15. Called "Freedom to Farm," part of it describes United States attempts to solve the farm problem.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange on June 15 was 3,239,342 shares, down from the 1960 peak of 3,321,923 shares in mid-May. The June 15 total was the second highest for the year to date. In mid-February, the short interest stood at 2,736,012 shares, the low for the year.

Net income of the Northrop Corporation for the nine months ended on April 30 was reported yesterday at $5,313,000. That compared with $5,350,000 in the 1959 period. Sales fell to $170,466,000 from $195,775.000.
Cus D'Amato was only a spectator in a black Homburg hat at the Polo Grounds last night.
WARSAW, June 20 -- The Fifth Plenum of the Polish Communist Central Committee convenes tomorrow to decide the investment policy that will govern Poland's economic life for the next five years.
Former President Harry Truman said here yesterday that his sympathies were with President Eisenhower because of the recent anti-American demonstrations in Japan.
The slowdown in the major (large household) appliance industry appears to be turning into a full-fledged slump.
ALBANY, June 20 -- Legislators were assured here today that there would be no political repercussions from an investigation that will begin soon into The state's public-welfare program.

The capacious Indian canoe at the American Museum of Natural History, an object of fascination and a receptacle for the surreptitious deposit of chewing gum and candy wrappers for more than half a century, went on a journey yesterday.
Yesterday was "a very, very, important day" for Jan Cwiklinski, a former Polish sea captain. He became an American citizen.
WALL TOWNSHIP, N.J., June 20 (AP) -- A man accused of murdering a woman last week confessed today to an unsolved murder last summer, the police said.

Reynolds Co., Inc., and associated investment bankers are offering today 300,000 common shares of Alside, Inc., Akron, Ohio, producer of aluminum siding. The shares are priced at $11 a share. Proceeds from the sale will be used to purchase consumer paper from the company's distributors and dealers.
MOSCOW, June 20 -- A new agency with extensive powers over regional economic councils has been created in Moscow to coordinate industrial management in the Russian Republic of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The United States' delegate to the East-West disarmament talks at Geneva said today that the West needed a fresh approach to disarmament.
Stocks declined yesterday for the seventh straight session. On average, stock prices have lost a major part of this month's earlier gains.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 20 -- A cash haul that the police estimated at $368,000 was taken by thieves who smashed through the ceiling of a vault in the State Motor Vehicles Department early today.
Pilots in wildcat strikes against Eastern Air Lines and Pan American World Airways were subjected to increasing pressure from Federal courts and their own union yesterday to return to work.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that old-age benefits payable under the Social Security Act might be cut off from an alien, deported in 1956 because of membership in the Communist party.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., June 20 (AP) -- William Seanor of Stanford, fighting back from crippling automobile accident injuries, stroked a 2-under-par 69 today and took the halfway lead in qualifying play for the National Collegiate golf championship.

A strong civil rights plank, making some Federal funds for schools dependent on desegregation, will be urged today on the Democratic National Platform Committee by the New York State Democratic Committee.

The defeat of a world champion is a stunning, jarring thing. Especially to the man who has been conquered. To imagine invincibility, then suddenly to find yourself a piece of common clay, is a sad thing.
The cotton, futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 8 points (40 cents) off yesterday in a quiet market.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Mayor Wagner and Newbold Morris are pondering whether or not to permit a gathering of the American Nazi party in Union Square on -- of all 365 days -- the Fourth of July.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court accepted for review today a second challenge to an Arkansas law of 1958 requiring public school teachers to list all organizations to which they have belonged or contributed in the last five years.

"Elmer Gantry" will have its local premiere at the Capitol Theatre on Thursday, July 7. The color-film version of the noted novel by Sinclair Lewis, published in 1927, was adapted and directed by Richard Brooks with Burt Lancaster portraying the title role of the controversial evangelist.
Masters and other ship officers aboard East and Gulf Coast passenger and dry-cargo ships asked their employers yesterday for up to 22 per cent more in basic wages.
SAN ANTONIO, June 20 -- Two leading Roman Catholic physicians disagreed here today whether sex should be discussed in mixed groups in the church's premarital counseling.

Although not quite a year old, the Financial Ministry of Pedro G. Beltran, who also holds the post of Prime Minister of Peru, is attracting wide attention in financial circles because of his achievement in halting inflation and bringing stability to the cost of living there.

The course of events in Japan in recent weeks has demonstrated clearly that two vital issues are at stake. One is Japan's position as a key bastion in the defense structure of the free world, now represented by the mutual security pact and the American bases in Japan. The other is the fate of Japan's new democracy.
"Omnibus," which has been off television for a year, will be resumed next fall over the National Broadcasting Company network. Alistair Cooke will return as host.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 20 -- The yachts in the race from Newport were working this way today in poor visibility and light, variable airs in what was likely to be one of the slowest of the biennial ocean contests.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- Compact car output in the first six months of this year will fall just short of one million units, production figures indicated today. However, this is three times the number built during the 1959 period.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 20 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he planned to campaign across the country for Republican Congressional candidates who agree with him politically.
After showing an increase for two weeks, steel production is expected to drop slightly this week.
ST. PAUL, June 20 -- Roy Wilkins, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, praised Vice President Nixon today for his "good record on civil rights."
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Administration said today it had increased Federal charges for a broad range of services.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate adopted today an amendment by Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Minnesota Democrat, to repeal the 4 per cent income tax credit allowed stockholders on their dividend income:

The brokerage concern of J. P. Howell Co., Inc., Montclair, N.J., and Michael La Marca, its president, were temporarily restrained yesterday by the United States District Court of New Jersey, from further violating the anti-fraud and net capital provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
HAVANA, June 20 -- Maj. Raul Castro, Minister of the Armed Forces, made a vitriolic attack on United States foreign policy today.
HONOLULU, June 20 -- President Eisenhower returned to the United States today from a nine-day Far Eastern journey of goodwill to hear welcome shouts of "Aloha!" from cheering Hawaiian crowds.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 20 -- With Premier Khrushchev of the Soviet Union sitting at his side, the leader of the Rumanian Workers (Communist) party accused "United States imperialist circles" today of attempting to halt the recent trend toward a relaxation in world affairs.

Ingemar Johansson never stirred. Floyd Patterson stood frozen in a neutral corner. The knockdown timekeeper tolled 7 and suddenly the tableau sprang into motion. Patterson did a dance of joy. He knew then that the Smorgasbord Smasher was out colder than a Swedish mackerel and that he himself had regained the heavyweight championship of the world.

DETROIT, June 20 -- That self-satisfied look with which they left Chicago last night still adorned the faces of the Yankees when they arrived here this morning. What's more, this being an off day, nothing possibly could happen that would alter the picture that shows them atop the American League standings.
THE high polish of sterling silver collections on museum shelves is the envy of most women. Just how this lustrous sheen is obtained and maintained was disclosed by a recent survey.

The Laurel Leaves Laurel crowns, and the honor of it all, were the complete and ample rewards for winning the Olympic Games of ancient Greece. In a sense the same goes for the games in their modern revival; it is a safe guess that few or none of the young men and women who score at the games in Rome this summer will feel any lack of compensation.
Floyd Patterson last nighty became the first man in the history of boxing to regain the heavyweight championship of the world.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Supreme Court today left standing a Circuit Court ruling that had directed the Federal maritime board to clarify its reasons for denying a route to Pacific Far East Line.

Bowlers may be arguing with umpires in the near future as if they were baseball players. There may be bands playing during matches as if they were football games. Bowling teams may even be allowed unlimited substitutions.

IT is open season for beach picnics and back-yard barbecues. Among the many amusing and practical accessories that have cropped up for summer outdoor diners are oversized bibs found at Elder Craftsman, 850 Lexington Avenue.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP) -- Billy Cannon, the all-America halfback from Louisiana State University, today won a court victory over the Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League that will enable him to fulfill a $110,000 contract with the Houston Oilers of the American Football League.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senate passed today a one-year extension of excise and corporate income taxes that bring in $4,000,000,000 a year in revenue. The vote was 84 -- 0.
Third and Lexington Avenues will not become one-way streets until July 10, Mayor Wagner's office announced yesterday.
An atmosphere simulating the old-time Mississippi River boats will prevail tomorrow night on a moonlight cruise up the Hudson River for the benefit of the Cerebral Palsy Center of Roosevelt, L. I.

ALGIERS, Algeria, June 20 -- Algeria was tense but surprisingly calm today as newspapers and radio stations spread news of the nationalist leaders' acceptance of General de Gaulle's offer to discuss a cease-fire with them in Paris.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Supreme Court cleared the way today for more hearings by the Civil Rights Commission on Negroes' voting rights in the South. The court held that the commission could subpoena voting registrars and compel them to testify without giving them the names of Negroes who had filed complaints against them.
Benjamin Levy, a 50-year-old lawyer of 1799 Lexington Avenue, was indicted here yesterday on charges of attempted grand larceny and misconduct as a lawyer.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- The grain futures market encountered general selling today and posted numerous losses running from about a cent to more than 2 cents a bushel.

Lola Fisher, who played Eliza Doolittle during the eight-week tour of "My Fair Lady" in the Soviet Union, has withdrawn from the Broadway company. After the Russian trip, she was to have resumed her affiliation with the local troupe, not only as Pamela Charles' understudy but also as a member of the chorus.
It is an axiom among military commanders -- and maybe among boxing managers -- that fighting men do not become effective until they have been "blooded."
TRENTON, June 20 -- A proposed state regulation to ban all air pollution was supported by some New Jersey residents but opposed by industry representatives at a hearing today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call by which the Senate adopted today a tax bill amendment by Senator Joseph S. Clark, Pennsylvania Democrat, curtailing the entertainment expenses that may be written off as business expenses for tax purposes:
A riotous mob of angry fans tried to break down the gates at the Polo Grounds last night to see the championship fight between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Before a capacity audience of 20,000 listeners, the Philadelphia Orchestra, under the direction of Wilfrid Pelletier, opened its six-week series of outdoor concerts at Robin Hood Dell tonight.

THE behavior patterns of earthquakes are rarely predictable and the tremblor that hit San Francisco over the weekend was a real shocker. So precarious was the perch of Bill Rigney as manager of the Giants that even the most backward seismologist knew that he'd topple at the first shake.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 20 -- At the end of a perfect June day that brought out 20,000 for the opening of the Wimbledon tennis championships, Ronald Holmberg's quest for the title ended today with his first match.

The Brookmeade Stable's 2-year-old filly Bowl of Flowers set a track record for five-and-a-half furlongs at Belmont yesterday when she won the $37,620 Filly Division of the National Stallion Stakes by nose from the Cambridge Stable's Shuette before 24,570.

The six - story apartment house at 1070 Anderson Avenue, at 165th Street, in the Bronx, has been acquired by FischerLandis, real estate investors and operators. The property was sold by the Derson Realty Corporation through Stanley Russell Associates, brokers.

The management of Freedom land, the Bronx amusement park that opened Sunday, reported yesterday that attendance was closer to what had been expected. During the day the crowd on hand averaged about 15,000.
Except for a rise, in shortterm yields on Treasury securities there was little to distinguish yesterday's trading session in the bond market.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The defense of your editorial position given in your reply to Eustace Seligman's letter on the handling of the U-2 incident (issue June 13) was altogether too mild in rebutting his proposition that the use of the "cover story" has been "blown up out of all proportion to its importance."
The description of the heavy-weight title fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson by rounds. (Opinion of round winners are those of Joseph C. Nichols):

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 20 -- A postscript was added today to the popular complaint that many pupils cannot write acceptable English. According to a New York City school official, neither can many prospective teachers.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today the purchase of two blocks near the Capitol for $5,000,000. The property is expected to be used for a second annex to the Library of Congress.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- Horace Stoneham acted on impulse, he admits, when he removed Bill Rigney as the manager of the Giants Saturday. However, the Giants' president made it clear today that he was in no rush to pick a permanent successor to the departed pilot.
KANSAS CITY, June 20 (UPI) -- Andy Carey celebrated his return to the Kansas City Athletics' line-up tonight with a home run and double, driving in four runs in a 9-6 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday that it had appointed Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., as the agency for all Shell marketing activities.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs rose sharply this week.

The number of blind persons in New York State reached 27,716 last year, an increase of 1,258 over the previous year, the Commission for the Blind, New York State Department of Social Welfare, reported yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., June 20 -- Virginia's Commission of Game and Inland Fisheries has been investigating the striped bass population of one of the state's major reservoirs. The commission has found that the rockfish have been thriving and reproducing at the huge Buggs Island Lake.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Alabama asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider its decision of May 31 limiting to three and a half miles the state's rights to submerged lands in the Gulf of Mexico.

General of the Array Douglas MacArthur has declared that Japan Constitution adopted during the Allied occupation while he was Supreme Commander after World War II, did not stand in the way of giving the police Sufficient power to maintain order.

The pilots of Eastern, Pan American and other airlines who are reporting "sick" these days are, in effect, striking against the public interest. Their action stems from the policies of the Air Line Pilots Association, which, in effect, is attempting to outmaneuver the Government.

BRIONI, Yugoslavia, June 20 (Reuters) -- President Tito and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic declared today that uncommitted nations should have a bigger voice in world affairs.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J:, June 20 -- Glenn Kunkel, a 19-year-old freshman at Fairleigh Dickinson University, won the qualifying medal in the thirteenth annual New Jersey junior public links golf championship today with a 38, 38 -- 76 at the Ferncliffe Golf Club.

The State Banking Department said yesterday that it would permit banks to hold authorized but unissued shares up to 5 per cent of their shares outstanding for use in acquiring smaller institutions. The announcement ends a long-standing restriction agains banks' having authorized but unissued shares.

PARIS, June 20 -- With agreement by the Algerian Nationalist rebels to send a peace mission to Paris, French Government sources immediately made it clear that an advance Algarian emissary would be welcome.

Relations between the United States,and Cuba continue to deteriorate. How much worse they can get without leading to a dangerous explosion is anybody's guess. Unhappily, it looks as if they will get still worse before they can get better.

John J. Stanton, a $6,280-a-year inspector, was suspended yesterday by City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa. This was result of testimony last week that he had taken bribes so that rock-salt purchases that failed to meet city specifications should not be rejected.

Investors' fancy has played up electronics suppliers in the last two weeks -- not the giant "Blue Chips" such as General Electric and Westinghouse but the suppliers of components, with old names in some cases, and medium values.

NEARLY 200 years after the world's most celebrated tea party, Boston harbors a special affection for the brew And tea parties, according to Mrs. Willard Richards, continue to be one of the city's favorite forms of entertainment.
The unearthing of a 3,000-year-old tomb on the site of the ancient city of Dothan in Jordan was reported here yesterday by a member of the Dothan archeological expedition from Wheaton (Ill.) College.
YONKERS, June 20 -- Saul Finkelstein's Stormy Dream scored a one-and-one-quarter length victory in 2:03 1/5 in the Elmsford tonight before 22,110 at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- In three important labor decisions today the Supreme Court laid down the policy that arbitrators should be able to do their work with little or no interference from the Federal courts.
TUNIS, June 20 -- After nearly six years of war, the leaders of the Algerian National Liberation Front agreed today to go to Paris to talk peace.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) -- The Air Force announced today that advanced models of its Titan intercontinental ballistic missile will carry a bigger hydrogen warhead than earlier models.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Steps to revitalize downtown business areas were described today by spokesmen for a number of cities.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 20 -- Six African nationalist leaders from South Africa urged all African states today to refuse or sever diplomatic relations with their country as part of a general boycott of the Government of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd.

TOKYO, Tuesday, June 21 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi is reliably reported to have stated his willingness to announce his "intention to resign" as soon as the new United States-Japanese mutual security treaty comes into force.
TUNIS, June 20 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a communique issued here today by the Algerian Provisional Government:

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 20 -- A pair of victories today by Runyon Colie of Mantoloking, N.J., sailing Dr. Britton Chance's Complex III, gained the Barnegat Bay entry a first place tie with Ted Hood's and Bradley Noyes' Fantasi in the final United States 5.5-Meter Class Olympic Trials.
STOCKHOLM, Tuesday, June 21 -- It had been advertised as a "waiting-up for Ingo," but it turned out to be a wake.

MILWAUKEE, June 20 (AP) -- The Braves climbed into second place in the National League by downing the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-1, tonight on a pair of homers by Hank Aaron and the relief pitching of Joey Jay.
SAN NICOLAS, Argentina, June 20 -- The blast furnace at the National Steel Works, rising from the pampas here, was fired up today in a notable moment in Argentina's industrial history.
MINOT, N.D., June 20 -- Vice President Nixon said tonight that he favored creation of a United Nations pool of surplus food to feed the world's hungry.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday his support of Senator John F. Kennedy for the Democratic nomination for President.
An arbitrator was asked yesterday to decide wage levels for 600 workers whose employers conceded they were underpaid and whose union recognized that there was no money for wage increases.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Nearly two-thirds of the increase in the population of the United States since 1950 occurred in suburbs, the Census Bureau reported today.
Commodity futures drifted generally down in dull and featureless trading yesterday on New York exchanges.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today;

The New York State Power Authority's $100,000,000 market borrowing for the Niagara Project will consist of $80,000,000 of term obligations bearing interest of 4 1/3 per cent and due in 2006 and $20,000,000 of serial obligations bearing interest of from 3.5 to 3.75 per cent interest.

Sidney J. Ungar testified yesterday that he had agreed to pay for remodeling Hulan E. Jack's apartment because Mr. Jack was in politics and "probably could do favors for me." Mr. Ungar, a lawyer and real estate promoter, was a prosecution, witness at Mr. Jack's trial before Judge Joseph A. Sarafite and a jury in the Court of General Sessions.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 20 -- Nicholas Kip skippered Andover Academy to two straight victories today as five of the nine qualifying races in the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association's twenty-fifth regatta were held on Manhasset Bay.
GENEVA, June 20 -- Geneva's two East-West conferences were in political suspension today while their futures were being decided in Washington and Moscow.
Manhattan's last stable for dray horses -- most of them used by lower East Side carters and peddlers -- is about to be torn down to make way for a Greenwich Village apartment house.
The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen moved yesterday to Vacate a court order prohibiting a strike on the Long Island Rail Road.

THE error of omission is often just as culpable as the error of commission, but in bridge at least it is likely to pass without notice. In the deal shown, played in a lunchtime game in a New York office, the wrong player was blamed.

WHITE PLAINS.,N.Y., June 20 -- Two teams tied today at a net 67, three strokes under par, in the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association pro-amateur tournament at Fenway. A sudden-death match of cards decided the winning team.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that an enemy alien might not appeal to the United States courts if the Justice Department rejected his claim to property seized by the United States during World War II.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner proposed today that National Airlines, one of the smallest of the twelve trunk airlines, be made the basic trans port service across the southern part of the United States.

BONN, Germany, June 20 -- A parade of politicians marched through Dr. Konrad Adenauer's office today as the 84-year-old Chancellor, refreshed by a month's holiday under the Italian sun, went back to work with characteristic vigor.

MADRID, June 18 -- An influential group of Madrid University instructors, editors of campus reviews and other Spanish student leaders is offering to support Don Juan de Bourbon as Spain's next King, provided he restores democracy.
The Board of Higher Education approved last night higher faculty salaries at the seven colleges under its jurisdiction and the addition of 205 teachers to the staffs of four of them.

Ground will be broken today for the Americana of New York, an 800-room luxury hotel at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-first Street. It will be the first major hotel to be built in Manhattan in thirty years.
LONDON, June 20 -- With coal and fuel supplies now readily available, the Government has abandoned its plan to accelerate the building of nuclear power stations.
BLANCA, Colo., June 20 (AP) -- Two men from Los Alamos, N.M., plunged to their deaths in a fall on the Blanca Peak in southern Colorado yesterday.
A group of distaff Highlanders from Iowa was in town yesterday, preparing to carry not coals to Newcastle but kilts and bagpipes to Scotland.

The General Electric Company's computer department has entered the market for medium-priced, general purpose all-transistor computers, it was announced yesterday. Three auch computers previously produced by the company were made for specific customers and specific purposes.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision requiring Brown Shoe Company, Inc., of St. Louis, to dispose of its interest in assets and business of G.R. Kinney Company, Inc.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, June 21 -- President Eisenhower ended his two-day visit to South Korea last night. He left behind an affectionate and determined people riding the crest of a hew wave in Korean-American relations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP) -- The National Football League, now a thirteen-team circuit with, the addition of the Dallas Cowboys, will open its seventy-eight-game 1960 schedule Friday night, Sept. 23, with the Los Angeles Rams, playing host to the St Louis Cardinals, Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today.

The Port Authority is making a new attack this summer on an old enemy of the bus commuter -- the eye-smarting, nostril-burning smoke and fumes given off by buses entering, leaving or loading passengers at the authority's West Side terminal.

ON a warm summer evening many a German retreats to his favorite beer garden to sip for hours a pale pink beverage. It is served in a glass that is shaped something like a champagne goblet but is almost as big as a goldfish bowl.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 21 -- George O'Day's Wistful outstripped her rivals today in the fourth trial race of the International 5.5-meter yachts seeking United States Olympic selection.
AUTUMN brides who are dressed by the Tailored Woman can be sure of keeping up with the Joneses. The tiny figure of Princess Margaret casts a long shadow over this shop's bridal collection.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 21 -- At close to 9 o'clock this evening, Earl Buchholz and Chuck McKinley walked off the Wimbledon center court the winners from India's Davis Cut team of Ramanathan Krishnan and Naresh Kumar in a two-and-a-half-hour tennis match that had the gallery screaming from tension and excitement to the last point.
A HOUSE with everything in it for sale is on view near Altman's branch store in Short Hills, N.J.

THE coast-to-coast introduction of electronic schizophrenia appears to have been successful. In untold numbers of homes on Monday evening the radio was tuned in to the Floyd Patterson - Ingemar Johannson fight while the television set, with the sound off, was adjusted to see the annual ceremony of the Emmy prizes.
Senator Jacob K. Javits joined Representative John V. Lindsay yesterday in planning legislation to repeal the 10 per cent Federal excise tax on theatre tickets.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 21 -- The establishment of a national marine biological reserve in Cold Spring Harbor will be recommended to the Senate Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs.

YESTERDAY (June 21, 1960) THE PRESIDENT In Hawaii. White House said a 4.2 billion surplus for the year starting July 1 wag in jeopardy because of spending and tax legislation taken or planned by Congress.

Oslo, Norway, is borrowing $10,000,000 in the United States capital market today through a sale of twenty-five year 5 3/4 per cent sinking fund external loan bonds underwritten by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., Lazard Freres Co., Smith, Barney Co. and associates.
A group of foreign students ended a year's study in this country yesterday with a vigorous defense of student demonstrations elsewhere.

ON the eve of observing the centennial of the Civil War, which began in early 1861, Charles Laughton's stage version of "John Brown's Body" is being revived at the Players Theatre on Macdougal Street for a limited engagement.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (UPI) -- The Phillies beat the Chicago Cubs, 7 -- 6, in thirteen innings in the first game of a double-header tonight and were leading in the second game, 7 -- 5, when it was suspended at the end of eight innings because of the National League curfew rule.
WARSAW, June 21 -- Wlady-slaw Gomulka, announced today that Poland would invest almost as much money in the next five years as she did in the last ten years.

OXFORD, Miss., June 21 (UPI) -- Jim Lee Howell, head coach of the New York Giants lost his temper on the witness stand today while testifying about the National Football Club's dealings with Charlie Flowers. Two United States marshals were ordered to subdue Howell.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Administration applied last-minute pressure on Congress today through warnings that the expected budget surplus was vanishing.
