PARIS, Wednesday, June 22 -- The French Government awaits a clarification of procedural snags that appeared to be delaying the arrival here of the advance emissary of the Algerian rebels.
DETROIT, June 21 -- A leading New York rabbi proposed here tonight that a "declaration of principles" be written to clarify the relationship of Reform Judaism to the State of Israel.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The idea of a "super-Secretary of State" apparently came out of a series of off-the-record gatherings that President Eisenhower had with Washington correspondents and columnists about a year ago.

Bill Fugazy of Feature Sports, Inc., said yesterday that New York would not get the return title fight between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson "unless the city provides adequate police protection."
KEY WEST, Fla., June 21 (AP) -- The Navy unveiled today what it called its deadliest anti-submarine missile system. It is called ASROC.
PITTSBURGH. June 21 (UPI) -- Vernon Law of the Pittsburgh Pirates, with the aid of Elroy Face, beat the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 3-2, and scored his eleventh victory.
A Federal judge gave riders on the Long Island Rail Road another week of strike insurance yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, June 21 -- Following is the text of Vice President Nixon's speech today at the national convention of the Junior Chamber of Commerce here:

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 21 -- Andover Academy's talented Nicholas Kip added a second place today to the pair of firsts he had posted yesterday as the Massachusetts team led eight other schools into the three-race final for the Inter-scholastic Yacht Racing Association's Mallory Cup.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur yesterday received the highest decoration Japan can confer on a foreigner who is not a head of state.
LONDON, June 21 -- Premier Khrushchev said today that the Soviet Union was looking to the American people to elect a President to correct the mistakes of the Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Fredrick M. Eaton, the United States representative at the East-West disarmament talks in Geneva, has put two alternatives before United States policy-making officials.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 21 -- The committee arranging the Darien-New Canaan Autumn Cotillion gave a tea this afternoon at the New Canaan Country Club for the forty-eight young women who will be presented then and their mothers.

A preview performance of the "Puppet Carnival," which will be presented in the five boroughs this summer by the Department of Parks, may be seen Saturday at 2 P.M. in Central Park. It will be presented at Pilgrim Hill at Seventy-second Street, just west of Fifth Avenue. Admission is free.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- An Administration-supported bill to reduce wheat production without increasing price supports was rejected today by the House of Representatives. The vote was 108 to 92.
The wildcat strike that has disrupted operations of Eastern Air Lanes and Pan American World Airways apparently is over.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points down to 6 points up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

BONN, Germany, June 21 -- Chancellor Adenauer said today that it was Soviet political strategy to create as much unrest as possible before the United States elections in the hope of influencing the outcome.

Market yields on short-term basic debt investments held the spotlight in the bond market for the second successive day yesterday. There was broad buying of Treasury bills, reversing the rise in yields that took place on the discount paper on Monday.
TUNIS, June 21 -- The departure of the Algerian nationalist representative for preliminary contact with the French Government in Paris appeared to have been delayed tonight, probably until Thursday.
Officers of nine major labor unions have taken the first formal step toward organizing a nonprofit corporation to operate a chain of cut-rate drugstores in this city.

THIS is the way American designer Norman Norell sees the chic woman on Fifth Avenue next fall: her hair is shingled shorter than Zelda Fitzgerald's at the height of the Twenties; her eyes are ringed with circles of black (made with minstrel show burnt cork); her mouth is a slash of red in a dead white face, and she is wearing suits with culottes or divided skirts.
A new information center, operating on the road as well as in City Hall, was set up by the city yesterday.
A faceless, one-legged aluminum eagle with a thirty-seven-foot wingspread and drain holes for rainwater in its tail was carved into three pieces yesterday and trucked out of its native Brooklyn.

WHEN General of the Army Douglas MacArthur told a Joint Session of Congress and several million television viewers on April 19, 1951, that "old soldiers never die -- they just fade away," he apparently was thinking of some other old soldier.
PESHAWAR, Pakistan, June 21 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan urged Pakistanis tonight to make a "most determined effort" to achieve substantial economic progress within the next five years.

The Bulova Watch Company and its subsidiaries, in the fiscal year ended on March 31, had a 75 per cent increase in earnings from operations on a sales gain of 14 per cent, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June, 21 -- Premier Ben-Gurion said here today that a meeting with Dr. Frondizi would be a fine thing, provided that the Argentine President accepted Israel's position that Eichmann remain in Israel until after his trial.

HONOLULU, June 21 -- President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Christian Herter are agreed that great good toward friendly relations was achieved in three of the four areas of the Far East the President visited.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 22 -- Railway, bus and street car workers suspended work for several hours early today in a protest against Premier Nobusuke Kishi's Government and the ratification of the United States-Japanese security treaty.
An officer of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company who started as a clerk in the accounting department back in 1928 became president of the nation's largest tobacco company yesterday.
The Riegel Paper Company is planning a major expansion of its packaging activities.

Twenty-seven more persons were injured in automobile accidents here last week than in the corresponding week a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. The total injured last week was 1,200.

The two five-story apartment houses at 2322 and 2326 Ryer Avenue in the Bronx have been sold by the Lube Realty Corporation to a client of Hyman Greenberg, lawyer, and resold to Irving Salitsky, real estate operator.
The production of last weekend's Vanderbilt Cup revival at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., was a triumph for the raceway staff and the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The House of Representatives is locked in a political dispute on the issue of ''getting tough" with Premier Fidel Castro through the Cuban sugar quota.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 21 -- Several recent studies show that Roman Catholic married couples use contraceptive birth control "in about the same measure" as their Protestant arid Jewish neighbors, the director of the National Catholic Family Life Bureau said here today.
The National Maritime Union has re-elected Joseph E. Curran, its president since its founding in 1937, by an overwhelming margin.

Earnings of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company for the first fiscal quarter ended May 31 were 3 or 4 cents a share less than in the quarter ended May 31, 1959, when the net was 14,638,000 or 68 cents a share, Ralph W. Burger, chairman and president, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Senate neared approval of the United States-Japanese Security treaty tonight and then put the vote off until tomorrow.

LONDON, June 21 -- The stock market staged a modest rally here today, although prices remained sensitive and net price changes were irregular. The cessation of yesterday's selling encouraged a little buying, especially of undated gilt-edge issues and the blue chips.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have been greatly disturbed by press reports of the demonstrations being staged by Japanese students in Tokyo. The implication is that the Communist party is behind the mass demonstrations. But we should not be misled by the Communists making capital of a situation of unrest.
THE people whose job it is to write about hat fashions for fall -- and those who just chat about them over lunch for that matter -- are likely to run out of superlatives this season.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Times is to be commended for its excellent editorial of June 15 which pointed out the injustices inherent in our present importation of Mexican farm workers and urged the modification and termination of this program.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: No name in public service is more distinguished than that of Herbert H. Lehman. By deliberately denying him a delegate's role to the national convention, the State Committee has tried to weaken and humiliate the man who symbolizes the greatest achievements of the Democratic party.
THE protest of several leading New York players against the terms of a scheduled inter-city match between New York and Los Angeles, as reported here last week, has apparently run its course.

Frank Gragsso has purchased from a client of Walter Scott Co. the property at 325 to 343 East Fifty-sixth Street, 100 feet west of First Avenue. It was held at $1,300,000. A resale is pending to a builder who has commissioned George G. Miller, architect, to design a fourteen-story apartment building.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 21 -- Following are excerpts from a speech deivered by Governor Rockefeller today at a luncheon of the Binghamton Rotary Club:
A new, improved transformer, said to be the first important innovation in such electrical equipment in seventy-four years, was introduced yesterday by Sylvania Electric Products, Inc.
LONDON, June 21 -- A demand for the withdrawal of United States forces from Britain was sounded anew today by Frank Foulkes, the most powerful Communist in the British trades union movement.
A state inquiry offered figures yesterday indicating that the city had incurred $450,495.31 in extra costs beyond the contract prices on rock salt set with one company since 1955.

The local opening dates have been set for three forthcoming features. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "The Subterraneans," co-starring Leslie Caron and George Peppard and based on the Jack Kerouac novel, is due July 6 at the Beekman Theatre.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture today estimated the spring pig crop at 49,103,000 head, down 16 per cent from the level of the 1959 spring crop.
Evidence is accumulating that cancer may be linked to changes in a particular -cell chemical, according to a progress report to be released today by the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research.

MILWAUKEE, June 21 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves swept a double-header from the Sat Francisco Giants, 9 -- 6, and 2 -- 1 tonight. The second game went twelve innings. The Braves took the opener with an eleven hit assault and the relief pitching of a rookie, Ron Piche They captured the second game on a sharp single by Ret Schoendienst.

Twenty-five years ago Jack Feddersen, a young sales representative of H. A. Selmer Inc., musical instrument manufacturer, was sent to Chicago to hear a new band. The band was reportedly blovwng up a storm in the world of jazz.

MADRID, June 21 -- General-issimo Francisco Franco of Spain and Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar completed today a review of world and domestic developments at a meeting in western Spain near the Portuguese border.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Tourists added to the United States balance-of-payments problem last year.

Sidney J. Ungar testified yesterday that Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan had rejected a suggestion to tell the truth about Mr. Ungar's $4,400 payments for remodeling Mr. Jack's apartment.

As part of their post-summit propaganda drive the Soviets have begun to downgrade the Geneva disarmament conference. The Soviets can conduct this campaign with impunity because the West will not answer in kind. But the West can and should be able to make a more effective answer than heretofore, and such an answer is now being discussed in Washington, London and Paris.
HAVANA, June 21 -- The protest of the United States Embassy against the arrest of two assistant legal attaches was rejected tonight by Dr. Raul Roa, the Minister of Foreign Affairs.

THE city's major summer music series, the annual concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium, began last night. Pierre Monteux, Mischa Elman, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer and Tchaikovsky were the chief contributors who set them on their way.
A group of American concerns whose ships sail under so-called "flags of convenience" has replied to charges of substandard wages and working conditions by American maritime unions.
Stocks declined again yesterday in active trading. Profit taking took a toll of recent market leaders, particularly the specialized electronics.
The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's plans to acquire control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad were attacked yesterday by two neighbors.

As more of the 1960 United States Census figures from over the nation are made public by Washington it becomes apparent that New York City has done extraordinarily well in maintaining its population in the last decade. Nine of the ten largest cities in the country had a decline, and New York's percentage of decline was the smallest.

PARIS. After six weeks turbulence and reviving cold war we may take comfort that there is at last a real prospect of settling the conflict between France and the Algerian National Liberation Front (F.L.N.). Excepting the artillery duel off China's coast, that conflict is the world's only hot war.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 21 -- Patrice Lumumba won his first test of strength in the Congolese Parliament today. As a result, he replaced Joseph Kasavubu as the man designated to form a Government of the Congo, which will become independent of Belgian June 30.
Pilots of Eastern Air Lines and Pan American World Airways began a return to work yesterday that appeared to signal the end of their wildcat strikes over a Federal flight regulation.
The Alabama Education Authority borrowed $50,000,000 in the public bond market yesterday at an Interest cost of 3.9995 per cent.

CYNICS have sometimes said that the only requirements for compiling an anthology are a pair of scissors and a pot of paste. This is a cheap canard. Although some anthologies are obviously mere commercial projects intended to earn ah honest penny, many are born of their editors' passionate enthusiasm.

KANSAS CITY, June 21 (UPI) -- Home runs by Jerry Lumpe and Marv Throneberry enabled the Kansas City Athletics to outscore the Boston Red Sox, 11 -- 7, tonight and hand Bud Daley his tenth victory of the season.

YONKERS, June 21 -- Adios Lutz, owned by Paul Wixom of Chicago and driven by Hugh Bell, scored a neck victory over Quick Jo in the Lamp Post Corner-Hotel New Yorker pace before 21,955 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
State Controller Arthur Levitt and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. offered yesterday to resign as delegates-at-large to the Democratic National Convention to make room for former Senator Herbert H. Lehman.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21 -- Israel informed the Security Council tonight that a meeting between her Premier, David Ben-Gurion, and President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina on the Eichmann case had been arranged.

GRANGE - OVER - SANDS, England (Canadian Press) -- Residents of this Lancashire town claim a record for collections for the World Refugee Year Fund. The total was u3,304 ($9,251) representing u1 3s 2d (more than $3) per capita.
WASHINGTON June 21 -- There is an increasingly aggressive and even bitter note in Senator Lyndon Johnson's campaign for the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- The House Post Office Committee took no action today on proposed postal-rate increases that would yield $554,000,000 a year. This apparently doomed the Administration measure.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Thousands of service men with small offenses on their military records are losing or will lose their retirement pay under the so-called Hiss Act. A Pentagon official said today, the situation was a "gross injustice."
NEW IBERIA, La., June 21 (AP) -- A four-car collision killed nine persons near here last night.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Two Democratic Senators assailed the Interstate Commerce Commission today for what they termed its favoritism toward the rail-roads in rate cases.

The Senate voted on Monday to repeal the 4 per cent dividend tax credit on dividends exceeding $50 a year. The action came after Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Democratic majority leader, was able to switch two votes to save the amendment by a 42 to 41 vote.
Fifty-three witnesses offered a variety of proposals for Democratic campaign planks at an all-day hearing yesterday.

DETROIT, June 21 -- Mickey Mantle and Whitey Ford, buddies on and off the field, were the main collaborators as the front-running Yankees fashioned their fifth straight victory tonight at Briggs Stadium. After warming up with an infield single, Mantle slugged two homers, making it easy for Ford to go all the way and blank the Tigers, 6-0, before 39,311 fans.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold reported today that countries with "centrally planned" economies In recent years have made increasing attempts to introduce more flexibility into their operations by raising the level of foreign trade in relation to national income.
The United States Lines Company yesterday elected John M. Franklin to the new post of chairman of the board and chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Dr. Linus C. Pauling, a Nobel prize-winning biochemist, today risked possible contempt of Congress charges by refusing to identify to a Senate unit the scientists who helped him petition the United Nations in 1958 to ban nuclear tests.
CLEVELAND, June 21 (AP) -- Good relief pitching by Johnny Klippstein tonight helped Jim Grant gain his thirteenth straight decision over Washington as the Cleveland Indians beat the Senators, 5 -- 4.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- The United States Government will continue to be a major tenant in office buildings across tie country, a Federal official said today.
Knockout in the boxing ring occurs when the brain's organizing network is suddenly overwhelmed by nervous signals, two nerve specialists reported here yesterday.
THE following dinner menu is offered as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
ST. LOUIS, June 21 -- Vice President Nixon derided critics of the Administration's economic policy today and predicted that the Soviet economy would not overtake the United States in this century.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 21 -- The Misses Margo Mason Barrett, Mary Byron Gardner and Margaret Louise von Kennig, debutantes of the season, were honored this evening at a dance given by their parents.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- Robert Anderson, the play-wright, has been signed by producer Martin Manulis to write the screen version of "The Night They Burned the Mountain," the autobiography of Dr. Thomas Dooley.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 21 -- Clayton Ewing's welded aluminum fifty-eight-foot yawl Dyna, a distinguished fresh-water campaigner, from the Great Lakes, was established today as the leader in the ocean race from Newport.

Mike Nichols and Elaine May failed to appear on the Emmy awards telecast Monday night because their comedy sketch was built around a home-permanent hair product -- the same product sold by a sponsor of the show.
QUEBEC, June 21 -- Tomorrow's provincial election will probably be decided by Quebec's rural vote.

The distant May, July, September and October world sugar positions fell to new lows for the lives, of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. All other months except January dropped to new lows for the move.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 21 -- Joe Dunn, a local business consultant, has two avocations -- fishing and Civil War history. There's plenty of both hereabouts.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, June 21 -- When the London drama critics arrived at the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre here tonight to see the opening performance of "The Taming of the Shrew," they found the air full of rumors.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- An improved shipper demand and the smallest Tuesday supply in two months firmed the butcher hog market here today and it hit its highest top price in seventeen months.

Martin Schulman, a Greenwich Village real-estate operator, was advised yesterday by Joseph Goldberg, lower Manhattan rent administrator, to stop buying buildings for demolition and to restore his tenements to "at least the condition they were in when you bought them."

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 21 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed today the creation of a First Secretary of the Government. This official would work directly under the President in promoting the nation's interests abroad and its security at home.
Directors of the First National City Bank of New York elected four vice presidents yesterday.
SAN DIEGO, June 21 -- Men of rare talent should be given an opportunity to serve as guest teachers In public schools, a national conference on teacher certification was told today.

GENEVA, June 21 -- Western delegations, to the disarmament conference here, goaded for days by the captain of the Soviet bloc, decided today they did not have to go on taking it from the Communists' second team.

HONOLULU, June 21 -- President Eisenhower relaxed on a luxuriant United States Marine Corps golf course today. His swing was good and so were his spirits. In this paradise of the Pacific the cares and strain of his Far Eastern trip dropped quickly from the President's shoulders.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter told Senate questioners today that there should be a return to "traditional channels and procedures of international contact." The nation's top diplomat appeared to be arguing against such methods of the recent past as direct contacts between chiefs of government or summit conferences without careful preparation.
Protests continued to mount here yesterday against efforts by the American Nazi party to conduct a political rally in Union Square July 4.

IT unquestionably was a publicity gimmick when Joe Louis was hired as an adviser to the discredited Floyd Patterson for his return match with invincible Ingemar Johansson. Yet the Dark Destroyer offered the perfect blueprint.
YONKERS, June 21 -- Mrs. Gino Scalamandre and Gary Vandeweghe of the Rockville Country Club today won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's twenty-sixth annual sister-brother championship.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Television sets are selling faster than at this time last year but appliance sales are down, two company executives said today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A previously unknown Lincoln letter, which sheds the first light on what has become a "lost Lincoln day" for historians, was presented today to the Library of Congress.
MASSENA, N.Y., June 21 (AP) -- More cargo carried in fewer ships is the trend on the St. Lawrence Seaway in the first two months of 1960 operation, a report showed today.
A step was taken yesterday toward eventual elimination of a technical roadblock to building on Staten Island, but the immediate problem remained.

INWOOD, L.I., June 21 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of the Meadow Brook Club, Jericho, L.I., fashioned a parequaling 40, 36 -- 76 and took a two-stroke lead in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole, medal-play championship at the Inwood Country Club today.
Paul Gerhardt Hoffman, editor of Suburbia Today, monthly magazine supplement, was found dead at 2:30 A.M. yesterday in his apartment at 7 West Twenty-eighth Street. He was 54 years old.

A handcuffed prisoner who had just been found guilty of two narcotic charges leaped over a banister and plunged to his death yesterday as he was being taken to a cell in the Federal Court Building, Brooklyn.

Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson were agreed on a couple of things yesterday. Each expressed the idea that the other was a pretty good fellow and each thought that a rematch would be very much in order.

What the world has fastened on, in the Algerian situation, is the simple fact that at long last representatives of the Algerian rebels are going to Paris to talk peace. The instinct to concentrate on this development is right. A ray of sunshine has broken through the dark clouds that hang over Algeria and it brings hope of fairer times ahead.

Two Staten Island hospitals replied yesterday to a charge that they had refused to admit any physicians affiliated with the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York to practice for the last two and one-half years.

Public financing totaling $162,000,000 was furnished by investment bankers yesterday for hydroelectric power developments in New York State and in California. The New York State Power Authority sold $100,000,000 of term and serial bonds for the Niagara Project to a banking syndicate on terms representing a borrowing cost of 4.14 per cent.
LLOYD HARBOR, L.I., June 21 -- Robert Moses is seeking to add the vast estate of the late Marshall Field in this community to the network of Long Island State Parks, it was revealed today.

BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -- Joseph J. McNamara, 76 years old, who accepted a call to active duty from the list of Navy reservists today was assigned an administrative task in the headquarters of the First Naval District, Boston.
Senator Stuart Symington called upon the United States yesterday to meet the challenge of a Communist-planned economy with more vigorous government planning for free-enterprise economy.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 21 -- A proposal that the Federal Government consider providing direct financial aid to commuter railroads split the State Conference of Mayors today.
The Bethlehem Steel Company and shipyard union leaders were reported near agreement here last night on details of a proposed three-year contract.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Jim Landis' home run in the ninth inning gave the White Sox a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
Teh publishers of "The Human Side of F.D.R.," by Richard Harrity and Ralph G. Martin, were inadvertently omitted in yesterday's Books of The Times column. It was issued by Duell, Sloan Pearce.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., June 21 -- Residents of the rural town of Yorktown in northern Westchester are discovering that a tax bonanza provided by the International Business Machines Corporation may change the skyline.
Manuel Ycaza, the Panamanian jockey, suffered a broken left collarbone yesterday after his mount, Runspurtytoo, had fallen in the sixth race at Belmont Park.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Selling pressure continued in the grain futures market today and several contracts on the Board of Trade reached their lowest levels of the season.
Four youths were held yesterday for court hearings in the fatal stabbing of a 16-year-old boy during a street brawl Monday night between two Brooklyn gangs.
DETROIT, June 22 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis voiced its unanimous opposition here today to the practice of reading the Bible for devotional purposes in public schools.
NAIROBI, Kenya, June 19 -- Preparations for racially integrated schools are being made in Kenya, where only four years ago integration was bitterly opposed.
CHICAGO, June 22 -- Unlike some fads in furniture, color seems to be here to stay. Colored furniture has lasted for eighteen months or through three markets in the wholesale furniture showings here.

YONKERS, June 22 -- Widower Creed, who tied the world mark for a mile and a half at 3:04- 2/5 in (the first leg of the International Pace, is the 9-to-5 favorite in the third portion of the series at Yonkers Raceway, tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A Justice Department official indicated today that a runaway grand jury had been responsible for the recent prosecution of twenty-nine major oil companies on criminal antitrust charges.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- One attribute of Dr. Herbert Friedman -- and a fiting one for a scientist dealing in the infinite mysteries of the universe and the malfunctioning complexities of rockets -- is patience.
ALGIERS, June 22 -- Local nationalist commanders in the Algiers region have ordered their forces to discontinue all terrorist atacks against civilians, a French Army spokesman asserted today.
MILWAUKEE, June 22 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves scored five runs in the first four innings tonight and went on to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 7 -- 4. It was Milwaukee's fifth straight victory.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22 -- Ninety-six hours after they had started from Newport last Saturday, the yachts in the 635-mile race to these islands were making painfully slow progress today dead against faint southeasterly breezes.
A minor rally developed late yesterday afternoon and stocks closed with a gain on average for the first time in nine trading sessions.
GENEVA, June 22 -- The Soviet bloc issued a special statement today accusing the West of stalling the disarmament talks here or plotting their failure.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 22 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr., of the Meadow Brook Club increased her lead to nine strokes with a 76, 73 -- 149 in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal-play championship at the Nassau Country Club today.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 -- Rip Van Wimbledon has done it again. Grizzled Gardnar Mulloy, the oldest man in the all-England field, trounced Britain's best -- Mike Davies of Wales -- in straight sets as a sellout crowd of 27,000 jammed in this flaming June afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury indicted six major electrical manufacturers and five individuals today on charges of fixing prices and rigging bids on Government and private contracts.
"The Robert Herridge Theater," which has long shopped around for an outlet on the air, may start soon on WCBS-TV here.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 -- A world youth leader warned tonight that Christian civilization faced collapse because modern youths were "being betrayed by powerful and sinister forces."

MABLBORO, VT. A SKILLET is more exciting than a camera, a ladle more exacting than a lens. This is the opinion of Fenno Jacobs, a highly successful and internationally known photographer who, in his middle years,' exchanged a professional darkroom for an equally professional kitchen.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 (UPI) -- Bob Friend of the Pittsburgh Pirates hurled his fourth shutout of the season tonight, a 5-0 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals. It marked his ninth victory of the season and stretched the Pirates' home winning streak to seven games.
The political chief of the state's merged labor federation last night called Harry S. Truman "a good President but, regrettably, not a good ex-President."
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's "Report to the People" on the city's plans for combating juvenile delinquency this summer:

The First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States would not be worth the paper it is written on if its guarantees failed to cover even the most outrageous and objectionable expressions so long as they are not likely, to quote the Supreme Court's Terminiello decision in 1949, "to produce a clear and present danger of a substantive evil that rises far above public inconvenience, annoyance, or unrest."
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- In the third setback of the week, numerous gram futures contracts hit or barely missed their lowest levels of the season today on the Board of Trade.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- Talent Show, receiving a heady ride from Ray Broussard, swept from the third position on the near turn and hurried to a length-and-a-half victory today in the twenty-sixth running of the $56,100 added Massachusetts Handicap.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The president of Harvard University and the chairman of the House Education Committee quarreled today over a move to repeal the non-Communist affidavit required of college students seeking Federal loans.

The International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots and the American Merchant Marine Institute agreed yesterday to go to arbitration on the question of wage demands made by the ship officers union.
LONDON, June 22 -- The British Labor party announced a new defense policy today. The policy advocated leaving the Western strategic deterrent of nuclear weapons to the United States.
WASHINGTON, June22 (AP) -- Legislation liberalizing the Congressional pension system was sent to President Eisenhower's desk today.
A State Supreme Court justice yesterday awarded the custody of a 3-year-old boy to his foster parents after describing the 18-year-old natural mother as unfit to raise the child.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Government's incentive payment to producers on 1959 crop wool will be 43.2 per cent of the dollar returns they received from the sale of the commodity.

The promoters, the police and the State Athletic Commission traded statements yesterday over who was to blame for the gate-crashing and other spectator shenanigans at Monday night's heavyweight title fight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- "The Marriage-Go-Round" is before the cameras after a mild go-round with the censors.

J. Luther Cleveland will retire on July 1 as chairman of the executive committee of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Cleveland was chairman and chief executive officer of the Guaranty.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. apologized today to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for "unnecessary and unwarranted statements which I made in the heat of the West Virginia primary."
FOR years bridal consultants have tried to solve the bride-to-be's problem. Most girls want a dress that is as traditional as grandmother's, and, at the same time, socially functional.
QUEBEC, June 22 -- A major upset in Quebec politics seemed assured tonight as the Liberal party held the lead in today's provincial elections.
A committee of experts yesterday called for drastic revision of the chemistry teaching Program in New York City's high schools.

DETROIT, June 22 -- Really rolling now, the front-running Yankees routed the Tigers 7 -- 3, before 30,394 fans at Briggs Stadium 'tonight. For Casey Stengel's crew it mean six in a row and thirteen of fourteen. If that isn't a pennant-winning pace, what is?
CHICAGO, June 22 -- A railroad union leader today termed the movement toward rail mergers a management device aimed at weakening and dismembering unions "in the name of economy and efficiency."
The Board of Estimate will consider today the most advanced medical research project ever undertaken by a municipality in this country.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 22 -- East "European Communist party leaders fell into-line today as Premier Khrushchev pressed, the doctrinal dispute over the policy of peaceful co-existence.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 22 (AP) -- C.V. Whitney's Chinchilla rallied from far back today and won the $26,500 Tyro Stakes at Monmouth Park. Defeating Martin L. Wilson's Song of Wine in the last strides, he scored at odds of better than 47 to 1.
A marina designed to meet every need of the pleasure boat owner and his craft is being planned for the Hudson River near the northern tip of Manhattan. It will cost about $3,570,000.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 22 -- Peter Colodny, a former University of Vermont golfer, posted a 73 for low-gross honors in the annual Mittelmark Memorial Tournament at the Fenway Golf Club today.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 22 -- Governor Rockefeller discovered today that a man in politics cannot lose himself for a day even in the vastness of a 3,000,000-acre forest preserve
The time for decision is near in a protracted Pentagon struggle over development of satellites for world-wide communications.
Financing plans involving the issuance of securities valued at more than $257,000,000 were made known yesterday by two utilities and a financing concern.

When Dorothy and Fred Walsh of Frenchtown, N.J., showed a Bouvier des Flandres at the Westminster show in 1956 it created a stir among dog fanciers. It was the first time the "cattle dog of Flanders" had been shown in Madison Square Garden in four years.
MILWAUKEE, June22 (AP) Alvin Dark, Philadelphia Phillies' infielder, was purchased tonight by the Milwaukee Braves.

Of all the governmental tasks today that of heading the first independent Government of the Belgian Congo is surely the most difficult. Only a week remains before Patrice Lumumba, head of the radical National Congolese Movement, must take office, and the problems that he faces are enormous.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Phillies played half an inning to defeat Chicago, 7 -- 6, and complete a suspended game tonight. Then they belted two homers for a 6-3 victory in regularly scheduled contest.

Great Western Financial The Great Western Financial Corporation, California savings and loan holding company, announced yesterday the declaration of a 100 per cent stock dividend. It is payable on Aug. 1 to holders of record of July 15.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- The Senate passed tonight an $8,459,412,900 money bill to operate the Government's independent agencies after rejecting a proposal to deny Federal aid to airports with segregated facilities.

Once again plagued with the general economic boom, the Federal Bank of West Germany raised the bank rate from 4 to 5 per cent about three weeks ago. But despite the move to tighten money, stocks continued to advance faster than ever -- 8 per cent in the period of June 7 through June 15.
LONDON, June 22 -- The House of Lords among whose members are several newspaper owners, Rebated today the general moral and professional health of the British press.

The offer of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. to step aside as delegate at large to the Democratic National Convention to make room for Herbert H. Lehman received a chilly reception yesterday from Michael H. Prendergast, the party's state chairman.
After fifty-two years with the agency -- forty-four of them as its chief executive officer -- Stanley Resor is stepping down as the active head of the J. Walter Thompson Company.

DUBLIN, June 22 -- With final practice rounds of 66 and 65, respectively, over the par-72 seaside course at Portmarnock Golf Club, Arnold Palmer and Sam Snead today were established as 2-to-1 favorites to win the Canada Cup for the United States.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 22 -- The six-nation European Economic Community appears to be performing surprisingly like a common market long before it really is one.
The writer of the following letter is Director of Research of the Sloan Institute of Hospital Administration of the Graduate School of Business and, Public Administration, Cornell University.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee completed action today on a bill gradually raising the minimum wage to $1.25 an hour and putting about 5,000,000 more employes under wage and hour regulations.
New York City tenants are being evicted to make way for new, high-rent housing at a rate almost double that of 1959, a study of Temporary State Rent Commission figures showed yesterday.

CHANCELLOR, Va., June 22 -- Even having the law on his side doesn't mean a fellow is going to catch a fish. Today, Virginia's Commission of Game and Inland Fisheries assigned two wardens in two parts of the state to act as guides for two fishing safaris.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Vice President Nixon at St. Louis yesterday outlined the Republican party position on an issue inherent in the broad one that is expected to dominate the 1960 campaign. The broad issue is the relative capacity of the two Presidential candidates cope with the inflamed conditions in the world.
Under Bill Boland's hard drive along the rail, Emil Dolce's Manassa Mauler got home in front of Ken-Love Farm's 10-1 shot, Amber Morn in the $28,550 Stymie Handicap at Belmont yesterday.
Yields on basic short - term debt investments shrank further yesterday in a bond market that lacked other significant movement.

ST. PAUL, June 22 -- A proposal for a new line of Negro protests this summer and fall, growing out of the student sitin movement, was placed before the youth and college section of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Oliver M. Gale, who has been a special assistant to two Secretaries of Defense, left the Pentagon today to head a special five-man information unit for the Republican National Committee.

Two keys, mailed special delivery, and two anonymous telephone calls to detectives of the West Fifty-fourth Street police station led to the recovery yesterday of $150,000 worth of stolen sporting goods and merchandise.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson berated the Administration today for "a depressing lack of vital new ideas in our foreign policy."

THE chemise, a frisky ghost that never would lie down and properly die, has done some heavy haunting lately. Yesterday it marched back into real life, and James Galanos did it Mr. Galanos is the moody, brilliant California designer who does not especially care about being loved by all the women of America.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -- Office space in the nation's major office buildings now totals 89,400,000 square feet, a record. Rentals average $4.02 a square foot, also a record,, and the national vacancy rate is 3.2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Development Loan Fund has lent India $66,000,000 for five power projects in the last two months without requiring that she spend it all in this country.
HONOLULU, June 22 -- President Eisenhower attended to some matters of administration and then turned to relaxation at golf today.
TRENTON, June 22 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed today designed to assure the continuance of essential railroad commuter services in metropolitan northern New Jersey

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Your editorial "Basque Protest" of June 15 was a good one, but I wish it had displayed a greater sense of urgency. Perhaps it would have if, like me, you had been privileged to read the letter to the recent national convention of the Socialist party from Rodolfo Llopis, General Secretary of the Spanish Socialist Party in Exile.

Conclusive findings as to wrongdoing in city purchase of rock salt for snow removal since 1955 must await examination by the District Attorney. But the four-day public hearing by the State Commission of Investigation, after a long inquiry led by Whitney North Seymour Jr. as chief counsel, has certainly turned up evidence of lax, irregular administration in one or more city departments, if not worse.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A limited Federal-state program of medical care for needy elderly citizens was tentatively approved today by the House of Representatives.
A recently resigned New York City assistant corporation counsel and two Los Angeles physicians have been indicted in Queens in the illegal sale of new-born babies.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The House Rules Committee virtually buried today all chances for a Federal school construction bill.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Early Wynn of the White Sox snapped his five-game losing streak tonight by pitching a two-hitter that beat the Baltimore Orioles, 3 -- 1.

The Senate approved the new treaty with Japan yesterday by the overwhelming vote of 90 to 2. And this morning in Tokyo, the treaty was made immediately effective by the exchange of signed documents of ratification.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- A Senate committee report raised the question today of whether the Eisenhower Administration "makes a sham of the law" by seeking friendly Democrats for appointments not open to Republicans.
The bearded and barefoot operator of a Greenwich Village coffee shop told yesterday about his troubles with Federal agents over a little known drug called peyote.

A situation "even more critical than in previous years" confronts the city this summer in its battle against juvenile delinquency, Mayor Wagner said last night.

Japan's classic company, the Grand Kabuki, lowered its final curtain last night at the City Center after a scheduled threeweek stay that easily could have been indefinitely extended on the basis of public demand. And, with it, the lights went out on one of this season's most remarkable theatre events.
DETROIT, June 22 -- Walter P. Reuther warned the auto industry today against juggling production schedules in September and October for political purposes.
The Atlas Powder Company has redesigned its stock certificate with the help of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

NANUET, N.Y., June 22 -- The Rockland County police are investigating the death of Mrs. John Mehrtens, 73-year-old widow of a New York City policeman, whose nude and bound body was found today near her home on Alice Drive here.

The lease on the five-story Elton Hotel at 101 East Twenty-sixth Street has been sold by Henry Christopher West to an investing group represented by Charles Kelman, lawyer.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A bill to provide a moratorium for owners of new American tankers unable to finance principal and interest payments on their Government-insured mortgages met strong opposition today.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 22 -- Philips Andover Academy won the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association's Mallory Trophy in a thrilling finish on Manhasset Bay today.

ALBANY, June 22 -- State equalization rates for Manhattan and Brooklyn real estate have dropped slightly, according to the final 1960 figures released by the Board of Equalization and Assessment yesterday.

Archie Moore, the world light-heavyweight champion, yesterday was granted a postponement of his title fight in Toronto with the European titleholder, Eric Schoeppner, scheduled for July 18.

Gift From Venice Venice recently presented to New York City a tablet commemorating the arrival in 1635 of New York's first Italian immigrant -- Peter Albert!. Since that time much, of Italy has come to the United States -- Botticellis to our museums, Toscaninis to our concert halls, Apulian peasants to our farms and vineyards and Fermis to our laboratories.
MOSCOW, June 22 -- Premier Khrushchev's defense of his thesis that war can be avoided and of his right, to amend the doctrines of Lenin aroused unusual interest in Moscow today.
The American Nazi party yesterday, was denied the right to hold a rally in Union Square on July 4.

H.B. Cantor, hotel owner and proponent of trans-Atlantic travel at $50 a trip, urged yesterday that the Federal Govrnment adapt its housing construction loan program to the passenger shipbuilding industry.

The Maryland State Roads Commission borrowed $20,000,000 yesterday on bonds secured by special revenues. The borrowing cost the state 3.5151 per cent interest.

Robert Z. Greene, a director of the Automatic Canteen Company of America, has sold 16,500 shares of the common stock, according to the latest insiders' report of the New York Stock Exchange.

Attorneys for the Long Island Rail Road and its 1,350 unionized trainmen sought agreement yesterday on a strike truce formula. The line is now operating under a Federal court order prohibiting any walkout before 12:10 A.M. next Thursday.

SOME time in the distant future, when Floyd Patterson joins Joe Louis as one of boxing's elder statesmen, he is likely to pause long enough to think back to the turning point in his career. If he thinks deeply, he will be able to pinpoint it to that day when the bumbling New York State Athletic Commission accidentally did him a favor.
BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- Joseph J. (Specs) O'Keefe, whose testimony sent eight fellow bandits to jail for life for the $1,219,000 Brink's robbery, was adjudged today to have "paid his debt in full."

Today's new film is "Bells Are Ringing," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's color adaptation of the Broadway musical co-starring Judy Holiday and Dean Martin, at the Radio City Music Hall. Vincente Minnelli directed and Arthur Freed produced, from a scenario adapted by Adolph Green and Petty Comden from their original stage success.

Three groups of teen-agers representing Junior Achievement companies in the New York area were honored yesterday by the New York Financial Writers Association, Inc., for writing the best annual reports to stockholders.

First-quarter net income of the American and Foreign Power Company was estimated at 22 cents a common share yesterday toy Henry Sargent, president. He made the estimate to some 250 stockholders of the utility holding company during the annual meeting at 100 Trinity Place.

Pilots of Eastern Air Lines and Pan American World Airways continued to report for flight assignments yesterday as they ended wildcat strikes that crippled Eastern for eleven days and disrupted some Pan American schedules for four days.

The Central Intelligence Agency has published a prediction that total production in the Soviet Union will grow by about 80 per cent in the next decade. The indicated Soviet output in 1970, if the prediction proves correct, would be close to the total United States production in 1958.
It has taken a year to arrange it, but a testimonial dinner will be given tonight to Queens Borough President John T. Clancy by the Queens branch of the Urban League.

The nation's inventories of gasoline dropped by 3,563,000 barrels last week. This was the sharpest drop for any week this year. The fall reflected the start of the heavy summer motoring season and demand from farmers who are in their busiest period of the year.

World sugar futures fell on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday as traders reacted to reports that Congress was nearing agreement to authorize cutbacks in this country's imports from Cuba.

The treasurer of a union local in the International Longshoremen's Association heard yesterday an alleged tape recording of his conversation with a paid informer of the Waterfront Commission. They talked about the amount of dynamite that would be required to blow up a store in Bordentown, N.J.

IN "The Marrying Maiden," which opened last evening, the Living Theatre leaves the avant-garde behind. "The Balcony," "Krapp's Last Tape" and "The Connection" have met their match and become obsolete.

Senator John E. Kennedy will meet with the Liberal party policy committee here today in an effort to assure himself of Liberal endorsement if he gets the Democratic nomination for President next month.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 10 points (50 cents a bale) up yesterday.
Sanitation workers complained yesterday that they had "suffered chemical burns" and incurred hazards in handling rock salt imported from the Dominican Republic for city snow removal.

ANNAPOLIS, June 22 -- Rear Admiral John F. Davidson assumed his duties today as superintendent of the Naval Academy and chief of the Severn River Naval Command. He relieved Rear Admiral Charles L. Melson in a change-of-command ceremony.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate gave its overwhelming consent today to the new security treaty with Japan.

Abridge editor on a busman's holiday, Richard A. Miller of The Gazette and Daily of York, Pa., played the deal shown in highly expert company, admired the play of his opponents, and wound up with an excellent score.
CAMDBN, N.J., June 22 -- Senator John F. Kennedy called on the American people tonight to turn "once again" to the Democratic party for leadership "as they have" in periods of "extreme crisis."

LONDON, June 22 -- The improvement in the stock market that began late yesterday continued today and prices moved slowly forward in reduced trading.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 23 -- Life can be beautiful in the suburbs, but it also can have its aggravations -- as almost every suburbanite knows. Today was Aggravation Day in Stamford.

Store fronts with basements are becoming increasingly popular among wholesale concerns in the accessories field, particularly in the area of the East Thirties.

Deck Scow Captains Local 335 of the Seafarers Internation- al Union has filed a $100,000 damage suit against four major carriers of industrial sand and gravel.

MORE than 2,000 happy but highly critical young women converged in Brooklyn this week to see how they might look as brides.

HONOLULU, June 23 -- President Eisenhower conferred by telephone today with Vice President Nixon. They discussed the President's Far Eastern trip and his forthcoming television report to the nation Monday night.

Senator John F. Kennedy told the Liberal party yesterday that he hoped to win the Democratic nomination for President without a single Southern vote in the convention. He also told the party he regarded the civil rights issue as a moral question.
Drivers for Terminal System, Inc., one of the largest fleet taxicab operators in the city, voted overwhelmingly yesterday against affiliation with James R. Hoffa's Teamsters union.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The House of Representatives rolled up a deceptively one-sided vote of 380 to 23 today for a Federal-state program of medical care for the needy aged.

An apprentice mechanic for the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., of fifty years ago was elected president of the company yesterday.

Pleasure boat skippers on the inland fresh-water lakes have in at least one respect an advantage over their salt-water brethren. They have no tides to worry about.

DUBLIN, June 23 -- A couple of invalids from South Africa stole the show and the lead from Arnold Palmer and Sam Snead of the United States late today in the opening round of the seyenty-two-hole international golf championship for the Canada-Cup.

The Kratter Corporation, real estate investment company, plans to diversify its activities through the acquisition of a company listed on the New York Stock Exchange with a market value exceeding $50,000,000, Marvin Kratter, chairman and president, said yesterday.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $176,000,000 to $550,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $164,000,000 to $589,000,000.
