CHICAGO, June 23 (UPI) -- A bases-filled walk to Bob Boyd forced in one run in the eleventh inning, and Gene Stephens drove in another with a sacrifice fly as the Baltimore Orioles scored a 5-3 victory today over the Chicago White Sox.
NEW DELHI, India, June 23 -- Reliable sources confirmed today that major fighting between Tibetan rebels and Chinese Communist forces had spread to western Tibet.
The Erie Railroad reported yesterday "red ink" operations for May and also for the first five months this year.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 -- Big Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, the United States indoor tennis champion, defeated Ulf Schmidt of Sweden, who used to be United States indoor champion, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 11 -- 9, to lead a parade of talent into the round of sixteen at the all-England lawn tennis championship amid spasmodic showers today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 23 -- The Bermuda race this year was the slowest ever held as the yachts, plagued by only vague whispers of wind in the early stages and then by howling squalls in the latter stages, straggled across the finish line in rag-tag order.

The Oliver Corporation, whose name has been linked in mergers with other companies, is actively negotiating a possible sale of a major share of its business to the White Motor Company. J.N. Bauman, president of White and A.W. Phelps, chairman and president of Oliver, announced yesterday following board meetings in Chicago that important progress has been made toward acquisition of Oliver's farm equipment business by White.
Stocks advanced yesterday for the second day and a new wave of optimism rippled through Wall Street.
HAVANA, June 23 -- Premier Fidel Castro threatened today to meet "economic aggression" by the United States with the seizure of all American-owned property and business interests in Cuba.
ARLINGTON, Va., June 23 -- A restaurant chain opened its doors to Negroes here today. It was the first such action by well-known restaurants in Virginia to abandon the color line.

THE question of who wears the fanciest pants in the family should stump no one. These days women have the greatest choice ever of sleek, colorful and imaginative pants styles. Now that trousers have become a major part of many women's wardrobes, place and personal dimensions govern the wearing of this easy-going fashion.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 23 -- Two exciting races in the United States Olympic trials today brought about a virtual deadlock between Fantasi, owned by Ted Hood and Bradley Noyes and George O'Day's Wistful in the International 5.5-meter yacht competition.
CHICAGO, June 23 -- A Democratic "kingmaker" declared today that he believed Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts was virtually assured of the Democratic Presidential nomination.
Operations of the Dana Corporation and its subsidiaries in the nine months ended on May 31 resulted in a net income of $13,827,670 after taxes and all charges, the report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The new Transit navigational satellite was working so well today that Navy officials were predicting it would locate ship positions within a few hundred feet, pinpoint the distances between continents and define more precisely the shape of the earth.
GENEVA, June 23 -- The Western powers sharply retorted to the Soviet bloc today for questioning their good faith in the disarmament talks and holding out the threat of a break-up.
Columbia University announced yesterday it had received a gift of $1,000,000 toward the construction of the new building for its Graduate School of Business.

JUDY HOLLIDAY in the movie and the New York Naval Shipyard Choir on the stage line out some robust entertainment in the new summer show at the Music Hall. And "line out" appears the most fellcitous expression, to be used as the verb.
ROME, June 23 -- Alitalia, the Italian airline, announced today plans to seek public financing and to expand its world-wide operations.
CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians beat the Washington Senators, 7 -- 6, on an unearned run today and swept a three-game series.
A novel charge of piracy by customs men has been made by an American trader against Brazilian officials in the Amazon territory of Amapa.
Strong indications developed last night that a new and binding strike deadline on the Long Island Rail Road would be set for 12:01 A.M. July 10.

THE psychic bid in bridge is like the bluff in poker. An expert uses it for its negative effect. He does not expect to make a profit from his psychics, but wishes to instill doubt in the minds of his opponents.

POULTRY in recent months has often been an economical choice at meat departments. But the price tag alone does not indicate which kind of poultry -- turkeys, ducks or chickens -- is the best buy. It is necessary to know how much actual meat there is in each pound of the various birds.

Edward Wherry, Los Angeles department store executive who in September will take over the job of president of Bonwit Teller, Fifth Avenue specialty store, said yesterday he admired the fashion job the store had done.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (UPI) -- A new indictment charging six major electrical manufacturers with conspiring to fix prices was handed up today by a Federal grand jury.
An iron dumbbell fell from an eighth-floor window here yesterday and struck a Detroit business man on the head, injuring him critically.

TOKYO, June 23 -- With the new United States-Japanese security treaty in effect as of today, its chief opponents maneuvered for position in Japan's political warfare. New elections in the near future were indicated.

THE PRESIDENT In Hawaii. THE SENATE Approved and sent to House authorization bill for a ten-year deep-sea research program with cost of more than $400,000,000; confirmed three regulatory board nominations.
BONN, Germany, June 23 -- Chancellor Adenauer denied again today that the Deutsche mark would be revalued.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- A rookie outfielder, Ken Walters, smashed his seventh home run of the season in the eighth inning tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies scored a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
The city's police were reminded yesterday that the summer season -- when everyone remains outdoors longer on hot muggy evenings -- posed some special problems.
A series of small fires on the IND yesterday morning disrupted subway traffic and brought a strong exchange between the Fire Department and the Transit Authority.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- -- Leaders of both parties worked frantically today to keep alive prospects for a Federal school construction bill.

BONELESS chuck steak is making news this week with a 6-cent drop in price. It now sells generally for the unusually low cost of 79 cents a pound and is being offered in some stores at a bargain 53 cents a pound.
A large-scale television workshop program for teachers will be established next fall to improve the teaching of science in the city's elementary schools and of English in the secondary schools.

QUEBEC, June 23 -- The Liberal party's unexpected provincial election victory yesterday in Quebec, where the National Union party was ousted after a sixteen-year rule, has implications that are likely to cast a new light on the Canadian political situation.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 23 -- President Francois Duvalier said Tuesday that Haiti was "at the limit of sacrifices" and was "exhausted."

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's appointments of a general and an admiral to Federal regulatory agencies were confirmed by the Senate today over protests against permitting military influence in Government to spread.

AT 3 o'clock in the afternoon on May 25, 1660, just four days before his thirtieth birthday, a tall young man with a swarthy complexion and a saturnine expression stepped ashore at Dover and at once fell upon his knees to render thanks. A minister presented to him an ornate Bible, which he accepted, saying that it was the thing he loved best in the world.

The one-story building at 135-37-39 West Forty-second Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), has been purchased by a client of Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., brokers, from Louis Forer.
SAN ANTONIO, June 23 -- James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, Archbishop of Los Angeles, said here tonight that "there is no separation of church and state," and there never can be.
The leader of the American Nazi party said yesterday that he expected to speak in Union Square on July 4, despite Mayor Wagner's ban.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The House of Representatives yielded to the Senate today to limit free and "blind", mailing by members of Congress.
An Investment banking group managed by Bache Co. offered yesterday 400,000 common shares of the Electrada Corporation at $12 a share.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Federated seamen's and waterfront unions joined steamship operators today in backing legislation to keep Communists off merchant ships and docks.

Several advertisers have been having a difficult time of it recently because of knockouts, discharged baseball managers and pilots who would not fly with Federal Aviation Agency inspectors just behind them.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 23 -- The New York State Bar Association moved today to keep lawyers from states with lower legal standards from automatic admission to practice in the Federal courts in New York.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- Senators challenged the head of the United States Information Agency today to explain why, despite the expenditure of millions of dollars on United States information activities, the Communists appeared to be winning the propaganda war.
WAUKEGAN, Ill., June 23 -- Adlai E. Stevenson called on both parties tonight to "keep Mr. Khrushchev out" of the Presidential campaign.
Of the seven horses in the feature race at Belmont Part yesterday, none had a smaller chance of winning than Peter Fuller's Rough Fellow -- or so the wagering of the 18,726 fans indicated.
CINCINNATI, June 23 (AP) -- With the echos of a scolding by Manager Walt Alston goading them, the Los Angeles Dodgers wove ten singles and five walks into a 6 -- 2 victory over Cincinnati tonight.

One of the top officials of the International Longshoremen's Association confirmed yesterday the Waterfront Commission findings of criminal elements in the dockworkers' union. But he also supported the repeated contention of I.L.A. leaders that they have sought to eliminate ex-convicts and "notorious hoods."
ELMSFORD, N.Y., June 23 -- Most residents of Greenburgh do not want a town library and consequently none will be built at this time, officials reported today.

Waterbury, Conn., borrowed $2,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of bonds maturing serially from 1962 to 1979 to a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The House, in a surprise action, defeated today a bill to raise price supports on wheat and cut wheat acreage. As a result, there is little chance of any new wheat legislation this year.

Fairmont Foods Co. Stockholders of the Fairmont Foods Company yesterday at their annual meeting in Omaha approved an increase in authorized common stock to 2,500,000 shares from 850,000 shares. P.F. Seiger, financial vice president, noted, "We have no immediate plans for using the new stock, but we are constantly talking with companies about acquisitions and we don't want to get caught short of stock."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- Culturally, Hollywood comes alive in the summer.
LONDON, June 23 -- The British Government moved on two fronts today to stave off inflation and to keep the national economy sound.

The threat of a strike at ten voluntary hospitals, scheduled for any time after last midnight, was put off last night for at least a week. At the same time labor leaders echoed the "high hopes'' expressed recently by Mayor Wagner that a permanent peace would be found.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Grain and soybean futures prices mustered their first general advance in almost a week on the Board of Trade today but failed to hold the extreme gains.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- In the face of published suggestions for a review of the United States' policy of bases on the periphery of the Soviet Union, Defense Department officials insisted today that the bases were needed to counter the threat of aggression.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- In the few days remaining before the start of the Presidential nominating conventions there are several constructive things that might be done in the interests of both parties and the nation.
ALBANY, June 23 -- Senator John F. Kennedy received an overwhelming majority for the Democratic Presidential nomination in a poll at a caucus of the New York convention delegation here today.
ALBANY, June 23 -- The Democratic state leadership backed down today from its decision to exclude former Senator Herbert H. Lehman from the state delegation to the party's national convention.

Market Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli announced yesterday that the city had taken ownership of the 126-acre site on which it will build a $25,000,000 wholesale produce market in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.

MISS MARGARET LOUISE JOHNSTON, assistant archivist at the Public Record Office in Belfast, Northern Ireland, is so busy looking up Americans' ancestry that she has little time to wonder about her own.

With the three-year freeze on bank holding company expansion expiring on June 30, the Marine Midland Corporation has proposed to acquire the First National Bank of Poughkeepsie and to operate it as the twelfth unit in its state-wide system.
Queen Elisabeth of Belgium has commended the United States for its "exceptional participation" last month in the music competition bearing her name.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 23 -- Today we fished the James River. More than 300 years ago Captain John Smith and other members of the Jamestown Settlement tried their luck regularly just north of here.
AMONG the contrasts that characterized the concert at Lewisohn Stadium last night, none was more vivid than the one that existed between conductor and soloist.

"Portrait of Max," a biography of the late Max Beerbohm by S.N. Behrman, will be published by Random House and is the October selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club. The volume is a product of a warm personal relationship.
Judge Louis Goldstein has recommended the dismissal of six teachers accused of making false statements about past membership in the Communist party.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of June 21 on "F.A.A. and the Pilots" calls for comment since it evidences a grave misunderstanding of the issues involved in the recent work stoppage on Eastern Air Lines. The pilots raised no issue of pay or working conditions but the simple issue of air safety.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- The House Administration Committee responded today to charges of travel allowance abuses by imposing a $25 daily limit on expense accounts of House members making trips in this country.

The case of Humanity vs. Adolf Eichmann in the United Nations came to an end yesterday when the draft resolution deploring the methods by which Eichmann was removed from a haven in Argentina to a jail in Israel was approved by the Security Council.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Reduced steel production bad further adverse effects on both rail and truck freight loadings last week, both transportation industries reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

Loans to business at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose $47,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $226,000,000 the week before and of $2,000,000 in the 1959 week.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 23 -- The Security Council asked Israel tonight to make "appropriate reparation" for the unauthorized transfer of Adolf Eichmann from Argentina to face trial in an Israeli court.
"Queen far a Day," the daytime television giveaway show, has become the center of a controversy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Senator Fulbright's constructive proposals regarding the Arab refugee problem, in his Senate speech of June 15, are to be applauded. His proposals warrant thoughtful consideration not only by the Arab nations and by Israel, but by every thinking American.
A survey of the needs of tenants along the right-of-way of the projected Lower Manhattan Expressway was ordered yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
Sidney J. Ungar testified yesterday that Borough President Hulan E. Jack had not repaid him for the remodeling of Mr. Jack's apartment in early 1958.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 23 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of the Meadow Brook Club captured the women's Long Island Golf Association title for the sixth time today with a fifty-four-hole total of 149, 75 -- 224 at the Creek Club.

The heaviest sampling in the history of the Leather Show was reported yesterday at the opening of the two-day exhibit at the Statler Hilton Hotel. The fifty-seventh semi-annual event is sponsored by the Tanners Council of America.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Friday, June 24 -- Patrice Lumumba received the approval of the Congolese House of Representatives early today for the new nation's first Government, after a last-minute compromise with Joseph Kasayubu.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The United States decided today to send Fredrick M. Eaton back to the Geneva disarmament talks with new directives.

The American-Japanese treaty is now in effect, but the tumultuous events leading up to its ratification have raised grave apprehensions about the stability of Japan's new democracy, without which the treaty would be worthless. And the most disturbing aspect of these events is that the most active elements in them were masses of Left-Wing students and professors in alliance with Left-Wing labor.
World sugar futures fell sharply again on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday as broad selling continued in anticipation of changes in this country's quota of Cuban sugar imports.

The American-Japanese treaty is now in effect, but the tumultuous events leading up to its ratification have raised grave apprehensions about the stability of Japan's new democracy, without which the treaty would be worthless. And the most disturbing aspect of these events is that the most active elements in them were masses of Left-Wing students and professors in alliance with Left-Wing labor.
The local bill imposing a $5,000,000 use tax on trucks and passenger cars for hire was signed by Mayor Wagner yesterday morning.

THE cold buffet increases in popularity with the approach of warm weather. But as appealing as a cold meal may be -- whether eaten indoors, on the patio or carried on a picnic -- one hot dish such as scalloped potatoes gives it a hearty, satisfying quality that it otherwise lacks.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A resolution to permit radio and television networks to give free time to Presidential candidates was approved today by the Senate Democratic Policy Committee.

New developments in a previously announced plan to film "The Longest Day," Cornelius Ryan's book on the Allied invasion of Normandy, have been disclosed by producer Raoul Levy and his associate, Michael Mindlin Jr.
TOKYO, June 24 -- Japanese went about their normal business today amid a political calm they had not experienced in more than a month.

PARIS It is generally accepted that within two or three years Western defenses will be at a temporary disadvantage when Soviet production of longrange ballistic missiles, or ICBM's, is sufficiently ahead of United States production of these weapons to show a real disparity in relative strength.

Jittery trading marked world sugar dealings yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices fluctuated sharply during the session as traders awaited further developments concerning Premier Fidel Castro's recent threat to seize all American-owned property and business interests if the Cuban sugar quota was cut by Congress.

As the weather warms, so thoughts of cooking correspondingly cool. At such times it is good to make use of foods that require no heating and little preparation. Such a product is the langostina, a tiny lobster that is available in the food freezers of many city shops.

William Zeckendorf has been re-elected chairman of the Realty Foundation of New York. Others renamed were Lee Thompson Smith, Louis J. Glickman and Jack D. Weiler, vice presidents, all for their fifth terms.
CLEVELAND, June 24 -- The Yankees, scoring four times on only one hit in the seventh inning, broke a 6-6 deadlock and beat the Indians, 10 -- 6, at Mu nicipal Stadium tonight.

Joseph V. Spagna charged yesterday that he was being "degrade 1 and vilified simply because it has become fashionable in some circles to seek to destroy public servants." He declined to identify whom he meant.

PARIS, June 24 -- President de Gaulle has "agreed in principle" that the Ivory Coast, Dahomey, Niger and Voltaic republics in West Africa shall have full independence without first negotiating cooperative agreements with France.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 24 -- Details of the second International Tin Agreement were announced this afternoon at the adjournment of closed-session deliberations that lasted one month.
A six-story apartment house containing forty-nine suites at 735 Bryant Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Geisinger Germain to Irving Walscy.
The leader of the American Nazi party said yesterday that he would go to New York next Wednesday to start legal action for the right to speak in Union Square on July 4.
The Lionel Corporation is expanding its electronic activities into the aviation and missile fields through the acquisition of Antom-Inco, it was learned yesterday from a reliable source.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 24 -- A former life-saving station that became a church-on-the-dunes in 1879 for this resort community will open for the summer Sunday. The Rev. Dr. Frederick M. Morris, rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, New York, will be in charge of the morning service.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 (AP) -- Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell scattered seven hits and drove in a pair of runs for the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight as they whipped the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 1. It was the eighth straight loss for the visitors.
PARIS, June 24 -- The prospect of peace talks between France and the Algerian rebels has produced the first real crystallization of French opinion since the fighting began sixtyekght months ago.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Republican charges that the Democrats on the House Agriculture Committee are "pro-Castro" have led to a deadlock on whether the Cuban sugar quota should be reduced.
Ten persons, including three children, were injured yesterday when a stagecoach overturned at Freedomland in the Bronx.

Saying he had "had enough," Martin Schulman, a Greenwich Village real-estate operator, walked out of a stormy tenanteviction hearing yesterday before Joseph Goldberg, Lower Manhattan rent administrator.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 24 -- One of this town's Selectmen sharply criticized his colleagues today for approving an expenditure of $8,500 to equip the kitchen of the new $293,000 volunteer firehouse in Old Greenwich.
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday to eliminate delays official processes that might impede the current construction boom here.

LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) -- Geoff Griffin, South Africa's controversial pace bowler, had seven no-ball calls against him today and then performed the hat trick on the second day of the second cricket test against England at lord's.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of June 16 "State Tax Reduction" condoned the Governor's announcement of the tax cut as being "good politics." If by "good politics" you refer to a shrewd appeal for votes, I concur. If, however, you mean this program to be a reflection of a sound basic policy, I disagree vehemently.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 24 -- Four peacocks are coming to, live at the United Nations.
CINCINNATI, June 24 (AP) -- Willie Mays' one-man offense and the relief pitching of Johnny Antonelli helped the San Francisco Giants score a 5-3 victory over Cincinnati tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- A special examiner closed today a review contest over a Miami television channel after having heard a witness tell a story of attempted outside influence in the case.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (UPI) -- Ken Walters, a rookie outfielder, and Robin Roberts combined tonight to bat and pitch Philadelphia to a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals for the Phils' sixth in a row -- their longest winning streak since the end of the 1958 season.

Having piloted the new American-Japanese security pact to final ratification in defiance of massive mob violence against him and his policies, Premier Kishi has now announced his impending resignation to calm the emotional storm that grips Japan and pave the way for new elections.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A Massachusetts scientist has invented the near-perfect musical instrument. With its double keyboard and row of pedals, a musician should be able to duplicate accurately all the sounds of all the instruments in an entire orchestra.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 24 -- Navy Salute, owned by the Duffy Stables of Rye, N.Y., won the open jumping touch-and-out blue ribbon at the Fair-field County Hunt Club horse show today.

The State Department has now changed its policy and is in favor of a cut in Cuban sugar exports to the United States. This is a move of first-rate political importance in our relations with Latin America as well as Cuba.

THE Hogarthian life and variety of Times Square is celebrated in "Carnival Crossroads,"* by W.G. Rogers and Mildred Weston. Their book is one of the breeziest regional studies of the year -- though I don't think any university is going to give them twin doctorates for their enterprise in this baccalaureate month of June.

Sidney J. Ungar denied a suggestion by defense counsel yesterday that he had taken advantage of Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan. The session was one of the stormiest since the trial of Mr. Jack began last week.
The Hamburg-American Line has sold the cruise ship Ariadne to a newly formed British corporation for about $3,500,000.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- The House passed a bill today to make the terms of regulatory agency members more uniform despite charges the measure would contribute to the political "spoils system."
DETROIT, June 24 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis voiced the hope here today that Adolph Eichmann would be accorded "every measure of justice."

KANSAS CITY, June 24 (AP) -- Gay Brewer Jr. of Crystal River, Fla., shot his second 3-under par 69 today and took the 36-hole lead in the $15,000 Kansas City pro-amateur golf tournament with a 138 total. Paul Harney of Worcester, Mass., was only a stroke behind with a 71 for 139.

HAVANA, June 24 -- Premier Fidel Castro reiterated tonight that American-owned property in Cuba would be confiscated in proportion that the Cuban sugar quota in the United States was reduced by the Congress at Washington.

Mayor Wagner instructed the Fire Department and Transit Authority yesterday to work out an "accelerated plan" to clean up rubbish in the subways. He also called for a more effective subway fire-prevention program.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 23 -- The hatreds that paralyze Finland's political life have dealt President Urho Kekkonen a major defeat for the second time in less than three weeks.
MILWAUKEE, June 24 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers scored two runs on only one hit in the tenth inning tonight and defeated Milwaukee, 5 to 3. The loss snapped the Braves' six-game winning streak.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 -- Maria Bueno of Brazil, the reigning queen at Wimbledon, and Karen Hantze of San Diego, Calif., who gives every promise of becoming one, advanced to the quarter-finals of the women's singles today.

THE Queen of Thailand will arrive in New York on July 5, and several of her costumes no longer are a secret. For one thing, the fabrics used by Pierre Balmain in creating three outfits are on view and for sale at Thaibok, 3 East Fifty-second Street.
ST. PAUL, June 24 -- America's principal Negro union leader warned today that "the gulf of misunderstanding seems to be widening between the Negro community and the labor community."

A single overriding issue has emerged in the debate on Communist doctrine between the Soviet Union and China: Should Premier Khrushchev be accepted as the fount of doctrinal authority, the successor to Marx, Engels, Lenin and Stalin?
Lexington and Third Avenues will be converted to one-way operation on July 17, Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley said yesterday.
A West German telecaster, following a trend set by Europe-browsing American TV shows, is busy in New York filming a special series to be shown in Germany next season.

"Damn few actors are capable of doing anything except extensions of themselves. I'm not at all against. The Method, but I think most people stop short, of developing the graces of acting, such as voice, movement and proper timing."

Directors of the New York Central Railroad met here yesterday and wrestled for six hours with the problems presented to that system by the offer of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway to buy the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 24 -- Residents of the so-called back-country area are protesting the Board of Education's plans to acquire part of a twenty-three-acre tract for a new elementary school.
A microbe that is generally believed to be a rare harasser of humans is probably killing and crippling a great many persons throughout the world.
Dr. John J. Theobald, the city's Superintendent of Schools, received permission yesterday from the State Board of Regents to hire additional deputy superintendents who are not necessarily educators.
PARIS, June 24 -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina said today that he was "entirely satisfied" with the United Nations Security Council resolution on the Eichmann case.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Following is the state Department's transcript of Secretary of State Christian A. Herter' news conference today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of June 23 on the Rockwell case, you stated that, "if he were left quietly to speak his piece, however revolting and abominable it is, he would create no impact." The city administration is completely in agreement with this, as were the leaders of a number of organizations with which we discussed the matter.
The red lightship that marks the Ambrose Channel has been described as the world's best known floating beacon.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman urged the Senate today to restore funds cut by the House from the foreign-aid budget, but a citizens group critical of the program asked for a reduction of $2,000,000,000.

Housing and conformity Whenever the subject of conformity in America is being discussed, several things are usually mentioned as proof that too many of us are living up to other people's expectations.

THIS deal, played at the Metropolitan Unity Bridge Club, is one of a common type in which neither side knows how much it can make and keeps on bidding largely because it is equally unsure of defeating the opponents.
NEW DELHI, June 24 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru strongly supported the revised Soviet disarmament plan today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 24 -- Mrs. Edward Landau of Fenway and Lois Hallager of Bonnie Briar, each with a gross score of 81, led a field of fiftyseven low-handicapped players in the Women's Tri-Cbunty Golf Association Tournament at the Elmwood Country Club today.
An outbound freighter crashed into and sank the lightship at Ambrose station in heavy fog early yesterday.
Two tornadoes roared through communities in the Northeast yesterday, unroofing houses and hotels and felling power lines, poles and trees.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 24 -- Premier BenGurion indicated today that he was ready to consider Israel's controversy with Argentina over the Eichmann case closed.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- George D. Heron, president of the Seneca Indian Nation, said today he was opposed to the Government's taking part of the Seneca's New York State reservation regardless of how much money the Indians received for it.

Ground was broken yesterday for the third municipal garage to be started under the Department of Traffic's off-street parking program. City officials and business executives attended the ceremony in the Bronx, at 190th Street and Jerome Avenue where the 140-car facility will be built on the southeast corner.
The hand-to-mouth operation of steel mills these days promises a short time between receipt of an order and shipment.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Two authorities on African affairs told the American Society of African Culture today that the future of African political developments could not be predicted at this time.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter defended today the recent conduct of United States foreign relations and said Premier Khrushchev had come close to interfering in this country's internal affairs.
Stocks milled, backed and filled yesterday, and then closed thoroughly irregular. There was no definite trend, but key averages edged up.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Teamsters Union said today it was withdrawing its controversial $400,000 deposit from the Florida National Bank at Orlando, Fla.
YONKERS, June 24 -- Steamin' Demon broke the Yonkers Raceway record with a 2:00 2/5 mile tonight in winning the $25,000 Purdy Trot before 25,930 fans.

SAN DIEGO, June 24 -- Parents who would not trust their children's lives to an unlicensed surgeon apparently have no qualms over trusting their youngsters' future to unqualified teachers, it was suggested here today.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Senator John F. Kennedy praised the Negro sit-in demonstrations today as a sign that "the American spirit is coming alive again."

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The index of average wholesale prices at the primary market level declined 0.1 per cent to 119.5 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

American President Lines and other United States steamship operators serving the Far East want to get back into the China trade. The companies are supporting an amendment to United States Foreign Assets Control Regulations that would enable them to carry Red Chinese cargoes to non-United States ports.

An ex-convict who had been a $9,200-a-year vice president in an International Longshoremen's Association local seven years ago, earned $12,720 last year as a clerk in the local, an investigator of the Waterfront Commission testified yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- The grain futures market settled back into its recent pattern of general weakness today and posted a majority of declines for the fourth day this week.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Who sets the furniture styles today? The store buyers, a panel of dis gruntled designers agreed at a meeting yesterday. The meeting was held in the Merchandise Mart during the current wholesale showings of furnishings.

LONDON, June 24 -- Bargain hunting after yesterday's falls helped some of the Industrial leaders stage a rally in the stock market here today. However, the general tone was dull and losses of less than a shilling (14 cents) predominated.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 24 -- Joseph Kasavubu was elected Chief of State of the new Congolese nation today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 24 -- President Romulo Betancourt suffered light burns today when an assassin's bomb exploded alongside his car during Army Day observances here. The explosion killed his chief aide-de-camp, Col. Ramon Armas Perez, and his chauffeur.
KANSAS CITY, June 24 -- Clint Courtney's ninth-inning double scored Brooks Robinson from second base tonight as the Baltimore Orioles registered a 6-5 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 24 -- The New York State Bar Association heard conflicting views today on a proposal that the United States abandon its limited recognition of the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice.
The grandson of the noted financier of the Eighteen Nineties, Thomas Fortune Ryan, was elected president of the $100,000,000-a-year, world-wide Royal McBee Corporation yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A Congressional investigation into the operations of the Port of New York Authority apparently is still being planned, despite appeals for a conference rather than an inquiry from two Governors.

David Krause, Assistant Professor of English at Brown University, has written "Sean O'Casey: The Man and His Work." It is a critical study of the dramatist's complete work and an attempt to reconcile the events that have shaped O'Casey's life and inspired "his fiery genius."

HAMPTON, Va., June 24 -- The Sand Shark Society of Southern Chesapeake Bay must have been in convention today. Delegates to the meeting -- if it was a meeting -- swarmed around Capt. Marshall Smith's forty-six-foot sports fishing boat, Marsha Ann, as if it were a free lunch counter.
Backers and exhibitors of the British Exhibition, which will end a seventeen-day run at the New York Coliseum tomorrow, were described yesterday as "delighted" with response to the show.

Another actlve week is ahead in the market for new capital. Bonds of utilities and governments slated for offering are valued at more than $21O,000,000 and a $50,000,000 debenture issue of Montgomery Ward Credit Corporation is expected to swell the total Lehman Brothers expects to market the Montgomery Ward issue on Tuesday.
A Greenwich Village pharmacist was charged yesterday with selling habit-forming, dangerous and new drugs without prescriptions.

Condition and a slight edge in punching power enabled Doug Jones of New York to score a split decision over Von Clay of Philadelphia in their ten-round light-heavyweight fight at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Office space is occupied almost as fast as it becomes available in major buildings in the United States and Canada, according to the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The chairman of the Citizens for Johnson. [Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas] today described as incredible a statement attributed to Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts that Mr. Kennedy hoped to win the Democratic Presidential nomination, without a Southern vote.
The development of oil reserves in the Sahara will not have an immediate major impact upon the world's tanker industry, according to the current report of W.G. Weston, Ltd., of London.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, May 29 -- In the center of this capital city there is a treeframed war memorial inscribed with the dates of three wars -- World Wars I and II and a third war that has been fought only in the jungles of Malaya.
A strategy "that is total and totally new" is being sought by the National Council of Churches to meet "staggering changes" in this country today.
MOST young boys look forward eagerly to receiving their first pocketknife. Like other milestones in the process of growing up, many boys consider the possession of one an important step.

TENAFLY, N.J., June 24 -- LaJunta White of Englewood and Michael Cestone of Forsgate won the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day mixed foursome tournament over the Knickerbocker Country Club course today.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman announced yesterday that he would accept the belated offer by party leaders of a place as a delegate at large to the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles next month.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 24 -- The second annual Newport Folk Festival got under way tonight with a program that marked a bold, but generally successful, departure.

Houston Fearless Corp. The acquisition of Marchetti Associates, Boston, electronics research and engineering company, by the Houston Fearless Corporation was announced yesterday by Noah Dietrich, chairman of the Los Angeles company.
An issue of $19,800,000 of serial bonds of the District of Columbia Armory Board will be offered for sale on July 7. The bonds will come due froin 1970 to 1979.
DETROIT, June 24 (AP) -- Jim Bunning pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 4-0 victory over the Washington Senators tonight, yielding only three singles.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 24 -- Boston University's amazing high jumper, John Thomas, raised the world record to 7 feet 2 inches tonight under highly dramatic circumstances at the Amateur Athletic Union's seventy-second annual national track and field championships.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare announced the appointment today of an eight-man board of physicians to review the decisions of Dr. Henry A. Welch.
Efforts of the National Mediation Board to head off a strike of 1,350 Long Island Rail Road trainmen collapsed yesterday.

CARLETON MITCHELL achieved pre-eminence in salt-water yacht racing after a tortuous passage that began in New Orleans and foundered briefly in the underwear department of Macy's. He reached a temporary port-of-call yesterday when he won the Newport-to-Bermuda race for the third straight time.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Domestic manufacturers of jet transports are losing money on every plane they deliver, an industry spokesman said today. Unless they can make additions sales, he said, the builders of jet transports would cost so never break even. Presumably, then, they must depend on other products to cover losses sustained in jet-plane production.
MEXICO CITY, June 24 -- The Mexican Government has no immediate interest in gaining control of the foreign-owned Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., it was said last night.
"Look at 'em out there. You don't see as many people around the paddock at a stakes race."
DUBLIN, June 24 -- Sam Snead came to the rescue as Arnold Palmer faltered and the United States went out in front today at the halfway mark in the 72-hole Canada Cup golf tournament.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 24 -- The Soviet Union has offered to supply all the gasoline, kerosene and fuel oil that Ceylon needs at 10 to 20 per cent below ruling world prices.

Security is playing an increasingly important role in the security business. More and more brokerage houses are putting added emphasis on internal safeguards to protect their customers' financial interests as well as their own from theft, loss or manipulation.

LE MANS, France, June 24 -- On the eve of the world famous twenty-four-hour endurance race for sports cars and less than a week after the Grand Prix of Belgium in which two drivers were killed and two others hospitalized, the talk today inevitably was of accidents and the need for safety measures.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Consumer Price Index rose again in May to another peak.
The Brooklyn medical center for longshoremen and their dependents handled 20,000 more patients in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, 1959, than it did in the previous year.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Senate-House conferees rejected today two proposals to increase Federal revenue. The group struck out provisions for ending tax advantages on dividend income and restricting business entertainment allowances.

PANAMA, June 24 -- The Panamanian secret police have seized a shipment of eighteen packages air-freighted from Havana for the Cuban Embassy here and say that one they opened contained Communist propaganda.
Floyd Patterson took the heavyweight championship back to public school 614 yesterday.

The United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer, drew with Laszlo Szabo of Hungary yesterday after twenty-three moves of a Kink's Indian defense in the second round of a chess masters' tournament in Buenos Aires, according to a report from South America.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 24 -- The Government was reported today to have "advised" the anti-Communist Democratic League to disband or face official action.
OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 24 -- Three authorities on urban planning praised tonight a proposed development of luxury homes to be built in clusters on the old Whitney estate here.
The attack on President Romulo Betancourt yesterday followed a long tradition of violence in Venezuelan political life.
GENEVA, June 24 -- The United States has prepared revised disarmament proposals giving cautious emphasis to the step-by-step elimination of the vehicles of delivery of nuclear weapons.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 24 -- Sybil Wolfenshon of the Engineers Country Club won first prize with 40 points in the Women's Cross County Golf Association's tournament at the Brookville Country Club today. She posted a 36, 40 -- 76 for lowgross honors.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, June 23 -- Reports that there might be a conflict between the Dutch and Indonesian military forces in New Guinea have failed to ruffle the tranquillity of this green, rainswept little capital of Dutch New Guinea.
HONOLULU, Junk 24 -- President Eisenhower will return to Washington Sunday.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Bob Shaw posted his first victory in three weeks as the Chicago White Sox downed the Boston Red Sox, 2 -- 1, tonight, before 29,320 fans.
Prices of United States Govrnment bonds eased generally by 2/32 to 4/32 in an inactive trading session yesterday. For the week, most prime-risk debt securities lost ground slightly.

Bausch Lomb Stockholders of Bausch Lomb, Inc., at a special meeting held yesterday in Rochester N.Y., approved a new issue of not more than $7,225,000 subordinated debentures. The debentures are to be offered to stockholders on the basis of $100 of debentures for each thirteen shares of stock held.
THE PRESIDENT In Hawaii; announced he would make TV address to the nation on Far Eastern trip on Monday.

Parents will be able to borrow $1,500 to $10,000 at 6 per cent simple annual interest to help finance a college education for each of their children under a model student loan program adopted by the New York State Bankers Association.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson will go to the Democratic National Convention with at least 502 first-ballot votes, according to a report compiled by his campaign managers.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined by 1 to 8 points (5 to 40 cents a bale) yesterday.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 24 -- The conference of independent African states unanimously called on its members tonight to invoke strong trade sanctions against the Union of South Africa and urged that diplomatic relations be either severed or withheld.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24 -- It was a case of the old men beating the boys in the yacht race from Newport today. That was the way Henry K. (Bunny) Rigg, a member of the winning crew, wrapped up the remarkable third successive corrected-time victory for Finisterre in the 635-mile ocean classic.

WASHINGTON -- One of the greatest surprises and advances in international travel in the post-war era, has been the changes wrought in the Passport Office of the United States. This unit of the State Department had slumbered in bureaucratic style through the ages, and it continued to operate at the traditional governmental pace even when post-war tourists began multiplying their numbers and the miles they were covering.
OSLO, Norway, June 25 -- Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange rebuked Anastas I. Mikoyan today for having attacked Norway's friend, the United States, while he was a guest of the Norwegian Government.
HONG KONG, June 25 -- Communist China marked today the tenth anniversary of the start of the Korean War with a restatement of its "hard" ideological line in strong terms.

DETROIT, June 25 (UPI) -- Miss Thriftway of Seattle finished far in front in the final heat today to win the fourteenth annual Detroit memorial power boat race by 300 points. She scored a total of 1,200.

WIMBLEDON, June 25 -- Barry (The Bear) MacKay and Earl (Butch) Buchholz, America's one-two punch, reached the men's singles quarter-finals of the All-England lawn tennis championship at Wimbledon today.
One of the largest international maritime unions has broken with the traditional election procedure in which top officials are elected by delegates, rather than by the members.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 25 -- Representatives of a score of African states, either independent or hoping soon to be, have labored for solidarity here for the past two weeks. But they disclosed by their deliberations that unity, like independence, entails growing pains.

While Detroit is busy selling compact cars that are designed to give more miles a gallon of gasoline, officials of some states are scratching their heads wondering if it is really true. If it is true, they wonder, will gasoline tax receipts decline, or will more motorists be driving two cars farther than they used to drive one?

GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, Mont., June 25 -- A sharp behind-the-scenes political struggle between Senators John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson developed today as Democratic Governors began to arrive for the fifty-second annual Governors Conference.

Competition in the second section of the International Soccer League will begin at the Polo Grounds Saturday with the Red Star team of Yugoslavia meeting Rapid Vienna. The game, which will start at 8:30 P.M., will be preceded by an exhibition contest.

A steady wind of thirty to forty miles an hour over Long Island Sound, with puffs up to fifty, cut yesterday's Yacht Racing Association regatta to nine starters and three finishers. But this, the smallest fleet sent on Y.R.A. races in years, provided one of the most exciting finishes in a long while and a show of fine seamanship by the crew of Sam Barton's International, Aries.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 -- San Francisco has just been convicted in a study by its Council for Civic Unity as a city where racial discrimination is still the practice in housing.
PARIS, June 25 -- Scientists from ten European countries are searching for a formula to pool Europe's talent and resources to enter into an exploration of space.

The Men, the Issues Lord Bryce remarked of American politics that "the Presidential election throws the country for several months into a state of turmoil." At the same time, he said, it "forces everyone not merely to think about public affairs but to decide how he judges the parties." With the first convention fifteen days off, the turmoil is increasing and the judging -- of men and issues -- growing sterner.
The smoking tobacco industry, which depends on pipe smokers for its revenues, has emerged from the doldrums which existed three years ago. It is enjoying one of its most successful years.

Testimony on Jack The trial of Hulan E. Jack, Manhattan Borough President, began in the Court of General Sessions seventeen days ago. He is charged with having violated the City Charter by accepting 54,400 from Sidney J. Ungar, a lawyer and real estate operator, and with conspiracy to conceal the transaction. The $4,400 went for remodeling the Jack apartment.

More than 500 youths competed in a two-hour written examination yesterday for 250 training jobs with the Police Department under a new cadet corps programs. The test was held at the Baruch School of Business and Public Administration, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

When Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the Boston and Maine Railroad, walks into his office in Boston's North Station next Friday, the date stating at him from his desk calendar pad should evoke both a shudder and a sigh of relief.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- There has been a lot of back-stairs chatter about the Vice-Presidential candidates in the last few days and the trend is now running definitely to Senator Hubert Humphrey on the Democratic side and Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge on the Republican.

When S.S. Rajah -- an Indian exporter from New Delhi -- announced last week that he was tearing down Manhattan's last stable for dray horses to build an apartment house, he also came up with some interesting ideas on what an apartment building should be.
ABOARD THE YACHT MINOTS LIGHT, Hamilton, Bermuda, June 25 -- The slowest race in the 54-year-history of the Newport-to-Bermuda yachting event it surely has been, but certainly not the dullest.

BASEBALL With left-handed Diek Stigman limiting them to four singles and striking out ten, the American League's pace-setting New York Yankees were beaten by the Indians at Cleveland yesterday, 4 to 1.

TOKYO, June 25 -- Osaka policemen were pelted with rocks and stabbed with poles when they tried to control one of several demonstrations, held in Japan today to protest against the new security treaty with the United States. At least seventy-two policemen were injured.
LONDON, June 25 (Reuters) -- Great pace bowling by Brian Statham and Alan Moss wrecked South Africa's chances today in the second cricket test against England at Lord's.

Manufacturers of glass bottles are staging a major campaign to win back the beer packaging markets they have lost to metal cans in recent years. Their weapon is a light-weight no-deposit bottle that can be thrown away after use instead of being returned to the store where it was purchased.
Two burglars, operating with speed, daring and precision, stole $30,000 worth of engagement rings early yesterday from a small display window of Cartier's, on Fifth Avenue at Fifty-second Street.
RALEIGH, N.C:, June 25 (AP) -- Terry Sanford, who espoused North Carolina's middle-of-the-road approach to school integration, won the Democratic nomination for Governor today in a run-off primary.
A crosstown bus jogs along the Lower East Side on a warm summer evening. Neighbors lounge around outside, chatting.

THE study of world politics, like everything else, has become the preserve of the specialist. This is a matter of concern not only to the general reader, who must now turn to a bewildering multitude of monographs for guidance and illumination.

EXCEPT for the fact that each was an outstanding Dodger pitcher, there would seem to be little that Carl Erskine and Preacher Roe had in common. Erskine was the polished and aristocratic gentleman from Indiana. The Preach was a hillbilly from Arkansas, who pretended to be much more of an unlettered yokel than he was.
A wonder horse of his generation, the Italian-bred Ribot, was paraded before the grandstand between the third and fourth races at Belmont Park yesterday.
Investor-owned electric and gas utilities are heading into another peak year as many other industries cope with falling sales, production cuts and lay-offs.

STANTON, Del., June 25 (AP) -- Glad, a 2-year-old filly who does her best running in the stretch, turned in a typical effort at Delaware Park today and defeated thirteen others of her age in the twenty-third and richest running of the Polly Drummond Stakes.

VIGNETTE and colors of another United States stamp -- the 4-cent stamp to commemorate the centenary of the founding of the Boys' Clubs of America Movement -- were announced yesterday by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.

TOKYO, June 25 -- Recent disorders in Tokyo, centering on the new United States-Japan mutual security treaty, have called attention to the growth of "neutralism" in a country that has heretofore been counted as a stanch member of the Western alliance.
Profit-sharing programs took the lead in new retirement plans in the first quarter of 1960, filings with the Internal Revenue Service indicated.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- An adamant Administration letter caused irritation among House and Senate conferees today as they met to compromise Congressional differences over defense appropriations.
PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- The first-place Pittsburgh Pirates resorted to second-line pitching today and squeezed past the last-place Chicago Cubs, 7 -- 6, before 20,428 fans.
CINCINNATI, June 25 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants made it two in a row over Cincinnati today by winning, 5 -- 2. Billy O'Dell scattered ten hits for his third success against seven defeats.
The cast of characters in the merged melodrama among the Eastern railroads was enlarged last week.

Since the night in 1871 when Mrs. O'Leary's cow kicked over the lantern that set most of Chicago ablaze, city fathers in virtually all American communities have assumed responsibility, in the form of building codes, for the disaster-proof construction of new structures.

Soviet authorities have dashed United States hopes for an expanded exchange of graduate students. In a seeming reversal of policy, Russian negotiators have used delaying tactics to a point that now makes it certain that this year's program will, at best, be substantially reduced.
A group of French and American students seemed to be agreed yesterday that the Paris summit conference never had a chance to succeed because neither side had been prepared to budge from its position.

IN this novel about the mores, myths, ethnological origins, racial clashes and stately ambitions of Hawaii, Peter Gilman provides tailored reading for people who regard fiction as a waste of time. Relying upon his post-war experience as Associated Press man on the South Pacific beat, the author in this first novel gives us an anthology of fact, fiction and good human interest stuff about an island Eden he knows well.
Evidence early this year that a new economic surge was beginning in major world areas is being more than confirmed by official and private reports from abroad.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- This was the week in which the United States Government Jettisoned the last vestige of its policy of "patience and forbearance" with the Cuban Revolutionary Government of Premier Fidel Castro.
British industrial concerns are going ahead with the commercial development of the hovercraft, a vehicle that resembles a flying saucer and travels on a cushion of air.

IT was a happy thought to stage "The Tempest" again in the lordly playhouse at Stratford, Conn. In 1955, before anyone understood the stage in the new building, "The Tempest" was put on as the second production by a hastily assembled troupe that included Raymond Massey, Christopher Plummer, Fritz Weaver, Earle Hyman and Jack Palance.
The plunge of an elderly Long Island man beneath a subway train here early yesterday led to the discovery that his wife had been beaten to death a few hours previously.
People looking for an advance show of Fourth of July fireworks next Friday when the new Omnibus Banking Law goes into effect in New York State seem likely to be disappointed.
MEXICO CITY, June 25 -- Two political leaders, in major policy speeches yesterday, defined Mexico's ideological position as "revolutionary" and "moderately Left."

TO THE EDITOR: I remember, as a child, thinking that the medicine which stung most obviously did the most good. Mr. Williams has built a reputation and a followingbased on that fallacious principle: that the moat violent, ugly and perverse is closest to the truth.
Because some parents repeatedly insisted on applauding their children, commencement exercises at a Bayside, Queens, junior high school were abruptly halted on Friday.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 25 -- The Olympic-conscious athletes of the United States continued their record-breaking spree in tonight's concluding session of the Amateur Athletic Union's severity-second annual track and field championships.

THE annual Emmy prizes of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences were symptomatic of the present state of video. There were a few awards that had some genuine relationship to quality; there were others that merely underscored the pitiful lack of contention in many programing areas.

LE MANS, France, Sunday, June 26 -- Oliver Gundebien and Paul Frere of Belgium, driving a twelvecylinder Ferrari, held a slight lead after twelve hours of the rain-drenched Le Mans twenty-four-hour endurance race today.

LONDON, June 25 -- The British labor movement has begun to move slowly but unmistakably toward a position that excludes nuclear weapons and considers neutralism and pacifism as practical policies. This change is of utmost importance to the future course of British politics and, in certain conditions, to the alliance between the United States and the United Kingdom.

BUENOS AIRES, June 25 -- While President Arturo Frondizi travels in Europe receiving official honors and urging investors to put their capital into Argentina, a plan to overthrow the President is being fomented in the army.
GENEVA, June 25 -- The Western powers began trying to build a united front today to meet a Soviet political offensive in the disarmament negotiations.

WHEN an event takes place, often its occurrence can be traced to the initial enthusiasm of a single man. This will be the case next month when Janacek's "Katia Kabanova" is given at the Empire State Festival at Harriman State Park near Bear Mountain.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 25 -- A twin drive on a global scale to recruit youth for Christian work was started here today as part of a five-day youth congress of the Seventh-day Adventist Church.
A fire broke out early today in the IND subway line downtown, disrupting express service on the West Side for more than an hour.
PARIS, June 25 -- Three rebel representatives in well-cut business suits walked from an airplane at Orly Field here today bearing the hope of peace in Algria.

A small man with a big smile, tireless, energy and a sense of humor, David W. Harris has just completed fifteen years as top man at the Universal Oil Products Company. In turn, that concern has recently completed its first year as a publicly held company after a hectic private life.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 25 (AP) -- Navy men searched the upper reaches of Guanabara Bay today for victims and wreckage of a Brazilian airliner that plunged into the fog-shrouded water last night as it came in for a landing.
The complete integration of indoor and outdoor living has been achieved in the design of a house built recently in the tropical setting of a Caribbean hillside overlooking the sea.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo. IN some of the most primitive villages of the Congo, in the remote mountains of Kivu province, white visitors are greeted with the shrill chant, "In-de-pen-DANCE! In-de-penDANCE!" Virtually every Congolese is impatiently awaiting next Thursday, when Belgium will grant this African colony its independence.

By now, nearly every pleasure boat in the nation has been scrubbed, painted, varnished, overhauled, pampered, petted and has gone down the railways or been lowered by other launching devices to take their places among the flotillas for a summer of vacationing fun.
LOS ANGELES, June 25 -- The Air Force is setting up a new agency to manage the engineering, research and development aspects of its missile and space programs.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- California's rich valleys are being looked upon as a testing ground for a new organizing drive among the nation's domestic farm workers.

STOCKBRIDGE, MASS. NAUMKEAG is a garden of many gardens tucked in the Berkshire hillsides of Stockbridge, Mass. It will be open to the public starting Friday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and daily thereafter, except on Mondays, during the summer months.

Inside Japan For nearly a month, Japan has been the scene of massive demonstrations and protest strikes aimed at defeating the country's new security treaty with the United States. Demonstrations continued after the pact went into effect last week, but the tension in Tokyo appeared to have relaxed considerably.

FOR more than seventy-eight years Helen Keller, who reaches her eightieth birthday tomorrow, has heard no sound and seen no ray of light. She knows the human voice, the echo of music, the singing of birds, the faces of people and of nature only as a child one and a half years old, or as she is aware of them by touch or smell.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 25 -- The social season here will gain momentum tomorrow when the first of two horse shows to benefit the Parrish Museum will be held on the newly set up horse-show grounds of the Stanley Howard estate overlooking North Sea Harbor.

A small-scale venture in international financial cooperation linking a New York union and a tiny African village will enable two young members of the Kikuyu tribe in Kenya to take advantage of scholarships offered by American schools.
ST. PAUL, June 25 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People approved "without reservation" today the intent and method of the student sit-in-Movement.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 25 -- Beverly Kantor of the Fox Hills Farms Stables in Pleasantville won the hunter-seat horsemanship championship for local-area riders today during the first day of the fourteenth annual Sleepy Hollow Country Club horse show.
THE old proverb, "A stitch in time saves nine," certainly applies to summer pruning. A little pinch here, and a little snip there will keep many a shrub and evergreen from getting out of bounds.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 25 -- A third year of integration will begin this fall at Little Rock public schools. About a dozen Negroes, perhaps a few more, will be enrolled in formerly all-white schools.
Three rabbis, in sermons here yesterday, commended Mayor Wagner for refusing to grant a permit for an American Nazi party rally in Union Square on July 4.

EAST, west, home's best. That's what the philosopher said, and it is particularly so for a movie critic when he can come home to a batch of interesting films. Such was the good fortune of this peregrinating scribe, back to a summer-bound Manhattan after a fascinating journey abroad.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 25 -- Premier Khrushchev declared today that the Communist world had fought and would continue to fight for a lessening of world tension, peaceful coexistence and an end of the "cold war."

CHANTILLY, France, June 25 (UPI) -- Johnny Dawson, a 57-year-old California real estate broker, won two matches easily today and advanced to the final of the French amateur golf tournament. He will meet the perennial champion, Henri de Lamaze of France, for the title tomorrow in a thirty-six-hole match.
Advertising people faced with a difficult problem have a tendency, along with most other members of the human race, to go away and hide.

FOR THIS WEEK: Perennials, lawns, roses and annuals may require a supplemental feeding where rain has leached soil nutrients. . . . Use great caution when spraying weedkillers around shrubbery and terrace walks. . . . Pinch chrysanthemum plants at the tips if it has not been done to force branching. . . .

IN 1946 a highly amusing novel called "The Pursuit of Love" was published here and introduced its readers to a large and eccentric English family named Radlett. The Radletts were understood to be pretty much draws from life: that is, from the upbringing of their author, Nancy Mitford.

CARLO CASSOLA is recognized in Italy as the still, small voice of the intellectually hostile generation that grew to manhood during fascism. Like Vittorini and Pavese, his masters and seniors in the postwar neo-realist movement, Cassola roots his works in understatement.

Tests and procedures used by American colleges to choose students were assailed yesterday by a group of educators as undemocratic and discriminatory. The charges were made in a report that also found that, contrary to the general assumption, more top students dropped out of college than did not go to college.

HARGEISA, Somaliland, Sunday, June 26 (Reuters) -- Crowds danced in the streets here, bonfires blazed from the hills and fireworks burst in the sky as last midnight spelled the end of Britain's rule in Somaliland.

CLEVELAND, June 25 -- With Jimmy Piersall limiting his histrionics to one spectacular catch in the outfield, the Indians concentrated on baseball and turned back the Yankees, 4-1, before a Ladies' Day crowd of 40,038 at Municipal Stadium today.

THIS long novel can be described briefly as a kind of "West Side Story" transposed to the environs of Coney Island. The comparison is warranted not because George Mandel's novel is derivative -- it deals with a group of Jewish youths, and a family, the Rakusins, during the Nineteen Thirties -- but because his characters give the impression of dancing put their roles in a ballet.

ROME, June 25 -- Italy's $40,000,000 airport at Fiumicino is rapidly nearing completion. The Ministry of Public Works hopes to have it ready for use by the end of July. Italy is expecting a big influx for the Olympic Games late in August.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Business activity at the midyear is at record levels in many important respects, but the records are not up to expectations and there are significant areas of weakness.

WASHINGTON, D.C. -- Could there be something symbolic in the fact that Washington's favorite picnic area is a spectacular place of turbulence and ceaseless activity, instead of the sort of placid greensward so often associated with pastoral dining?

IN the summer of 1864 a 19-year-old orphan named James K.P. Miller absconded with $3,500 of his guardian's money and, under the alias of J. Sidney Osborn, went west to Salt Lake City. There he operated cigar and book stands.

TELEVISION Westerns have come under new attack from the old frontier foe of the cowboys -- the Indians. This time, however, the Indians are up in arms over video portrayals that depict them as ruthless savages intent only on plunder and atrocity.

ROWE, Mass., June 25 -- During the first two weeks in July the Yankee Atomic Electric Company plans to start loading fuel elements into the reactor of its new $50,000,000 nuclear power plant on the Deerfield River.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 25 -- Stephen Bayne, the 17-year-old Westbury High School student who rejected an American Legion post citizenship award because he did not "respect" the Legion policies, will not attend his graduation exercises tomorrow.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- This historic New England seaport's old multimillion-dollar mansions are playing a modern part in the revival of Newport's former glory. They are marble palaces in which the rich lived like royalty.

A RECENT debate in these pages between critic Marya Mannes and playwright Tennessee Williams on the state of the American theatre has provoked heated debate among readers. Miss Mannea led off (May 29) with the charge that, at too many plays during the recent theatre season, the audience had been "harrowed, shocked or simply mesmerized by very unpleasant characters doing very unpleasant things and using very unpleasant language."

ONCE again, the issue of foreign economic aid has been the center of stormy debate. The money issue hats been settled for the present, but the basic fault has not been corrected. As they have been year after year, the arguments on both sides are based upon a single major premise -- namely, that the primary purpose of aiding under-developed countries is to win friends and allies in return.
SAN DIEGO, June 25 -- A new era of cooperation in the education of teachers appears to be developing between two factions that have fussed and feuded for more than half a century.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Quiz Star, owned by the Harbor View Farm, took the lead in midstretch and drove to a length-and-a-quarter victory in the $28,875 Grassland Handicap at Washington Park today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The political tension in Japan has recently attained its peak, according to the press, radio and television. But I feel that most of the daily reports do not furnish the true situation from the Japanese point of view.

First, the traveling public was caught in a feud involving the pilot inspection issue, a fight that the airline pilots and their union have been waging against the Federal Government in the shape of Gen. E.R. Quesada, head of the Federal Aviation Agency.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 25 -- A mob fight in one section of the African quarter here revealed today the discontent of supporters of Jean Bolikango, who lost last night to Joseph Kasavubu in a contest for Chief of State.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Willis Conover, who conceives, researches, writes, programs, produces and announces the Voice of America's only daily musical program, has just returned from a visit to some of his thirty million fans.

CHICAGO, June 25 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox rallied to tie the score twice today and then beat the Boston Red Sox 7 -- 6 in the twelfth inning when Joe Ginsberg scored from third on Tom Sturdivant's wild pitch.

At the beginning of this month the privately owned merchant fleet under the United States flag totaled 1,010 vessels of 13,934,493 deadweight tons, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported last week.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 25 -- Business men are in conflict with the Board of Education here over whether the local tax base should be broadened for schools. A public hearing on the measure will be held Wednesday night.

PROGRESS REPORT -- The half-way point in the four-year life of the National Defense Education Act of 1958 was marked last week with a report on the present status of its provisions. Out of the total $1 billion authorized by the act, Congress has so far appropriated more than $275 million.

A SINGLE-LENS reflex camera that uses No. 127 film for twelve super-slide (1 5/8x1 5/8-inch) pictures has been introduced to the American market by Ideax Corporation, 150 Fifth Avenue. It is the Japanese-made Komaflex-S, the first and only camera in its design class.
To help apartment seekers determine the quality of the suites they inspect, a leading apartment house builder has drawn up a brief checklist of items to look for.
FRANKFORT, Ky., June 25 -- Kentuckians will begin paying a type of tax next Friday that was abandoned in 1936 after a year and a half of trial.

AT midnight Thursday, when Actors Equity run-of-the-play contracts expire, the New York theatre season of 1959-60 will draw to a conclusion. THE gardener who spends a lot of time weeding and watering has probably not discovered mulching, the practice of covering the soil around plants to conserve moisture and prevent weed growth. Organic materials are most widely used.

NO other or the twenty-one republics of the Western Hemisphere has a more superficial resemblance to the United States than does Argentina, the most southerly of our neighbors. LOS ANGELES -- Twentyseven miles offshore from Los Angeles, the island of Santa Catalina rises precipitously out of the Pacific. JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 25 -- President Sukarno today installed his hand-picked Parliament despite sharp opposition from various anti-Communist, Moslem and other political forces in Indonesia.
