The New York State Bar Association charged yesterday that the state's fight against alcoholism "has fizzled almost to collapse."
Sidney J. Ungar testified yesterday that he had not received any interest on the $4,400 loan he has said he made to Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan for remodeling Mr. Jack's apartment.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 27 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion told Israelis today that in his meetings with President de Gaulle in Paris he had "definitely found a common language regarding world problems and Israel's special needs."

BALTIMORE, June 27 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators scored three unearned runs in the tenth inning and defeated Baltimore, 5-2, tonight, knocking the Orioles out of first place in the American League.

A book about "the vast and burgeoning volume of dishonest dealing in the United States" will be published July 20 by Harper. Called "The Operators," it is the work of Frank Gibney, a Life Magazine staff writer.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., June 27 -- Lenny Marinello of Brookville and Joe Watrous of Nassau County posted a 64 today and tied Bob White and Pete Cassella of Brookville for honors in a Long Island Professional Golfers Association tournament at the Middle Bay Country Club.
GENEVA, June 27 -- The Soviet Union broke up the East-West disarmament negotiations today.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Supreme Court, dividing 5 to 4 held today that Federal courts might not admit evidence seized by state officers in violation of the Constitution.
Thousands of retailers milled through home furnishing showrooms yesterday to see new lines of merchandise for fall. Buying was described as surprisingly good for an opening day.
MOSCOW, June 27 -- Soviet Communists were scolded again today for the continuing ineffectiveness of their indoctrination of the Soviet people.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In your editorial "Freedom of Speech" (June 23) you object to Mayor Wagner's refusal to grant George Lincoln Rockwell, leader of the American Nazi party, a permit to speak at a Fourth of July rally in Union Square. The ambiguities of your argument discredit the validity of the editorial.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 27 -- Soviet Ambassador Vladimir Georgiyevich Yakovlev failed to answer a summons to the Ceylonese Foreign Ministry today.
The Park and Police Departments have started cracking down on people who lay out newspapers to keep dry or avoid grass stains while sitting in Central Park.

THE fiftieth state is busily at work cutting and stitching popular native fashions for export to the mainland. The latest shipment to arrive from Hawaii is a group of sun-drenched tropical prints in polished cotton at the Penthouse Gallery, 15 West Fifty-fifth Street.
Trees will prove a better longterm investment than tenants on valuable land in midtown Manhattan, James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
Rumors last week that the Beneficial Finance Company was negotiating to buy almost half the common stock of the Western Auto Supply Company yesterday were translated into reality.
Eugene Ionesco, the Rumanian-born French writer whose avant-garde plays have made him one of Europe's most controversial literary figures, is fashioning a musical for Broadway.
YONKERS, June 27 -- Billy Haughton will drive Caduceus the New Zealand pacer, in Thursday night's $25,000 International Encore at Yonkers Raceway.

BONN, Germany, June 27 -- Finance Minister Franz Etzel opens this week a budget battle that wia have a considerable influence on West Germany's efforts to control inflation at home and to expand its economic aid programs abroad.

Securities of Montgomery Ward Credit Corporation valued at $50,000,000 were offered to the public yesterday by Lehman Brothers and associated underwriters. The credit concern was organized last February to finance deferred payment accounts of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., the Chicago retail store operator and mail-order merchandiser.
Two ninety-minute concerts by the New York Philharmonic; with Leonard Bernstein conducting, will be televised next season over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
HAVANA, June 27 -- The Cuban Government began an investigation today into the cause of the explosion of an army ammunition dump at Cayo Cruz, in Havana Harbor.

It was a day of waiting yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange -- waiting for a signal that might cause stocks to go up or down. So, stocks marked time until the signal finally came about 3 P.M. when the American Iron and Steel Institue issued its steel production estimate for this week.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have read with some interest the letter of James M. Landis commenting on your editorial of June 21 "F.A.A. and the Pilots."

The Consumer Price Index of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics moved into all-time high ground again in May. Contrasted with the jump of a full half of a percentage point in April, the May increase of one-tenth of a point was nominal. However, it represents the fourth consecutive monthly advance this year and the eleventh in the past fourteen months.

PARIS THE are world is flourishing in Paris this summer. To begin with, there are now almost 300 art galleries, as opposed to half that number three years ago. And each gallery is trying furiously to expose to the public as much as possible, as often as possible and with as much publicity as possible.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review the conviction of Bernard Goldfine and his secretary for contempt of court in their failure to produce records for income tax investigators.

The Berkshire Farm for Boys will benefit from the Nov.-29 performance of "The Unsinkable Molly Brown." The new Meredith Willson-Richard Morris musical is scheduled to open at the Broadway Theatre on Nov. 3.
THE following dinner menu is given as a, guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe ia suggested for an easily prepared main dish.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The State Department reacted with official denunciations and unofficial surprise and mystification today to the abrupt Soviet withdrawal from the Geneva disarmament talks.
The state's Security Risk Law, which allows summary dismissals or disqualifications of Civil Service employes or applicants in so-called "security agencies," will expire Thursday.
Many economists espouse the theory that inflation is not a dangerous thing. In fact, they assert, economic growth need some inflation as a spur.

The installation of what is believed to be the largest non-government electronic data processing system under one roof reached the half-way mark yesterday with the commissioning of an RCA 501 at the home office of the New York Life Insurance Company, 51 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor charged in testimony made public tonight that the National Security Council had failed to settle defense policy questions that were "crying for decision" when he was Army Chief of Staff.
GENEVA, June 27 -- "This is a scandal!" shouted the French delegate. "It is hooliganism!"
GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, June 27 -- Prime Minister John G. Diefenbaker of Canada urge tonight a wider sharing of leadership among free Western nations to combat Communist divisive tactics.
GARFIELD, N.J., June 27 -- Four employes were burned today in a flash fire and explosion at Faulkner Associated Industries, an aluminum extruding plant at 158 Belmont Avenue.
ROME, June 27 -- The Italian Government is considering legislation to aid the nation's depressed shipbuilding industry.

An intensified campaign to reduce the number of fires on subway and elevated lines was announced jointly yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. and Charles L. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority.

MANILA, June 27 -- At least 100 persons were reported dead and hundreds missing after a typhoon slashed across the island of Luzon today. It was the Philippines' second major weather disaster in a month.

The congestion of court calendars in New York City has been a chronic condition persisting so long as to be a disgrace, reflecting on judges, lawyers, the State Legislature, Congress and the public for tolerating it. Various measures of legislative relief are in prospect, through creation of more judgeships, through constitutional revision of the court system.

THE Dodgers obviously did not shed their affinity for the bizarre just because they deserted. Brooklyn for the gold and glitter of Los.Angeles. They brought their screwball tendencies with them and this flair for the unusual has given them the blind staggers this season. The once-proud champions of the world staggered into town yesterday for their sandlot benefit game with the Yankees as a laggard, sixth-place team.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- The cruelest of misfortune and the superfine Italian hand of Nicola Pietrangeli eliminated the United States's last two representatives from the men's singles today in the tennis championship at Wimbledon.

The United States champion, Bobby Fischer, and Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia adjourned after forty-one moves last night in the fourth round of the international chess masters' tournament in Buenos Aires, according to a report from Argentina.

A 75-year-old matron clad in white, whose appearance belies her age, announced with a soft smile yesterday that she would doff her nurse's cap Friday for the last time in a career that spanned fifty-three years, forty-two of them on the staff of the Roosevelt Hospital.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- By a 4-to-4 vote, the Supreme Court today upheld an ordinance in Dayton, Ohio, requiring home owners to admit housing inspectors without search warrants. Justice Potter Stewart disqualified himself from the case because of his former connection with Ohio.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate adopted today a resolution that would allow radio and television networks to give free broadcast time to major party Presidential candidates in 1960.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- George Lincoln Rockwell, self-styled leader of the American Nazi party, said today he had called off plans to speak in New York on July 4.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., June 27 (AP) -- Dick Drott pitched seven innings of no-hit ball today in a 5-0 victory by the Chicago Cubs over the Cleveland Indians in the nineteenth annual Hall of Frame game. The Indians got two hits off Moe Drabowsky, who pitched the eighth and ninth.

Following is the text of a communique on a meeting of representatives of the Soviet bloc countries held in Bucharest, Rumania, during the congress of the Rumanian Workers (Communist) party there last week, as issued here yesterday by Tass, the Soviet press agency:
GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, Mont., June 27 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts appealed directly today to every Southern Democratic convention delegate to support his nomination for President.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. June 27 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that the debate on international disarmament be resumed at the 1960 session of the General Assembly, which is scheduled to open Sept. 20.
GENEVA, June 27 -- United States officials hurriedly scratched the word "secret" today from copies of a carefully guarded document and put before the world the plan the Communists had refused to see.
The Waterfront Commission will begin studying today the 1,132 pages of testimony recorded during the five-day hearing on crime on the New York-New Jersey docks.
Bus service on Madison and Lexington Avenues and on four crosstown routes was halted last night when drivers of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company staged a wildcat walkout.

HELENA, Mont. June 27 -- Montana Democrats elected a seventeen-vote uninstructed delegation to the national convention today. A majority of the delegates plan to vote for Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts for President.
In the last three and a half months a man accused of having struck a policeman has been shifted five times between Bellevue Hospital and Felony Court. No immediate end to the cycle is in sight.
A perspiring Mayor Wagner got an earful of complaints from a throng of equally sticky citizens yesterday in a place famous for talkers and thinkers on the body politic -- Greenwich Village.

ROME, June 27 -- With less than two months separating Rome from the Olympic Games, city officials finally have decided on certain heroic measures which may avoid the colossal traffic jam many persons expect.

LONDON, June 27 -- The Soviet Union leveled a sharp personal attack on David OrmsbyGore, Minister of State in the Foreign Office, in a letter from Premier Khrushchev delivered to Britain today. Mr. Khrushchev also sent letters to other Western Governments blaming the West for the deadlock at the disrupted disarmament talks in Geneva.

FIVE young musicians who have won high awards in major musical contests were honored, by the city, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Three of them appeared there " as soloists, and, in an intermission ceremony all five received bronze medals from Mayor Wagner.
Helen Keller, who has devoted much of her life to helping the blind; spent her eightieth birthday yesterday honoring a fellow worker in the same cause. He is Col. Edwin A. Baker of Toronto.

NEW HAVEN, June 27 -- The controller of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad ascribed the road's plight today to an "overpowering loss" in passenger revenue rather than to the decline in freight traffic.
All world sugar positions fell to new lows for the lives of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. All traded months ended lower and prices closed at the lows of the day.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Productivity in private industry -- the output per man per hour-increased by more than 4 per cent last year. Preliminary estimates indicate it is not doing that well this year.

None of the Communist delegations attended a brief ceremony held at the United Nations headquarters in this city yesterday afternoon commemorating the tenth anniversary of the U.N. intervention in Korea. Representatives of sixteen nations, including our own, whose soldiers had fought under the U.N. flag in Korea were invited.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- A trend toward newspaper consolidation was deplored today by Arthur Rosenstock, president of the American Newspaper Guild.
Prices slipped a little in the bond market yesterday in an inactive trading session.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 27 (UPI) -- The Chapel Hill School Board assigned three Negro first graders to white schools tonight. The assignments, will take effect in the fall.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Supreme Court will decide next term whether Federal courts may enjoin state officials from using wiretap evidence in state trials.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The dictionary has a word to describe the effect on Southern Democrats in Congress of the mounting rumors that Senator Kennedy prefers Hubert H. Humphrey, his Minnesota colleague, as his runningmate. The word is consternation.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Power Commission could authorize sales of natural gas without time limit even though the contracting parties sought a permit for a specified period only.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 27 -- Thomas F. Scholl of Glen Cove and his son, Tommy, were the first to play the Garden City Golf Club course today. They did so well they won the Father and Son Golf Association championship with a net score of 68.

WHAT is the longest historical novel in the English language? Well, after bowing affably to other worthy contenders, we may say with prudent confidence that it is P.G. Wodehouse's saga of the gaga, the unending ripping, tripping, gripping story of that young-man-about-London, Bertie Wooster, and his Odyssean valet, Jeeves.

The Bowling Proprietors Association of America has served notice to all tournament-minded bowlers: Compete in league and tournament play on our alleys, or else Whether the bowlers will accede to this threat is another matter.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Senate Elections subcommittee announced today it would investigate alleged illegal tactics in the campaign leading up to tomorrow's North Dakota Senatorial election.

Premier Khrushchev dealt another hard blow to world peace yesterday when he repeated his Paris performance and in the same dictatorial manner torpedoed the ten-nation disarmament conference at Geneva by ordering his own and his puppet delegates to walk out.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Soybean futures posted their third general advance today on the Board of Trade and led a generally higher grain futures market with gains running to a cent a bushel.

New York City's attempt to combine racial integration in the schools with improved education for all is showing limited progress against heavy odds, Superintendent John J. Theobald indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that integrated mining companies could not compute their mineral depletion allowances on the value of their finished products. The court was unanimous.
TOKYO, June 27 -- Leaders of Japan's principal political parties engaged today in separate conferences, struggling with the problem of finding a new Premier.
New York's frustrated National League fans, under cover ever since the Dodgers and Giants headed west more than two years ago, finally came out of hiding last night.
LEVITTOWN, N.J., June 27 (AP) -- Two Negro families will move into this previously all white community in July and August, Levitt Sons, Inc., announced today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 27 -- Three Venezuelans were accused by the police today in Friday's assassination attempt on President Romulo Betancourt.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The House Agriculture Committee approved today a one-year extension of the Sugar Act that included authority for the President to reduce the Cuban sugar quota in 1960 and to eliminate it in 1961.
Vice President Nixon was accused here last night of using a French newspaper story about Adlai E. Stevenson in an attempt "to destroy the integrity of Stevenson's foreign policy position."
Trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road gave official notice yesterday that they would strike at 12:01 A.M. Sunday, July 10.
Coast Guard investigators were told yesterday that the watertight doors had not been closed on the relief lightship that was rammed and sunk Friday morning.

"Triumph of the Will," a 23-year-old Nazi propaganda film glorifying Adolf Hitler, the National Socialist party and the German youth movements that helped to precipitate World War II, was given its first commercial showing here last night.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Congress tried to move at high speed today to meet a pre-convention adjournment deadline two weeks away, but made slight progress.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs are fluctuating again.

A theatre repertory company under State Department sponsorship is to be formed next year to represent the United States on Europe's stages. The troupe will be part of the President's Special International Program for Cultural Exchanges.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The International Monetary Fund today applauded the trend to greater international trade freedom through the removal of currency restrictions.

Four apartment buildings, three of them in the Bronx and one in uptown Manhattan, have been sold by the Herman Estates to an Investing client of M. Kenner Co., broker in the transaction. The aggregate sale price of the properties exceeded $1,300,000.

MAX GERSH is a professional at emergencies. In the wake of hurricanes, floods, fires or oil-burner flare-ups, this genial gentleman arrives on the scene with one or twenty men to pick up the charred, broken, moldy, sodden or ashen remains and set them to rights.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea -- The Netherlands Government's program of pushing rapidly ahead with self government for the people of West New Guinea has posed anew the question of self-rule for all New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Eisenhower said tonight that his Administration would hold fast to its present course in foreign relations. He proclaimed his trip to the Far East successful and valuable, although disorders in Tokyo led to cancellation of his scheduled visit to the Japanese capital.

A futile effort was made shortly before 5 A.M. yesterday to break a window of the Tiffany store on Fifth Avenue at the corner of Fifty-seventh Street. A suspect was arrested on an attempted burglary charge.

JUNE is a leafy month of milestones. This June, while campus bells ring out four short but long long-lived years, 100,000 women are graduating from colleges across the country. For the majority, in time, the satincircled diplomas mark the descent from ivory towers to park playgrounds, push-button kitchens, supermarkets and finished basements.

THE tinkling bells on the Good Humor man's cart an sounding out across this land for their fortieth summer To celebrate that anniversary and to entice the hungry both young and old, exotic new iced confections have been created.

The American Machine and Foundry Company has been awarded an $81,567,000 contract covering construction of thirty-six launching systems for the Titan intercontinental ballistic missile. The contract brings the company's participation in the Titan program to some $166,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Supreme Court dismissed today an appeal by five Negroes convicted of trespassing on a former municipal golf course in Greensboro, N.C. The course had been leased to private operators who maintained a segregated policy.

PARIS, June 27 -- The man the Algerian nationalists chose to make their first peace contact with the French Government is a big, cheerful, outspoken lawyer who knows Paris as well as he knows Algiers.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27 -- Henry Cabot Lodge declared today that a strong and watchful United Nations should serve to discourage future "Koreas."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 27 -- Al Feminelli of Dellwood posted a six-under-par 34,32 -- 66 on his own ball at the Wykagyl Country Club today and paced his team's victory in the Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur tournament.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Eisenhower has devised a simple procedure for dealing with his critics and his defeats: He simply ignores the critics and claims victories.
PARIS, June 27 -- French and Algerian rebel representatives met today for two sessions of what was reported to be hard bargaining over conditions for convening full delegations for peace talks.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points off to 3 up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.

DeVilbiss co. The directors of the DeVilbiss Company, manufacturer of paint spray equipment, declared a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share on the common stock yesterday. It is payable on July 21 to holders of record of July 11.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 27 (AP) -- Money donated for poliomyelitis victims has been misused by the improper administration of the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation, Minnesota's Attorney General charged today.

DETROIT, June 27 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, issued a statement today relative to the allegations made yesterday by Gov. G. Mennen Williams.
LOS ANGELES, June 28 -- If a pupil strikes a teacher, the teacher has a legal right to hit back, a national meeting of educators was told today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 28 (AP) -- Win, lose or draw, Ingemar Johansson's; next fight will be his last, the former heavyweight champion said today.

Sales of the California Packing Corporation during the first fiscal quarter ended on May 31 will be about 4 per cent above the 1959 level, Roy G. Lucks, president, told the annual meeting yesterday. He added that on a full-year basis sales have increased materially over the years and "we confidently expect this growth pattern to be maintained."
The last major bus strike in New York City started in the early hours of Jan. 1, 1953, and ended twenty-eight days later in the early hours of Jan. 29.
The Soviet Union and Communist China appear to have compromised some of their ideological differences in the conference held at Bucharest last week.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Last December the United States and eleven other nations which participated in the International Geophysical Year in the Antarctic signed a treaty governing future relations in that desolate area. Earlier this week the Foreign Relations Committee voiced its approval.
ABERTILLERY, England, June 28 (Reuters) -- Forty-five coal miners were killed here today in an explosion and cave-in 1,000 feet below the ground. All the bodies were recovered.

TOO many beauty salons in New York are about as relaxing as a subway ride in the rush hour. Customers consider themselves lucky if they do not have to wait to have their hair shampooed, set or brushed out. When they leave the salon, their hair looks fine, but their nerves are not.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Supporters of the proposed new Continental League suffered a setback tonight in their effort to shake the major league grip on about 3,600 professional baseball players.
STRATFORD, Ont., June 28 -- If you decide to put on one of Shakespeare's dull plays, send for Douglas Seale on the double.

ST. LOUTS, June 28 (UPI) -- Ed Bailey's 375-foot home run into the right-field pavilion sparked a five-run first inning tonight that powered the Cincinnati Reds to a 10-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
JERUSALEM, June 28 -- Marlene Dietrich left Israel for Paris today. And she left it standing fairly on its ear.
EAST NORWALK, Conn., June 28 -- Sub-par golf by Dick Siderowf of New Britain, the 22-year-old Nutmeg State open champion, was the feature of the Connecticut amateur golf championship today.
FLORIDA, Cuba, June 22 -- "What will happen when the Americans and the Batistianos try to take your new house and your job away?"
FARGO, N.D., Wednesday, June 29 -- Republican Gov. John E. Davis held a tenuous lead early today over Representative Quentin Burdick, a Democrat, in North Dakota's special Senate election.

THE cult of the temperamental fashion designer seems to be on the way out. Judging from the 1960 Coty American Fashion Critics Awards, a mercurial disposition is not a prerequisite for obtaining recognition in the United States garment Industry.

Robert Moses testified yesterday that Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan told him in 1956 he was under obligation to Sidney J. Ungar. room, Mr. Moses walked from the witness stand to the defense counsel table and shook hands with Mr. Jack, saying, "How are you, Hulan?"
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Wes Covington's lead-off homer in the sixth inning today helped carry the Milwaukee Braves to a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

"HENRY V" will open the New York Shakespeare Festival this evening at the Belvedere Lake Theatre, near West Eightieth Street and the West Drive, in Central Park. Performances will be given nightly except Mondays at 8:30 o'clock.

MADRID, June 28 -- The Spanish Government is considering establishing a central authority for petroleum development here. The effect would be to untangle a potential $200,000,000 American oil investment now snarled in red tape.

In another diversification move, the Singer Manufacturing Company, signed an agreement yesterday to buy the Cobble Brothers Machine Company, Inc. and Cobble Brothers Sales Company, Inc., Chattanooga, Tenn.

PHILADEPHIA, June 28 (AP) -- Pancho Herrera clouted his ninth home run tonight and extended his batting streak to twenty consecutive games as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Log Angeles Dodgers, 2 -- 0, behind Dallas Green's three-hit pitching.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 28 -- A far-reaching agreement that gives Beryllium Resources, Inc., the right to explore for develop, mine and concentrate beryllium minerals on a cost-plus basis for the Mexican Government has been negotiated with the Atomic Energy Commission of Mexico.
Hoagy Carmichael, the song writer, will recall "Those Ragtime Years," when he stars in a one-hour television show of that title next October over the National Broadcasting Company network.

YONKERS, June 28 -- Caduceus, the fast-starting New Zealand pacer, will be worked at two miles tomorrow by Bill Haughton in preparation for Thursday night's International Encore one-mile pace at Yonkers Raceway.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 28 -- Belgian and Congolese ministers combined efforts today, two days before independence for the new state, to check a separatist movement in the rich copper mining province of Katanga.
MANDRA, Pakistan, June 20 -- Fifteen solemn-faced Pakistanis gathered today in a small white-washed hall here to try to solve some of the problems of their world.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Administration won today a two-year battle with Congress for money to construct a new super-sized aircraft carrier of the Forrestal Class.

The bond market resumed its advance yesterday. Treasury obligations were helped by reports from Washington that the Government's cash position was unusually good and that July-December cash financing requirements would be the smallest in some years.

The urban renewal and commuter railroad problems of large cities, including New York, must be solved promptly or there will be "complete chaos" in the cities, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter told Congress today that "the events of the past three months" had left no possible doubt that the goal of the Communists to dominate the world remained unchanged.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The House Rules Committee shelved one high-priority bill and cleared another today as Congress sought to build up a head of steam for an adjournment drive.

BEHIND an unimposing brick facade at 331 East Sixtyfifth Street lies a garden oasis hardly bigger than handkerchief. It is the lair of Vincent-Harmik, a talented team of milliners whose fourth collection was shown to the press yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- A panel of three Federal judges ruled 2 to 1 today that Robert G. Thompson, an official of the Communist party, could be deprived of veterans' payments for a World War II disability because he spoke against United States intervention in Korea.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Henry R. Luce, the editor and publisher, proposed today that the United States make formal declaration -- perhaps by Senate resolution -- that winning the "cold war" is the nation's urgent goal.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of June 24 on "The A B C of Democracy" you offer the Japanese Left-Wing intellectuals a lucid and correct definition of democracy, representative government and majority rule as we understand it here in the United States.
Jeff King, who says he is 108 years old and the Army's oldest ex-Indian scout, arrived in New York yesterday for his first visit to the big town.

Stockholders of the National Union Electric Corporation at their special meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday approved the merger with Eureka Williams Corporation through an exchange of stock. C. Russell Feldman, chairman and president of National, said the merger is expected to become effective tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Dear Ingemar: You asked me what you should say in your forthcoming TV report to the Swedish people about the recent regrettable incident with Mr. Floyd Patterson at the Polo Grounds in New York.

When the Belgian Congo become independent Thursday the West will face a major test of whether democracy can recover from past mistakes in Black Africa. If it can not, one may be certain chaos wil supervene; and hard on the heels of chaos will come the Sino-Soviet bloc.

ROME, June 28 -- Pope John XXIII promulgated a new "constitution" tonight for the diocese of Rome. It tightens discipline for the clergy and defines more accurately the duties of the Roman Catholics in Rome.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 28--The prestige of American tennis receded almost to the vanishing point today as the United States found itself shut out of the semi-finals of the men's and women's singles the all-England championships.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The House of Representatives approved today, 208 to 15, a bill to tighten the regulation of broadcasting and to outlaw payola and the rigging of quiz shows.

Stockholders of the Hotel Corp. of America were encouraged yesterday by the possibility of receiving a stock or cash dividend next year. Irving M. Felt, chairman of the executive committee told the annual meeting here that he would make a favorable recommendation to directors if business warranted.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 1,283 persons were injured in traffic accidents in the city last week, an increase of 102 over the same period in 1959.

A BUS strike and preparations for a Little League ball game kept Peter Gerard Joseph Blumenauer shuttling between a telephone booth and a makeshift speakers' stand yesterday. Mr. Blumenauer is the chairman of Section 401 of Transport Workers Union Local 100, a relatively obscure job until last Monday night.
Edward Albee's much discussed and lauded play, "The Zoo Story," will have the distinction this summer of being the only current off-Broadway venture to have a second company touring the silo circuit.
Six persons relaxing in a Brooklyn neighborhood park were injured yesterday when a limb of an elm tree fell on them. Among them were a grand-mother, her daughter and the latter's two children.

Stock prices continued to slide yesterday, with about half of the day's losses incurred in the final half hour of trading. The selling erased about $2,000,000,000 of "paper" values from listed issues.

CHARLESTON, S.C. June 28 (UPI) -- A youthful tanker captain and two shipmates trying to ride their flooded ship into harbor were transferred to a tow vessel tonight. They planned to beach the stricken vessel on the South Carolina coast.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today filed a suit intended to break up the recent merger of Bliss Laughlin, Inc., of Harvey, Ill., and Sierra Drawn Steel Corp. of Los Angeles.

JOSE GRECO and his Spanish Ballet attracted one of the largest audiences of the season to Lewisonn Staudium last night. A crowd of 11,000 listeners greeted with enthusiasm the dancing and singing of the Greco forces, with the Stadium Symphony Orchestra conducted by Roger Machado.
A 20.4-foot 1960 Cadillac Fleetwood 75 limousine belonging to the Kings County Democratic Committeee has been turned away from parking garages at least twice in recent months because of its size.

Floyd Patterson, who regained the world heavyweight boxing championship last week, was honored at a brief City Hall ceremony yesterday, during which Mayor Wagner presented the champion with the City's Medallion.
Smaller, less expensive electronic home entertainment instruments will soon be on the market as a result of a new General Electric Company device, the company said yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 28 (UPI) -- Shareholders of the Chicago and North Western Railway Company and the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway Company today approved by overwhelming votes a plan for the North Western to purchase the M. St. L. for $20,920,000.

MOSCOW, June 28 (UPI) -- The influential daily Literary Gazette praised Adlai E. Stevenson today but it grouped all other American Presidential prospects together as representative of "monopolistic capital."
MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 29 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Tass announcement:

SALT LAKE CITY, June 29 -- Gene Fullmer's Utah neighbors are confident that the world middleweight champion will repel Carmen Basilio's challenge here tomorrow night. But they are not so confident as bettors elsewhere appear to be.

GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, Mont., June 28 -- An effort to brake Senator John F. Kennedy's Presidential bandwagon failed today at the Governors Conference. In fact, there were signs of growing strength for the Massachusetts Senator.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Administration is sounding out Congress on obtaining legal permission to show the Soviet Union the nuclear explosives to be used in test-detection research.
YESTERDAY (June 28, 1960) SECURITY COUNCIL Recommended admission of Mali to U.N.
A public hearing on the proposed new zoning law for the city will be held in City Hall Sept. 12 and 13, the City planning Commission announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- King Phumiphol Aduldet of Thailand started a five-day state visit today and was welcomed by President Eisenhower. On his arrival the King remarked that he felt at home. "I was born here in this country, so I can say the United States is half my motherland," he told a crowd of 75,000 who welcomed him and Queen Sirikit to Washington.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 29 -- The Soviet Union announced early today that it would test another group of long-range missiles in the Central Pacific next month.

"THE ARTS OF BELGIUM, 1920-1960," an exhibition opening today at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets, includes a large room filled with abstractions that might have been done anywhere in Europe or America and a generous proportion of other paintings that have something closer to what could be called a national character.
The Transit Authority had good news yesterday for its subway and bus riders. It promised to maintain the 15-cent fare at least until the end of 1961.
LONDON, June 28 -- President Eisenhower's report to the nation last night apparently has failed to answer European doubts about the vigor and realism of United States leadership of the West.
GRAYLING, Mich., June 28 (AP) -- Records were broken in three of four categories today in the second round of the national field archery championships by five competitors.
Two youths and two sailors were stabbed last night in the East New York and downtown sections of Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Old-crop soybean futures slumped rather sharply today after three successive broad gains. The grain market was generally easier.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 10 points (50 cents a bale) up yesterday. The near July contract rose a point.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Treasury expects to borrow about $6,500,000,000 in cash in the coming six months -- less than in any July-December period since the Eisenhower Administration took office.
MOSCOW, June 28 -- The Soviet Union sought today to put the main burden of guilt for suspension of the Geneva disarmament talks on the United States.
CHICAGO. June 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 28 -- The Government has formally named the Dominican Republic in connection with the assassination attempt last Friday on President Romulo Betancourt.
HAVANA, June 28 -- The Havana University Student Federation withdrew from the university's governing council today as a conflict between the students and professors threatened to paralyze the school.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Army is strengthening antiaircraft defenses of seven major metropolitan areas, including New York.
BALTIMORE, June 28 (AP) -- Johnny Temple's home run in the eleventh inning led the Cleveland Indians to a 3-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.
BRIDGE experts talk chiefly about bridge hands, but not about the kind of bridge hand -- the squeeze and the throw-in play -- that the less advanced player talks about.

The election of Joseph W. Barnett as president of Cannon Mills, Inc., was announced yesterday by Cannon, a leading producer of towels, sheets and other domestics and one of the ten largest textile manufacturing organizations in the country.

A FEW days ago I found myself telling a friend on the 8:04 commuting train into New York that the best international spy thriller I could think of was "Rogue Male" by Geoffrey Household. It was only several hours later that I realized that Mr. Household's masterpiece of its popular genre was published all of twenty-one years ago.

The national point races of the Sports Car Club of America at Lime Rock, Conn., on Saturday will start at 11 A.M. The gates will open at 9. With more than 125 entries recorded by the New England Region of the club, the sponsors, at least six events will have to be run.
Backers of Adlai E. Stevenson yesterday discounted Senator John F. Kennedy's chances of winning the Democratic Presidential nomination on either the first or second ballot.
NEW HAVEN, June 28 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad would need $100,000,000 to modernize its passenger car fleet, an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing was told today.
The city received an unhappy reminder yesterday that a union's rank and file can run wild as readily as a bus -- and with much more damage to the community.
Citizens traveling abroad may be using a new passport after Jan.1, Frances G. Knight, director of the State Department's Passport Office, said here yesterday.

STE. AGATHE DES MONTS, Que., June 28 -- The professional head of the Rabbinical Council of America asserted here tonight that the increasing synagogue affiliation by American Jews "does not necessarily represent religious growth."

The Yankees returned to the task of keeping the rest of the American League underfoot last night. This Casey Stengel's Bombers achieved with neatness and just the proper amount of suspense to satisfy a gathering of 20,002 at the Stadium.

THERE is probably no group in America more closely identified with food than the Pennsylvania Dutch. And starting next Saturday their kith and kin will converge on Kutztown, Pa., for the eleventh annual Pennsylvania Dutch Folk Festival.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday it would seek to buy 1,550,000 shares, or 60 per cent, of the common stock of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. It would give in exchange $35,000,0000 of Central stock and $13,950,000 in cash.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The New York Central Railroad lost its bid today to block proposed railroad mergers and acquisitions in the East.

Forty or fifty years ago they were school boys. Yesterday they were thirteen old grads paying a sentimental visit to Public School 10, a red brick building that was built on 117th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue in 1894, and will be soon demolished.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- House investigators made public today a disputed report charging that serious defects had reduced the usefulness of thousands of Army tanks and other combat vehicles.

MONTAUK, L.I., June 28 -- Just when it seemed that swordfish were going to do their Independence Day shopping early this year, the broadbill rush suddenly tapered off today. Only a few were seen from Block Island to Long Island's Hamptons.

Quebec has the best credit rating in North America, "better even than Texas," according to Pierre Perriau, general manager of La Societe Internationale de Transactions Canada, Ltee In Montreal yesterday, he announced that a group of private French banks, through La Compagnie Francaise de Transactions Internationales in Paris, stands read to lend the Quebec Government $100,000,000.

Moscow has now confirmed that Bucharest was the scene last week of an international Communist conference, as the West had suspected. The Bucharest Declaration issued Monday is the result of that conference and the most authoritative statement of Communist policy issued since the similar international Communist conclave in Moscow held during November, 1957.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The National Association of Securities Dealers (N.A.S.D.) today expelled seven members for alleged violation of its fair practice rules.
LONDON, June 28 -- Copper arid gold-mining shares were the strongest sections of the stock market here today.

GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, Mont., June 28 -- The formation of a Great Lakes Regional Governors Conference to stimulate the use of the St. Lawrence Seaway was announced today by Gov. Michael V. DiSalle of Ohio.
BOSTON, June 28 (AP) -- Don Mossi broke Detroit's three-game losing streak by beating the Boston Red Sox, 10--1, on nine hits tonight.
The controversial loyalty oath required of all academic high school graduates was condemned and praised yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Education.
GREENWICH, Conn, June 28 -- Mrs. Rector Davol of Round Hill and her 17-year-old son, John, won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association motherand-son championship today.
NEW CITY, N.Y., June 28 -- Rockland County Supervisors were asked here today by the Rockland County Conservation Association to establish a park commission.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) --Julio Becquer's sacrifice fly with the bases filled in the fourteenth inning gave the Washington Senators a 2-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

The wildcat strike that began Monday night and spread through the Omnibus Division of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines system yesterday was an outrage. Called without warning, a breach of contract, a defiance of the impartial arbitration of grievances that is a fixture in the industry, it caused inconvenience to several hundred thousand patrons.

Grand Central Artists' Materials, Inc., has taken a twenty-one-year net lease on the five-story office building at 3 East Fortieth Street from Nation-wide Investors, Inc., the owner. Charles Griffin and Richard J. Doherty Jr. of Cushman Wakefield, inc., were the brokers.

An American edition of the memoirs of the late Maulana Abul Kalim Azad, friend and coworker of Gandhi and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru for Indian independence, will be published July 6 by Longmans, Green.
If there was a paucity of buses in midtown yesterday, there was a plethora of taxicabs. There was, in fact, plenty of alternate transportation for regular users of the struck bus lines.

The Sanitation Department wheeled mechanized equipment into action Monday night and yesterday, and by nightfall the Battles of Rock Salt Mountain on the Lower East Side were only a day away from passing away into local folklore.

Double-feature day at Belmont Park yesterday brought star performances by Ambassador, the favorite in the mile-and-one-half hurdle race, and W. Arnold Hanger's Waltz, the second choice in the co-feature, the Huntington Handicap, at a mile and a sixteenth.

GENEVA, June 28 -- The Western powers are considering a plan to put the disarmament question and the issue of the Communist walkout from the disarmament conference before the United Nations as soon as possible.

PITTSBURGH, Wednesday, June 29 (UPI) -- The game between the San Francisco Giants and the Pittsburgh Pirates was called this morning because of the 12:50 curfew, with the score 7-7. The contest must be replayed In its entirety.

The first step was taken yesterday toward a permanent coordinating council to pool the economic and political influence of labor-management welfare funds covering 3,500,000 New York unionists and members of their families.

Monday's successful one-night presentation of "Triumph of the Will" has prompted the managers of the New Yorker Theatre to book the 1937 Nazi propaganda film for a first-run engagement early this fall.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Fifteen "liberal" Republican Senators issued a "Declaration of Purpose" today.

The City Council passed a long-debated measure yesterday that would bring coin-operated or automatic laundries under that section of the city's Administrative Code governing and licensing regular laundries.
The Tampa Electric Company borrowed $25,000,000 in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of about 4.89 per cent.

We must continually ponder on the sad state of Cuban-United States relations. A delicate and dangerous pass has been reached and it is vital for North Americans to understand the issues, the feelings and -- in so far as it is possible -- the policies of the Cuban revolutionaries.
GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, Mont., June 28 -- Following are excerpts from a statement read today by Governor Rockefeller of New York to a Governors Conference meeting here:

In his Progress Report on the Board of Education's efforts toward greater integration New York's School Superintendent Theobald stressed that the job cannot be done by "piecemeal" effort. He also warned that the schools must not be made scapegoats for society's shortcomings. It is easy to agree with this, as well as with Dr. Theobald's insistence that, while integration must be a priority aim, the overriding target is the improvement of education for all children.

California accepted the single bid for $75,000,000 of veterans and school bonds yesterday, but rejected the bid on $18,000,000 of harbor bonds. Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, and Bankers Trust Company managed a merged syndicate placing the bids.
A wildcat strike of 1,500 bus drivers in Manhattan shut down twenty-one routes yesterday and upset the riding habits of 250,000 persons.

A good proportion of advertising concerns itself with the problem of motivating a house-wife to choose one bar of soap in preference to others and then to move the bar from the shelf to her shopping cart.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright of Arkansas said today that Administration "bumbling and fumbling" in the U-2 plane incident had helped bring United States prestige and influence in world affairs to a "new low.'
The nation's landscape architects were advised yesterday to get down to earth in the small gardens of suburbia.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 28 -- The Government announced today that 1,200 persons jailed during South Africa's state of emergency would be released in the next two weeks.
YESTERDAY (June 28, I960) THE PRESIDENT Met with Republican Congressional leaders; greeted the King and Queen of Thailand, exchanged awards with the King and gave a state dinner for the royal couple.

A renewed drive for fuller United States adherence to the International Court of Justice was started here yesterday. Its supporters will ask both the Democratic and Republican National conventions to pledge support for repeal of the so-called Connally reservation to this country's acceptance of the court's jurisdiction.

SPURNED by Walter O'Malley when he ran off with the rich heiress from Los Angeles, Brooklyn fans still carry the torch. The Flatbush Faithful are as madly in love with the Dodgers as they always were. One-sided though the romance has become, adoring Brooklynites rank it with Romeo and Juliet or Abelard and Heloise.

After almost eighteen months' delay the city's first governmentplanned industrial project moved closer to reality yesterday. J. Clarence Davies, chairman of the Housing and Redevelopment Board, announced the selection of a tentative sponsor for the ninety-five acre, $20,000,000 Flatlands Industrial Park in Brooklyn.
Six of the world's great ocean liners steamed into New York harbor between 8 and 9 A.M. yesterday, carrying a summer record total of 6,267 passenger from European and Mediterranean ports.

Public golf links in this city arid Westchester and five stateowned courses in Nassau County will ban all future tournaments sponsored by the Metropolitan Golf Association because Negroes reportedly are barred from these events.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Democrats have made the first major strategic move of the Presidential campaign.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 29 -- The Government has decided to impose severe restrictions on the 1,200 persons who are to be released in the next two weeks after having been jailed during South Africa's emergency.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 29 -- Despite a favorable decision from the State Education Commissioner, Dr. Herbert B. Smith's future as school superintendent here looked doubtful today.

The company supplying the city with Dominican rock salt has offered to pay the city any money due for short weight or lack of quality -- and to do so on the basis of amounts established by a state investigation. The company has also offered to end its current contract with the city.

Between 200 and 300 persons who had been watching firemen battling the last of the theatre fire at Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street turned their attention to a police chase last night and attempted to free a prisoner.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- Seven manufacturers of turbine-generators and other electrical equipment were in- dicted today on antitrust charges of fixing prices and rigging contract bids to the Government and private industry.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, June 29 -- Belgian and Congolese officials signed today a treaty of friendship and collaboration.

Isolationism is almost dead in the United States, but there are a few vestiges left. One of them is the so-called Connally Reservation to our adherence to the International Court of Justice. It is past time to get rid of it.

LONDON, June 29 -- The British Transport Commission had an over-all deficit of more than u73,830,000 ($206,724,000) last year. But this was u15,500,000 ($43,400,000) less than its deficit the year before.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Nineteen persons were named defendants today in an indictment charging a million-dollar mail fraud. The indictment had been suppressed since March 15.
Trans World Airlines announced yesterday an arbitration award raising wages of T.W.A. hostesses and pursers by 8 per cent and reducing the maximum number of flying hours per month on jets.
BONN, Germany, June 29 -- West Germany is preparing a dramatic proposal for a summit meeting of the six members of the Common Market to speed their integration.
MAUSTON, Wis., June 29 (UPI) -- Six boy campers who panicked and let loose of a guide rope stretched across the swollen Wisconsin River were believed drowned today.
Fifty-four days and one gale Out of Bremerhaven, Germany, the fifty-five-foot ketch-rigged motor yacht Rolling Stone V came to safe mooring yesterday at City Island, the Bronx.

Conservationists, alarmed by the increasing roar of bulldozers, pleaded yesterday for a campaign to set aside 220 square miles of open land in the New York metropolitan area for the good of this generation and future ones.
Efforts by the wildcat Manhattan bus strikers to extend their walkout to the two other divisions of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., failed yesterday.

Wildlife and the Law In the tables of evolutionary development drawn up by biologists, paleontologists, anthropologists, geologists and others man is a new arrival; it would be no exaggeration to say that in the long span during which life has been evolving on earth we humans have been here only for the past few minutes, relatively speak- ing.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 29 -- The Provisional Government is enacting two laws evidently intended to suppress political factional fighting or any attempt at counter-revolution.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- The doorkeeper of the House, William L. Miller, has been notified that his voluntary services at the Democratic National Convention are being dispensed with for the sake of economy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 29 -- Reliable sources said tonight that the United States proposal to submit the disarmament deadlock to the United Nations Disarmament Commission had received an unenthusiastic reception among United Nations delegates.
The organization of Frederick Brown has purchased a twostory taxpayer at 2220-26 Broadway northwest confer of Seventy-ninth Street, from the Rockdam Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Harold R. Tyler Jr. of New York, who was nominated Jan. 26 to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, was finally given a hearing today in a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

GENEVA, June 29 -- Valerian A. Zorin, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, who broke up the East - West disarmament conference here Monday, said today that he hoped the United Nations General Assembly would call for a resumption of negotiations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- Politics and the movie industry have formed a loose partnership for the Democratic National Convention next month and the agenda runs from Walt Whitman to tours of movie studios.
CHARLESTON, S.C., June 29 (UPI) -- The Atlantic claimed the disabled tanker George MacDonald just sixty miles from shore early today, after a long fight to save her.

When the eighth annual season of free chamber-music concerts in Washington Square begins on Aug. 1, Alexander Schneider will return to the podium in the park after an absence of five seasons to conduct the first 1960 event.

FARGO, N.D., June 29 -- Democratic Representative Quentin Burdick took a paperthin lead over Gov. John E. Davis late today after a night and day of ballot-counting in North Dakota's special Senate election.
I Half a year's over. What have books to show Posterity -- or this day's recreation?
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The President and Mrs. Eisenhower today accepted for the White House antique furnishings for an entire room, assembled at a cost of about $100,000.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the appointment of a twenty-member Advisory Board of Public Welfare to help the city carry out its extensive public-assistance program.

Larry Evans, a former United States chess champion, was held to a draw in forty-two moves yesterday in the fifth round of the international tournament at Beunos Aires, according to a report received here through South American news sources.
MOGADISHU, Somalia, June 29 -- Mogadishu, which history has had a way of bypassing through the centuries, is bathed in the glow of public notice.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 29 -- Industrial production in the Middle East rose "considerably" in 1959, according to an economic survey of the region by the United Nations Secretariat.

WHAT Joseph Papp is giving his audience for free in Central Park is a lot more than many producers are selling on Broadway for as much as $9.90 a ticket. His revival of "King Henry V," which opened last night, is a vividly beautiful and rousingly paced pageant.
NEWARK, June 29 -- The Metropolitan Regional Council agreed today on the wording of a proposed bill that would turn it into an official tri-state agency.

A new seasonal drop of 1,130,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute for the week ended last Friday. At the week-end supplies were 203,252,000 barrels, compared with 204,372,000 a week earlier and 198,271,000 a year before.
STRATFORD, Ont., June 29 -- In "A Midsummer Night's Dream" you have to take your choice between movement and poetry. Apparently the two can never be happily mated.
PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers took both ends of a twilight night double-header from the Philadelphia Phillies, 6 -- 3 and 5 -- 2, tonight before 25,572.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the World Bank) announced yesterday it is making two loans totaling $32,800,000 for electric power development in Honduras and Peru.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The wisdom as well as the propriety of checking the rumors which fly around in politics at all seasons, especially in the year of a Presidential election, have lately been impressed on Governor Williams of Michigan and the Southern Congressional leaders in Congress.

Electric power production rose for the third consecutive time in the week ended last Saturday. The latest figure of 14,213,000,000 kilowatt-hours compared with 14,053,000,000 a week earlier, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The San Francisco Chronicle made two legal moves today to block the National Broadcasting Company's acquisition of television stations in San Francisco and Boston.
HONG KONG, June 29 -- Communist China declared today that lasting world peace would come only with elimination of the imperialist and capitalist systems.

Cotton futures closed unchanged to 13 points (65 cents a bale) up on a comparatively modest turnover on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. There were no new incentives and for the most part, the market drifted aimlessly with final quotations at about the day's best levels.

Stock prices continued to fall yesterday at the opening, then recovered somewhat on selective buying. At the close, The New York Times combined index of fifty listed issues stood at 368.57, off 0.61 on the day.

GLACIER NATIONAL PARK Mont., June 29 -- Former President Harry S. Truman's dramatic, unexplained resignation as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention was interpreted widely today as a sign that he had given up his hope of preventing the Presidential nomination of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
A crescendo of student hisses that culminated in the booing of the principal brought an angry end to the 101st commencement exercises of Stuyvesant High School yesterday.
Directors of the National Gypsum Company yesterday authorized the acquisition of the Allentown Portland Cement Company through an exchange of shares. The transaction involves about $30,967,317.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Democratic Congressional leaders decided today to bring Congress back to Washington after the conventions for a pre-election session to deal with major domestic bills.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 29 -- Gene Fullmer, as rugged a the mountains of the Wasatc Range that overlooked the seen of the bloody battle, again stopped Carmen Basilio in their second match for the Nations Boxing Association version of the world middleweight championship.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 29 -- Robert Hill, 14-year-old son of an Air Force staff sergeant, took off today from Mitchel Air Force Base here accompanied by his father to make his second delivery of medical supplies to Dr. Albert Schweitzer in French Equatorial Africa.
"SICK" marriages are behind some cases of sterility, according to Dr. Robert N. Rutherford, assistant clinical professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Washington.

A collection of letters to and by Jawaharlal Nehru will be published Sept. 2 by Asia Publishing House and distributed by Taplinger Publishing Company. Called "A Bunch of Old Letters," it will contain 368 items presenting the ideas, emotions, hopes and observations of Nehru himself, Gandhi, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, Mao Tse-tung, Sir Stafford Cripps, George Bernard Shaw, Clare Booth Luce and many others.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of June 25 on the Cuban sugar quota, while recognizing "the liabilities of the new State Department policy" in terms of "strengthening the Castro regime," points out as a basis for this action that "the present Cuban foreign policy, if followed long enough and far enough, [may] bring the danger of international communism too close to be bearable."

AMERICA'S track and field forces have been improving at so giddy a pace in each Olympic Games that they now are confronted with the virtually insuperable task of thinking up something sensational enough to serve as an encore. They're probably never going to make it.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, who is Chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said today that some New York Federal judges had only themselves to blame for a heavy backlog.
A Supreme Court justice upheld yesterday the right of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to refuse to let The New York Post inspect its contract and other files.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Hundreds of union leaders, most of whom are raising funds in an effort to banish Republicans in the months ahead, raised $20 apiece tonight to toast a Republican who commands their respect.

An antitrust action brought by the Government against the Hertz Corporation, said to be the largest motor vehicle renting and leasing company in the country, was ended yesterday in Federal Court here with the entry of a consent judgment.
NEW HAVEN, June 29 -- The New Haven Railroad's "Operation Sparkle" -- a newly instituted car-cleaning program -- will not be quite so sparkling during July.

IN "Strangers When We Meet," Ernie Kovacs, cast as a disenchanted, successful novelist, soothes his disturbed architect-friend, played by Kirk Douglas, with the pointed advice, "don't lose your head, you didn't invent infidelity."
A strike of Virginia dressmakers over the opening by their employer of an Irish affiliate was settled yesterday on a basis as unusual as the walkout.
The Continental Baseball League will attempt to operate in or out of organized baseball, Branch Rickey indicated yester- day. It hopes to get started next year, but in any event no later than 1962.
The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, producer of encyclopedias and the Harvard Classics, will soon acquire the Macmillan Company.
The modified plan of reorganization for the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company was officially confirmed yesterday in an order signed by Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson.
LONDON, June 29 -- Prime Minister Macmillan asked Premier Khrushchev tonight to reopen the negotiations on disarmament broken off by the Soviet Union Monday.

Securities of Wallace Properties, Inc., Dallas real estate concern, valued at about $14,880,000 are being offered to the public today in units consisting of $25 of 6 1/2 per cent fifteen-year convertible subordinated debentures and 3/4 of a share of common stock at a price of $31 a unit.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Nike-Zeus anti-missile missiles will be test fired against fast-moving Atlas intercontinental ballistic missiles rather than against slower Jupiter intermediate-range rockets.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Following is the text of the United States Government's memorandum entitled "Provocative actions of the Government of Cuba against the United States which have served to increase tensions in the Caribbean area," which was submitted to the Inter-American Peace Committee on June 27 and issued by the State Department today:

STE. AGATHE DES MONTS, Que., June 29 -- The Rabbinical Council of America appealed to the American voter today to judge every candidate in the national elections "by his platform, person and record rather than by his religious affiliation."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 29 -- The Metropolitan Golf Association's senior championship ended in a draw today. Three who tied for the title with gross scores of 76 will return to the Sunningdale Country Club on Saturday morning for an eighteen-hole play-off.
Genesco, Inc. Genesco, Inc., announced yesterday that it plans to acquire Kingsboro Mills, Inc., through an exchange of stock.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Most grain futures contracts drifted along without a push either way today on the Board of Trade, and prices generally ended with only small net changes from previous closes.

The breath-taking transformation of Africa reaches a new peak of interest this week when 20,000,000 Africans in four former colonial territories covering an area half the size of the United States formally assume their independence. This raises the number of independent African states from four at the end of the last war to sixteen, and their number may reach a score by the end of this year.
VALHALLA, N.Y., June 29 -- A neglected four-mile stretch of the busy Taconic State Parkway from Valhalla to Hawthorne was called a menace to motorists today by the Automobile Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A State Department spokesman said today that the Cuban seizure of the Texas Oil Company refinery in Santiago de Cuba was "a naked seizure of property in contravention of the norms of conduct by responsible governments."

Intentionally, named the cham- pion sprinter of 1959, took a long rest before starting his 1960 campaign. He had a leg ailment and his owner, Harry Z. Isaacs of Baltimore, agreed with his trainer, Ed Kelly, that the colt, now a 4-year-old, should have time to find himself.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- The path was cleared today for a House showdown tomorrow on Democratic "must" legislation to increase the Federal minimum wage -- but only at the expense of another union-backed bill.
When a woman who is not pregnant buys a maternity dress because it is irresistibly chic, that is a fashion headline.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 29 -- Negotiations about the British military bases in independent Cyprus were nearing final agreement tonight after two long plenary meetings between the British and Cypriote sides.
Mayor Wagner may testify today when the defense opens its case in the trial of Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Joey Jay, seldom used as a starter, pitched his way back into the Milwaukee Braves mound spotlight by defeating the Cubs, 3-1, in the second game of a double-header today. The Chicagoans won the opener, 3-2, on a pinch single in the ninth.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee recommended unanimously today that three high officials of the powerful Port of New York Authority be cited for contempt.

When Mrs. Edward P. Renner of Lakeville, Conn., exhibited her paintings at the final meeting of the season of the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club, they stirred up a great deal of enthusiasm. Primitives, in the Grandma Moses style, the works depicted dog show scenes.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Eisenhower said today he was "thinking" of a vacation in Newport, R.I., starting next month. But he would return in August when Congress reconvenes to complete unfinished business.
Mayor Wagner was asked yesterday to call an emergency meeting of the Board of Estimate to provide funds for summer jobs for teen-agers.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The State Department accused Cuba today of having contributed to tensions in the Caribbean by using lies and slander against the United States.
Bedloes Island, the home of the Statue of Liberty, was officially renamed Liberty Island yesterday. Washington, Paris and New York were represented at the ceremony.
In a Fourth of July salute last night, high bursting shells were detonated on the Hudson River from twin barges near Ninetieth Street.

BONN, Germany, June 29 -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina promised today that his nation would deliver suspected criminals to their accusers abroad if legally convincing "proof" of misdeeds was presented.

What with late-afternoon rains to intimidate (and inundate) prospective concertgoers, and exploding fireworks over the Hudson River to compete with the performances of the evening, last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium turned out to be a rather dispiriting affair.

The threat of a holiday-weekend strike was hanging over the Bronx Zoo last night.

LIVERPOOL, England, June 29 (AP) -- Dock workers voted today to end their nine-day wildcat strike. They said they would press demands for higher wages, improved pensions and a shorter work week through normal union bargaining channels.
GLACIER NATIONAL PARK Mont., June 29 -- Governor Rockefeller said flatly today:
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Air Force is abandoning all flying activity at Ladd Air Force Base, Alaska, and the Army is negotiating to take it over.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Administration will wind up its final fiscal year tomorrow with its third budget surplus, totaling close to $500,000,000. The surplus is the first in three years and the smallest in the Eisenhower period.
The fresh advance in United States Government securities was given impetus yesterday by a strong and broad demand for Treasury bills and other short-dated securities.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., June 29 -- The Siwanoy team of Joseph Pittore, a Bronxville lawyer, and James Iverson, a clerk in his law office, won the thirtieth British Victory Cup golf tournament at Fairview today.

ALBANY, June 29 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court jury awarded $75,000 tonight to Dr. E. Leonard Cheatum in his $200,000 slander suit against former commissioner Louis A. Wehle of the State Construction Department.
Barnaby Blunderbuss, a forgetful pirate, Julio, his monkey, and Danny Jones, a schoolboy, met yesterday at Public School 42, Orchard and Hester Streets, Manhattan.

THE man who is defending Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack in General Sessions Court, Carson DeWitt Baker, is considered by many to be the most prominent Negro attorney practicing in New York.

ALBANY, June 29 -- The Public Service Commission today blocked the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's request for increases of 10 percent in commutation fares and 5 per cent in one-way, roundtrip and multiple-trip tickets, effective Friday.
One of the most entertaining broadcasting tidbits for stay-at-homes during the holiday weekend that starts tomorrow should be the intensive reports on highway congestion by local radio stations.
GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, June 29 -- By a vote of 30 to 13, the Governors' conference went on record today in favor of using the Social Security System to provide medical care for the aged.

A reorganization of certain divisional operations and the appointment of John W. Brooks and Richard W. KixMiller as new executive vice presidents were announced yesterday by the Celanese Corporation of America.
PARIS, June 29 -- The preliminary Algerian peace talks ended today without a formal conclusion and with the next move up to the rebel Provisional Government.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A new formula for expansion of the Social Security system to provide health insurance for the aged was put forward today with the backing of influential Senate Democrats.

Leaders of a half-dozen Brooklyn Heights neighborhood groups met yesterday to fire "an opening salvo" against city plans to make the controversial $19,500,000 Cadman Plaza project a small-unit luxury housing development.

An "ultimate" merger of the New York Central, the Chesapeake and Ohio and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroads, is strongly favored by Howard E. Simpson, president of the B. O., whose stockholders have separate purchase offers before them from the Central and the C. O.
The nation's bankers expect business in the second half of this year to be good.
The redevelopment of the twenty-nine-acre tract in lower Manhattan now occupied by the Washington wholesale market as a major industrial layout was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

The liquidation of world sugar futures and the transferring of holdings forward weakened prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Commission houses were on both sides of the board. Today is notice date and 7,850 tons are expected to be delivered against commitments.

THE neighborhood theatre managers who decided to open "The Sword and the Cross" yesterday on a double bill with Cecil B. De Mille's colossal circus thriller, "The Greatest Show on Earth," deserve a bonus for shrewdness.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 29 -- Little Tumbler won the $24,- 050 Colleen Stakes in a sea breeze today. The Meadowbrook Stable's filly whisked over the five-and-one-half-furlong course at Monmouth Park like a zephyr from the near-by ocean.

YONKERS, June 29 -- Adios Butler, who last year became the first pacer in harness racing history to capture the gait's triple crown, has been estab- lished the 4-to-5 favorite in the $50,000 Harness Tracks of America final at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.
The New York Institute of Technology, 135 West Seventieth Street, has developed and installed an electronic testing laboratory that teaches, tests and acts as a private tutor.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 29 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club had a four-stroke lead after the first round of the Women's New Jer- sey Golf Association's thirty-seventh annual fifty-four-hole medal-play championship was completed today.
Progress on all major building projects in this city was imperiled last night when 2,500 unionized sheetmetal workers voted to strike at midnight tonight.
MEXICO CITY, June 29 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos has served warning that his administration is prepared to crack down on political agitators.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 -- There will be an all-Australian men's singles final at Wimbledon for the fourth time in five years.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- King Phumiphol Aduldet of Thailand told Congress today that the time was ripe for even closer cooperation between the United States and his Southeast Asian kingdom in view of present world tension.
PARIS, June 29 -- The stakes are enormous -- for France and the Western world as a whole -- in the current maneuverings toward negotiations for peace in Algeria.
The long fight over unionization in the city's voluntary hospitals is expected to come to a peaceful end at a union rally tonight.
MONTAUK, L.I., June 29 -- One of the largest swordfish seen off Long Island this season -- a broadbill estimated at 500 pounds -- shook the hook as he was being gaffed today.

THE PRESIDENT Saw Gordon Gray; saw the King of Thailand; participated in the dedication of a new National Grange building; attended briefly testimonial dinner for Labor Secretary Mitchell; nominated Clare H. Timberlake to be Ambassador to the Congo.

A syndicate headed by Soltzer-Lampert, realty investors, has acquired the nine-story building at 202 Riverside Drive, at the southeast corner of Ninety-third Street. The group bought the parcel in the name of Riverview Equities Corporation from Realty Associates, Ltd., through Philip Hersh, broker.
A number of top-level management changes were announced yesterday at Textron, Inc., diversified manufacturing organization.

The deserted shell of the R.K.O. Twenty-third Street Theatre, at Eighth Avenue, on historic showplace known in the last century as the Grand Opera House, was burned out by a spectacular five-alarm fire yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Vice President Nixon pokes fun at "growthmanship" in his St. Louis speech. At long last the Republican leaders are beginning to discuss growth, though in an irreverent manner. Charles H. Percy, the platform chairman of the Republican party, has already sponsored a $900 billion projection for 1975.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 29 -- Governments are now displaying an enlightened attitude on refugees and are accepting many formerly denied admission, the United Nations was told today.

LONDON, June 29 -- Selective buying by small investors in a market poorly supplied with stock lifted prices of industrial shares here today. There was a fairly long list of modest gains by steel, brewery, paper and store shares.

MANY New Yorkers sing praises of their fair city and dismiss lightly its shortcomings. Others point up its shortcomings and minimize its virtues. But very few pause in the hustle and bustle of everyday living to do anything constructive about its deficiencies.

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 -- Chinese Communist troops clashed with a Nepalese border patrol Monday in the territory of Nepal, according to an official report received today by the Nepalese Government. One Nepalese soldier was killed and eighteen persons were reported to have been taken prisoner.

Arthur Cantor confirmed a report yesterday that he had reached an agreement for the production rights to "The Birthday Party," a drama toy Harold Pinter, a young British playwright who has been hailed by some critics as a genius and by others as an enigma.
BOSTON June 29 (AP) -- Two-run homers by Ted Williams and Russ Nixon of the Boston Red Sox gave a 4-2 victory today to Bill Monbouquette over the Detroit Tigers.
