HAVANA, June 29 -- The Cuban Government seized the Texas Company petroleum refinery at Santiago de Cuba today when officials of the plant refused to refine Soviet oil delivered by the Cuban Petroleum Institute.
HENLEY - ON - THAMES, England, June 29 (AP) -- Harvard's unbeaten lightweight rowing eight opened its bid for a third straight Thames Challenge Cup by breaking the record for the event today.
BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP) -- Dick Stigman held Baltimore to six singles tonight and knocked in two runs as Cleveland gained a 5-3 victory over the Orioles.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- A fairly brisk general demand on the Board of Trade sent several grain futures contracts wall ahead most of the time today, but the advances were trimmed near the close.
A union leader's three-year bout with recurrent hepatitis helped to produce last night's prescription for curing the labor ills of voluntary hospitals in this city.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30 -- Four American lightweight crews won races at the Henley Royal Regatta today and moved a step nearer to Britain's top rowing prizes.
MOGADISHU, Somalia, Friday, July 1 (Reuters) -- The new republic of Somalia was proclaimed at a minute after midnight today.

At the first telecast from the Democratic convention from Los Angeles on the night of July 10, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation will introduce its new corporate symbol, the fifth in the seventy-four year history of the company.

Replying to Premier Khrushchev's letter seeking to put the blame for his demolition of the Geneva disarmament conference on the West, Prime Minister Macmillan has notified the Soviet ruler that his efforts to split the allies is in vain and warned him that "until agreement on disarmament is reached we intend to maintain our collective defense arrangements."

WITHIN recent months, Chinese restaurants have cropped up on the local scene like bean sprouts in a hothouse. More than a score have opened in the last two years and, in the opinion of Dong Kingman, it is a national trend.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The continued low level at steel production last week produced a further decline in rail and truck freight loadings, both industries reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed a resolution today providing for a Congressional recess from July 2 to Aug. 8:
NEWPORT, R.I., June 30 -- Newport's seventh annual Jazz Week-End, which began tonight, promises to be the jazziest of all.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 30 -- Vincent Astor left an estate of more than $127,000,000, according to an appraisal filed yesterday in Dutchess County Surrogate's Court by the New York State Tax Commission.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the United Nations Disarmament Commission should allow the dust to settle before taking up the disarmament question.
NEWPORT, R. I., June 30 -- Even the staid old Newport Casino has caught the excitment of the Newport Jazz Festival and will profit thereby for the benefit of its National Tennis Hall of Fame.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Republic of Congo, June 30 -- An attack on colonialism by the Premier of the new Republic of Congo marred the ceremonies today in which King Baudouin of the Belgians proclaimed the territory's independence.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 30 -- A thirty-one-member High Council of Inquiry was appointed tonight to investigate charges against officials and members of Parliament in the former government controlled by the Democratic party.
DENVER, Colo, June. 29 -- Customer dissatisfaction is "haunting" appliance manufacturers, the director of Whirlpool Corporation's consumer relations division declared here today.

The Treasury's decision to hold its $5,000,000,000 July financing operations to short-term borrowing on Treasury bills was good news yesterday for the longer-term sections of the bond market, but the news reached the financial district too late in the afternoon to stir much trading interest.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa filed charges of "incompetency and misconduct" yesterday against the inspector who checked on the city's $700,000-a-year rock salt purchases.

An evangelist trumpeted "The Old Rugged Cross" from the window of a second-story chapel in the financial district yesterday. Business people crossing Nassau Street on their way to lunch looked up, wondering what the trumpeting meant.

WHEN Prudencio de Pereda was a little boy in Brooklyn he was completely surrounded by Spaniards. Most New Yorkers probably don't know that there was a Spanish Colony on Brooklyn Heights forty years ago. There was and it was just as intensely Spanish as other sections of the city were Italian, Jewish, Polish or Armenian.
Commencement exercises for Stuyvesant High School, disrupted on Wednesday when many seniors booed the principal, came to a polite but rather chilly conclusion yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Republicans rebelled today against Democratic plans for a postconvention session of Congress, but appeared powerless to block it.
A wildcat strike by eighty dockworkers on Pier 97, North River, went into its second day yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers rallied twice tonight and Ed Roebuck, a relief pitcher, protected a four-run lead as they defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 10 -- 6. Vice President Nixon watched the game.

The American Home Products Corporation elected its sixth president yesterday. He is William F. Laporte, who joined the company as a trainee twenty-two years ago. One of the youngest men to hold this office in the big drug, food and household products concern, Mr. Laporte succeeds the late Walter P. Silbersack, who held the post fifteen years.
Stock values on the New York Stock Exchange dropped in aggregate paper value by about $15,000,000,000 in the first six months of this year. This represented a dip of about 10 per cent.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 -- A bitter dispute flared today between the Democrats' national chairman, Paul M. Butler, and other party notables, especially former President Harry S. Truman. Mr. Butler, opening his office at the Democratic National Convention headquarters here, expressed ''bitter resentment" over allegations attributed to Mr. Truman and others that he had "rigged" the convention in favor or nator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the front-running candidate.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System dropped $138,000,000 to $412,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements dropped $90,000,000 to $469,000,000.

EAST NORWALK, Conn., June 30 -- Dick Siderowf of New Britain won the Connecticut amateur golf championship today. Siderowf, a 22-year-old Duke University graduate who recently completed his Army service, beat a 40-year-old hometown neighbor, Bill Kufta, 7 and 6, in the scheduled 36-hole final at the Shorehaven Club.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild, reporting that its membership growth had been held down by job losses in newspaper mergers, authorized exploration today of a possible merger with shop unions into a giant newspaper union.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- Vice President Nixon said today that Congress should finish its business before the political conventions.

The city has successfully raised a steamship company's rent for pier facilities that have yet to be built, Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, announced yesterday.

JACKSON, Miss., June 30 (AP) -- Mississippi Democrats, guided by Gov. Ross Barnett, tried today to show that they will stay in the national convention even if they do not like the decisions there.

Starting today, all investment advisory services must file their sales literature and advertising with the office of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, it was learned last night. The requirement is contained in a law passed by the 1960 Legislature and signed by Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Republican National Chairman said today that Governor Rockefeller of New York was giving the Democrats political ammunition with his attacks on the Eisenhower Administration.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed a bill today to continue for another year war-time corporation taxes and excise levies on cigarettes, beer, wine, new cars and local telephone calls.

YONKERS, June 30 -- Tar Boy in 1:59 1/5 and Adios Butler in 1:58 4/5 split the honors in what many rated the greatest double feature in local harness racing history tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 30 -- Continuing to play fine golf, Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club added a 78 to a first-round 72 for a 36-hole total of 150 at the Montclair Golf Club course today.

The Regional Plan Association and the Metropolitan Regional Council return to their mission of warning the tri-state area to acquire open land for recreational purposes before it is too late. Niering, ecologist and conservationist, who had the help of more than a hundred members of the National Audubon Society.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Senate Judiciary Committee is presently considering, without public hearings, the German war claims bill H. R. 2485 involving the question of the vested German assets and who should be eligible claimants.

As the 1960 model year draws to a close, auto production is on the decline. Production for the week to end tomorrow was estimated at 128,000 units in this country, about 10 per cent below that of a week before. Columbia University announced yesterday the promotion of thirty-five faculty members to the rank of professor. Forty were promoted to associate professorships, and sixty-four to assistant professorships.

Federal Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon was confronted yesterday with a perplexing problem in the case of a Polish seaman who is seeking political asylum in this country.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 4 points up to 3 points off yesterday. Evening up in the July position was the feature. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

John Kenneth Galbraith disusses United States economics and history in his newest book, "The Liberal Hour," which will be published Aug. 2 by Houghton Mifflin. The volume, which is made up of his revised lectures and magazine articles, is divided into three parts.
YORK, England, June 24 -- The 18-year-old daughter of a former American musical comedy star is playing the Virgin Mary in the revival of the York Mystery Plays.
Gerald Klot, acting assistant director of the Board of Education's Bureau of Community Education, was suspended yesterday as the board continued its investigation into alleged payroll padding.
Delays and confusion on the road over the Fourth of July week-end can be minimized in many cases by steering clear of bottlenecks and detours in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A conservative coalition pushed through the House tonight a wage-hour bill more limited in scope than the proposals of the House leadership and the Eisenhower Administration.

IF the Fourth of July calls for fresh salmon, this week end is likely to prove expensive. It is necessary to pay $1.50 a pound for good quality salmon. However, blueberry pie should prove more normal fare; the fruit is in heavy supply and in-expensive.
The Broadway theatre received another helping hand yesterday in its current campaign to repeal the 5 per cent city tax on theatre admissions.

HAVANA, June 30 -- The director of the Cuban Petroleum Institute said today that no date had been set for ordering the Havana refineries of Esso (Cuba), Inc., and the Shell Petroleum Company of Cuba to process Soviet crude oil.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
To thousands of children in the city, yesterday was one gigantic sign that read "This Way Out."
The Cuban Government should not encounter much difficulty in getting Soviet crude oil transported to the Texaco refinery it has seized, tanker owners and ship-chartering brokers said yesterday.
The city's voluntary nonprofit hospitals and their unionized employes yesterday approved a formula intended to guarantee at least five years of labor peace.
MOSCOW, June 30 -- A leading United States research engineer said today that the Soviet Union lagged behind the United States in adapting new automation techniques to industry.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the House voted today for a $1.15-an-hour minimum wage proposal as a substitute for a $1.25 bill:
BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP) -- Jim Gentile, who went in as a pinch-hitter, hit two home runs and drove in five runs tonight as the Baltimore Orioles trounced the Cleveland Indians, 9 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Authority for the President to reduce Cuba's share of the United States sugar market was approved unanimously today in the House of Representatives. The vote was 394 to 0.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A recent Senate resolution to "ease" the equal-time provision of the Communications Act temporarily, as described in your issue of June 28, aims at relieving the broadcast industry from a flood of claims from numerous "splinter" parties for free time comparable to that provided to the major party Presidential candidates.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

As a parting salute to their former pals now toiling in the livery of Kansas City, the Yankees yesterday weighed in with some of their heaviest armament at the Stadium. What followed was, like digging up the old Maine and sinking it again with an atom bomb.

STRATFORD, Ont., June 3O -- Since Julie Harris has a unique personality, it follows that her Juliet is unique. During three and a half centuries, the part may have been played as modestly as she plays it, but certainly not in the last quarter of a century.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Government will borrow $3,500,000,000 cash next week and use $500,000,000 of it to retire part of an issue of securities maturing in the week following.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Two New Yorkers awaiting Senate confirmation as assistant attorney general apparently face a delay until August at least.
LONDON, June 30 -- Industrial shares maintained their improvement in the stock markets here today. Although demand was still highly selective, gains of around 6 pence (7 cents) were common.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Following is the text of President Elsenhower's message to Congress today on his veto of the Federal pay-increase bill:
BOSTON, June 30 (AP) -- Don Buddin scampered home with the winning run today as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Detroit Tiger's, 11 -- 1, in a weird eighth inning.

Bonds called for redemption before maturity dropped to $13,986,000 in June, the lowest amount for any month since last August and the least for a June since 1934, when only $12,562,000 was redeemed. The refunding compared with $14,529,000 in May and $68,065,000 in June, 1959.

STE. AGATHE DES MONTS, Que., June 30 -- The Rabbinical Council of America appealed to United States Attorney General William P. Rogers today to place the American Nazi party on his subversive list. The council is the largest Jewish Orthodox rabbinical body in the United States.

TUNIS, June 30 -- Ferhat Abbas, Premier of the Algerian rebel Provisional Government, will not go to Paris to discuss the Algerian question under the terms outlined by the French, authoritative Algerian quarters indicated here today.
Council Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey was accused by the Citizens Union yesterday of demonstrating a "rather shocking" kind of "official arrogance and abuse of official position."
The Federal Aviation Agency has begun an experiment to determine whether aircraft are flying excessively low in approaching New York International Airport.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose $16,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the comparable week a year ago, they declined $75,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Congress gave final approval today to a compromise 40,000,000,"000 military spending bill. It carried $661,600,000 more than President Eisenhower had requested.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 30 -- The Westchester Hills and Round Hill Club four-man squads reached the final of the first Westchester Golf Association's junior team championship at the Quaker Ridge Club today.

The New York Philharmonic, the Boston Symphony and the Philadelphia Orchestra will play in Carnegie Hall next season, rather than at Hunter College. This was assured yesterday when the City of New York took title to the "saved" Carnegie Hall from Carnegie Hall, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- King Phumiphol Aduldet of Thailand, a leader in the campaign against cholera, poliomyelitis and leprosy in his country, dedicated today the new $3,500,000. Biological Standards Building at the National Institutes of Health.

BROOKS ATKINSON may wish to reconsider his retirement as drama critic of The New York Times. Last night he was the central figure in one of the sketches in the Phil Silvers special show over Channel 2.

VIENNA, June 30 -- Suave Soviet officials, expert Russian cameramen and hardworking little bands of Austrian Communists used the special tricks of the propaganda trade today to try to make Vienna's reception to Premier Khrushchev look less devastatingly chilly than it was.

ACCRA Ghana, Friday, July 1 -- Ghana made a complete break today with the Constituion bequeathed her by Britain in 1957. Her Parliament was prorogued and a few minutes after last midnight she became a republic within the British Commonwealth.
Fuel shipments for planes using New York International Airport were cut off at 12:01 A. M. today by a teamster strike.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Generations of New York State secondary school students have grown up on Regents examinations. The recognized merit of the Regents as instruments of evaluation has established them as standards for measurement of pupil achievement with nation-wide influence.

The American Chain and Cable Company, Inc., announced yesterday that its subsidiary, the Electro-Mech Corporation, Norwood, N. J., had acquired the Reliance Manufacturing Corporation, Reliance, Glen Cove, L. L., makes industrial control and detection instruments.
Offerings to the public of new bonds here declined in June, while stock flotations increased over the levels of recent months.
STRATFORD, Ont., June 30 (AP) -- The Stratford Shakespearean Festival said a formal good-by today to Brooks Atkinson, drama critic of The New York Times, who is retiring from his post.
TWO years ago Noel Morrow Flagg did not know his Ispahans from his Bokharas. Today he buys them by the truckload for Altman's.

Builders have purchased the four apartment houses at 325 to 335 East Forty-ninth Street, between First and Second Avenues, from Park-Lex Estates, Inc. Adele Kirsch was the broker. Walter Scott Co. represented the buyers.
While an audience of more than 10,000 watched, a British performer was fatally injured last night in an eighty-five-foot fall from a platform near the ceiling of Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, June 30 (UPI) -- Ernie Banks smashed his 250th major league homer and Richie Ashburn got his 2,300th major league hit to lead the Chicago Cubs to an 11-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Key doubles by Al Smith and Joe Ginsberg in the tenth inning carried the Chicago White Sox to a 4-2 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Former President Harry S. Truman appears to have ended any remaining chance for Senator Stuart Symington to win the Democratic Presidential nomination.
GENOA, Italy, June 30 -- About forty persons, mostly policemen, were injured in a two-hour-long riot today during a general strike that brought business activity to a halt in this port city.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., yesterday urged the impartial chairman of the transit industry to take action to end the wildcat strike by Manhattan bus drivers.
THE annual Sacandaga Championships begin today at the Adirondack Inn in Sacandaga Park, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The recess motion by the Democratic leadrship, which Congress will be obliged to approve because of the clogged condition of the legislative calendar, may move Senator Johnson of Texas to a commanding position as a Presidential candidate at the Los Angeles convention.
FORT LEE, N.J., June 30 -- The Palisades Interstate Park Commission announced today a program for creating a series of six small parks here on land it owns along the top of the Palisades.

Fifteen years after the end of the second World War there are still more than one and one-half million refugees who for one reason or another have left their homes in Europe, the Middle and Far East and other areas. This figure does not include about one million Arabs who lay claim to a part of the territory of the State of Israel.
Mayor Wagner testified yesterday that Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan had never tried to influence his vote in the Board of Estimate in favor of Sidney J. Ungar's projects.
WASHINGTON June 30 -- The House Judiciary Committee today recommended that three top officials of the Port of New York Authority be cited for contempt of Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Farm product prices dropped 2 per cent between mid-May and mid-June, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Ben R. Gordon has resigned as president of Stern's, New York department store, effective July 15. He announced yesterday that he would leave the store and also Allied Stores Corporation, the parent company.
PARIS, June 30 -- Tariffs come tumbling down all over Europe tomorrow, and the economic division of the Continent will begin to be felt for the first time.
Thousands of city dwellers broke for the hills and the seashore yesterday. Getting an early start for the Fourth of July week-end, they departed as the hottest day of the year arrived here.
LOS ANGELES, June 30 -- A charge that some parents are trying to undermine the public schools was made here today at the National Education Association's annual convention.

When the nation's fiscal year 1959-60 came to an end yesterday the Treasury was able to report that, in round figures, its receipts for that year had exceeded expenditures by $500 million. There were intimations that when the final tabulation has been completed, in a fortnight or so, the figure may reach $600 million.
AS the seasons came around in their due course, so does Gershwin Night at Lewisohn Stadium.

(JUNE 30, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Vetoed Federal pay increase; signed bill providing for United States participation in the International Development Association; signed bill continuing for another year present rates of corporation taxes and some excise levies; met with National Security Council; saw Doctor Saulnier, chairman of Economics Advisers Council; attended dinner with Mrs. Eisenhower given in their honor by King and Queen of Thailand.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Lyndon B. Johnson, the Senate majority leader, has jumped to the position of "strongest possible" candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in the opinion of 407 newspaper men and 220 of his fellow members of Congress, a poll showed today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill that would permit the Secretary of State to withhold passports from suspected subversives.
VIENNA, June 30 -- Vienna gave Premier Krushchev the silent treatment when he arrived today for a nine-day state visit.
FARGO, N. D., June 30 -- Representative Quentin Burdick has defeated Gov. John. E. Davis by a whisker in North Dakota's special Senate election, double-checked unofficial returns showed tonight.
The stock market started to get ready for the long holiday week-end yesterday.
William C. Newberg left the Chrysler Corporation yesterday in the midst of a dispute after only two months as its president.
The Case of the Garrulous Parrot was resolved yesterday in East New York Magistrate's Court.

AS is his habit, Mr. John, a master of the millinery world, has turned to another era for inspiration for his fall collection shown yesterday. This time around it is the romantic appeal of Victorian days that has moved the designer to turn out hats with all the elegance, romantic allure and femininity that any woman could wish for.
The Grey Advertising Agency, Inc., announced yesterday that it was merging with the L. H. Hartman Company, Inc.

Trading in commodity futures was dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices closed Irregularly. Coffee, potatoes, soybean oil, platinum and lead rose; cocoa, eggs, pepper, rubber, wool, cottonseed oil and copper declined, and price movements for sugar, hides and zinc were mixed.

The upper level of Grand Central Station was a pleasant oasis in this hot, sticky city yesterday. There, in the investment information center of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., Olympic figure skating champion Carol Heiss Jenkins stepped on to a miniature skating rink to open the "Pepsi Ice Capers."
Seven, new foreign-made features have been obtained for release this year by two of the major American film importing companies. Five of the acquisitions were made by Lopert Films.

ON a fine summer day, city streets are filled with the proudest mothers in the world pushing the handsomest crop of babies yet. This year, some of them can travel stylishly in the imported baby carriages now at Gimbels.

Stocks rose slightly in light trading yesterday as traders prepared to adjourn for the three-day Independence Day week-end. The firmer tone came in the last hour of trading after a day of desultory, pre-holiday action.

It is a brave but foolish woman who descends on a beach without first getting ready for it. Her figure is not the only criterion for looking well in a bathing suit. She should also consider her feet, her skin, her hairdo and her legs.

LONDON, June 30 -- However worrisome the big deficit in the United States balance of payments may be at home, it has been a major factor in saving Europe from some severe monetary trouble this summer.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., July 1 (AP) -- Mickey Wright of San Diego knocked three strokes off women's par today on the rainsoaked Sheraton County Club course and her 71 led the field of twenty-eight in the opening round of the 72-hole Ladies Professional Golfers Association championship.
Mariners, especially those sailing the Pacific, would be well advised to keep a sharp lookout for stray mines, according to marine underwriters here.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., July 1 -- Long Island's largest school district was in turmoil today as a result of the dismissal of the superintendent of schools by members of the outgoing school board.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- Neale Fraser, the winner of the Davis Cup for Australia and the championship of the United States in 1959, realized his crowning tennis ambition today at Wimbledon.
PARIS, July 1 -- The Algerian rebel envoys flew back to Tunis tonight in an atmosphere that was rapidly chilling for the peace talks they had come to arrange with the French Government.

Hospital patients, present and future, are the clear winners in the voluntary hospital labor policy changes that have been worked out by labor and hospital leaders in cooperation with Mayor Wagner. There will be no strikes now by Local 1199 in eleven hospitals as had been scheduled -- and safeguards are provided against any other strikes for five years to come.

YESTERDAY (July 1, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Met with Cabinet; saw Agriculture Secretary Benson; presented Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, with new fifty-star flag to be flown over Independence Hall, Philadelphia, July4; saw chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Twining; motored with wife to Gettysburg farm for July 4 weekend.
A stoppage of the city's entire construction activity was threatened yesterday as a result of strikes by 10,000 union workers In the sheet metal, steamfitting and asbestos trades.

TOKYO, July 1 -- The Japanese Government rejected today Sioviet complaints that Japan had entered into an "aggresive" agreement with the United States in renewing their military security arrangements.
Sales of the eight major department stores and their branches in New York rose 3.4 per cent last month above those in the 1959 period, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Republican Senators, led by Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, came today to the defense of President Eisenhower's handling of the U-2 incident. They charged critics with "irresponsible" and partisan attacks.

MOGADISHU, Somalia, July 1 -- Demonstrators of three Opposition parties were forced back by the police today as they attempted to march on the Parliament Building, where the National Assembly of the new Republic of Somalia was sitting for the first time.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 1 -- A parking plan based on trading stamps given by merchants is scheduled for a five-nonth test here beginning Aug. 1.

A national alliance of antisegregation groups said yesterday it would press for declarations by both the Democratic and Republican National Conventions in support of a seven-point civil rights program.
STE. AGATHE DES MONTS, Que., July 1 -- A new English edition of the Orthodox Jewish prayer book will be issued soon in the United States.

"ONE MAN'S PLEASURE: A Journal of the Wilderness World,"* by Hugh Fosburgh, is a diary of a year in the Adirondacks. It is the best way of getting close to nature vicariously in New York State I have seen in a long time. After reading it I feel I'm already back from my vacation. But please don't tell The Times auditors that.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Louis C. Wyman, Attorney General of New Hampshire, in The Times of June 25 referred critically to the activities of the Religious Freedom Committee and other organizations on behalf of Dr. Willard Uphaus.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Government has sent to Moscow its reply to Premier Khrushchev's message received earlier this week criticizing the United States and its allies for their stand on the disarmament question.
Record benefits of $5,396,000 were paid to members of the National Maritime Union last year. The members were covered by three union-management-administered personal security benefit plans.

RYE, N.Y., July 1 -- Westchester Hills defeated Round Hill, 13 -- 5, at Apawamis today in the final round of the first Westchester junior interclub team, golf championship for the Theodore G. Law Trophy.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 1 -- A 1960 white Cadillac owned jointly by fifty-seven members of the Fire Department here appeared today to be something of a white elephant.

COUNTLESS women wear the pants in the family; it is the rare man who wears the apron, strings -- by choice. Countless women think they do not see enough of their husbands; one woman in particular knows she sees too much of hers.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- A top price of $18.75 a hundred pounds was paid today for butcher hogs, the Highest in almost eighteen months. Buyers noted that the supply of 3,000 head was the smallest in more than six years.

PARIS, Saturday, July 2 -- President de Gaulle's reply to Premier Khrushchev on the disarmament issue, made public here at 5 o'clock this morning, expressed shock at the Soviet leader's charges of French vacillation and denied that Soviet proposals had met French disarmament aims.

At least some cab drivers neglected yesterday to tell their fares that the city's 10-cents-a-ride tax was no longer in effect, a spot check showed. About one rider in three had a chance of getting the refund, according to the check.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 1 -- Photographs of official records circulated here today indicated that farmer Premier Adnan Menderes had dipped into Government funds for some of his personal expenses.
A 2,000,000-ton charter contract signed last week by the Greek shipowner Stavros Niarchos with the Soviet Union attracted wide attention yesterday as a result of the Cuban oil crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- Congress voted $150,000 today to enable the Federal Communications Commission to monitor television programs for evidence of possible abuses, despite warnings that the action might lead to Government censorship.

Reveries of a Counselor Each year at this time a number of unassuming persons -- school teachers, college professors, students in biology and others who can be classified generally as "ex-Boy Scouts" -- emerge from cocoons of winter sedentary life to become the pride of camp directors, the scourge of campers: they become nature-pioneering counselors.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 1 (AP) -- Here's a tip straight from the paddock: If you have a hear ailment stay away from the track.

LAFAYETTE, La., July 1 (AP) -- Bishop Maurice Schexnayder of Lafayette warned his diocese today that Roman Catholics guilty of criminal negligence in automobile accidents resulting in their death would be denied Christian burial.
''Time for Fun," the children's show that was withdrawn last week from WABC-TV, may find a Saturday spot on the same station.
The four-day wildcat strike of Manhattan bus drivers on twenty-one routes ended yesterday morning after a back-to-work movement had developed among the rank-and-file drivers.

A strike of professional and clerical workers that closed twenty-four day camps and other summer recreational activities for 10,000 children and adults in the city's Jewish community centers yesterday was tentatively settled last night.
HAVANA, July 1 -- The Government seized today the last two foreign-owned oil refineries in Cuba, and all their storage and other facilities.
KATMANDU, Nepal, July. 1 -- Nepal's Home-Minister, S.P. Upadhya, said today that inhabitants had begun an exodus from the Mustang region, which was attacked Monday by Communist Chinese troops.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 1 (AP) -- Harvard's favored lightweight crew and a darkhorse eight from the Detroit Boat Club today stroked into the semi-finals of the Thames Challenge Cup event at the historic Royal Regatta.
ALBANY, July 1 -- Seven New York City state-chartered banks acted today to open seventeen suburban branches as the state's new omnibus banking law went into effect.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
WITH today's boom in art, more and more families of painters and sculptors have left their garrets and taken up residence in suburbia.

An investor has assembled the blockfront on the west side of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), from Charlton to Vandam Street, in a series of deals that took nine months to complete. The property has a frontage of 203 feet on the avenue and includes the parcels at 14,16 and 18 Charlton Street and 5 and 7 Vandam Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1 -- The sparsely attended daytime sessions, which frequently prove to be the most interesting events at the Newport Jazz Festival, produced another memorable group of performance today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, today accused Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, of having created a clash between Congress and two sovereign states.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild adopted a resolution today urging a careful study by labor of political candidates before endorsing any.
The defense unexpectedly rested yesterday in the trial of Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan without Mr. Jack's taking the witness stand.
ROME, July 1 -- A world-wide, five-year "Freedom From Hunger" campaign was launched by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization at its Rome headquarters today.
"X" now equals a victory for the seventy-four tenants fighting eviction at 400 East Forty-ninth Street, a building just north of the United Nations that is doomed to destruction by developers.

A syndicate headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank has submitted the best bid for $15,000,000 of school construction bonds of Dallas, Tex. The securities are obligations of the Independent School District.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- Representative Chet Holifield of California won today the leadership of the Democratic Liberals in the House and announced a drive to strip party conservatives of their grip on legislation.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A Long Island engineer has invented an automatic baseball umpire with an unerring eye for balls and strikes. Its indelible memory retains the course of the ball in relation to the plate and batter.

GRAHAMSVILLE, N.Y., July 1 -- There's too great a tendency to question an angler's sanity. The contention of many critics is that fishermen take their work too seriously. They maintain that angling is not like carrying mail and that such items as hail, rain and gloom of night should at least make a fellow pause before making the rounds.

ALBANY, July 1 -- The Public Service Commission today authorized a 20-cent increase effective July 11 in the Brooklyn Union Gas Company's minimum monthly charge. The change is part of a new tariff setting uniform residential rates throughout the utility's territory in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

Taking the lead at the start, MisHellen carried the silks of FsMcIver Prlckett to success in the-Liberty Belle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. With George Gibb riding, Mrs. Hellen sped to a three-length triumph over the Rockburn Farm's Recite in the six-furlong event for 'i'iilies and mares.

Modern science and mass appetite may soon make Peter Piper obsolete in the pickle-picking business. The pickle industry in this country, concerned about the farmers' ability to produce an adequate supply of raw cucumbers, is pressing for the development of an efficient system of mechanical harvesting.

Productivity in private industry in the United States increased between 4.2 and 4.4 per cent in 1959, according to the Government's preliminary estimates. "Productivity" as here used is a measure of the efficiency of production in the private sector of the economy in terms of man-hours of work for a given amount of production. It is not to be confused with the figures on total industrial production or with the more comprehensive Gross National Product.

Pal Benko, a Hungarian refugee from New York, and Laszlo Szabo of Hungary, with scores of 4 -- 2 each, yesterday took the lead in the chess masters tournament at Buenos Aires, according to a report reaching here last night through South American news sources.

A British military board of inquiry was convened here yesterday to investigate the fatal plunge of a Royal Marine officer at Madison Square Garden Thursday night during a performance of the British Military Tournament and Tattoo.

Consolidated Foods Corp. The Consolidated Foods Corporation, processor and distribiutor, has acquired 51 per cent of the stock of Vinagrera Veneizolana, processor of vinegar and sauces, in Caracas., Venezuela. S. M. Kennedy, president of Consolidated, said that this was his company's first operation in Venezuela.

BONN, Germany, July 1 -- Chlorophyll, the sustance that taps the energy of sun, air and water to make plants grow, has been artifically produced for the first time in a Munich laboratory, the West German Association of Chemical Industries has announced.
BALTIMORE, July 1 (AP) -- Milt Pappas hit a two-run homer, his first hit of the season, and held the Chicago White Sox to five hits tonight as he sparked the Baltimore Orioles to a 4-0 victory.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The feud between Paul M. Butler, the Democratic National Chairman, and Mrs. India Edwards, cochairman of the citizens' committee for Senator Lyndon B. Johnson for President, continued today in Chicago, where Mrs. Edwards was a visitor.
Cotton futures moved irregularly yesterday. Final quotations were 3 points (15 cents a bale up) to 14 points (70 cents) off with the far-off deliveries showing relative heaviness.
The Bank of New York yesterday reported earnings for the first six months of 1960 equaled $10.70 a share, compared with a profit of $8.31 for the similar period a year earlier.
A new index prepared by two American economists indicates that Soviet industrial production more than doubled during, the last decade.

A pre-holiday spirit settled over commodity trading yesterday on New York exchanges. Most future prices drifted aimlessly and closed irregularly mixed in narrow trading. Evening of positions for the long week-end accounted largely for the volume.

ST. LOUIS, Saturday, July 2 (UPI) -- Joe Cunningham's two-out double in the eighth inning drove in two runs as the St. Louis Cardinals won the second game of a twilight-night double-header from the Milwaukee Braves, 7-5.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 1 -- Agreement was announced tonight on all outstanding differences in the negotiations aimed at transforming Cyprus from a British colony to an independent republic. A communique issued after a meeting of British and Cypriote leaders gave details only regarding the financial aid Britain will provide the new republic.
Congregation B'nai Torah; the Reform Jewish temple in Highland Park, Ill., has started something new in worship.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Following are the rollcall votes by which the Senate and House overrode today President Eisenhower's veto of a pay-increase bill for Federal employes:

The millions who ride the city subways should feel safer soon. Fire Commissioner Cavanagh's efforts to get action against subway fire hazards have resulted, through the Mayor's intervention, in a thoroughgoing city transit fire prevention program. It will be carried on jointly by the Transit Authority and the Fire Department -- also, hopefully, helped by the subway riders themselves.

A report that Amelia Earhart might have been executed by the Japanese after she made a forced landing near the Pacific Island of Saipan twenty-three years ago today was broadcast yesterday by a radio correspondent.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 (UPI) -- Frank Leahy, a oncegreat coach of Notre Dame, resigned tonight as general manager of the Los Angeles Chargers because of ill health. The club said that a successor would be named soon.

CLEVELAND, July 1 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company today started disciplinary layoffs for workers accused of participating in a production slowdown at the company's stamping plant in Walton Hills, a company spokesman announced.
DETROIT, July 1 (AP) -- More passenger cars were built in the United States in the first half of 1960 than in the first half of any previous year except 1955.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The discount rate on the Treasury's regular weekly offering of ninety-one-day bills today was down less sharply than on last Monday, and that on the 182-day bills was virtually unchanged.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 -- Kennedy forces braced themselves tonight for a big artillery barrage from that old World War I gunnery officer, Capt. Harry S. Truman, who moved from command of Battery D to the Presidency.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has ordered a thoroughgoing shake-up in his inspection division. Seventy of 110 inspectors will receive new assignments "as soon as possible," probably within two weeks.
BONN, Germany, July 1 -- Nine of the fifteen German party members of the Bundestag, including two Federal Ministers, announced today that they were joining the Christian Democratic Union.
City tax collections for 1959-1960 set a record.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Governor Rockefeller presented a detailed Government reorganization plan today and observed that what this country needed was a "superstrong President."
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Congress overrode today President Eisenhower's veto of a bill to give pay increases to 1,500,000 Federal employes amounting to some $764,000,000 a year.
A strike of 400 fuel-truck drivers and operators delayed lights at New York Internaional Airport yesterday and last night during the busy holiday rush.
NEW HAVEN, July 1 (AP) -- The week-old Interstate Commerce Commission hearing into the deficit-ridden New Haven Railroad recessed today until next Wednesday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Although your editorial of June 22 "Hope for Algeria" recognized that "today's world is a new world" and the inevitability of Africa's surge toward independence, on one particular aspect of Africa's struggle for freedom -- the Algerian problem -- your editorial policy has been generally notable for its lack of understanding and sympathy.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 1 -- Venezuela will call an emergency meeting of the Organization of American States to consider new Venezuelan accusations against the Dominican Republic.

Fortified by the assurance that the Treasury would not be in the market to borrow at intermediate or long-term this month, United States Government interest-bearing securities scored expected price gains yesterday.

ROME, July 1 -- Thirty-seven American debutantes were presented to Roman aristocratic society in a glittering ball at the Grand Hotel here tonight. A group of young princes of the "Black" (papal) and "White" (formerly royal) nobility were at hand to dance waltzes and cha-chas with the girls.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming sent to Capitol Hill today a bill designed to deal sternly with defects in drug manufacturing that were brought out by the Senate. Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee.

THE Association of American Playing Card Manufacturers, whose constant purpose is to help people play card games, is engaged in a campaign to promote the formation of bridge clubs in large offices and industrial plants.
Sales and earnings of the True Temper Corporation rose slightly in the fiscal year ended on April 30 from the level of a year earlier, the company reported yesterday.
LONDON, July 1 -- Industrial shares rallied in the stock market here today after week-end profit-taking had depressed prices and net movements were irregular.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club shot a three-under-par 73 today and won the thirty-seventh annual Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54-hole championship with a 223 total.
A Stuyvesant High School alumnus yesterday criticized the students who booed the principal during the commencement exercises on Monday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP) -- The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association today announced it had opened twenty new branches in California in the last six months and now had total resources of $11,227,653,264.

The gay dash of the Yankees, which already seems to be giving promise of an early liquidation Of the American League, came to a halt last night. But it wasn't anything the opposition had to offer that stopped the Bombers.

FLINT, Mich., July 1 (AP) -- Dave Hill of Jackson, Mich., a brash youngster just a few years removed from the caddie ranks, took the first-round lead in the $52,000 Buick open golf tournament today with a 4-under-par 68.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- At the retail level of business, the volume of consumer installment credit rose again in May but the amount of new credit extended was below April's peak.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower pledged today that the United States would honor its collective security treaty commitments to Thailand.
ALBANY, July 1 -- Ninety-nine laws enacted by the 1960 Legislature went into effect today. They ranged from a relaxation of restrictions on bankers to a tighter regulation of pawnbrokers.
PUGWASH, N.S., July 1 -- To the skirl of distant bagpipes and the sputter of racing out-board motor boats, Cyrus S. Eaton received the Lenin Peace Prize today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- (UPI) -- The House Government Operations Committee accused the Eisenhower Administration today of failing to provide the American people with protection against atomic destruction.

PARIS. France's most serious long-range problem is how to keep Gaullism after de Gaulle has gone or, in other words, how to insure a peaceful return to normal government. For the Fifth Republic, with its dynamism, its flair for grandeur and its one-man administration, is not normal.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Senator John F. Kennedy told Jackie Robinson today that in his campaign for the Presidency he would make no political commitments inconsistent with full support for Negro rights.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- A Scout rocket veered off its path high above the Atlantic Coast tonight, two minutes after launching, and was destroyed.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- A blanket settlement of $770,000 for relatives of nine victims of a 1959 air crash was approved in Circuit Court here today. It was one of the largest recovery orders ever made.

On May 25, 1928, the dirigible Italia crashed on the frozen emptiness of the Arctic Ocean and the disaster brought on one of the greatest series of Arctic searches in the history of polar expeditions. The story of the tragedy and the events that preceded and followed it are told by Wilbur Cross in "Ghost Ship of the Pole."

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 1 -- With John Thomas of Boston University supplying the supreme thrill with two world-record leaps in the high jump, the Olympic-minded track and field athletes of the United States flung a rousing challenge at the rest of the world today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 1 -- The implementation of the five-year program to stimulate world food production and to improve distribution in under-developed countries already is under way.

THE man who officially opened the Freedom-FromHunger Campaign yesterday in Rome is a man on whom famine once made ah impression so deep, so revolting and so terrifying that the memory has dominated his life for the last eighteen years.
A moderately heavy holiday week is scheduled in the market for new capital. Major fixed-interest security issues totaling about $150,000,000 are on the agenda.
Even though New Yorkers were pelted by rain and delayed at terminals, they nevertheless bravely streamed out of town yesterday on the long Fourth of July week-end.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- A bullish trade report indicating slow development of the corn and soybean crops attracted a strong demand in futures trading today and prices were bid substantially higher.

The Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday it planned to offer to exchange common shares for all of the outstanding common stock of the Saco-Lowell Shops, Boston manufacturer of textile machinery.
FROM London, Ont., Mrs. Sally Hill recently sent what she describes as the best recipe she has ever come across for a pie. it was given her, she adds, by her mother.
VIENNA, July 1 -- Premier Khrushchev lectured Austrians today on the virtues of neutrality and continued his controversy with the West on the second day of his nine-day state visit.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Roy McMillan's sacrifice fly and a pinch single by Willie Jones produced two twelfth-inning runs that lifted the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- United States patience with the Cuban Government was rubbed thinner today by Havana's seizure of additional foreign-owned property.
LONDON, July 1 -- Britain urged her exporters today to make a determined effort to expand sales in the other countries of the Seven-Nation European Free Trade Association.

ACCRA, Ghana, July 1 -- Kwame Nkrumah acted less than an hour after his inauguration as the first President of Ghana today to tighten Government spending and to take control of the country's economic development.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- An error in a House-approved bill appeared today to jeopardize chances for broadened wagehour legislation this year.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Tiros I, the first weather-eye satellite, has ended its useful life in space after demonstrating the feasibility of using satellites to forecast weather on earth.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Exports and imports in May were in line with normal seasonal patterns, according to Department of Commerce estimates. The department reported that the month's exports of merchandise were $1,670,000,000.
Gloomy boathouse owners sat around the Hudson River's edge yesterday, speculating about the ways of their affluent society.

Crescent House, a seven-story apartment building at 31-85 Crescent Street, Astoria, Queens, has been purchased by Mrs. Lean F. Cantor and Mrs. Florence Ackerman, two of the most active women syndicators of real estate in the metropolitan area.
LOS ANGELES, July 1 -- The National Education Association broadened somewhat its stand on school integration today. The association acted at the closing session of its annual convention.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 1 -- The American Federation of Government Employes asked fourteen Congressmen and George Meany, president of the A. F. L.-C. I. O., last night to take steps to see that there would be no action on the proposed discontinuance of the Panama Line during the Congressional recess.
Construction men now making a clearing in a northern British Columbia forest are the pioneers of what is described as "the longest railway started in the century."

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 1 -- The Islander, a 230-ton fifty-three-car ferryboat that had been tied up here on Martha's Vineyard by a seamen's strike since April 15, started her run to the mainland at 2:48 P.M. today.
Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany gained a tenuous hold on first place in the Buenos Aires chess tournament yesterday, according to South American news sources.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 2 -- The fortitude and devotion of the 8,500 persons who heard last night's Newport Jazz Festival program at Freebody Park was put to a severe test by a drenching rain that began before the concert started and was still pouring down when it ended.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- The House Space Committee called on the United States today to speed up its space program and put a man on the moon before 1970.
ALGIERS, July 2 -- French policies in the interior of Algeria have not been affected by the preliminary peace negotiations held in Paris.

WELL-TIMED for the vacation season, a film-developing kit designed for travel will reach the camera stores throughout the country this week. The portable system offers the traveler the advantage of processing his film en route and seeing his results soon after shooting.
