THOSE who are celebrating this Fourth of July at baseball parks or race tracks probably will quench their thirst with beer or soda pop. Those who are spending the holiday at home may sip in leisurely fashion on tall, cool drinks like gin and tonic or Tom Collins.
On and on roll the Yankees and even if the end of their dazzling dash is not yet in sight, the finish of the American League flag race may not be too far away.
MANOKWARI, New Guinea, June 30 -- Dutch military activity is considerably more evident in the western end of Netherlands New Guinea than 500 miles farther east at Hollandia.

Three Brooklyn youths seized in a running, gun battle with detectives late Saturday were held yesterday -- one without bail and two in high bail -- on charges of felonious assault and unlawful assembly. A 14 -- year-old boy was held as a juvenile delinquent.
BONN, Germany, July 3 -- Landlords are cheering and tenants are weeping in West Germany. The state has relaxed its grip on rents and has promised to abolish all controls by 1966.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., July 3 (UPI) -- Mickey Wright matched par 74 today and regained first place in the Ladies' Professional Golfers Association championship by one stroke. She has a 54-hole total of 221 at the Sheraton Country Club course.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 3 -- After two days of record-smashing, before an enthralled total of 106,000 fans, the fifty-four athletes who won fifty-six places on the United States Olympic track and field team scattered to their homes today.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 3 (AP) -- Severe windstorms swept north-central Indiana's Wabash Valley early today, killing at least one person and leaving several cities in a state of emergency.
MOSCOW, July 3 (AP) -- Ludmila Shevtsova-Lysenko of the Soviet Union set a world record of 2 minutes 4.3 seconds today for the women's 800-meter run.

County and town officials in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Bergen and Fair-field Counties vigorously endorsed yesterday a report by the Regional Plan Association calling for conservation of open land in the suburbs.

A nervous little man with a wide-eyed look was seen, walking quickly out of a Manhattan branch library the other day with three books under his arm --three of the seventy books he has stolen this year from the New York Public Library system.
Net assets of the Canada Jeneral Fund, Ltd., were $76,287,767 on May 31, it has been announced. The figure compared with $81,076,801 on Feb. 29 and $98,174,742 on May 31, 1959.

ROME, July 3 -- An "explosion of luxury" marks the incipient holiday season in Italy, as pictured with disapproval by national magazines. There is a mounting cry for tax agents to watch what is going on at the seaside and in the mountains.
Landlocked Switzerland, with a growing merchant fleet, has ratified five conventions of the International Labor Organizaion on seafarers' working conditions.
The Red Queen was not talking about New York City, or its nursing shortage, when she told Alice:
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, House Democratic leader, emerged soon after 5 o'clock this morning from the Senate-House conference on the sugar bill.

The eleventh annual Report on Exchange Restrictions, issued by the International Monetary Fund, dealing with the year 1959 and early 1960, made its appearance last week. In the opening paragraph of its general review the report declares: "During 1959 and the first four months of 1960, progress in reducing or eliminating exchange restrictions has been substantial and has been made on a wide front; restrogressions have been comaratively few." It goes on:
PITTSBURGH, July 3 (UPI) -- Steady pitching by Don Drysdale combined with a 13-hit attack led the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 6-2 victory over the Pittsburgh pirates today.

The premiere of "Wrangler," a Western about "a wandering cowboy with an eye for women," has been postponed. It was to have made its debut at 9:30 P.M. Thursday over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 -- Democrats are watching Governor Rockefeller's efforts to influence the Republican National Convention with almost as much interest as they are the developments affecting their own nominating session, which opens here a week from tomorrow.

LONDON, July 3 -- A belief that the coming Presidential election will end an era in British relations with the United States is a powerful motive behind Britain's shift toward closer military and economic ties with Western Europe.

The report "Searchlight on New York," made by the Community Service Society, is an impressive survey of the city's multitudinous social welfare activities. It not only classifies and measures their extent but shrewdly analyzes the most urgent needs to be met in the future and where the responsibility lies in meeting them.
MAUTHAUSEN, Austria, July 3 -- Premier Khrushchev used his visit to a wartime Nazi concentration camp today to emphasize the determination of the Soviet Union to have its way ultimately in Germany.

BUENOS AIRES, June 30 -- The outstanding features of the Argentine economy at midyear are the stagnation of production, with the exception of oil, a relative price stability, and a growing rate of foreign and national private investment.

LARCHMONT, July 3 -- Western Long Island Sound isn't noted for fine sailing weather. But this doesn't seem to stop many skippers from doing a good bit of yacht racing on that unpredictable body of water.

LINZ, Austria, July 3 (UPI) -- Premier Khrushchev said today that he was willing to negotiate with any future United States Government but that talks with the Eisenhower Administration were impossible.
CHICAGO, July 3 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs routed Jim O'Toole with a four-run attack in the fifth inning today and beat the Cincinnati Reds, 7 -- 5.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to foods that are low in cost. A recipe is suggested for a main dish that is easy to prepare.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 3 -- Two college youths, combining concrete mixer, a makeshift chemical laboratory, unbounded confidence, parental advice and hard work, have succeeded in their first business venture.

DARIEN, Conn., July 3 -- The color and style of the roof planned for the Howard Johnson Restaurant under construction on the Boston Post Road, at Ledge Road, has brought objections to the town's Architectural Advisory Committee.
The Bronx Zoo has some or the aspects of a nursery these days.

W. Averell Harriman took issue Sunday with former President Harry S. Truman's insertion that the Democratic National Convention had been "prearranged" for the benefit of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts.
Senator John F. Kennedy flies here today to answer former President Harry S. Truman's questions about whether he is ready for the Presidency.
Week Ended July 1, 1960 British pound sterling and Canadian dollar showed steady undertones in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Business transacted was moderate in size.

George B. Rabinor, Abi Kalimian and Fred Manocherian, builders, have taken title to a plot of land on the east side of Cruger Avenue, between North Oak Drive and South Oak Drive, the Bronx, where they plan a ten-story apartment house.
THE Bikini, the little suit that got the big promotion from the sportswear industry this year, has not lived up to expectations. Is it the weather or our Puritan, heritage?

One of the principal features of mutual funds is that the stocks in their portfolios are pretty well spread out in terms of industries and their locations. Strength through diversity, both economic and geographical, is a basic tenet of mutual fund philosophy.

A mortgage banking and housing unit has been transferred from the City Controller's office to the newly created Housing and Redevelopment Board. The unit has accumulated a $471,526 surplus in the four years it has been operating.

PARIS. Our Japanese policy might be summarized in a slightly modified quotation from Euripides: "The gods visit the sins of the uncles upon the nephews." The uncle, Gen. Douglas MacArthur, worked hard to neutralize Japan little more than a decade ago.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A weary Congress recessed this morning after an all-night wrangle over reduction of Cuba's share in the United States sugar market.

Souvenir for the Fourth For several years the Post Office has provided the nation with a safe and sane souvenir of the Fourth of July: a new four-cent postage stamp with the Stars and Stripes in full color.

FLINT, Mich., July 3 (UPI) -- Gene Littler, who went through the first forty-seven holes of the Buick open golf tournament without going over par, had four -over-par holes on the back nine of the third round today. As a result, he slipped into a four-way tie for the lead at the 54-hole mark.

SPOLETO, Italy COTTON dresses and open sandals are the daytime garb of women here for the short but chic season of the third "Festival of Two Worlds." No slacks are allowed on the street in this tiny hillside town, where Gian-Carlo Menotti, organizer and director of the festival, has brought bright prosperity to old Etruscan surroundings.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 -- Gov. LeRoy Collins of Florida said today that he would insist upon an orderly procedure, fair to all candidates, to record changes in votes during a roll-call at the Democratic National Convention.
BABYLON, L. I., July 3 -- A southwest wind, which reached 25 miles an hour, curtailed the Babylon Yacht Club regatta today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- Actors here had a special reason to celebrate this Fourth of July week-end. They were looking forward to at least four years of labor peace, after the most hectic six months in Hollywood history.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 -- This week will see the lowest point in steel activity since the 195 recession. Not only will mills to shut down for Independence Day, but many will not reopen for some time. Plants will be shut down either for mass vacations or because of a lack of business for that particular minor because of a combination of both factors.
Governor Rockefeller charged last night that the Republican party leadership was not interested in competition, for the Presidential nomination or in a discussion of the issues.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 (UPI) -- Ron Laird of the New York Pioneer Club paced a field of forty-nine Olympic hopefuls in the fifty-kilometer walk today, covering the distance in 4 hours 40 minutes 9 seconds.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson said today that he agreed with Harry S. Truman's statement yesterday that Democratic National Convention proceedings "are taking on the aspects of a prearranged affair."

LARNACA, Cyprus, July 3 -- Dr. Fazil Kutchuk faced stiffening demands from the Turkish Cypriote community today that he spurn the Cyprus agreement until the Turks had been assured of receiving their portion of civil service jobs in the new republic.
BALTIMORE, July 3 (AP) -- Roy Sievers scored both Chicago runs today as the White Sox edged the Baltimore Orioles in an eleven-inning pitching duel, 2 -- 1.
ST. LOUIS, July 3 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3, today on Del. Crandall's infield hit with the bases filled and two out in the fourteenth inning.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 29 -- "The National Front does not exist today," said a political observer, echoing the growing pessimism here over the Colombian political scene.
A group of sixteen Protestant teachers and clergymen and one Roman Catholic priest left New York last night for a six-week "professorial workshop" in Israel.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- Johnny Klippstein's relief pitching in the opener and a sixteen-hit attack in the second game enabled the Cleveland Indians to sweep a double-header from the Washington Senators, 5-2 and 11-5, today.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said yesterday that five Soviet nuclear scientists would arrive in New York tomorrow to visit high-energy physics laboratories.

AMSTERDAM, July 3 -- International issues closed last week with losses on the stock market here after some fairly wide price swings. Trading was fairly brisk early in the week, but dealings slowed toward the end of the period.

The mystery has finally been solved surrounding a letter in which Benjamin Franklin wrote in 1787 of "the enthusiastic joy with which the Day of the Declaration of Independence is everywhere annually celebrated."
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 3 -- United States prestige appears to have fallen considerably in Pakistan since the illfated U-2 plane took off from Peshawar to spy on the Soviet Union two months ago.

BONN, Germany, July 3 -- The West German ambassadors were prominently at the head of the line last week to present their credentials as the new African republics of the Congo and Somalia celebrated their independence.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 3 -- The remaining performances of the Newport Jazz Festival were canceled today by a 4-to-3 vote of the Newport City Council. The action followed a battle last night between a crowd of several thousand persons outside Freebody Park, where the festival was being held, and the state, naval and local police.
LONDON, July 3 -- An Oxford professor asserted today that the late Sir Arthur Evans, the archaeologist, had "misrepresented his findings" in Crete.

BALTIMORE, Monday, July 4 (AP) -- The broad stripes and fifty bright stars of the nation's new flag rose majestically over Fort McHenry at midnight in fresh tribute to Hawaii and solemn commemoration of this 184th Independence Day.

The decline of freight damage claims to almost the vanishing point should not make management complacent, trucking officials were warned at a recent meeting of the American Trucking Associations' National Freight Claims Council.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Congressmen can be candid. One who was, and needed to be, last week was Representative Frank E. Smith, the Mississippi Democrat who wrote the now-famous "haste makes waste" amendment to the Minimum Wage Bill.

A 500-pound uranium ball, said to be the first ever produced, has been machined into a perfect sphere by Hydromatics, Inc., of Livingston, N.J. The sphere will be part of a special flo-ball valve to be used in the giant Enrico Fermi nuclear reactor now under construction in Lagoona Beach, Mich.
Organized medicine in Nassau County expressed opposition yesterday to moves by nine major unions to open a chain of-cut-rate drug stores in the metropolitan area.
A new effort got under way yesterday to head off a strike of trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road at 12:01 A.M. next Sunday.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- A late rally left the grain futures market with numerous good gains for the week after the previous week's general setback carried several contracts to their lowest levels of the season.
PARIS, July 3 -- The possibility of formal peace talks between the French and the Algerian Nationalists to end fighting in Algeria has produced important variations on the Paris stock market.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Eichmann case raises two fundamental legal issues. There is first the transfer of Eichmann by volunteers from Argentine soil to Israel. This issue, it is hoped, is now closed after the two-day debate in the Security Council.

We celebrate today, by jamming the roads with automobiles and in other festive fashions, what is officially known as Independence Day. We do not make as many speeches as our ancestors used to do, but our idea as we drive along is the same as theirs was -- namely, that we no longer owe allegiance to King George III or any other British monarch.
The summer storm that crashed down on the city last night was tracked as a wavering blue line on a radar scope as it moved swiftly from the northwest outrunning holiday motorists.

At today's holiday matinee of "The Music Man," a comely woman with red hair, who stands 5 feet 5 inches in her stocking feet, will raise the baton in the orchestra pit of the Majestic Theatre to lead twenty-eight men and one woman through one of Broadway's most popular scores.
MINSK, U.S.S.R., June 24 -- Touring a Soviet industrial plant is like witnessing a religious rite.

RHEIMS, France, July 3 -- Jack Brabham of Australia, the world champion easily won the Grand Prix de France today. It was his third straight major victory and the fourth of five this season for the Cooler factory team.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 3 (AP) -- History was made today in the boxing ring. For the first time in Southern Africa, white and black boxers were matched.

BETHPAGE, L.I., July 3 -- Templeton bowed today to Bethpage, 4 -- 3, but beat Peru, 7 -- 2, and won the round-robin polo tournament at Bethpage State Park. Peru defeated Bethpage in the other game, 4 -- 2.

DENVER. TWO pertinent problems having to do with senior citizens were taken up last week at the fifty-first annual meeting of the American Home Economic Association. The first concerned planning ahead for retirement.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Contrary to your editorial of June 25 ("Cuba's Sugar Quota") the abolition of sugar quotas would be neither "sensible" nor "economic."
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -- The Undine Barge Club of Philadelphia took a sizable lead today for the Barnes Trophy at the eighty-sixth annual national rowing championships.
BODO, Norway, July 3 (AP) -- A Soviet rescue cruiser joined the search today for a United States reconnaissance plane and its crew of six men missing for two days north of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Tiros I weather-eye satellite has given a practical demonstration of its forecasting ability by showing how it could have steered a B-52 bomber away from a cloudy rendezvous point over the Atlantic Ocean.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- A spokesman for Senator Kennedy stated recently that the Senator was not taking cortisone drug for any illness.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- The report on Latin America suggested that Cuba was moving too fast with land reform and giving away too much land for nothing.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4 -- This was a quiet day of stock taking for Newport following the cancellation yesterday three Newport Jazz Festival programs scheduled for late night and today. Almost all the visitors here for the festival had left by noon and the tow quickly settled back into it
BALTIMORE, July 4 (AP) -- The nation's new fifty-star flag was raised here over historic Fort McHenry, birthplace of "The Star-Spangled Banner," as the climax of colorful midnight ceremonies.

BABYLON, L.I., July 4 -- Three skippers made series sweeps as the week-end invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club ended today. Bill Ludlum's Ever Reign I, in the Snipe Class, Ed Ketcham's Old Forty Four, among the Sailfish, and Jim Andersen's Good Bye, among the Seaford skiffs, all had three straight victory guns.
PESHAWAR, Pakistan, June 23 -- An uneasy peace prevails along Pakistan's northwestern frontier as a result of a lingering quarrel with neighboring Afghanistan.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- Amid the roll of drums and the blare of a bugle the nation's fifty-star flag was raised at Independence Hall today by a Marine Corps color guard in colonial uniforms.

ACAJUTLA, El Salvador, June 30 -- President Jose Maria Lemus paid a visit today to a model farm here that the Government hopes will demonstrate how El Salvador's povertystricken tenant farmers can improve their lot.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 4 (AP) -- Oklahoma Democrats and Republicans pick nominees for a variety of offices tomorrow.
It was a long day at the national fencing championships yesterday.
Damage suffered in Sunday night's storm has forced a nine-day postponement of the 1960 Empire State Music Festival, it was announced yesterday by Frank Forest, general manager.
The American Bowling Congress tournament, the annual sports competition with the greatest number of entries, may be held in New York in 1965.

STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) -- W. Logan Grier Jr.'s undefeated homebred colt, Itsa Great Day, won the $23,600 Christiana Stakes at Delaware Park today. He set his third track, record and scored his fifth victory.
PARIS, July 4 -- Leaders of eight autonomous African republics in the French Commuinity were in Paris today to begin negotiations with the French Government for their independence.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 4 -- President Romulo Betancourt said today it was clear the Dominican Republic had been involved in the attempt on his life on June 24.
YONKERS, July 4 -- Chancey Farvel, handled by Fred Bradbury, scored a surprising onelength victory over Jan Hanover in the Independence Day Pace before 24,855 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
ACCRA, Ghana, July 4 -- President Kwame Nkrumah proposed today the formation of a non-nuclear bloc, either of uncommitted nations in Asia and Africa or solely of African states.
THE remoteness of John F. Kennedy from the stereotype of the Irish-American politician is symbolized in a special way by the man who has been his closest adviser for most of the last eight years.
Beginning next fall, the name of Brooks Atkinson will adorn a Broadway theatre.
Ten ninth-grade mathematics teachers from the metropolitan area will go back to school this morning to learn a new method of individualized instruction.
TUNIS, July 4 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation from the French, is the text of a communique issued here today by the Algerian Provisional Government:
The King of Thailand and the King of Swing held a jam session last night and rocked the rafters at the Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

The Council of the Diocese of New York has sold St. Mary of the Angels Protestant Episcopal Church, on Cranford Avenue between White Plains Road and Barnes Avenue, to St. Paul's Slovak Evangelical Lutheran Church, formerly at 1179 Hoe Avenue.
BOSTON, July 4 (AP) -- The Baltimore Crioles split a doubleheader with the Boston Red Sox today by winning the second game, 8 -- 6, with two unearned runs. The Red Sox took the opener, 10 -- 7.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 4 (AP) -- A group of Southern segregationists asked Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas today to head a Southern block to prevent the nomination of either Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas or Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts for President on the Democratic ticket.
One afternoon recently an employer telephoned Arthur Mann, director of the State Youth Employment Service, to discuss a 16-year-old girl who had been referred for a job.

New York may be many things to many people, but between sailors and the city there appears to be a case of love at first sight. Visitors from the Navy fleet moored in the North River say the city has "more of everything than anything."

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Tuesday, July 5 (Reuters) -- Iceland protested to Britain today that a British destroyer had hindered the arrest of British trawlers fishing inside Iceland's twelve-mile fishing limit.
In the growing air-freight forwarding industry time is valuable:
The average tramp vessel in the world's merchant fleet is getting bigger, speedier and younger, according to a report issued by W.G. Weston, Ltd., British shipping analysts.
INGLEWOOD, Calif, July 4 (UPI) -- Prize Host, with a 17-pound pull in the weights over the favored Bagdad, today scored a wire-to-wire victory in the $54,200 American Handicap at Hollywood Park.
New York City's skyscraper boom hag spread in a modest way to Governors Island, headquarters of the First Army.
COLORADO SPRINGS, July 4 (UPI) -- The Unser brothers of Albuquerque, N.M., captured two first places and a second today in the annual Pikes Peak hill climb before 12,000.
The General Electric Company has given notice that its 110,000 unionized employes cannot expect any "pot of gold" in contract negotiations this fall.

PARIS, July 4 -- As delegates started checking in today for the annual meeting of the International Lawn Tennis Federation on Wednesday, the word was that a showdown would be avoided on the proposal to establish a new class of "authorized players."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 4 -- Arthur Kelly's Swizzle led a fifteen-boat Manhasset Bay One-Design fleet to the finish line today as sixty-one yachts showed up for the inter-Club racing on Manhasset Bay.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The accounts in The New York Times of Vice President Nixon's recent St. Louis speech on economic growth and of Governor Rockefeller's reported reactions to it conveyed the impression, at least to me, of some kind of fundamental disagreement between them.
FAIR LAWN, N.J., July 4 -- The recently formed Fair Lawn Mental Health Center expects to open a clinic here about Sept. 1. It will serve children of the community and adults who live or work here.

LONDON, July 4 -- Computers at the University of Manchester are to be used in an attempt to find a physical explanation for the differences in the size of the planets of the solar system and the distance between them.

ONE of New York's perennial summer delights is the series of concerts under the stars at Lewisohn Stadium. Honoring it and Mrs. Charles S. Gugenheimer, founder and guiding spirit of the open-air concerts, B. Altman Co. has gathered together a group of suitable summer fashions, feminine in feeling, in the seventh - floor Better Dress Department.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 4 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer carded a 5-under-par 67 and aging Gene Sarazen a 69 today in the first qualifying round of the centenary British open golf championship. The courses at St. Andrews took their worst beating ever.

The National Council of Churches and the national federation of Reform Jewish temples will ask the Democratic platform committee this week to support repeal of the immigration quota system. This discriminates against Southern Europeans and Orientals.

AACHEN, Germany, July 4 (AP) -- William Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., today won the third and last qualifying heat of the European Grand Prix horse jumping competition. The American Olympian rode Riviera Wonder.

The 175-year-old General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, whose membership has taken in whip makers, quill manufacturers, bell hangers and television engineers, will celebrate Independence Day tomorrow at its headquarters, 20 West Forty-fourth Street.
DETROIT, July 4 (AP) -- The end of 1960 model auto production has begun and output will drop steadily between now and the end of August.

Sword Dancer, the horse of the year in 1959, was the horse of the day at Aqueduct yesterday. The chestnut colt, owned by the Brookmeade Stable of Mrs. Isabel Dodge Sloane, won the mile-and-a-quarter Suburban Handicap in the track record time of 2:01 3/5 under the guidance of Eddie Arcaro.

Although New York real estate brokers have leased more than 25,000,000 square feet of new office space for clients in the last ten years, most brokerage concerns themselves are retaining their old offices.
The national head of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen gave the green light yesterday for a strike of the union's 1,350 members on the Long Island Rail Road at 12:01 A.M. Sunday.
CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians whipped the Kansas City Athletics twice today, 4 -- 0 and 7 -- 4.

LARCHMONT, July 4 -- The best sailing day of the three-day week-end, with a whipping breeze of about twenty miles an hour, helped skippers of the Yacht Racing Association celebrate Larchmont Yacht Club's eighty-first annual one-day regatta on Long Island Sound today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4 -- Plans for the annual Shaggy Dog Ball and dinner dance benefiting the Hampton Animal Shelter, Inc., of Bridgehampton, have been announced by Mrs. Spelman Prentice, the honorary chairman. The fete is to be held July 30 at Montrose, the former estate of Mrs. Hugh Chisholm, which is being opened to the public for the first time.
FRENCH LICK, Ind., July 4 (AP) -- Mickey Wright of San Diego, Calif., posted a three-under-par 71 today and won the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship with a 72-hole total of 292.

THE corn may not be "as high as an elephant's eye" on the terraces at Bellevue Hospital, but the little "green thumb patients there are just as hope ful about their small stand of corn as any Oklahoma farmar about his vast acres.
TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Industrials today took their biggest beating in four months in a stock market that failed to draw interest in any section.

MONROE, Wis., July 4 (UPI) -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining said today that too many Americans were "more concerned with economic security from the cradle to the grave" than with making the sacrifices needed to preserve their freedom.
This summer millions of Americans will learn more about the geography of their country from free road maps, made available to them by oil companies, than they ever did from school text books.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Seven toy manufacturers, four wholesalers and a trade association today were accused by the Federal Trade Commission of using unfair business practices.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 4 -- Global production and income established new peaks in 1959 and the upswing of recovery continued into the present year, the world economic survey of the United Nations reported today.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 4 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower wound up his holiday week-end here with another eighteen holes of golf today.

CAMBRIDGE, N.Y., July 4 -- Hedges Lake in Washington County, a mile long, a half-mile wide and 200 miles from New York City, completed the first big week-end of the black bass season today with the rest of the state's waters.
As a result of the first major post-war revision of its sailing schedules to the West Coast of South America, the Grace Line will now be able to provide two weekly sailings to that area.
Following is the transcript Senator John F. Kennedy's news conference at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday:
WILMINGTON, Del., July 4 (AP) -- Dr. Barbara Moore, often called Britain's walking wonder, today strode many sun-baked miles closer to her final goal -- New York.

During the session just ended the Supreme Court of the United States put 2,178 cases on its docket and disposed of 1,822 cases. Not one of these cases was trivial, even though it involved, as one did, no more than two ten-dollar fines levied against a Negro by a Louisville, Ky., police court. Some decisions revealed differences of temperament and belief among the high tribunal's nine middle-aged or elderly men.
ST. LOUIS, July 4 (UPI) -- Roger Craig pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 5-4 victory over St. Louis today after the Cardinals had won the opener of a double-header, 6 -- 2.

BONN, Germany, July 4 -- Secretary of the Army Wilbur M. Brucker corrected himself today after remarks he made at a news conference here had been interpreted to mean that West Germany's Defense Minister wanted long-range missiles for the Bonn regime's armed forces.
LONDON, July 4 -- The profusion of first, middle and surnames, one of the facts of life in Britain as baffling to visiting Americans as cricket, has now been firmly tied to the class system.
HONOLULU, July 4 (UPI) -- The new flag was raised over the fiftieth state today in a brief and solemn ceremony at Iolani Palace.

A third book about Adolf Eichmann is being rushed into print. Scheduled for publication this month by New American Library as a 50-cent Signet Book is 'The Case Against Adolf Eichmann," edited by Henry A. Zeiger, with a foreword by Harry Golden.
Citizens of the northernmost block of St. Paul Avenue in the East Bronx were in no holiday mood yesterday.

THE open pair championship in the annual Fourth of July tournament at Sacandaga Park, N.Y., was won by Ralph Hirschberg of New York and Mrs. Muriel Kaplan of Philadelphia, who had an unusually high score of 470 match points in the final of the two sessions.
H.K. Porter Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had acquired a French producer of steel, railway cars and components and other industrial products.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Tuesday, July 5 -- Israel has asked Argentina to consider the Eichmann case closed.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 4 -- Full-time faculty members of the University of Minnesota medical school have begun to pay the university a part of fees collected from private patients treated in University Hospitals.
IT'S more than five years since Jim Rathmann last was handed a traffic ticket for speeding. It isn't that he no longer drives fast. He does. But he now chooses his spots better.

July 5 and an Anniversary No public observance is provided for the day after July 4, but this year it is the sesquicentennial anniversary of the birth of a man who gave the nation, and New York City in particular, much to remember.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 4 (AP) -- J. Howard McGrath, former United States Attorney General who resigned his post under fire in 1952, released tonight the contents of a personal letter from former President Harry S. Truman that he interpreted as an apology from Mr. Truman for having forced his resignation.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 4 (UPI) -- Except for Arnold Palmer and Gene Sarazen, most other members of the twenty - four - man American contingent ran into trouble in the British open today.
WARSAW, July 4 (UPI) -- The Polish Army appeared today to have completed a command-level shakeup of its main political board.

Officially, the fifty-star American flag reached New York yesterday as it reached the rest of the world. For the most part, however, star-counters found privately displayed flags still shy a star or two.
BERLIN, July 4 -- A cuban Government official said in East Berlin today his country wanted diplomatic relations with all Communist countries.

DETROIT, July 4 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers beat the Chicago White Sox twice today. Jim Bunning pitched a three-hit, 3 -- 0 victory in the opener and Norm Cash hit a homer for a 3 -- 2 triumph in the second game.
MOGADISHU, Somalia, July 4 -- The new Republic of Somalia completed today four days of festivities marking its independence from Italian and British rulers.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) -- A total of 5,200 fifty-star flags were flown on the flag pole on the nation's Capitol today.
LONDON, July 4 -- Most sections of the stock market were quiet here today and generally easier at the close.

FLINT, Mich., July 4 (AP) -- Burly Mike Souchak calmly dropped in a 7-foot putt on the seventy-second hole in a dramatic finish and won the $9,000 first place money in the $52,000 Buick open golf tournament by a stroke today.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 -- The formal preliminaries of the 1960 Democratic National Convention -- the first such assemblage in Los Angeles -- get under way tomorrow. At 2 P.M. the convention's Platform Committee, headed by Representative Chester Bowles of Connecticut, will open hearings, which will continue through Friday.
LONDON, July 4 -- South Africa's future membership in the Commonwealth, should it become a republic, was the subject of sharp debate in the House of Commons today.
LUXEMBOURG, July 4 -- Gunfire crackled through the summer warmth today, raising the crows and echoing through hills that know this sound of warfare.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Sometime this fall, near the second anniversary of the suspension of atomic tests, United States scientists plan to explode a nuclear device deep underground at the Nevada test site.
SALZBURG, Austria, July 4 -- Premier Khrushchev gave warnings and promises to Austria today as he toured through an aloof countryside.
TUNIS, July 4 -- The Algerian Provisional Government rejected today conditions set down by France for prospective peace talks in Paris.
Brainard Field, the major commercial airport of Hartford, Conn., will become the site for a new industrial park five minutes from the city's downtown business section.

HAVANA, July 4 -- The sugar workers' union alerted its members today to seize United States-owned mills in Cuba as soon, as Premier Fidel Castro ordered reprisals for the expected cut in the United States sugar quota.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- One of the most important unions in the movie industry has chosen Independence Day to open a strong attack on actors, producers and directors who make movies abroad to take advantage of low-cost labor or to evade taxes.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 4 -- Archbishop Makarios said today that the new republic of Cyprus would pursue a foreign policy that would be independent of any military bloc.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP) -- Gene Conley, backed by some extra base hits, pitched Philadelphia to a 5-2 victory over Cincinnati today in the windup of a double-header. Young Jay Hook hurled a four-hitter in shutting out the Phils, 5-0, in the opener.

The Bangu Athletic Club of Rio de Janeiro defeated Sampdoria of Italy, 4 -- 0, yesterday and gave an impressive demonstration of the style of play that enabled Brazil to capture the world crown two years ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 4 -- Special United Nations representatives will remain in the new Republics of Congo and Somalia during the critical early weeks of independence.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Republic of Congo, July 4 -- Congolese troops fired into a crowd of political demonstrators in Coquilhatville today, killing ten and wounding about twenty.

Yeshiva University outlined yesterday plans to build a fivestory, $3,000,000 classroom and Administration building at the southwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 185th Street in the university's main center.
BALTIMORE, July 4 (AP) -- Johns Hopkins doctors have developed a simple method for restoring heart beat by applying pressure on the chest.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- The Idle Hour Farm's Julmar led all the way today in the $29,200 Longfellow Handicap over the Monmouth Park grass course before a crowd of 31,237.

It is now two years since the Supreme Court struck down the State Department practice of denying passports to persons it considered possible subversives. The Republic still stands, and indeed the passport system is working better than ever. The State Department has removed from application forms a question about Communist party membership.
David MacTavish Loovis, 34-year-old author, former newspaper reporter, hotel clerk, waiter and salesman extraordinary, said yesterday that he had "taken the plunge."
LOS ANGELES, July 4 -- Backers of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson's Presidential candidacy proposed today a health test for all Democratic contenders.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 4 (AP) -- The "three great enemies" of American freedom are communism, fascism and the Roman Catholic Church, a former Federal judge said today.

The pellmell rush to independence this year of so many of the states of "Black Africa" should bring home to Americans the vital necessity that we not be caught short again -- as we have been so many times since the second World War -- in our relations with countries just emerging into nationhood.
Holiday traffic deaths set a grim record as millions rushed homeward last night at the end of the Fourth of July week-end.

MILWAUKEE, July 4 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates maintained their three-and-a-half game grip on first place in the National League today. They beat Milwaukee, 7-2, after the second-place Braves had fought from behind for a 7-6 victory it the ten-inning opener of the double-header.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Liberal Democrats are quietly organizing a new drive to curtail the House Rules Committee's power to stifle and delay major legislation.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4 (UPI) -- Jack Smith of Spartanburg, S.C., won a bumper-to-bumper duel with his hometown rival, Cotton Owens, today and captured the Firecracker 250-mile race by two feet.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Jack Sanford blanked the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 0, on four hits today in pitching the San Francisco Giants to victory in the opener of a double-header. Fine relief pitching went for nothing in the 1-1 second game, called after fourteen innings because of darkness.

A landlord reluctantly has been evicting about a hundred young tenants in the last month from the Clara de Hirsch Residence for Working Girls at 225-East Sixty-third Street. The evictions mark a temporary abandonment of a home that, for six-three years, has served immigrant and working girls of the city.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) -- The Treasury began today a survey of depreciation tax "write-offs" that could lead to tax savings for virtually every business, in the nation.
LOS ANGELES, July 4 -- A change in Democratic National Convention rules that would bar any state from changing its vote during a roll call has been suggested to the convention's Rules Committee.

In trying to select a television show to fill the 10 to 10:30 P.M. Thursday time slot next season, the Columbia Broadcasting System is as puzzled as an Aqueduct addict studying the daily double. Like the race track fan the network also wants to pick a winner.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The general taxpayers whose glorious inheritance from the Declaration of Independence was extolled today by politicians all over the place heard no mention of how Congress again has exchanged for re-election votes a vital part of this inheritance.
Underwater sound waves generated by depth charges have been picked up almost halfway around the world, Colum bia University announced yesterday.

Foreign Commerce Weekly for June 20 carries a projection of the United States balance-of-payments picture for the year 1960 as a whole, and it is hardly calculated to buttress the hopes raised by the January-April visible trade figures. True, the Commerce Department's tentative estimate for the current year does show a reduction in the deficit compared with those of 1958 and 1959.

HAVANA, July 4 -- Thousands of Chinese residents of Cuba are being asked by the Chinese Communist Government to fill out questionnaires on their jobs, relatives and properties both here and in China "so that we can represent you more efficiently in our country."
Senator John F. Kennedy declared yesterday that the "strength and health and vigor" of a young man were needed in the White House.

The first setback in the negotiations between the French and the Algerian nationalist rebels has now occurred. In a communique issued in Tunis yesterday the Algerian National Government in Exile said that it would not send Premier Ferhat Abbas to France to continue negotiations in present circumstances.
The possibility of reducing criminal influences in maritime unions by a change in election procedures was a major topic last week among labor and management officials.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Senate investigators said today the one major ingredient that was lacking throughout the country to deal with the juvenile delinquency problem was trained social workers.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) -- Ten sellers of contact lenses were charged with making false advertising claims today by the Federal Trade Commission (F.T.C.).

MILWAUKEE, July 4 (AP) -- Officials and front-office employes of the Milwaukee Braves became emergency ushers today when the 150 regular ushers went on strike shortly before the double-header with the Pittsburgh Pirates.
The favorite reading matter of many Americans across the country is being put in the mail. It is the Sears, Roebuck catalogue -- 1,594 pages fat.
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The Claiborne Farm's Dunce, back at his favorite track, scored 3neck victory today in the $55,250 Stars and Stripes Handicap at Arlington Park.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Yankees' winning streak, along with Casey Stengel's patience, went by the boards today as the club lost to the Senators, 9 to 8.

A spokesman for the Air Transport Association asserted yesterday that airlines did not have a policy of booking more passengers than capacity to make up for the 10 per cent of passengers who make reservations, but do not show up.

After eight rounds of the chess masters tournament in Buenos Aires, Samuel Reshevsky, a former United States champion, leads a field of twenty by a half-point, according to a report received Sunday night from South America.

A RESIDENT of Antwerp once characterized the cuisine of Belgium as possessing opulence and a truculent nalvete. It was said in the most flattering sense, for dishes with clotted cream are no more and no less exquisite than a perfectly prepared, plain, boiled chicken with leeks.

"THE CHARACTER OF AMERICAN HISTORY"* is a good book to be reading these days. It gives the long perspective, and all that, at a time when we are rather uproariously discussing current issues. And it strikes useful balances for those who think we are either heading stubbornly for hell in a handbasket or setting out on a somewhat bemused safari toward the Elysian Fields.

BORDEAUX, France -- Every year at this time, Western Europe goes ga ga over a twenty-two-day bicycle race called the Tour de France. Today, the Tour pedaled into this wine-rich, Southwestern city, got its usual tumultuous reception and paused for breath.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The sale of Federal surplus equipment for use in teaching science has tripled in the last year and a half through the establishment of a chain of twenty "supermarkets."

MOSCOW, July 4 -- Five hundred prominent Muscovites, including three of Premier Khrushchev's associates, ignored a recent deterioration of diplomatic relations today and showed up at the United States Ambassador's Independence Day reception.
The Sanforized division of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., will introduce its new Sanforized-Plus trade-mark label to consumers in August with a major advertising campaign.

NEW YORKERS are bound to welcome the Metropolitan Museum's seventh annual Summer Loan Exhibition of paintings, which opens today and will be on view through Sept. 4. It comprises 132 privately owned paintings, many of them well known and also of the highest quality, and it is a predominantly French occasion, emphasizing impressionist and post - impressionist masters.

The evening performance on Sept. 13 of the Royal Ballet (formerly Sadler's Wells) at the Metropolitan Opera House will benefit the Professional Children's School. On that night the group will perform a full-length version of Tchaikovsky's "Sleeping Beauty," starring Dame Margot Fonteyn.
LONDON, July 5 -- The National Union of Railwaymen joined the National Union, of Mineworkers today in opposing any plans to decentralize control of Britain's nationalized industries.

Prices of United States Government and prime corporate bonds scored impressive gains yesterday, bearing out the indications that arose in the late pre holiday trading of last week. Many new high prices for the year were established among both Treasury and corporate issues.

The Federal Maritime Board will begin hearings in Washington today on an application by Waterman Steamship Corporation for permission to continue certain foreign flag operations after it becomes a United States subsidized shipping line.

A pentagon has been added to Wall Street. Yesterday, Blyth C., Inc., large investment banking concern, opened a new corporate trading room with a five-sided amphitheatre" arrangement of the trading desks.
The City Stores Company yesterday declared an unusual, optional dividend, offering to stockholders either cash or

Irregular price movements characterized cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange today, with the near-by positions relatively steady. Trading was again slow. Evening up in old July was the feature.
COME fall, the younger set may be tipping its hat to Mr. Arnold.

"There's a man outside with $100 and he'd like to come in," a waiter declared yesterday in the course of a private, jam session that featured Benny Goodman, jazz clarinetist, and Phumiphol Aduldet, renowned saxophonist and King of Thailand.
The case against Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan is expected to go to the jury today.
In Greenwich Village last week the complaint was "save the old Village." On the middle West Side this week the gripe is to do something about the landlord.
The Princeton Club has contracted to sell its property at he northwest corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, vhere it has been situated for the last thirty-seven years.

Earl (Butch) Buchholz and Charles (Chuck) McKinley two 10-year-olds from St. Louis, were named yesterday to the United States Davis Cup squad of four that will compete in the American zone tennis eliminations at Quebec against Canada, July 15 through 17.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, said today that a Senate staff study provided fresh evidence that favored contractors could get an unlimited monopoly on inventions they developed at taxpayers' expense.
Mayor Wagner signed a bill yesterday increasing at once the fees charged by the Department of Buildings for processing plans and applications for construction.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 5 (AP) -- Harvey Gaylord, former president of Bell Aircraft Corporation, has been elected president and treasurer of the Bell Aerospace Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Textron, Inc., it was announced today.

Following is the transcript of a televised news conference held in Washington yesterday by Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, as recorded by The New York Times. Senator Johnson read a prepared statement and then answered questions from reporters.

Ship engineers aboard passenger and dry-cargo ships of East and Gulf Coast steamship companies were granted a 5 per cent across-the-board increase yesterday in base pay and overtime rates by an arbitrator.
The last obstacles to the independence of Cyprus have now been surmounted. By the middle of August a hew nation, the Republic of Cyprus, will join the world community.

TOKYO, July 5 -- Japan's extreme Leftists, including the radical student federation that played a key role in forcing the cancellation of President Elsenhower's visit here last month, are being torn by ideological strife.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is a considerable -- and growing -- movement of opinion toward Governor Stevenson again being the democratic candidate for President. But this movement has not been joined by a small if often distinguished number of former supporters of the Governor.
A test of the Metropolitan Golf Association's sincerity in disclaiming discrimination against Negroes was proposed yesterday, but appeared to be blocked by a technicality.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- For the longest time tonight it looked as if the Senators were due for utter frustration. First they lost their tempers and then it appeared they would lose a ball game to the league-leading Yankees.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 5 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, said today that he did not think the Democratic National Convention had been rigged.
LONDON, July 5 -- British Government securities and blue-chip industrials provided most of the business in today's stock market dealings here.
LONDON, July 5 -- Britain is adopting a policy of "wait and see" in her approach to the European Economic Community, Reginald Maudling, President of the Board of Trade, indicated tonight.

BLUEBERRIES are as Amarican as Plymouth Rock or the covered wagon. Long before Columbus reached the New World, many Indian tribes gathered these "berries plentiful." And, according to early explorers, the Indians taught the colonists how to dry the berries to extend their use beyond the then-short season of three or four weeks.
Among the American young women who will be honored at the first Ball of the Silver Rose to be held on Saturday at the Schwarzenberg Palace in Vienna are four from this area.

The First Westchester National Bank of New Rochelle plans to split its stock two for one, pay a 2 per cent stock dividend on the increased number of shares to be outstanding and increase the cash dividend, Arthur J. Geoghegan, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The migratory farm-labor situation a the United States was described today as "the ugliest kind of human waste."
LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) -- An Air Force officer said today there was photographic proof that Amelia Earhart was executed and buried by the Japanese on the Island of Saipan in 1937.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Back in the White House after a long week-end at his farm in Gettysburg, Pa., President Eisenhower signed a batch of secondary legislative bills today and talked politics with Vice President Nixon.

A college graduate, who left his job several weeks ago to concentrate on fencing, and a 37-year-old bakery owner provided the highlights last night in the final of the epee competition in the national fencing championships at the Hotel Commodore.
The Appellate Division handed down a ruling here yesterday that may cost the state $21,000,000 in Federal taxes for state-reimbursed improvements in harness tracks.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 5 (AP) -- Air Vice Marshal Keith L.B. Hodson of Canada was killed late today parachuting from a disabled 2-33 jet trainer twelve miles South of here.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The federal National Mortgage Association announced today that it would increase the prices it paid for mortgages.
LONDON, July 5 -- The most extensive collection of Pablo Picasso's paintings ever assembled was opened tonight at London's Tate Gallery.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Following is the text of a note delivered today to the Cuban Ministry of Foreign Relations by the United States Ambassador, Philip W. Bonsal:
The city's new meter maid force brought more than $210,000 in additional revenue to the municipal treasury last month.

PARIS, July 6 -- Thirty years after the United States Lawn Tennis Association first voted to hold an open tournament, the International Lawn Tennis Federation is expected to take enabling action tomorrow.
UNDER the compelling leadership of Josef Krips, Stadium Concerts began last night its most ambitious sustained project of the summer -- a three-concert Beethoven festival.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 5 -- The Council of Ministers, the transitional Government, set the dates today for Cypriotes to elect their first Parliament.

The formal announcement by Senator Lyndon Johnson that he is a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination is about as surprising as was a similar announcement by Senator John Kennedy last Jan. 2. In fact, the only remarkable thing about it is that the majority leader has held off so long, when it had been perfectly clear that he was working toward the Presidency for many months if not years.

No progress was reported early this morning after city, state and county officials had met with union and company heads for five hours in a new attempt to avert a strike on the Long Island Rail Road at 12:01 A.M. Sunday.
Maple Lane Gardens, a nine-building group containing fifty-two units in Teaneck, N.J., has been acquired by Maple Lane Associates, a syndicate headed by Max Fluss.
A $500,000,000 price tag over two years was put on union contract demands yesterday by the General Electric Company.

The Franklin National Bank of Long Island, Mineola, charged in the State Supreme Court yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was disqualified to sign the state's new banking law because of the Governor's "direct or indirect interest in various banking institutions."

Peter Glenville, still regretful but undaunted by the conflicting film and stage commitments that prevented him from directing "Room at the Top" two years ago, plans, as compensation, to make new films with the prize-winning drama's stars.
AS MUCH as it likes music, the public of the Lower Eastside Neighborhoods Association's concerts seems to like Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt even more.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 ( AP) --Johnny Podres, a southpaw, pitched a four-hit shutout and was aided by erratic San Francisco play as the Dodgers defeated the Giants, 8 -- 0, before 47,698 tonight.
TRENTON, July 5 (AP) -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today he would not surrender to "dictatorial demands" by Congressional investigators for the Port of New York Authority's confidential records.
The New York delegation to the Democratic convention is not rigged, and no one has tried to rig it in favor of Senator John F. Kennedy, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.
BOSTON, July 5 -- Bernard Goldfine went to Federal prison today for contempt of court in a tax case.

The First National City Bank of New York and its affiliate, the First National City Trust Company, reported yesterday that combined net operating earnings were $37,929,000 or $3.10 a share, for the first six months of 1960.

FEW women are as conscious of figure problems as Edith Lances, Saks Fifth Avenue's capable custom corsetiere. For more than twenty years, Miss Lances has been designing shapely creations to control and camouflage the female form.

When the curtain is lowered on "The Miracle Worker" Saturday night, Kathleen Comegys, who plays Aunt Ev in the William Gibson play, plans to "get away from the greasepaint" and "stop kicking the trunk around."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5 -- Reliable sources said today that the United States had decided not to press for a meeting this month of the United Nations Disarmament Commission.
BONN, Germany, July 5 - The United States told West Germany today that it was not pulling its weight in providing aid to the developing countries of Asia, Africa and South America.
Ninety-eight students and teachers who were scheduled to fly to Europe Saturday for two months of camping trips have been camping instead at a New York hotel, waiting for an airplane.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Sharp relief pitching by Lindy McDaniel and a run-scoring triple in the eighth inning by Bill White led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Presidential campaign is beginning to perform its traditional function. It is creating friction but it is testing character. It is full of tricks and maneuvers, charges and counter-charges, but in its rough way it is uncovering truth.

WHEN Dave Sime was an undergraduate at Duke, he was a slugging outfielder of big league potential. He also was a sprinter of extraordinary promise. But he finally reached a point where he had to choose between baseball and track. What to do?
Worthless academic "honors" ire being sold to American scholars by trans-Atlantic diploma mills.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- Paul M. Butler, the Democratic National Chairman, predicted today that this year's Democratic convention would be able to agree on a platform without a major floor battle.

The great Boer trek of the Eighteen Thirties is the subject of a new novel by Stuart Cloete called "The Fiercest Heart." Houghton Mifflin will issue it Aug. 8. It tells of the thousands of men, women and children who left the security of the Cape Colony and moved into Africa's interior looking for freedom "from all law other than the laws of God."
VILLACH, Austria, June 5 -- "Life is short," Premier Khrushchev said today, "and I want to see the Red Flag fly over the whole world in my lifetime."
Flights at New York International Airport again were subject to minor delays up to an hour yesterday as a result of a strike of 400 fuel truck drivers.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 5 (AP) -- Gene Sarazen, 58, and Arnold Palmer today led a thin line of Americans through the second qualifying round for the centenary British open golf championship.

A few specialties gave yesterday's stock market a surface sheen but most of the list was dull and flabby. The market averages declined slightly and volume remained relatively depressed -- 2,780,000 shares, against 2,620,000 shares for the pre-holiday session on Friday.
It is grimly significant that the ideological dispute between Communist Russia and Communist China centers about one point -- whether war is inevitable or not.

SHUSHAN, N.Y., July 5 -- Roy Brown was glum today, Roy Brown likes to see lots of trout fishermen on the Battenkill, which passes through this village, among other places. Roy Brown runs a small place on the Battenkill's banks he calls the Tackle Box.
LONDON, July 5 -- Britain has lodged a "strong" protest against the seizure of the Royal Dutch Shell Group's refinery in Cuba, the Foreign Office disclosed today.

PLANETARIUM shows, films, live animal programs, story-hours and lecture-demonstrations are among the activities offered in a full-day schedule at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place.
A special grand jury will begin an inquiry here today to determine whether criminal charges should be lodged against witnesses for false testimony in the investigation of television quiz shows.
As he officially opened the first of the city's summer play streets yesterday, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy joined the children in fun and games on Hester Street on the Lower East Side.

IN the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Spirit in Havana, a man wore the robes of a priest, but he also had a mustache, unusual for a priest. The disguised man was Jose Miro Cardona, dean of the Havana Bar Association.
The record traffic-death rate over the Independence Day week-end was tabulated at 442 persons yesterday.

Domestic sugar futures fluctuated yesterday in nervous trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Volume was light, with most traders preferring to wait until further action is taken on the new sugar quota law.
BOSTON, July 5 (UPI) -- Chuck Estrada permitted only five hits while his Baltimore Oriole team-mates collected fourteen in a 9-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.
"General Electric Theatre" will deviate from its usual half-hour entertainment format in November to present a special one-hour television program on the field of education.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz of New York asked his fellow attorneys general today to fight business racketeers by supporting legislation pending in Congress.
WILTON, Conn., July 5 -- A 17-year-old youth barricaded himself in his room today, fired several times at policemen outside and then ended the siege by walking onto a porch and shooting himself.
Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., where the Governor gave a party in honor of King Phumiphol and Queen Sirikit. Mr. Goodman and the King had also played together in Thailand in 1956.

SALLY VICTOR has been called "the dean of American millinery design" and with good reason. Not only has she been in the business longer than any of her colleagues, but her popularity with fashionable women never has wavered.

GENEVA, July 5 -- The Soviet Union accepted today a British plan for assuring East-West parity in the top jobs of the projected international control organization that would enforce a ban on nuclear weapons tests.
ALBANY, July 5 -- The State Civil Service Commission today reported evidence of fraud in the examination papers of seventy candidates for police positions in Suffolk County between 1953 gnd 1957.
PARIS, July 5 -- Although the "feel" of prosperity is almost as strong as ever, the rate of economic expansion in Western Europe has actually slowed noticeably so far in 1960.
ATHENS, July 2 -- The Government of Greece has announced plans for the construction of a $207,000,000 industrial complex for the production of aluminum metal and hydroelectric power.

HAVANA, Wednesday, July 6 -- Dr. Jose Miro Cardona, Cuba's Ambassador-designate to the United States, broke with the Government of Fidel Castro yesterday. He requested asylum in the Argentine Embassy.

Formula Junior racing in the United States became "big time" two weeks ago in the Vanderbilt Cup race at Roosevelt Raceway. Last week-end at Lime Rock, Conn., it took another step toward becoming the keenest competitive event on the lists of the Sports Car Club of America.
A scheme in which six persons set up fifteen phantom companies at various times in the last five years and then closed them and collected $41,900 in unemployment insurance was disclosed last night.

MILWAUKEE, July 5 (AP) -- Rocky Nelson hit his second homer of the game in the tenth inning tonight and led Pittsburgh to a 5-4 victory over Milwaukee. The triumph lifted the Pirates' National League lead to four and one-half games.
Injuries in traffic in the city increased last week compared with a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. But traffic deaths declined.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- Attempts to bar dissident Southerners from the Democratic National Convention will probibly be confined to a few individual delegates, high party officials predicted today.

Sales of Essex Universal Corporation for the fiscal year ended on March 31 rose about 70 per cent to $17,977,110 from 510,613,820 in the preceding fiscal year, Joseph Harris, president, reported yesterday.
CIEGO DE A VILA, Cuba, June 21 -- The thick and matted growth of the marabu is again casting its blighting shadow over large areas of Cuban pasture land where only recently fat cattle grazed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A forward step has been taken by a group of distinguished lawyers and citizens in forming a committee to fight for the repeal of the Connally Reservation to our adherence to the International Court of Justice.

BOONVILLE, Ind., July 5(AP) -The first shipment of molten aluminum was transported from Aluminum Company of America's (ALCOA) Warrick works at Yankeetown today to General Motors' Central Foundry division plant in Bedford -- across 115 miles of rugged Southern Indiana hill country.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- Democrats formally opened pre-convention preparations today with the prospect of an early clear-cut test of strength between Senator John F. Kennedy and his combined opposition on a rules-change issue.

An analysis of recent shifts in the ranks of manufacturing centers, by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., disclosing some startling facts, could lead to revised thinking about marketing and sales. The results of the study, published in the latest issue of Dun's Review, the company's magazine, shows that Chicago ranks as the nation's major center, based on the total value added to raw materials and products in the industrial process.
Paul Hall, president of the Seafarers International Union, yesterday condemned visits to the Soviet Union by leaders of maritime and other trade unions.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The United States filed a vigorous protest today with Cuba against her seizure of two United States-owned oil refineries.
Striking workers at ready-mix concrete plants agreed yesterday to return to work this morning under a two-week extension of contract bargaining, an industry spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson announced today that he was a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
The Attorneys General of New York and New Jersey set up a program yesterday to aid one another in prosecuting business men engaged in fraudulent consumer operations carried on across state lines.
Steel output this holiday week is expected to plunge to its lowest level for a non-strike period in more than a decade.

Production of natural rubber lagged behind "demand in the first four months of this year, the Rubber Study Group of the Department of Commerce reported yesterday. A United Press International dispatch from Washington quoted the group as stating that production from January" through April was 630,000 tons and consumption 675,000 tons.
American tourists in France were promised "smiles as well as political stability" yesterday.
TUNIS, July 5 -- "Sooner or later real negotiation will impose itself" in the Algerian war, Premier Ferhat Abbas of the Provisional Government told the Algerian people tonight.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 5 (UPI) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr won nomination for a third term today. But one of the state's six incumbent Congressmen faced a fight to the wire with an old rival.

Richard M. Hexter has been named executive vice president and general manager of the Ovitron Corporation, Long Island City, Queens, manufacturer of electrochemical control devices. He was Eastern regional sales manager for Thompson Ramo Wooldridge Products Company, Cleveland, producer of jet engine and automotive parts.

Doubts and uneasiness on the business outlook have become nore pronounced among consumers, and optimism has shown a "marked decline," the University of Michigan Survey Research Center reported yesterday in Ann Arbor, Mich.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 5 -- This was reception day for 804 arrivals at the United states Military Academy -- 803 red-faced, breathless neophyte cadets and William Childs Westmoreland, who had been here before.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- The report of today livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ROME, July 5 -- Recent cases of students' jitters have brought forth authoritative appeals to the press and public not to sensationalize the examination season.

Hoffman International Stockholders of the Hoffman International Corporation at their annual meeting here yesterday approved a proposed two-for-one split of the common stock and raised the authorized common shares to 1,000,000 of 50 cents par from 500,000.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Republic of the Congo, July 5 (Reuters) -- Premier Patrice Lumumba declared last night a policy of "positive neutrality" between East and West for this newly independent republic.

An upstate radio newsman was credited with the capture of a paroled convict who last night admitted to New York detectives the slaying of two elderly Queens pensioners found dead Monday in their apartment.
PESHAWAR, Pakistan, June 22 -- A 9,000-foot airstrip bakes beneath a torrid summer sun here.
The unassuming dignity of a young King and the captivating smile of his radiant Queen won a multitude of admirers here yesterday.
YONKERS, July 5 -- P.J. Baugh's King Nola from Charlotte, N.C., scored his third straight victory of the season in the feature pace before 22,122 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

The appointment of Fred B. O'Mara as vice president in charge of production for the National Carbon Company was announced yesterday by James R. Johnstone, president of National Carbon, a division of Union Carbide Corporation.
Needham, Mass., is planning the sale of $2,300,000 of school bonds on July 13. The issue will be dated Aug. 1, 1960 and will come due serially on Aug. 1 from 1961 to 1979.

NEW DELHI, India, July 5 -- India will require $4,620,000,000 in foreign exchange to finance projects proposed in her third five-year-plan, which is to begin next April. The third plan calls for a total investment of the equivalent of $23,625,000,000.
Samuel Reshevsky as the United States drew in seventeen moves with Laszlo Szabo of Hungary yesterday in the ninth round of the chess tournament at Buenos Aires.
Clearances of many types of apparel, led by sportswear and vacation items, began In earnest yesterday under the impetus of heavy advertising.

OF the special bids used by the Italian team, which seemed to do nothing but win for nearly four years until unexpectedly it collapsed in the most recent world championship tournament, perhaps the bid most admired by American players is the two-bid to show a three-suited hand.

BOSTON, July 5 (AP) -- The twenty-two players picked by Manager Al Lopez to complete the 1960 American League All-star squad were listed yesterday by the league president, Joe Cronin. Two coaches, two batling practice pitchers, a batrang practice catcher and a trainer were also named.
Pincus Sober, the chairman of the "United States Olympic Track and Field Committee, began a campaign yesterday to send John J. Kelley to Rome.
MOSCOW, July 5 -- The Soviet Union fired a rocket into the mid-Pacific today and an official announcement said it had hit close to its target 8,078 miles from the launching pad.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- The third consecutive advance in grain futures prices today raised nearly all contracts by major factions to more than a cent a bushel on the Board of Trade.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 5 (AP) -- Max Conrad, a 57-year-old grandfather, set a world record for marathon flight today after 30 hours and 3,640 miles in the air.
The Transit Authority was afflicted yesterday with real and imaginary troubles.
A Buildings Department employe was suspended yesterday on charges of falsifying records for a contractor who sought special favors from Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco of Staten Island.

In the hot months, New York residents sometimes become "commuters" to the Jersey shore, "Solid Sam" Boulmetis, the 32-year-old jockey, uses a slightly different system. He lives on the Jersey shore in Asbury Park and commutes to Aqueduct.
The New York City Department of Health administered 507,770 Salk anti-polio shots to school children in the school year that ended last week, the department announced yesterday.
Two men who had been deputized by a patrolman to help him while he was being attacked by a narcotics suspect in Harlem were arrested yesterday for refusing to do so.
ROME, July 6 -- Communistled anti-Fascist mobs fought with the police in Rome today as the Italian Government's position weakened.

A state Supreme Court injunction barring the International Maritime Workers Union from interfering with the operation of Incres Steamship Company's two cruise vessels was upheld yesterday in a split decision by the Appellate Division.
LONDON, July 6 -- Anyone for tennis? Not lawn tennis, mind you, but real tennis, known in the United States as court tennis.
The economy seemed to be moving along "a high plateau" as the first half-year ended, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its latest Monthly Review.

Satellites and Dolphins There are surprises on all sides these days. Two of the latest have come from scientists. A radio-astronomer in California, R.N. Bracewell, has announced his belief that a satellite from another planet may be in orbit around our earth.

World sugar futures dropped 3 to 8 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a turnover of 16,400 tons yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trade selling offset buying by Cuban interests in the 1960 positions.

The Brunswick Corporation is expanding its operations in boat building through the purchase of the Larson Boat Works, Inc., of Little Falls, Minn. and its subsidiaries. Brunswick acquired the Owens Yacht Company last February.
ROME, July 6 -- An official inquiry into the Sicilian Mafia, conducted by the central Government and representatives of the national Parliament, is expected to open soon.

HAVANA, July 6 -- Armed with a new confiscatory law, the Cuban Government was prepared today to nationalize additional United States-owned property in reprisal for Washington's drastic cut in the Cuban sugar quota.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- President Eisenhower will be greeted with brass bands and a parade when he comes to Chicago on July 26 to speak at the Republican National Convention.

DAVID KIDD married Aimee Yu in Peiping eleven years ago. He is an American scholar who now teaches in Japan. His bride was a daughter of a statesman who had been Chief Justice of the Chinese Supreme Court. Their story is told in Mr. Kidd's new book, "All the Emperor's Horses"* -- chapters of which you may have seen in The New Yorker.

Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons -- supported by an assortment of cognate and marired Fitzsimmonses to the number of thirty-eight -- was the chief actor in a presentation tableau that took place in the new Aqueduct race track in the main lobby at noon yesterday.
Plans entailing large sums of new financing and investment for important phases, of economic development in countries of three major world areas were announced yesterday in Washigton and London.
BOSTON, July 6 (AP) -- Jack Kralick's four-hit hurling and a first-inning burst built on shoddy Boston pitching gave the Washington Senators a 4 -- 0 victory over the Red Sox tonight.

The Columbia Broadcasting System confirmed yesterday that "Eyewitness to History," which heretofore had appeared sporadically, would be televised each Friday from 10:30 to 11 P.M. beginning next fall.
CLEVELAND, July 6 -- More than 500 church leaders began discussion here today of a document that many believe will shape the future of the Protestant unity movement.
A saddle for a camel, when it is not adjusted properly, can be a treacherous thing.

Activity in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange broadened measurably yesterday. Prices moved narrowly. There was liberal evening up in the near-by July position. At the close, prices were 4 points (20 cents a bale) up on the current July delivery and 1 to 11 points (5 to 55 cents) off on the forward months.

Leonard N. Cohen, a West Side Democratic district leader, has lost his $13,000-a-year post as secretary to a State Supreme Court Justice following his club's action in calling for the ouster of Carmine G. De Sapio as county chairman.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- George Altman ruined the major-league debut of Ed Bauta, a 24-year-old pitcher, with a pair of three-run homers in successive turns at bat today as the Chicago Cubs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 10-1.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

TORONTO, July 6 (AP) -- Al Balding of Toronto toured the St. George's Golf Club course today with an eight-under-par 64 and took a two-stroke lead in the first round of the Canadian open championship.

Prices of United States Government and other prime-risk bonds surged forward again yesterday as the conviction widened in the financial district that a period of slackening business and lower interest rates than exist now lay ahead for the economy.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower said today that he hoped there would be no need to resume the testing of nuclear weapons and that some kind of permanent ban could be worked out with the Soviet Union.
A king's ransom in rough cuttable diamonds will be auctioned by the Bureau of Customs on July 27.
