GETTING in and out of taxicabs -- a local sport requiring Ilama-like agility -- should be more challenging than ever this fall with the new high hats. The latest designer to join in the tall millinery story being told and retold about town is Irene of New York, one of the best-liked women in the business.
Governor Rockefeller took personal charge last night of efforts to prevent a strike on the Long Island Rail Road at 12:01 A.M. Sunday.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 6 -- Dave Smalley of Larchmont, N.Y., John Marvin of Boston and Thomas Barrett of Madison, Wis., were the victors in three contests of the United States' semi-final Olympic tryouts in the Finn Class today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended June 29:

FREEPORT, L.I., July 6 -- Two speed-boat professionals from Florida, competing on strange waters amid lighthouses, harbors and buoys they could not recognize, won today's marathon around Long Island -- a grueling, always dangerous 280-mile boat race.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce came out today against a House-approved health care program for the aged and every other proposal before Congress for helping the elderly pay their medical bills.
NEW YORK is in the throes of a sandwich boom. It is a trend attributed to everything from air conditioning and the rise of new buildings to changing diets and shopping habits.
BALTIMORE, July 6 -- Whitey Ford, the fellow they used to give the ball to whenever serious trouble threatened the Yankees, returned to a familiar role tonight.
PARIS, July 6 -- There will be no open tennis championship in 1961 and perhaps not for some rears to come.
The case of Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan was given to the jury at 1:05 P.M. yesterday and, without reaching a verdict, it was locked up for the night at 1:33 A.M. today.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- General profit-taking today halted the three-day rise in grain futures prices as numerous contracts slipped major fractions to more than a cent a bushel.
Ten dedicated young men and women from England have just begun a summer of supervising children's recreation programs in settlement houses on New York's lower East Side.

ROME, July 6 -- Danilo Dolci does not look the part of the "Sicilian Gandhi." He is nearly 6 feet tall, pasty-faced and paunchy. His many Italian critics jeer that his repeated public fasts helped him to slim down a bit.

MILWAUKEE, July 6 (AP) -- Gene Conley, a 6-foot 8-inch pitcher, hit a three-run homer in the tenth inning and led Philadelphia to an 8-5 victory over Milwaukee tonight after the Braves had put down a rally with the National League's first triple play since 1958.
The English-Speaking Union of the United States will benefit at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sept. 28, when the Royal Ballet, formerly Sadler's Wells, will present "Ondine."

SYLVESTER GINTELL, former member of the New York Bridge Whist Club's team that won the Vanderbilt Cup, is now partly retired from bridge as well as business, but he still ventures forth occasionally from his retreat on the upper Hudson to play in a tournament.

The relief lightship at Ambrose Station was observed by shore radar in her proper location off New York Harbor minutes before she was rammed and sunk by an outbound freighter, Coast Guard investigators were told yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

Electric power production rose for the fourth consecutive time in the week ended last Saturday. Output totaled 14,247,000,000 kilowatt-hours, the highest level in four months, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it had named the chief of the Communist party organization of the city of Moscow as its Ambassador to Hungary.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter published on June 24 taking issue with your editorial of June 21 on "F.A.A. and the Pilots" James M. Landis conveniently misses your key point: that the walk-out by Eastern Air Lines pilots was in open defiance of a court order.

WALTER FLORELL is a designer who backs up his belief that all fashion parts must equal a well-coordinated whole. At one time strictly a milliner, now he creates hats to complement the clothes, coiffures and furs (added this season) that he also designs.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- Columbia Pictures has added three films to the slate of producer Jerry Bresler. One of these films, "The Flying Yorkshireman," has been in the Hollywood mills since 1938.

ALGIERS, July 6 -- A rebel group abducted fourteen Moslem dignitaries near Geryville, in northwestern Algeria, and later killed twelve of them, a French Army spokesman declared tonight. The victims included seven members of the Municipal Council elected under French auspices, he added.
The State of North Carolina borrowed $10,695,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance capital improvements.

Michael H. Prendergast, state Democratic chairman, and Carmine G. De Sapio, national committeeman, declared yesterday that New York's support for Senator John F. Kennedy had not been affected by Harry S. Truman's criticism of Mr. Kennedy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 6 -- A United Nations study group recommended today that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, "the statesman best capable of expressing the interest of the world at large," be invited to attend future summit conferences.
A NEW, unusual, and promising summer series of four free concerts opened in Greenwich Village last night with a program of contemporary music played in the Loeb Student Center of New York University.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 6 (AP) -- Leonard P. Sasso's Staretta hung on to score the first stakes victory of her career today in the $24,750 Miss Woodford at Monmouth Park.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 -- The temporary political headquarters of America: Pershing Square, Los Angeles * * * Dreamers and drifters and hecklers and defenders of lost causes, the Union Square of the West with palm trees.

Today's new film is "Elmer Gantry," a color version of the controversial novel about evangelism by Sinclair Lewis, at the Capitol Theatre, Broadway and Fiftieth Street. Burt Lancaster and Jean Simmons star in the United Artists release, with Dean Jagger, Arthur Kennedy, Shirley Jones and Patti Page in featured roles.

The insiders' list issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange shows that Harry Scherman, writer, editor and chairman of the Book of the Month Club, Inc., bought 5,000 shares of its stock on June 27 and that his wife, Bernardine Kielty Scherman, also a writer and editor, acquired 14,500 the same day.
LONDON, July 6 -- Selective but steady demand for British Government securities and industrial blue chips again were the highlights of today's business on the stock exchange here.
PARIS, July 6 -- President de Gaulle addressed a new appeal to the Algerian rebels today to end the fighting and participate in "the great work" of creating a new Algeria.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower disclosed today the Government's preliminary estimate that business activity rose only slightly in the spring, but to a record rate of $503,000,000,000 a year.

A huge Navy blimp on a search mission crashed into the Atlantic Ocean fifteen miles off the New Jersey coast yesterday afternoon. At least one of the twenty-one men aboard was killed and seventeen were reported missing.
LONDON, July 6 -- Hugh Gaitskell's leadership of the Labor party was threatened anew today as two major unions went on record opposing policies he advocates.

The Electrolux Corporation, manufacturer of vacuum cleaners and other household appliances, has leased two floors in the Pfizer Building, an office structure rising at 235 East Forty-second Street, northwest corner of Second Avenue.
The strike by 320 fuel truck drivers at New York International Airport moved into its sixth day yesterday, with no date set for mediating the wage dispute.
The United Steelworkers of America reported yesterday that it had come through the longest and costliest strike in steel history with a net worth of $26,440,807.
A former securities salesman was accused yesterday of having defrauded seven clients of a total of $111,940.
A New York Athletic Club foil team won the national championship last night at the Commodore Hotel in an exciting final.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Government borrowed $3,500,109,000 today at an average discount of 2.823 per cent. It borrowed the funds on an issue of 252-day bills that may be used to pay taxes due next March 15.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that its earnings after taxes were $36,699,253, or $2.73 a share, in the first six months of 1960.
The state and its employes' and teachers' retirement systems have made a formal commitment to supply $76,000,000 in mortgage funds for the Rochdale Village cooperative housing development, in Queens.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 6 -- Patricia Tiernan of Wheatley Hills, the defender, took a six-stroke lead with a 38, 36 -- 74 in the 54-hole medal-play championship sponsored by the Women's Cross Country Golf Association at the Cold Spring Country Club today.

CAMBRIDGE, N.Y., July 6 -- The fishing attractions of this part of Washington County are the Battenkill River, for brown trout, and two small lakes within a quarter-mile of each other, Hedges and Lauderdale, for bass.
Norman Thomas, spokesman for the Socialist Party-Social Democratic Federation, has given the Democratic platform committee his party's views on civil rights, other domestic issues and foreign policy.
A national advisory agency on education, free of Federal subsidy or governmental influence, was recommended yesterday by a leading educator.

The stage was set yesterday for further developments in the separate attempts of the New York Central Railroad and the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway to acquire major interests in the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 6 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer opened his bid for the British open golf championship with a three-under-par 70 today but the bubble burst for Gene Sarazen.

JOSEF KRIPS and the Stadium Symphony Orchestra played the second concert of their Beethoven festival at Lewisohn Stadium last night, with David Bar-Illan, pianist, making his Stadium debut as soloist in the "Emperor" Concerto.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP) -- Stan Williams pitched a three-hitter and walloped a three-run homer for the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight in besting the San Francisco Giants, 10 -- 0, before 51,863 fans.
Senator John F. Kennedy interrupted his Cape Cod vacation yesterday to fly here to confer with J. Raymond Jones, powerful Harlem poltical leader.
President Eisenhower's news conference yesterday touched on a subject much discussed in military intelligence circles: the dangers of a Soviet base in the Western Hemisphere.

GENEVA, July 6 -- The United States joined the Soviet Union today in formally approving a British plan for allotting the main posts in the projected control organization for policing a ban on nuclear weapons tests.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- Measures beyond economic sanctions were demanded today against the Castro Government in Cuba.

The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would begin the "educational phase" of its anti-littering campaign in the subways this week-end. This is to be followed immediately by a crackdown on offenders.

SYRACUSE, July 6 -- The unusual will be seen along with the routine tomorrow as the three-day United States Olympic rowing trials start on Onondaga Lake.
DETROIT, July 6 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics pushed across two runs in the eighth inning tonight on two hits and a wild pitch to give Bud Daley a 6-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y. July 6 -- The havoc wrought by power shovels and sledge hammers at two revered landmarks in Sleepy Hollow has begun to make sense to residents of the valley. For three years most had been baffled by the continuing destruction.
KLAGENFURT, Austria, July 6 -- Premier Khrushchev warned Austria today that her neutrality would be imperiled if the United States used its rocket bases in northern Italy against the Communist world.

The worst airship accident in history was the 1933 crash of the dirigible Akron in a thunderstorm off Barnegat, N.J., in the same area where the Navy blimp crashed yesterday. Seventy-three lives were lost in that accident.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower rejected today Governor Rockefeller's recent charge that the President had permitted United States defenses to deteriorate in the face of increasing Soviet military might.

Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that he would not decide whether to dismiss or reinstate Purchase Commissioner Joseph V. Spagna until after his return from the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Four railroad unions, representing about 200,000 workers who operate trains, proposed today that the work rules dispute be submitted to a study commission composed of representatives of the unions, the railroads and the public.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 -- Robert F. Kennedy predicted today that the outcome of the Democratic National Convention would be decided by noon Monday, five hours before it opens officially.
The first steps toward automation of its atomic power equipment plant at San Jose, Calif., have been taken by the General Electric Company, it was announced yesterday.

Hail to Reason returned to stakes-winning status yesterday in the $37.800 Tremont Stakes at Aqueduct. The chestnut colt owned by Patrice Jacobs moved smoothly to take the five-and-a-half-furlong sprint by three lengths over Frank Sherman's Bronzerullah.

The United States Committee for Refugees and the publishing house of Doubleday have announced the winners of the jointly sponsored Refugee Award. First prize of $500 was awarded to Mrs. Claire Hedervary, a Hungarian-born Belgian citizen and an Auschwitz survivor now living in Great Neck, L.I., for her nonfiction book, "Broken Bridges."
Oliver Smith, who of late has served the theatre in the dual capacity of designer and producer, will sponsor Carol Channing this season in an intimate revue called "Showgirl."
A restaurant employes' union won the right yesterday to continue "informational" picketing of the Stork Club during hours that would not affect deliveries by members of other unions.
LUCHON, France, July 6 -- The Tour de France bike race is scenery, sport and circus all in one. It is steep mountains, agonizing climbs, harrowingly swift descents.

LONDON, July 6 -- Little-known facts about the State of New Jersey are being turned up by a United States history professor digging into British origins.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- A two-run homer by Roy Sievers in the ninth inning gave the Chicago White Sox a 7 -- 5 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight before a crowd of 22,966 it Municipal Stadium.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- Soviet newspaper readers, who subsist on a heavy diet of ideological and economic comment, were treated today to a report of a mail robbery and three killings.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 -- Following is the official program for the Democratic National Convention. All times are Pacific daylight saving time, which is three hours earlier than New York time.

President Eisenhower's decision yesterday to reduce Cuba's sugar quota in the United States by 700,000 tons, almost her entire unfilled allotment for this year, focused attention on the methods used to control the amount of sugar that may be marketed in the United States.
Although "big" stocks held their ground and the market averages slipped only a little, recent favorites, especially those in electronics, staged a bear market of their own yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 6 -- The Soviet Union's most traveled canine astronaut, a fluffy white mutt called Otvazhnaya, or Courageous, soon will be ready to start training for her sixth rocket flight into the upper atmosphere, Moscow newspapers reported today.
The International Shoe Company set a record for sales in the six months ended on May 31 the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday. Earnings rose 22 per cent above the 1959 level.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your June 28 news story on the Labor Department's report on productivity in 1959 does not altogether check with the Government agency's report. The record should be straightened out.
A company to manufacture several new types of synthetic rubber has been formed as a joint venture by the Stauffer Chemical Company and American Synthetic Rubber Company, it was disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, July 6 -- The soaring auction value of Impressionist and modern French paintings on the London art market was demonstrated today in one of the season's richest sales.

The British Labor party brought out a number of fascinating and sometimes spectacular figures in the last thirty years. Among them none was more outrageously attractive than Aneurin Bevan. He was one of those men who aroused passions in others because he was passionate and provocative himself. And with it all he was, in the hackneyed phrase, the salt of the earth.

NEW HAVEN, July 6 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it intended to outline tomorrow a "blueprint" of questions about the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's plans, and that it expected the carrier to answer them.
An investigation was begun by Governor Rockefeller yesterday into the parole of a convicted slayer who was arrested Tuesday night on a charge of killing two elderly men in Queens.
At Herbert H. Lehman's Park Avenue apartment there are more than 150 boxers. But the neighbors never complain, for all the dogs are ceramic.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 -- No matter who is nominated for the Presidency by the Democratic National Convention, he will have two movies campaigning for him.

UNLESS a cruel fate perversely hammers him down again, Theodore Samuel Williams, a spry old codger of 41, soon will pass Master Melvin Ott in the home-run standing and move into the exalted No. 3 place on the list. Still ahead and slightly out of reach will be Jimmy Foxx with 534.
A new controversy has developed between parents and school officials in a rezoned school district on the East Side.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The deep divisions over individuate and policies that exist in the Democratic and Republican parties will plainly appear at the Los Angeles and Chicago conventions, and then be glossed over as much and as long as possible in the interest of getting their candidates elected.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 -- Northern scouts ran into Southern outposts today in the opening skirmish of the quadrennial Democratic conflict over a civil rights plank.
The Illinois Bell Telephone Company borrowed $50,000,000 in the public market yesterday at an interest rate of about 4.8 per cent.
Samuel Reshevsky, the leader in the international chess masters' tournament at Buenos Aires, drew in the tenth round yesterday with Bobby Fischer, his successor as the United States champion.

BENSON, Ariz., July 6 (AP) -- Members of a small religious sect have sealed themselves in their homes and church, apparently awaiting an atomic attack from which they expect to be the only survivors, a sheriff's officer reports.
SEOUL, Korea, July 6 -- The Korean Cabinet rejected yesterday a proposal by a joint Korea-United States economic board for a joint study of plans to formulate South Korea's national budget.

After months of oratory, volumes of testimony and countless dire predictions, the final Congressional action on the 1961 defense appropriation bill differed only in slight degree from Administration recommendations.
YONKERS, July 6 -- Adios Butler is expected to meet his toughest competition tomorrow night in his first free-for-all race.

Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Republican National Platform Committee, conferred here for nearly three hours yesterday with Governor Rockefeller. Later he said he believed the Governor and Vice President Nixon had "a community of interest on many basic issues."
The King and Queen of Thailand saw the sights in Manhattan yesterday -- and themselves became a sight-seeing attraction to many hundreds along the way.
CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP) -- Bob Skinner hit an inside-the-park grand-slam home run in Crosley Field tonight that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 5-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.
The New York State Motor Vehicles Commissioner may not deny a driver's license solely because the applicant is a Communist, Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy ruled yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 (UPI) -- Feature Sports, Inc. has filed an application with the State Athletic Commission to stage the third Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson bout in Los Angeles, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Eisenhower virtually ended today Cuba's sugar sales to the United States for this year.

LONDON, July 6 -- Twenty years ago when London was burning and the Germans were winning the war, Aneurin Bevan was one of an irrepressible group who sat out the air raids in the grill room of the Savoy Hotel.

Republic Glass Corporation of Manila announced yesterday the start of operations by its new window and sheet glass plant near the Philippines city. The $5,000,000 plant, which incorporates advanced automation equipment, was said to be the first producing sheet glass in the Philippines.
LONDON, July 6 -- Aneurin Bevan, the happy warrior of British socialism, died peacefully in his sleep this afternoon. He was 62 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission charged today that Inland Container Corporation, Indianapolis, violated the antitrust laws when it bought the Louisville, Ky., plant of the General Box Company in 1958.
Dr. Barbara Moore of Britain, the walking vegetarian, limped briskly into Times Square last night after having hiked 3,387 miles from San Francisco in eighty-five days.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 6 -- Elements of the Congo's army mutinied today.
Plans for a new motion-picture theatre to be constructed on the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street were announced yesterday by Charles B. Moss and Associates.
The Grand Union Company posted the highest first-quarter earnings in its eighty-eight-year history, according to the statement issued yesterday by Thomas C. Butler, president.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class 1 rail carriers during May at $47,000,000. This compared with $72,000,000 in May, 1959 and $27,000,000 in May, 1958.

Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, now a declared candidate for President, said here yesterday that the Democratic National Convention would be a "good clean fight, free of religious, racial or regional prejudice."

CHICAGO, July 6 (UPI) -- Automatic Canteen of America, Inc. has been negotiating during the last two months for acquisition of Nationwide Food Services, Inc., an industrial feeding concern. Nationwide had sales last year of $20,000,000, according to Automatic Canteen's announcement.
PARIS, July 6 (AP) -- American dancer Gene Kelly invaded the musty confines of the Paris Opera tonight with a leggy, sexy modern ballet that shook the crystal chandelier.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that the Eisenhower Administration had failed to grasp the fact that urbanization was "America's No. 1 domestic problem."

THIS would be a good week to switch to a vegetarian diet. Following seasonal increases in wholesale prices, several cuts of meat have gone up at retail. These include pork loins and center chops, chuck steaks and chuck roasts.

CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP) -- Bob Skinner's two-run double in the top of the ninth capped another of the Pittsburgh Pirates' late inning rallies tonight as they scored a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.
Fortified by an almost forgotton court ruling of 1928, Tiffany Co. is bringing a taxpayer's suit today to stop the city from building Huntington Hartford's gift cafe in Central Park.

CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) -- Billy Pierce pitched the Chicago White Sox to a 9-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight as the Sox swept the two-game series.

The President, at his Wednesday news conference, brought up a subject that has been a matter of considerable speculation and comment in business and financial circles during recent weeks. This is the unusual severity of the traditional daily summer decline in steel production, whose seasonal low point is frequently associated with the July Fourth holiday.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 -- Michael H. Prendergast said today he was planning to call a caucus of the New York delegation Tuesday morning in anticipation of a floor fight on civil rights at the Democratic National Convention.

YONKERS, July 7 -- Adios Butler, handling a star-studded field of free-for-allers with comparative ease, won the $25,000 All-America Pace in 1:59 1-5 before a cheering crowd of 30,169 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
"Laughter's a Funny Business," a television series offering an analysis of humor, its motivations and responses, will lake its debut at 11:30 A.M. Sunday over Channel 4.

DETROIT, July 7 (UPI) -- A strike, vacations and the loss of a work day because of the July 4 holiday will drop car and truck assembly in the United States to its lowest point of the year this week, Automotive News said today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., -- July 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission warned the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad today that it could not expect public funds unless it adopted a "whole new concept" of operations.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 7 (AP) -- A second straight 67 enabled Roberto de Vicenzo of Mexico to retain the lead at the halfway mark in the British open golf championship with 134 today. Arnold Palmer of Latrobe, Pa., was seven shots back.

Operations of the Corning Glass Works and its subsidiaries in the first half of this year resulted in consolidated profit of $12,353,269, equal to $1.81 a common share, the report disclosed, yesterday. The figures excluded a non-recurring capital loss of $2,308,132 resulting from the sale of investments.

Ralph E. Casey, president of he American Merchant Marine Institute, bluntly criticized yesterday the "further study" attitude of most of the sixty-three nations represented in London at the recent International Connention for the Safety of Life at Sea.

SYRACUSE, July 7-Stirring finishes in all three eight-oared heats provided the excitement today as the weeding-out process started to determine the American rowers who will go to the Olympic Games in Rome next month.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $28,000,000 to $440,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements dropped $46,000,000 to $443,000,000 from a revised figure of the preceding week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Knowing your desire for accuracy as to fact and for objectivity in editorial opinion, I am convinced that your editorial of June 30 "Mr. Celler and the Governors" resulted from a basic misconception as to the nature of the Judiciary Committee's inquiry into the activities and operations of the Port of New York Authority and from misinformation about the Judiciary subcommittee's proceeding on June 29.

TRENTON, July 7 -- Ned J. Parsekian, acting State Motor Vehicle Director, today announced that beginning Aug. 1 his department would crack down on New York residents who registered their vehicles in New Jersey.

"HOME is where the heart is" is a familiar adage. To judge from the experience of the Department of Agriculture, the converse is equally true. Its ten most popular publications all concern the home. And the fact that four of the top five are related to food seems to demonstrate considerable preoccupation with this aspect of home life.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Marine Corps has ousted a young Bronx man who had been involved in the American Nazi party headed by George Lincoln Rockwell.

BALTIMORE, July 7 -- Taking inventory of their natural resources as the American League pennant race nears the halfway mark, Manager Casey Stengel and General Manager George M. Weiss agreed today on what the Yankees needed most to keep themselves on top.

MILWAUKEE, July 7 (UPI) -- Warren Spahn needed a double play to take him out of a bases-filled jam in the ninth inning, but retired twenty-one straight batters tonight and allowed only five hits as the Milwaukee Braves shut out the Philadelphia Phillies, 2-0.
A 51-year-old man working as a porter in a Westchester mental hospital turned up yesterday as an heir presumptive to $250,000 left by a scrap metal dealer in Scotland.
LOS ANGELES, July 7 -- Four days before the first bang of the gavel, traditional frenzy, confusion and mystification took over the scene of the Democratic National Convention today.

The Medical Arts Building, an eleven-story structure containng twenty-three combination apartment and professional offices at 1882 Grand Concourse, southeast corner of Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Joseph Simon. The building occupies a plot 190 by 70 feet.
A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that special patrolmen employed by the Sanitation Department had no power to issue summonses charging disorderly conduct.

THE invigorating, thinking and candor of Walter Lippmann, columnist for The New York Herald Tribune, were brought to television last night in an hour-long interview on "C.B.S. Reports" over Channel 2.
Reports yesterday indicated that the slump that had been plaguing furniture, large appliances and some other household products had bypassed television sets and radios.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Radio contact has been lost with Pioneer V. Thus has ended the useful life of a space vehicle that established a record of comnuncating over nearly 23,000,000 miles and made several major discoveries about the solar system.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 (UPI) -- Stan Musial drove in three runs today with, a basesfilled single and a sacrifice fly and led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-3 victory over the fading San Francisco Giants.

THE fountain at the Plaza should have flowed champagne this week when Bergdorf Goodman introduced its fall millinery in Miss Jessica's famous custom department. A special excitement swept the occasion as the result of the presence of Sirikit, Queen of Thailand.
Bumpy-Road had smooth going in the main race of Aqueduct yesterday. The 5-year-old owned by Mrs. Irving Gushen took the six-furlong event by live lengths under the guidance of Sam Boulmetis.
LAUREL, Md., July 7 (AP) -- Bally Ache became the first entry today for the ninth $100,000 Washington D.C. International on Nov. 11.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 -- James Leonard Reinsch has the impeccable, unruffable appearance of a man for whom carnations and lapel-buttonholes were invented. He manages to maintain this suave facade, behind gleaming spectacles and beneath precisely wavy brown hair, despite the demands of a job that he has compared to "producing 'Ben Hur' for a one-night stand" -- namely, staging the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United States apparently will pay its customary premium price for sugar to replace the 700,000 tons cut from Cuba's quota, despite a suggestion by Agriculture Secretary Ezra Taft Benson that the lower world price might be paid.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 7 -- Patricia Tiernan of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club, the defending champion, matched par with 37, 37 -- 74 today for a two-day total of 148 and a thirteen-stroke lead in the Women's Cross County Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship.
Chicago, Ill., borrowed $37,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance expansion of the street lighting system and other public improvements.
The City Council declared unanimously yesterday that wherever possible further construction of high-rent or luxury apartment houses in slum clearance areas should be avoided.
A strike of between 15,000 and 25,000 non-operating employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad was called yesterday to start "at midnight July 25 or some days thereafter."
ROME, July 7 -- A Communist-called strike failed to tie up Rome today but resulted in the killing of four persons and the wounding of twenty in a northern Italian city.

A group headed by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. offered yesterday $24,000,000 of twenty-year 5 3/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of the Mississippi River Fuel Corporation priced at 99.7Q per cent and accrued interest to yield about 5.40 per cent to maturity.
Jeno Hamori, a Hungarian refugee now living In Philadelphia, captured the national saber championship in a fenceoff at the Commodore Hotel last night.
"Good wife certificates were awarded last night to the wives of night students who received degrees from New York "University's College of Engineering.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended July 2 were 15 per cent above the level of the 1959 period. There was one fewer selling day in 1959, because of the Fourth of July holiday fell on Saturday.
The chairman of the State Parole Board yesterday defended the board's action last month in freeing a convicted killer who on Tuesday, admitted slaying two elderly Queens men.

THE cold-blooded realists long have insisted that there is no place for sentiment in baseball, pointing out examples of dire consequences that often followed the yielding to emotions. But they are wrong. The naming of Ted Williams and Stan Musial to the All-Star squads gave a warm glow to every fan, just as was the case a year ago.

World sugar futures opened weak but closed sharply higher yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The market dropped 5 to 10 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) at the opening.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- America's export total for May was $1,791,500,000 a trifle lower than in April, but about one-sixth, higher than in May, 1959, the Department of Commerce reported today.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 -- A challenge was filed here today in an attempt to bar a member of the Virginia delegation from the Democratic National Convention. However, officials of the convention Credentials Committee said that the welcome mat was out for Southern Delegates as a whole.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission added two names to its "restricted" list of Canadian stocks today, with a special warning to the American public.

Loans to business by the fifteen member banks in New York City that report weekly declined to $124,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday. That compares with an increase of $16,000,000 the week before and a drop of $44,000,000 in the 1959 week.

CLEVELAND, July 7 -- The movement for Protestant unity passed a major milepost here this afternoon when the three-year-old United Church of Christ unanimously adopted a constitution designed to "glorify God continually and to serve Him everywhere."

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals affirmed today the conviction of Alden Whitman, a copy editor for The New York Times, on charges of contempt of Congress. Mr. Whitman refused to identify one-time fellow-Communists for the Senate Internal Security subcommittee in January, 1956.

A biography of Premier Khrushchev by George Paloczi-Horvath, called "Krushchev: The Making of a Dictator," is planned for Sept. 21 publication by Atlantic-Little, Brown. The author, an ex-Communist, says the Premier, unlike Lenin and Stalin, is entirely the product of the party "apparat," a personality molded by forty years of living and working within a totalitarian regime.

LONDON, July 7 -- Industrial shares continued their advance on the stock exchange here today. Interest was again centered on the recognized leaders, many of which rose a shilling (14 cents) or more. Gains of a few pence were common among second-line shares.
SANTANDER, Spain, July 7 (Reuters) -- The editor of America, Roman Catholic weekly in the United states, said today that freedom of the press was essential.
A woman lawyer in Queens has gone to court to try to force the county bar association, exclusively male since it was founded eighty-four years ago, to admit her.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- A late rally sent soybean futures well ahead today on the Board of Trade but the grains continued under light to moderate pressure and finished in a steady to weak range.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill granting a new tax break to the mining industry despite the Treasury's earlier insistence that the "special tax relief" was not justified.
HAVANA, July 7 -- Premier Fidel Castro pictured Cuba today as a small, valiant country standing firm under a staggering blow to its economy by an imperialistic United States.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 7 -- Garbage dumped by a private concern next to a radio tower in the Hackensack Meadows has put gremlins in the broadcast signals, the owners of Station WMGM charged in a suit filed here today.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 7 -- The six nations of the European Common Market were confronted today with the toughest test to date of their willingness to become an economic unit.
A 12.6 per cent increase in the last decade has brought the number of general care hospital beds in New York to 37,427.
LOS ANGELES, July 7 -- Southerners cautioned the Democratic National Convention today against taking action on civil rights so "extreme" that it would drive the South out of the party.
MOL, Belgium, July 7 -- Prince Albert of Belgium dedicated today a new processing plant for used atomic-fuel elements.

Loft buildings in Manhattan had a vacancy rate in April of about 2.5 per cent, compared with 2.9 per cent a year ago, the Real Estate Board of New York said yesterday. The decline in available space was attributed largely to an increase in demand by light man acturing concerns.
Plans for using the city's transit, parking and public safety facilities to cope with any emergency caused by a strike on the Long Island Rail Road next Sunday were announced at City Hall yesterday.
The city's newly acquired little white whale arrived at the Coney Island Aquariam yesterday "in better shape than the men who brought it."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 7-- One hundred and two teams learned today that sub-par scores were necessary to qualify in the John G. Anderson Memorial tourney at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

HAVANA, July 7 -- Cuba pegged the price of her sugar at 3.25 cents a pound today in a nove to offset the loss this year af 856,000 tons in sales to the United States.
"The Queen and the Rebel," the Italian drama that Ugo Betti wrote in 1949, four years before his death, has been acquired for Broadway presentation next winter.
The advisory council to the state's Youth Employment Service announced yesterday a stepped-up program to find permanent jobs for youths 16 to 19 years old.
Governor Rockefeller urged yesterday the resumption of underground nuclear testing by the United States to pave the way for a vigorous and realistic effort to achieve armament control.

The nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday declined 2,526,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The decline reflected in part the heavy demand by motorists prior to the Fourth of July holiday.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 7 -- President Eisenhower got off to a good start on a golfing vacation here today after a flight from Washington to the naval air station at Quonset Point.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 7 -- Austria announced today that she would ask the 1960 session of the General Assembly to endorse "a true autonomy' for the German-speaking inhabitants of the South Tyrol, known to Italians as the Alto Adige.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 7 -- Mrs, Harrison R. Weaver of the Scarsdale Golf Club, Mrs. George Bishop of the Pelham Country Club and Mrs. E.C.K. Finch of the Country Club of New Canaan each finished 4 up in match play against par at Mount Kisco today.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., formerly Loew's, Inc., yesterday reported its earnings for the forty weeks ended June 9 were at a twelve-year high of $7,317,000. They represented a gain of 18.8 per cent over the 1959 period, when $6,152,000 was cleared.

THERE will be no need for a second biography of Thomas Wolfe, now that his former literary agent, Elizabeth Nowell, has performed the job so thoroughly. "Thomas Wolfe"* is a long and straightforward account of the literary and personal trials of the American novelist who, more than any other, was the central character of his books.

VIENNA, July 7 -- Premier Khrushchev seemed subdued and tired tonight as he declared on television that the Soviet Government was prepared to sign a disarmament agreement based on controls if the Western powers were willing.

Dr. Barbara Moore, Britain's walking exponent of vegetarianism, took a constitutional around Central Park yesterday.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 6 points up to 2 points off yesterday, with the distant positions inclined to lag. Trading was slow and price movements highly restricted. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 8 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission, expects to have a small nuclear reactor that can produce a continuous atomic explosion early next spring.

ALBANY, July 8 -- A new Legislative committee was appointed today to overhaul the state Alcoholic Beverage Control Law and investigate other aspects of the liquor industry.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 (AP) -- Nineteen - year - old Ray Sadecki pitched a four-hitter and 39-year-old Slan Musial supplied the power tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals beat San Francisco, 7 -- 1.
HARTFORD, July 8 -- The United Aircraft Corporation appeared headed today for a prolonged strike after the collapse of negotiations late last night.
MEXICO CITY, July 8 -- Robert C. Hill spent more than an hour with Foreign. Minister Manuel Tello this evening. The usually affable American Ambassador appeared grim after the talk.
ABOARD S.S. LEONARDO DA VINCI, at Sea, July 8 -- Italy's newest passenger liner has been designed to be the safest ship in the country's merchant marine.

WEST ORANGE, N.J. July 8 -- Wes Ellis of Mountain Ridge carded a five-under-par 33, 34, 67 today and led the pros in the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association pro-senior tournament at the Crestmont Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Elsenhower "Atoms-for-Peace" program has failed for lack of international leadership by the Administration, according to a study prepared for the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy.

Lambert Feasley, advertising agency, has leased two and one-half floors in the building being constructed by Uris Brothers at 850 Third Avenue, between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets. The space contains 32,000 square feet and will be occupied early next year.
LOS ANGELES, July 8 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson arrived in Los Angeles today displaying the gray in his hair with new aggressiveness. He predicted victory some time after the second ballot.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 8 -- President Eisenhower called Secretary of State Herter to a conference here next Monday to discuss the comprehensive plan of mutual assistance between the United States and all Latin-American republics except Cuba.

JERICHO, L.I. July 3 -- Patricia Tiernan of Wheatley Hills finished with a 37, 38 -- 75 at the Meadow Brook Club today and a three-day total of 223 to retain her Woman's Cross County Golf Association medal play championship.

A FASHION show that brought out some of the best hatted heads to be found in any audience took place yesterday when the Fashion Group presented its annual fall millinery show and luncheon at the Astor Hotel.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- A forecast of clear and warmer weather over the week-end set off fairly active liquidation in new crop corn and soybeans today on the Board of Trade and prices for these futures weakened.

The National Union Electric Corporation has further diversified its activities through the purchase yesterday of the Durham Manufacturing Corporation, Muncie, Ind., producer of folding metal furniture. Terms were not disclosed.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 8 -- Every available member of this city's 275-man Police Department was ordered to join the search today for the hold-up man who shot and killed a 27-year-old patrolman last night.
