TO THE EDITOR: I read with more than ordinary interest your article about Helen Keller "At 80 -- The Miracle of Helen Keller" (June 26). I was doubly interested in that reference to Miss Keller's great affection for Jo Davidson, because of the fact that it was I who first introduced Helen Keller to him.

To the Screen Editor: TO Bosley Crowther's recently published list of German pictures that have teen shown with notable success in this country, I should like to add two that, even though not yet generally released, were highly honored at this year's Oscar contest.

AUCKLAND, N.Z. -- It is winter now in this half of the world, and New Zealand is launching a drive to develop a winter tourist season comparable to its summer one. Until now, New Zealand's appeal to United States tourists has been as an escape from the North American winter, since down here it is high summer when the northern hemisphere is in the grip of snow and storm.

Keenation of the Elkcam Stable had lust enough left to hold off the closing challenge of the Pebble Brook Farm's Irish Lancer in the Peter Pan Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. At the finish of the mile-and-an-eighth race it was Keenation by a nose over Irish Lancer. The next horse, the favored Francis S. of the Harbor View Farm, was seven lengths farther back.

CONCRETE terraces which are poured in grid form have become popular with suburban homeowners. The surface is broken up into a series of squares by strips of redwood. Pattern and texture are achieved Toy treating with partially exposed aggregate.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 9 -- The Yugoslavs are seeking, and seem likely to get, international financial backing to take an unusual step for a Communist-ruled nation.
A program started two years ago to prevent urban blight by refinancing and improving marginal properties has proven so successful that it will be expanded to satisfy the demand.
SYRACUSE, July 9 -- An inspired Navy varsity crew, which had shown improvement with each appearance this season, won the eight-oared final today at the United States Olympic trials.

HOLLYWOOD. THOUGH much of the talk in the movie industry last week was about the Democratic convention due to start tomorrow at the near-by Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena, the big dream was about pay-television.

Nostalgia for old New York's Newspaper Row has been stirred by the recent announcement that a skyscraper will be erected in the area facing City Hall Park, a part of town virtually untouched by the building boom.
Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany remained tied, 8 -- 4, for the lead in the international chess masters tournament yesterday at Buenos Aires.
A farmhouse model has been introduced at Colonial Park in Glen Cove, L.I. The colony, milt by Sol M. Klapper and Abe Kaplan, is on a sixty-acre tract on Porter Place.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 9 -- A fleet of fifty-four yachts, including an eight-time winner named Chanteyman, was entered in the Riverside Yacht Club's twenty-ninth annual Stratford Shoals race, starting tonight.

TO the rich but dwindling tradition of melting-pot fiction, this atmospheric little book brings a distinctive savor and an unsung milieu -- the Spanish colony of Brooklyn. As in most other immigrant enclaves, the special folkways of the Spanish in New York are going the way of the trolley car.

THE time has come for a new scholarly synthesis of the now almost legendary period in American history between the accession of Warren G. Harding and the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt. What we need most is some fresh thinking about the Twenties.
LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- Organized labor's spokesman, George Meany, made the rounds of the Democratic Presidential aspirants today in behalf of labor's platform proposals.
About a thousand office jobs lave been lost to teen-agers this summer because of a tightened interpretation of the laws controlling the employment of minors.

A FEW months ago, I abruptly was confronted by a gifted, but highly effusive, actress, intently devoted to an inspirational Broadway play in which she was then starring. Having learned that the work had failed to inspire me, she proceeded to defend its merits, emphasizing its effect on audiences.

TO THE EDITOR: My husband and I visited Cuba recently and found communism to be as inconsequential there as it is in the United States. Therefore we read your article on Major [Che] Guevara ("Shadowy Power Behind Castro," June 19) by Tad Szulc with considerable interest, expecting that your writer had unearthed a story totally obscure to Cubans.

TO THE EDITOR: As one who has often used The Times as a model in teaching high school English. I regret finding a misleading error in it. I refer to "Playing Political Possum Isn't Easy" (June 26) by Henry F. Graff.
A vice president at Lane Bryant rues the agreement he has made with a social agency to provide short-term jobs for former mental patients.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 9 -- President Eisenhower is planning to make the strongest possible demand to the Congress when it reconvenes next month for completion of his legislative program and against unbudgeted appropriations.

GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK, Wyo. -- While vacationists by the thousands view the lofty Grand, Tetons through their automobile windows as they speed through Jackson Hole, about twenty-four tourists a day are seeing meadowlands, mountain ranges, osprey, eagles and moose from slow-moving floatboats on the Snake River.

Letters Abroad, Inc., a voluntary, nonprofit affiliate of President Eisenhower's People-to-People Program, will benefit from a preview of the paintings from the Hallmark Art Award international fine arts competition.
Utter simplicity in dividing space in a home often leads to the most livable layouts. An example of this may be found it a house completed recently in the Sterling Forest community near Tuxedo, N.Y.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 9 -- Kel Nagle, a one-time woodcutter from Australia, smashed Arnold Palmer's bid for a golf grand slam today by winning the British Open championship with a record-tying 278. A stirring comeback by the American champion fell one stroke short.

WHEN one considers the multitude of Westerns published since the turn of the century it is not difficult to understand why writers in this field often fail to come up with fresh situations. The wonder is that there are so many good ones.
TOBAY BEACH, L.I., July 9 -- The completion by the Town of Oyster Bay of a two-mile waterfront recreation area on Long Island's south shore was observed at a ceremony here today.

Closed circuit television is being used to give tenants and prospective tenants at the Colonnade Park Apartments in Newark a panoramic view of that city's changing skyline as well as of the surrounding countryside.
Two more countries are seeking to attract the registration, foreign-owned merchant shipling under their flags.
The concept of the merchant mariner as a nautical maverick -- a picture part fancy, part fact -- is changing.
HOLLYWOOD, July 9 -- Show business seems to have much stronger appeal for politicians than politics has for Hollywood show people.

AT this time of year almost every garden, no matter how small, yields some flowers and foliage for cutting. Whether blooms are cut from herbaceous plants, shrubs or trees they should be given a period of conditioning before being arranged.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 9 -- Coming from well off the pace, William B. MacDonald Jr.'s 4-year-old filly, Royal Native, won the fifteenth running of the $28,950 Molly Pitcher Handicap at Monmouth today. Reginald N. Webster's Quill was second. Miss Orestes, who won last year, was third.

EUGENE, Ore., July 9 -- Rafer Johnson smashed the world decathlon record today with a sensational series of performances that won the National Amateur Athletic Union title and put him on the United States Olympic team.

This page -- Chinchilla rises like skyscraper in a tall toque that will be one of the luxury items of the season. Made to order by Bob Greene of Irene. Worn with these strong hat shapes are jeweled earrings the size of small ear muffs. These, Miriam Haskell.
COLORADO SPRINGS, July 9 (AP) -- A total of $55,000 Boy scouts will attend the Fifth National Boy Scout Jamboree from July 22 to July 28.

The nation's wheat growers are in the midst of harvesting another near-record crop. Produced on a minimum national allotment of 55,000,000 acres, or some 25,000,000 fewer than in the World War II years, this bumper crop of bread grain reflects the improved efficiency and know-how of American agriculture.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- The Conference on Economic Progress said today that President Eisenhower's tight money policy had produced wasteful costs at all levels of government, raised unemployment and increased inflation.

A ranking union leader, sureying the record of recent national wage settlements, summed up his reaction last week in this glum epitaph: "We certainly didn't need an armored truck to take home the gains we won in the big negotiations this year. We could have used kiddie kar."
CINCINNATI, July 9 -- "There is no single cause of delinquency, likewise there is no single program of delinquency prevention. This means that [we] must be free to try out new ideas and programs."

TORTOLA, B.V.I. -- It is always delightful to return to an idyllic vacation spot and discover that it has not changed or, if it has, perhaps a little for the better, After a four-year absence, we sailed once more into the emerald archipelago of the Brittish Virgin Islands and were happy to find that their tranquillity and natural beauties had not been disturbed.

For Americans, and especially for business men, the big news of the week came from Cuba. Seizure of the foreign oil refineries by the Cuban Govrnment was followed by a sharp cut in the American sugar quota for that country by President Eisenhower.

IN the translator's own words, this short novel by Rene Daumal is "an adventure tale bordering on science fiction, encompassing poetic and broadly comic passages, leading into spiritual quest." It is the posthumous work of an anguished and venturesome Frenchman who had apparently found inner peace before he died in 1944, at the age of 36, after a long illness and a We of intense intellectual speculation.

AN energetic grandmother approaching her seventy-ninth birthday, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, better known to New York's Stadium Concerts attendees as "Minnie," combines (as one writer has said) the speech habits of Casey Stengel and Mrs. Malaprop.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 AP) -- Ernie Banks' homer in the twelfth inning and Don Elston's relief pitching carried the Chicago Cubs to a 7-6 victory over San Francisco today. It was the Giants' fifth consecutive loss.
The sleek and elegant Leonardo da Vinci is the latest example of the ability of Italian shipbuilders, artists and interior decorators to produce ships that are beautiful without and within.
HARTFORD, July 9 -- After twenty-eight years, history has repeated itself for Connecticut's delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- After five years of controversial discussion, financing of the proposed Pinellas Bayway System of roads, causeways and bridges near here finally has been completed, and construction soon will get under way.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 9 -- Elderly persons here will receive a questionnaire in September designed to determine their recreational, economic and health needs.

The academic year just ended has produced a treasury of new cliches. Since some of them are replacing old familiar jargon, with which readers of educational journals and speeches have learned to live more or less comfortably, the time seems ripe for an abridged dictionary of the educational cliche of 1959-60.

TRAVELERS around the globe or parts thereof will find both ideas and picture-taking counsel in sixty-print color show that opened last week at the Kodak Photographic Information Center in Grand Central Terminal.
A nine-room Colonial dwelling has been opened at Greenway, a thirty-two house development east of Rivervale Road, near Blakeney Place, in River Vale, N.J.

BILLED as a popular history at our political wars since 1860, "Jumbos and Jackasses" deals mainly with the fifty Democratic and Republican national conventions during a century of two-party conflict. The book itself has much of the character of a convention; usually vivid and entertaining, sometimes a bit dull and repetitious, often ridden with cliches but sometimes rising to real eloquence.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 9 -- The old order and the new meet in the Anderson Memorial golf final here tomorrow. Bob Brownell and Ralph Bogart of Washington, who have competed in this top flight four-ball competition for fourteen years, clash with the young Connecticut team of Don Hoenig and the 18-year-old Jimmy Grant.
More than 55,000 tax forms have been sent out to truck and other commercial-vehicle owners in the city in anticipation of the first deadline of July 25 under a new city law.

OSCAR and I have been working together for over eighteen years consistently and continuously. In all that time I think I can say with complete safety we have had only one unresolved argument and that was over a matter of short pants versus long ones.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 18 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist rulers are worried about the way things are going down on the farm. They want more meat, butter and potatoes -- but so far not much attention has been paid by the farmers to the demand.
SOME day in the future -- in 1985, perhaps -- an aging professor in some conservatory or university will sit beside an organ console listening as a gifted student plays.
The bond market is free from strain for the first time since the business recession of 1957 petered out in the spring of the following year.

EVERYBODY who hunts in New York State next fall for the first time will have to complete a four-hour course in firearms safety before getting a license. The courses will be given by authorized instructors whose addresses will be supplied by the license-issuing agents.
The country's stores are making ready in a big way for the onslaught of the buying public for back-to-school merchandise and fall apparel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The (extraconstitutional) party nominating-convention method of choosing our Presidents has more defects than could easily be enumerated, but a few minor reforms would at least cure some of them.
NEXT to Albert Schweitzer's own autobiographies this book gives a more intimate view into the life, work, purpose and spirit of Dr. Schweitzer than any this reviewer has read.

ALBANY, July 9 -- Following is the text of a memorandum for the 1960 Republican party platform, submitted today by Governor Rockefeller to Charles H. Percy, chairman of the platform committee of the Republican National Convention:
The nation's best-known home builder began work last week on another suburb.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 9 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus is telling Arkansas voters that the issue in the July 26 primary is whether they will give him a fourth term or "surrender the state to a puppet Governor" of "hard-core integrationists."
The days of most lightships that have stood watch off the coasts of the United States since 1820 appear numbered.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., July 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Olga Fikotova Connolly of Los Angeles, although complaining about the take-off area, won the discus throw in the women's division of the Amateur Athletic Union national track and field meet today.
THERE are only two bidding conventions that go back beyond contract bridge to its predecessor, auction bridge. Both are defenders' conventions, designed to make partner bid his best suit.

AN exhibtion of bonsai (potted dwarf trees), introduced by Yuji Yoshimura, will be on display from Tuesday through July 23 at Takashimaya, Inc., 562 Fifth Avenue. Accessories for mailing bonsai -- including turntables, tools, soil, moss, training wire and washed sand -- also can be seen.
In a converted Navy ammunition chamber housed in a basement at 550 First Avenue scientists are compiling some of the facts of life in an atomic age.
A strike shut down the Long Island Rail Road at 12:01 A.M. today after a last-ditch peace effort by Governor Rockefeller had collapsed.

AS Khrushchev blustered and threatened before the cameras of the world last May, there were moments when he appeared to be calling off his challenge of economic competition in favor of a competition RAYMOND VERNON n a professor of international trade and investment at Harvard's Graduate School of Business Administration. much grimmer. Today, however, the theme of competitive economic coexistence seems on the ascendancy in the Kremlin once again.

MEXICO CITY. Here in Mexico City last Thursday new vistas of opportunity were opened for Mexico's 600,000 orthopedically handicapped citizens with the formal dedication of the Mexican Institute for Rehabilitation by President Adolfo Lopez Mateos.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 9 -- Tom and Dave Pryor, with Pelican, led a seventeen-boat Lightning Class fleet across the finish line in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's interclub session today. There was a seven-knot northerly wind.

FARMINGTON, Conn., July 9 -- After nine sporting group victories, Ch. Sam of Blaircourt, a black Labrador retriever, was named best of show for the first time, in the twelfth annual dog show and obedience trial of the Farmington Vailey Kennel Club at the Farmington Valley Polo Club today.

The Department of the Interior officially standardized the spelling of 436 place names throughout the country yesterday. Most of these had borne the same, or approximately the same, names for generations anyway.
HAVANA, July 9 -- Americans who have lived in Cuba as long as thirty years are sorrowfully leaving in the face of an intensified hate campaign by Premier Fidel Castro.

A combination masonry and panel facde is being used in an apartment house under construction at 79 West Twelfth Street, at the Avenue of the Americas, giving the building strong horizontal lines. The aim is to create a Continental effect in keeping with the scale of the neighboring Greenwich Village houses.
LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- The battle over the Democratic civil rights plank shaped up today as one with the big guns on the Northern side.

LONDON, July 9 -- "The pulse of progress beats differently for different parts of the world," Aneurin Sevan, who died this week, once wrote. Nowhere is this more true than in Africa, where differences in political, economic and social conditions among individual countries have caused continent-wide turbulence that is a challenge to Africans and, in differenet senses of the word, an opportunity for the, Western world and the Communist bloc.

VIENNA, July 9 -- The United States and West German Ambassadors protested today for the second time in forty-eight hours against the Austrian Government's passivity in the face of Premier Khrushchev's daily attacks during his visit on their countries and government heads.

LEO KERZ came back from Europe the other day resembling no one so much as your wife fresh from a fling in a Paris salon. Mr. Kerz came back, loaded with projects, none of which, like the little lady, he could resist.

Leading analysts for Wall Street firms are not gloomy about the future. Predictions of imminent collapse of the market are virtually absent. But here and there are veiled suggestions that the investor might be wise to sell now and pay capital gains taxes on some of his holdings -- notably those in "big" stocks or in stocks with elephantiasis of the price-earnings ratio.

LONDON, July 9 -- An Esso petroleum, company tanker exploded while unloading crude oil at Milford Haven, Wales, early today. The chief steward jumped overboard and was drowned. Three other members of the fifty-five-man crew and a fireman were injured.
Independent tanker operators declared yesterday that an attempt by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) to curtail the chartering of vessels to the Soviet Union "was doomed to failure."

The headlong rush of the Africans into independence has been enormously complicated by their backwardness. The majority of them -- illiterate, living for the most part in primitive tribal societies in the bush --have no conception of what independence means.

A man who allegedly hurled lye at a group of card players in Harlem yesterday was beaten by a crowd of fifty persons. Ten of the card players, one passer-by and the attacker himself were injured by the lye.

The island of Cuba, set in the Caribbean Sea ninety miles off the Florida keys, is smaller (44,206 square miles) than the state of New York, and has fewer people (6,466,000) than the City of New York. Cuba's total national income (about $2.7 billion) is less than the U.S. spends on cosmetics.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 9 -- Jane Paige, racing the International sloop Hotel for only the fifth time, registered a bristling victory as Orienta Yacht Club conducted the Yacht Racing Association regatta for a fleet of 135 craft on Long Island Sound this warm and sultry afternoon.

ROME, July 9 -- At least ten persons killed, several hundreds more or less severely injured, and Some thousands arrested or detained -- this is the heavy balance sheet of one week's rioting out of a blue sky in several Italian cities.
WARREN, Ohio, July 9 (AP) -- Louise Suggs, the leading money winner on the women's golf tour, fired her third straight sub-par round today for a five-stroke lead in the $16,000 Trumbull open.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 9 -- The New York Athletic Club's forty-seventh annual Block Island predicted-log event was won today by Mrs. Beatrice L. Miller in her 40-foot Punkin III with an accuracy score of 98.95 per cent.

HUNDREDS of Democratic delegates are streaming into Los Angeles today, lining up for hotel rooms, unpacking their noise makers and beginning the delegation meetings, corridor caucuses and buttonholing that will last almost nonstop for six days.

IN all probability, the most eloquent advocate dramatic ballet has ever had was Jean Georges Noverre, whose "Lettres sur la Dense et sur les Ballet" was published just 200 years ago. His Book, a classic of dance literature, has run into many editions and been translated into many languages, even including, most recently, the Korean! It is indestructible, because its principal thesis is as valid today as it was in 1760.
A Brooklyn architect believes that abuses and scandals in the building field could be eliminated if licensing of builders were required.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, July 9 (AP) -- Violence erupted today in two eastern Congo areas, where rebellious African troops killed two Europeans. This first slaying of Europeans by Africans in the current disorders served to hasten the mass flight of whites from the seething Congo.

ONE of the great scientific events of our day has been the awakening of interest in oceanography. Several factors converged to give this century-old science a transfusion of cash, talent and glamour that has made it very likely the fastest-growing scientific field.
LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- More than 5,000 cheering supporters of Adlai E. Stevenson gave him a tumultuous welcome late today upon his arrival at International Airport.

TAKANABE is a town of 20,000 on Kyushu, the southernmost island of mainland Japan. A number of its leading citizens have provided further evidence of how musicians from, one nation can serve as bridges to the people of another.
LIMA, Peru, July 3 -- Peru is exploring measures to curtail the overproduction of fish meal.
THE first substantial experiment in broadcasting financed by listeners rather than by sponsors has encountered a variety of difficulties.

LELAND HAYWARD, Who produced a television special last January titled "The Fabulous Fifties," may do another next season. It would be among the several specials that "General Electric Theatre" plans to present over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

To the Travel Editor: I hold the dubious honor of batting 1000 on oversold bookings for flights to Indianapolis. Twice now I have brought my wife and child to the airport well in advance of departure time, only to be informed that the flight had been oversold and that they could not be accommodated.
A $130,000 increase over the previous year in sales of works of art, antiques and home furnishings was reported yesterday by the Plaza Art Galleries.
Hulan E. Jack announced yesterday he would not resume the duties of Borough President of Manhattan for the immediate present.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Tougher housing codes are the key to effective urban renewal, officials of the National Association of Housing and Redevelopmen said in a report this week. It was critical of courts that thwart this purpose.
BARRANQUILLA, Colombia -- Steaming up the Magdalena River from this port in Colombia on a towering old sternwheeler must be much the way it was traveling on the Mississippi a half century ago.

RAILROAD excursions are continuing to gain in popularity. In this area, the Long Island Rail Road has scheduled a series of Saturday trips to supplement its twenty-eight Sunday tours. A 300-mile, all-day rail and bus trip to Montauk and Riverhead is slated for July 23 and again on Aug 13.
TO THE EDITOR: YOUR recent review of Seymour Krim's "The Beats" is illustrated by a photograph (see below) captioned "Beat pad in San Francisco." The picture was taken in my apartment.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 9 -- An emergency dental service plan to provide care when the family dentist is not available on week-ends and holidays was announced today by the Tenth District Dental Society.
ALGIERS, July 9 -- The most important thing that happened here in recent weeks was that nothing happened on the day of the arrival on French soil of the first nationalist rebel delegates.

AFTER leaving St. Elizabeth's and before setting out for Italy, Ezra Pound was persuaded by his publisher, James Laughlin, to read some of his poems before a microphone. Caedmon, alert and responsible, has now issued the LP disk, Ezra Pound Reading His Poetry.
Manhattan's garment center', which for decades was primarily a manufacturing area, today puts more emphasis on modern showrooms and sales offices.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 9 -- The problem of over-supply is worrying the Texas oil industry, The present indications are that it will take about three years for the demand for oil to catch up with the supply.
LIMA, Peru, July 9 -- A high-level United States financial study mission will arrive here Tuesday for a direct look at Peru's land and housing problems.
New York's first preview of "Tenderloin," a musical comedy starring Maurice Evans, will take place on Oct. 11 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. It will benefit the New York City Mission Society.
YONKERS, July 9 -- The Thunderbird Stable's Tyson Scott, driven by Hugh Bell, scored a half-length victory over Great Lullwater in the $10,000 Monitor Trot before 32,866 at Yonker's Raceway tonight.

THE PLACE The Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena, built last year, is two and one half miles west of downtown Los Angeles, where the Democrats have their headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel. It seats 2,950 on the arena floor and 13,050 spectators in the press section and balconies.
LAKEHURST, N.J., July 9 (AP) -- Seventeen Navy divers struggled today to cut free a wrecked blimp at the ocean's bottom.

To the Travel Editor: We would like to take this opportunity to congratulate you on your penetrating article, "Turbulence on the Airways," which appeared on June 26. It is our opinion that you have done the air traveler a great service by bringing some of the facts mentioned in your article to the attention of the Civil Aeronautics Board, the Federal Aviation Agency and ail the collective airlines, as well as the public at large.

THE debacle at Newport last week-end, when a battle between the police and collegiate beer-can bombardiers outside the park where the Newport Jazz Festival was being held led the City Council to cancel the last three programs of the festival, caused some musical aspects of this year's festival to be overlooked even while it brought into very sharp focus some extra-musical matters.
BERKELEY, Calif., July 9 -- Universities in the United States trying to solve problems related to the cost of providing higher education have been advised to pool their resources.
BONN, Germany, July 9 -- Premier Khrushchev has cried wolf so often on West Berlin that his latest threat against the city has caused scarcely a ripple in this capital.

THAXTED, England. LAST winter, in the Essex village where I have been spending a year, I met a young woman whom a friend had described as "jolly keen on horses." She was blonde and handsome and reminded me of Strindberg's Miss Julie.
The air freight industry is faced with a problem of which should come first -- the right airplane that will build up the business or the business that will permit the development of the airplane.

COZAD, Neb., is a pleasant little town (pop., 2,190) on Highway 30 in the valley of the Platte River. About fourteen miles east of it is Lexington (pop., 5,068), also a comely town today, though at one time, as the unsavory Plum Creek, it virtually belonged to Print Olive, most notorious of Nebraska outlaws.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 9 -- Sand drains as much as 130 feet deep, the longest yet to be used in highway construction in New Jersey, will be employed to stabilize a one-mile stretch of the Bergen-Passaic Expressway through the Overpeck Creek Meadows.

Trail THE newspapers recently carried a story that the Senate Government Operations Committee was seeking a way to stop traffic in pornographic literature -- without getting into the realm of improper censorship.

LA FORET-FOUESNANT, France -- Brittany, tucked into the far western rim of France, stands more apart from the rest of the country than any state, including Alaska, does from America. Not only is it isolated from the rest of France physically, but so is the thinking of its people, so is their mode of life.

LONDON. JUST what is Picasso after? What has been going on in the pictures that for nearer seventy than sixty years have been erupting from this volcano of modern art? Such questions, and others, ring through all the echoing chambers of twentieth-century esthetic controversy and are by no means still yet.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The dam of patience in dealing with the regime of Fidel Castro finally cracked this week. Acting on the authority given him by an angry Congress, President Eisenhower virtually eliminated further imports this year of Cuban sugar.

BALTIMORE, July 9 (AP) -- Harmon Killebrew hit two home runs today as the Washington Senators defeated Baltimore, 7--2. The loss was the Orioles' fourth straight and their sixth consecutive setback at home.
CHICAGO, July 9 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox scored five runs in the first inning today and beat the Cleveland Indians, 8 -- 4. The victory lifted their winning streak to four straight games.
TELEVISIONS quadrennial spectacular starts tomorrow with the opening in Los Angeles of the Democratic National Convention, followed two weeks later for the Republican version in Chicago.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey has been chosen to place Gov. Robert B. Meyner in nomination at the Democratic National Convention. The Governor is New Jersey's "favoriteson" choice.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- The remains of an early Phoenician settlement have been found beneath the ruins of a Roman City by the Libyan reconnaissance expedition of the Univernity of Pennsylvania Museum.

CAIRO, July 9 -- Nearly all Cabinet ministers of the Egyptian and Syrian regions of the United Arab Republic gathered in Cairo today for the opening of the first General Congress of the National Union.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 9 -- "Why fire the coach, and break up a winning team?"

BERLIN. FOR twelve busy days and nights this city was submerged in flags and youthful film fans. They were the most conspicuous evidence of the tenth annual Berlin International Film Festival, which ended last Tuesday night.
BOULDER, Colo., July 9 -- Three Supreme Court Justices joined 272 other Judges and lawyers from around the country here this week for a conference on the administration of the Federal courts.
LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- John Fitzgerald Kennedy, the tousle-headed Senator from Massachusetts, flew in here today to the sound of trumpets.

A novel type of bulk carrier capable of unloading and loading two kinds of material at the same time with its own equipment is now operating in the Gulf of Mexico. The vessel is the 523-foot Martha Mac.

The movement for some form of national education planning gained high-level support last week when Dr. John H. Fiseher, dean of Teachers College, Columbia University, urged the establishment of National Council on Education. He called for a group, chartered by Congress, such as the American Red Cross, but financed by foundations, local school boards and other groups rather than by Federal money.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- The business of putting words in convention orators' mouths has come a long way since erratic "prompting" scrolls were pressed into service, with many a hitch, at the political conventions in 1952.

IN the fall of 1912, Bulgaria, Serbia and Greece abruptly mobilized against the great putrescent empire of the Ottomans. The tiny hill state of Montenegro had no regular divisions to mobilize, but in mid-October its militia struck through the Albanian hills, the allies followed, and the First Balkan War began.

To the Travel Editor: MAY I fire the first shot in the annual batttle of returning travelers and United States Customs personnel (Idlewild species) ? That the Customspeople have a job to do, a job that requires a certain intrusion on one's privacy, is not questioned, but I strongly protest that this job does not have to be done in a rude, surly and insulting manner.

ALTHOUGH it is only twenty-two miles off the coast of India, the island of Ceylon has a personality all its own. In an orderly and affectionate manner, Christine Weston writes about every aspect of this "lush, beautiful, blue-encircled" island.

JACKSON, Miss., July 9 (UPI) -- Mississippi, under the administration of Ross R. Barnett as Governor, has given its official blessing -- and financial aid -- to the Citizens' Councils, which seek the preservation of racial segregation.
LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- The Democratic convention looks, sounds, and even smells exactly like every other big political blowout of the last twenty years, but it Is not the same.

ROME, July 9 -- Riots are not usually featured in a Roman holiday. Hotels and travel bureaus here received a few cancellations today, but most American tourists appeared to regard the political riots as an added sight-seeing attraction.

THE pianist Hephzibah Menuhin, like her violinist brother Yehudi, began as a child prodigy. Unlike him, she did not continue her performing career. Now married to a sociologist and living in London, Miss Menuhin makes recordings when in the mood.

It is easy to regard a national political convention as more spectacular than significant. The popular interest is indicated by the fact that the convention that opens in Los Angeles tomorrow will have almost twice as many reporters and commentators in all media as there are delegates and that its television and radio audience may be a hundred million.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Giving older persons "a larger purpose in life than just staying alive," is "a task of prime importance for education in our times," a pamphlet prepared for next January's White House Conference on Aging emphasizes.

LOS ANGELES, July 10 -- In the days when Los Angeles was still the City of the Angels and movie producers had just graduated from puttees, a Democratic Convention here among the palms could have been explained in easy socko phrases understandable without a degree in political science or parapsychology.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 10 -- Wilbur Ketcham sailed his Definances to victory today and gained series tie with Bud St. John's Tomahawk in the Narrasketuck Class as the Narrasketuck Yacht Club's week-end invitation regatta came to a close.

A NYONE with a passion and palate for the exotic fare of the Far East would travel far to find a restaurant that fits the bill better than the recently opened Mi Cin at 130 West Forty-fifth Street (between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas).
LOS ANGELES, July 10 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey emerged tonight as the last of the holdouts among the favorite-son candidates in the North.
A happier, fuller and more significant life lies essentially through simple living, a Canadian minister told a congregation here yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 10 -- Reliable sources said tonight that Dr. Raul Roa, Foreign Minister of Cuba, would call on Dr. Jose A. Correa of Ecuador, president of the Security Council for July, tomorrow morning.
LOS ANGELES, July 10 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said today that as President he would be prepared to recommend higher taxes if necessary to make move secure the nation's defense.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 10 -- Robert Miller's thirty-two-foot ketch Souffle won the Riverside Yacht Club's twenty-ninth annual over-night race to Stratford Shoal and back today.
LIMA, Peru, July 10 -- "We have a year to work. Then the elections will be upon us."

DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 10 -- Chancellor Adenauer said today that the people of East Prussia must have the right of self-determination.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Roy Sievers belted a three-run homer and capped a five-run, sixth-inning rally that carried the Chicago White Sox to a 6-4 victory today after the Cleveland Indians had won the first game of a double header, 6 -- 2.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 10 (UPI) -- Ramanathan Krishnani of India and Luis Ayala of Chile entered the final of the Swedish international tennis tournament today.

A partial tie-up of operations on the Pennsylvania Railroad added last night to the hardships created by the day-old strike on the Long Island Rail Road. The Long Island tie-up is expected to cause a wide traffic jam today as a result of the increased use of buses.
LOS ANGELES, July 10 -- Former President Truman said today that he definitely would not come to the Democratic National Convention.
PITTSBURGH, July 10 -- Inventory cutbacks and depressed demand from some of the major consumers was the principal reason for the recent poor production schedules in the steel industry.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The ten-day-old Government of the Congo has been 'out of effective office' for the last twenty-four hours and Belgian troops are taking control, State Department officials said today.

HAVANA, July 10 -- The rally that Premier Fidel Castro was to have addressed today was the occasion of the most elaborate display of security measures witnessed in Havana since the Cuban revolution a year and a half ago.

The Automatic Canteen Company of America has entered the commercial financing field through the purchase of the Commercial Discount Corporation, Chicago-based finance company. The transaction involved $5,882,994.

Keeping abreast of the trends in the many-faceted, highly competitive food business is one of the most difficult jobs facing executives in that field. The task would be an impossible one were it not for research specialists, whose function is to keep track of trends and interpret them for food industry executives.
LONDON, July 10 -- Britain rejected tonight a request from the Premier of Katanga Province in the Congo for the assistance of troops in Northern Rhodesia in restoring order in the province.

Samuel Reshevsky of the United States took the lead from Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany yesterday in the thirteenth round of the international chess masters tournament at Buenos Aires, according to South American news sources.

A newly formed manpower council outlined a program yesterday to help workers in the city who do not earn much to improve their skills and earn more.
The rule books were thrown out yesterday when thirty-three cars raced in the Greenwhich Village Motor Sports Club's annual all-in-Manhattan rally.
LOS ANGELES, July 10. -- If Senator John F. Kennedy is nominated for President, his Democratic National Chairman will be the first non-Catholic in that post since 1928.

THE bride who has Princess Margaret's figure but lacks her exchequer may find the preparation for her wedding an ordeal. Since bridal departments in stores carry standard sizes the young woman tries on a gown, looks in the mirror and finds a sorry image.
Long Island taxi operators reported a sharp drop in business yesterday as the first effect of the Long Island Rail Road strike.

America's Midwest is the subject of an anthology, edited with introduction and commentary by Walter Havighurst, which Coward-McCann will issue Sept. 26. CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- New crop soybean and corn futures hit or reached the fringes of their highest levels of the season last week on the Board of Trade but failed to hold the peaks.

BALTIMORE, July 10 (UPI) -- Jim Lemon hit a two-out homer in the ninth inning, his twenty-first of the year, as the Washington Senators scored a 2-1 victory over the fading Baltimore Orioles today.

Picket lines at Pennsylvania Station spread the effects of the Long Island Rail Road strike to the Jersey side yesterday, but commuter service between New York and New Jersey was not immediately threatened.

A strong case exists for the abandonment of Roman Catholic efforts to have laws enacted against contraceptives, a prominent Catholic scholar declared in a report presented here yesterday.

Proceeds from the Oct. 13 performance of "Irma, La Douce" will further the work of Greenwich House. The Marguette Monnot-Alexandre Breffort musical, starring Elizabeth Seal and Clyde-Revill, is scheduled to open at the Plymouth Theatre on Sept. 29.

A new Census Bureau report just released contains important implications politically, socially and economically for the nation. The study, though it doesn't come entirely as a surprise, reveals that for the first time in the nation's history fewer than one person in ten is counted as living on a farm.
JERSEY CITY, July 11 -- International League baseball will return to this city and Roosevelt Stadium at 8 P.M. Friday after an absence of nearly ten years.

Market values on the New York Stock Exchange slipped a little more than $3,000,000,000, or 0.89 per cent, yesterday. The primary cause seemed to be word that Soviet fighters had downed an American plane over the Barents Sea.

Atlas Copco A/B The directors of Atlas Copco A/B, Swedish maker of air compressors and pneumatic equipment, announced yesterday an increase in its capital stock of 562,500 shares. The increases will enable the company to acquire the Swedish Diamond Rock Drilling Company, known in many countries as the Craelius Company.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 11 -- The office of Suffolk County Children's Court Judge was elevated today from a part-time to a full-time job at $25,000 a year. The change is effective Sept. 1.
DETROIT, July 11 (AP) -- One of the nation's largest makers of automation machinery announced today it was bidding on a big Russian order of auto engine manufacturing equipment.

NOTTINGHAM, England, July 11 (Reuters) -- England beat the touring South African cricket team by eight wickets today and took a 3-0 lead in the five-match test series. England finished with 287 and 49 for two to South Africa's 88 and 247.

IF there is an opening for a gimmick, Mr. Arnold will find it. This imaginative designer offered a series of adjustable hats in this week's presentation of his fall hat collection. His designs are ingeniously put together so that a pyramiding cloche can be crushed to small beret proportions, pouffs of tulle can be detached to disclose small satin evening hats, or extended turbans can be tucked up close to the head.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Justice Department said today it had found no evidence that any Federal law had been violated in the West Virginia primary on May 10.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Organized labor virtually wrote its own ticket in the Democratic platform today.

YONKERS, July 12 -- Darcie Hanover, a bay by Scotch Victor -- Desira Hanover, owned by Ted J. Zornow of Pittsford, N. Y., and driven by Levi Harner, scored a neck victory over the favorite, Carlene Hanover, in 2:15 2/5 in the $26,405 Hudson Filly Trot before 20,562 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 12 -- The nation that emerged to replace Belgium's mid-African colonial empire twelve days ago asked today for United States and Belgian troops to keep the country together and end bloodshed.

Benny (Kid) Paret, the world welterweight champion from Santa Clara, Cuba Knocked out Garnet (Sugar) Hart of Philadelphia in 2:36 of the sixth round in the mail event at Madison Square Garden last night.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- The astonishing civil rights plank in the Democratic platform signifies a major shift in the controlling forces of the party in the last four years.
KENILWORTH, Ill., July 12 -- Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Republican Platform Committee, predicted today that the committee would achieve "absolute harmony" on a civil rights plank.

ROME, July 12 -- It may take only ten minutes to cook spaghetti al dente, but it took Rome nearly ten years to organize its couture fashion show under one roof. For nearly a decade the Italian couture has been split right down the middle.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Ten Southern states fought in vain tonight to prevent the Democratic National Convention from adopting the toughest civil rights platform plank in party history.
GENEVA, July 12 -- The United States proposed today the creation of a pool of Western and Soviet nuclear explosive devices open to inspection and use by both sides.

ALTHOUGH the watermelon has become such an integral ingredient of the American picnic, it has not always formed part of the local scene. The fruit is actually native to Africa, where it was popular with the African native.
SEATTLE, July 12 (AP) -- A contract for research and development of the solid-fuel Minuteman ballistic missile was signed here today by the Air Force and Boeing Airplane Co.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 12 -- The Shorehaven Golf Club team of East Norwalk, Conn., today won the Ike golf tournament by two strokes. Jerry Courville and Mike Vitti scored 292 for two rounds at Whippoorwill and Tamarack.
Sales and earnings of the General Electric Company in the second quarter and first half of this year dropped from the levels of the 1959 periods.
NEW DELHI, India, July 12 (Reuters) -- Five persons were killed today and more than 2,000 were arrested as a nationwide walkout by Government workers gathered momentum.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Convention enthusiasm has slumped like a bride's souffle. It's like an old-time movie house, where the operator mixed up the reels and showed the ending too soon.

Samuel Reshevsky of the United States strengthened his hold on first place in the international chess masters' tournament in Buenos Aires yesterday with a score of 10 -- 4, according to South American news sources.

A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the City of New York could not collect the sales tax it assessed against a Brooklyn business man on the value of an automobile he had traded in on a new model.

Once more the crying need for a permanent United Nations police force is illustrated by the urgent call for help from the new Republic of the Congo. If such a force had existed, there would have been no occasion for the Congolese Government, harassed by violence, mutiny and secession, to ask yesterday for United States troops to restore order.
Merck Sharp Dohme, drug manufacturers, announced here yesterday that the United States Public Health Service had released 120,000 doses of its new Salk type of vaccine against poliomyelitis.
The form players among the 25,065 racing fans at Aqueduct had a fine day yesterday. On the nine-race card, public choices came through with six victories, including the feature event.
MEXICO CITY, July 12 (UPI) -- Three thousand Mexican university students marched past the United States Embassy tonight chantiing "Cuba yesYankees no" and tried to burn an American flag.
EVERY bridge student learns fairly early that he should not waste trumps by unnecessary ruffing. Trump length in declarer's hand usually means control of the entire hand.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- More than 2,000,000 high school and college students and graduates joined the nation's labor force in June, adding substan tially to employment and to unemployment as well.

The Democratic party platform is severe in its criticism of the conduct of foreign policy by the Eisenhower Administration. It calls for regaining "the initiative on the entire international front" and a new regime that will "at long last speak with a single confident voice in world affairs."

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday that it had arranged to borrow $240,000,000 in United States dollars and Deutsche marks from the Central Bank of Germany for twelve years at a 4 1/2 per cent interest rate.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- The bearish Government crop report set off a rather heavy volume of liquidation in corn futures today and all contracts closed in a weak range.

World sugar futures were weak early in the session on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday but recovered most of the losses and closed at or near the highs of the day. Final quotations were 2 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) up to 2 off on 22,250 tons.
HAVANA, July 12 -- The Havana University Student Federation today demanded the resignation of the university's Governing Council in its fight to control the university.

Norrkoeping of Sweden and Rapid of Vienna, Austria, will meet in an International Soccer League match at the Polo Grounds tonight. Each team lost by one goal last Sunday during a league double-header. Each is looking for its first victory of the league season.

Stocks related to national defense held their ground fairly well yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Coppers also rose, but other groups were weak as the list gave up more than $3,600,000,000 -- 1.1 per cent -- in market value.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 12 -- The New York Yacht Club, usually concerned with races for cruising yachts up to seventy feet long or a little better, ran one today for children sailing pumpkin-seed-sized boats.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. predicted today that Senator John F. Kennedy could not carry New York as the Democratic Presidential nominee.
Ail innocent motorist who paid a traffic ticket to avoid the trouble of fighting the case in court got his money back yesterday -- with an apology from the city.
Governor Rockefeller urged yesterday that an inter-American conference of foreign ministers be called for next month to map hemisphere action to meet the threat of internationa communism.
The state board of inquiry set up on orders from Governor Rockefeller failed yesterday in its first effort to settle the Long Island Rail Road strike.
The United States Court Appeals broadened its attack on wiretapping here yesterday to include "any evidence obtained as a result thereof" by the New York State police or prosecutors.
The committee planning the autumn theatre benefit for the George Junior Republic had its final summer luncheon meeting recently.

JERSEY CITY, July 12 -- The leasing of Roosevelt Stadium to the International League farm club of the Cincinnati Reds, until last week known as the Havana Sugar Kings, was approved today by the city commission by a 4-to-0 vote.
Emma Willard School alumnae in the metropolitan area will hold a benefit art exhibition and dinner in observance of national Emma Willard Day on Oct. 26.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo asked Secretary General Dag Hammarskjoid today to provide "military assistance" for his hard-pressed Government.

The Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks informed Pan American World Airways yesterday that a new three-year contract had received sufficient votes to ensure ratification. The contract provides for a 38-cent-an-hour package increase.

BUFFALO, July 12 (AP) -- Ward Wettlaufer, a Walker Cup star, sank a 3-foot birdie putt on the 373-yard, par-four first hole at the Country Club of Buffalo today and enabled the United States to score its second straight extra-hole victory over Canada in the Carling Cup golf series.
A solemn crew-changing ritual necessitated by the Long Island Rail Road strike forced the suspension of two early morning runs yesterday on the New York, New Haven and Hartford.
Legal technicalities and amliguities are hampering the Board of Education in its eforts to modernize the adminstration of the city school system.

In 1567, Sir John Hawkins sailed from Africa with a fleet of slavers destined for the Gulf of Mexico and the Spanish colonies in defiance of Spanish law. Overcoming storms and mutiny and navigating uncharted seas his venture was almost successful.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Senator John F. Kennedy promised today to introduce in Congress next month an emergency farm bill to attack what he called the "No. 1 domestic issue."

Securities of American Can Company valued at $50,839,000 are being placed on the market by underwriting groups. A new issue of $40,000,000 of the paper and metal container company's 30-year 4 3/4 per cent debentures due 19990 is being offered today at 100.80 to yield investors 4.70 per cent. Morgan Stanley Co. and Clark, Dodge Co. managed the offering group.
Expansion, according to those in charge, "never came up" yesterday, even though there were baseball meetings all over town.
William D. Fugazy, the newly elected president of Feature Sports, Inc., will leave today for Dallas to discuss an offer to stage the next heavyweight championship fight there.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 12 -- President Eisenhower ruled out today the use of United States troops to help keep order in the Congo, holding that the problem was one for the United Nations collectively rather than any one nation.

DETROIT, July 12 (UPI) -- A United Auto Workers local has asked Premier Khrushchev not to do business with a company that wants to sell auto production machinery to the Soviet Union. The company and the union have had a long-standing labor dispute.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 12 -- American and British research workers will be sent to Kenya in August for intensive work on a new anti-cancer drug -- Methotrexate.

It will be Vernon Law of the Pittsburgh Pirates against Whitey Ford of the Yankees when the National and American League all-stars clash today at Yankee Stadium.
The National Defense Education Act came under fire yesterday from a committee of the National Council of Churches as violating the separation of church and state.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 12 -- Light air and a last-place finish by the defending champion, Mrs. Allegra Mertz of the American Yacht Club, today turned the Syce Cup competition for the Long Island Sound women's sailing championship into a tight battle.

A new burst of strength thrust prices of United States Government securities and other prime-risk bonds upward yesterday. Many of the recent issues of Treasury prime corporate obligations touched new high prices for the year.

After the long stage wait of Monday, the elements of drama and substance developed quickly: the live video confrontation between Senators Lyndon B. Johnson and John F. Kennedy, the vivid close-ups of Adlai E. Stevenson's survival of the demonstration on the convention floor and the first party platform to be supplemented by film.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., July 12 -- The favorites had little trouble moving through the first round of the Garden State Women's Golf Association match play championship today at the Green Brook Country Club.

The International Business Machines Corporation rang up the largest sales and earnings in its history for a second quarter and a first half in the periods ended June 30, according to Thomas J. Watson Jr., president.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson seized the headlines momentarily today in what was widely regarded as a last-ditch bid to slow the bandwagon of Senator John F. Kennedy.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- The Democratic National Convention overrode Southern protests tonight to adopt a "big-budget" platform that included the strongest civil-rights plank in party history.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- The Democratic National Convention received today a sweeping platform of expanded Federal action to promote economic growth, strengthen foreign alliances and wipe out all forms of discrimination.
Cuba's crude oil supplies from the Soviet Union are assured for the next month, tanker operators reported yesterday.
A contract has been signed for the biggest single purchase of bowling equipment in the history of the industry, it was learned yesterday.

THE man who took over as the permanent chairman of the Democratic National Convention yesterday in Los Angeles is known for his eloquent oratory and good presence, but he is in the chair above all as a one-man bridge between the Northern and Southern factions of his party.
A system for measuring with hitherto unequaled precision the flight of rockets and missiles is being developed by General Electric Company under a $15,500,000 Air Force contract.

BONN, Germany, July 12 -- Members of the United States and British military missions attached to the Soviet Army in East Germany were "manhandled" by the East German police in separate incidents last month, it was disclosed today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12 -- Enormous losses of world food supplies each year through careless or inadequat storage are being reduced gradually by the application of new scientific methods of prevention.

Bronson Van Wyck and Leslie Buck, both from Montclair, N.J., advanced to the fourth round of the boys division in the Eastern junior and boys tennis championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday.

LIMA, Peru, July 12 -- A highlevel United States financial mission arrived here today to plan the first social investment program to be carried out under a new expanded aid policy toward Latin America.

LONDON, July 12 -- The stock market was unsettled here today. Yesterday's weakness on Wall Street, the shooting down of an American plane by Russians and home labor troubles combined to make investors move cautiously.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) off to 7 points (35 cents) up yesterday. An expanded turnover reflected the evening up in the old July delivery; which expires today at 12:30 P.M.

The latest sign of the evergrowing interest in European securities is that application has been made to the London Stock Exchange for a listing of the shares of August Thyssen-Huette, A.G., the West German steel maker.

Nassau County, L.I., borrowed 27,062,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance sewerage and other public improvements.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The far-reaching United States proposal in Geneva today to pool atomic explosive devices with the Soviet Union was viewed here as bringing the prolonged test-ban talks to a crucial, stage.

LONDON, July 12 -- Prime Minister Macmillan today promised the Labor Opposition to discuss with President Eisenhower modification or improvement of the agreement on United States air bases in Britain.

Despite the sharp downturn in the last three months, production of steel in the first half of 1960 was the third highest in history for any six-month period, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: In opposing an extension of the Social Security Act to assure care, for the aged I wish to emphasize that my opinion is based on personal experience after having practiced medicine for thirty-five years. Within this period two developments are responsible for the problem under discussion: extension of the life span and retirement of people at 65 years of age if the pension is to become operative.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- A Republican leader said today that Senator John F. Kennedy's path to the Democratic Presidential nomination was being paved with "a little payola."

PARIS, July 12 -- Former Premier Pierre Mendes-France criticized today the failure of President de Gaulle to move swiftly toward peace in Algeria by relying on the broad public support offered him for such a policy.

LOS ANGELES Party platforms customarily promise utopia at bargain rates and this year's Democratic pledge is no exception to the rule. Americans are assured they will have a more effective military and diplomatic policy if only they throw the Republicans out.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Tension within the New Jersey delegation to the Democratic National Convention mounted today as Gov. Robert B. Meyner insisted on maintaining his role as a favorite-son candidate for the Presidential nomination.

Nat Koslow, Inc., designer of jewelry, has leased a floor in the building at 724 Fifth Avenue, near Fifty-sixth Street, and will move from 42 West Forty-eighth Street. A. Sheldon Jaffe was the broker. Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., is agent for the building.

EAST side, west side, New York is a summer festival for children as well as adults. In addition to special film programs, puppet shows and story telling hours, there are many opportunities to broaden a child's horizons in this city.
A $25,000,000 development of commercial and residential buildings is planned for a nine-acre site in Hempstead, L.I.

Junior high school boys from Bergenfield, N.J., have stirred up a minor international astronomic controversy in the dignified pages of Science, official journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DURHAM, N.H., July 12 -- Sixty-three eager athletes received the opportunity today to prove, in the vernacular of football coaches, whether they were men or boys. When the day was over, many knew the truth, but couldn't face it. Others were too exhausted to care.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 -- The president of the National Retail Hardware Association told the group's sixty-first annual convention today that the industry had entered the 1960's with the "most favorable conditions recorded since the lush days of the late Forties."

A "Caribbean program" to help political refugees from the regimes in Cuba and the Dominican Republic was announced yesterday by the International Rescue Committee. The committee hopes to raise $1,000,000 to help the refugees.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The United States aircraft carrier Wasp was en route today from anti-submarine duty in the Caribbean to help, if necessary, in evacuating refugees from the Congo.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Increasingly heavy pressure was being brought on Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri today to make himself available for the Democratic nomination for Vice President.
OTTAWA, July 12 -- Talks with the United States began here today on ways to make nuclear weapons available to Canada.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Air Force conducts extensive reconnaissance flights with heavily instrumented planes that have combined scientific and military purposes.

THOMAS SCHERMAN returned to Lewisohn Stadium for the seventh consecutive season last night, leading the Stadium Symphony Orchestra in an all-Brahms program. His soloist was Rudolf Firkusny, back at the Stadium after a five-year absence, as soloist in the D Minor Piano Concerto.

UNION, N.J., Wednesday, July 13 -- A 25-year-old Hungarian refugee believed to have slain two policemen Sunday night and four persons in New Brunswick last January was shot and critically wounded here last night.
