TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The regrettable events of the past week in the newly independent Congo bring to mind several problems which should have been considered by more nations than the Belgians and Congolese alone in the crucial weeks prior to independence.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 14 (UPI) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy described her husband today as "strict -- but very affectionate."
LOS ANGELES, July 14 (UPI) -- Walter P. Reuther today "enthusiastically" endorsed Senator John F. Kennedy over Vice President Nixon in the November Presidential election.

THANKS to the university presses, some profitable ideas are available in nonprofit book form. Though seldom constructed for the best-seller lists, such books are welcome because they have an air of reference and permanence. Here are two whose subjects are nothing less than America and its people, and they are readable besides.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed a bill today extending the home loan program for World War II veterans for two more years.

JERSEY CITY, July 14 -- International League baseball returns to this city tomorrow night after an absence of ten years when the Jersey City team meets the Columbus Jets in the first of a three-game series.

The real wonder at Aqueduct yesterday was that 16,035 patrons showed up to play the races. It was raining so hard an hour before post time that sports fans stayed indoors and probably bethought themselves of a book.

Builders, who recently bought the property at 325 to 335 East Forty-ninth Street, between First and Second Avenues, for improvement with a fourteen-story apartment house, have enlarged the site by the purchase of the abutting property at 328-30 East Fiftieth Street.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Every once in a while -- like once a minute -- some unlicensed philosopher says that ''politics never change." But tonight's convention proceedings showed that politics at least fluctuate.
Following is the transcript of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson's speech to the Democratic National Convention after his nomination last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
THERE is a play called the smother play, of which it is said that every bridge expert knows it and no bridge expert has ever seen it actually occur.

JERUSALEM (Israel Sector), July 14 -- Adolf Eichmann today chose Dr. Robert Servatius of Cologne, West Germany, to defend him at his forthcoming trial, a spokesman of the Israeli Ministry of Justice announced tonight.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 14 -- A major new national research facility, including the world's most powerful magnet, will be opened here at the Massachusetts Institute in about three years.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 14 -- The Belgian Government indicated today that it suspected a Communist plot had brought on the turmoil that has torn the former Belgian Congo for the last week.

HAVANA, July 14 -- A fourteen-man Communist Chinese trade mission headed by Lu Hsu-chang, Deputy Minister of Foreign Commerce, will arrive in Havana tomorrow. It is expected to negotiate an agreement with Cuba involving the purchase of a substantial amount of sugar, possibly 500,000 tons.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 14 -- The Security Council is expected to meet late next week to consider a Soviet complaint against "new aggressive acts by the United States Air Force."
An inspector who had checked on the city's $700,000-a-year rock salt purchases was summoned yesterday before a New York County grand jury.

Phil Silvers' next show on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network is scheduled for Oct. 8 from 8:30 to 9:30 P.M. It will be the comedian's final show under a contract with the Carling Brewing Company, which has sponsored three others.
The striking trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road made it clear yesterday that they wished Governor Rockefeller's special board of inquiry would close up shop.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has ordered an investigation to determine whether Howard Hughes, or any of his business interests, have acquired control of Northeast Airlines.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Under Secretary Ralph J. Bunche on United Nations aid for the Congo:
A new top-level position has been created by the Board of Education to cut red tape in the school system and improve communications between the schools and headquarters.
New Orleans, La., received bids yesterday on $6,200,000 of serial bonds for the city's water and sewerage systems.
Plans for an early start of contract negotiations between the General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical. Radio and Machine Workers appeared yesterday to be doomed.
SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 14 -- Thomas Luddy of Westchester Hills won the Metropolitan Golf Association's forty-third junior championship at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown threatened today to investigate the ticket situation at the Democratic National Convention.

The nomination of the second Roman Catholic ever to run for President of the United States brought appeals from Catholic, Protestant and Jewish clergymen yesterday for a campaign without reference to religion, according to United Press International.

The Lamont Geological Observatory's new sixty-foot schooner Grace will leave soon for Bermuda on a research trip. A rocket-shaped seismograph, which will operate from the ocean bottom at a depth of almost three and a half miles, will be aboard.
Escapade, a 22-year-old, 72.5-foot yawl owned by bearded, 56-year-old Baldwin M. Baldwin of Los Angeles, is the apparent leader in the trans-Atlantic yacht race from Bermuda to Sweden.
GLEN FALLS, N.Y., July 14 (AP) -- Three experienced golfers and a teen-ager emerged victorious today in the quarter-final round of the state women's amateur golf tournament.

Bond prices again moved into new high ground for the year yesterday as investing institutions and other retail interests bid more keenly for the prime debt securities held by dealers. All parts of the market -- United States Government securities, corporate bonds and local government obligations -- shared in the day's gains.

EASTON, Pa., July 13 (AP) -- A United Mine Workers leader and a hard-coal mine operator were convicted of involuntary manslaughter today. They had been accused of responsibility for the death of twelve men in a mine disaster Jan. 22, 1959.

Following are excerpts, compiled by The New York Times, The Associated Press and United Press International, from editorials published yesterday on Senator John F. Kennedy's nomination for President by the Democratic National Convention:

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- The choice of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson as Senator John F. Kennedy's running mate today virtually guaranteed close teamwork in shaping legislation when Congress reconvenes next month.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -- John Wayne, who has made more money riding horses that Kentucky Derby winners, today predicted a happy future for the horse opera in movies despite indications that it may be fading on television.

Old and new office buildings in Manhattan as of May 1 had an occupancy rate of 97.6 per cent, compared with 97.5 per cent a year ago. The slight difference prevailed in spite of 5,680,191 square feet of space being put on the market during the year in fourteen new competitive structures.

LONDON, July 14 -- Prime Minister Macmillan told Parliament today that the withdrawal of Belgian troops from the Congo before the arrival of a United Nations force would leave "a complete vacuum" in the unsettled new republic.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Southerners were jubilant today over Senator John F. Kennedy's selection of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson as his Democratic Vice-Presidential running mate.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas was nominated for Vice President tonight by the Democratic National Convention as Senator John F. Kennedy's running mate.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The United States has agreed to a formal arrangement to give Britain advance notice of Air Force flights from British bases that could be interpreted in Moscow as provocative.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14 -- The summer White House accused Soviet authorities today of "just lying" in their official charge that Soviet airspace and territorial waters had been violated by the United States reconnaisance plane shot down in the Arctic July 1.

Cotton futures moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) off to 15 points (75 cents) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices averaged higher most of the session on the traded positions and the market seemed to be attracting a little increase in public participation.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- The story in Los Angeles -- this fabulous symbol of the new American empire beyond the Rockies -- is not really the rise of Senator Kennedy.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Senator John F. Kennedy's choice of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson as a campaign partner today was a swift, bold stroke to bind the wounds of the Democratic party. The new national leader from Massachusetts sought a bridge to the South. He believes that he found it by way of Texas, for the Texan was the South's candidate for President.

The crowd of 38,362 at the major leagues' all-star baseball game in the Yankee Stadium on Wednesday was disappointing, but there were mitigating circumstances. For one, New York never has been strong for exhibition baseball, unless the games carry some significant meaning like the recent Los Angeles Dodgers' visit that drew 53,492.
Directors of the New York Central Railroad ordered yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, payable Sept. 9, to holders of record of Aug. 11.
JUAN-LES-PINS, France, July 14 -- A Yugoslav orchestra playing in the best Count Basie manner astonished Western jazz fans here and took top honors at the first European Jazz Festival.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Republicans were trying hard today to appear uninterested in developments among the Democrats in Los Angeles.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Jaren L. Jones, the chief planner for the Republican National Convention, charged today that Senator John F. Kennedy's campaign had cost millions of dollars, not the $250,000 that the Senator had reportedly estimated.
The American people understand what the United States' basic purposes are, but are not articulate in expressing them, Dean Rusk, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Lyndon Baines Johnson's nomination for the Vice Presidency brought the intense, sometimes mesmeric Texan still further in his journey from the obscurity of the House of Representatives.

VIENNA, July 14 -- Douglas Dillon arrived today for a two-day visit during which the Austrian Government is expected to request that the United States use its power and prestige to force a compromise between Europe's two rival trade blocs.

IT wasn't only the political old guard that perished in Los Angeles. The pontificating commentators of television also succumbed in the early hours of yesterday; they couldn't withstand the fresh breeze of David Brinkley's wit.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Adlai E. Stevenson summed up his political situation in these words today:

Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers of Brooklyn was chided yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. He was called negligent about trial procedure in a unanimous decision reversing the conviction of a man accused of robbing a Brentwood, L.I., bank in 1955.

Loans to business by the fifteen member banks in New York City that report weekly declined $33,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday. This compared with a decrease of $124,000,000 the week before, and a rise of $11,000,000 in the 1959 week.

Sir Thomas Beecham's "Frederick Delius," a biography of the English composer who was a close friend of the celebrated conductor for twenty-five years, will be published by Knopf on Monday. The book, which was written in fulfillment of a personal pledge to the composer's widow, draws on correspondence and memories, as well as extensive notes made by Mrs. Delius.
George H. Lesch, president of the Colgate-Palmolive Company, was named chief executive officer yesterday.
Park Commissioner Newbold Morris hearkened yesterday to criticism from his predecessor Robert Moses. He said: "Mr. Moses is absolutely correct. I am impulsive."

The State Superintendent of Banks, G. Russell Clark, announced yesterday that he had decided to postpone the banking board meeting scheduled for next Monday. He said the postponement was intended to give banking institutions a chance to comment fully on applications for new branches by New York banks under the new banking law.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 13 -- Iraq is suffering from another attack of the jitters, a chronic condition during her two years as a republic.

THE good news in furniture this season goes far beyond its appearance in a room. Judging from the first collection of furniture to appear here after the recent showing it Chicago, women will not be disappointed by the way drawers work, by the snag-proof interior finishes, the decorative papers used to line the insides of shelves and the never-fail magnetic catches on doors.
NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., July 14 -- Authorities seized $282,000 in cash tonight in a raid on a numbers bank described as the largest ever uncovered in New Jersey.

Allan P. Kirby, chairman and president of the Alleghany Corporation, holding company, has reorganized the management of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., of Minneapolis, giving full recognition to Alleghany control of that company.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended July 9 were 13 per cent below the level of the year before.
Senator John F. Kennedy said in an article appearing under his by-line yesterday that the next President "must make it clear to Khrushchev that there will be no appeasement."
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Angered by recent Soviet statements and actions, the United States postponed today talks with the Soviet Union on a civil airline agreement.

Camels appear to be having a run of good fortune in getting bookings as models. Recently a campaign was announced to push camel's hair sweaters and matching socks. A camel from the Bronx Zoo was hired for the job.

TOKYO, Friday, July 15 -- Japan was poised this morning to embark on a new phase of her turbulent experiment in popular democracy. Her Premier-designate was already on record as favoring continuing close ties with the United States.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 14 -- An American veteran of the Korean War, now a missionary, has played a leading part in saving 183 men, women and children of American missionary families in the Congo.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- The first and only ballot required to nominate John F. Kennedy as the Democratic candidate for President proved again, and with unusual emphasis, how ambition for this particular office can corrode the judgments of wise and experienced politicians and impel high-minded men to do petty things.
A bright-haired, lively 11-year-old girl is suffering an ironic fate in this city: Because she has a "fatal" disease but is not expected to die, nobody wants her.
A hastily arranged agreement between City Hall officials and a Harlem landlord yesterday eased the threat of eviction for sixteen families, including eighty-three children.

WHAT traveler has sampled roast lamb in a Roman restaurant? What voyager to Deauville has eaten fresh-caught Dover sole bathed in a white wine sauce? Who has sat in a bistro on the banks of Lac Leman in Switzerland dining on truite au blue with sauce hollandaise without wanting to duplicate these dishes in his own, his native land?
Prices moved quietly down in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. Volume continued to shrink, touching the lowest figure in three months.

Ingemar Johansson, the recently dethroned heavyweight boxing champion, whose loss of the title caused grief in some advertising circles because of tie-in campaigns that had to be discontinued, did manage to do right by one institution before that fateful fifth-round knockout.
Judge Joseph A. Sarafite in the Court of General Sessions yesterday set Oct. 5 for the second trial of Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan.
FORT MONMOUTH, N.J, July 14 -- The Army Signal Corps dedicated a memorial fountain here today to heroic wartime homing pigeons.

Tri-Continental Corp. Investment assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation were $413,797,346 on June 30, against $394,142,866 on March 31, the closed-end investment company has announced. The latest figure was slightly below the record high of $414,303,032 last Dec. 31.
LONDON, July 14 -- With Britain's trading position deteriorating, Prime Minister Macmillan is planning to open a major drive to increase exports.

Food Machinery The Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had decided to withdraw its proposed offer to acquire the Saco-Lowell Shops, Inc., textile machinery maker, through an exchange of stock.

Heavy rains and high winds struck at the metropolitan area yesterday, uprooting trees, damaging homes, downing power lines and contributing to a series of highway accidents that left four persons dead.
GENEVA, July 14 -- Almost three weeks after the collapse of the East-West disarmament talks, a strange sort of one-sided disarmament conference is still going on in Geneva.

Merger discussions between the Seeburg Corporation and th Itek Corporation have been under way in New York and Boston during the last couple of weeks, it was learned yesterday. It was indicated that if completed the merger would involve an exchange of stock.
Following is a transcript of the speech of Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pennsylvania nominating Senator Lyndon B. Johnson for Vice President, as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The United States placed around the Western Hemisphere today a "keep out" sign meant for Premier Khrushchev.

YONKERS, July 15 -- Traveling on the outside for the last five-eighths of a mile, Steamin' Demon, George W. Van Camp's double-gaited trotting champion from Circleville, Ohio, scored a three-quarter length victory in the $15,000 Katonah Handicap Trot before 30,045 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A recent article by Gene Currivan on the Biological Sciences Curriculum Study and your editorial "Teaching Biology" focused on several reasons why modernizing biology courses is important, in terms of deciding what knowledge is critical for citizen literacy, what materials are appropriate for this purpose, and how these can be woven into a coherent whole.

DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- The United States auto industry turned out 104,164 cars this week despite a strike which idled sixteen Ford Motor Company plants, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade newspaper, in its weekly report today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Robert Goldstein was named today to be head of production of the Twentieth Century-Fox studios here. He succeeds Buddy Adler, who died on Tuesday.

WITH summer in full swing, city dwellers are making a beeline to the country as many week-ends as possible. The thoughtful guest remembers that, although summer living may be casual, the hostess does have to go to some trouble in week-end preparation.
NEW DELHI, India, July 15 -- The Indian Government sliced in half today its import duty on foreign motion pictures, most of which come from the United States.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- The decisive figure in this election may very well turn out to be Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas. With him on the Democratic ticket, the South will be appeased if not comforted, and the Democrats will have a chance of putting together again the winning Roosevelt coalition of the Solid South and the spreading urban areas of the North.

Although Bobby Fischer succeeded Samuel Reshevsky as the chess champion of the United States and has become a world figure in the sport, it is Reshevsky who has been faring the better of the two in the tournament at Buenos Aires.

HARTFORD, July 15 (AP) -- The United Aircraft Corporation said today that action by non-strikers who sought to oust the United Auto Workers as bargaining agent at two plants blocked further negotiations with the union.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- Joe Adcock's grandslam homer in the fourth inning powered second-place Milwaukee to a 7-5 triumph over Philadelphia tonight.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Brooks Robinson slammed a home run, a triple, a double and two singles in leading the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight before a crowd of 43,704.
LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- The 1960 Anglo-Japanese trade agreement was signed today, opening new opportunities in the British market for Japanese exporters.

It could be argued that Premier Khrushchev has done us and the whole Western Hemisphere a good turn by calling in question the continued validity of the Monroe Doctrine. The State Department's declaration on Thursday upholding it will rank as a document of first-rate importance.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just read Kennett Love's story about commuter opinions of the Long Island Rail Road strike in your issue of July 12 and feel I must express myself on the subject.

The arbitrator's award which has required a New York clothing manufacturer to bring back a "runaway shop" operation is important. It illustrates the exceptional power a labor union may have to control the location of an employer's business and it raises the whole question of the powers of arbitrators under labor union contracts.
Services will be held tomorrow in St. Patrick's Cathedral and the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine to mark Captive Nations Week.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Millions of Americans suffered an acute and personal sense of loss, even of despair, when Adlai Stevenson was not nominated for President at Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The once solid walls of atomic secrecy are beginning to crumble, ironically because of a desire to let the Russians have a peek at some old United States weapons.

HAVANA, July 15 -- Cuba has served notice on other Latin-American Governments that it considers "inopportune" the Peruvian proposal that a conference of American foreign ministers be called to consider her dispute with the United States.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington is scheduled to replace Paul M. Butler as Democratic National Chairman when the Democratic National Committee holds its reorganization meeting tomorrow.

JERSEY CITY, July 15 -- The return of International League baseball to Jersey City, after a ten-year absence, was marked tonight by perfect weather; a Mayor who insisted he could throw a slow curve; a twenty-pound cake made with a quart of rum, and the appearance of a beauty queen whose enthusiasm for baseball cost her a job.
PARIS, July 15 -- The Republic of Gabon became today the eighth autonomous African state in the French Community to be granted full sovereignty by the French Government this week.

Play is the subject of study at Public School 125 in Manhattan where 350 children and a staff of twenty-nine adults delve into the curriculum with a rapture usually not found in other areas of academic research.

A well-dressed man with an alleged penchant for trotters and round numbers savored a few minutes of freedom yesterday. He walked out of Felony Court, where an extortion charge against him had been dismissed, and was rearrested in the corridor on a charge of grand larceny.
With roles completed In forthcoming dramas from Italy. Germany, France and Hollywood, Maria Schell is en route to Ireland for her next film, a "Lolita"-type suspense melodrama called "The Mark."

REGGIO EMILIA, Italy, July 15 -- The Communist mayor of one of Italy's most Communist cities asserted today that an upsurge of the wartime resistance spirit and not an order from Moscow had started the recent riots here.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 15 -- Reaction among Western sugar beet producers and processors to the Department of Agriculture's increased sugar beet allotment is generally favorable, although they are watching Washington as to their next move.
LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- As Senator Kennedy demonstrated so notably, this is the era of organization in politics. Spontaneous guys, to misquote Leo Durocher, don't win.
Bond prices scored further gains yesterday in a trading session that was uncommonly broad and active for the eve of a mid-July week-end.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The current transmutation of more former French African colonies into "sovereign" states points up the continuing process of disassembly of the French colonial empire. In the past weeks Senegal and French Sudan (combining as the Mali Federation), Madagascar and seven other former French possessions have entered the same category as had previously Indochina, Morocco, Tunisia, Guinea and other former French colonies, as independent nations.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- A Presidential emergency board today termed demands of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers against the Atcheson, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad "unreasonable" and recommended that they be withdrawn.

What Happened in Otero County Fifteen years in the life of a child is almost enough to run him completely out of the joys and privileges of childhood. Later in life fifteen years can do a lot of quiet damage without being noticed; pausing to glance back one is often astonished to find how much has happened for good and for ill while one's attention was otherwise engaged.

G. Russell Clark, State Banking Superintendent, announced yesterday that Prudential Savings Banks, Brooklyn, People's Bank for Savings, New Rochelle, and Mechanic's Exchange Savings Bank, Albany, have each applied for permission for a branch under the state's new banking law.

LONDON, July 15 -- Vauxhall Motors, Ltd., General Motors' British subsidiary, freed its dealers today from charging list prices for their cars. Throughout the country came reports that as much as u150 ($420) was being slashed off the price of u1,000 ($2,800) Vauxhalls.
NEW DELHI, India, July 15 -- India signed an agreement with the Soviet Union today to import 1,500,000 tons of Soviet petroleum products in the next four years.
Monument Lawn in Central Park became virtually a forest of "Littering Prohibited" signs yesterday.

LONDON, July 15 -- Prices of industrial shares slipped back further in the stock market here today. It was the end of the three-week bookkeeping account period. Most falls were small and the selling was light.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 15 -- Belgium sharply rejected today a Soviet note charging her with aggression against the Republic of the Congo.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- Premier Khrushchev acceded quickly today to an appeal by the Government of the Congo for Soviet intervention if the West does not end its "aggression" against the new African republic.
CLEVELAND, July 15 (AP) -- Capt. John C. Murray, director of the Lake Carriers Association Navigation School for forty-two years, announced his voluntary retirement today.

The public hearing held by the New York State Legislative Committee on Health Insurance Plans on the alleged discrimination by Staten Island hospitals against doctors associated with the Health Insurance Plan served a useful purpose. The issue has been given the state-wide public attention it deserves and the position of both sides has been clearly established by the representatives of each.

The Los Angeles, Calif., Board of Harbor Commissioners has approved the sale of up to $28,000,000 of revenue bonds to help finance expansion of port facilities. The bonds probably will be offered for sale about Nov. 15.
BRUSSELS, July 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Belgian note to the Soviet Union:
Eddie Arcaro will seek his fourth victory in five years in the $100,000 added Monmouth Handicap at Monmouth Park today and with First Landing under him he is a heavy favorite to make it.
LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a message yesterday by Chief of State Joseph Kasarubu and Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo to Premier Khrushchev, and of the latter's reply:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Industrial production declined in June, primarily because of slumping metals -- principally steel. Considering the sharpness of the cutbacks in steel production since last March, a dip in the over-all production figure was almost overdue.

Teamsters union officials, led by James R. Hoffa, the international president, proposed a settlement last night in the fifteen-day-old strike of 400 fuel-truck drivers and operators at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 15 (AP) -- Mario Davila, chairman of the new Christian Action party, which is backed by the Roman Catholic Church, charged last night that Puerto Rico's established parties were trying to block his group from growing.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The United States denounced as "intemperate, misleading and irresponsible" today Premier Khrushchev's demand that the West halt what he called aggression against the Congo.
QUEBEC, July 15 -- The United States, after a shaky start, led Canada, 2 -- 0, today at the end of the first day of their Davis Cup American zone tennis series.

About 3,600 years ago, when the farm problem was entrusted hopefully to the god Ninurta, educated persons already knew the egghead, the virtues of charity and the stringencies of management labor relations, scholars have found.
NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., July 15. -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood won the seventh annual Garden State Women's Golf Association championship on the 5,949-yard, par-74 Green Brook course today.
LONDON, July 15 -- A national committee acting for seamen participating in an unofficial strike will meet in Liverpool Monday to prepare an omnibus resolution embodying all their requests.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP) -- Ernie Broglio of the St. Louis Cardinals pitched a one-hitter against the Chicago Cubs and struck out fourteen -- tops in the National League this season -- to gain a 6-0 victory.
BOONTON, N.J., July 15 -- Par remained intact today as 167 competitors, the largest entry ever, played the rain-delayed opening round of the New Jersey Golf Association's open championship.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 15 -- Officials indicated today that a $275,000 numbers game raided last night might have operated across the Bergen county line.
LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- The girl who wasn't there, Lynda Bird Johnson, expressed remorse today that she had missed her father's biggest moment at the Democratic National Convention.
MOSCOW, July 15 -- The Soviet Union categorically rejected today the United States protest against the shooting down of a United States RB-17 reconnaissance plane in the Arctic July 1.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- Senator John F. Kennedy was surprised when Senator Lyndon B. Johnson agreed to accept second place on the Democratic ticket, according to a well-authenticated report current here today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Martin F. O'Donoghue resigned today as chairman of the board of monitors of the Teamsters Union. He said his assignment to clean up the union had been frustrated by the constant harassment of James R. Hoffa, the union president, and Hoffa lieutenants.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Wheat futures prices slumped under fairly heavy hedge selling on the Board of Trade today, but soybeans reversed their downward trend for the first time in four days. Other grains were steady to easier.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 15 (AP) -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim has called on the Western-owned Iraq Petroleum Company to give Iraq a bigger share of its profits.
The lay leader of Riverside Jewish Center at West 103d Street was fined $400 yesterday for Building Code violations in two slum tenements he owns a block away.

JERSEY CITY, July 15 -- This community today staged a noisy welcome for members of its new International League baseball team in a twenty-mile tour of the city's main streets by an eight-car motorcade led by motorcycle policemen.
Following is the text of Adlai E. Stevenson's speech last night introducing Senator John F. Kennedy at the Democratic National Convention's closing meeting in Los Angeles:

Following are the texts of the speeches of acceptance last night by Senators John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, the Democratic candidates for President and Vice President, at the Memorial Coliseum in Los Angeles, as recorded by The New York Times:
MEDFORD, Ore., July (UPI) -- Senator Hugh Scott, a Pennsylvanian Republican, accused the Democratic Presidential nominee, Senator John F. Kennedy, of fuzzy thinking on the problem of Taiwan Strait.

An Art Festival, which will consist of an exhibition, auction and buffet supper at the Pierre on Oct. 31, will mark the thirtyfifth anniversary of the Opportunity Shop, a fund-raising auxiliary of the Community Service Society.

New highs for the life of the contracts from next July forward were established yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange as futures closed unchanged to 20 points ($1 a bale) up. Trading was at an extremely slow pace with the continued buying interest in the far deliveries again the highlight of the market.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A man who has worked in the field of the Securities and Exchange Commission for longer than the commission has existed was sworn in today as one of its five appointed members.

VIENNA, July 15 -- Under Secretary of State Douglas Dillon told the Austrians today that the most realistic way of adjusting the differences between the European Economic Community and the European Free Trade Association was to negotiate agreements on specific commodities.

The J.J. Newberry Company, a chain of junior department stores, has leased a building to be constructed for its occupancy in the Gardiner Manor Shopping Center at Bay Shore, L.I. The structure, for which excavation has been started, was leased from Robert D.L. Gardiner, the developer, through the L.J. Phillips-Wood.

Abraham Lincoln received, the Presidential nomination in Chicago 100 years ago. Historians credit David Davis, Lincoln's campaign manager, with procuring his nomination and election and with suggesting many appointments during Lincoln's two terms.
LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- Doubting Negro delegates put Senator John F. Kennedy through a difficult, although respectful, question period today.
PICNICKERS are advised to freeze sandwiches they plan to take with them to avoid the danger of food spoilage. The sandwiches will defrost en route to the picnic site and be ready to eat when needed.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 15 -- United Nations troops began arriving in the Republic of the Congo today as Premier Patrice Lumumba called for the "immediate withdrawal" of all Belgian forces from the country.
Federal mediators abandoned hope yesterday that they could arrange for a resumption of service by Monday on the strikebound Long Island Rail Road.
Wider horizons in the communications world have become a literal reality with the recent development of a new communications system.

HAVANA, July 15 -- The Havana University Student Federation seized control of the University tonight and named a board to replace the governing council. The council rejected the federation's demands that it resign.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., served summonses on the Transport Workers Union yesterday in a $500,000 suit for damages to the company in the recent four-day wildcat strike of Manhattan bus drivers.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 15 -- Johnny Marvin today won the fifth race of the United States final Olympic sailing trials in the Finn Class.
CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP) -- Sandra Haynie, a tiny teenage Texan, and Judy Eller, 20, a tall Tennessean, reached the final of the Trans-Mississippi women's golf tournament today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 15 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis shot a 39, 38 -- 77 in the qualifying round of the Women's Tri-County golf championship at Westchester Hills today. Despite an 8 at the seventeenth she was only three over par.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold began today to mobilize United Nations experts for the Republic of the Congo.

Such issues as disarmament and Berlin, which previously had been the exclusive prerogatives of the United Nations, were handled by direct negotiations between the great powers, and the General Assembly took what was left.

LIMA, Peru, July 16 -- United States lending agencies and Peru completed negotiations today on an extensive new credit program to meet Peru's housing and agricultural needs.
IN American homes today, traditional styles are sitting pretty in the parlor, while bareboned modern furniture now does heavy duty in such areas as the family room.

THE DEMOCRATS VIEWS ON THE TICKET In addition to nominating their strongest candidate for the Presidency the Democrats now have chosen their ablest available man for the Vice Presidency.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 16 -- A Johannesburg physician has perfected modifications to the standard type of equipment for giving anesthetics through a face mask that he contends can reduce mortality and morbidity from anesthetics.
HAVANA, July 16 -- The Castro regime seized today an American-owned fertilizer plant at Matanzas, sixty-five miles from Havana on the north coast.

THERE is a quaint distinction to this new novel by A.A. Murray -- it's a tale about South Africa in which the Negro population is no more in evidence than, say, Eskimos generally are in novels about Canada. Mrs. Murray tries, earnestly but clumsily, to juggle two quite different themes: the evils of money, and the problem of being a Jew in an alien world.

There was a little of everything for the 8,441 fans at last night's International Soccer League match between Bangu of Brazil and the Sporting Club of Portugal at the Polo Grounds. There were big, booming long shots, short delicate light touches and a ding-dong argument that took about five minutes.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- Say good-bye to the father image as a prerequisite to successful Presidential politics. It will pass into limbo along with the log cabin this year.

ALGIERS. TO an American who shares their life, the world of the Europeans in Algeria is a self-contained universe in which certain truths are self-evident and certain realities lead to perfectly understandable human reactions. Everything makes sense.

A Columbia Broadcasting System radio editorial criticized Park Commissioner Newbold Morris yesterday for proposing that counties adjacent to the city permit New Yorkers to use all their park facilities.

LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- Laszlo Tabori, the former Hungarian track star now living in Santa Clara, Calif., bought a new pair of running shoes today and promptly won the mile in the British championships in 4 minutes 1 second.
Antonino Rocca and Rickie Starr defeated Pompero Firpo and Jerry Graham in the feature wrestling match at Madison Square Garden last night.
This week's major exhibition, "New Spanish Painting and Sculpture," opens Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art.
THREE Pittsburgh foundations have put up $200,000 for a study that may result in a new hall for the Pittsburgh Symphony in 1963 or 1964.

THIS year David C. Cooke retires from his fifteen-year-old task of culling the year's crop of crime stories and presenting an annual volume of "The Best" a chore which earned him, in the spring, a special Raven award from Mystery Writers of America for his services to the mystery short story.
DARIEN, Conn., July 16 -- The Town Zoning Board and Planning Commission has recommended that a forty-five-acre tract adjacent to the Connecticut Turnpike be acquired for a public park.
NORWALK, Conn., July 16 -- The League of Women Voters has entered a controversy here over teacher salaries with a demand that the Mayor "find some way" to restore a budget cut.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska. FOR Fairbanks gardeners the highlight of the summer is the Fairbanks Flower Show. The show, which is open to the public, is slated Saturday and next Sunday in the lobby of the Alaska National Bank.

MOSCOW, July 16 -- The Soviet Union promised today to send 10,000 tons of food to the strife-torn Congo to help stave off a shortage that it said had been caused by "imperialist aggression" against the new African republic.
NEW DELHI, India, July 16 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru will leave tomorrow to try to restore political stability in one of the several areas where unrest has seethed in recent weeks.

Presidential nominating conventions are traditionally noisy affairs. This was so last week in Los Angeles and will be next week in Chicago. The noise is there even when there is little to be noisy about.

SUMMER, that lazy, lustrous season the poets write about as a time of sweet repose and gentle contemplation, is for the residents of some rural glens a time when they are driven nearly dotty with activity. These are the summer theatre operators who follow the azaleas and peonies with stubborn tread, cadging stars, printing tickets and painting the umber barns calamine pink.

The Democratic ticket of Kennedy and Johnson is a formidable one, probably the strongest vote-getting combination possible within the party, and certainly composed of two of the shrewdest political strategists in this nation.

CARPI, Italy, July 16 -- Anticlericalism and an efficient network of agricultural and consumer cooperatives are the main sources of Communist strength in this heartland of Northern Italy's Communist belt.

MARBLEHEAD, July 16 -- For a while today, after the completion of the last two races of a seven-race series to pick the United States single-handed sailing Olympic representative, it seemed that Tom Allen of Buffalo had earned the right to go to Naples.
Guinea, July 1 -- In the cool, mile-high valleys of the central highlands primitive Papuans are making a rapid transition from Stone Age customs to the ways of the modern world.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, July 16 -- Cheap labor and two thriving ports are enabling this Portuguese territory on Africa's east coast to make economic progress.

URBANA, III., July 16 (AP) -- A group of faculty members contended today that the prestige of the University of Illinois had been damaged by the way officials had handled the case of Prof. Leo F. Koch.

NOT always has the Democratic party deserved this heroic Republican reproach of yesteryear. One of the longest-lived political factions of our egalitarian age -- second in years, indeed, only to the English Conservative party -- the American Democrats have been led, from time to time, by genuine statesmen: Calhoun, for instance, and Cleveland, and Wilson.

WITH urbanity, wit and a cool judicial sense, Norman F. Furniss, chairman of the Department of History and Government at Colorado State University, has reconstructed a tragi-comic episode in American history, the "Mormon War" of 1857-58, and reviewed its causes and its aftermath.

Travel between North America and Europe and the Mediterranean one way by air and one way by sea will be facilitated through an air-sea agreement between steamship lines and air carriers spanning the North Atlantic.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- The Democratic nominee for President mapped a strenuous three months for himself today and wished it was longer.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 16 -- The disorders in the Congo have set whites and Africans in South Africa pondering as never before.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The President's Commission on National Goals, hard at work after a halting start, is becoming more a commission on national problems.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 16 -- The sixty-second Race Week of the Larchmont Yacht Club produced the largest starting fleet ever today -- but just barely. There were 447 starters. There had been five fewer a year ago, when this important canvas carnival had reached its previous peak.
New York City has suffered a drop in population in the last ten years, but not as great as had been indicated in tentative progress-report figures issued last month by the Census Bureau.

BOSTON, July 16 -- When Massachusetts legislators trail back from summer cottages and political conventions Aug. 1 they will be asked to ratify a compact paving the way for joint use of correctional institutions by the six New England states.

LONDON, July 16 -- Few people on the top levels of the British Government would quarrel with George Brown's statement today that this is "the most dangerous summer since 1939."

MOSCOW, July 16 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union made public tonight its three-day-old memorandum charging repeated "buzzings" of non-military Soviet ships by United States Air Force planes over the high seas.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, July 16 -- A spokesman for a labor union showed coolness today toward recommendations before President Eisenhower for a change in the way governors of the Canal Zone are selected. LONDON, July 16 -- Soviet attacks on three critical fronts of the global cold war this week achieved superficial gains in the endless contest between East and West. ALGIERS, July 15 -- The first steps were taken here today toward the creation of representative commissions to study various aspects of Algeria's future evolution.

THE George Washington Shrine, one and a half miles west from Route 9W on the east bank of Tappan Creek in Old Tappan, N.Y., has been opened to the public after extensive restoration. LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington was elected Democratic National Chairman today with an all-Kennedy team to direct the party's election campaign.

ASCOT, England, July 16 (AP) -- Aggressor, a 100-8 shot, defeated Petite Etoile, a filly once owned by the late Aly Khan, by half a length today and won the ninth running of the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes. It was one of the biggest upsets in the brief history of the race.
ONE of the most discouraging communiques to reach this department within recent weeks comes from a public-relations concern and has to do with altering the taste of wine to make it more palatable.

New York has been ruled out definitely as the site for the third Floyd Patterson-Ingemar Johansson heavyweight title fight, United Press International said it had learned last night. IF judged by the number of copies sold, the reading of new books of poetry is not one of America's favorite indoor sports. When the American male takes his ease of an evening with a decanter of seltzer water at his elbow, a dog at his feet and a fire burning on the hearth, he does not reach for -- say -- W.D. Snodgrass' "Heart's Needle" (winner of the 1960 Pulitzer award for poetry).
SLOATSBURG, N.Y., July 17 -- Ten men and three women were selected today for the United States Olympic canoeing team following two days of trials at Lake Sebago, Harriman State Park.

FLORENCE, July 17 -- On the twentieth occasion of high fashion showings in Florence, the Italians got an official pat on the head from France, high priestess of haute couture, and a news-making start from the Florentine designer, Emilio Pucci.

BOONTON, N.J., July 17 -- Al Mengert won the New Jersey Golf Association's open championship by five strokes today, just as he had done in 1957 and 1958.
Western governments were asked yesterday to put the problem of the "captive nations" at the top of their agenda in future negotiations with the Soviet Union.

All seeded players advanced in the Eastern senior clay court tennis championships yesterday. Dr. Reginald S. Weir of Fair-lawn, N.J., the defender, led the field into the third round at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
Union bindery workers have agreed to a new six-year contract, giving them a $5.25 package increase and pledging them to cooperate fully in utilizing technological improvements.

LAW and order in the Congo have been put into the hands of a veteran soldier for peace. Maj. Gen. Carl Carlsson von Horn, who flew to the Congo yesterday to head the United Nations force there, has devoted his life to the army, but his active service has been on humanitarian missions, not on the battlefield.

BALTIMORE, July 17 (AP) Seven Star Class sailing skippers, led by Blair Fletcher of the West Jersey fleet, qualified today for the Olympic Trial final by their performances in the Eastern eliminations.
DETROIT, July 17 -- The Yankees spent a long and frustrating afternoon in Briggs Stadium today. But though they lost two games they still managed to retain their game-and-a-half league lead.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, the Democratic Presidential nominee, has said on more than one occasion this year that "tight money" must go. His platform, which is no more compelling than platforms ever have been, says: "As the first step in speeding economic growth, a Democratic President will put an end to the present high interest tight money policy."
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Bob Shaw and Early Wynn hurled the Chicago White Sox to a double victory over Baltimore today, 2 -- 1 and 14 -- 2.
PARIS, July 17 -- The consumption of petroleum products in France has been much less than in other European countries in recent years.
LOS ANGELES, July 17 -- Senator John F. Kennedy u facing a difficult and ticklisli problem -- how to keep all the divergent groups of his sup porters in New York from working at cross-purposes.

GREEN perfume still may be found, but the red silk stockings are a thing of the past. As recently as 1955 the broadway musical, "Silk Stockings," held up that elegant hose as the height of femininity, but lit was only a sentiment.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 17 Neale Fraser of Australia and Maria Bueno of Brazil, the Wimbledon champions, head the entries from fourteen nations that will begin play here tomorrow in the Swiss tennis' championships.
PARIS, July 17 (AP) -- Gastone Nencini of Italy today won the Tour de France -- the toughest, longest and bloodiest bicycle race in the world.

Last October Bernard Berenson died at the age of 94 in his Italian villa "I Tatti." He had made the identification of Italian Renaissance paintings one of the most exacting of sciences and for more than half a century his attribution of a painting was one of the most essential conditions for its sale.
The scope of Soviet oil-carrying operations on a world-wide scale was disclosed this week end in a confidential report made available here.
GENEVA, July 17 -- The Swiss stock markets were sharply influenced last week by the gloomy international scene.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your July 8 editorial on the current rate of steel output, about 43 per cent of capacity, fails to draw the obvious political conclusion -- namely, that the Republican Administration has signally failed to provide any stimulus for economic growth.
The number of criminal trials in the last year set a record for the United States Court House on Foley Square, United States Attorney S. Hazard Gillespie Jr. said yesterday.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz disclosed yesterday that he was obtaining copies of real estate boards' codes of ethics to see whether new provisions against "blockbusting" practices were needed.

The twelve-story apartment building at 17 East Eighty-ninth Street, northwest corner of Madison Avenue, has been sold by Bertram F. Bonner, builder and realty investor, for 2,000,000 to Francis S. Levian, lawyer.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17 -- Cornelius Shields Jr., called Glistening Glit by his opponents, became the Larchmont Race Week leader in the International One-Design Class today. He padded a first place to yesterday's second on as fine a sailing day as Long Island Sound ever had produced.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17 -- The Security Council will meet Tuesday afternoon, at the request of the Soviet Union, to discuss the situation in the Congo.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 (UPI) -- A rookie right-hander Tom Cheney, shut out the Cincinnati Reds, 5-0, on four hits today as the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates divided a double-header with the Reds. The Reds won the opener, 6 -- 5.
By the Beautiful Sea That infectious disease -- gadgetitis -- has spread to our swimmers, with the result that our beaches this summer are encumbered with all manner of accessories and accouterments.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 17 -- About 3,500,000 Ceylonese will elect a new Parliament Wednesday in their second national election this year.
The Democratic plank for school integration by 1963 was strongly defended last night against a Republican challenge.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We read recently in the columns of The Times of the Mayor's pledge to Commissioner Peter Reidy to increase the number of plan engineers and construction inspectors in the Department of Buildings. No doubt these increases over and above the specific authorizations in the current budget are needed.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- J. Edgar Hoover reported today that Communists were attaining alarming success in inciting unsuspecting college youths throughout the world to join in outbursts of violence.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- The steel industry was in the doldrums last week and more of the same is slated for this week. Part of the dullness had been forecast but it was far from reassuring to steel people. Added to their woes is the uncertainty of the start in auto steel buying for the new model runs.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17 -- President Eisenhower said today that he was willing to provide Senators John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson with confidential national security information during the campaign -- but not through intermediaries.

Special services were held yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral and the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine to mark the opening of Captive Nations Week.
LONDON, July 17 -- The stock market showed considerable steadiness last week despite a flow of bad news at home and abroad.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 17 (AP) -- Chris von Saltza and Lynn Burke paced the Santa Clara (Calif.) Swim Club to the Amateur Athletic Union's women's outdoor championship today. Three world, eight American and eleven meet records were broken in the four-day competition.

HAVANA, July 17 -- A mass celebrated in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Havana today for "all those who fight and suffer persecution under Communist regimes" erupted into a noisy demonstration against communism.

The New York City Ballet opened this summer's Empire State Music Festival Saturday evening. The festival was to have opened July 7 but because of a storm that damaged facilities at Bear Mountain the opening was delayed.
June, according to Oscar Hammerstein 2d, is a time when things are "bustin' out all over." Recent sales reports from several leading mutual funds indicate the same kind of enthusiasm.
THE Southern New England Championships, played at Norwich, Conn., over the week-end, is the oldest bridge tournament in New England.
Governor Rockefeller turned his back yesterday on any draft for the Presidency that did not have the support of the Republican party leadership.
The proposal to build a municipal parking garage under Bryant Park at the Avenue of the Americas and Fortieth Street has been renewed by a trade organization.
ORANGE, N.J., July 17 -- A possible ring of airborne burglars is being investigated by the police here.

Lexington and Third Avenues joined the one-way parade yesterday in what Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley called a "smooth and efficient transition." It was exactly 11 A.M., as forecast, when Mr. Wiley, operating from a mobile radio unit at field headquarters on the northeast corner of Sixty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, proclaimed as "complete" the conversion of the avenues into one-way thoroughfares.
Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson disclosed yesterday that the relief case load had dropped 3.3 per cent in New York City in the last ten years.

TOKYO, Monday, July 18 -- Hayato Ikeda, a tough-minded pro-Western leader in Japan's post-war political struggles, was named Premier today by a majority vote of the lower house of the Diet (parliament).

QUEBEC, July 17 -- United States, tennis players concluded their invasion of this historic city today by sweeping the last two singles for a 5-to-0 triumph over Canada in the opening round of Davis Cup American zone play.
LOS ANGELES, July 17 -- An emergency farm program based on conservation payments to bolster farm income in 1961 is being formulated by Senator John F. Kennedy's farm advisers.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (AP) -- Willie Mays tripled home the winning run with two out in the eighth inning today as the San Francisco Giants scored a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A lot of people were surprised by the choice of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson as the Democrats' Vice-Presidential nominee.

THOMPSON, Conn., July 17 -- Harry Carter of Litchfield, Conn., won the Formula Junior race here today in a Lotus, capping a five-hour program sponsored by the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America.

This afternoon a mass X-ray operation will begin through the cooperation of the Fire and Health Departments. Its objective is no less than chest X-ray pictures of all the 12,500 members of the Fire Department -- without cost to any one of them. Ordered by Commissioner Cavanagh, on recommendation of the department's Medical Division, the chief purpose of the program is to reveal unrecognized conditions that call for medical attention.

Last week Kenneth F. Gautier looked back into the early Twenties, back to a day in July, 1920, when he got a job with the United States Lines, slotting mail for the company's growing fleet of passenger ships that plied the North Atlantic routes to Le Havre, Southampton and other European ports.
MOSCOW, July 17 -- Maj. Raul Castro, Cuba's Armed Forces Minister, flew into Moscow today for unheralded talks with Soviet leaders.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Growing political tensions in Haiti, a slowly deteriorating economy and a resentful President, Dr. Francois Duvalier, in that Caribbean country are worrying the United States Government.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The year-by-year chart of total United States business activity will show henceforth that there was no recession in 1958.
The city is facing a major obstacle to approval of the 2,500-apartment Bellevue South slum-clearance project. It is the relocation of 2,100 families and 200 small businesses that would be dislocated.
LULUABOURG, The Congo, July 16 (UPI) -- Murder, rape pillage and arson made Luluabourg what it is today -- a, dead city.

Nassau and Suffolk commuters begin today their second work - week without railroad transportation into New York. There is some hope, however, that developments during the day may help end the strike on the Long Island Rail Road.
CAIRO, July 17 -- The two-year-old United Arab Republic gets its first Parliament this week.
Week Ended July 15, 1960 A firm undertone prevailed in the foreign exchange market last week. British, pound sterling and Canadian dollar fluctuated narrowly on moderately active dealings.
Bishop Herbert Welch, 97-year-old retired Senior Bishop of the Methodist Church, said in an interview yesterday that communism was not "congenial" to Japan.

A BRITISH view of American political conventions was presented yesterday afternoon by three Englishmen appearing with Eric Sevareid on the program known as "F.Y.I." over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Army has quietly increased its combat infantry force in Panama by 1,000 and sent 3,000 men to Korea to reduce the proportion of Korean nationals wearing United States uniforms there.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Conge July 17 -- The Congolese Government issued an ultimatun to the United Nations tonight to clear all Belgian troops from the Congo within seventy two hours.

CLEVELAND, July 17 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators, who had dropped ten straight games to the Cleveland Indians, swept a double-header from them today, 3 -- 2 and 5 -- 3, with a fist fight between Vic Power and Earl Battey enlivening the opener.
About 30,000 tribesmen in New Guinea have been sealed off from the rest of the world by the Australian territorial government to halt the spread of a deadly hereditary disease that they alone carry.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 17 -- Swizzle captured Manhasset Bay One-Design Class honors today by beating Jonathan Benedict's Spindrift across the finish line by 13 seconds at the interclub sailing of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 17 -- Andrew Kostanecki of Indian Harbor maintained his lead in the East-of-Rye competition of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound today by winning in the Luders-16 class. Robert P. Marshall Jr. was second with Electra.
Chain store retailers are borrowing from space age technology to speed the flow of vital sales data from widely dispersed operating units to central buying and administrative offices.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17 -- In a reflex action against depressed conditions over more than five years, prices of hard fibers staged a "spectacular recovery" in 1959, the Food and Agriculture Organization reported today in its monthly bulletin of agricultural economics.

KANSAS CITY, July 17 (AP) -- Boston's Tom Brewer hit a third inning home run and turned in an eight-hit pitching performance today as the Red Sox whipped the Kansas City Athletics, 4 -- 2, for their seventh straight victory.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Joseph F. Carlino, Speaker of the New York Assembly, was named today to head a subcommittee of the Republican National Convention's Platform Committee. His group's subject will be civil rights and immigration.

The rather widely discussed downward trend in the nation's money supply was interrupted in June by a reversal of the movement to the extent of $600 million, according to the latest figures of the Federal Reserve Board. This still left the money supply -- that is, net demand deposits plus currency in circulation -- $2.7 billion below the corresponding figure for June, 1959.

LIMA, Peru, July 16 -- Representatives of three South American nations interested in forming an air union similar to one being discussed in Europe have concluded a meeting here, with delegates of ten other nations attending as observers.
Ethiopia will move into the jet age next year.

BOSTON, July 17 -- Senator John F. Kennedy returned tonight to the political soil that nurtured him. A crowd of at least 15,000 of his adherents turned out to greet him at the Logan International Airport in East Boston.
ROME, July 17 -- Premier Fernando Tambroni is expected to resign tomorrow or Tuesday to make way for an emergency Government supported by all four Center parties.
God's requisite for Christians was likened yesterday by the dean of Princeton University Chapel to his mother's admonition to him in his childhood: "Silence, laddie, there's worse to come."

MAJOR league baseball is holding what is said to be a rather momentous meeting today in Chicago, one that could have far-reaching effects. Unfortunately, the world will little know what is done or said there.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 17 -- The Rev. Dr. Dan M. Potter, director of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, said here today that Now York's "summer festival" in the Times Square area was "repugnant to any person of good taste, let alone those who hold to high moral and spiritual standards."

A new producing team has stepped forward with plans to do the musical version of the fictionized film biography of Pancho Villa, the Mexican bandit-patriot.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The chief planner for the Republican National Convention promised to day a "short and snappy" program that, he said, was designed to restore the American people's faith in the convention system.

About 150 foreign service officers of the United States Information Agency -- some of top rank -- have failed to qualify for the agency's proposed new career service status. They were among 800 employes of the agency who took tests early this year.

LOS ANGELES, July 17 -- In the brief time since his nomination, Senator John F. Kennedy has demonstrated a decisive mastery over the Democratic party and the disparate elements that support it un-matched by Democratic Presidents in office.
HAYWARDS HEATH, England, July 17 -- If you've ever longed to own and operate your own railroad, the Bluebell Railway Preservation Society can show you how to do it.

LENOX, Mass., July 17 -- For an orchestra violinist to work his way upward through the ranks, so to speak, by appearing as soloist with his own orchestra is an event of some rarity. This fact lent added interest to the fine performance this afternoon of Joseph Silverstein with Charles Munch and the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

More than twenty irate, wild-swinging fans swarmed onto the Polo Grounds field and attacked the Swedish players in the second half of the International Soccer League game between Sampdoria of Italy and Norr-koeping of Sweden yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Movie production at the studios of Twentieth Century-Fox here will be stepped up, the new boss of the studio promised today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The National Science Foundation is assuming a significant new role as the Federal patron of the sciences by helping universities rebuild their outdated research laboratories.

The Internal Revenue Service announced last Friday that it would embark on an educational program this week to find out if the small business men of Brooklyn, "are aware of and complying with the Federal tax laws requiring the filing of returns."

A Protestant clergyman, in a televised discussion of ghost-writing, recalled yesterday that as a college student he had provided material for three chapters of a book that appeared under the name of the college dean.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews clouted his nineteenth home run and Lew Burdette posted his tenth pitching victory today as the Milwaukee Braves defeated Philadelphia, 7 -- 3, to sweep a three-game series.

The chess quartet representing the United States in the fifteen-team international students' tournament at Leningrad, won, 3 -- 1, from Czechoslovakia in the first round yesterday, according to Soviet news sources.
MILAN, Italy, July 17 -- An automobile ride into the heart of "Italy's most American city" is a study in frustration on wheels.
TOKYO, July 18 -- Hayato Ikeda, who succeeded Nobusuke Kishi as Premier of Japan today, is known as a man who leaves no doubt as to where he stands at any particular moment.

NICE, France, July 18 -- The twenty-two day, 2,600-mile Tour de France bike race ended quietly at Paris yesterday. The winner was Gastone Nencini, 30 years old, of Italy. The loser was France and all Frenchmen, or so the country seems to feel.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 18 (AP) -- Exaltado, an Argentinebred 5-year-old, won the Cissel purse at Monmouth Park today by five and a half lengths.
Stocks continued their dogged downward progress yesterday, dropping $2,000,000,000 in market value in a market which, like its five predecessors, was at its weakest in the final hour.

The Gotham Ball committee, under the chairmanship of Mrs. William J. O'Shea, met recently at the Plaza with some of the debutantes who will be presented at the fete on Nov. 24 at the hotel. Among the young women was Miss Rosemary Addis Ranzini.

THE JOURNEY,"* by Jiro Osaragi, is a probing novel of modern Japan. It would not be extravagant to say that you can learn from it more about what makes the contemporary Japanese tick than from a deck of treatises on the eternally changing state of affairs in those islands.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 18 -- With most of the players arriving late, from Germany and England, Giuseppe-Merlo and Antonio Maggi of Italy won the only men's singles matches today in the opening round of the Swiss tennis championships.
JACKSON, Miss., July 18 (AP) -- Gov. Ross Barnett recommended tonight that Mississippi bolt the Democratic party and support a third-party, candidate for President.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 19 -- Japan's newly elected Premier Hayato Ikeda, completed ,the selection of his Cabinet early this morning within twelve hours of his election.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 18 -- "Peace and excitement are found here," the local guidebook says of the Cape Cod community.

MADRID, July 18 -- The "Rodriguez" season officially started throughout Spain today and in every city and town the sports were turning out in formfitting suits and two-tone shoes.

Lortogs, Inc., manufacturer of children's wear, has leased a floor containing 50,000 square feet of space in the building a 85 Tenth Avenue, in the Manhattan Industrial Center, from the Glickman Corporation.

The bond market held yesterday the high price level gained over the last fortnight, but trading slowed.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the fraud conviction of Alexander L. Guterma, without dissent.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 17 -- A Belgian official just back from the Congo said today his Government was preparing a documented record of rape and other violence against Belgians. The document will be presented to the United Nations.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 18 (Reuters) -- Moise Tshombe, provincial Premier, who proclaimed Katanga Province independent of the Congo, demanded today United Nations recognition within forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson asked the Labor Department today to clarify quickly what constitutes a labor dispute in agriculture.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today urged the American public to study the plight of Soviet-dominated nations "and recommit themselves to support of the just aspirations" of those countries for freedom.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18 -- Larchmont Race Week, Long Island Sound's big sailing festival, settled into the routine of its eight-day run today after those yachtsmen competing only on week-ends returned to work.
GREAT GULL ISLAND, L.I., July 18 -- Sleek, saucy terns by the thousands are back on this island after having been routed by the military at the time of the Spanish-American War.

ORANGE, N.J., July 18 -- Top-seeded Carmen Lampe made an impressive start in the New Jersey State women's tennis championships today at the Berkeley Tennis Club.
BUENOS AIRES, July 18 (AP) -- Samuel Reshevsky of New York retained his half-point lead In the international chess tournament tonight by defeating Argentine Rossetto of Argentina in forty moves.
LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- Five hundred delegates from twenty-one nations met here today at the First International Congress on Congenital Malformations.

"It was the fourth monkey I've caught here in the past three weeks," Tom Morton of the American society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said yesterday.

The Coast Guard began an inquiry yesterday into the collision last Friday of the 603-foot tanker Alkaid with an unidentified submerged object in the East River near the United Nations Building. None of the ofcers or the thirty-seven German crew members was injured.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Fifteen Eastern railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to let them increase passenger fares by as much as 5 per cent, effective Sept. 1.
ALBANY, July 18 -- A new Clode of Fair Practices for the Executive Branch of the state government was issued today by Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administrator ordered a fast start today on the new Federal program of direct loans for housing for the aged. The program was signed into law by President Eisenhower last week.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Governor Rockefeller refused today to predict that Vice President Nixon could defeat Senator John F. Kennedy in November. The Governor arrived here by plane to testify before the Republican Platform Committee, which meets tomorrow afternoon. The convention opens Monday.
The city's newest pair of one-way avenues had their first workaday test yesterday. Third Avenue was a traffic dream, but Lexington Avenue was an early morning nightmare.
North American Aviation, Inc., had net income of $16,526,000 in the nine months ended June 30, compared with $21,941,000 a year earlier, the preliminary report disclosed yesterday.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 18 -- The Cabinet met today in the face of the threat of intervention by Soviet troops against Belgian armed forces in the Congo.

TRENTON, July 18 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court directed the Newark Board of Education today to review the dismissal of a teacher who refused to tell a legislative investigating committee if he had been a member of the Communist party.

A clothing manufacturer sought yesterday in Supreme Court to have set aside an arbitrator's order that he reestablish his plant here and pay a union more than $200,000 in damages for having moved the plant to Mississippi.
FLORENCE, July 18 -- This afternoon the showings at the Pitti Palace got off to a dreary start, but ended up with a smashing collection.

MERRILL, Wis., July 18 (AP) -- An explosion and fire demolished a department store here today, killing at least six persons and injuring twenty. Rescue workers searched the ruins with the belief fifteen others remained trapped inside the charred debris.

PARIS, July 18 -- Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, mother of the Democratic Presidential candidate, exuded confidence in her son's victory in November at an impromptu press conference at Orly Airport here today.
DETROIT, July 18 (AP) -- Sales of imported cars in the United States have fallen behind last year's pace.

GENEVA, July 18 -- The United States will continue to press for a treaty banning tests of nuclear weapons despite the opposition of some American scientists, James J. Wadsworth, United States negotiator, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs fell back again this week. They had climbed last week with the pressure of heavy additional short-term borrowing to cover the Government's summer cash needs.

DETROIT, July 19 (AP) -- Rocky Colavito's single through the box in the eighth inning ruined Pedro Ramos' bid for a no-hitter tonight, but the Washington hurler finished with a one-hitter and a 5-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

With these figures demonstrably higher than indicated earlier, it became necessary to adjust upward related key economic statistics for that and subsequent years.
