TO THE EDITOR OF THENEW YORK TIMES: The Congo is like the nursery tale; all the King's horses and all the King's men will never put it together again. The disintegration is complete. A complex structure consisting of sixteen million people divided into 200 tribes, speaking five major languages and held together by a handful (less than 20,000) of officials and technical experts, has collapsed.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission added two more record distributing companies to the list of those charged with making payola payoffs to disk jockeys.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Plans to offer trans-Atlantic charter flights at costs as low as $222 a round trip were disclosed here today.

FLORENCE, July 19 -- Yes terclay's collections -- those of de Barentzen, Simonetta and Fabiani, made fine pickings for coat and suit buyers. This afternoon the Pitti Palace was set afire with controversy by baby-faced Roberto Capucci's wild collection, which at least gave some of the dress buyers a break.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 19 -- Belgian officials were encouraged today by reports of easing tension from the Congo.
KANSAS CITY, July 19 (AP) -- Bud Daley wild-pitched the winning run home in the tenth inning, and then the Baltimore Orioles went on a rampage to beat the Kansas City Athletics, 9 -- 3, tonight.
CHICAGO, July 19 (UPI) -- Following are the temporary and permanent officers of the 1960 Republican National Convention:

Branch Rickey, the president of the Continental League, yesterday agreed to discuss baseball's expansion plans with representatives of the American and National Leagues. In a telegram to Warren C. Giles, president of the National League Rickey suggested that the meeting take place in New York early next week.
BETWEEN the two of them, Benny Goodman and his clarinet are capable of making strikingly different kinds of music within a short time.

With enthusiasm low and volume sliightly improved, the stock market went through a quiet session yesterday. After showing a small profit for most of the day, prices on the New York Stock Exchanged dipped in the final hour and closed with a small loss.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 19 -- The birds are back but Otto Standke, the professional bird chaser from Great Bend, Kan., is not.

MILWAUKEE, July 19 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves capitalized on a shaky St. Louis defense and swept to their sixth straight victory tonight, defeating the Cardinals, 9 -- 5. The Braves scored twice in the seventh inning and twice in the eighth, on Hank Aaron's twenty-fifth home run.

GENEVA, July 19 -- The Soviet Union rejected today the latest safeguards offered by the United States to assure that nuclear explosions to develop controls for underground tests would be devoid of military value.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 19 -- Reflecting this spring's sharp slump in steel demand, the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company today reported net income for the six months ended June 30 was $18,889,010, equal to $5.42 a share, on revenues of $350,403,718.
Plans for an $850,000 extension and alteration of the Central Synagogue, at 652 Lexington Avenue, were filed with the Building Department yesterday.

THE United States Navy's Task Force will arrive in New York Friday and will be here through Thursday, July 28. An aircraft carrier, six destroyers and a submarine will be open to the public on Saturday and Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M. at Piers 84 and 86 (Fortyfourth and Forty-sixth Streets) on the Hudson River.

C.R. Smith, president of American Airlines, denied yesterday that he had urged San Francisco business and civic leaders at a luncheon in 1957 to support the line's position in| a route case then before the Civil Aeronautics Board.
LONDON, July 19 (Reuters) -- Following are the texts of a British note to the Soviet Union on the RB-47 incident and of a letter from Prime Minister Macmillan to Premier Khrushchev:

The dramatic debate in the Security Council on the Cuban complaint against the United States has to be recognized as a skirmish in a hard-fought battle. The ferocity of the Russian delegate's attack on the United States and the strong reply from Ambassador Lodge were evidence of the extent to which Cuba is being used as a pawn in the cold war.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 19 -- Smoldering tensions between the army command and the Communist party are beginning to break out into the open in a major political development in neutralist Indonesia.

Even before directors of the New York Central Railroad met on June 24 to discuss a purchase offer to be made to holders of Baltimore and Ohio Railroad common stock, the Central was actively purchasing B. O. common shares in the open market.
The case against four youths accused of murdering two boys a knife attack in a West Forty-seventh Street playground last August appeared certain to go to the jury late today.

New highs for the life of the contracts were registered again yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange in most of the distant cotton deliveries The market was nervous and Irregular throughout the day and selling clipped prices later.

Sales and earnings of the R.J. Reynolds Tabacco Company, whose Camel cigarettes outsell all other brands, were the highest for any quarter and half-year In the company's history in the three and six-month periods ended on June 30, Alexander H. Galloway, president, reported in a statement released for publication today.

MIAMI, July 19 -- A 17-year-old graduate of a Miami high school told a crowded courtroom today that she had obected to talk about God in her school because the talk was "about a God that is not my God."
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Barry MacKay, the top-seeded player, and Bernard (Tut) Bartzen today gained the third round of the National clay courts tennis tournament with straight-set triumphs.

Uses of the B.F. Goodrich Company for the first six months of this year were the largest for any half-year in the company's history. Earnings, however, were 7.3 per cent below the 1959 level, reflecting higher natural rubber and employment costs this year and low competitive pricing of replacement tires and some other product lines, J.W. Keener, president, reported yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- Two Navy destroyers collided in fog eight miles at sea this morning. Eleven men were killed and six injured. The accident occured off Newport Beach, thirty miles south of Los Angeles.

OCEAN BEACH, Fire Island, L.I., July 19 -- A group of college students jammed desks and typewriters into a tiny room over a bar and grill here this week. The group, barefoot and clad in the unofficial Fire Island uniform of shorts and T-shirt, was determined to maintain publication of this resort area's sun-drenched weekly newspaper.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Governor Rockefeller pulled out of Chicago today but not out of the Republican Presidential race.
Sight-seers at the Battery yesterday saw a man jump from a tugboat and land feet up on the canopy of a life raft in a demonstration of the raft's potential.

TOKYO, July 19 -- Japan's newly elected Premier, Hayato Ikeda, said today that the policy of his Government would be founded on continuing close ties with the free nations of the Western world and prosperity based on political cooperation at home.

LONDON, July 19 -- Dullness prevailed at the opening of the stock market here today. The sentiment reflected the international political situation, the weakness on Wall Street yesterday and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's warning that Britain must increase exports.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (AP) -- Juan Marichal made his major league debut with a one-hit performance as the San Francisco Giants beat the Philadelphia Phils, 2 -- 0, tonight. Clay Dalrymple's pinch single with two out in the eighth inning spoiled the young right-hander's bid for a no-hitter.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 19 -- Colombia feels strongly that the coming meeting of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States on the Cuban crisis must make clear that the unity of the inter-American system and not a dispute between Cuba and the United States is the prime consideration.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 19 -- Work has started on arrangements for the thirteenth annual thrift sale of the Morristown Junior League.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 1.096 persons were injured in traffic mishaps here last week. This was twenty-nine more than in the corresponding week of 1959.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many newspapers recently have given generous emphasis to the idea of a world food bank administered by the United Nations, and a suggestion that our great stocks of food be stored close to the centers of population, against the emergency needs of our people in the event of nuclear attack.

MEXICO CITY, July 19 -- Preliminary agreements have been signed for a joint Mexicali-United States gas pipeline operation extending from Reynosa on the Texas border to San Luis Rio Colorado, about forty miles east of Mexicali on the California border, Pascual Gutierrez Roldan, director of Mexico's nationalized petroleum industry, has announced.

A twenty-four-family apartment house at 231-33 East Thirteenth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, was sold by Philip Hirsch to the Alstu Realty Corporation, operators, and immediately resold to a client of Saul Berger.

BONN, Germany, July 19 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin won the unanimous endorsement of the Social Democratic party's national executive today as the Opposition's candidate for Chancellor in the 1961 West German elections.
So-called uninsurables are a rapidly diminishing group, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.
The bond market was active and strong yesterday, with United States Government securities figuring prominently in the higher prices.
HAVANA, July 19 -- Ambassador Philip W. Bonsal of the United States protested today an attack on an American woman and her two sons and the arrest of Tad Szulc, a correspondent of The New York Times.

CINCINNATI, July 20 (UPI) -- Glen Hobbie of the Chicago Cubs pitched seven innings of perfect baseball tonight on the way to a two-hit, 4 -- 0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in the opening game of a doubleheader. The Reds won the second game, 4 -- 3, with the help of Wally Post's three-run homer.
MILWAUKEE, July 20 (AP) -- Warren Spahn hurled the forty-ninth shutout of his career in defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-0, tonight as the Milwaukee Braves gained their seventh straight victory.

YONKERS, July 20 -- Seven of the twelve 2-year-old pacers in tomorrow night's $121,243 Empire Pace of one mile at Yonkers Raceway are progeny of Adios. In the overnight betting line, Adios Don, who will start from the No. 3 post position with Bob Camper driving, is the 8-5 favorite.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 20 -- Bob Pennell of the Cleveland Yacht Club took the lead at the outset of the first of seven races to determine the United States Olympic representative in the Star Class and defeated Harry G. Nye of the Chicago Y.C. by five seconds today.

IN what to considered an extraordinary move, without precedent in the fashion world, one of America's most creative and influential designers has decided to lend an official helping hand to his imitators.

WHEN Mrs. Ellie Fields steps across one of her husband's carpets in the Edward Fields' showroom at 509 Madison Avenue, wearing spike-heeled shoes and trailed by her poodle, Koko, she invariably walks away with a sale.

Canada does not have diplomatic relations with China, but next month Canadians will be seeing the Peking Opera, a troupe of singers, dancers and acrobats that has played in Europe, Asia and Latin America, but which has been barred in this country because of the State Department's refusal to give visas to its members.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 (AP) -- Sam Jones stopped Philadelphia, 3 -- 1, today as the San Francisco Giants won their third game in a row.

The calm and measured tone in which Prime Minister Macmillan expressed his concern over Premier Khrushchev's wild belligerency only emphasizes the seriousness of the great offensive now being mounted on many fronts by the rulers of the Soviet Empire.

DENVER, July 20 -- Blond and muscular Byron Raymond White, a 43-year-old political novice and former All-America football player, has emerged as a new face in national politics. Mr. White, who is nicknamed "Whizzer" for his football prowess in the Thirties, was appointed today as chairman of the nationwide Citizens for Kennedy organization.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- In the light of the Congo crisis, State Department officials are anxiously studying the problem of Soviet penetration of the African continent.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Civil rights and farm issues dominated Republican platform hearings today. At the same time, a sparsely attended foreign policy session heard a warning that the Soviet Union had begun "a new kind of subversion and aggression."
The former Republican leader of Huntington, L.I., won a new trial yesterday when his conviction on a charge of attempting to extort $5,000 from sand and gravel contractors was reversed.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- The Security Council will begin debate Friday afternoon on a Soviet charge that an American RB-47 reconnaissance plane was flying over Soviet territory when it was shot down July 1.

In a dull and lackluster session, traded positions on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved 5 points up to 13 down. A point is 5 cents a bale. The pattern of trading paralleled that noted for some time and there was nothing outstanding in the news or the operations in the cotton futures market.

KANSAS CITY, July 20 (UPI) -- Ray Herbert scattered eleven hits and Marv Throneberry hit his seventh home run of the season tonight in leading the Kansas City Athletics to a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

Directors of the Sinclair Oil Corporation at a meeting held here yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock. Since December, 1955, the company has been paying quarterly dividends of 75 cents a share.
CHICAGO, Juy 20 (AP) -- Home runs by Roy Sievers and Al Smith led the Chicago White Sox to a 7-1 victory over Boston tonight.
William Zeckendorf yesterday gave up his plan to build a 2,000-room hotel bearing his name on the Avenue of the Americas just north of Rockefeller Center.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 20 (Reuters) -- Moise Tshombe, provincial Premier, said here today that if United Nations troops were sent to Katanga Province "they will be opposed, if necessary by force."

A BEST friend of the late Robert R. Young, the maverick railroad financier who in 1954 acquired control of the New York Central system in a bitter proxy contest with the Morgan-Vanderbilt interests. . . . Regarded fondly by fellow railroad presidents as one of the most talented executives in the industry . . . . Born on Chicago's South Side on March 12, 1901.

In a surprise move, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. announced last night that he planned to give up his seat in Congress "not later than 1964." He has been a Representative from Harlem for sixteen years.
The heavy seasonal demand for gasoline resulted in a drop in stocks of that product of 4,061,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad yesterday authorized the company's president, Howard E. Simpson, to press immediately for a merger of that carrier with both the giant New York Central and the rich Chesapeakt and Ohio Railway.

One of the busiest incubators of Broadway enterprises this season is the Westport (Conn.) Country Playhouse. Before the summer is finished, at least eight new attractions, with aspirations for the Main Stem, will have tried their wings there.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today to brush aside objections from labor unions and three other railroads and approve quickly a merger of the Erie and Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroads.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 20 -- Representatives of the six Common Market nations faced with a United States request to keep down their tariff on tobacco and with a Greek appeal that they raise it put the decision off today until September.
Atoms for peace will be the topic of a two-hour special documentary show to be televised by the American Broadcasting Company next month.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Miguel Olvera, an Ecuadorian who weighs 118 pounds, upset Earl Buchholz Jr. of St. Louis today in the National clay courts tennis championships. 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

Last night was "Spanish-American Night" at Lewisohn Stadium, sponsored by El Diario de Nueva York and attended by an audience that included an impressive roster of diplomats from Latin-American countries.

PARIS, July 19 -- In the face of the worst spasm of innternational tension since the Suez-Hungary crises of late 1956, European money and stock markets have remained calm. There has been a natural sharp drop in stock prices in Burssels, led by Congo stocks. Elsewhere -- in Frankfurt, Zurich, Milan, London and Paris -- markets have been a little nervous and have for the most part ceased their sustained up ward movement.

THE brown lipstick campaign is in full swing. Anticipated with horror by most males but apparently the rage among young girls, the brown-lipped phenomenon has proved less frightening than had been foreseen. In fact, the cosmetic industry may have some method in its summer madness.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
The operatic double bill presented in the Whitman Auditorium at Brooklyn College last night prefaced Leoncavallo's "I Pagliacci" with Puccini's "Gianni Schicchi."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 20 -- A fortnight after the start of turmoil in the Congo it is possible to see from the perspective of Brussels that a rampage of Congolese troops In Thysville started an exodus of whites from the whole country.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 20 -- President Alberto Lleras Camargo indirectly warned Cuba tonight that Colombia would break off relations if Cuba intervened in his country.

AKRON, Ohio, July 20 -- The Firestone Country Club course may prove to be the most exacting on which the Professions Golfers Association champion ship has been played, but it doesn't ruffle Arnold Palmer one bit.
A STRONG, authoritative bulletin on fishing along the Miramichi, together with certain terse social notes, has just come in from a correspondent of established brilliance.
Long Island Rail Road workers accepted a Federal mediation proposal to end their eleven-day-old strike yesterday, but the company rejected it.
Red Star of Yugoslavia defeated the Sporting Club Portugal, 3 -- 0, in the closing game of an International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds last night.
The formation of "vigilante groups" to aid the police in curbing crime in high hazard areas of the city was opposed last night by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.
LONDON, July 20 -- Modest but persistent demand for leading industrials was the highlight of the stock market here today.
Branch Rickey and Bill Shea flashed the hit sign to official of the Continental League yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- The Congo made its first appearance at the United Nations today in the person of a young, confident, Belgian-educated diplomat.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., announced yesterday sharp declines in its second-quarter and six-month losses from those of a year earlier and predicted profitable operations for the third and fourth quarters.
Mayor Wagner called on the city's Department of Real Estate yesterday for a report on charges that tenements owned and operated by the city harbored slum conditions.
The American Machine and Foundry Company announced yesterday record net income, revenues and unfilled orders for the first six months of this year.

LEOPOLDVILLB, the Congo, July 20 (Reuters) -- United Nations officials arriving in the Congo from five continents face the task of helping a country nearly as big as Europe to learn how to govern itself.

New high prices for the year were scored by most issues of the Treasury's interest-bearing securities as well as prime-rated corporate bonds yesterday as a new wave of bids came into the market for gilt-edge fixed-income securities.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- The Republicans are coddling the 4,600 members of the press who will report on their convention next week.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 20 -- Neale Eraser of Australia and Maria Bueno of Brazil, both champions of Wimbledon and the United States, made their opening appearances in the Swiss international tennis tournament today as play moved into full swine after a day of rain.
CLEVELAND, July 20 -- Roger Maris hit his thirty-first homer of the year tonight and Mickey Mantle his No. 23.
The State of Washington Toll Bridge Authority borrowed $30,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of a second floating bridge across Lake Washington.
LONDON, July 20 -- One of the most critical periods in the life of an unborn child occurs between the second and the sixth week of its prenatal existence.

HAVANA, July 20 -- The Castro regime has notified the United States-owned Cuban-American Sugar Company that its two big sugar mills, Delicias and Chaparra, in Oriente Province will be seized immediately, according to a company official here tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Federal budget showed a surplus of $1,068,101,353 in the fiscal year 1960, which ended last June 30. It was a spectacular improvement over the $12,400,000,000 deficit of the previous year. The surplus resulted largely from a sharp post-recession rebound in tax revenues and a string of unforeseen events that reduced expenditures.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Thursday, July 21 -- Mrs. Sirima Bandaranaike, widow of the assassinated Prime Minister, seemed assured today of becoming the world's first woman Premier.

SAN SIMEON, Calif., July 20 (UPI) -- A series of brush fires fanned by winds of up to eighty miles an hour burned out of control today. Some 50,000 acres were blackened and hundreds of persons fled cabins and homes.

According to Stephen Baker there are 25,000,000 dogs in the United States. In his new book, "How to Live With a Neurotic Dog" (Prentice-Hall, $3.50), Baker says a conservative estimate would place about 25,000,000 in the neurotic class.
J. Clarence Davies Jr., chairman of the new Housing and Redevelopment Board, asked the city yesterday to approve without further delay the $25,000,000 Bellevue South slum clearance project.

The Republican party platform offers an opportunity to say something positive, useful and inspiring about Latin America. If ever a declaration of the sort needed saying, this is the year it ought to be said.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Grain futures trade today was centered mainly on the expiring July contracts and price changes there were generally broad in a brisk final rush to even up commitments.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -- Larchmont Race Week's junior regatta set a record today as 304 yachts staffed by youngsters from 8 to 17 years old participated. The young skippers demonstrated exemplary standards of seamanship under difficult conditions.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 20 -- A fraction of a minute prevented the defending champion, Billy Parke of the Point o' Woods Yacht Club, from gaining a tie with John Fauth of the Babylon Yacht Club in the first day of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's junior championship.
ALBANY, July 20 -- A winning bet on a horse race was paid by the state today, more than five years after the longshot wager was made.
Still moving In leisurely andu unexcited fashion, stocks moved off yesterday for the eight successive day. Volume remained low.
The chairmen of two companies changed the size of their large shareholdings last month, according to the latest insiders' report issued by the New York Stock Exchange.

BONN, Germany, July 20 -- Mayor Willy Brandt has warned Chancellor Adenauer that yielding to Soviet pressure against the planned meeting of the West German Parliament in West Berlin this fall could have "serious effects" in the threatened city.

SUMTER, S.C., July 20, (AP) -- Two RF-101 jet planes crashed today shortly after a pre-dawn take-off from Shaw Air Force Base. Both pilots were killed. One of the planes smashed into a farmhouse and exploded, killing an elderly couple.
The city appointed a physician to a new post yesterday where he will supervise medical care services for the 350,000 persons who receive public assistance here.

Bernard J. Rosenshein has formed Rosenshein Associates, to specialize in the development of shopping centers. Mr. Rosenshein was formerly with Republic Funding Corporation, New England Industries, and Leonard L. Farber.

The major issues in American politics and social life are examined by Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota in "Frontiers in American Democracy." World will issue it in October. Senator McCarthy says the purpose of the book is to indicate the expanding obligation of government in a nuclear age.

Some of the surprises in Santa Claus' bag of Christmas toys are surprises no longer. Santa has become so involved in scientific matters, and so puzzled, that he is turning a large part of his assembly work over to his young patrons.
Reports yesterday indicated that retail prices of refrigerators would decline soon.

A conflict that has been simmering for some time between James Johnson Sweeney, director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, and the foundation that runs the museum has boiled over, Mr. Sweeney has resigned.
State Controller Arthur Levitt, the only Democrat holding a state wide office, announced plans yesterday to campaign throughout the state for the Kennedy-Johnson ticket.
KINGS PARK, L.I., July 20 -- Two men were out and a man was on third base last night when 11-year-old Edward J. Hughes 3d stepped to the plate for his Little League team.
An American physician who left the Congo last week after flying twenty-seven others to safety In his own plane believes that the country may be dangerous for whites for years.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 20 -- The production of music has been added to the hot-weather pursuits of 165 boys and girls here.

Electric power production rebounded from an Independence Holiday-week level of 13,031,000,000 kilowatt-hours to 14,208,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago output came to 13,415,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Backers of Vice President Nixon and Governor Rockefeller began practice sniping at each other today. They acted for all the world as if they expected a serious battle between the two Republicans at next week's national convention.
Members of a plumbers' union local that covers Manhattan and Bronx construction workers voted last night to empower their negotiating committee to call a strike.

PARIS, July 20 -- The French Government and the North Atlantic alliance both indicated today that they would oppose interference from any source with the United Nations mission to re-establish order in the Congo.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 20 (AP) -- A Belgian plane crashed into a volcanic peak in the Congo today, killing thirtyfour Belgian soldiers and injuring seven.
The short interest in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 3,050,003 shares on July 15, well below the 3,247,042 shares a month earlier and the lowest since Feb. 15.

JERSEY CITY, July 20 (AP), -- Richmond's Virginians rolled up a 5-0 lead in the first three innings and then managed to protect it the rest of the way for a 5 -- 3 triumph over the Jersey City Reels tonight before 11,827 fans.
Huge jet-powered air freighters capable of carrying 100,000 pounds of cargo at 600 miles an hour were forecast yesterday as the next step in transport.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Procter Gamble Company was forbidden today to make unlimited, exclusive contracts with the makers of automatic washers to pack samples of P. G. soaps and detergents in new washing machines and dishwashers.

GENEVA, July 20 -- Semyon K.Tsarapkin of the Soviet Union declined today to put into the record of the nuclear test-ban conference his public rejection of the United States plan for guaranteeing that nuclear explosions for research purposes would have no military value.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 -- Former President Herbert Hoover accepted a favorite role today. He dedicated a new boys' club.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Colfax Maid, purchased for $2,300 as as yearling, earned $59,300 today with a brilliant victory in the 598.500 Arlington Lassie Stakes at Arlington Park.

A new apartment building will be constructed on Lenox Hill as a result of the sale yesterday by Harry Horwitz and Milton Barkin, realty investors, of the property at 1056 to 1064 Lexington Avenue and 123 East Seventy-fifth Street.

A good many people on Madison Avenue have misgivings about the Republican National Committee's plan to set up its own organization, Campaign Associates, to handle its advertising during the 1960 campaign.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Democrats and Republicans use different formulas for apportioning delegates to their national conventions among the states and territories.

LONDON, July 20 -- Britain would find it "fatal" to alert her defense policies in accord with Premier Khrushchev's "growis or smiles," the Secretary of State for War told the House of Commons tonight.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- Vice President Nixon, serenely confident of his own nomination for President, was reported on good authority today to have limited the field of possible running mates to three.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 20 -- Twenty-thousand angry Africans marched on the center of Salisbury today. Police riot squads dispersed them, using tear gas against some.
LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) Women soon may have the choice of wearing their coats back to front if manufacturers adopt an idea shown here today by Charles Creed, one of Britain's top couturiers.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- A long-range study of airport needs reportedly may be in prospect for New Jersey. If undertaken it would include a careful look at jet airports proposed for both Morris and Burlington Counties.

THE perplexing and ominous problems caused by the lack of summer jobs for New York City's youngsters were eloquently outlined last night on WABC-TV.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 20 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis gained the semi-final round of the women's TriHounty golf championship over the 5,617-yard par-74 Westchester Hills Country Club course today.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 20 -- Three top slots in the Kennedy-Johnson campaign organization were filled today.
Daystrom, Inc., plans to expand its manufacturing line of electrical and electronics products through the acquisition of Wiancko Engineering Company of Pasadena, Calif.

Westchester officials denied yesterday that resident requirements in some of their parks were aimed at keeping out New York City's Negroes and Puerto Ricans. They rejected a proposal to open the parks to all comers on weekdays.
Whitney North Seymour, president-elect of the American Bar Association, yesterday supported the Citizens Union report criticizing the political selection of judges in New York City.
LONDON, July 20 -- Next spring European scientists plan to send an immense balloon high over the Mediterranean. One of its objectives will be to see if there are gamma rays coming from space.

PARAMUS, N.J., July 20 -- Twenty per cent of the high school seniors and juniors in twenty-two communities in Bergen and Passaic Counties, or about 1,000 students, would attend a two-year community college if one were within easy commuting distance, according to a survey.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 (AP) -- A pituitary bank, to supply hormones for the treatment of human dwarfism and other glandular afflictions, announced its opening here today.
"ENJOY, ENJOY!"* is Harry Golden's best book. The genial scourge of bigots is at the top of his form here, implementing the Declaration's call for life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

The results of adjourned games from the seventeenth and eighteenth rounds of the international chess masters tournament at Buenos Aires left Samuel Reshevsky of the United States and Victor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union tied for the lead yesterday at 12 1/2 -- 5 1/2
Patrice Jacobs' Hail to Reason survived a rough race and an objection to win the $29,750 Great American at Aqueduct yesterday.

MIAMI, July 20 -- A boy who said he had no religious faith testified in court today that he had been required to attend a public high school Easter program in which another student portrayed Jesus on the cross. The boy stood up and spread his arms to show how the student actor had been stretched out.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 20 -- The Congo Cabinet decided today "to appeal immediately to the Soviet Union or any other country of the African-Asian bloc to send troops to the Congo" unless the United Nations Security Council took effective action tonight to expel the Belgian troops. in the Congo in the last two weeks. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: That Senator Lyndon Johnson's nomination for Vice President rubbed the fur the wrong way of a substantial number of delegates at the Democratic National Convention, was clearly and audibly evident Nevertheless, in order to vote for Kennedy, the voter, much as he may dislike Johnson, must vote for him.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 20 -- The Organization of American States fact-finding mission completed today its investigation of Venezuela's charges that the Dominican Republic organized the attempted assassination of President Romulo Betancourt here June 24.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- The United States informed Secretary General Hammarskjold today that it was providing the United Nations force in the Congo with ten C-47 aircraft and twenty jeeps.

A group led by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won award yesterday of $4,815,000 of Atlantic Coast Line Railroad equipment trust certificates, maturing annually from 1961 to 1975. The group bid 98.13 with a 4 1/4 per cent coupon, reoffering the certificates to yield from 3.65 per cent to 4.50 per cent.
The solution to this country's school problems requires planning on a national scale and increased Federal aid, Earl J. McGrath, a former United States Commissioner of Education, declared yesterday.

Earnings of Kennecott Copper Corporation for the second quarter fell slightly to $24,459,374, or $2.21 a share, from the $25,363,648, or $2.29 a share, cleared in the 1959 period, it was announced yesterday.

ABOARD U.S.S. OBSERVATION ISLAND, off Cape Canaveral, Fla., July 20 -- The Navy opened a new chapter in warfare today as a submarine -- for the first time -- successfully fired a ballistic missile from under water.
Seven hundred and fifty elderly New Yorkers left hot, frequently lonely, homes yesterday to ride around the harbor in a white four-decker passenger barge.
BRUSSELS, July 20 -- Premier Eyskens declared today that Belgium was protesting to the United Nations against a radio speech made last night by Anciet Kashamura, the Congo's Minister of Information.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Reporters Edward Hudson and Dick Witkin reported objectively events recently resulting in refusals of pilots to fly under unacceptable conditions. However, your editorial of June 21 "F.A.A. and the Pilots" was misleading.
A political crisis is generally a bad thing for a country. The crisis through which Italy is now passing is, on the contrary, one of the most hopeful political developments of recent years.

DETROIT, July 20 (AP) -- Faye Throneberry made the most of one of his rare starting assignments today, driving in five runs as the Washington Senators downed the Detroit Tigers, 8-6, and gained sole possession of fifth place.

Small Cars and Our Economy As is known by now, the small car is having its effect on the American economy. First it was the foreign-made small car, each sale of which meant one less sale by an American manufacturer.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- Twenty-five Asian and African nations asked the General Assembly today to take up the Algerian situation once again as a continuing threat to world peace. The Assembly will open here Sept. 20.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Photographic evidence has been obtained showing that pimple-like white dots exists within the turbulent sunspots that periodically blotch the face of the sun.
A program to prepare young inmates for release will be started Monday at the city's prison on Rikers Island.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Thursday, July 21 -- The United States served notice this morning that "we will do whatever may be necessary," in association with other United Nations members, to keep Soviet troops out of the Congo.

A port-wide strike was called yesterday by 700 deck scow captains who help move 10,000,000 tons of crushed stone, sand and gravel used each year for building and road construction in the metropolitan area.
HONG KONG, July 20 (AP) -- Communist China has granted two Americans permission to visit relatives serving long-term sentences in Chinese prisons on espionage charges.
Prices of world sugar futures opened off sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange following recent advances, but rallied later in the trading session to close mixed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- An ironing board was propped against the wall outside the door of the apartment. From the molding over the living-room doorway two freshly laundered shirts waved in the hot breeze.

THE saying goes, "If you tell me what you eat, I will tell you who you are." This could be paraphrased to say that if you tell me how long you bake your souffles I will tell you whether you are French or American.
Four teen-aged youths have been found guilty of the slaying of two 16-year-old boys in a West Forty-sixth Street playground last August.

The Johns-Manville Corporation and its subsidiaries had declines in sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30. This reflected the general softening of business accompanied by price declines in several important product lines, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended July 13:

CLEVELAND, July 20 -- This is the time of season when days are long and tempers run short. The boys are only beginning to feel the heat and the real contenders have yet to separate themselves from the rebellious also-rans.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell called today, for more responsibility and imagination in the private sector of the United States economy to meet the challenges of the Nineteen Sixties.
Eddie Arcaro got off his losing streak with Mrs. Jules Schwartz' Mark the Way at Aqueduct yesterday. The premier rider had complained earlier that he hadn't had a winner in twelve races.
NETCONG, N.J., July 21 -- State Conservation officials flew a "bombing" mission over Lake Musconetcong here today.
Domestic sugar futures tumbled yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar exchange on news that the Department of Agriculture would announce its major sugar purchase program after the market closed.

THERE is something as inescapable in the performance of three one-act plays as there is in a football game. When you are trailing by a couple of touchdowns and the clock is running out it is awfully hard to come out on top.

GSTAAD, Switzrland, July 21 -- Neale Fraser stood perilously close to defeat today in the Swiss tennis championship. Only his sterling fighting qualities enabled the Australian holder of the Wimbledon and American crowns to pull out his match with Antonio Maggi of Italy, 6 -- 8, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Government had a $702,000,000 surplus in its "cash" budget for the fiscal year ended June 30. That means that the Government took $702,000,000 more out of the national economy than it put in, and thus had a slightly restrictive effect.

Samuel Reshevsky of the United States, the leader in the Buenos Aires chess tournament, played a twenty-move draw with Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland yesterday in the final round, according to South American news sources.
A firm offer for the purchase of the Kansas City franchise in the American League is under consideration, a lawyer for Mrs. Carmen Humes, the widow of Arnold M. Johnson, acknowledged yesterday.
BETHEL, N.Y., July 21 -- Charley Dickey of Greenwood, S.C., has got to be told that plastic eels were strictly no good so far as the black bass of Black Lake were concerned today.

Continental Can Directors of the Continental Can Company declared a regular quarterly dividend of 45 cents a share payable on Sept. 15 to stockholders of record of Aug. 22. In the dividend table of yesterday's editions of The New York Times, the figure was incorrectly printed as 40 cents a share.

THE proving ground for a woman's stamina in keeping up with the news in furniture and decoration is the ninth floor at Macy's, where 100 new settings go on view today. The settings range from twenty-four full-size rooms to "vignette" displays of various dimensions.

With stock prices, as measured by The New York Times fifty stock average, down nearly 66 points since the start of the year -- the worst "point" break for any first seven months in history -- Wall Street analysts and economists around the country are showing increasing concern.

CULLY POWERS, the central character of George Bluestone's novel "The Private World of Cully Powers," is a recruit undergoing basic training. But he will scarcely be recognizable to his uncounted colleagues who have donned their quota of fatigues. For Cully is a willing, nay, an eager, GI.
The casting dispute that threatened to hamper the forthcoming production of Eugene Ionesco's play, "Rhinoceros," has been resolved.

An investing client of Benjamin Lebenbaum, lawyer, has purchased from Shirley McPherson the five-story apartment house for twenty-five families at 438 East 159th Street, southwest corner of Elton Avenue, the Bronx.
More than $300,000,000 in private construction work in the city faces a sharp curtailment today as a result of the strike on sand and gravel scows in the harbor.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 2 percent above the level of a year ago.

EVERY time Casey Stengel casts his eye over the standing of the clubs, something he does quite often these days, then glances over the individual averages to see who is leading in homers, runs-batted-in, etc., a shiver runs up the old boy's spine.

MORE than twelve years have passed since the French film version of Dostoevski's trenchant and indestructible novel, "The Idiot,' first was shown here. With the arrival yesterday at the Normandie of the handsome, Russian color edition of this noted work came another illustration of the somber idea that the literary and cinema fields are separate and apart.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Jon Douglas, a Stanford quarterback in 1957, and three Davis Cup players today swept into the semi-finals of the national clay courts tennis championship.

MILWAUKEE, July 21 (UPI) -- Larry Jackson, with a relief assist from Lindy McDaniel, ended the Milwaukee Braves' victory streak at seven today with a 9-4 triumph for the St. Louis Cardinals. The winners scored six runs in the sixth inning, their bggest frame on the road ths season.

AKRON, Ohio, July 21 -- Arnold Palmer dealt par and most of his rivals a smashing blow today. The United States Open and Masters champion led by a stroke with a three-under-par 67 in the first round of the Professional Golfers Association championship at the Firestone Country Club.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $88,000,000 to $429,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $46,000,000 to $522,000,000.
DURHAM, N.C., July 21 (UPI) -- Dr. Charles A. Fenton, a Duke University professor and prize-winning novelist, killed himself today in a plunge from the twelfth floor of the Washington Duke Hotel.

LONG BEACH, Calif., July 21 -- Comdr. Albert T. Ford told a naval board of inquiry today that his destroyer, the U.S.S Collett, was going about twenty knots, or 23 miles an hour, through fog when it rammed the destroyer Ammen Tuesday.

Lumber production rose to 184,497,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday. Output was 141,469,000 board feet in the preceding Independence Day holiday week, according to reports from regional associations.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Unless Something goes terribly wrong Vice President Nixon will be nominated for the presidency here to the accompaniment of thuds from the gavel that was used to proclaim the candidacy of Abraham Lincoln 100 years ago.

CINCINNATI, July 21 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs, scoring six runs in the seventh inning whipped the Cincinnati Reds, 8-1, today. Bob Anderson, a right-hander, pitched a seven-hitter and gained his third victory against seven losses.
LONDON, July 21 -- Soviet trawler fleets and submarines recently have intensified their electronic espionage of Britain's defenses, officials said today.
LARCHMONT, N.Y. July 21 -- The first really unsatisfactory day of the six completed during Larchmont Race Week was this one, but it wasn't so bad that competition of sorts was impossible.
DETROIT, July 21 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers battered three pitchers for ten hits, including a three-run homer by Rocky Colavito, and beat the Washington Senators, 9 -- 5, today.

GREENWOOD, Va., July 21 -- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Langhorne Gibson of Ramsay of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Parthenia Ross Gibson, to Noel Stevens. He is the son of Mrs. Charles Elmo Stevens of Charlottesville and the late Mr. Stevens.
A short interest position of 832,657 shares on July 15 was reported yesterday by the American Stock Exchange. That represented an increase of 28,714 shares in the short position since June 15.
Declines in earnings for the quarter and six months ended on June 30 have been reported by two leading tobacco companies.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Agriculture Department authorized today the purchase of 617,385 tons of sugar from thirteen countries or foreign possessions to replace amounts cut from Cuba's quota.

The purchase of fixed-income securities by institutional investors carried the bond market to new high prices in all areas yesterday. The debt of the United States Treasury was the market leader. Dealers in corporate and local government securities made large placements with investors, too.
DARIEN, Conn., July 21 -- Claude Harmon opened a three-stroke lead in the Westchester County open golf tournament at Wee Burn today.

MOSCOW, July 21 -- Defense Minister Raul Castro of Cuba left Moscow quietly today carrying with him pledges that the entire Communist camp would help the Caribbean republic fight off possible United States military intervention or economic blockade.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 21 -- The shadow of famine and disease hangs over Leopoldville's 300,000 inhabitants.

Francis Chichester, a 59-year-old British adventurer and map publisher, sailed briskly past Ambrose Lightship late yesterday afternoon, all alone aboard his trim thirty-nine-fool sloop Gipsy Moth III.

ROBERT HERRIDGE last night presented on Channel 2 a program bearing the attractively simple title of "The Sound of Miles Davis." And it was just that, a half hour performance by the trumpeter that was not marred by burdensome explanations of jazz, synthetic swing jargon or a contrived jam session.
FLORENCE, July 21 -- The Florentine showings, which started out wearing boxing gloves, ended up with a kiss on the hand in true Continental fashion.

OTTAWA, July 21 (Canadian Press) -- The international water highway into the Great Lakes -- the St. Lawrence Seaway and Welland Canal -- is handling more bulk cargo shipments than ever before, but package freight is falling off.
Five former supporters of Premier Fidel Castro declared here last night that his regime was wrecking Cuba's economy. They called for support of efforts by Cubans to overthrow it.
SALEM, Mass., July 21 (UPI) -- John P. Marquand left the bulk of his estate to two of his five children, according to his will filed for probate today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- One of the most dramatic contrasts in Hollywood today is to be found at Universal City, a land of hangar-sized sound stages once owned by Universal-International and now the property of Revue Productions, a television company, with Universal as a tenant.

The ballistic missile Polaris, successfully launched from the nuclear submarine George Washington on Wednesday, will be the subject of a book by James Baar and William Howard. To be called "Polaris: The Story of a Weapon," the book will be issued in November by Harcourt, Brace.

ANY woman planning a summer trip to Europe had better not visit the sixth-floor fur salon of Arnold Constable. If she does, she may never travel. For the equivalent cost of two weeks abroad, she can find a number of furs in the store's new fall and winter collection that will induce her to stay home.
Two of the four youths convicted of killing two 16-year-old boys in a West Forty-sixth Street Playground last August now face a mandatory death sentence.
When the New York Philharmonic opens its 1960-61 season in Carnegie Hall on Sept. 29, the first-night audience may be so dazzled by what it sees that it may have difficulty attending to the music.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City declined $117,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This contrasted with an increase of $40,000,000 in the 1959 week.

With trade and speculative elements on the sidelines, an exceedingly quiet session with negligible price changes prevailed on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. At the close, prices were 2 points (10 cents a bale) up to 7 points (35 cents) net off.
Federal mediation efforts to end the twelve-day-old Strike of Long Island Rail Road trainmen made no progress yesterday after separate talks with union and company negotiators.
NEWARK, July 21 -- The Federal Bureau of Roads has turned down the request of Essex County officials that sections of the proposed east-west freeway be depressed.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- Vice President Nixon delivered to the Republican National Convention's Platform Committee today what was described as a strong civil rights plank.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Highway deaths could be cut in half by 1970 through modification of auto design, according to an engineer's report, published today by the Public Health Service.
Tenements owned and operated by the city do not harbor slum conditions, Real Estate Commissioner Ferdinand Roth assured Mayor Wagner yesterday in a report.
A Bronx man was accused yesterday of attacking a patrolman who had deputized him to assist in an arrest of a 15-year-old boy. The boy escaped in a scuffle, but later was caught.

After thirty-five years at 17 Varick Street, the Merchants Refrigerating Company will move to the new Uris Building at 850 Third Avenue, at Fifty-first Street. The company has leased a floor there containing 10,300 square feet of space for executive offices.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 21 -- Patricia Tiernan of Wheatley Hills and Mrs. S.E.H. Gerry of Piping Rock took the first-day lead today with 38, 36 -- 74 in the sixth annual 36hole best-ball tournament staged by the Women's Cross County Golf Association at Sands Point.
WASHINGTON, Friday, July 22 (AP) -- Wheat farmers voted by a smashing 87.3 percentage to continue the price support program for the 1961 crop in yesterday's referendum.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 21 -- Rioting in Salisbury's African townships continued today for the second successive day.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Plans were announced today to afford delegates at the Republican National Convention next week a view of everything they would see on their television sets at home except the commercials.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that he doubted the Soviet Union would carry out its threat to send combat troops to the Congo. The Secretary read statement in which he said he found it "hard to believe" the Moscow was ready to "set itself against the United Nations" by a separate action.
Madison Square Garden made formal application yesterday for a New York Baseball franchise in the proposed expansion of the National League from eight teams to ten.

The Continental League announced yesterday a formula for the payment of indemnities to minor league cities invaded by the proposed third major league. The plan was approved unanimously by the league's eight franchise owners at the conclusion of a two-day meeting at the Warick Hotel.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 21 (AP) -- Mickey Wright, the defending champion from San Diego, took the first-round lead today in the United States women's open golf tournament. She shot a one-under-par 71 over the Worcester Country Club course today.
A compact navigation device designed to show a plane pilot his location at all times was demonstrated yesterday in flights from Teterboro Airport.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- A dispute over the position of two Columbia Broadcastings System cameras at the Republican National Convention faded out today.
MIAMI, July 21 -- A Bible-quoting Presbyterian lawyer challenged the religious beliefs of an articulate Unitarian minister in circuit court here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (UPI) -- Robin Roberts turned back the San Francisco Giants with one hit today while pitching the Philadelphia Phillies to a 3-0 triumph.
The Governor and the first three men in line of succession to his office may all be out of the state at times during the Republican National Convention next week.
JERSEY CITY, July 21 (AP) -- The Jersey City Jerseys collected nineteen hits and crushed the Richmond Virginians, 13 -- 4, tonight.
Man was in the Western Hemisphere about 30,000 years ago and left the earliest art known in the Americas to document his existence here, two scientists reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- A familiar figure wandered today among early arrivals at the Republican National Convention.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 21 (AP) -- Arend D. Lubbers, a 28-year-old graduate student at Rutgers University, said today he would interrupt his studies to become president of Central College in Pella, Iowa.
Floyd Patterson received a small token of esteem -- a jeweled crown valued at $35,000 -- from his manager, Cus D'Amato, last night.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- The drycleaner behind the Chicago lake front advertising "You Messum -- We Pressum" is in for a week of lean business.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices gained 25 cents a hundred pounds today, and the market extended its long, steady climb to the highest price in more than eighteen months.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight carloadings last week totaled 607,081, cars, or 3.8 per cent above the 1959 level. Comparisons with last year included the first three days of the steel strike.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Friday, July 22 -- Following is the text of the Ceylonese-Tunisian resolution adopted by the Security Council this morning:

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- The grain futures market generally started in a higher direction today and without changing its course finished with numerous gains of a major fraction to more than a cent a bushel.

MOSCOW, July 21 -- Premier Khrushchev's pledges of support to the Governments of the Congo and Cuba have caused Western experts here to weigh the capabilities of Soviet armed forces to undertake overseas missions.

The Kratter Corporation, publicly owned real estate investment concern, is planning to diversify its operations through the purchase of about 51 per cent of the outstanding common stock of the Crescent Petroleum Corporation.

The case of the Dominican Republic is now ready for the foreign ministers of the Organization of American States. Venezuela accuses the Dominican dictator, Generalissimo Trujillo, of organizing the almost successful attempt to assassinate President Betancourt on June 24.
Plans to build in 1963 a new trans-Atlantic cable that will greatly expand direct telephonic communication between this country and Britain were announced yesterday.

A $3,000,000 building for the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, made possible by a gift of $2,500,000 from Jeremiah Milbank and the late Dunlevy Milbank, was announced yesterday by the institute's president, Bruce Barton.

HISTORY has known many empresses and queens who were political leaders. Yesterday for the first time a woman assumed the more prosaic but powerful post of Prime Minister. Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike (pronounced See-ree-MAH-voh Bahn-drah-NYE-kah). who assumed office in Ceylon following the election victory of her party, is, in a tradition honored in East and West, the widow who enters public life to carry on her husband's work.

GENEVA, July 21 -- The United States sharply rejected today Soviet charges that its research project for developing ways of enforcing the projected treaty banning nuclear weapons tests could serve military ends.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your July 20 issue appeared a letter from Stuart Cloete on the peoples and problems of the twenty-one-day-old Republic of the Congd.
A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Committee to Secure Justice for Morton Sobell had a case against the Tavern on the Green and Robert Moses. He ordered the case tried.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 21 -- Overcoming a disastrous first hole, Jimmy Bostwick of Meadow Brook won the medal with a par-equaling 36, 34 -- 70 today in the thirty-seventh Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Nassau Country Club.

The final result of the Federal budget for the year 1960-year ended June 30 last -- shows that the Government has not only finished the year in the black but has achieved a surplus of receipts over expenditures of $1,068 million.
The Board of Education moved forward yesterday in its plans to modernize the administration of the city school system by setting up four high-level posts, under the Superintendent of Schools.
LONDON, July 21 (Reuters) -- Norman Hartnell, Queen Elizabeth's dressmaker, opened his fall showing today with his first line of "budget clothes."

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Accounts of violence by Congolese soldiers, thankfulness to be home and a desire to return and Serve the Congolese people were related today by members of the first large group of American refugees to reach the United States from the strife-torn African nation.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 21 -- Flight crews of El Al Israel Airlines went back to their planes today after they had kept them grounded or six days to support their demands for better working conditions.
RICHMOND, Va., July 21 -- Virginia re-established its first line of defense against full-scale school integration today.
YESTERDAY there was a formal observance in Dayton, Tenn., of the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Scopes trial, which was one of the sensational events of the Nineteen Twenties.

Directors of the Louisvillle and Nashville Railroad Company yesterday reduced the quarterly dividend to $1 a share. It is payable Sept. 12 to stockholders of record of Aug. 1 and compares with $1.25 a share paid in previous quarters.
LEOPOLDV1LLE, the Congo, July 21 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba informed the Congo Senate today that he planned to fly to New York to state his case in the United Nations Security Council.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The economics of the 20,000-word, something-for-everybody Democratic platform are breath-taking.

BONN, Germany, July 21 -- The European Common Market has suffered its first significant setback in the accelerated drive to integrate the economies of its six members -- France, Italy, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

Financial institutions in Nassau and Suffolk County complained yesterday that the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn had readied a new branch office in a Valley Stream, L.I., shopping center without waiting for approval from the State Banking Board.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that the outlook for foreign trade in steel mill products during the rest of 1960 was for declining United States imports and rising exports.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Following is the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Christian A. Herter's news conference today:
CHICAGO, July 21 -- Governor Rockefeller will wait until he sees the party platform next week before deciding whether to challenge Vice President Nixon.
NEWARK, July 21 -- One of Newark's more spectacular construction jobs is going on without the usual supervision of sidewalk superintendents. The work is taking place sixty feet above street level.

LONDON, July 21 -- The day when living tissues will be either transformed or made to specification in laboratory glassware has been brought at least one step nearer by the discovery of a substance that increases the size and speeds the growth of nerve cells.
A case that seeks to bring about the enforcement of a citizenship rights provision of the Constitution has been begun in the Federal District Court Here.
Reform Democrats held out an olive branch to Tammany last night and it will be available until the election on Nov. 8.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 21 -- Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, newcomer to politics, was sworn in today as Prime Minister of Ceylon. She will also be Foreign Minister and Minister of Defense.
Production and consumption of newsprint reached record levels in June and the first six months of the year, trade associations, reported yesterday.

LYNBROOK, L.I., July 21 -- An awareness of the foreign and domestic issues that confront this country has been indicated by voters replying to a survey in the Third Congressional District, on Nassau County's South Shore.
Nanette Fabray will star in "Yes, Yes, Nanette," a situation comedy series to be televised by the National Broadcasting Company on Fridays from 8:30 to 9 P.M. beginning Jan. 6.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 21 -- President Eisenhower moved today for an early meeting of the United Nations Disarmament Commission.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- If Nelson Rockefeller ever needs to borrow little extra cash, he had better stay away from the Republican National Committee. For the Grand Goblins of the G.O.P. have taken a hearty dislike to the Governor of New York and would in their present mood gladly trade him to the Democrats party for Lyndon Johnson or Harry Byrd.
HURRAH for the red, white and blue -- tomatoes, potatoes and blueberries, that is. They are high in supply and low in cost this week-end.
An American freighter was stopped by an armed Soviet patrol vessel in international waters of the Pacific July 7 and asked to identify herself, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States agreed today to sell Poland $130,000,000 worth of surplus farm products.
Commuters stranded by the Long Island Rail Road strike are in a predicament similar to that of the gambler who was told the roulette wheel was fixed.
The Bolger Company of Chicago, which specializes in corporate image evaluations, has completed image profiles of eleven consumer magazines.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Friday, July 22 -- The Security Council, by unanimous vote, adopted early today a resolution requesting Belgium to proceed "speedily" with the evacuation of her troops from the Congo.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 21 -- The United States will ask tomorrow for a meeting of the eighty-two member Disarmament Commission, delegation sources said today. A meeting is expected during the first weeks of August.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 21 -- Senator John F. Kennedy will formally begin his campaign for President in the two new states, Hawaii and Alaska, about Sept. 1.
MATADI, The Congo, July 21 (AP) -- A United Nations task force of Moroccan infantrymen took over this strategic port city from mutinous Congolese soldiers in a bloodless ceremony today.

LOS ANGELES, July 21 (AP) -- Hal Smith, the Coliseum's most destructive guest, hit two homers for the second straight night as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated Los Angeles, 4 -- 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Vernon Law.
LONDON, July 21 -- A selective demand for some of the industrial leaders helped the stock market to score further small gains here today. The exception was commodity shares.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 21 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis and Mrs. William Greenberg of Ridgeway will meet in the thirty-six-hole final of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship over the Westchester Hills Country Club course tomorrow.
ACAPULCO, Mexico, July 21 -- An obviously weary and harassed Lyndon B. Johnson, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, began a brief seaside vacation today in this Pacific tourist center.

A difference of opinion on profits that William C. Newberg made from suppliers of parts to the Chrysler Corporation was the compelling reason for his sudden resignation as president of the automotive concern.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- On the surface most national conventions of the political parties are alike. But there is a basic relationship between the Democratic and Republican conventions of 1960 that is more remarkable for its difference than for its similarity.
LONDON, July 21 -- The thirty-five-nation International Sugar Council increased world export quotas today to enable Cuba to sell to other countries the sugar the United States has refused to buy.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 21 -- King Baudouin said today that the Congolese people would have succeeded in governing themselves if the leaders of the hew Government had accepted the help offered by the Belgians. Belgium granted her African colony independence June 30.
Commissioner of Sanitation Paul R. Screvane testified yesterday at a departmental hearing for John J. Stanton, a suspended inspector in the City Controller's office.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, won a legal victory today when the United States Court of Appeals here ruled in effect that he could be ousted only by the union's membership in a regular election.
The Southern Pacific Company, operator of that Western railroad, raised $6,000,000 yesterday in the public market to help finance the purchase of 546 new freight cars.
For the ninth straight day prices fell yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, sending the market average back to the lowest point since Nov. 28, 1958.

YONKERS, July 21 -- All in all, it was a great night for the Adioses tonight at Yonkers Raceway. Almost as they pleased, Adios Don won the $121,243.75 Empire Pace and Adios Butler took the $25,000 Armonk free-for-all pace.

A RED complexion often denotes internal heat, but this is not necessarily true of the pepper. A red pepper may be hot or mild, depending on the variety. The "sweet" green pepper ripens into a fiery red, but this grown-up version is actually slightly mellower and sweeter than the green and a little less tough in texture.
