One of the most pressing problems in the courts dealing with youth and family cases in the city is going to get the thorough public appraisal it so badly needs: the adequacy of the professional and social welfare auxiliary services and how they ought to be strengthened.
BOSTON. July 22 (UPI) -- Two aging Boston sluggers, Ted Williams and Vie Wertz, hit home runs toniglit to offset a pair of homers by Jimmy Piersall of Cleveland and the Red Sox scored a 6-4 victory.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Foreign policy and defense gave Republican platform drafters a hard time today.
The third heavyweight championship title bout between Floyd Patterson and Ingemar Johansson will be held in the Los Angeles Coliseum on Tuesday night, Nov. 1.
BRUSSELS, July 22 (AP) -- Defense Minister Gilson said today that Belgian troops being displaced by United Nations forces in the Congo were pulling back to Belgium's military bases in the Congo.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 21 -- One of the most ambilious ventures in international economic cooperation ever undertaken -- the harnessing of the mighty Mekong River -- will enter an important new phase on Monday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 -- The United States requested today that Dr. Luis Padilla Nervo, president of the United Nations Disarmament Commission, call a meeting early in August to take up the collapse of the ten-nation disarmament talks in Geneva.

The blockfront on the south side of East 185th Street, between Bathgate and Bassford Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Lee Alan Enterprises, Inc., to the G.A.D. Reaily Corporation. The deal was for cash over a first mortgage of $35,000.
NORWALK, Conn., July 22 -- Mayor John Shostak, who has been trying to make this city move attractive to visitors, is extending his program to include cleaner streets and a brighter City Hall.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 22 -- It is legal in Yonkers now to wash clothes on Sunday in coin-operated, self-service public laundries -- even though church members and apartment dwellers protest that it violates the Sabbath.
CHICAGO July 22 (AP) -- A late burst of buying sent soybean futures sharply higher again today on the Board of Trade and raised all new crop months to their highest levels of the season.

A $44.40-for-$2 straight price flashed on the mutuel board after Briar Close of the Oatlands Farm finished first by a nose in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Those comparatively few fans in the crowd of 24,803 who "had" the horse had to wait out a stewards' inquiry, though, before they were able to collect.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 22 -- In a match replete with excitement and fine golf, Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis regained her women's Tri-County golf championship today.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July,22 -- A heavy so'wester, which blew up to twenty-five miles an hour, played a big role in deciding the Great Soth Bay Yacht Racing Association's junior sailing championship today.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- In a three-hour marathon, Barry MacKay, United States Davis Cup star, advanced to the final of the national clay court tennis tournament today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Times of July 19 carried a "News Analysis" on the Long Island Rail Road strike by A.H. Raskin, the burden of which appears to be that the National Mediation Board's efforts to resolve the dispute over the past eight and one-half months have been hampered by state and local government intervention.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Following is the official program for the Republican National Convention. All times are Central daylight time, which is one hour earlier than New York time.

YONKERS, July 22 -- The Joe-Mar Stable's Victory Dinamic, driven by Sacher Weiner, scored a one-and-a-half-length victory over Uncle Dave in the $10,000 Pony Express Trot before 25,990 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 22 (AP) -- Dennis Rounsavelle, 19 years old, who never had won a national title, tonight bettered the world record in the 400-meter individual medley.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22 -- President Eisenhower reiterated today that the recent ten-nation disarmament talks in Geneva had made clear this nation's dedication to world peace, despite the Soviet walkout from the parley.
Skepticism on the chances of success for the Congo International Management Corporation (CIMCO) was widespread yesterday in American financial and business circles.

Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points off to 4 up yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale. Trading vas extremely slow with one Exception involving a switch of 5,000 bales of new December to new March.

The upward movement of (prices in the bond market ran out of steam yesterday. Bond men on both the investment and distribution sides must have become aware, finally, of the appeal of July vacation weather, because many desks were vacant with the imminence of another summer week-end.

LONDON, July 22 -- Weekend profit-taiking sales turned industrial shares irregular in the stock market here today. A predominance of small losses among the leaders caused the Financial Times index of industrial stocks to fall seven-tenths of a point to 314.8. However, the index has added 3.5 points in the week.

Rochester, N.Y., will take bids Sept. 1 on $9,157,500 of serial bonds to finance various public improvements. Of this total, $4,270,000 will be for the East High School, $1,817,000 for land acquisition, $1,380,000 for buildings, and the rest for road and sewer improvements.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 119.6 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

PERCY URIS is in the news T just now because the Uris Buildings Corporation, which he and his brother Harold control, has just taken over the big property near Rockefeller Center that was intended for the Zeckendorf Hotel.

The Government's Small Business Administration announced yesterday in Washington that it had licensed the First Small Business Investment Corporation, of New Jersey. The company, first of its kind in New Jersey, was organized by the National State Bank of Newark, second largest bank in the state.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- If anyone goes home from this Republican National Convention with dark circles under the eyes, It will be the women involved, not the men.
GUATEMALA, July 22 -- National police and army units opened fire here tonight to break up groups of men trying to demonstrate against the state of siege imposed Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Washington errors opened the door tonight for a Kansas City victory. Six of the Athletics' runs were ured.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Vice President Nixon's strategists have decided not to woo the South at the possible risk of losing important blocs of electoral votes in the North and Northeast.
Two $100,000 added races -- the Arlington Classic in Chicago and the Hollywood Juvenile Chamnionsmp at Hollywood Park -- highlight today's thoroughbred program.
An air conditioning engineer who allegedly used a borrowed city badge to arrest two balloon peddlers this month was himself arrested yesterday and charged with impersonating a public officer.
SALISBURY, Southern 'Rhodesia, July 22 -- Troops were sent into Salisbury's African townships today to restore order after another major anti-Government demonstration threatened to develop.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- The tension between Vice President Nixon and Governor Rockefeller on the eve of the Republican National Convention began to alarm some leading Republicans today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 -- With only tomorrow to go the yachtsmen of Larchmont Race Week were approaching the wire this fine sailing day with some class championships all but stowed away and other leaders clinging precariously to slim advantages.
GLASGOW, Scotland, July 20 -- The Gorbals, long Britain's most notorious slum area and once the home of dangerous razor gangs, is undergoing a remarkable transformation.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 22 (AP) -- Bill Parks of the Chicago Yacht Club gained a firm grip on first place in the United Stages Olympic Star Class trials today. He finished third and first in two races on Sandy Hook Bay.

The reduced level of steel production and higher employment costs cut the second-quarter net income of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation to $741,000 from $7,819,467 in the 1959 period. For the first half, the producer of stainless tool and specialty alloy steels showed a net income of $5,532,584, against $12,369,009 a year before.
BALTIMORE, July 22 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored two unearned runs in the fourth inning tonight and went on to a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers before 24,892 fans.

While Francis Chichester, the winner of the one-man boat race across the Atlantic, rested in his hotel room last night, three Englishmen, a Frenchman and an unidentified, noncompetitive trawler were still at sea.
DACCA, Pakistan, July 8 -- A growing bond of unity is slowly closing the broad emotional gap between East and West Pakistan.
PARIS, July 22 -- The United States and France gave ground today and agreed that trade matters should play a prominent role in the new Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- Farm spokesmen differed sharply today over the meaning of a referendum yesterda in which wheat farmers vott 87.3 per cent for continuation of Government controls for the crops.
Giovanni Buitoni, a 68-year-old spaghetti manufacturer, plans to turn over some of his business responsibilities to his wife so that he can build a new career for himself as an opera singer.

FRESH gray and white awning walled in with masses of green ivy gives a distinctive look to the corner of Seventieth Street and Lexington Avenue, where Soupcon recently has established itself. Wedged into 203 East Sixty-first Street for the past eleven years, this store now has enough space to display fully its antique furniture accessories and food products.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 22 (AP) -- A lawyer for Edwin Ashby, former Republican leader in Ulster County, pledged today that he would produce his client. Ashby, a convicted perjurer, had been declared a fugitive and his bail ordered forfeited earlier in the day.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower was so elated today over the successful firing of a Polaris missile from a submerged nuclear submarine that one of the new vessels was called from duty for inspection by the President next Monday.
Fears that the tightness in the sugar market may continue for some timed caused domestic sugar futures to rise yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
PATERSON, N.J., July 22 -- The Little People of America met here in convention today.
TRENTON, July 22 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner returns home this week-end from a brief post-convention vacation to face one of the most serious problems of his political career.
WURTSBORO, N.Y., July 22 -- This getting up at dawn is absolutely no good. It is a grave mistake to do it because it brings pain and sorrow, and it is absolutely no good.

Second-quarter net income of $32,741,458, equal to 51 cents a share, was reported yesterday by the New York Telephone Company. This compared with $31,073,769, equal to 49 cents a share, for the like quarter of 1959.
JERSEY CITY, N.J. -- July 22 (AP) -- A four-run rally in the seventh inning tonight gave the Jersey City Jerseys a 5-3 victory over the Miami Marlins.
UNION CITY, N.J., July 22 -- A general-alarm fire early today destroyed an automobile showroom and garage containing forty cars. The owner estimated the damage at $450,000.

DARIEN, Conn., July 22 -- Claude Harmon of Winged Foot won the Westchester County Golf Association open tournament for the sixth time today and with one of the greatest margins of victory in the thirty-nine-year history of the competition.
Vasken I, Supreme Patriarch-Catholicos of the ancient Church of Armenia, will bless the site of the new Armenian Apostolic Church of Bergen County at 5 P.M. tomorrow.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- In the mezzanine of the LaSalle Hotel, a harried gentleman from South Carolina was talking about the new glamour boy and white hope of the once-powerful Republican Old Guard.
The conference of the foreign ministers of the American states, which will probably take place in San Jose, Costa Rica, now shapes up as one of the most important hemispheric meetings in years.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 -- The wives of the six crewmen of a United States RB-47 reconnaissance plane shot down July 1 by the Soviet Union listened grimly today as the incident was debated in the Security Council.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 22 -- A winner of $46,000 in last month's Irish Sweepstakes was free today under $500 bail pending Union County grand jury action on a charge for possessing three books of sweepstakes tickets.
A 31-year-old honor detective was accused yesterday of planning an armed robbery that assertedly netted him and a civilian accomplice $1,150.

Debt securities totaling more than $105,000,000 are scheduled to be offered at competitive bidding in the public market next week. Another $95,000,000 of debt securities is expected to reach the market through negotiated sales.
The threat of a construction paralysis in the city receded yesterday when the Teamsters Union withdrew its support of the strike of 750 captains of sand and gravel scows in the harbor.

AKRON, Ohio, July 22 -- The unexpected happened in the Professional Golfers Assocition championship today. The lead slipped from Arno Palmer's grasp. A score of 39 on the first nine of the Firestone Country Club course led to 74 for 141 for the United States Open and Masters titleholder.

The Perfect Alibi The strike of the Long Island Rail Road's conductors is undoubtedly an inconvenience to scores of commuters. But it is probably being enjoyed by certain people who can use it as the perfect excuse for not going where they don't want to go and for not doing what they never wanted to do in the first place.

Deep, indeed, was the intrigue in which both sides were involved last night at the Stadium. However, the plotting had nothing to do with the ball game, witnessed by 48,603 fans who saw the Chicago White Sox whip the Yankees, 11-5.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 22 (AP) -- The defending champion, Mickey Wright of San Diego built her lead in the United States women's open golf championship to two strokes today by posting her second straight orie-under-par 71.
LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) -- Today was the third and last day of the showings by Britain's eleven top couturiers.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 22 -- Airborne Belgian troops and Congolese mutineers fought a battle near a Katanga mining center today.
MOSCOW, July 22 -- Soviet leaders and newspapers reacted angrily today to the proclamation in the United States of Captive Nations Week.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- Securities and Exchange Commission officials are looking into the activities of William C. Newberg, former president of Chrysler, for possible violation by Chrysler of reporting requirements in Federal securities laws.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 22 -- Jack Lyons of Garden City Golf Club defeated the medalist, James Bostwick of Meadow Brook, 6 and 4, today as match play started in the thirty-seventh annual Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Nassau Country Club.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has delayed his departure for the Congo to await the arival here of premier Patrice Lumumba from Leopoldville. Mr. Hammarskjold will leave Tuesday night, at the earliest, instead of tomorrow as originally planned.

A customary roosting place for platitudes is in the foreign affairs planks of our party platforms, where, couched in the homely vernacular of politics, happy generalizations are handed to the voters. However, thanks to the efforts of Senator John Sherman Cooper (Republican of Kentucky), who has been charged with preparing the Republican diplomatic program, this will almost certainly contain two nuggets of truth.

LONDON, July 22 -- Derek C. Walker-Smith, Minister of Health, unexpectedly resigned today from Prime Minister Macmillan's Government at a critcal juncture.
LONDON, July 22 -- Dr. Hastings K. Banda, leader of the Nyasaland African nationalists, counseled the new Congo Government today to "look to the United Nations" for help in easing its growing pains.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 -- A dispute between Premier Abdul Karim Kassim and the foreign-owned Iraq Petroleum Company threatens Iraq with a substantial reduction in the $280,000,000 she receives yearly in oil revenues.

The consolidated net income of Texaco, Inc., was $177,342,162, or $2.93 a share, in the first six months of this year, Augustus C. Long, chairman, announced yesterday. This represented a 7.3 per cent rise from the $164,961,377. or $2.78 a share, in the first half of 1959.
HAVANA, July 22 -- The United States-owned Mercedita sugar mill has been seized by the Government, it was announced today.
Hundreds of shiny new bowling balls will start rolling soon from the little town of Booneville, Ark., as a result of an extraordinary community money-raising effort.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 22 -- W. Averell Harriman, wartime Ambassador to the Soviet Union, delivered a foretaste today of the aggressive campaign on foreign policy that Senator John F. Kennedy will wage in bidding for the Presidency.
Motorists are forced to pay premium insurance rates as poor risks simply because their agents are in the bad graces of insurance companies, a state inquiry was told here yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, July 22 -- Argentina declared the Israeli Ambassador unwelcome today as the latest move in the dispute with Israel over the seizure of Adolf Eichmann, accused Nazi war criminal, in Argentina two months ago.

PARIS, July 22 -- Exploratory talks seeking to eliminate obstacles to the deployment of Polaris intermediate-range ballistic missiles in France and elsewhere in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are under way here.
A novel rendering of the traditional Stations of the Cross has been on display in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus of Columbia University.

CHICAGO, July 22 (UPI) -- An attorney for eight airline sought a Federal court injunction today to bar a "blockade" of airport facilities by members of the Air Line Pilots Association. The pilots are striking against Southern Airways, Inc.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (AP) -- Four airmen died in plane crashes today while helping ground fighters battle the worst forest fire in thirty years in nine parched Western state.

Directors of the Budd Company elected Harleston R. Wood, president of the Alan Wood Steel Company, a director yesterday, Mr. Wood, a native of Philadelphia and a descendant of the founder of the steel company, was a key figure in the reorganization of the Alan Wood Company after the war when the Wood family reacquired a controlling interest that had been sold to Koppers Company and other interests in 1929.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The nation's total output of goods and services rose to a rate of $505,000,000,000 a year in the second quarter, according to a preliminary estimate published today.

DETROIT, July 22 -- The United Automobile Workers Union offered today to assist the Chrysler Corporation in its investigation of its executives' interests in outside supplier companies. At the same time, Sol A. Dann, a Detroit lawyer and owner of 5,100 shares in Chrysler, asked, directors to "institute all appropriate criminal and civil action" against persons "guilty of defrauding Chrysler stockholders."
The two major unions of television performers have agreed to join hands before reaching across the bargaining tables in negotiations with employers.

With a temperature forecast of 75 to 80 degrees, a week-end of Olympic bicycling trials begins at 10 o'clock this morning in Central Park. The main roadway will be closed to traffic for the first time in the park's history.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A Soviet diplomat accused of spying has been directed to leave the United States immediately.
LOS ANGELES, July 22 (UPI) -- Don Drysdale, a right-hander, struck out fourteen men tonight as the Dodgers beat the Phillies, 2 -- 0. It was his fourth victory in a row.
Mayor Wagner opened the city's Golden Jubilee Camporee of scouting yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Governor Rockefeller returns to the convention wars tomorrow. He wil arrive'by plane at noon.

"THE Paratrooper of Mechanic Avenue,"* by Lester Goran, is a resolutely grim novel about savage life in the lower depths. While many other novelists and expense-account society sociologists are busy telling us the dangers, the awful perils, of too much money, Mr. Goran concentrates on the hazards that face people who have too little.
TWENTY-SIX years ago a 14-year-old Queens boy named Harold Joseph Pryor became so emotionally captured by histories of the American labor movement that the course of his life was changed.
LENOX, Mass., July 22 -- The Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood has been in existence well over two decades, but tonight was the first time that the Faure Requiem has been heard on the premises.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 -- Following is the text of a letter from Henry Cabot Lodge of the United States to Dr. Luis Padilla Nervo, president of the United Nations Disarmament Commission, requesting a meeting early in August:
HONG KONG, July 22 -- A new attack on "modern revisionists" who reinterpret Lenin's theories was made in Peiping today.

The General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers showed mature statesmanship in beginning negotiations for a new contract a month earlier than had been planned. The present agreement will run out on Oct. 1 and the sweep and complexity of the issues involved, most important to the nation's economy, have made it evident that no time should be lost in getting down to business.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- This, is a schizophrenic convention, torn between the dignity of which the planners boast and the hokum that is lurking in the wings. The Republicans want very much to be dignified without being dull, sane without being somnolent.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 22 -- Premier Gatson Eyskens indicated today that Belgian troops in the Congo were still authorized by the Government in Brussels to go into action when necessary.

The Parker Pen Company's directors have elected the youngest president in the 72-year-history of the concern. He is Daniel Parker, 35 years old, who will serve as chief executive officer. He becomes the fourth president of the organization.

The Health Department has intensified its inspections of milk handling and processing as a result of complaints from housewives that some stores have been selling "sour" or "spoiled" milk since milk dating ended April 30.

FAIRVIEW, N.J., July 22 -- A team of experts has tentatively endorsed the mile-long tunnel of the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad here as a nuclear bomb shelter. The tunnel runs through the Palisades about 200 feet below the surface and links tnis borough with Edgewater on the Hudson River.

The wave of teen-age violence in Manhattan last summer was the worst in the borough's history, the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday. Seven teen - age youths were slain and seven injured in five brutal outbreaks.
A national Italian-American service organization voted here yesterday to combat the "vilification" of Italian-Americans as gangsters in television, movies and radio plays.

THE tea room, that circumspect eating establishment characterized by candlelight and white-haired motherly hostesses, often owes much of its appeal to its hot breads. These are generously brought around to the table several times.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Stricter regulations to make sure that physicians are fully informed on the possible dangers of prescription drugs were issued today by the Food and Drug Administration.

The boom in farm real estate values continued from 1954 through 1959. Now, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City in its latest monthly review of business conditions, the boom may be ebbing.
The leader of 1,350 striking Long Island Rail Road trainmen suggested last night that the strike could be ended immediately if the line added a penny to the price of single-fare tickets.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A professional photographer has discovered that vibrating the developer liquid with ultrasonic waves turns out much better pictures. He agitates the developer for five seconds each minute, leaving it calm the rest of the time.
ROME, July 22 -- The task of forming Italy's twenty-second Cabinet since World War II was entrusted today to Amintore Fanfani by President Giovanni Gronchi.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (AP) -- VVilmer Mizell, in trouble much of the time but strong in the clutch, pitched Pittsburgh to a 4 -- 1 victory over, San Francisco tonight, increasing the Pirates' National League lead to two and a half games over the Milwaukee Braves.

Stocks pounded downward yesterday for the tenth successive day, touching the lowest point since Nov. 26, 1958, and ending with a net loss so far for 1960 of 16.87 per cent, as measured by The New York Times average.

The one-story industrial building fomerly occupied by Gould Eberhardt on Fabyan Place, south of Chancellor Avenue in Irvington, N.J., has been leased by Sol Entin to Value Fair, Inc. The structure, containing 150,000 square feet of space, will be altered for occupancy as a department store and supermarket by the Valy Fair chain of stores, for which Valley Fair, Inc., is the realty agent.

The wholesale price of sugar was raised yesterday to its highest level since 1923, effective today, and retailers arc expected to add the increase to their prices in a matter of days. Futures prices also went up, adding 3 to 10 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a turnover of 5,000 tons.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Women will get equal representation with men on all convention committees, Mrs. Clare B. Williams, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Elsenhower has ordered a cut in Federal employment for the third year in a row.

Victor Korchnoi, the Soviet champion, and Samuel Reshevsky of the United States finished in a tie for first place in the Buenos Aires chess tournament, according to a report from Argentina. Each had a 13 -- 6 score.

Elfrida von Nardroff, who won $220,500 on the television quiz show "Twenty-One," testified yesterday before a grand jury considering perjury charges against witnesses who appeared before a previous panel.
On Monday morning, thirty persons from six states and Puerto Rico will check in at New York University to attend the school's third annual summer motion picture workshop in creative film making.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 22 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today granted the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation a $1,800,000 rise in its natural gas rates but rejected the company's proposal for a $3,940,000 increase as excessive.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 22 -- President Romulo Betancourt said today that the Latin-American democracies must take charge of the task of telling the Soviet Union to "keep hands off America."
The Port of New York Authority confirmed yesterday plans to use an old wooden Newark Airport traffic tower temporarily at La Guardia Airport during the reconstruction of the Queens airfield.
TOKYO, July 22 (AP) -- Japan's new Premier, Hayato Ikeda, said today that he was satisfied with the United States' trade policy toward Japan.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We noted with considerable interest the editorial in The Times recently regarding the Mexican farm labor program.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- Republican Vice-Presidential possibilities spread like split levels in suburbia today.
CROTON - ON - HUDSON, N.Y., July 22 -- The City of New York was threatened today with retaliation for dehydrating this Hudson Valley village's 55-year-old artificial lake.
A plan to provide a six-lane traffic link between the Forest Hills subway station on Queens Boulevard and the 1964 World's Fair grounds is meeting strong opposition from residents in the area.
A week-end Crusade for Rockefeller was started here last night by the newest of the Draft Rockefeller groups to appear on the political scene.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 22 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba signed today a sweeping fifty-year contract with a United States company for the development of the Congo's mineral and hydroelectric resources.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- The Soviet Union demanded today that the Security Council "insist" that the United States take immediate measures to stop "new aggressive actions by the United States Air Force and prevent their recurrence."
The Idlewild Bon Voyage Liquor Corporation took off yesterday on what could be a long trip through the courts.

BUENOS AIRES, July 22 (UPI) -- Today's development constituted a virtual break in Argentine-Israel diplomatic relations, which have deteriorated since the Argentine Ambassador to Israel, Rodolfo Garcias Arias, was recalled in mid-June.

CINCINNATI, July 22 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals reached Joe Nuxhall for seven hits and five runs in the first two and a third innings tonight and coasted to a 8-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. The early outburst included a home run by Daryl Spencer, a triple and two doubles.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The United States Consumer Price Index rose to a record in June one-fifth of 1 per cent higher than in May.

LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) -- The Moscow radio said tonight that the Polaris missile, successfuly fired Wednesday from a submerged submarine off Cape Canaveral, would not save United States "militarists" who were "now compelled to creep into the ocean depths."

An American edition of Andre Billy's biography, "The Goncourt Brothers," will be published Sept. 12 by Horizon Press. The French novelists and literary collaborators, Jules and Edmond Goncourt, were dedicated to each other and to the arts, and they were pioneers of the realistically frank modern novel.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22 -- President Eisenhower received a progress report today on the work of his National Goals Commission. It assured him that its final report would be kept "sterilized from partisan political considerations."
A PERFORMANCE of Handel's seldom-seen opera "Alcina" and the United States debut of Australian coloratura Joan Sutherland will be features of the Dallas Civic Opera season, Nov. 4 through 23.

CARMEL, N.Y., July 23 -- Ch. Cappoquin Little Sister, a black toy poodle, today scored her seventh best in show, four of them in the last eight days, in the annual Putnam Kennel Club show. The winner is owned by Miss Florence Michelson of Fort Lauderdale and was handled by Anne Hone Rogers of Mahopac, N.Y.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 20 -- Scottish business men and Government agencies are engaged in a two-pronged drive to improve Scotland's economy.
In the air over El Centro, Calif., one day last week a Lockheed Hercules air freighter made a record test drop of a full cargo of 40,500 pounds in a single "package."

Francis S. held the lead all the way to win the $54,100 Dwyer Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The colt, owned by the Harbor View Farm, engaged in a stirring stretch duel with the Pebble Brook Farm's Irish Lancer, whom he beat by a neck in the race of a mile and a quarter.
Norway continues to look after the health of her seaman at a downtown office that was opened here eighteen years ago as a wartime emergency meaure.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- The man who clipped Richard M. Nixon's beetling eyebrows and powdered Dwight D. Eisenhower's bald pate expects to do so again at the Republican National Convention.

McCALL, Idaho -- Until a few years ago, Idaho's deep gorges, granit peaks and timbered wildernesses were available only to millionaire sportsmen or eccentric hermits. Now, as recreation plays an increasing role in the state's commerce, the haunt of the hermit is apt to be the playground of the tourist.

IN considering the discussions of humor that one encounters in print from time to time, the thought obtrudes: it needs, in general, a rather humorless person to devote much time to an analysis of humor. Among such analysts the possible jokes are known to be few and easily classified, ranging in a narrow circle from jokes about mothers-in-law to those about overripe cheese.

PITUITARY BANK -- The opening of the world's first bank of human pituitary glands to supply hormones for the treatment of human dwarfism and other glandular deficiencies was announced last week by the University of California Medical Center in San Francisco.

IN a home planting as in a commercial orchard, success in growing apples depends on effective control of Insects and diseases. A sound control program is based on four factors: (1) recognition of the trouble; (2) selection of effective pesticides and fungicides; (3) timing of applications, and (4) thorough coverage of fruit and foliage with the chemical.
The blending of a home's formal and informal living areas into a large, virtually unobstructed area has resulted in an unusual room layout in a model house just opened on Long Island's South Shore.

FROM Nassau in the Bahama Islands comes an object lesson for the travel industry everywhere in the world, and especially in the United States where, in Government circles and even in the thinking of many misguide economists, tourism still considered a kind of second-class industry.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Senate Barry Gold water of Arizona charged Vice President Nixon today with a "surrender to Rockefeller." The Senator also promised to lead a fight on the floor of the Republican National Convention against the agreements on the platform laid down in New York this morning by Mr. Nixon and Governor Rockefeller.
With twenty-two new fiber glass yachts provided for the trials by the Finn Class Association, non-owners had the opportunity to qualify for the United States Olympic team and one of them made it.

An exhibition of "Photographs for Collectors" to be held Oct. 1-16 at the Museum of Modern Art will signal the start of a greatly expanded print-selling program at that institution. The show will display work by about fifty photographers and will be held in the art lending service gallery on the sixth floor of the museum at 21 West Fifty-third Street.

Substantial revisions in the methods of designing, merchandising and financing Manhattan apartment houses have taken place in the last four years, according to a builder who has resumed activity in this field after, a four-year hiatus.

THE handling and consequences of the U-2 affair are still being debated, and their importance has been underlined by the recent episode of the RB-47 reconnaissance aircraft. So far, most of the discussion has centered on the timing of the May Day flight that failed, and on the content of the official explanations that ensued.
LONDON, July 23 -- Premier Khrushchev's latest adventures in political bushwhacking have had a salutary effect in Britain.
RED BANK, N.J., July 23 (AP) -- Records were smashed in six of seven classes today as power boats competed in the National Sweepstakes regatta on the Navesink River.

VIENNA, July 17 -- Three hundred and fifty priceless paintings of the famous Habsburg collections spanning the fifteenth, sixteenth, seventeenth and eighteenth centuries have been put on view in the restored Kunsthistorisches Museum of Vienna.
Even a long, nation-wide sizzling hot spell could not appreciably improve the worst year since 1957 for stores and wholesalers selling room air conditioners.

TO THE EDITOR: IT has long been our policy to permit men and women confined in Federal prisons to write manuscripts in their spare time and submit them for publication so long as they do not exploit their own criminal career or that of others.

INITIAL preparation is about to begin on the screen version of "Hawaii," James A. Michener's sprawling novel of the history and development of our fiftieth state and, as might be surmised, some practical changes are in order.
MOSCOW, July 23 -- The other day the editors of a Communist youth newspaper asked a 17-year-old girl to drop into the office to explain her behavior at a party.

After a Century The bulletins of the Civil War Centennial Commission are already pointing out that practically every day of the next five years will be the 100th anniversary of some event relating to the War Between the States.

A number of young women from New York, Westchester, Connecticut, Long Island and New Jersey will make their formal bows to Society at the Mistletoe Debutante Ball, to be held at the Pierre on Dec. 23. The annual event is a benefit for the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
LONDON. SOME years ago, Terence Rattigan invented a character called Aunt Edna, who was the personification of that British playgoer the dramatist must please, if he is to be successful.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 23 -- The last Belgian troops pulled out of the metropolitan area of Leopoldville tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, July 23 (AP) -- Former Gov. Earl K. Long battled his way into a run-off for the House seat from Louisiana's Eighth Congressional District today. He will face Representative Harold Mc-Sween in the run-off on Aug. 27.

BALTIMORE, July 23 (UPI) -- Clem Labine, a Detroit relief pitcher, walked Jim Gentile with the bases filled and two out in the ninth inning tonight, and the Baltimore Orioles won, 4-3, in the second game of a twilight-night double-header.
Eighteen butchers in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn were arrested yesterday and charged with short-weighting in the sale of chickens. One butcher was a woman.
LOS ANGELES, July 23 (UPI) -- More than 900 forest fires, started by flashes or ashes, raged through nine Western states today.
WHAT are you working on now?" a friend asked me recently. "I'm hunting for a plot," I told him. It is a familiar predicament for me. It is, I imagine, for most novelists.

FROM the enchanting little Louis XVI style opera house built for the summer residence of the Swedish Kings at Drottningholm, to the luxurious new Festspielhaus nearlng completion at Salzburg, is a startling journey.
When the gavel is brought down to open the proceedings, at the Republican Presidential convention in Chicago tomorrow, one of the newest marketing techniques will be on view.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 23 -- Belgian officials expressed skepticism today about the amount of financial help that L. Edgar Detwiler would provide for the Congo.

THE apartheid-minded Afrikaner is rapidly becoming the heavy of South African fiction. Whereas Alan Paton treated his viewpoint with a certain amount of dignity in his novels, later writers have become more biting as the race issue becomes more exacerbated.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson picked Governor Rockefeller today as the strongest Republican Presidential candidate.

The Congo, a country one-third is big as the United States in the heart of Black Africa, is a wildernees of steamy equatorial jungle and vast stretches of grassy plain. Enormously rich, it is the source of half the world's uranium, 75 per cent of Its cobalt, 70 per cent of its Industrial diamonds.
MARSTRAND, Sweden, July 23 (Routers) -- The United States and Sweden each had a victory to its credit in the competition for the Scandinavian Gold Cup at the end of today's sailing.
JERSEY CITY, July 23 (AP) -- Raul Sanchez held Miami to five hits today as Jersey City defeated the Marlins, 2-0, in the International League.

Still Derailed "Tired driving? Take the train!" the Long Island Rail Road advises in its advertisements. By the end of last week, most of the railroad's 77,000 commuters and 95,000 singlefare riders would have been happy to heed that advice.
With international tension heightened and domestic business still spotty, the accent was acutely on caution in Wall Street again last week.
MILAN, Italy, July 18 -- The arrival of the Sicily-Milan train here every morning is a poignant reminder that there are two Italys.
GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 23 -- The report of Michael Davies' finish as a Davis Cup player appears to have been premature.
The New York Public Library is considering using the old, vacant Jefferson Market Courthouse in Greenwich Village as a branch library.

STANTON, Del., July 23 -- When Quill, Reginald N. Webster's gallant little 4-year-old filly, lowers her head and turns on the speed, look out. She won the $35,800 New Castle Stakes at Delaware Park today with one of those thrilling stretch runs that have marked her lucrative career.
EASTVIEW, N.Y., July 23 -- Grasslands Hospital, which takes a bigger bite from Westchester tax funds each year than any other unit of county government, has reached a crossroads.
FROM the time, last winter, when The Lambs lionized Brooks Atkinson in testimony to his years of service as a drama critic for this newspaper, the trophies and assorted distinctions have piled up.

LAWRENCE, L.I., July 23 -- Julius Rosen, Democratic candidate for Congress in the Third Congressional District, charged today that his Republican opponent, Representative Frank Becker, had "deliberately rigged" the questions in a poll of 117,000 voters to bolster his own political position.
The changes that have taken place in apartment house construction over the last four decades are clearly shown as a seventeen-story building, the Concourse Terrace, nears completion in the Bronx.
The silhouette of Long Island suburbs, regarded in the post-war era as the symbol of home styling in the East, is taking on a slightly new appearance as a result of a shift in style emphasis.

A SKING for Government subsidy of the theatre was represented by Brooks Atkinson in a recent Sunday column as an invitation to control. By this token, commercial theatre, the very antithesis of Government-supported theatre, should be a veritable bastion of freedom, a powerhouse of provocative and unorthodox ideas.

After Bertiand Russell's argument for neutralism had been received by The New York Times Magazine, the editors asked him to consider five questions raised by his articie. They follow, with his replies.

Resident buying offices reported last week that shipments and orders of fall merchandise were on the rise after a seasonal lull in activity the week before largely because of heavy vacation schedules.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Dr. Charles Richard Clark, a scientist who was a senior member of the research staff of the Johns Hopkins University Operations Research Office in Bethesda, Md., died today at the Washington Hospital Center.
BLOCK ISLAND, R.I. -- Standing at the tip of Grove Point, on the northern end of this picturesque island twelve miles off the southern New England coast, is a monument to the area's 'first settlers.

IRVING STONE once commented that Calvin Coolidge "aspired to become the least President the country had ever had; he attained his desire." Few will quarrel with this verdict. There is not a single piece of legislation or a single memorable public policy one associates with his tenure of the Presidency.

LONDON, July 23 -- Britain intends to "keep In contact' with the Soviet Union and press the Soviet Government for the settlement of disputes by discussion and negotiation, Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd said today.

LONDON, July 23 (UPI) -- Pat Smythe of Britain won the Daily Mail Cup championship jumping event today. George Morris of New Canaan, Conn., suffered bad luck when his mount stumbled and threw him at the outset of the closing event of the Royal International horse show.
OCEANSIDE, L.I., July 23 -- The South Nassau Communities Hospital, a nonprofit institution that serves twenty-one communities on the South Shore, will embark soon on a ten-year expansion plan.
Three top economists expect an economic recession either late this year or early next year. Two others look for a continuing high level of economic activity but nothing like a boom.
Thirty-three years ago a muscular red-haired lad of 19 named Fritz Robitschek decided to run away from his home in Stuttgart, Germany, and try his luck in the United States.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 23 (AP) -- Japanese Boy Scouts were highly concerned as to whether they would be welcome at the National Scout Jamboree here after President Elsenhower's proposed visit to Tokyo was canceled last month.

EDWARD TAYLOR was a Puritan, born in Leicestershire, England, probably in 1642. In 1668 he came to America, and bearing a letter of recommendation to Increase Mather, was admitted into Harvard College, where he was a classmate of Judge Samuel Sewall.

PARIS, July 23 -- There were unconfirmed reports today that President de Gaulle had not looked with favor on the proposal made to him two days ago by Paul-Henri Spaak for equipping France with United States-built Polaris intermediate-range ballistic missiles.

LONDON. DURING the six weeks I have been in England I have read only three books in their entirety; one old, one recent, one new. (Though I have dipped into several others, I must confess to having spent a perhaps disproportionate share of my reading time on a renewed acquaintance with the British press.)
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 23 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, the 1956 Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, is waging a desperate fight to retain his Senate seat.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- The Republican platform agreement reached today by Vice President Nixon and Governor Rockefeller appeared calculated to bring important political benefits to both.

To the Travel Editor: It is rarely indeed that I, a publicity-shy housewife and mother, become so agitated as to express my opinions other than verbally, but the article in the Travel Section of July 10 entitled "The Family Is the Menace on the Family Tour" by Betsy Wade is so completely ridiculous that I cannot resist the desire to reply.

JOHN CROSBY once wished that there were a name for people who infest television broadcasts -- like "plips." There's an equally urgent need for a name applicable to the books written by and about television folk: "bokks," or "bookels," perhaps.

New York's wholesale fashion markets reflected renewed interest in fall merchandise last week. There was an increase in buyer registrations as retailers swung into the order-checking phase of fall planning. At the same time, buyers sought quick renewals on summer dresses and other hot-weather seasonal items for further promotions.
A substantial increase in the number of American families who own second homes for summer or other seasonal use is foreseen by observers of the nation's real estate scene.
Bond prices have been rising almost uninterruptedly since April, and the general feeling in all Street is that the upward movement is far from spent.

SARASOTA, Fla. -- The novelty of a Mr.-and-Mrs. golf tournament, open to any husband and wife team, is being offered this summer by a group of eleven hotels and motels in the beach area here and in downtown Sarasota.
INVERNESS, Scotland, July 23 -- The quest for the elusive Loch Ness monster is reaching such proportions that some of the Highlanders living near the loch are afraid the monster may get hurt.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The convention of the Democratic party has declared its support in the civil rights section of the platform for "whatever action is necessary to eliminate literacy tests * * * as requirements for voting."

NIAGARA FALLS, Ont. -- Eighteen times a day apiece, the two powerful new boats named respectively the Maid of the Mist and the Maid of the Mist II one by one ply a short, bumpy course from their dock here practically into the water-curtain of the two spectacular cataracts that make up Niagara Falls.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- A dramatic, pre-dawn Nixon-Rockefeller platform accord cleared the way today for next week's Republican National Convention to nominate Vice President Nixon for President without serious opposition -- and perhaps none.
LONDON, July 23 -- Two of the world's largest radio telescopes are scanning the heavens in an effort to determine whether the universe was born in a huge explosion ten billion years ago.

The Sheltering Arms Children's Service will benefit from the evening performance of "The Unsinkable Molly Brown" on Nov. 17. The musical, starring Tammy Grimes, is scheduled to open at the Winter Garden Theatre on Nov. 3.

IN television's present pre-occupation with politics scant notice has been paid to the latest development with respect to feature-length motion pictures made since 1948. The long-awaited thaw in the general freeze on showing recent movies on home TV has come about; the only remaining questions are how and when they will be exhibited.

ONE hundred years ago, a pathetic musical figure of the late Romantic era was born in Windischgraz, a village in the region of Styria, which lies south of Vienna. His name was Hugo Wolf, and misfortune seems to have lain in wait for him almost from the moment of his christening.
Forty-four pedal-pushers exceeded the 25-mile-an-hour speed limit at Central Park yesterday before 500 policemen and about 50,000 strollers who couldn't have been more casual.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 23 -- Thailand is preparing what may be the most far-reaching study of democracy and its forms and procedures ever undertaken by a Far-Eastern nation.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 23 -- To meet increasing demands for its services, the Mental Health Consultation Center of Bergen County will move into larger quarters next week.

A SINGER who wants to find a chorus to sing in can consult the American Choral Foundation's "Listing of Non-professional Choruses in the New York Metropolitan Area." An instrumentalist who wants to find friends to play chamber music with can consult the annual directory of the Amateur Chamber Music Players.

It's high time vacation-bound pleasure boat skippers from the Hudson River waters or Long Island Sound ports strayed off their beaten paths to get acquainted with new cruising adventures. That goes for weekenders, too.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has budgeted an expenditure of $15,000,000 for the first three months' operations of the United Nations Congo force and an accompanying technical assistance program.
PAMPLONA, Spain, July 15 -- This is the story of a tourist, wild cow and the fiesta here.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 23 (AP) -- American swimmers broke two world and three United States records today in the Amateur Athletic Union championships.

PARIS, July 23. -- The hard Soviet line in international affairs is viewed by French experts as a tactical shift based on-the Kremlin's belief in electoral paralysis in the United States, not as a prelude to a dangerous adventure.

Department store sales in the nation rose 2 per cent in the week ended July 16 from the 1959 level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. In the prior holiday week, sales fell 14 per cent below the year-ago level, which did not include the Fourth of July holiday.
PARIS, July 23 -- Western Europe, full of prosperity, is also full of warnings about inflation.

THIS should be, as Babe Ruth used to say, "one helluva story if it's told right." The lovable Bambino invariably would manage to garble whatever he tried to put over. We hope to do better, even if we're unfamiliar with the subject.

BY planting every available inch of soil -- except for a few narrow walks -- a Queens home owner has transformed a 40x60-foot backyard into a highly productive vegetable garden. Andrew Colman, who raises fruits and vegetables as a hobby, has successfully adapted space-saving techniques used in European countries.

IN a neat counterpoint to the growing age of specialization, the theatre owners of the nation merit a moment in the spotlight for their growing variety of enterprises. There was, of course, a time when motion-picture exhibitors were single-minded men, dedicated exclusively to the presentation of films in theatres.

THE Independent Airlines Association, representing the nation's supplemental (formerly the non-scheduled) air carriers plans to offer on Sept. 1, fourteen-day air charter flights to Europe for about $222 the round trip.

THIS was the House of Fear, a fascinating feature of the Continent of Atlantis, now in process of creation at the Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer studio, where men were being transformed into beasts or half-beasts at the behest of a man in exotic robes, who spun a crystal and intoned: "Now you will close your eyes.

A NEWS release from the State of Connecticut has uncovered a new development in the world of striped bass and has shown why fly fishermen have to be watched every minute to keep them from shattering the laws enacted for their benefit.
SALISBURY, Southern, Rhodesia, July 23 -- The riotous events of last week in Salisbury, capital of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, have increased concern over future race relations here.

THIS lively and enthusiastic introduction to Frederic Mistral, the Provencal poet, provides the best possible initiation to Provence -- to its scenery, its past, its customs and a poetical simplicity which not even the noisy herds of holiday-makers in ever dwindling bikinis and the congeries of the world's drinking classes along the Riviera have succeeded in spoiling.

AN extraordinary circumstance of much contemporary art criticism is that its major premise, when contemporary painting is under, sympathetic examination is taken for granted by the critic but not understood by the reader.

John Coleman, lean and red-bearded, rolled his 1925 Austin Chummy convertible into Austin Clark's automotive museum at Southhampton, L.I., last week and checked his mileage. He had just completed an 11,100-mile journey from Buenos Aires.
The Port of New York Authority is seeking help from governors across the nation.

CHIBOUGAMAU, Que. -- This is where the road ends in the heart of the Hudson's Bay wilderness. In contrast to the luxury of the Saguenay River Valley with its breath-taking scenery, this is the frontier of northern Quebec.

Prospects for early settlement of the Long Island Rail Road strike worsened yesterday as union engineers made it definite that they would not return to work unless they received a shorter work week or higher wages.

LIKE any other piece of mechanical equipment, an air conditioner can function effectively only if it is used properly. Regardless of whether it is window-mounted or wall-mounted, there are certain operating and maintenance procedures for maximum efficiency and economy of operation.

TWO handsomely package sets of two LP's apiece currently offer trip through time and space to the old West. One set travel to last century's frontier with all the comfort and smoothness of a jet airliner, while the other takes the slow, bumpy, but authentic trail of the covered wagon.

A raised ranch house combining the facilities of ranch and split-level homes is being shown at Hallmark Village, a community of 300 dwellings on Dee Park Avenue, Babylon, L.I. 500 feet south of Exit 39 on the Southern State Parkway.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 2 -- Bizzy Monte-Sano, a 19-year-old Larchmont youth who attends Yale and teaches salling as a junior instructor at the American Yacht Club, was declared the outstanding skipper of the sixty-second annual Larchmont Race Week tonight.
LONG BEACH, Calif., July 23 (AP) -- The skipper of a destroyer said today he had tried vainly to avoid a collision Tuesday after spotting another ship bearing down on him through dense fog.

TlHE Rocky Mountains of Colorado have noble majesty. They invite summer-time hikes through valleys and across ridges to learn of their fascinating wild flowers. In recent summers I have spent several days hiking in the most verdant regions to see natural phenomena never to be forgotten.
Wall Street, seldom swift to bestow its affections, has found a new darling -- the small business investment company.

VICENTE ESCUDERO will celebrate his sixty-eight birthday in America next October. And he is not coming over merely to be guest of honor at any cake-cuttings, either; he is going to dance, which is a happy surprise all around.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 23 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg, S.C., overcame a sevenstroke deficit today, finishing with a 292 and becoming the first four-time winner of the United States women's open golf championship.

BONN, Germany, July 23 -- The United States has expressed concern to its allies over the growing practice of extending private medium-term commercial credits to the Soviet bloc for purchases of strategic materials.

TO THE EDITOR : HERBERT J. MULLER says in his review of "Nehru on World History": "Nehru wrote this book in a British jail. Are political prisoners in Russian or Chinese jails free to write and publish their reflections?"

IN this excellent and important study Elliot Goodman traces the development of Russian totalitarian imperialism He demonstrates how carefully selected elements of Marxism and Russian nationalism have been fused into a design for "an omnipotent totalitarian Soviet world state, which the Soviet leadership continues to pursue relentlessly, and often skillfully."

A ruckus developed last week over New York banks' starting branches in the suburbs. In letters to each member of the State Banking Board accompanied by photographs, the Nassau-Suffolk Financial Council asked if the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn had received advance assurance that its application for a branch would be approved.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Bernard (Tut) Bartzen of Dallas swept past Rod Laver of Australia, 6-4, 6-1, 6-8, 6-2, today and gained the final of the national clay court tennis tournament.

ATLANTA, July 23 -- The South seemed resigned this week to steering a traditionally Democratic course in the November Presidential election. But the ticket of Sennator John F. Kennedy and Senator Lyndon B. Johnson brought no outpouring of enthusiasm.
A Presbyterian minister who is prominent in Australia said last week he had found that cancer "quite often yields to spiritual healing."

Two senior monopolitan Amateur Athletic Union swimming championships and four development events will be held in the New York Athletic Club pool at Travers Island, Pelham Manor, N.Y., on Friday evening.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- Governor Rockefeller of New York seems determined to imitate Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois in demonstrating how not to win a Presidential nomination in 1960.
DETROIT, July 23 -- A three-way race for the Democratic nomination for Governor will be the main attraction in the Michigan primary election on Aug. 2.

Widow-Premier For the first eight of Ceylon's dozen years as an independent member of the British Commonwealth the Government was in the hands of the moderate United National party. Then the 1956 general elections swept an opposing coalition into power.

History may decide that the sudden revival of activity in the United Nations, as witnessed by the debates in the Security Council last week on the Congo and on the RB-47 plane incident, should be ranked as one of the important developments of 1960.
ROME, July 23 (AP) -- The Olympic village is ready.
Frozen bread, an innovation in one of man's oldest known foods, is being introduced to New Yorkers.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 -- President Eisenhower has determined he will keep "hands off" the selection of a running mate for Vice President Nixon at the Republican National Convention.

LONDON, July 23 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo stopped over here this evening on his way to the United States. He had a private talk with John D. Profumo, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, and other British officials.
The 10,000 members of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, one of the nation's most important maritime unions, will begin voting Aug. 1 on a proposal to modernize its organization.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., July 23 -- Firing the best round in the tourney's fifteen-year history, the team of Fred Smith and John Paskowitz took a three-stroke lead today in the opening round of the state Scotch four-some championship.
An unusual facade, with metal decorative grilles set into a glazed white brick exterior, distinguishes Cameo House, an apartment building that has just opened in Hempstead, L.I.
ATLANTA, July 23 -- Democrats face the possibility today that an aggressive campaign will be needed to win the South in the November Presidential election.

CINCINNATI, July 23 (UPI) -- Walt Moryn hit a two-run homer off Bob Grim in the tenth inning today, the St. Louis Cardinals winning, 7-5, from the Cincinnati Reds. The game was marred by seven errors.

DOVER, Del., July 23 -- Delaware's grade-a-year program for desegregation of its public school system was struck down this week by a three-judge unit of the United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 23 -- Mayor James W. Kelly Jr. today proposed that Essex County municipalities through which the proposed east-west freeway would run pay 10 percent of the cost of depressing the roadway.
NEW DELHI, India, July 23 -- Dr. Krishnalal Shridharani, a leading Indian newspaper man and author, died here today of a heart attack. He was 50 years old.
KATMANDU, Nepal, July 23 -- Chinese Communist troops have made at least a dozen incursions into northern Nepal in the last two months, according to usually reliable sources here.
The State Board of Cemeteries last week asked the State Attorney General to intervene in a suit in Supreme Court to defend a schedule of cemetery fees that the board had approved.
The staff of the Flight Safety Foundation is how preparing to deal with a new set of safety problems that it expects to arise in virtually all areas of aviation.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 23 -- The Stamford Yacht Club's annual predicted-log contest today was won by Ellas A. Kalil in his fifty-five-foot Irene K. V, with an accuracy score of 99.45 per cent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Prof. Alfred E. Kahn, in his letter published July 10, suggests that Cuba's taking of the oil refineries flowed directly from the cut in the sugar quota and questions "the economic wisdom of these policies." He concludes by stating that "the primary considerations underlying our action are of course primarily diplomatic and strategic" and wonders "how this move is expected to halt Cuba's drift toward communism."

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, July 23 -- A semblance of sanity is beginning to return to the Congo's capital but the unreal, nightmarish atmosphere of the past two weeks has not yet vanished. The nightmare defies description. There has been a full measure of human tragedy but also a good deal of low comedy.

Title THE front cover of Houghton Mifflin's autumn catalogue is composed of thirty-five small pictures of its autumn authors. They are identified by last name only -- Schlesinger, Ciardi, Auchincloss -- save for one.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 23 (AP) -- Lieut. Robert L. Beck retained a narrow lead in the United States modern pentathlon trials today despite a tenth-place finish in the cross-country run.

TO THE EDITOR: In describing the Moscow airport ("First Visit to a Muffled Colossus," July 3), Britisher James Morris may have misled your readers. He describes it as "one of the prime air junctions of the world * * * crammed and cluttered with unfamiliar aircraft, more than you have ever seen in your life before," and notes the "tremendous sense of imperial power" that emanates from "this pulsing terminus."

A LIST of 300 country fairs in the northeastern states and eastern Canada should serve as an adequate reminder that harvest time is approaching. From now to mid-November, these celebrations will constitute one of the principal rustic attractions for tourists.
Two college professors who have been teaching summer courses in religion saw some of their students yesterday for the first time.
PARIS, July 23 -- Thorkil Kristensen of Denmark was named today as Secretary General of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 23 -- Pappa's All scored a nose victory today in the $143,200 Hollywood Juvenile Championship for 2-year-olds.

To the Screen Editor: I APPRECIATE your review of "Elmer Gantry," published last Sunday. I have seen the picture and believe it is a great one. However, as a student of Sinclair Lewis' books, I must disagree with your statement that Hollywood wreaked no indignities on the source book in this case.

WASHINGTON. July 23 -- For the 100 years of its life from Lincoln through Eisenhower, the formal celebration of which begins in Chicago next week, the Republican party has done a good job of preserving a remarkably consistent image of itself.
SYRACUSE, July 23 -- A two year study of vandalism here indicates that when student feel disassociated from their schools property damage resuits.

FOR THIS WEEK: Dust DDT on flower border edges to ward off striped stalk borer which migrates to annuals from weeds. . . . Check softwood cuttings for adequate moisture. . . . A mulch and proper watering prevents blossom-end rot of tomatoes. . . . Disbud those dahlias being groomed for shows. . . . Cut bouquets in the morning.

HAVANA, July 23 -- Communist China will purchase 2,500,000 long tons of sugar from Cuba, at an average of 500,000 tons a year, for the next five years. Peiping will grant Cuba a credit for her to buy "complete factories" in China, according to a joint trade treaty signed here late tonight.

Up Polaris Cmdr, James B. Osborn, captain of the nuclear submarine U.S.S. George Washington, wired President Eisenhower last Wednesday afternoon: "Polaris -- from out of the deep to target, Perfect." The Navy had, for the first time, successfully fired its Polaris missile from under water.

Soviet Russia's bellicosity over Cuba and the Congo has so far tended to stir anxiety chiefly in its threats to world peace. In light of past Soviet behavior, however, it may prove to be the stormy overture to a bloodless economic offensive.
BERLIN, July 14 -- How should co-eds of a Communist teachers college be disciplined if they stay out too long at night with their boy friends?

ONE of the 1960 nominating conventions has passed into history; another looms ahead. In combination, the two focus attention on the issue of Presidential popularity. And, in this connection, the White House years of President Eisenhower provide a fascinating case study.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Weather Bureau told today how the Tiros I weather-eye satellite performed an unexpected meteorological feat by photographing a "square" cloud that spawned tornadoes over Oklahoma.

To the Screen Editor: I want to register my despair, horror and anger upon seeing Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho," a film which is currently being shown in New York; despair, because of my own confusion on the problem of film censorship in this country.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 23 (AP) -- John Konsek, the defending champion, and Eddie Kaczor, both of Buffalo, won theit matches in a tense semi-final round today to reach the final of the thirty-eighth annual New York State amateur golf championship.

The Glen View Development Company has announced the opening of Allison Court, a colony of split-level and Colonial dwellings on Van Emburgh Avenue in Ridgewood, N.J. The houses, which have exteriors of brick and cedar siding, are priced at $28,900.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 23 -- Connecticut's first Republican Congressional primary election will be held Wednesday in Fair field County.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The chairman of a House subcommittee investigating the withholding of information by the Executive Branch said today that the Pentagon stamped "secret" on enough peacetime documents each week to pile up a tower higher than the Empire State Building.
CHALNA, Pakistan, July 7 -- The Governor of East Pakistan stood on the rickety wooden porch of a shop that advertised ganja (marijuana) and opium.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- The Democratic farm plank has cheered farm belt advocates of high Government price supports and strict production controls on basic crops. It has disappointed advocates of less Government regulation of farming.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- The University of Chicago plans to spend $75,000,000 to expand its campus.

CLARYVILLE, N.Y. -- The Catskill Mountains are about as highly a developed and built-up mountain and resort area as exists anywhere in the world. In some places, one might fairly question whether things have not been overbuilt.

PARIS -- The Ile de France, whose heart is Paris, can be considered in many ways the heart of France. It was, under the Old Regime, a French province but, like the other royal provinces, lost its actual political significance with the Revolution.

CHERRY POINT, N.C., July 23 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Harry R. Van Liew of the Marine Corps Reserve, a senior United Airlines pilot, died of a heart attack here today while playing golf. He was 55 years old and lived in St. James, L.I.

The urgent problems facing public education in the United States were illustrated in concrete local terms last week by thirty-seven school superintendents from thirty-three states who are meeting at Teachers College, Columbia University, this summer in an effort to find some answers.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York has been appeased by Vice President Nixon but unless he changes his mind at the last minute he has not been captured. He has influenced and improved the Republican platform but he has not joined the Republican ticket.

LOS ANGELES, July 23 (AP) -- With Roger Craig pitching a three-hitter, the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight scored a 2-0 victory and extended the Philadelphia Phillies' scoreless streak to twenty-four innings.

The United States team defeated Mongolia, 3-0, yesterday in the seventh round of the international students' chess team tournament at Leningrad. The victory gave the first-place United States team a 22-5 record in the standing, according to a wireless report from the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Vice President Nixon indicated today "he thought Governor Rockefeller of New York was out of the race to be the Republican party's Vice-Presidential candidate. The Vice President gave his views at a hastily called news conference on Capitol Hill.
Rockefeller Statement The Vice President and I met today at my home in New York City.
LOS ANGELES, July 23 -- Nine Western states were battling this week-end against one of, the worst outbreaks of forest fires in a generation.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 -- Juan Marichal scored his second victory in two major league starts by stopping the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-1, today on four hits. Home runs by Bob Schmidt and Willie Mays drove in the San Francisco runs.

Jittery in the infield, uncertain in the outfield and none too solid on the mound, the Yankees succumbed, 5-3, to the White Sox at the Stadium yesterday. The immediate effect of this third straight New York setback and seventh straight Chicago success was a switch in the top two positions in the standings.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- The pulse of pre-convention activities quickened today. The lobbies of the Conrad Hilton and the Sheraton-Blackstone hotels began to look like Grand Central Terminal at rush hour. Carpenters swarmed through the superstructure of the International Amphitheatre, nailing everything in place with hammer blows that crackled and reverberated in the 12,500-seat arena.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Governor Rockefeller definitely ruled out today any possibility that he might accept the Republican Vice-Presidential nomination. He said that if necessary he would issue a "Sherman statement" to that effect.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 23 (Reuters) -- Belgian authorities said today their troops would remain in Katanga Province as long as the province's Premier, Moise Tshombe, wanted them to.

MONTREAL, July 22 -- Quebec's first liberal premier in sixteen years, Jean Lesage, is moving fast, and for some a little furiously, to make good his election promises.

YONKERS, July 23 -- The Mercury Stable's Silver Song with Howard Camden at the controls, scored a half-length victory over Air Record in 2:02 3-5 in the Monitor mile trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight before 33,015 fans.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Steel mill activity fell this month to less than half of capacity, the lowest rate in twenty-one years, excepting strike shutdowns. Automobile production has climbed this year to the second highest level since the invention of the steering wheel.

BOSTON, July 23 -- Jimmy Piersall was thrown out of another game today, but the Indians, on Jim Perry's eleventh victory of the season, gained a 4-2 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.

IN this second volume of his history of the American Communist party, Theodore Draper maintains the high standard set in his "The Roots of American Communism" three years ago. The present volume carries the story from the party's emergence from the underground in 1923 to the assumption by Earl Browder of the party leadership in 1929.

GREAT NECK, L. I., July 23 -- A 26-year-old housewife was kidnapped early today after her husband had been shot by an intruder in their $75,000 home in the Harbor Hills section of this Nassau County village.

NEW HAVEN, July 23 -- Thomas F. Creamer, friend, adviser, disciplinarian and chaperon of Yale University students for thirty-eight years, will be missing from the campus when classes resume in September. Mr. Creamer, 67-year-old captain of the campus police and acting chief since January, will retire on July 31.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: New York is the city where "7,710,346 Americans live * * * and enjoy the benefits * * *." With the new shift of Lexington and Third Avenues to one-way motion, one wonders how many of the seven million "enjoy" this latest "benefit," let alone how many will "live" through it.
Mrs. Dorothy Strauss, a former New York lawyer, died in a fire at her summer home on Gott Island, near Bar Harbor, Maine, early Friday. She was 72 years old.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, W.I. July 12 -- A new cattle and poultry feed mill began operations last week in the middle of a bauxite mining area in Jamaica's hills. Early this fall the First National City Bank of New York will open its first Jamaican branch.
LONG BEACH, L.I., July 24 Battling crowded Long Island highways and an intense sun, Bill Omeltchenko won the Amateur Athletic Union 21.1-mile walk today.
PARIS, July 24 -- Sunday in Paris is quiet. All doors are tightly sealed, except at the French Couture houses where the traditional last minute nightmares are boiling.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 24 -- Violence spread today to Bulawayo, one of the principal industrial cities of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It seems the Long Island Rail Road is making another contribution to the creeping history of a changing suburbia.

Whatever it was that Yankee pitchers had been doing wrong recently, Eli Grba stopped doing it yesterday. The bespectacled young right-hander, who flinches only when confronted by a vowel, went all the way, outpitched and outlasted Herb Score and others and stopped the front-running White Sox, 8-2.
ROCHESTER, July 24 (UPI) -- John Konsek defeated a fellow Buffalonian, Ed Kaczor, 8 and 6, today to become the first player to win the New York State amateur golf title three times in a row.
Around 8 o'clock on a hot summer evening the sun's rays, striking across town, light up East Harlem's decaying building fronts and turn the lines of fire-escapes into a fine, gilt tracery.
A church missionary who has spent twenty years in Burma said yesterday that the task of Christian missionaries in Asia was growing increasingly difficult.
CHICAGO, July 24 -- Governor Rockefeller again deferred today a decision on the role he would play at the Republican National Convention, pending a final report from the platform committee.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, the Democratic National Chairman, said today that "deathbed conversions do not carry conviction." He referred to the platform accord reported yesterday between Vice President Nixon and Governor Rockefeller of New York.
The Rev. Peter J. Daly of the Jesuit Order, headmaster of the Loyola School, a Roman Catholic high school at Park Avenue and Eighty-third Street, died Saturday in Pisa, Italy. He was 51 years old.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner were urged yesterday to investigate the strike of 4,000 steamfitters on New York construction projects.
PAKIA, Greece, July 24 -- Peasants flocked here today amid sunbaked olive groves and vineyards to the dedication of a Greek Orthodox church in this hamlet in the Peloponnesian mountains.
The Rev. Dr. Albert T. Mollegan of the Protestant Episcopal Theological Seminary in Virginia said yesterday that no one would "ask or want" a man's religion to influence his public life.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to express admiration and appreciation for the article by Richard Eder, "Youth Squeezed by City Job Crisis," published July 5. It not only presented the facts that threaten youth in New York City and across the continent, but pierced the pious sentiments and pretensions that have too long characterized inaction in this field.
