The many thousands of people who depend on the Long Island Rail Road, bedeviled enough by the trainmen's strike, now face still more trouble -- a refusal of the engineers to return to work when the trainmen go back. The price the engineers have set for their return is a day off every week or premium pay for week-ends and holidays.
PARIS, July 24 -- A mission of International Monetary Fund experts is in Paris negotiating with representatives of the Bank of France on means to achieve greater convertibility of the franc.

THE forthcoming campaign between Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy apparently will include face-to-face debate on television. Such a step should add immeasurably to interest in the campaign.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo said today he was "very optimistic, very satisfied" after a two-hour conference with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

CHICAGO. Our basic foreign policy, which throughout this century lurched between isolationism and active intervention, has clearly settled on the latter. Americans at last have learned the lesson of Thucydides, who wrote of ancient Athens: "We hope to be excused if we forswear our old principle of complete political isolation, a principle which was not adopted with any sinister intention but was rather the consequence of an error in judgment."

TRENTON, July 24 -- Bob Marshman, a 23-year-old driver from Pottstown, Pa., won a 300mile midget auto race before a crowd of 16,000 today. The contest was the longest ever run for these small (110 cubic-inch displacement) editions of Indianapolis-type machines.
GENEVA, July 24 -- Volume continued low on the Swiss stock markets last week. Trading was adversely affected by the troubled international situation caused by the events in the former Belgian Congo.
HAVING quietly but firmly been asked to hold its request for a major league baseball franchise in abeyance, Madison Square Garden returns tonight to its first love. This, of course, is boxing.

Nothing seems to do more to make the Communist countries want Cuban sugar than the fact that the United States does not intend to take as much of that commodity as it has been doing in past years. President Eisenhower cut back this year's remaining Cuban import quota on July 6, under authority given him by Congress, by about 95 per cent.

The Bon Odori, or Remembrance Dance, a venerable Japanese Buddhist folk festival celebrating the end of the monsoon season, the emergence of monks from their summer retreat and the memory of seven generations of ancestors, is becoming part of the folklore of the Upper West Side.

ELISABETHVILLE, July 24 (AP) -- While Premier Moise Tshombe of Katanga tries to convince the world that Katanga will remain an independent pro-Western state, no one -- not even his Belgian supporters -- quite believes it.

The decision to authorize an independent Citizens for Kennedy committee in New York constitutes a move to get the enthusiasm and emotional commitment a candidate needs to carry the state's forty-five electoral votes.

Motorists traveling through Queens face congestion and delay for the next three years as a result of the massive $95,000,000 program to provide smooth traffic access to and from the 1964 World's Fair.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 24 -- Gordon Stott of the home club today regained the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship he had won in 1950. Stott defeated Charley Slicklen of North Hempstead, 3 and 1, in the 36-hole final at the Nassau Country Club.

It looks now as if the "calm before the storm" cliche weren't going to apply to this summer's weather and hurricanes. As East Coast dwellers well know from past ordeals, the tropical storms that form in the Atlantic-Caribbean area and often whirl up the coast are more likely to strike us between the middle of July and the end of September, but seldom after November sets in.

U.S. NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, July 24 -- Premier Fidel Castro and his supporters were converging to- day on Santiago de Cuba and the Sierra Maestra range, forty miles from here, to celebrate the revolutionary holiday of July 26.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- A committee revolt against Nixon-Rockefeller platform proposals tonight disrupted the harmony among Republicans on the eve of their convention. The party's twenty-seventh National Convention, which opens tomorrow morning, will nominate Vice President Nixon for the Presidency.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., July 24 (AP) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson said today that Congress would be able to complete its work when it reconvened Aug. 8.
MOSCOW, July 24 -- The Warsaw Pact nations announced tonight that Soviet Marshal Ivan S. Konev, their supreme military commander, had been replaced by Marshal Andrei A. Grechko.
ELISABETHVILLE, The Congo, July 24 (Reuters) -- The Government of Katanga Pro- vince accused Belgium today of letting it down by failure to press at the United Nations for its independence.
RABAT, Morocco, July 24 -- The Moroccan Government has embarked on a program to regroup the country's small land holdings to form more productive agricultural units.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- Mike Mansfield of Montana, assistant Senate Democratic leader, said today that American foreign policy would be a key issue in the Presidential campaign but that the debate should be kept on a "high level."
Two features, both of which arrive on Wednesday, comprise the week's list of film newcomers.
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 18 -- Laotian farmers are going about the age-old business of setting out their rice plants despite two threats hanging over them.

PITTSBURGH, July 24 -- Steel production and shipments this month will probably turn out to be the lowest since the recession of 1958. That was the view here last week as no change appeared in the volume of new orders.
LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers scored eight runs in the third inning today and handed the Philadelphia Phillies their third straight shutout, 9 -- 0.

CAMPUS fashions this fall promise more bounce to the ounce in both color and styling, Striking back at the Bermuda shorts ban, designers have come up with impudent versions of the culotte-skirt ending just above the knee, often teamed with new longer, bulkier sweaters.

Plans to relocate the New York air traffic control center away from the city by late 1962 or early 1963 in line with a nation-wide dispersal program have been announced by the Federal Aviation Agency.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 24 -- Planners of the Kennedy-for-President campaign are building their organization and their hopes on four basic approaches.

SALERNO, Italy, July 24 (UPI) -- A wealthy mystery man of European auto tracks caused his own death and injured nineteen spectators today when his Cooper smashed off the course and caught fire during a race here.

BALTIMORE, July 24 (AP) -- Jackie Brandt's eleventh-inning single, his fourth hit of the game, scored Billy Klaus with the deciding run as the Baltimore Orioles won, 2 -- 1, from the Detroit Tigers today.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A touch of gray in the hair may be helpful to a Presidential candidate but it is not very good for an actor.
Intervention by George Meany resulted last night in the acceptance of a formula for ending the strike of 750 captains on sand and gravel scows in the harbor.
LENOX, Mass., July 24 -- The week-end emphasis of the Berkshire Music Festival programs at Tanglewood was on two virtuosos -- one established for many years, the other on his way up.

DISHONESTY is sometimes funny, though it is always serious. The humor rises occasionally from the imaginative bluffing some individuals do when questioned about their deceits. Take the salesman who blandly turned in a $200 expense-account chit covering lunch for two. When the accounting department went into a flurry, he explained that his client appeared so shabby that on the way to the restaurant he steered the man into Brooks Brothers and bought him a suit.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The swift pace toward practical exploitation of space is forcing a reappraisal of the Government's role in developing and controlling the use of space.

Too many Roman Catholics "betray ignorance and fear by the sheep's clothing of superstition," the Rev. John J. Foley said yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which has only one exclamation-point type of program ("Tightrope!") left on the air, will add another on Nov. 13. The new one is titled "Oh, Those Bells!" and stars the Wiere Brothers, whose given names are Herbert, Harry and Sylvester.

Aluminium, Ltd., plans the construction of new facilities at Arvida, Quebec, for the production of aluminum by a basically new process, Nathanael V. Davis, president, announced over the week-end. The new facilities are expected to be in operation in about two years and their capital cost is placed at about $4,000,000.
CHICAGO, Monday, July 25 -- The Republican Platform Committee called yesterday for a defense posture "superior to all potential foes."
GREENWICH, Conn., July 24 -- James Starkweather's Loon led the Rhodes-18 Class home today on Long Island Sound in the East-of-Rye championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association.

A LITTLE girl named Patricia of Washington, D.C., was studying American history one day and asked her father, Richard, "Is it true that Abraham Lincoln, our sixteenth President, was the first Republican President?"

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Washington handed Kansas City a 6-3 victory by committing five errors in one inning today, but the Senators triumphed, 10 -- 2, in the second game of a double-header as Camilo Pascual pitched shutout ball for seven innings, with Ray Moore relieving.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 24 -- Carl and Arthur Buhr sailed Fury to victory in the Lightning Class today in Interclub racing on Manhasset Bay. Dick-Sykes' Dixie was second in the fleet of thirteen.

LONDON, July 24 -- Despite the slight tremors felt, here during last week's declines in Wall Street, the London stock market continued at its steady pace and in some instances registered slight gains.

The Board of Estimate has decided to discuss informally this week the possibility of moving ahead soon with the $25,000,000 Bellevue South slum-clearance project.

The bitter fight in Chicago over the wording of certain planks of the Republican platform belies the glib theory that platforms really don't mean a thing. They do have significance even though they are almost never completely fulfilled. They do reassert the party's philosophy and they bring it up to date; they set the tone of the campaign and establish a standard by which the party can be judged.

Considerable recent improvement of United States exports was seen yesterday as producing a surplus of $3,400,000,000 of exports over imports by the end of this year. Last year's surplus was barely $1,000,000,000.

THE crayfish recently arrived in town and there are rumors, so far unsubstantiated, that Swedes are flying over simply to enjoy a pre-season taste of their favorite-shellfish. In Sweden the gathering of crayfish is limited to the month of August.

The Zale Jewelry Company's record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended March 31 were largely a result of expansion, Morris B. Zale, chairman, said at the annual meeting here yesterday. Net income was $3,088,866, or $1,96 a share, on sales of $51,643,834.

Net income of the Ford Motor Company in the second quarter was 19.5 per cent below the record earnings achieved in the 1959 period, the company reported yesterday. Earnings for the first half of 1960 were 7.4 per cent below those of the corresponding period last year.

World sugar futures closed higher yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in fairly heavy trading. CHICAGO, July 25 -- The Republican Platform Committee approved a foreign policy plank today that stands largely on the record and program of the Eisenhower Administration.

BONN, Germany, July 25 -- A little unusual soul-searching was going on in West Germany today as result of the Brettheim verdict -- the acquittal of a former Nazi general of a charge of hanging three German civilians a month before the end of World War II.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 25 -- President Eisenhower gave his personal endorsement today to the proposed resolution on national defense awaiting adoption by the Republican National Convention.
MOSCOW, July 25 -- Nearly forty-three years after the Bolshevik Revolution, the Soviet Government still is struggling to rid its people of the desire for private profit.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba said today that peace and order in the Congo would be restored "within five minutes" after the complete withdrawal of Belgian troops.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- The Nixon family, preparing for its most important moment, held a reunion at O'Hare Airport today.
The Magma Copper Company had a net income of $2,882,137, equal to $2.39 a share in the quarter ended on June 30. This compared with $2,058,672, or $1.71 a share, for the 1959 quarter.
GARY, Ind., July 25 -- Desire Defauw, former musical director and conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, died of pneumonia today in his home here. He was 74 years old.

The reduced rate of operations was reflected in declines in sales and earnings in the second quarter and half year for the Armco Steel Coloration. The company expects a gradual upturn in the operating rate by late August.
A highly paid consultant complained bitterly yesterday that the company that hired him didn't seek or take his advice.
Plans were announced yesterday for the first new major hotel to be built in Lakewood, N.J., in thirty years.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Hedge selling and profit taking were controlling factors today in grain futures trading and prices retreated all along the line.
Robert Moses has invited or has made plans to invite more than thirty distinguished citizens of the city to go abroad during the next seven months to promote the 1964 New York World's Fair.

JEROME WEIDMAN'S "Before You Go"* is bound to be one of the outstanding successes of the year. It is a heady balance of cheers and jeers. And it has all the elements of dramatic effectiveness that make for that strange manifestation of the people's choice -- a best-seller.
CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Reels scored all their runs in the last three innings today to beat the Chicago Cubs, 6 -- 5, and break a four-game losing streak.

Emile Griffith, a tireless welterweight from the West Side, scored a unanimous decision over Jorge Fernandez of Argentina in a nontelevised fight at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 3,200 paid $8,000 to watch it.
The reign of "Queen for a Day" on the National Broad casting Company television network will come to an end Sept 2.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 25 -- The Belgian Government is abandoning part of its plan of financial aid to the Congo and will concentrate on helping Katanga Province and other sections of the Congo that are able to maintain order.
A four-day strike that had threatened to halt more than $500,000,000 in private and public construction in the city ended yesterday.

Sales and earnings of Philip Morris, Inc., for the first six months of this year bettered those of a year earlier. This reflected improved sales of the company's major cigarettes -- Marlboro, Parliament, Alpine, Benson Hedges, and Philip Morris, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president, reported yesterday.

Harvey Kuenn, the Cleveland Indians' player representative, tonight called off a planned meeting to discuss Jimmy Piersall's recent on-field temper tantrums.
Every major group declined yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange extended its July slide to the eleventh successive trading session.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Most doctors, hospitals and nurses will be grateful to The New York Times of July 4 for bringing to the attention of the public the continuing shortage of nurses. Disquieted will be the professional nursing educators and the National League for Nursing, who believe that their approach to all matters relating to nursing contains the final answer.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 25 (UPI) -- Dotted Swiss finished one of the greatest seasons in western racing history today when he won his second $100,000 added race on the closing program at Hollywood Park. He scored by nearly six lengths in the $109,200 Sunset Handicap at one mile and five furlongs.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25 (AP) -- The leading players in the sixty-first annual Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship reached the second round today at the Merion Cricket Club.
John J. Kelley, who is considered by track experts to be the finest marathon runner the United States ever has produced, made the Olympic team yesterday after a month of doubt.

William Welch's new comedy, "How to Make a Man," has moved several steps closer to Broadway with the signing of two performers for important roles and with the reaching of an agreement for a pre-production film sale.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Governor Rockefeller squeezed his, way into the convention hall tonight virtually unnoticed.
The city conceded yesterday that many of New York's 74,590 commercial and public buildings might have serious structural defects that have not been detected.

PARIS, July 26 -- If an applause meter could have been tucked away in the newly air-conditioned Nina Ricci showroom late this afternoon, it would have registered a hit. In a day jammed with bright showings, Ricci led the group.
The bond market surged to new high price levels yesterday as broad demand returned in all sectors after a brief breathing spell before and after the week end.
Except for the aircrafts, stocks made a general advance yesterday.

World sugar futures prices advanced yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on reports in trade circles that Cuba soon might raise its minimum export price from the present 3.25 cents a pound to 3.50 cents.

A contract to purchase the four-story business building at the southeast corner of Third Avenue and Forty-seventh Street has been resold by Jack Brause, realty operator, to a client of Stephen S. Scopas, lawyer.
State and Federal peacemakers combined forces last night in a new effort to settle the Long Island Rail Road strike.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Federal Communications Commission demanded an explanation today of why three Little Rock Ark., television stations carried speeches by local Democratic candidates instead of the Republican National Convention session on Monday night.

The foreign policy plank approved by the Republican platform committee is different in tone from the corresponding plank of the Democrats. It is more strident, more military-minded, tougher in approach -- but not fundamentally different in the basic essentials.

Grassy Sprain Village, a twostory garden apartment development at Tuckahoe Road and Salisbury Road, off Central Avenue, in Yonkers, has been purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation, Morris Karp, president.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 26 (UPI) -- Rod Laver of Australia, the runner-up at Wimbledon, advanced to the third round of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis tournament today by defeating Jim Schnaars of Philadelphia, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.
BOSTON, July 26 (UPI) -- The league-leading White Sox defeated the Red Sox for the eighth successive time tonight, pounding five Boston pitchers for twenty-one hits in a 16 -- 3 Chicago victory.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Soybean futures were well supported today in a broad recovery on the Board of Trade, but the grains scarcely stirred and finished within small fractions of preceding closes.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 26 President Sukarno in a speech last night indicated that the Communist party need not be feared by the people of Indonesia. He said the party had views that were similar to his on some issues, such as anticolonialism and anti-imperialism.
CHICAGO, July 26 -- Republican platform draftors tonight gave Vice President Nixon most, but not all, of what he wanted on civil rights.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 26 -- Gov. Orval E. Paubus, symbol of Southern opposition to school desegration, easily defeated four opponents today in the Democratic primary. He thus became the first to win nomination for a fourth term as Governor.

WARREN, N.H., July 26 -- Spring floods made some changes in the Baker River and a subsequent mild drought has dropped the water a bit, but the trout fishing hasn't been hurt too much, so far as a three-hour check can show.
Henry C. Alexander, chair man of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York said yesterday that he did not believe a recession was inevitable next year.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., plans to expand its manufacturing activities into Latin America through the proposed acquisition of a half-interest in Droguerias Aliadas, S.A. of Colombia. The manufacturer, wholesaler and retailer of pharmaceutical and proprietary drug products is the largest of its kind in South America.
The Government filed suit in Federal court here yesterday to recover $9,862,053.34 in income taxes, penalties and interest from Albert L. McLennan of Vancouver, B.C.
The levels of alcohol in the blood that are used to determine whether an automobile driver is "drunk" should be lowered, it was suggested here yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves remained within a half-game of the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates by downing the San Francisco Giants, 3 -- 1, tonight.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 26 -- Mike Mallon of Westbury led the way into the semi-finals of the Long Island Golf Association junior championship at the Garden City Country Club today.

LONDON, July 26 -- Dull conditions prevailed in most sections of the stock market her today. Sentiment was affected by the further weakness on Wall Street yesterday, rioting in Southern Rhodesia and drop in automobile exports.
The Florida State Board of Education borrowed $7,770,000 in the bond market yesterday in behalf of twelve county governments needing financial assistance in building public schools.
PARIS, July 26 -- Expansion in American business activity will probably resume in the last quarter of this year, European economic chiefs have just been told.
SEOUL, Korea, July 26 -- South Korea is bringing to a close the most orderly, selfconscious general election campaign in its twelve years as a free nation.

YONKERS, July 26 -- Miss Sarah Rodney, the filly who was sent to Jimmy Jordan by mistake for training at Orlando, Fla., last winter, captured the biggest plum of her short career before 20,637 persons at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

Efforts by Mayor Wagner's administration to root out corruption in the Buildings Department have led the Depart ment of Investigation to set up a pilot project, using punch cards, to police the way violations are followed up.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Administration officials described the Russian proposal today for three annual on-site inspections in the Soviet Union as disappointing and completely unacceptable for enforcing an atomic test ban.

The 26th of July is the day of days in revolutionary Cuba, a day of celebration and a day on which to assess the state of the nation. It was on July 26, 1953, that Fidel Castro led the suicidal attack on the Moncada Barracks in Santiago de Cuba which was to lead ultimately to the overthrow of the Batista regime on Jan. 1, 1959.
An African nationalist group that plotted revolt in the West Indies and hold-ups in this city to finance its operations was disclosed yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Charles Abraham Halleck, who has a reputation around his home town of Rensselaer, Ind., as an expert fisherman, spent a long time angling for the Republican Vice Presidential nomination.
CHICAGO, July 26 -- New Jersey delegates to the Republican National convention voted unanimously today to urge Vice President Nixon to select Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell as his running mate.

THE concert given at Lewisohn Stadium last night marked the New York debut of Zubin Mehta, a young conductor born in Bombay, India, and educated at the Vienna Academy of Music. He is the son of Mehli Mehta, former conductor of the Bombay Symphony, who is now second violinist in the Curtis Quartet of Philadelphia.

The biggest construction spree in the history of the gas utility and pipeline companies is in the making. This report comes from the American Gas Association, which projects expenditures this year of $2,333,000,000 for new plant and facilities.

The Mesabi Iron Company, owner of iron ore properties in Minnesota, has submitted a draft of a proposed trust indenture to the Treasury, According to Arnold Hoffman, president of Mesabi. If acceptable, he said, it would be the first step toward permitting the company to dissolve as a corporation and become a royalty trust.
The heads for the city's elementary and high school divisions were announced yesterday by Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.

"Men of Good Intentions," a study by Blair Bolles of the corruption that has "bedevilled" Presidents of the United States since World War I, will be published by Doubleday on Aug. 5. The author is a former associate editor of The Toledo Blade and is now a vice president of a major industrial concern.
The Soviet Union yesterday displaced the United States as the leader in the international students chess championship at Leningrad, according to a report from Soviet news sources.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 26 -- The bullet wound that has kept Michael Fekecs in a coma for fourteen days was self-inflicted, the Middlesex County Prosecutor, Edward J. Dolan, said today.

GENEVA, July 26 -- The Soviet Union offered today to allow international teams to carry out three on-site inspections on its territory annually to detect possible violations of the projected treaty banning nuclear weapons tests.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 26 -- Mrs. William B. Kirkland of Piping Rock and Mrs. J.B. Balding of Creek, the defending champions, were tied with two other teams today in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's 36-hole, better-ball tournament at the Shinnecock Golf Club.
GREENVILLE, S.C., July 26 (AP) -- Officials of this city of 65,000 imposed a curfew today on all persons 20 years of age and under in an effort to halt a wave of racial incidents.
CHICAGO, July 26 -- A man can't even get his shoes shined in this city without being on television.
THE "bridge marathon" record of 74 hours 47 minutes that four South African college students claimed in April, as reported here yesterday, seems to have been beaten even before they set it.
Five former employes of the Board of Education were indicted in Brooklyn yesterday in a payroll-padding scheme involving $19,907 over a four-year period.
The proposed "immediate" three-way merger of the Baltimore and Ohio, the Chesapeake and Ohio and the New York Central Railroads has been derailed for the time being at least.

WHITE PLAINS, July 26 -- After a two-month investigation, a Westchester County grand jury reported in State Supreme Court here today that it had found no proof of corruption in the White Plains Police Department.

Both the Democratic and the Republican parties recognize the importance of "growth" in the American economy. The Democratic platform sets as a goal "an average rate of 5 per cent annually." The Republican platform asserts that much has already been accomplished in the matter of annual "growth" but agrees that "we can and must do better."
HUNTINGTQN, L.I., July 26 -- Town and Suffolk County officials urged today the acquisition of a 427-acre tract in South Huntington as a site for a county park.
BULAWAYO, Southern Rhodesia, July 26 -- Six Africans were killed here today, five by police fire and one by a beating by other Africans in rioting.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and Patrice Lumumba, Premier of the Congo, agreed today on the "immediate" dispatch to the Congo of administrative personnel and experts on internal and external security.
BONN, Germany, July 26 -- A rare coalition of churchmen, labor leaders, Social Democrats and state governments heaped angry criticism on Chancellor Adenauer today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 26 -- A delegation of Naga tribesmen met Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today to press their demand for a separate state within India.

KANSAS CITY, July 26 (AP) -- Nancy Roth of Elkhart, Ind., upset the British and United States amateur champion, Barbara McIntire, 1 up, in a first-round match of the women's Western amateur golf tournament today.

A fresh effort will be made here next Tuesday to carry forward President Eisenhower's proposal for a labor-management "summit" conference.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and sales of gas, electricity and steam for the twelve and six months ended June 30. However, net income in both periods trailed the year-earlier levels.

LONDON, July 26 -- Unmoved by the outcry in the Conservative, Labor and Liberal parties, Prime Minister Macmillan will announce tomorrow the appointment of the Earl of Home as Foreign Secretary in the reconstructed Government.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Henry Cabot Lodge, United States representative at the United Nations, was an almost sure bet today for the Republican vicePresidential nomination.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Government has formally rejected a United States appeal to resume disarmament talks at Geneva. The Russians charged Washington with lying in blaming them for the break-up of the tennation East-West conference.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 26 -- The Congolese Finance Ministry disavowed today Premier Patrice Lumumba's sweeping agreement with an American company for development of the country's natural resources during the next fifty years.

A nation-wide group of investment concerns headed by Morgan, Stanley Co., Glore, Forgan Co. and William Blair Co. is placing on the market today 550,000,000 of 4 3/4 per cent debentures due in 1981 of the International Harvester Credit Corporation, wholly owned subsidiary of the International Harvester Company.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 26 -- The start of the Eastern Junior Race Week regatta today was marked by the disqualification of 116 Blue Jay class skippers for failing to sail the prescribed course.

The investment banking concern of Hayden, Stone Co. has announced that it will admit five new general partners next Monday, subject to approval of the New York Stock Exchange. They are James A. Cunningham, David N. Danielson and Ara A. Cambere, all , of Chicago, and Donald Arthur Jr. and Anthony P. Rizzuto of New York.
The New Yorker Theatre's successful Monday night film society presentations will be extended through the fall and winter on a biweekly basis.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Only those in whom pride of authorship is the ruling passion can possibly understand the intensity of a semantic battle which has been fought at the Republican National Convention between the literati on Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's staff and the practical politicians on Vice President Nixon's.
CLEVELAND, July 26 -- The machine-tool industry is lagging well behind the forecasts of further increases linked to industry's expansion but the reasons are by no means pessimistic.

The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday its entry into the field of electroluminescent lighting. Up to now, the field, less than ten years old, has been dominated by three companies. Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, is the leader by a wide margin.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 26 -- Dr. Ralph M. Gheenlee's mahogany-hulled yawl, Simba, led the cruising division today as the fleet moved from Fishers Island on the second leg of the American Yacht Club cruise.

Demonstrations by pro-Castro and anti-Castro Cubans on the seventh anniversary of the uprising that gave the name to Fidel Castro's revolution kept hundreds of New York's policemen busy yesterday preventing clashes.

LONDON, July 26 -- The work in hand at British shipyards at the end of June was the smallest since September, 1946, in so far as the total tonnage of the ships under construction was concerned.

BELLPORT, L.I., July 25 -- Close competition marked the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week regatta today. Only four of the twenty-one classes were able to produce repeat winners.

JERSEY CITY, July 26 -- A 4-year-old registered nurse who had been held in a Hudson County mental institution since 1958, even though she had been considered sane, won her freedom today. Superior Court Judge David A. Pindar ordered her release on a writ of habeas corpus.

FOR six years Adrian Hayter, a lone, hard-headed young New Zealander, beat his way home from England in a thirty-two-foot yawl. He covered 15,000 miles, with some lengthy stop-overs for repairs to his boat, the Sheila, and for wage-earning. The course was England, Gibraltar, Algiers, Tobruk, Suez, Aden, Bombay, Goa, Colombo, Sumatra, Bali, Australia, New Zealand -- the "wrong way around the world," as winds and tides generally prevail east to west.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 26 (AP) -- Lawyers for The New York Times renewed their contention today that the newspaper did not do business in Alabama and could not be sued for libel in state courts.

Senator John F. Kennedy said yesterday he would work "very closely" in the New York phase of his Presidential campaign with Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman.

Casey Stengel, whose brainstorms have led to nine Yankee pennants in eleven years, had another one last night at the Stadium. His latest inspiration had little to do with the 6-1 Yankee victory over the Cleveland Indians, but it proved to the 37,632 fans that Casey was still in there thinking.
A basic guide for the classification of nuclear-powered ships will be published soon by the American Bureau of Shipping, David P. Brown, president of the association, disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- At political sword points only a week ago, Governor Rockefeller and Vice President Nixon joined today in a powerful demonstration of concord.

FABYAN, N.H., July 27 -- It is easy to believe that the Ammonoosuc is rated one of the three or four best natural trout streams in New Hampshire, a state full of good natural trout streams. A couple of hours of fishing in it under bad weather conditions just about nails it down.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 27 (AP) -- A pre-trial hearing on libel suits filed against The New York Times erupted today in a brief verbal clash between opposing attorneys.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday a slight decline in net income for the second quarter compared with last year's levels despite an increase in sales. However, both sales and earnings of the nation's largest automobile producer rose for the first six months of 1960, with sales setting a record.

ARMONK, N.Y., July 27 -- The rural town of North Castle, where commuters predominate, received preliminary plans tonight for the first big commercial building to be put on its tax rolls. The structure will be built by the International Business Machines Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency said today it would limit the amount of insurance an air line passenger would be permitted to buy at the National Airport in Washington.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, July 27 (UPI) -- Mike DeJohn of Syracuse, gained an eightround victory over Dick Richardson of Wales, the European heavyweight champion, tonight when the referee disqualified the Welshman for butting.
A former Tammany clubhouse in Greenwich, Village once the proudest in the, city may sound again with new hurrahs.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 27 -- A three-hour denunciation today by the chief of the Communist delegation to the Military. Armistice Commission marked the seventh anniversary of the cease-fire that halted the Korean conflict.
DETROIT, July 27 (UPI) -- The United States swimming hopes in the 1980 Olympics suffered a major setback today when Jeff Farrell of Wichita underwent an emergency appendectomy.

The El Paso Natural Gas Company its offering holders of its common stock the right to subscribe for 1,136,890 additional shares of common. The subscription price is $29 a share and the basis one share for each fifteen held last Tuesday.
PARIS, July 27 -- Dior has abandoned the waist, elongated the torso and shifted the emphasis of the silhouette to well below the hips in a most provocative collection shown this morning.
OOTEBORG, Sweden, July 27 (UPI) -- Ingemar Johansson agreed today to the Nov. 1 date aboLos Angeles for his third fight with the world heavyweight champion, Floyd Paterson.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo submitted to Secretary of State Christian A. Herter today a plea for men and money to keep alive his twenty-seven-day-old republic.

"The Hyphenated Family: An American Saga," Hermann Hagedorn's story of his GermanAmerican family, will be issued Aug. 15 by Macmillan. He tells how the family tried, with devastating results, to live in two countries at once.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey described Senator John F. Kennedy tonight as immature and brash.

Directors of the General Foods Corporation yesterday elected E. Burke Giblin and Arthur E. Larkin Jr. vice presidents. Mr. Giblin joined the company In 1946 and last October became general manager of the Jell-O division.
Considering that soccer is not an aquatic sport, four of Europe's entries in the International League gave fine exhibitions as they sloshed through a double-header at the Polo Grounds last night.
An adventure series in which money will co-star, much as it does in "the Millionaire," will start oh the Columbia Broadcasting System TV network Oct. 7.
NYACK, N.Y., July 27 -- Ten Rockland County railroad stations on the West Shore Division of the New York Central were sold today to Irving Maidman, a New York real-estate man.

"THIS DEMI-PARADISE: A Westchester Diary,"* by Margaret Halsey, is the season's liveliest journal of a safari into suburbia. You may think that there's absolutely nothing fresh to be said about the folkways of commuters and their celebrated tribal customs. But Miss Halsey's book shows that the hand that wrote "With Malice Toward Some" has not lost its touch for the absurd.
A campaign by major independent oil companies to hamper the delivery of crude oil from the Soviet Union to Cuba has met some minor successes, marine tanker brokers reported yesterday.

LONDON, July 27 -- The national executive committee of the Labor party made it clear today that the Labor Members of Parliament were not bound by the statements of policy laid down by the party's annual conference.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 27 -- Iran severed diplomatic relations with the United Arab Republic today and gave Cairo's Ambassador here twenty-four hours to get out of the country.
An expansion of the city's summer high school program was urged yesterday by Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education.

Houston, Tex., received bids yesterday on issues of serial bonds totaling $10,525,000 to finance public improvements. The best bid, submitted by the First National City Bank of New York, designated an interest cost of 3.4465 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- A helicopter carrying passengers between airports suddenly lost power, and plunged in a mass of flames into a suburban cemetery tonight. All thirteen persons aboard were killed. Wreckage was scattered over a wide area.
CHICAGO, July 27 -- President Eisenhower has never been more appealing or more effective politically than he has been this week in Chicago.
The matter of selling sheets through advertising has always posed something of a problem.
GENEVA, July 27 -- The United States, the Soviet Union and Britain agreed today on how to recognize a suspicious earth tremor that would bring into play their projected treaty to ban nuclear tests.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended July 20:
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The margin requirement for purchases of stocks was reduced from 90 to 70 per cent today by the Federal Reserve Board.

KANSAS CITY, July 27 (AP) -- Sandra Spuzich, a kindergarten teacher from Indianapolis, defeated the defending champion, JoAnne Gunderson of Seattle, on the twentieth hole in the women's Western amateur golf tournament today.
LONDON, July 27 -- A British doctor has bad news for wives whose husbands shore: women are more easily cured than are men.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday it would lease four floors in Grand Central City, the skyscraper proposed by Erwin S. Wolfson and associates on a site adjoining Grand Central Terminal on the north.

The New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants disclosed yesterday that it had put into effect important revisions in the rules of professional conduct governing its 10,600 members. The changes were approved by a large majority of the membership.

The consolidated net earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for the first half of this year were estimated yesterday by M.G. Rathbone, president, at $315,000,000, the same as in the 1959 period.
HAVANA, July 27 -- Cuba is getting enough Soviet crude oil to prevent a shortage and the production of fuels will be increased steadily, according to engineers of the Cuban Petroleum Institute.
BONN, Germany July 27 -- Chancellor Adenauer will fly to Paris for talks with President de Gaulle Friday, but in a furious mood and only because the French forced his hand.

Fairly active trade covering in the near deliveries and continued accumulation of new crop positions caused a rally yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Closing prices were unchanged to 16 points (80 cents a bale) up.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (UPI) -- Jack Sanford, usually a loser in Candlestick Park, held the second-place Milwaukee Braves to four hits today while pitching the San Francisco Giants to a 5-0 triumph.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Bob Allison singled home the winning run tonight as the Washington Senators edged the Detroit Tigers, 5-4 in fifteen innings.
TRENTON, July 27 -- The Appellate Division of Superior Court found today that a lower court's voiding of a Fair Lawn scavenger contract was "a municipal investigation instead of an impartial trial."
Thousands of tons of refuse were left lying on city streets yesterday when angry sanitation workers suddenly stopped work to protest a breakdown in wage negotiations with the city.

LYNBROOK, L.I., July 27 -- Striking Long Island Rail Road trainmen appear to have found a variety of things to keep them busy while they are not working on the railroad.

He has been uncompromising on positions when he conceived that his chance of election in November depended on maintaining them. He has yielded on others, though more n form than in substance, for precisely the same reason.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 27 -- Ceylon's woman Prime Min ister said today she had no fear her Government would be drawn against its will to the Left.

The village elders of Croton-on-Hudson found, yesterday that they could swiftly draw water for drinking and swimming from New York City's Cornell Dam in their backyard -- but only if they were willing to pay the legally established rate for it.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 27 -- Senator John F. Kennedy watched the Republican nominating ceremonies on television tonight. He postponed a public appearance when the convention ran later than he had expected.

The Mayor's office was accused yesterday of "government by abdication" in its housing program. And it conceded that no effective action had been taken for nearly two years to clean up one of the city's most hazardous slum tenements.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 27 -- Andres Cova Salas, 43 year-old leader of the pro-Castrc 26th of July Movement in Venezuela, was seriously wounded by policemen here today.
PARIS, July 27 -- Andre Malraux, the Minister of Culture, has promised to give Parliament an explanation of how the French art masterpiece "The Fortune Teller" was taken out of France.

Stocks staged a broad retreat yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and lost $2,000,000,000 of aggregate market values.

ALBANY, July 27 -- The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled today that billboards and other advertising signs that impair traffic safety may be barred from private land along the highways.

Motion picture rights to "Bye Bye Birdie," the successful musical at the Martin Beck Theatre, have been acquired by Columbia Pictures, it was announced yesterday by Samuel J. Briskin, vice president in charge of West Coast activities for the studio.

To improve the quality of secondary education educators must focus their attention on who is to be taught and what the schools' responsibility is, a Columbia Teachers College professor said yesterday.

CHICAGO July 27 -- A cloud no bigger than a "Goldwater for President" button hung over the International Amphitheatre tonight as the Republicans assembled to ratify the nomination of Richard M. Nixon.
Federal maritime officials will press for an "adequate" ship replacement program in its next budget proposals later this year, Vice Admiral Ralph E. Wilson said here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Thursday, July 28 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon swept to a first-ballot Republican Presidential nomination last night and the right to face Democratic Senator John F. Kennedy in the November election.

A Manhattan travel agency executive was accused yesterday in Kings County Court of swindling seventy-five members of a fraternal organization of 23,850 he had collected for a chartered flight to Israel.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 27 -- State Senator Abner W. Sibal of Norwalk won Connecticut's first Republican Congressional primary election today.
PARIS, July 27 -- President de Gaulle is expected to stress reinforcement of European political cooperation in his week-end encounter here with Chancellor Adenauer.

Roger L. Stevens, the real estate man and Broadway theatrical producer who has had his hand in more than a dozen productions in a season, will embark on an off-Broadway venture. Unofficially, he has been behind a number of little theatre projects, and even now he plays a prominent part in the affairs of the Phoenix Theatre.

"This is the time of the year when dogs suffer from a series of ailments that we call 'summer troubles,'" said Dr. Robert L. Burkhart, the president of the Veterinary Medical Association of New York City, Inc.
Striking trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road again shouted down yesterday all suggestion for arbitrating the dispute that has halted the country's busiest commuter line since July 10.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 27 -- The Belgian Cabinet informed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today that it considered Belgian military bases in the Congo a subject for settlement only after order was restored.

LONDON, July 27 -- Buyers held off today on fears that the Government might again tighten credit regulations following the announcement of a sharp rise in bank loans last month. As a result prices declined in most sections of stock market here.

BULAWAYO, Southern Rhodesia, July 27 -- The death toll in this riot-torn city rose to twelve today as African workers flocked back to their jobs.

YONKERS, July 27 -- Harness racing fans who find trouble picking winners from the usual eight-horse fields will find their difficulties increased tomorrow night when ten meet in the $114,118.75 Hilltop Trot, the world's richest race for 2-year-old trotters.

Arthur G. Cohen and Zack C. Oslas, builders, have taken title to property at the north-west corner of Third Avenue and Fiftieth Street which they bought recently from the estate of Peter Doelger. LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 27 -- Despite the heavy rain that turned greens into miniature lakes, 102 competitors decided they would try to qualify in the Westchester amateur golf championship today.

DESPITE its size, the piano is a real baby among furnishings. The draught from open windows and the heat from steam pipes will injure its finish, metal parts and action. Darkness will cause its keys to yellow.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- An Illinois labor leader contended today that no union chiefs were happy with the choice of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas as the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee.

Last Thursday directors of the Chrysler Corporation met to approve a settlement of almost $500,000 from William C. Newberg, former president, who realized a tidy sum from his interest in a Chrysler supplier. The board is scheduled to meet here again today.

Some 7,200 fans at the Stadium were disappointed yesterday when the scheduled doubleheader between the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians was rained out. A Stadium rarity -- a twilight-night, one-admission twin bill -- was set for 6 o'clock today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 27 -- Israel has withheld official comment on the breakdown of relations between Cairo and Teheran over Iran's recognition of Israel.

The General American Transportation Company posted increases in sales and earnings in the second quarter of this year and records in both categories for the second half, the company reported yesterday.

BALTIMORE, July 28 (AP) -- Steve Barber of the Baltimore Orioles pitched a onehitter tonight for a 5 -- 0 vic tory over the Kansas City Athletics.
BOSTON July 28 (AP) -- An old political rivalry is on again between two of Boston's most respected families.
THE daring or the decorous student shopping for a fall wardrobe will find a diversity of trends in the stores.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- The choices by the Republican National Convention of 1960 of its nominees for President and Vice President make abundantly clear the party's belief that the American people in November will elect the candidates with the greatest direct experience in foreign affairs.

Samaria was so lightly regarded by the 24,702 fans at Aqueduct yesterday that she was made the outsider in the betting against four other 3year-old fillies. That circumstance failed to bother Ray Broussard, who guided the Hal Price Headley filly to victory at a $22.20-for-$2 straight payoff.

IF the different cuts of meat were laid end to end, they undoubtedly would confuse the average homemaker. Even after each cut was identified, there still would be the problem of how to cook it. Should it be roasted? Broiled? Braised?

Ina Balin, the 22-year-old actress who is gaining recognition for her performance in the current motion picture "From the Terrace," will co-star in a drama on "The United States Steel Hour" next month.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 28 -- The Soviet Union's recently awarded Lenin Peace Medal was pinned on President Sukarno tonight at a formal ceremony in the State Palace. With the prize went an award of 100,000 rubles, worth more than 1,000,000 Indonesian rupiahs (normally about $25,000).

BRISTOL, R.I., July 28 -- George B. Gibbons Jr. sailed his forty-foot sloop Mariann to 6-second corrected-time victor today in the First Division of the twenty-ninth American Yacht Club cruise.

DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -- The American Motors Corporation reported today its second highest earnings for a quarter. Net was $17,109,144, equal to 96 cents a share, in the second quarter. In the 1959 period, net was $16,083,801, or 90 cents a share.

Democratic and Republican platform writers have committed their parties, and the nation, presumably, to the goal of more rapid economic growth. BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 28 -- Belgium published today a summary of the testimony she has been accumulating on violence against whites in the Congo since July 5.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proposal of the "New Horizons Project," which is reported or your education page of July 24, that college teachers should hold state licenses or certificates to insure their competence, is disconcerting.

TOTHE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Midsummer is a time measured in days. How many days remain to us in Paris, Lake Louise or Honolulu? For how much longer shall we watch the sun setting in the sea or behind a jagged peak? Or else, in our haste to be off, how impatiently we count the days to departure.

DENVER, July 28 -- President Eisenhower sent a telegram tonight praising Vice President Nixon and Henry Cabot Lodge for their "wisdom and knowledge."
The steel industry's long-expected recovery is finally getting under way, but it will be a slow and gradual affair, it was said yesterday.
Two gunmen who apparently knew their way around the place seized an $11,145 payroll yesterday at the Prince George Hotel, Twenty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 28 -- The logistical problems in getting 10,000 United Nations soldiers into the Congo and deploying them into the roadless interior is a staff officers' nightmare.
The concept of using a house agency was dealt a severe blow yesterday with the announcement that Jackson Associates, Inc., of Holyoke, Mass., had merged with the Sackel Company, Inc., of Boston.
Federal mediators trying to end the deadlock between striking trainmen and the Long Island Rail Road laid the foundation yesterday for another approach to a settlement.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 28 (UPI) -- Four top-seeded Americans and Rod Laver of Australia reached the quarter-finals of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships today but Darlene Hard and Karen Hantze were upset in the women's division.
The Board of Estimate heard yesterday that buses sold by the Transit Authority as junk were bought, reconditioned and put back into service by private bus lines.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- The Soviet police detained three United States tourists, a Briton and a West German here today after an incident involving the handing out on A sidewalk of copies of the State Department's magazine Amerika.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- Vice President Nixon will run his campaign with the aid of an unusual board of strategy.
Inspectors from the Departments of Health, Buildings, and Gas, Water Supply and Electricity swarmed through a decaying slum tenement at 433 West Fifty-fourth Street yesterday.
As sports go, tennis is a rather ancient game. It may not go back to antiquity as does chess; but they were playing it in France before Louis XVI lost his head.
First-half earnings of the Chrysler Corporation fell $34,300,000 below those in the like 1959 period on a sales gain of $221,000,000.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I, July 28 -- Plans for the annual fashion show to benefit the Parrish Art Museum here have been announced by the co-chairmen, Mrs. Josef F.A. Comstedt, Mrs. Robert E. Jennings 2d and Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk. It will be held in the East Garden of the museum grounds on Aug. 10.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 28 -- Greenwich and near-by Stamford are having trouble with out-of-towners who use their municipal beaches.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 28 -- The Montclair Board of Education announced the hiring of a consultant today to review policies and procedures in the public school system.

SINCE the concert planned for Wednesday night at Lewisohn Stadium had to be canceled because of rain, the program played there last night combined elements of the programs previously announced for Wednesday and yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Vice President Nixon told the New York delegation today that he would consult Governor Rockefeller and State Chairman L. Judson Morhouse on all matters affecting New York if he is elected President.
WHILE university students in other countries let off steam through political demonstrations, American collegians confine their kicks to outwitting the faculty.

SANDS POINT, L.I., July 28 -- John Humm Jr. one of Nassau County's top drive-pitchand-putt products, easily captured the medal at Long Island's qualifying round for the Metropolitan Golf Association Amateur championship today.
Prices of prime bonds generally rose to new high levels for the year yesterday as the bids of professional dealers, geared by bullish expectancies, continued unabated.
LONDON, July 28 -- A tribal chief from the Southern Province of Nyasaland said here today that Africans in his country were not yet ready for a Government based on "one man, one vote.
LONDON, July 28 -- Prime Minister Macmillan re-established the House of Lords tonight as a source of leading members of the Cabinet.
Robert F. Kennedy told New York political leaders yesterday how the Kennedy-Johnson campaign would be run in New York State.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- A twohour conference of Republican leaders early today selected Henry Cabot Lodge as the party's Vice-Presidential nominee.

SOUR dough normally is associated with tough old prospectors of Alaskan gold rush days, but it has its sophisticated side too. Sour French bread apparently also figures prominently in the lives of San Franciscans.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Homer Brinkley's letter to The Times (July 23) regarding the Mexican labor program presents the typical views of the large commercial growers, who were recently described by Secretary of Labor Mitchell as being the toughest pressure group he has ever encountered.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 28 -- Dr. Luis Padilla Nervo of Mexico, president of the United Nations Disarmament Commission, suggested today that the commission meet Aug. 15 to take up the situation created by the break-down of the ten-power East-West disarmament talks in Geneva.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- Now that the stockyards have been give back to the four-legged animals a mood of uneasiness has settled over both political parties.
MOSCOW, July 28 -- The Soviet press rejected today President Eisenhower's proposal to let the world choose between communism and American democracy. It said this would violate national sovereignty.

BULAWAYO, Southern Rhodesia, July 28 -- Rioting in which twelve Africans died this week was attributed today by municipal officials to political extremism unemployment and the policies of Sir Edgar Whitehead Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia.
Capital Airlines, the nation's fifth largest airline, has had a stormy course during most of its more than three decades of operations.
David S. Meister, New York realty investor and builder, has sold the two-story business building at 110 to 120 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, to a syndicate of investors.
CHICAGO, July 28 -- For the sake of appearances and Chicago's merchants, the Republicans insisted today on trying to keep their convention alive.

Following are excerpts, compiled by The New York Times and The Associated Press, from editorials published yesterday on Vice President Nixon's nomination for President by the Republican National Convention:

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- (AP) -- The Treasury announced today an offering of $8,750,000,000 of Government securities. The offering will include $1,000,000,000 of eight-year bonds at 3 7/8 per cent and $7,750,000,000 of eleven and a half month certificates yielding 3 1/8 per cent.

The city was temporarily enjoined yesterday from enforcing the law requiring the dating of milk containers. Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division granted a show-cause order sought by milk dealers and dairymen.

A bitterly fought jurisdictional battle involving the Esso Standard Oil Company's fleet of tankers appeared to have ended temporarily yesterday with a victory by an independent union over a Seafarers International Union affiliate.
Over the angry protests of many sanitation workers, union leaders announced the end yesterday of a two-day walkout of city garbage collectors and street cleaners.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 28 -- Lyn Cunningham of Pequot Yacht Club captured honors in the even-numbered Lightning Class this afternoon as the Eastern Junior Race Week regatta concluded on Long Island Sound.

The last three berths on the United States Olympic bicycling team were filled yesterday by Jack Simes 3d of Closter, N.J.; Herbert Francis of New York and Jack Hartman of Los Gatos, Calif., they qualified at the 1,000-meter match sprint trials at Flushing Meadow, Queens.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 28 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said today he welcomed the Republican ticket of Vice President Nixon and Henry Cabot Lodge. But he declared that the Democratic party could whip them, possibly in every state.

A.C. Allyn Co., Inc., and associated investment bankers are offering today 950,000 common shares of the Florida Capital Corporation at $8 a share.

On the basis of Sandy Wilson's success with "The Boy Friend," which won him international acclaim, he easily could have had any one of the hard-to-get Broadway theatres this fall for his latest show, "Valmouth."

Former Secretary of the Navy Charles S. Thomas resigned yesterday as president or Trans World Airlines, Inc., after two years of service. Directors of the airline said Mr. Thomas had expressed his desire to return to his home and interests in Los Angeles.

THE twenty-eighth annual Brooklyn Championships will begin today at the St. George Hotel.
The Coast Guard is beginning to pound the table and look with a stern eye at some newcomers to pleasure boating.
BONN, Germany, July 28 -- The Bonn-Paris axis fashioned by Chancellor Adenauer and President de Gaulle is facing its toughest problem.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: N.Y,U. Prof. William Peterson's letter of July 22, discussing the economics Of the Democratic platform, leaves much to be desired. It is well to criticize utopian promises not backed by adequate economic plans.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- United Air Lines and Capital Airlines announced plans today to merge.

Typical of some of the adventurous programing of Richard Franko Goldman and the Goldman Band was last night's Prospect Park Concert.
Another high executive of the Chrysler Corporation is under investigation for possible "conflicting outside interests," L.L. Colbert, chairman and president of Chrysler, acknowledged yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 28 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold reported today that United Nations forces had branched out over a wide area of the Congo, occupying airfields, villages and key communication centers.
NEWARK, July 28 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell filed suit in Federal court here today to void an election held in February by the Independent Petroleum Workers Union of Bayway.

TWIN MOUNTAIN, N.H., July 28 -- By sheer resolution, as was proved today along the beautiful Ammonoosuc, man can rise above natural forces and honor himself with failure. It is this great quality, rather than reason, that distinguishes men from animals, for no animal has it.
The United States won three games from Finland in the eleventh round and took the lead in the international students' chess tournament at Leningrad yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP) -- Frank Howard drove in six runs with a grand-slam homer and a single tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated Cincinnati, 8 -- 6, before 20,885 fans.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Washington Senators edged the Detroit Tigers, 6 -- 5, tonight with a three-run rally in the ninth inning. The rally included one hit.

John J. Stanton, a city inspector for thirty-five years, was dismissed yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa. The Controller said a departmental hearing had sustained charges that Mr. Stanton had accepted bribes and falsified reports on rock salt deliveries.

The Federal Reserve Board has acted this week to reduce by 20 percentage points the minimum margin requirement for dealing in and carrying stocks on the organized security exchanges. Until further notice the margin rate will be 70 per cent of the purchase price, instead of the 90 per cent that has prevailed since October, 1958.
UPTON, L.I., July 28 -- Two theoretical physicists from Brookhaven National Laboratory here have proposed using a sort of cosmic spring balance for weighing the Galaxy, or Milky Way.

The election of Birny Mason Jr. as president of the Union Carbide Corporation was announced yesterday by Morse G. Dial, chairman and chief executive officer of the corporation. Mr. Dial announced also the election of Howard S. Bunn, former president, as vice chairman, a new position.

In American politics a formula often employed in choosing a candidate for the Vice-Presidency has been to "balance" the ticket ideologically, in the hope of appealing simultaneously to voters holding opposite points of view. With this formula in mind, Mr. Nixon was offered advice from various quarters in Chicago. One group would have had him choose a candidate from the border states, to offset and soften the civil rights sections of the party's platform.
DENVER, Colo., July 28 -- The temporary White House announced here today a loan of $53,200,000 to Peru for land development and a program of family-size farms.
GARDINERS ISLAND, L.I., July 28 -- The annual leg-banding of young ospreys (fish hawks) here last week took on the ludricous aspects of big game hunting with butterfly nets.
SPARTANBURG, S.C., July 28 (UPI) -- City officials acted today to bar crowds from congregating on streets or in stores because of outbreaks of racial violence.

YONKERS, July 28 -- Caleb captured the $114,118.75 Hilltop Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
VIENNA, July 28 -- The Habsburg question has returned to the forefront of Austrian politics.

The third volume in Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.'s "Age of Roosevelt" series will be published Sept. 7 by Houghton Mifflin and will be titled "The Politics of Upheaval." It concentrates on the years 1935 and 1936, when the country, had recovered from the early Depression years and "enthusiasm was beginning to bubble everywhere."
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 3 per cent above the level of the year before.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City fell $43,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The decline compared with one of $2,000,000 in the similar week a year ago.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- Martin Rackin, a well-known Hollywood writer-producer, has been named supervisory chief of production at the Paramount Studios.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday record net income for the twelve and six months ended on June 30. Gross revenues and sales were also at new highs for both periods.

The Owens-Illinois Glass Company expanded its sales in the first six months of this year to $279,200,447 from $267,290,984 a year earlier, J.P. Levis, chairman, reported yesterday. Earnings, however, declined from those of the 1959 period.

HE would cross a picket line; she wouldn't. He didn't sympathize with underdogs; she did. He did oppose the welfare state and progressive education; she didn't. Israel's progess as a maritime nation was advanced yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, July 28 -- The police and election officials went on an alert today for tomorrow's general elections.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration disclosed today that its next manned space craft, beyond Project Mercury, would be called Apollo.
PARIS, July 28 -- President de Gaulle has pledged that the autonomous Republic of Mauritania, in French West Africa on the Atlantic, shall have its independence next Nov. 28.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 28 -- The only former titleholder remaining in the Westchester Golf Association's amateur championship Is Tommy Goodwin, who moved Into the third round at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.

The eighth annual Ball of the Roses to benefit the Roosevelt Hospital's free medical care program will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Jan. 12. The dinner dance, which is being given by the Roosevelt Hospital volunteer committee and the board of trustees, is under the sponsorship of the Borden Company.
CINCINNATI, July 28 (AP) -- Pitchers for the Los Angeles Dodgers were accused today of using a "planned program of bean-ball throwing" against the Cincinnati Reds.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 28 -- This was a bright day of preparation for the New York Yacht Club's annual racing cruise, as magnificent a sailing fixture as any in the world The competition will begin to morrow, continue until Aug. 6 and bring into restless port-to-port action the flower of American yachting.

The five-story limestone town house at 111 East Seventythird Street, which until recently was occupied by the Albanian Mission to the United Nations, has been sold by Mrs. Anne E. Woodward. It was bought by Texas clients of Ruth F. Brown Associates, Inc., broker in the deal.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 28 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis and Mrs. Avery Rockefeller Jr. of Round Hill won the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association best-ball tournament today with a gross 38, 37-75 at the Country Club of Fairfield.

BALTIMORE, July 28 (AP) -- Gene Littler of Singing Hills, Calif., toured the Pine Ridge golf course in a repeat performance of his 1959 record of 65 strokes in the first round of the $25,000 Eastern open today.

TORONTO, July 28 (Canadian Press) -- Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., announced today that following a change in control of the company, all directors, except four representing management, had resigned to give the new controlling interest freedom in reconstituting the board.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 28 -- The only former titleholder remaining in the Westchester Golf Association's amateur championship Is Tommy Goodwin, who moved Into the third round at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.
