The dinner dance, which is being given by the Roosevelt Hospital volunteer committee and the board of trustees, is under the sponsorship of the Borden Company.
CINCINNATI, July 28 (AP) -- Pitchers for the Los Angeles Dodgers were accused today of using a "planned program of bean-ball throwing" against the Cincinnati Reds.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 28 (AP) -- Mickey Wright sank two twenty-five-foot birdie putts on the last four holes today and took the first-round lead in the American women's open golf championship with a 4-underpar 71.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Vice President Nixon is so busy he has not had time for much of a chat with his proud and beaming mother, the 75-year-old Mrs. Hannah Nixon.
A complex of television and radio studios dominated by a forty-story office building is planned for a block diagonally across Lincoln Square from the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Soybean futures resumed their upward trend today on the Board of Trade, but the grains were generally weak on the possibility of heavy cash arrivals Monday.

JERSEY CITY, July 29 (AP) -- Enrique Izquierdo's sacrifice fly with one out and the bases filled in the ninth inning scored Borrego Alvarez and led Jersey City to a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Royals tonight.
Arthur F. Young, regional census director, yesterday defended the 1960 count in Brooklyn that indicated a ten-year population loss of 134,174.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a Scots visitor to the United States whose home is not far from Loch Ness, I was interested to read in your paper about the famous monster which inhabits this loch.

BALTIMORE, July 29 (AP) -- Jack Harshman and Dick Stigman, Cleveland southpaws, stopped the Baltimore Orioles on six singles, two of them bunts, as the Indians won, 3-1, tonight and snapped a five-game losing streak.
Stocks whooped it up yesterday, making the widest one-day gain since May 3 and putting the greatest number of issues into the plus column since Sept. 24, 1959.
Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer has been named to represent the International Atomic Agency at a forthcoming physics conference in Rochester, N.Y.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 29 -- Dr. Jose A. Correa of Ecuador, the President of the Security Council for July, described today the recent work of the Council as "extraordinary."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are some startling facts and figures in The Times editorial (July 24) "Where the Congo's Hope Lies": In the eighty years of Belgian colonial rule, the 14,000,000 Congolese have yielded no native doctors, lawyers or engineers, and only sixteen have graduated from universities or colleges.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell pitched a two-hitter, and Don Hoak drove in three runs as the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates beat Chicago, 4-0, today, extending the Cubs' losing streak to eight.

The Police Athletic League will benefit from the second annual PAL Ball, a dinner dance, to be held at the St. Regis Roof Nov. 29. Mrs. Winthrop Aldrich is honorary chairman for the fete. Mrs. Edward Bemberg and Mrs. B. Rionda Braga, co-chairmen, head the benefit committee.

The procedural machinery for assuring democratic elections in labor unions, provided in the Landrum-Griffin Act, has been activated by Secretary of Labor Mitchell through a suit he has filed in the Federal court in Newark. It is designed to annul an election of union officers alleged to have been held in violation of the law.
DENVER, July 29 -- The temporary White House announced today the appointment of a new Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants scored two unearned runs and beat the Cincinnati Reds, 2-1, tonight behind Mike McCormick and the relief pitching of Johnny Antonelli.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm produce prices rose four-fifths of 1 per cent between mid-June and mid-July.

TECUMSEH, Ont., July 29 (AP) -- A mother told the police today that she kept three of her six children hidden indoors for eleven years to keep landlords and friends from learning she had such a large family.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It has become obvious in our democracy that the success of a political campaign may well turn as never before on the availability of money to engage mass promotion media -- the press, radio and television.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 29 -- Dr. Luis Padilla Nervo of Mexico, president of the United Nations Disarmament Commision, asked the members of the international organization today to agree to a meeting Aug. 15 on the arms issue.

New highs for the lives of the contracts were registered yesterday in the far October, December, May and June contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange. The market closed on a reaction from the best levels at 20 points ($1 a bale) off to 25 points ($1.25) up.

THE BALLAD OF PECKHAM RYE,"* by Muriel Spark, is a sparkling satire on diabolism. The devil in the case of Miss Spark's novel turns up in a part of London more familiar, let us say, to readers of George Orwell than to readers of Evelyn Waugh. Yet the effectiveness of the book lies in the way she has fused elements of those two strikingly dissimilar prophets of decline and fall.
World sugar options moved irregularly yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in fairly active trading.
John J. Stanton, a city inspector who was dismissed on Thursday in an inquiry into the city's purchases of rock salt, will appeal in Supreme Court for reinstatement in his $6,280-a-year job.

A new trial has been ordered in suits against a doctor and a hospital brought by the widow of a man who died of a heart attack immediately after the hospital allegedly had sent him home without treatment because it did not handle cases under the Health Insurance Plan.
On the eve of their meeting with the Soviet Union today, the United States team yesterday routed Hungary, 3 1/2 -- 1/2 in the twelfth round of the students' chess tournament at Leningrad.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Democratic leaders from thirty-five major cities east of the Mississippi River warmed up here today for a fast-moving drive to register more than 30,000,000 voters before the election in November.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 29 -- County Judge Lloyd P. Dodge and two co-defendants were convicted this afternoon of conspiracy to commit subornation of perjury.

The six-story building containing thirty apartments at 2454 Belmont Avenue, corner of East 178th Street, in the Fprdham area of the Bronx, has been sold by the Ferrad Realty Corporation to Irving Miller.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- James G. Cross would agree to resign as president of the Bakery and Confectionary Workers Union provided he gets a pension, a Federal judge was told today.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 29 (AP) -- Mickey Wright of San Diego shot a three-under-par 35, 37 -- 72, for 143 today, increasing her lead to three strokes at the halfway point in the $7,500 American women's open golf tournament.
HELSINKI, July 29 -- Three eruptions on the sun last July appear to have slowed the earth's rotation and thus lengthened the day by one tenth of a second, according to a leading French astronomer.
BAY SHORE, L.I., July 29 -- Two class championships were won today in the penultimate race of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week Regatta.
PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- Karl Hope has moved from president and treasurer to chairman of Perfect Photo, Inc., and has sold his holdings in the company to a group of New York investment bankers.
The Consumer Price Index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reached another all-time high in June at 126.5, up two-tenths of 1 per cent from the May level. (The B.L.S. index is based on 1947-49=100.)

MOSCOW July 29 (AP) -- The Soviet Union charged tonight that a West German plan to set up a radio headquarters in West Berlin was an "open encroachment" and demanded that Britain, France and the United States do something to prevent it.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Proof that a bomb caused the deaths of Julian A. Frank, who was heavily insured, and thirty-three other airline passengers was reported today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- Vice President Nixon conceded today that he would probably face a Democratic Congress if he was elected President.
For the first time in the history of thoroughbred racing, four $100,000-plus races will be run in a single day today.
Mediation efforts continued yesterday in search of a formula that might help end the strike that has halted the Long Island Rail Road since July 10.

Turning on their big brothers, the lowly Athletics downed the Yankees, 5-2, before 15,239 startled spectators at the Stadium last night. The onlookers had reason to be shocked. Kansas City's last victory here was posted on June 11, 1959.

BUENOS AIRES, July 29 -- Ambassador Willard L. Beaulac said today that successful United States economic cooperation in Latin America depended fundamentally "upon what the individual countries are doing for themselves."
PARIS, July 29 -- President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer shut themselves up in Rambouillet castle today to discuss their points of agreement and difference on the world scene.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made a loan of $70,000,000 yesterday to India for improvement and expansion of railways. The World Bank also announced a loan of $3,840,000 to El Salvador for the expansion of power facilities.
HAVANA, July 29 -- A top aide of Premier Fidel Castro acknowledged today that the Cuban revolution had a Marxist tinge.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Like any harassed husband, Vice President Nixon confessed today he got a haircut late yesterday after a prompting by his wife. Mrs. Nixon told her husband that his hair had grown so long that he might be confused with their spaniel, Checkers.
ALBANY, July 29 -- Governor Rockefeller's office announced plans today to acquire the Albany Country Club.
BOSTON, July 29 (UPI) -- Ted Williams singled home the only run tonight to give Bill Monbouquette of the Boston Red Sox his eleventh victory of the season, a 1-0 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.
Two-year-old twin sisters were killed yesterday in a fire that apparently was started by an older sister playing with matches in their Queens home.

Tiny atomic particles called protons, the cores of hydrogen atoms, were accelerated to a velocity close to the speed of light -- 186,000 miles a second -- yesterday afternoon at the Brookhaven National Laboratory at Upton, L.I.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Federal Communications Commission rejected today proposals that it set up specific controls over radio and television programs.

YONKERS, July 29 -- Caduceus, the pride of New Zealand who, as all the other free-for-all pacers, had tired of chasing the apparently uncatchable Adios Butler, achieved his first victory in this country tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

DETROIT, July 29 (UPI) -- The activities of at least two other officials of the Chrysler Corporation will be investigated in a study touched off by the resignation of William C. Newberg, former president, L.L. Colbert, chairman, confirmed today.
Something new has been added for people who like to feed peanuts to the elephants.

MANY Americans in Rome next month for the Olympics may become acquainted with one of the dishes restaurants there specialize in at that season. It is pomodori ripieni, tomatoes stuffed with rice that is seasoned with garlic, parsley, pepper and, rather surprisingly, a pinch of cinnamon.

THE homeowner who wants a European flavor in her decor needs no trans-Atlantic ticket. Ohrbach's already has done the traveling for her. Newly unpacked in this store's fourth-floor gift shop is one of the most intriguing collections of imports in New York.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 29 (AP) -- The United States suffered a discouraging setback in the race to be first with a man in space today when a giant Atlas missile exploded sixty-five seconds after blast off during a crucial heat re-entry test of the Project Mercury capsule.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 29 -- The Belgian Government announced today that it would bring home 1,500 of the 10,000 Belgian troops in the Congo.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Lederle Laboratories division of the American Cyanamid Company received this week the first United States patent for "live" polio vaccine. The advantages claimed for it are that it will keep for several months and can be taken orally in capsule form. The only poliomyelitis vaccine so far licensed by the Public Health Service for manufacture is the killed-virus type developed by Dr. Jonas E. Salk, which is given by injection.
The National Safety Council announced yesterday awards for outstanding safety records to twenty-one of the nation's forty-nine scheduled passenger airlines.

The H.C. Bohack Company, operator of a chain of supermarkets, has sold the building on plot 100 by 200 feet at the northeast corner of Avenue N and Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn. The sale was made to an investing client of Eliot Steuer, vice president of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker, in conjunction with Charles H. Lesser, co-broker.
BALTIMORE, July 29 (AP) -- Gene Littler of Singing Hills, Calif., retained the lead in the second round of the $25,000 Eastern open golf tournament today by shooting an eagle 3 on the last hole.

THE twenty-eighth annual Brooklyn Championships, one of the oldest contract bridge touraments played in this region, began yesterday at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn with 106 men's pairs and 76 women's pairs competing in the opening events.

LARCHMONT, L.I, July 29 -- Jim Iverson, a former metropolitan intercollegiate champion from Columbia, and Mark Stuart Jr., an erstwhile Georgetown golf captain, gained the final of the Westchester amateur championship today at Bonnie Briar Country Club.

ACCRA, Ghana, July 29 (Reuters) -- Ghana announced today a total boycott of Souh African goods and ordered all Ghanian seaports and airports to be closed starting Monday to South African ships and planes.
DARIEN, Conn., July 29 -- The Board of Education will spruce up several school buildings that a committee of fathers reports are "deteriorating."

It's getaway day at Aqueduct today and some horse owner is going to get away with $70,010. The Brooklyn Handicap, listed for its seventy-second running, has attracted a field of seven and if all go the gross purse will be $109,400, with $70,010 going to the winner.
TRENTON, July 29 -- Attorney General David D. Furman ordered all county prosecutors to report to him immediately any gambling situations with which they are unable to cope.

Plans have been announced for the first annual Montreal International Film Festival, to be held from Aug. 12 through 18. Sponsored by the Montreal Festivals Society, which annually presents a one-month program of special cultural interest, the event marks the Canadian city's most ambitious public undertaking in the field of the art film.

NEW ORLEANS, July 29 (UPI) -- Judge Oliver P. Carriere today granted Louisiana officials a temporary injunction preventing the Orleans Parish School Board from obeying a Federal court integration order this fall.

DENVER, Colo. July 29 -- President Eisenhower went fishing today. He did his fly casting from a river bank, determined to stay out of the fast water, although his host of the morning, Axsel Nielsen, put on his waders and went into the stream.

LONDON, July 29 -- Industrial shares responded to a broadening of demand in the stock market here today with rises ranging to 1s 6d (21 cents). The Financial Times Index of industrial stocks rose 2.4 points to 309.4.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 29 (UPI) -- Historians were excited today over an archeological discovery called "the most important find yet."

The prospects for increased prosperity in this country are analyzed by John Harriman, economic and financial columnist of The Boston Globe, in "It's Your Business," which Houghton Mifflin will issue Sept. 8. The writer disagrees with economists, business writers and experts on magazines and newspapers who predict an era of greater prosperity in the Sixties.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Vice President Nixon has requested the New York Republican organization to arrange a heavy schedule of appearances in New York City and its suburbs. He is also considering an intensive campaign upstate to take him into all the heavily populated areas.

EUGENE, Ore., July 29 (AP) -- World-record performances are possible in any of the field events and several of the flat races tomorrow, when the American Olympic team puts on its first dress rehearsal.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 29 -- Sir Edgar Whitehead, Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia, announced tonight a vast expansion of the security forces to deal with future outbreaks of violence in this British colony.

LONDON, July 29 -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that British and United States officials had been discussing the prospect of using bases in Britain for "replenishing" United States rocket-firing submarines in the future.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The United States promised economic aid for the Congo today but adopted a hands-off attitude toward Premier Patrice Lumumba's fight to keep Katanga Province from seceding.

CAIRO, July 29 -- The shouts of Moslem worshipers denouncing the Shah of Iran rang through the streets of downtown Cairo today. The Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, has affirmed Iran's de factor recognition of Israel.

A sharp rise in the volume of industrial bond prepayments lifted the total of bonds called for redemption in July before maturity to $36,036,000 from $13,986,000 in June. The month's total was the largest for any month since January and the biggest for a July since 1958.
Backing of the proposed merger between United Air Lines and Capital Airlines was expressed yesterday by executives of two other leading air carriers.
DENVER, July 29 (AP) -- The 17-year-old wife of an airman at Lowry Air Force Base successfully enlisted the help of President Eisenhower today.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board accused three large foreign airlines today of illegally trading transportation for publicity, promotional services or advertising.

GRAMERCY PARK residents not wanting to shop too far from their tree-shaded area might take note of Wilbur, 261 Third Avenue. This tiny shop has a variety of small, decorative items, all contemporary in design.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- The Republican National Committee re-elected Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky National Chairman today by a voice vote.
JERSEY CITY, July 29 -- An increase of $150,000 in its personal property tax assessments for 1960 is being appealed by the C.F. Mueller Company, manufacturer of macaroni and spaghetti.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 29 -- Leaders of the Textile Workers Union of America, charged today that new Eisenhower Administration proposals in current tariff talks "invite the destruction of the American woolen and worsted industry."
JAMESTOWN, R.I., July 29 -- The twenty-ninth annual American Yacht Club cruise ended on a flat note today. There was absolutely no wind and as a result no final-leg race from Bristol to Jamestown.

LOS ANGELES, July 29 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers belted Milwaukee, 7-3, tonight and moved to within two games of the second-place Braves as Stan Williams gained his eleventh victory before 56,648.

JERSEY CITY, July 29 -- A change in the city government from the present five-man commission to an administration by a "strong mayor" and nine councilmen was recommended today by the Municipal Charter Study Commission.
SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 30 -- Dr. John M. Chang's Democratic party, long the foe of former President Syngman Rhee, won South Korea's post-revolutionary election, returns today showed.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A preparatory commission proposed today that a meeting of the foreign ministers of the Americas in Costa Rica next month consider tensions in the Caribbean and the threat of Soviet intervention in Latin America.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 29 -- The State Department of Education has rapped the knuckles of the Peekskill Board of Education for not working with its superintendent.
New financing -- offerings of bonds and stocks to the public -- in July was the smallest for the month since 1957 and the least for any month this year.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.2 per cent to 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Japan Air Lines has urged the Japanese Government to open negotiations immediately with the United States for rights to extend its trans-pacific flights to New York City.
Sections of old wooden water pipes used to supply New York with water from 1800 to 1842 have been unearthed by workmen at Fulton Street between Pearl and Water Streets.
The Sunray Mid-Continent Oil Company in the first half of this year cleared $18,742.708, or 95 cents a common share, on gross income of $29,103,032.
ELKINS, N.H., July 29 -- Pond fishing turned out to be nothing tremendous today, for either trout or bass, but then it could have been worse. Nobody quite suffered skunkage.
BELLEVILLE, N.J., July 29 -- Wes Ellis of Mountain Ridge shot a four-under-par 67 today and led a record field of forty-eight pros and 139 amateurs at the Forest Hill Field Club.

The National Maritime Union has given full credit to James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, for settling a strike that threatened last week to stop construction in the city.

CHICAGO. The outer world contemplates United States policy intentions largely in terms of the men chosen to apply them. Therefore, one finds little interest abroad in the foreign affairs planks of our contending parties and much speculation on who will next head the State Department.
BUFFALO, July 29 (AP) -- The new American Football League puts its untested product on the market tomorrow night in one of the earliest starts in the history of the sport.
LONDON, July 29 -- Iain Macleod, Britain's Secretary of State for the Colonies, called today for a greater role for Africans in the Government of Nyasaland.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr., said today that it would take the rest of this year and possibly longer to get lagging construction of Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile bases back on schedule.
A persistingly strong bond market turned in a resounding and disquieting overture yesterday to the Treasury's $8,750,000,000 market borrowing of cash, scheduled for Monday and Tuesday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 29 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold met with the Congo Cabinet today. He is understood to have appealed for patience concerning the United Nations entry into Katanga Province and the withdrawal of Belgian forces there.
LONDON, July 29 -- The farthing, Britain's smallest coin of the realm, will be withdrawn from circulation.
Mayor Wagner and Michael H. Prendergast, the State Democratic Chairman, met yesterday and then announced agreement on their roles in the Presidential campaign.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 29 (UPI) -- Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., and Mike Belkin of Miami Beach today entered the semi-finals of the National junior and boys' tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, July, 29 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration disclosed today that constructon is scheduled to begin next year on a three-man space ship that could make voyages around the moon.
LONDON, July 29 -- Prime Minister Macmillan moved today out of 10 Downing Street, where most British Prime Ministers have lived and worked for more than 200 years.
LONDON, July 29 -- Laborite Members of Parliament called on the Government today to announce immediately that it intended to embark on its own space program.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 29 (UPI) -- Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., and Mike Belkin of Miami Beach today entered the semi-finals of the National junior and boys' tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, July, 29 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration disclosed today that constructon is scheduled to begin next year on a three-man space ship that could make voyages around the moon.
LONDON, July 29 -- Prime Minister Macmillan moved today out of 10 Downing Street, where most British Prime Ministers have lived and worked for more than 200 years.
MIAMI, Fla., July 29 (AP) -- Tropical storm Brenda, still gushing rain, swept over coastal North Carolina tonight on a course expected to take it into southern New Jersey by way of Norfolk, Va.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 29 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, 36-year-old Philadelphian, reached the semi-finals today in the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships.
NEW HAVEN, July 29 -- Mayor Richard C. Lee has proposed that persons living in slum areas stage late-afternoon sit-outs in the streets and snarl traffic to dramatize the need for better housing.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 29 -- Earlier this year Dr. Jose Antonio Correa, Ecuador's permanent representative at the United Nations, told a friend, "July will be a busy month." When the friend asked why, the South American diplomat replied "Because that will be my month as president of the Security Council.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Marra of Tamarack won the twenty-ninth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association husband-and-wife championship today.
Radio and television reporters folded their antennas and stole out of Chicago yesterday, terminating the industry's quadrennial chore of covering the Democratic and Republican National Conventions.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 29 -- Adlai E. Stevenson arrived in a campaign mood today for talks with Senator John F. Kennedy, Democratic nominee for President. He said he was ready to undertake any assignment given to him.

LENOX, Mass, July 29 -- A young man with a poetic look and a way with a piano keyboard, the Boston Symphony under Charles Munch, a cool summer evening in the Berkshires and the Rachmaninoff Third Piano Concerto.
FLINT, Mich., July 29 -- A small army of millwrights moved into the huge Buick assembly plant today to start the annual task of getting ready for a new model run.

Bangu of Brazil will face the favored Red Star of Yugoslavia soccer team in a nontelevised game at 6:30 tonight at the Polo Grounds. The second-section championship of the International Soccer League is at stake and more than 20,000 fans are expected.

The roar of refuse trucks and the clatter of empty garbage cans were heard in the city again yesterday. Municipal sanitation men, heeding the demand of their union leaders, returned to their jobs in full force after a two-day work stoppage.

PARIS, July 29 -- Today the French collections have come to a halt for the press, winding up with the showings of designs by Chanel and Desses. One big question comes to mind. What about Balenciaga and Givenchy?

The roar of refuse trucks and the clatter of empty garbage cans were heard in the city again yesterday. Municipal sanitation men, heeding the demand of their union leaders, returned to their jobs in full force after a two-day work stoppage.

PARIS, July 29 -- Today the French collections have come to a halt for the press, winding up with the showings of designs by Chanel and Desses. One big question comes to mind. What about Balenciaga and Givenchy?

Peru is to get two loans from the United States totaling $53,200,000 to finance land development and a program of family size farms. This is a good and practical demonstration that the United States intends to embark on a new and large aid program for Latin America, as James Hagerty's statement on behalf of President Eisenhower indicated.
Three cab drivers and an off-duty patrolman teamed up early yesterday to capture a razor-wielding thug who had robbed one of the drivers of $18.

Trees in Wall Street Tree-planting projects from time to time bring green leaves and protective shade along the busiest streets of Manhattan, enlisting the combined support of civic groups, business men and municipal authorities.
Financing arrangements for the $200,000,000 bridge-and-tunnel crossing to be built across the mouth of Chesapeake Bay are expected to be completed early next week.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Washington Senators rallied twice tonight to down the second-place Chicago White Sox, 7-5. Rain fell throughout the game.

Stock values this month declined more than in any previous July in history as measured by The New York Times combined average of fifty representative stocks. A sustained drop during the month for eleven consecutive trading days was the longest downward movement on record.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Henry Cabot Lodge said today that he would concentrate on foreign policy during the forthcoming political campaign but would not be limited to it because it overlapped other issues, such as farm policy.

LONDON, July 30 -- With chaos as its ally and ideological imperialism as its goal, the Soviet Union is on the move in Asia and Africa. The teeming bazaars of the Middle East, the parched fields of African farms, the starvation economy of much of Southern Asia are the new battlegrounds.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 30 -- With topnotch seasoned and young trotters and pacers ready for action, Roosevelt Raceway will open the fifty-one night second half of the 1960 harness racing schedule Monday night. Post time is 8:30, with the daily double windows closing at 8:20.

Measles is a highly contagious, acute disease, caused by a specific virus, Briareus morbillorum. It occurs in epidemics, which, in urban areas of relatively stable population, appear at intervals of three to four years.

LONDON. THE British are facing with some anxiety the prospect of losing their status as islanders. Before the end of the Nineteen Sixties the outskirts of Dover may be joined to Calais by a route under or over the Channel. For nearly a century the British have kept this threatening idea at bay, but they may not be able to retain their splendid isolation much longer.

To the Screen Editor: That Dr. Schwartz reacted to "Psycho" with "despair, horror and anger" reveals the kind of man we are dealing with. Such a response is appropriate perhaps to atomic fall-out, the Nazi revival or our foreign policy, but not to a movie essentially comic in intention and effect.

THE crisis in the Congo has dramatized the plays of power and the suctions of power vacuums in which, to greater or less degree, every one of the emerging countries between the Sahara and the Limpopo has been enmeshed. It has raised the questions: Are these new nations ready for independence? Can they survive the ordeal of independence?
PETERBOROUGH, N.H., July 30 -- Robert P. Bass, Governor of New Hampshire from 1910 to 1912, died here last night in Monadnock Community Hospital. He was 86 years old.
Brooklyn around 1910 will be recalled in the setting for the Golden Anniversary Ball of the Junior League of Brooklyn.
ST. LOUIS, July 30 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals packed most of their punch into a fourrun fifth inning in routing Chris Short and scoring a 6-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia. July 30 -- The time for . political and racial settlemen between Africans and whites in the Federation of Rhodesia am Nyasaland is rapidly running out, in the opinion of observer; here.
At midsummer, many a youngster vacationing from competition for high grades in the classroom is redoubling his efforts in competition for top scores on the ball field.

THERE are enough potential explosives in the painful marriage described by Edward Le Comte, in this disturbing first novel, to reach the latent partisanship in almost any reader. Not only is male pitted against female but American against European, conservative against liberal, Gentile against Jew.

A 15-year-old toy was shot in the neck when he tried to escape from the police, who had caught him in a stolen car after a seventy-block chase early yesterday. The boy, Benjamin Walker Jr. of 55 La Salle Street, died in a hospital a few hours later.
HARTFORD, July 30 -- The traditionally Republican state of Connecticut officially became a Democratic state today for the first time.

THERE are several bugs which are valuable in the garden because they prefer destructive insects for their food. Others, like the bee, are essential -- for without them, the majority of vegetables and fruits might never be pollinated and bear seed.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 30 -- Three representatives of the Katanga Provincial Government arrived in Brussels today and said that "the Belgian troops we invited to Katanga should not leave unless we decide they should."

Canada, which, until its victory at Detroit last summer, had never won a British International (Harmsworth) Trophy for supremacy in speed boat racing, now has the glory and excitement of defending the prize for the first time.
CAMBRIDGE, MASS. AMONG American college museums, the Fogg Museum at Harvard takes a leading place, rivaled but not eclipsed, by the superlative collections at Yale, Smith, and Oberlin.

HOLLYWOOD. TEN years ago, during filming of a motion picture, Bob Hope fell from a horse, amassing in the process bruises, contusions and nation-wide publicity. Apparently this masterly lesson in unpremeditated publicity was not lost on Mr. Hope's co-star of the time, Lucille Ball, who is once again teamed with him in Norman Panama's and Melvin Frank's "The Facts of Life."
The tropical storm that thrashed northward through the New York area yesterday hit the suburbs capriciously, flooding some localities, felling trees in others and merely ruffling many communities.
In 1898 a man in Point Carbon, Pa., bought a one-cylinder Winton. The sale may or may not have been the first sale of a motor car in the United States. The matter has been much in dispute.

MADRID -- A new revolution is brewing in Spain: the "wheel" revolution. Thirty million Spaniards are traveling increasingly by motor, and, as a result, a conservative, property-owning bourgeoisie is beginning to emerge in a land long torn by strife and class hatred.
Trailer communities are offering the possibility of country club living at Social Security prices to the nation's retired citizens.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- Injunctions designed to break an alleged monopoly in the community television field by Jerrold Electronics Corporation have been issued by Judge Francis L. Van Dusen in United States District Court.

CANADA'S "bush country" and the north-south Continental Divide suggest a remote and lonely land to many of us below the border. However, much of this region north of the upper Great Lakes is rapidly losing its isolation and frontier quality.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 30 -- Senators John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson promised today to put the "people's business" first at the reconvened Congressional session. This will be done, they said, before they begin heavy campaiging for President and Vice President.
THE most important single fact about "Communist Eastern Europe" is that it is the most anti-Communist area in the world.
NEW DELHI, India, July 30 -- The Government has refused to renew the visa of the correspondent here of Hsinhua, Pelping's press agency, an official spokesman said today.
Brenda, the reluctant baby hurricane, took several days to get started from her Gulf of Mexico birthplace and only late Friday picked up enough velocity to merit a name.

Department store sales In the nation rose 3 per cent in the week ended July 23 from the 1959 level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. In the preceding week there was a gain of 2 per cent from the year before.

OVER 10,000 blooms will be on display when the Long Island Gladiolus Society presents its annual show and exhibit Thursday and Friday at the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center, Long Island. Visitors are welcome between 2 and 9:30 P.M. on Thursday and from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. on Friday.

NEW HAVEN, July 30 -- Yale University's "Mr. Landscape" is dropping after thirty-five years the care of sixty-five acres of campus, seventy miles of academic walks and the turf of the Bowl and other athletic fields.
AFTER a discouraging Broadway season, it is consoling to consider the off-Broadway theatre o the same period. The little theatres presented approximately the same number of production as Broadway.

JERSEY CITY, July 30 -- A six-month search of old maps and city tax records plus a lotby-lot Inspection of a downtown tract has located the site and the original foundation of Jersey City's first stone home.
The Long Island Rail Road strike will enter its fourth week today with no settlement in sight. Mediation efforts are continuing.
Practice sessions begin tomorrow night for the two star-studded football squads that will meet in the second annual College Scholarship Bowl at Jersey City's Roosevelt Stadium Aug. 17.

IF someone says: "I have no friends; everybody hates me," and he believes his own statement, he will treat everyone -- even those who are trying to be helpful or friendly -- as an enemy. Thereby he makes his statement come true; he soon finds himself without a friend in the world. This is what has been termed the "self-fulfilling prophecy."

THE REPUBLICANS CONSERVATIVES-LIBERALS We are conservatives. This great Republican party Is our historic house. This is our home. Now some of us don't agree with every statement in the official platform of our party, but I might remind you that this is always true in every platform of an American political party.

Enough promises were made at Los Angeles and Chicago during the recent national conventions to cure education's ills -- if they are all fulfilled. They won't be, but whichever party wins in November there are indications that the next administration will put more emphasis on education.

MOST civilians are contemptuous of the "military mind." And many fear that the military often exceed their proper role in our democracy. Yet the fate of the nation may well depend upon military minds and their influence on high policy.
NORMAN, Okla., July 30 (AP) -- Fritz Vivian and Rus Camilleri registered upsets tonight as the United States Olympic wrestling team held its first elimination matches leading to the trip to Rome.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 30 -- Winnow paid $24.60 for $2 to those among the 34,259 harness racing fans who backed him tonight. The Clearview Stables' 5-year-old bay, at 11 to 1, won the final feature as the Yonkers Raceway spring meeting closed.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 30 -- Christine Truman, Britain's leading woman player, will compete in the United States Lawn Tennis Association championships beginning Sept. 2 at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
A recent tax ruling has jolted the cement industry and should lower its profits. Another tax decisions, yet to be clarified, may have an equally adverse efect.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) -- Two of the rubber industry's four biggest companies -- Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company -- reached agreement with the United Rubber Workers Union today on a wage settlement.
PARIS, July 30 -- President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer were reported today to have reached agreement on precise measures of political cooperation tending toward a European confederation.

GUIJA, Mozambique, July 17 -- Twelve new villages of peasant farmers from Portugal are being established here in the valley of the Limpopo River, 150 miles northwest of Lourenco Marques. A few years ago there was only wild African bush country here.
WHITE PLAINS, July 30 -- Mount Vernon civic leaders will meet here Monday with Westchester County officials to urge the adoption of a new plan for a mental health center.

CASEY STENGEL was 70 years old yesterday and should you see him today and remark he doesn't look a day older, you'd be eminently correct. For the old guy somehow never changes. Not that Casey hasn't aged physically these past eleven and a half years as field general of the Yankees.
STE. GENEVIEVE, MO. -- This eighteenth - century town, the oldest permanent settlement in Missouri, will mark the 225th anniversary of its founding with a gala celebration on Aug. 20-21.
NEW DELHI, India, July 30 -- A young missionary's allegiance to the United States temporarily snagged efforts to round out a Government council in Pakistan recently.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Glenn Hobbie stopped the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates on seven scattered singles today as he pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 6-1 victory. The Cubs had dropped eight decisions in a row.
THE San Francisco Opera, which has long wished to offer a spring as well as a fall season, may do so next year.

TO THE EDITOR: SINCE we at Putnam's are engaged in publishing a six-volume edition of the "Memoirs of Giovanni Jacopo Casanova," which I believe is the first trade edition of the complete, uncut memoirs available in English, we are delighted that Marc Slonim agrees so wholeheartedly with our estimate of the high value of the Casanova Memoirs as a historical document ("The Great Lover as He Saw Himself").
Cortisone may bring new hope of recovery for nearly 10,000 Moroccans paralyzed last fall by a subtle nerve poison in adulterated cooking oil, a British scientist has suggested.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 30 -- Scholarship programs have not kept pace with the financial needs of today's college students, so the use of loar funds is increasing sharply, the director of the Bureau of Student Aid at Princeton University said today.

APART from the arrival of "Elmer Gantry" at the Capitol Theatre, filmgoers have had precious little to cheer about during this obviously dolorous month. But, aside from this sad truth, the seemingly clouded screen scene definitely does have a silver lining.

If Vice President Nixon wins in November, he will be the fourth man in the country's history to have been elected President immediately after having been Vice President and without having succeeded to the Presidency through death.
NEVER during the long years in which Joseph Stalin was the absolute dictator of the Kremlin and William Randolph Hearst ruled San Simeon was a book like "Ask Me Anything" even wildly possible.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- The Nixon camp referred to The Congressional Record today in an effort to buttress allegations that Senator John F. Kennedy had suggested that President Eisenhower apologize to Soviet Premier Khrushchev over the U-2 incident.
BETWEEN now and the middle of August gaps in the vegetable garden can be filled for a late crop in the fall. Home-grown vegetables often are as welcome then as the first harvests of summer.

THAT President Eisenhower's Secretary of Agriculture chose to set down in a book what he has been saying for years is not surprising. The surprise is in the amount of space he uses to say that farmers are "truly the salt of the earth" and to recite a history of what he has often described as the "mess" the Administration inherited.

For Ages 12 to 16. ONE of the paradoxes of the Victorian age, when women were supposed to be fragile, dainty, well-high helpless (but also good housekeepers), was the emergence of that strong, stubborn breed known as suffragettes and, almost equally shocking at that time, the professional woman.
Fall occupancy is scheduled for several homes in the Milburn Manor development on Northern Boulevard at Milburn Avenue in Baldwin, L.I.

A spokesman for the German Lufthansa Airline said yesterday that it had no comment at present on Civil Aeronautics Board complaints in which, with two other foreign airlines, it was accused of illegally trading air passages for publicity, promotional services or advertising.
NEW DELHI, India, July 30 -- The leader of a delegation of Naga tribesmen, said today that Prime Minister Nehru had accepted in principle the establishment of a Naga state within the Indian Union.

NICE, France, July 27 -- With a forty-pound air bottle strapped to his back, ten pounds of lead belted to his waist, feet elongated by twenty-inch rubber flippers, and blinded by a face mask which is rapidly fogging up, the plunger is so clumsy that he can barely get down the ladder into the water.

LONDON. CO-PRODUCTION is the word here -- the good word in most mouths, but not so good, as yet, in some. The some are the trade unions, who foresee in production tie-ups with other countries a shrinkage in the total amount of work available.

We now enter upon a period of somewhat more than three months during which the theoretical voting population will decide between Vice President Nixon and United Nations Ambassador Lodge on the one hand and Senators Kennedy and Johnson on the other. On the basis of experience, about 60 per cent of the theoretical voters will vote.

ATLANTA, July 30 -- The liberal platforms of the two major parties have been received in the South with a mixture of distaste and resignation, but little surprise. The region won no concessions -- and none had been expected.
VIENNA, July 30 -- An Austrian assessment of the American political scene holds that the election of Vice president Nixon and Henry Cabot Lodge would be a misfortune for Western Europe.
BOSTON, July 30 -- The Massachusetts gubernatorial campaign offers a double-header this year, and voters look forward to a close fight In each contest.
BELLEVILLE, N.J., July 30 -- Voters here may be asked to decide this November on adopting the council-manager form of municipal government to replace the five-man commission form.

EUGENE, Ore., July 30 (AP) -- Bill Nieder of Lawrence, Kan., put the shot farther than the recognized world record today. But most performances were less than sensational as the United States Olympic track and field team competed in a meet ending its first week of training.
BALTIMORE, July 30 (AP) -- Gene Littler of Singing Hills, Calif., slogged his way to a one-over-par 73 for 206 today and retained a one-stroke lead in the Eastern open golf tournament.
BEARDED iris deserve a place in every perennial garden. They offer a wide color range and are adaptable to varied soil types. Varieties can be chosen for a succession of bloom.

His goal, of course, is not the White House but an unchallenged grip on the job he now holds provisionally -- the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the country's biggest and most powerful union.
MEXICO CITY, July 23 -- A small but militant group here is staging a rear-guard fight to save colonial landmarks. Some of these landmarks outdate similar historic shrines in the United States.

THE perennial question of whether photography is, or is not, an art recently received what appears to be a definitive answer. It came from George D. Culler, director of the San Francisco Museum of Art, on the occasion of an award presentation to Ansel Adams.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The ailing mother of Francis Gary Powers, the U-2 pilot who is held prisoner in the Soviet Union, has joined the flier's father and wife in planning to go to attend her son's spy trial next month if Moscow will allow it.

It is not too early to order fall bulbs for planting, especially of new Introductions and rarer types. . . . After rainfall is a good time to weed annual and perennial plantings. . . . Plant and divide Madonna lilies.

A tropical storm swept over New York City yesterday with flooding rains and high winds. In fourteen and a half hours it set a record rainfall for a July day -- 4.79 inches. Air, subway and motor travel was disrupted.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30 -- The Southampton Village Improvement Society will hold its annual Village Fiesta on the grounds of the Parrish Museum here on the afternoon and evening of Aug. 19. Proceeds from the event will go to the support of civic and charitable projects here.

Premier Patrice Lumumba, of the Republic of the Congo, arrived at New York International airport, Idlewild, Queens, early last night from Ottawa on his way back to the Congo. He responded heatedly to reporters when they asked him about the rape of white women in the Congo riots.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 (UPI) -- Aided by a two-run lead in the first inning, Don Drysdal pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-5 victory over the Mil waukee Braves today.

THE present plan to suspend the equal-time provisions of Section 315 of the Federal Communications Act to permit television debates between Vice President Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy has drawn the disapproval of the American Civil Liberties Union.

Week Ended July 29, 1960 British pound sterling showed a firm undertone in foreign exchange dealings during the past week. Canadian dollar, strong in the fore part of the week, sold off with the approach of the week-end. Volume of business transacted was fairly heavy at times.
Normalcy returned to the Stadium at twilight yesterday but not until after the Yankees had contrived to lose a second straight game to the lowly Athletics, 5 -- 2, in eleven innings.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 31 -- Two hundred and twenty-five persons crowded into the Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow today to worship again in the church, which was organized in 1697.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 -- In a clear effort to counter the idea that American scientific survey flights are of a Trojan horse variety, the Navy has placed on exhibit here one of the two planes of Project Magnet.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 (AP) -- Jack Spikes, a fullback from Texas Christian University, smashed over for two second-half touchdowns today as the Dallas Texans beat the Oakland Raiders, 20 -- 13, in an exhibition of American Football League teams.
The Cuban Government has been inviting students in the United States to see Premier Fidel Castro's revolution for themselves at cut rates.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 31 (UPI) -- The Australian champion, Rod Laver, and Ron Holmberg, the top-seeded American from Brooklyn, today gained the final round of the sixty-first Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 31 -- Abba Eban, Israel's former representative to the United Nations and Ambassador to Washington, was appointed Minister of Education today. Premier David Ben-Gurion had held the portfolio since April.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Georgetown University, a pioneer in developing language-teaching techniques, was awarded $61,491 today for a two-year project in developing methods for teaching three Bantu languages of Africa.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 31 -- Seven hundred Democratic leaders squabbled with customary amiability today in a legal preliminary to the November delivery of California's important block of thirty-two electoral votes to one of the Presidential nominees.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 -- Since the start of this century the North Pole has been moving toward Greenland at more than half a foot a year, it was reported here this week-end.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 31 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo said today he would ask the United Nations Security Council to send observers to his country to oversee the evacuation of Belgian troops.
ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP) -- Bill White drove in six runs with two homers today as the St. Louis Cardinals won a double-header from the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-2 and 5-3, before a crowd of 20,061.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Chief interest in grain futures trading centered last week on soybeans, where prices shifted rather broadly and closed with substantial gains.

School officials said yesterday the city could build a new elementary school every four years with the money it spent to repair damages caused by vandals.

WHILE baseball's deepest thinkers of the two present majors and the embryonic Continental League gather for their momentous "expansion meeting" in Chicago today, an odd thought comes to mind. Wouldn't Branch Rickey, head man of the pioneering Continentals, have it a lot easier were the minor league structure the same today as it was some forty years ago ?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The State Department said today the Chinese Communist proposal for a nuclear-free zone in Asia was "another meaningless propaganda gesture."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Rising prices forced the Administration to expand the tightly controlled sugar market today.

On the smallest volume in almost ten months, aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange sank about $2,900,000,000 yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 2 -- The second night of Roosevelt Raceway's summer meeting was another surprisingly happy one for the harness track's officials, stockholders and others who like to see good attendance no matter what the obstacles may be.

A third new film version of the life of Jesus, to compete with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "The King of Kings" and Twentieth Century-Fox' "The Greatest Story Ever Told," is being planned by Ray Stark, producer.

Governor Rockefeller promised yesterday to redouble his efforts to end the Long Island Rail Road strike.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- On the outskirts of the National League pennant race tonight, surprising detonations by the seventh-place Phillies forced the Giants to miss two steps in their march toward a better neighborhood.

Plans for a new stock exchange in New York, to be named the National Stock Exchange, Inc., moved ahead yesterday with the filing of an application for registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington.

IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Aug. 1 -- The public was warned today that the time avaiable to acquire and develop necessary outdoor recreational areas was rapidly being dissipated.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The opening skirmishes in the Presidential campaign have centered on a distorted, if not wholly false, picture of Vice President Nixon's powers.

The appointment of two vice presidents at St. John's University was announced yesterday. They are the Rev, Mark J. Mullin, who will be assistant superior, executive vice president and director of the university's Jamaica, Queens, campus, and the Rev. Louis A. Fey, who will be vice president for business affairs.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 2 -- A sixteen-month-old Doberman pinscher, Simba, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James Caro of Locust Valley, L.I. and handled by Mrs. Harland Meistrell of Great Neck, was chosen best dog in the Ox Ridge Kennel Club match show at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club indoor ring tonight.

A top executive of the International Air Transport Association has left the world airline body under undisclosed circumstances. Trade sources have reported that John Brancker traffic director, was forced to resign by the association's director general, Sir William Hildred.

The Detroit Tigers and the Cleveland Indians yesterday swapped field managers, Jimmie Dykes moving to Cleveland and Joe Gordon to Detroit.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today began drawing to a close its hearings into the operations of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
The Sperry Rand Corporation reported yesterday an increase of 6.2 per cent in sales for the quarter ended on June 30 from the 1959 level. But earnings declined 40 per cent, the company said.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of July 17 there appeared a notice about the agreement concluded with Poland according to which Poland will pay $40 million compensation for properties lost by American citizens through, nationalization or other taking over by the Polish Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Pentagon officials were understood today to have obtained President Eisenhower's approval for increased defense spending. Decisions on how much and for which weapons are to be made later.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The litter in the convention halls of Los Angeles and Chicago had scarcely been swept away when the first warnings of party secession began to be heard by Republican and Democratic headquarters. These threats normally lose their native hue of resolution as the campaign proceeds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Administration was in a quandary today and somewhat peeved with its own delegation as well -- over how to break a critical stalemate developing in the Geneva negotiations on a ban on tests of nuclear weapons.
Gold, motion picture and aircraft shares were strong in yesterday's weak session of the New York Stock Exchange, which saw aggregate market values crumble by almost $1,900,000,000.

Directors of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation voted yesterday to omit payment of a third quarter dividend on the compay's 5,792,181 shares of common stock. The company has been distributing 30 cents a share quarterly.
Potentially, there was good news for bird-watchers and duck hunters yesterday.

The Italian political situation is beginning to take shape, and that is an unusual state of affairs. There are few political situations in Europe more complex, more subtle, more shifting than Italy's.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A national project to provide talking tapes as well as talking books for the blind was announced today by the Library of Congress.
There is always danger in a highly competitive situation of an advertiser's becoming so much caught up in the battle that he hurts not only his competitor, but eventually himself.

An eighth-inning, two-run homer by John Blanchard saved the Yankees from their worst drubbing of the season last night at the Stadium. However the heroics of their third-string catcher merely averted a shutout.

Yesterday was mostly a day of pause for the bond market. The general spirit of bullishness persisted, but bond dealers were not disposed to press bids beyond the record high price areas reached in recent trading sessions.
The settlement of the Long Island Rail Road strike quickly set into motion last night the cleaning of dusty seats, the wiping of dirty windows and the reviving of rusty rails -- and rusty employes.

Dr. Rudolph Matas of New Orleans, who died in 1957 at the age of 95, was one of the great pioneers in surgery. A biography of him, called "Rudolph Matas," has been written by Dr. Isidore Cohn, who studied under Dr. Matas and was his associate and friend for fifty-four years, and Hermann B. Deutach, a New Orleans newspaper man and author.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway has had its top executives, including its president, Walter J. Tuohy, in Zurich, Switzerland, for the last ten days soliciting votes of Baltimore and Ohio Railroad stockholders in its struggle for control of that carrier against the giant New York Central Railroad.

AFTER wasting a deal of time traveling a circuitous route, stumbling over detours and bumping heads in futile recriminations, major league baseball finally seems to have arrived at a happy solution of its expansion problems. Our present two major leagues will now become ten-club circuits, New York will be back in the National League and everybody seems quite happy.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- The seven-furlong Test Stakes for 3-year-old fillies drew so many entrants today that it had to be run in two divisions. Favorites failed to pass either section.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3 -- Gen. Lauris Norstad, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, indicated today that he was confident his North Atlantic Treaty forces could cope with any threat against West Berlin from the Communist East German Government.
A record amount of electric- ity was produced in the nation last week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the present political campaign there has come up a matter that is quite disquieting -- the charge on the part of certain Republicans that the Democrats "got us into three wars." Can this charge be characterized other than as dishonest, disgraceful and despicable?

Deputy Mayor Paul T. O'Keefe entered the controversy with State Senator MacNeil Mitchell yesterday over who is to blame for slum conditions in the city.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 -- Michigan Democrats found a new political star today. They hope he will take the place of Gov. G. Mennen Williams when the Governor steps down at the end of the year.

ANYONE with more than a passing interest in the culinary arts might find more than passing interest in the Shaker Museum Festival to be held at Old Chatham, N.Y., next Saturday. Though the religious sect known as the Shakers achieved world-wide fame because of their furniture, they were, to a lesser degree, known for their cooking.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP) -- An alliance appeared in the making tonight by Sol Dann, head of the Chrysler Stockholders Protective Committee, and two New York lawyers who have filed a stockholders' suit against the Chrysler Corporation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On behalf of the long-suffering bus riding public of Manhattan -- the world capital -- I must protest the ever-worsening quality of service begrudgingly bestowed on their passengers by the bus companies. It appears to me that they are organized to be disorganized.
EARLIER this year President Hector Bienvenido Trujillo Molina of the Dominican Republic sat solemnly in an armchair on an elaborate reviewing stand while 300,000 persons marched past, ignoring him.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 3 -- The immense mass of Antarctic ice is growing at the rate of about 293 cubic miles a year, a Soviet glaciologist estimates.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Argentina ordered an investigation today into the kidnapping of Adolf Eichmann.

A $22,000,000 offering of common shares of the Boston Capital Corporation, the largest public offering yet undertaken by a small business investment company, was proposed under a registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The new company's 1,500,000-share offering would be made by a group headed by Shearson, Hammill Co.

HAVANA, Aug. 3 -- A pledge to "boycott" the United States if it should attack Cuba has been signed by representatives of Communist and other Leftist labor organizations of Latin America who are meeting in Havana.

Prices of domestic sugar futures tumbled yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in the wake of an additional sugar import authorization by the Department of Agriculture. The agency announced on Tuesday an increase of 123,524 tons.
LONDON, Aug. 3 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union made a threat today of long prison sentences or even death for aerial espionage as it prepared to prosecute three United States airmen for spying.
In the event New York obtains a National League franchise, the Continental League group in this city headed by Donald N. Grant expects to operate the baseball club.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Two pinch hitters, Carl Sawatski and Moose Moryn, delivered two-run hits and led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 13-8 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight. The triumph was the Cards' sixth straight.
California has rescheduled the sale of $15,000,000 of harbor improvement bonds for Aug. 17. The obligations will come due serially from 1965 to 1990.

In memory of Alexander M. Drummond, Professor of Speech and Drama at Cornell University for forty-five years, the Drummond Productions has been formed. The organizers ane Richard H. Smyth, Martin Rubin and Woody N. Klose.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The sterling area's reserves of gold and convertible currencies rose last month by L37,000,000 ($103,600,000), bringing the total to L1,070,000,000 ($2,996,000,000).
A dairy farmer who believes that Federal income taxes are unconstitutional went to jail yesterday on contempt charges arising from his rebellion since 1956 against revenue agents.
Leo Silver Sons, Inc., realty investors and builders, have purchased the building at 304 East Thirty-ninth Street from the Gokash Realty Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 -- Tell the boys in the back room to hold up a minute on that requiem for the San Francisco Giants. There's life in the old bunch yet -- though hardly enough to command respect from the seventh-place Phillies.
Thomas B. Rohan, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, was appointed by Mayor Wagner yesterday to be a justice of the Court of Special Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Army plans to use a new instrument-packed pilotless plane to radio information to battlefield commanders about the results of their nuclear missile fire into enemy positions.

The turbulent situation in the Congo, which confronts the world with the African problem in its most aggravated form, is now moving toward a showdown that involves not only the fate of the newly independent state but also the United Nations and possibly a question of war or peace.

AT Lewisohn Stadium last night this listener's heart went out to Ann Schein, whose unenviable fate it was to make her New York piano debut under glaring, hot stage lights on one of the most humidly uncomfortable evenings of the summer.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Frank X. Shields, a former Davis Cup tennis captain, believes more professional golf tournaments should be staged in the metropolitan area. He has succeeded in making his idea become a reality.

Thomas Mellon Evans, who is chairman of Crane Company, maker of plumbing equipment, made his interest in that company even more solid last month by the purchase of 15,000 shares, to increase his ownership to 179,500 shares.

The American Broadcasting Company asked Vice President Nixon and two Senatorial leaders last night for permission to broadcast the pending session of the Senate on television and radio. The session begins Monday.

Trussell, make more clear than ever before that hospitals are the key to Blue Cross rates. Plans for construction of a three-floor bowling center in the upper reaches of the Grand Central Terminal waiting room were disclosed yesterday. One floor will serve as the home arena of the New York team in the new National Bowling League.

The Girls Club of New York has chosen the Nov. 1 performance of "Face of a Hero" for its annual theatre benefit. The play is scheduled to open at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre on Oct. 20.
Several leases or space in office buildings in the downtown financial district were announced yesterday.
EVERY bridge teacher says he would rather have his pupils win than win himself.
The city school system is planning a new attack on vandalism.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3 -- The Soviet Union reported today that its geologists had uncovered immense new deposits of highgrade iron ore in the Kursk magnetic anomaly southwest of Moscow. The proximity of the ore to industrial centers should be of great value to the Soviet economy.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 -- the hundred and seventy-eight members of the University of Pennsylvania faculty denounced y the "harassment" of Dr. Linus Pauling by the Senate ernal Security subcommittee.

PADANARAM, Mass., Aug. 3 -- Henry Mercer's Weatherly won again on the New York Yacht Club cruise today. So did De Coursey Fales' Nina So did A.E. (Bill) Luders' Storm and so did Frederick (Ted) Hood's Robin.
Sales and earnings of the United Aircraft Corporation for the quarter and six months ended on June 30 declined from those of a year ago.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Stock market prices weakened slightly here today on balance, although no big selling developed.

Governor Rockefeller announced the settlement of the twenty-five-day-old Long Island Rail Road strike last night.
NO tourist in Paris is hunting down the "good little dressmaker" more assiduously this week than the professional American buyers, now that the haute couture showings have ended.
SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 3 -- North Korean Air Force pilot who defected to South Korea today said he had fled from the Communist regime because of a "yearning for freedom."

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 3 -- For the last quarter mile of the mile-and-a-sixteenth Choice Stakes at Monmouth Park today, the field of eight consisted of the front-running Kelso and seven pursuers. At the wire it was Kelso by seven lengths in the 556,800 event.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Two stainless steel absorption towers, to be used in Yugoslavia's first nitrogen processing fertilizer plant, were loaded aboard the American Export Lines' freighter Exporter today for shipment.

The medical committee of the Planned Parenthood Federation yesterday approved an oral contraceptive for distribution at the federation's affiliated centers over the nation.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 -- Jeff Farrell's bid to win a berth on the United States Olympic swimming team, despite a week-old appendectomy, failed tonight.

TRENTON, Aug. 3 -- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican, opened his campaign for re-election today. He said it would be the most intensive campaign of his career and that "nothing would be left to chance."

ROME, Aug. 3 -- After only one day's debate, the Senate gave the new Premier, Amintore Fanfani, and his all-Christian Democratic Government its vote of confidence by a majority that has been exceeded only once in Italy's post-war history.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 4 -- The Berkshire Music Festival combined today its annual display of student talent with its major operatic production of the summer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Again last week the citizens of the City of New York were victims of irresponsible union leadership which called a strike of sanitation Department employes. Last year it was the transit workers who negotiated a new contract while threatening to strike if their demands were not met.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Rocky Nelson supplied the batting and base-running punch to give George Witt his first triumph since 1958 as the Pittsburgh Pirates scored a 4-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers at Forbes Field tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The United States denounced today the Soviet Union's "incomprehensible" refusal to allow a United Nations investigation of the shooting down of the American RB-47 plane. It demanded in a note delivered in Moscow that the two fliers who survived be returned immediately.

WILTON, Conn., Aug. 4 -- The Board of Selectmen met tonight to decide whether a retired vice admiral has voted here illegally -- through no fault of his own -- for the last eleven years. After two hours of discussion, the board announced it would make its decision known today.

The National Dairy Products Corporation's sales and earnings for the first half of this year were the highest for any such period in the company's history. E.E. The eye of the camera, focused on New York City's streets, revealed a new world of beauty in the commonplace to teachers attending a conference on creativity this week at Columbia University's Teachers College.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Department store sales in the nation last week wove per cent above the level of a year earlier.

Organized labor's plan to transport union members by bus to a central voting registration place in the city has run into obstacles.

Negotiators for the city and the sanitation workers' union announced a tentative settlement yesterday of the dispub that touched off a two-day work stoppage of refuse collection and street cleaners last wek.

An examiner for the Federal Trade Commission yesterday ordered the Colgate-Palmolive Company to stop saying that its "Colgate Dental Cream with Gardol" provides complete protection against tooth decay. Ted Bates Co. is the agency for Colgate Dental Cream.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Ambassador Louis M.E.M. Scheyven of Belgium voiced to Secretary of State Christian A. Herter today Belgium's apprehensions over the operations of United Nations troops in the dissident Province of Katanga in the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Rail freight loadings showed a marked increase last week and truck freight loadings a slight decrease from 1959 levels.

Recent defections from the Cuban regime surely must be giving Premier Fidel Castro and his associates food for regret and anxiety. The latest to flee is Raul Chibas, who has sought refuge in the United States. Dr. Chibas is the brother of the late "Eddy" Chibas, the idol of Fidel Castro's youth, the man who was his leader in the Ortodoxo party before the Batista coup in 1952.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Thomas Cronin, Princess Margaret's butler for one month, announced today that he had quit the Princess' household because he just could not get along with her husband, Antony Armstrong-Jones.

The 1245 Park Avenue Corporation has announced the passing of title to property at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street, which it sold recently to Vladimir Leventon and Kurt Schlesinger, realty investors.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Bob Rosburg, who earned no cash in five previous appearances here, today gained the first-round lead in the Insurance City open golf tournament with a six-under-par 65.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Supreme Court Justice Mario Pittoni refused today to dismiss a $302,500 suit against a sporting goods store owner who allegedly had sold ammunition used in a homicide.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Jimnie Dykes, the new manager of the Cleveland Indians, agred today to accept a contract for the current season only.

Shipment of toys during the first half of 1960 ran 9.3 per cent ahead of the record pace of the previous year, according to officers of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A., Inc. However, the industry is not overly optimistic about the year as a whole, although it is far from pessimistic, according to Charles S. Raizen, president of the association.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Boncrist Farm's Nassue, a chestnut daughter of Nashua, held on gamely in the stretch at Monmouth Park today and beat the fast-closing Reba Mine Gold by a head in the six-furlong New Jersey Senate, a $4,500 allowance race for 2-year-old fillies.

Thousands of workers at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, shouted angry protests yesterday against a decision by the Federal Government to shift the construction of a super aircraft carrier to a private shipyard in Virginia.
