ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 4 -- The first meeting between Under Secretary Ralph J. Bunche of the United Nations and Premier Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province ended in complete disagreement today.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The Lake Superior iron ore district, which through two world wars supplied the vast majority of the ore for U.S. steel mills, furnished less than 50 per cent of the tonnage in the first six months of this year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Billy Martin, the Cincinnati Reds' second baseman, fractured Jim Brewer's orbital bone near the right eye when he hit the Chicago Cubs' pitcher with a right-hand punch during the Cubs' 5-3 victory over the Reds today.

Sports cars and racing drivers from all over North America will participate in the second annual running of the Interclub Championship Road Races on Aug. 27-28 at the Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit.

MIAMI, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Raul Chibas, one of the original architects of Fidel Castro's revolution, said tonight he fled Cuba "because that was the only way I could make it known to the Cuban people that I did not like what their Government is doing."

DAVID MELVILLE HEY-MAN, chairman of the Mayor's Commission on Health Services, whose report was made public yesterday, is a banker turned philanthropist. He entered the investment banking business as a young man just graduated from Columbia in 1912 and advanced to a partnership in Lewisohn Co. in 1933.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today charged Westinghouse Electric Corporation with giving discriminatory discounts to certain of its franchised dealers in automotive lamps.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 4 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's agreement to establish a Naga state within India appeared today to be no assurance of tribal peace.

Bond prices resumed their vigorous upward movement yesterday after two days of irregular fluctuations. Long-term obligations of both corporate and United States Government issue led the advance, with many issues reaching new high prices for the year.

The Boston Metropolitan District, Mass., borrowed $5,480,000 in the bond market yesterday on three issues of serial obligations. Of the total, $3,428,000 will go to finance improvements to the transit system.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 4 -- Senator Estes Kefauver won an unexpectedly one-sided victory today over a states' rights segregationist in the Democratic primary. His defeat of Judge Andrew T. Taylor raised the party's hopes for solid Southern support in the November Presidential election.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Government has agreed to pay $1,000,000 for infringing upon the patented rocket inventions of the late Dr. Robert H. Goddard, one of the early pioneers in development of today's spaceage missiles.
After drifting downward in listless fashion for almost five hours, the New York Stock Exchange rallied briskly in its final forty minutes yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Catholic Mission Secretariat reported today that there were 6,782 American Roman Catholic missionaries serving overseas.
Cotton futures advanced 2 to 15 points (10 to 75 cents a bale) on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
RUDOLPH VALENTINO rode off into the desert bearing Vilma Banky in his arms last night as an old Hollywood film classic was reviewed in a new television series.
The State Insurance Super-intendent turned down the application of Blue Cross in the New York area yesterday for increases in premium rates averaging 37.3 per cent.

"Happy Ending" is an example of an author's persistence. Nellise Child's comedy was first heard of in 1952, when the Theatre Guild had it under option. Renamed "Come to the Dance," the play was performed last December in Miami, Fla. Appearing in it then were Dennis King, Isobel Elsom and Irene Castle.

TOWNSVILLE, Australia, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Australian women smashed two world swim records and Murray Rose clearly demonstrated his superiority over John Konrads tonight in the third session of the Australian Olympic swimming and diving trials.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Owen Mandeville Jr. and Mrs. Thomas Hory of Winged Foot won the Metropolitan Golf Association's mixed-foursomes tournament at Knollwood today.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Betting Time flashed through the middle of the stretch to capture the $5,000 Garden City mile pace before 22,592 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Gulf and Western Industries Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it had acquired the Mal Tool and Engineering Company, Manchester, Conn., for more than $1,000,000 in cash. Gulf and Western, formerly the Gulf and Western Corporation, is en- gaged primarly in the manufacture and distribution of automotive parts.

HONOLULU, Aug. 4 -- Vice President Nixon ended a two-day campaign in the nation's newest state today. Meanwhile, he braved the assorted rigors of tropical downpours and the dietetic saturnalias called luaus.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The United States delegation decided today to bring its own lobbyists into action to counter Soviet efforts to prevent a meeting of the United Nations Disarmament Commission.
Last night's Lewisohn Stadium concert might have had a subtitle: "Twentieth-Century Composers Look Backwards."

TRENTON, Aug. 4 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner received a setback today in his efforts to block a Congressional investigation of the Port of New York Authority. He has been joined in this effort by Governor Rockefeller of New York.
MANY an outdoor art show or community crafts display is the work of a group of dynamic women, according to Bill Newgold, director of the Colony Arts Center, Woodstock, N.Y.

IN his introduction to Robert Shaplen's "Kreuger, Genius and Swindler" John Kenneth Galbraith calls Ivar Kreuger the Leonardo of swindlers. The term is apt in many ways. Kreuger was a swindler on a gigantic scale. But he was also an individual of remarkable imagination and great histrionic powers.
HAVANA, Aug. 4 -- Maj. Raul Castro, younger brother of Premier Fidel Castro, rattled Soviet rockets at the United States today.
American Metal Climax, Inc., (AMAX) yesterday reported substantially larger earnings than last year in the second quarter and six months ended last June.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 4 -- Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, ruler of the Dominican Republic for thirty years, was appointed today to head the country's delegation to the 1960 United Nations General Assembly session.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4 -- The easy time enjoyed by the second-seeded Ron Holmberg in retrieving His third-round match with Allen Fox of Los Angeles and the defeat of fifth-seeded Whitney Reed attracted major interest at the Meadow Club's invitation tennis tournament today.

United Air Lines, Inc., improved its operating revenues in the quarter and six months ended on June 30, but higher operating costs, reflecting the transition to jet service, adversely affected results.

The Siegler Corporation achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended on June 30, John G. Brooks, president, reported yesterday. Net income rose 45 per cent to $3,201,023 from $2,203,022 a year earlier.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Ray Sadecki pitched and batted the St. Louis Cardinals into second place in the torrid National League race with a 4-2 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.

SITKA, Alaska, July 29 -- A handsome, $66,000,000 pulp mill and a freighter, the Columbia Maru, which was tied up alongside it today, are symbolic of an economic partnership that Alaskans foresee for the forty-ninth state and Japan.

LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Aug. 4 -- The Legislative Council approved a law today that will bar racial discrimination in Northern Rhodesia's tearooms, cafes, restaurants, hotel dining rooms and lounges, and motion picture theatres.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4 -- The Newport Jazz Festival, Inc., filed notice today with the City Clerk of a $450,000 damage claim against the city for cancellation of its license for the festival concerts on July 3 and 4.
The Atlas Corporation announced yesterday a plan to dispose of 5,700,000 shares of the common stock of Summers Gyroscope Company of Santa Monica, Calif.
A broad reorganization of the city's health and hospital services was urged yesterday by the Mayor's Commission on Health Services after a seventeen-month survey.
A boy and his new dog met here yesterday.

NEW JERSEY is getting ready to declare a complicated set of game seasons for this fall, to satisfy the needs of ecology, hunters, landowners and the non-hunting public, or as many of these as can be satisfied.

"LIFE'S a pudding full of plums," wrote W.S. Gilbert, irascible member of an immortal partnership. Yet, oddly enough, plum pudding contains no fresh plums -- the word, in this case, refers to raisins.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club, who is seeking a fifth straight Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship, reached the final round at Innis Arden Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Just before the Senate recessed for the national conventions Majority Leader Johnson promised Chairman Fulbright of the Committee on Foreign Relations that one of the first actions after the Senate reassembles in Aug. 8 will be consideration of he Antarctic Treaty.

GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- James J. Wadsworth, United States delegate to the negotiations for a ban on tests of nuclear weapons, said today that he was "wholly at a loss to find any ground" for reports of Administration criticism of his handling of the talks.

IT may have been merely a coincidence but at the moment the Tigers and Indians made their amazing managerial swap, which sent the honorable James J. Dykes to Cleveland and Joe Gordon to Detroit, the Weather Bureau reported tremendous high gales sweeping over Western states, with emphasis on the Great Lakes area.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, Minister of Trade and Industry in British Guiana, said today that he sought a British loan of L2,000,000 ($5,600,000) to finance the beginning of a state electric power system for the territory.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 -- Another baseball spectacular starring Willie McCovey was presented at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.

The Willy Sutton Helping Hand Fund was estimated to total "under $10,000" yesterday by one of the trustees administering the trust formed by the convicted bank robber "to combat juvenile delinquency and rehabilitate ex-convicts."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The biggest horse-opera of the autumn TV season is likely to be the duel between Nixon and Kennedy, with the White House going to the winner.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 4 (AP) Houston was ordered today to integrate its schools a grade each year for twelve years starting this fall.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined by $36,000,000 to $315,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $18,000,000 to $486,000,000 from a revised figure the week before.
DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- Retail sales of new autos in July dropped 1.5 per cent below those in the same month a year ago for the first time this year.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 4 -- Muguet II of John M. Schiff's racing stable took the sixty-first running of the Beverwyck Steeplechase Handicap today. The French-bred 8-year-old was guided carefully by Flint Schulhofer as he moved to a five-length victory over the Sanford Stud Farm's Sun Dog.

STONY BROOK, L.I., August 5 -- Mrs. J.B. Balding of The Creek carded a 37, 43 -- 80 and won the low gross prize in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the St. George's G.C. today.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 4 -- Westchester County was excused today from paying a tax to Harrison on a new 51,000,000 hangar at the Westchester County Airport in that town. Supreme Court Justice Robert Doscher dismissed the town's suit to collect from the county a total of 32,500 town and school taxes upon Hangar E. assessed at $850,000.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The Nyasaland constitutional conference ended today with exceptional harmony and agreement on the course of the territory's advance toward self-government under an African majority.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- Powerful Mike Troy of Indiana swept the board clean of records for the 200-meter butterfly stroke tonight in the third day of the four-day tryouts to select the United States Olympic swimming squad.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose $66,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the 1959 week, they were up $38,000,000.
ROME, Aug. 4 -- In the southwest corner of the bastions enclosing the State of Vatican City, work is proceeding on the construction of a papal heliport.

A report on events now "shaking" the "Old South" is made by Dan Wakefield in "Revolt In the South." It will be published Oct. 15 by Grove Press as an Evergreen Target Book, a paperback. Mr. Wakefield is the author of "Island in the City," a report on New York's Spanish Harlem that was published last year by Houghton Mifflin.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Earl Battey belted a two-run homer in the eighth inning tonight and led the Washington Senators to a 2-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Following is the text of the United States note to the Soviet Union today on the case of the RB-47 plane shot down off northern Russia:

BONN, Germany, Aug. 4 -- Chancellor Adenauer predicted today that the six continental nations of the European Common Market and Britain, now in rival economic blocs, would reach "an understanding" by next year.

The State Attorney General has started action in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn to dissolve a real estate concern that operates seven slum buildings described as "the worst properties ever inspected" and inhabited mainly by relief clients.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Industrial shares scored more small rises than falls in the stock market here today. Sentiment was helped by the large increase in Britain's gold and convertible currency reserves, announced last night.

Soltzer-Lampert, realty operators, have purchased the nine-story apartment house with self-service elevator at 170 West Eighty-first Street from the Petal Realty Corporation. The building occupies a plot 65 by 100 feet and contains forty-six apartments.
Robert Moses said yesterday that the 1964 New York World's Fair already faced a shortage of exhibition space and that a "skyscraper" solution had been adopted by its planners.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The French people were told today that they should be neither unhappy nor wild with joy about their country's financial condition.

PAMPERING the palate obviously plays no part in an electronic computer's figuring. Asked to come up with the cheapest diet that would provide all the necessary nutrients, the machine solemnly suggested a melange of lard, beef liver, orange juice and soybean meal.

TOURNAMENT players, observing the results of the same deal played by many different persons, are sometimes puzzled when one player wins four or five more tricks than another, at the same contract and with the same opening lead.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America and the Pittsburgh Steel Company settled a dispute tonight over incentive wage scales. This ended the threat of a strike that had been scheduled to start Sunday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Within recent months there has been a widespread criticism in the current literature of the young foreign doctors who are employed as house physicians in various hospitals in our country. It has been emphasized that there has been a very high incidence of failures among these men in the Educational Council for Foreign Medical Graduates examination, required of graduates from foreign medical schools.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday missed the most disorderly demonstration ever held outside his private office at 22 West Fifty-fifth Street.

The first American vessel designed and built for oceangoing service to the nation's "fourth seacoast" -- the Great Lakes -- received a traditional, but unusually noisy, welcome to New York harbor yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. -- Joseph R. Vogel, president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, predicted today that the trend toward foreign production of movies by American companies would be accelerated.

A seven-week crackdown on narcotics peddlers in East Harlem resulted in the arrest of 103 persons and the seizure of a quantity of narcotics, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday.

In urging boating safety, especially among week-end navigators and vacationists, the Coast Guard has a new ally in insurance people. The Marine Office of America in New York, which is a group of loading insurers of pleasure boats, has designed what it calls a Float Plan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A new era of economic cooperation among Western capital-exporting nations will offset the rising volume of Soviet-bloc aid to politically sensitive under-developed nations, two documents released by the State Department today maintain.

The Electric Autolite Company has agreed to purchase a majority interest in the Equitable Leasing Corporation, an international industrial and business equipment leasing concern, officials of both companies announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The leadership of the House of Representatives has virtually urged members to spend an additional week campaigning before returning for legislative work.

PADANARAM, Mass., Aug. 4 -- Frederick E. (Ted) Hood of Marblehead, Mass., who makes sails for a living and knows how to use them expertly for an avocation, won a glamour prize today in the New York Yacht Club cruise for the second successive year.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 4 -- Three political leaders of Katanga Province were received today by King Baudouin. But it was plain after the meeting that they had received no indication that Belgium intended to recognize the independence of their state.
Machines that "teach" electronics have been added to the "faculty" of Keesler Air Force Base, Biloxi, Miss., makers of the mechanical pedagogues announced yesterday.

The strike of the Long Island Rail Road trainmen, happily now settled at last, was exceptional in many ways, an understanding of which should be helpful in dealing with such disputes in the future. Most exceptional were the 85,000 commuters and the thousands of other people who wanted to use the railroad during more than three long weeks but couldn't.
The Council of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom has announced its "satisfaction" with a move in the United States to waive the application of the Cargo Preference Act.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 4 (AP) -- J. Stuart Russell, 68 years old, farm editor of The Des Moines Register and Tribune since 1925, was killed today when his car struck the rear of a Linn County dump truck.
Domestic sugar futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in moderately active trading.

PARIS. CHIC French women have fallen prey to a new kind of snobbery. Once they confided with a contented smile, "It's Dior" or "It's Balenciaga." They now declare with equal pride that the dresses they are wearing come from Prisunic or Monoprix, the two leading chain stores in France.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 3 -- The brown waters of the upper Parana River are bringing down grisly evidence this winter of a jungle combat without quarter in eastern Paraguay.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox employed a youth-plus-age formula to sweep a double-header from the Kansas City Athletics, 5 -- 3 and 9 -- 1, today and avoid the American League cellar. The rookie battery of Earl Wilson and Jim Pagliaroni combined for a six-hitter in the second game.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Government announced today the formation of sentinel platoons -- a well-armed internal-security force of soldiers "willing to take the devil himself by the ears if necessary."
A longshore union local joined the Federal Government and an employer yesterday in a program to educate waterfront workers in safe cargo handling aboard ship.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 4 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has agreed in principle to lend Israel $27,500,000 for work on a new Mediterranean harbor at Ashdod, according to the governor of the Bank of Israel.
The Long Island Rail Road resumed operations early today after a new dispute -- involving one engineer -- had threatened briefly yesterday to keep the road strikebound.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- On the Central American isthmus the white of cotton bolls is more and more noticeable in the production and trade picture along with the green of coffee berries and the yellow of bananas.

Union stereotypers last night balked plans of The New York Times to print a small portion of the Sunday issue in Albany to relieve a strain on facilities here. The Times informed the union that, under their contract, it would file a claim for damages.

SEOUL, Korea, Aug. 5 -- Yoon Bo Sun, one of the two Democratic party rivals for the Premiership of South Korea, is a 62-year-old veteran of four decades of Korean politics, both legitimate and underground.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold surprised United Nations delegates today by calling a Sunday night meeting of the Security Council to discuss developments in the Congo.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 5 -- Faced with a threat of bloodshed, the United Nations suddenly called off today its plans to send United Nations troops into Katanga Province.

A group of Nigerian students who have won scholarships at leading American colleges and universities seemed to agree yesterday that their country-men were turning increasingly to the United States for higher education.
BESSY SHENG is a slight young woman with a voice as soft as a kitten's cry. But when she gives orders, a $350,000 machine sits up and obeys.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Government auditors questioned today the manner in which Federal researchers spent $715,000 for test samples of a new experimental cancer drug.
HAVANA, Aug. 5 -- The regime raised taxes today on profits, personal income and sales and established a gross tax on companies' receipts.

Bolivia inaugurates a new President today. He is Victor Paz Estenssoro, President once before from 1952 to 1956 and head of the M.N.R. movement which made Bolivia's revolution. The reins of office are being turned over to him by another moderate leader of the M.N.R., Hernan Siles Zuazo, who remained in office despite uprisings and economic difficulties of the gravest sort.

"AN AFRICAN TREASURY."* selected by Langston Hughes, throws fresh light on the Dark Continent. This is a collection of stories, memoirs, speeches, essays, poems and folklore. What makes it stand out significantly today is that much of the writing is by new native authors who have never been heard from before.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Earl Buchholz of St. Louis was a surprise choice today to meet Mario Llamas of Mexico in the Davis Cup elimination series beginning tomorrow.
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- Premier Khrushchev told Prime Minister Macmillan today that he still hoped for a summit meeting -- after the Presidential elections in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A Navy official reported today that Lieut. J.B. Barnes absentmindedly -- and successfully -- took off in a new-style jet fighter with its wings folded. The plane, an F8U Crusader, manufactured by Chance Vought, was designed for aircraft carriers.

TRENTON, Aug. 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner has made a nation-wide appeal for support in his efforts to block a Congressional investigation of the Port of New York Authority and to quash contempt citations against three of its top officials.
DETROIT, Aug. 5 -- Blond Chris von Saltza put the United States back on the free-style world-record list tonight with a smashing 4-minute 44.5-second clocking for 400 meters.

With the crisis in the Congo providing the latest focal point in the Communist challenge, the State Department has just issued a survey of aid to less developed countries by both the free world and by the Communist bloc. This document should enlighten the aid-seeking nations. It also contains a warning to Congress, which must still appropriate the funds for the mutual security program.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Plans were speeded today to organize thousands of local discussion groups as an adjunct of the projected television "debates" by the Presidential Candidates this fall.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5 -- President Eisenhower demonstrated anew today that "to a real golfer it never rains -- it just gets damper than usual."

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The National League president, Warren C. Giles, today fined Billy Martin, the Cincinnati Reds' second baseman, $500 and suspended him for five days as a result of his fight yesterday with the Chicago Cubs' pitcher, Jim Brewer.
ROME, Aug. 5 -- The Chamber of Deputies voted its confidence in the new Government of Premier Amintore Fanfani today.

A WORLD champion fisherman belongs in a category with a world champion horseplayer or ambassador; he can't win his belt under controlled conditions, as a world champion pie eater can. But Hy Peskin is going to pick one this year, just the same, as he has before.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The average wholesale price index was unchanged at 119.5 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of July 7 on "Defense Appropriations" contained a number of factual misstatements which should be corrected.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 5 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo telegraphed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today that if United Nations troops did not enter Katanga tomorrow, "I will be forced to revise my position."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff today credited swift United States logistics support with vital assistance to the United Nations in the Congo crisis.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 5 -- Maritime nations of the North Atlantic Treaty. Organization should establish reserve fleet for surplus commercial vessels just as the United States does, according to Ralph E. Casey.

Senator John F. Kennedy, in a seven-hour visit in the city yesterday, combined a strong bid for the support of minority groups with efforts to close the gap between warring factions of the New York Democratic party.

Kilmarnock of Scotland and Bangu of Brazil will meet at the Polo Grounds today for the International Soccer League championship. These teams, with records of four victories and one tie each, gained the laurels in their respective sections in the new league's first season.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The School District of Abington Township, Pa., asked the Supreme Court today to set aside an order forbidding Bible reading in township schools.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The State Department charged today that Cuban officials had stolen World War II trophies from the baggage of an ousted United States Embassy aide and planned to display them as evidence that the American and a colleague were "Nazi agents."

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Robin Ault of Cranford, N.J., won the United States junior chess championship for the second straight year today by winning one game and drawing another in the last Two rounds of play.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5 (AP) -- A freakish scoring play in the eighth inning gave the leagueleading Pittsburgh Pirates a 1-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight and broke up a fine pitching duel between Wilmer (Vinegar Bend) Mizell of the Pirates and Sam Jones of the Giants.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5 -- The New York Yacht Club cruise, one of the antiques of American yachting, came to its next-to-last race today at the traditional base of Newport. The skippers of three yachts in the five classes were exhilerated by the taste of victory for the first time.
JUNEAU, July 31 -- The Alaska salmon canning industry, hare hit by poor runs in recent years, put Its money this season on the predictions of a University of Washington scientist.
Sybil Wolfensohn, a 5-foot 2-inch 21-year-old brunette, won the Women's Cross County Golf Association match play championship yesterday at the North Hills Golf Club, Douglaston Queens.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 5 -- The story of the Yankees' 4-3 victory over the Athletics at Municipal Stadium tonight was not so much that Roger Maris helped wrap it up with his thirty-third homer. Nor was it that Art Ditmar won the game.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Two junior mathematicians of the top-secret National Security Agency appear to have "gone behind the Iron Curtain," the Defense Department said today.
Guest clergymen will occupy many New York pulpits tomorrow. A listing of some of the churches and their summer visitors follows; unless otherwise noted, the service will be at 11 A.M.:
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 5 -- Katanga Province proved in a test case today its determination to keep the United Nations out.

A series of shock waves slammed toward Brooklyn through a hard-rock tunnel three hundred feet beneath the East River at 7:43 last night buffeting a waiting crew of sandhogs and blowing the helmet off one of them.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board began an investigation today into the overbooking practices of the scheduled airlines.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 5 -- Adios Butler and Bye Bye Byrd two of the harness world's fastest pacers, may force the field to a world record in the $25,000 Summer Festival Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner described as illegal today the so-called guaranteed rates on railroad freight.

Jean-Paul Sartre is not only an eminent playwright but one of the foremost prophets of existentialism, a doctrine which stresses personal decision in the face of a purposeless universe. M. Sartre has now applied his writing talents and his philosophical analysis to our frenetic neighbor, Fidel Castro.
"The Leopard," the best-selling historical novel by Giuseppe di Lampedusa, will be filmed or location in Sicily next summer by Titanus Films of Rome.

The shopping center at the northeast corner of Suffolk Avenue and Wheeler Road in Central Islip, L.I., has beer purchased by an investor represented by Max Gelles, lawyer. The sale was the first since construction in 1954.
Prices of cotton on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 20 points up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
Earnings of Foremost Dairies, Inc., in the first half of 1960 were below the 1959 level despite an increase in sales, the company reported yesterday.
The Long Island Rail Road, which had been strikebound for twenty-six days, went back into operation yesterday -- without fanfare, without incident and without many passengers.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 4 -- Four laboratories, using completely different types of instrument, have observed a free vibration of the earth. Some geophysicists consider this a landmark in the study of this planet's interior.

Murray Kay, vice president of Pease Elliman, Inc., managing agent of the twelve-story office and showroom building a 159 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Thirty-second Street, announced yesterday a new plan for operating the building on a cooperative basis.

West Germany is in "a particularly favorable" position to assist underdeveloped nations, according to a report by the National Planning Association. The Bonn regime is of more value to the West in the cold war struggle than East Germany is to the Soviet bloc, the study concludes.
BELLPORT, L.I., Aug 5 -- Three Star class skippers were tied for the series lead for the Corry trophy going into the final day of sailing.

CHICAGO, Aug 5 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators knocked out Bob Shaw with if our runs in the first inning tonight and won, 6 -- 1, extending the Chicago White Box losing streak to a season high of five games.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Johnny Temple's seventh-inning squeeze bunt gave a 4-3 victory to the Cleveland Indians over the Baltimore Orioles tonight in Jimmie Dykes' debut as manager of the Indians.
Sluggish trading predominated yesterday on most New York commodity exchanges. Most of the volume involved evening of positions prior to the week-end.

ONE of the coolest collections of milk glass accessories around town can be found at Serendipity 3, 225 East Fifty-eighth Street. These chalkwhite pieces come in the form of old ice cream soda, ice cream sundae and banana split servers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: My attention has been drawn to the article appearing in The Times of July 17, datelined Carpi, Italy, July 16, concerning the struggle between the Catholic Church and the Communists in northern Italy.
BOOKSHELVES are a bestseller today, as they emerge from their role as the family catch-all to become the focal point in rooms.
The reassignment of Capt. Joseph A. Bresnan, Captain of the Port and commander of the New York Coast Guard Group since July, 1958, has been announced.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5 -- On grass soaked by an all morning rain, three of Austral ia's top campaigners and one American, Ron Holmberg, waded into the semi-finals of the Meadow Club's invitation tennis tournament today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The United States renewed its efforts today to have an early meeting of the Disarmament Commission. It gave its approval to plans to begin the session Aug. 15.
SOMERVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 5 -- The first break has come in an economic boycott against leaders of a drive for registration of Negro voters in Fayette County.

SAYVILLE, L.I. Aug. 5 -- Barney and David Lobel of the Cold Spring Country Club posted a 36, 35 -- 71 and won the Long Island Golf Association father-and-son championship by a stroke at the Island Hills Golf Club today.

VALPARAISO, Fla., Aug. 5 (AP)) -- A Bomarc-A successfully intercepted a pilotless B-47 Stratojet bomber over the Gulf of Mexico today as the jet made a simulated sneak attack on the northwest Florida coast.

Next April 12 will mark the centennial of the firing on Fort Sumtev and the beginning of the Civil War. Between now and that date a great many books dealing with the war will be published. At least four will be issued in October, three of them on Oct. 3.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves snapped a four-game losing streak with a 10-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

Narrow price fluctuations took place in the bond market yesterday following the Treasury's announcement of the successful outcome of its $8,750,000,000 August refunding operation. On the whole, the allotment of subscriptions announced by the Treasury was in line with what had been expected.
A remedial-reading clinic that charges children only 10 cents an hour opened its doors to students on the lower East Side this week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Edgar Monsanto Queeny, chairman of the finance commitee of the Monsanto Chemical Company, St. Louis, has invented a method for the direct use of liquid phosphorus as fertilizer.
NEWPORT, R.J, Aug. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morris Phelps gave a dinner dance at the Clambake Club here this evening to honor Mrs. Phelps' daughter, Miss Faith Low.
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- The Kremlin reassured the Soviet people today that contacts and exchanges with the West would go on despite an asserted infiltration of United States spies into the country.
A one-hour study of heart disease will be shown over WNEW-TV (Channel 5) on Sunday, Aug. 21 at 10 P.M.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Don Buddin's two-run triple was the big blow in a seventh-inning rally tonight that gave the Boston Red Sox a 4-to-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers and spoiled Joe Gordon's debut as the Tiger manager.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Swiss bank officials said today the Swiss stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad would vote soon on rival bids from the New York Central and the Chesapeake and Ohio railroads. Switzerland's "big three" banks, the Swiss Credit Bank, the Swiss Bank Corporation and the Union Bank of Switzerland, will jointly publish the rival offers in a newspaper advertisement next week, the sources said.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gen. Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Jr., son of the Dominican ruler, has joined his father in accepting an assignment out of the country, the Government reported today.

Matson Navigation The board of directors of the Matson Navigation Company yesterday tripled the company's quarterly dividend. The board declared a dividend of 90 cents a share. The rate had been 30 cents a share in previous quarters.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 5 -- A State Senator and a City Councilman from the Bronx proposed today that Westchester County ask patrons of its parks if they believe nonresidents should continue to be "discriminated against" in the parks.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Swiss bank officials said today the Swiss stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad would vote soon on rival bids from the New York Central and the Chesapeake and Ohio railroads. Switzerland's "big three" banks, the Swiss Credit Bank, the Swiss Bank Corporation and the Union Bank of Switzerland, will jointly publish the rival offers in a newspaper advertisement next week, the sources said.
CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- One of the "Hall of Fame" trees in Westchester County has died. Another is showing the ravages of age. But the grand patriarch of them all is in excellent health.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gen. Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Jr., son of the Dominican ruler, has joined his father in accepting an assignment out of the country, the Government reported today.

Matson Navigation The board of directors of the Matson Navigation Company yesterday tripled the company's quarterly dividend. The board declared a dividend of 90 cents a share. The rate had been 30 cents a share in previous quarters.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 5 -- Vice President Nixon landed here tonight on the final leg of an initial four-day campaign tour, covering Hawaii and three other states. MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 6 -- Cardinal Spellman, bitterly attacking the Communist powers, said today the world was living Text of the Cardinal's sermon will be found on Page 30. through "the most dangerous summer since 1939."
An account of efforts by American students visiting Moscow to inform Soviet citizens about the United States and of efforts by Soviet authorities to thwart the Americans was received here last week.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 6 -- Victor Paz Estenssoro assumed the Presidency of Bolivia today with a pledge of "cordiality and good relations" with the United States.

WASHINGTON -- The Washington Monument the towering white obelisk that dominate the skyline of the nation's capital, ranks as one of the world's most photographed landmarks, and upward of 2,000 visitors a day get the inside story of the shrine the hard way -- by climbing the 398 steps to its top.

In the hundred days since an American U-2 reconnaissance jet was shot down in Russia, the world Communist movement has waged a vigorous propaganda campaign against the United States in particular and the West in general. Rocket threats have alternated with sweeping proposals for com- plete disarmament, nonaggression pacts, peace treaties and summit meetings.

Just twenty-five years ago this month, on Aug. 15, 1935, a man who was christened William Penn Adair Rogers (he was part Cherokee Indian and said he was named for a chief who happened to be visiting his folks at the time) died in an airplane crash at Point Barrow, Alaska. The world mourned the passing of the man it had known as Will Rogers -- "the poor man's Plato," "the Poet Lariat."
BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Herbie Hild's Desiree, out of City Island, had a third and a ninth in today's final races to capture the Star class competition for the Corry Trophy.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- The largest ore vessel ever built for Great Lakes Service made her maiden voyage this week after a serpentine trip through the Manitowoc River.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, Aug. 6 -- Kenneth Kaunda is one of the young spirited political leaders of Central Africa.

BARNEGAT LIGHT, N.J. -- "Old Barney," New Jersey's century-old lighthouse on the northeast tip of Long Beach Island, is back in the business of receiving visitors who want to climb the 217 steps to the top to enjoy the twenty-mile view up and down the coastline.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It would appear that the Congo will have to remain under some form of U.N. mandate for at least a decade, probably much longer.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 -- Another season ended last week for the Mark Twain Summer Institute, a summer school with a difference.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- Douglas Aircraft Company this week announced the lay-off, effective at once, of 184 employes at its Long Beach plant where the DC-8 jet and the C-133 cargo carrier are in production.

AN observant parent, strolling in Central Park on a recent Sunday, reported that the zoo was too jammed for anyone to see the animals, and that the air was filled with the wails of cranky children and the screams of exasperated parents.
Aleksei N. Kosygin, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, has made public the first comprehensive inventory of Soviet wealth in recent years.

For Ages 12 to 16. SEVENTEEN-year-old Tina is spending the summer on the New England shore at the once-magnificent estate of her great-grandfather. The girl's widowed mother is occupied with reminiscences.

Through no fault of his own, U.N. SecretaryGeneral Dag Hammarskjold has had to return from the Congo with his mission only partly accomplished. The trouble is in the rich province of Katanga. On the face of it the difficulty, as the Secretary-General pointed out in the report he transmitted yesterday, does not lie with the Belgians, but with the internal situation in the Congo itself.

WHEN it was published in Greek "The Last Temptation of Christ" fanned the inquisitional flames lit by Nikos Kazantzakis' earlier writings, in which he had tried to lift Christ out of the church altogether.
THE integrity of the National Park System is threatened on many fronts, but in none more seriously at the moment than in the first and greatest of the national parks, Yellowstone itself.
Dr. Francis A. Jenkins, teacher and nuclear physicist died Wednesday of cancer in Peraita Hospital in Oakland Calif. He was 61 years old lived in Berkeley, Calif.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 6 -- Fortifications built by successors of Alexander the Great at Sardis, capital of the ancient Kingdom of Lydia, have been discovered by a Cornell-Harvard archaeological group that is exploring the vast site near Smyrna, Turkey.
USING a combination of native and cultivated plants, Mrs. Wallace Lockwood of Pittsford, N.Y., has designed a flowering 'woodland" in a moderately sunny to deeply shaded section of her garden.

ARE we moving toward a struggle between white and dark races? This question lowers menacingly over mankind today. Each of us will have his own personal answer to it. I will start by giving mine straightaway. I will then give my reasons for answering the question as I do.

ADMIRERS of Alain Resnais, the young French director whose first feature, "Hiroshima, Mon Amour," put him on the international movie map overnight, should be pleased to note that M. Resnais is not idling.

IN the preface to "Scan O'Casey: The Man and His Work," David Krause describes him as "a controversial and alienated figure." Through most of his life, which is now eighty years long, O'Casey has been hurling thunderbolts across his writing table.
THE biggest tournament played annually in the world, the summer championships of the American Contract Bridge League, will begin this week and continue through Tuesday, Aug. 23.

The State of New York is being challenged on two fronts -- in the courts and before the United States Civil Rights Commission -- because it restricts the right to vote to those who can read and write English.

HOLLYWOOD. ONE week from tomorrow, when Martin Rackin takes over as supervisory chief of production at Paramount -- a job that has been vacant since 1956 -- Hollywood will get a chance to start gathering evidence to back the gossip that has been circulating about his ability since his appointment was announced on July 27.

The Word in Translation The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, in its recently issued "Index Translationum" for 1958, listed Lenin as the most translated author in the world and the U.S.S.R. first among the sixty-four nations surveyed in number of translations.
The Democratic platform for the 1960 Presidential campaign deals with the problems of the cities and their suburbs as a major national issue.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 -- "I'd like to talk to you for a few minutes today about our country, its future, and what you can do about it * * * America needs more today than voting for a party label. It needs more than voting for a personality * * *."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- Publishers of the widely sold "Arthritis and Common Sense" were ordered by the Federal Trade Commission today to stop making "false" advertising claims that the diet described in the book would cure arthritis or rheumatism.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 6 -- Iceland, long a land of chronic inflation, has won control over her economic ills, but there is widespread, apprehension over the immediate future.

THE ironclad warship was perhaps the most stately, romantic, formidable and short-lived weapon of war ever devised by man. During its brief period of domination from mid-nineteenth to mid-twentieth century, the great powers spent unrecorded billions of dollars on the construction and maintenance of these massive status-symbols.

FICTION ANTHONY ADVERSE. Hervey Allen. (Bantam. 95 cents.) This immensely popular, immensely long and incident-packed tale, one of the best historical romances of this century, is now available for the first time in a single paperback volume.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Seventh-inning homers by Walt Moryn and Curt Flood enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 6 -- 5, today and lift themselves back into second place.
HONG KONG, Aug. 6 -- Communist China is resorting to extraordinary measures to produce food this year. Reports of these efforts carry evidence of shortages in supplies on the mainland.
Five girls and a boy survive a forty-foot jump from a blazing four-story tenement here yesterday. The girls hit the pavement, and the boy was caught by a laborer who had been working near by.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- Nothing in the Colorado travel field seems as interesting and encouraging as the astonishing comeback being made these days by the romantic old stagecoach roads of the Eighteen Seventies and Eighteen Eighties.

The New York City Mission Society's Good Neighbor Church and Community Center at 115 East 106th Street will benefit from an Open House Tea, to be held at the center on Dec. 1. Mrs. Ogden E. Edwards and Mrs. Reginald L. Murphey are co-chairmen for the event.

ROME, Aug. 6 -- A nine-mile Olympic Road skirting Rome's western suburbs was opened today. The road completed the extensive preparations this ancient and ambitious metropolis has made for the seventeenth Olympic Games beginning Aug. 25.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 6 -- Casey Stengel enjoyed today what baseball managers call a "rocking-chair game." The skipper of the pace-setting Yankees had few decisions to make and little to do as he and the 24,039 fans at Municipal Stadium watched the Yanks whip the Athletics, 16 -- 4.
Francis S. Bensel, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, made public yesterday the membership of its standing and special committees for 1960-61.
THE house shown on these pages represents one family's answer to a considerable challenge: finding a spacious home at a reasonable price in a desirable location.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Prepayment group dentistry programs have proved feasible and are beginning to spread.

Outlook for an "excellent" small grain crop and favorable livestock marketings should push farm income above year-ago levels and provide a general business stimulus for the district, the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis said in its monthly review.

HILLTOWN, Pa., Aug. 6 -- Ch. Talia of Villa Malta, a tiny, pert and thoroughly poised Maltese owned by Dr. and Mrs. Vincenzo Calvaresi of Bedford, Mass., outmaneuvered 481 other aspirants today to win best-inshow honors at the third annual Penn-Ridge Kennel Club allbreed event.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The majority of British newspapers commenting today on Premier Khrushchev's letter to Prime Minister Macmillan found nothing objectionable in it. Yesterday British Cabinet members had said they found its tone offensive.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. -- Tarpon fishing long has been an exciting and popular sport in Florida waters. For many years, several resort areas have conducted annual tournaments as a lure for tourists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Oil and water will not mix, according to a law of chemistry which has been incorporated into a famous adage. But those expert political pharmacists, John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon, are going right ahead with their effort to prove they will mix temporarily.

A spy mania is apparently once again being whipped up among the Soviet people by the Soviet Government. A rash of articles in the Soviet press these past several days has once again sounded the theme of "vigilance" against espionage and told readers of that press that a massive infiltration of agents disguised as students, tourists and the like, is being accomplished by the West.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A California import, Dotted Swiss, owned by C.V. Whitney, scored his sixth straight victory by taking the $53,750 Laurance Armour Handicap at Arlington Park today.

A heated exchange between Representative Emanuel Celler and the Port of New York Authority last week pointed up a bitter dispute involving the Port Authority, Congress and the Governors of New York and New Jersey. The dispute stems from a plan to build a jet airport in Morris County, N.J., to serve New York City.
The continued growth of electric utilities is becoming about as certain as death and taxes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States delegation to the recent Geneva disarmament talks expressed the view today that there was little hope of successful disarmament negotiations with the Communist bloc.

The world's most powerful atomic accelerator, designed to penetrate deeper than ever before into the dark realms of matter, started operation last week at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, N.Y. After a warming-up period of one hour, it accelerated a beam of protons -- positively charged nuclei of hydrogen atoms -- to an energy of more than thirty billion electron-volts (30 BEV), the highest energy so far achieved on earth by a manmade device.
The Douglas fir plywood industry again is confronted with a price famine in the midst of production plenty.

OUT on the North Shore of Long Island, some forty miles from Manhattan, lies Caumsett, a great estate assembled at Lloyd Neck by the late Marshall Field 3d. It extends over more than 1,400 acres of beautiful rolling countryside, offers magnificent vistas of Long Island Sound and runs down to an extended shoreline area of fiat, sandy beach.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- One new face will appear in the Senate Monday, increasing the Democratic majority to sixty-six compared with thirty-four Republican Senators.

THE opening here last week of Helmut Kautner's "The Rest Is Silence," a German language film that transposes Shakespeare's "Hamlet" into a present-day German situation and dialogue, presents this observer with an occasion to raise and discuss a thought that became a strong conviction in our mind while in Europe this spring.
This week will be a busy one for professional and amateur golfers in the metropolitan area.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sunday, Aug. 7 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold conferred last night and early this morning with leading delegates in an effort to reach agreement on a resolution that would induce the Katanga Provincial Government to permit the entry of the United Nations Congo Force.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Senate returns to work Monday, the House two weeks later. For four weeks, at most, the politicians are supposed to suspend partisanship and tend to the people's business.

Despite anti-segregation laws in a growing number of states, few home builders have ventured to open their developments to nonwhite families because they believe that sales to Negro or other nonwhite families would harm property values in white communities.

PORTLAND, Ore. MORE than 100 years ago daylilies were carried across the plains to the Oregon country in the covered wagons of the pioneers. Today the descendants of those plants are returning to American gardens as hybridizers in the Northwest release more and more new varieties to the public.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 -- Teams from the West seem to bring out the best in the normally derelict Phillies. Having developed a superiority complex at the expense of the San Francisco Giants earlier this week, they set about proving the inferiority of the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

TAVERNIER, Fla. -- Members of the Florida tourist industry, men accustomed to thinking big, are straining their imaginations to devise plans for developing the state's newest sight-seeing attraction. The trouble is that this newest drawing card for tourists -- the Key Largo Coral Reef Preserve near here -- is completely under Water and three miles out.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 6 -- The Zoning Board will meet here Monday night an an attempt to resolve a mounting controversy, over golf, country and swimming clubs in residential areas.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 5 -- The conference of geophysicists from many lands, which ended here today, has indicated, as never before, the complex and vital relationship between the earth and the sun.

Demand for rental apartmerits in two-family homes has proved so great in the southern part of Queens that a developer there has begun designing such structures for the rental of both suites. Customarily, two-family homes are built for sale to owners who will rent one of the apartments.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 6 -- With Bobby Ussery whipping and driving on the outside, Patrice Jacobs' 3-2 favorite, Hail to Reason, scored his fifth stakes victory today in the $136,875 Sapling at Monmouth Park.

WHEN used around the outside of the house, most metals eventually rust, tarnish or oxidize -- unless they are adequately protected by paint or other weatherproof coating. WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The political parties' national committees would have to act if their nominees for President or Vice President died, were hopelessly disabled or resigned before Election Day.

Prospects for a 10 per cent rebate on 1960 state income taxes soared yesterday as the State Budget Division released figures indicating that revenues this year would exceed the expected outgo by $120,000,000.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 1 -- The prospects for a major American aid project in Burma, a planned highway from Rangoon to Mandalay, have become doubtful.

LAST week New York was dead as far as new art exhibition openings were concerned, but it was very much alive with people going to see what is regularly on view in the city. On Tuesday, a typical summer weekday, 4,716 persons entered the Metropolitan Museum, and as many of them as possible were trailed through it by this observer between 10 A.M., when the museum opened, and 5 P.M., when it closed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- Jim Landis, his center-field job in jeopardy, hit a two-run homer and a two-run triple today as the Chicago White Sox defeated Washington, 9 -- 2, and snapped a five-game losing streak.

SAN DIEGO -- The foreign city that attracts the most American visitors any year nowadays is not a great world capital or metropolis but Tijuana, Mexico, relatively small and hardly famous. It is the border city at the northern end of Mexico's Baja (Lower) California, just south of San Diego and three hours by freeway from Los Angeles.

TO THE EDITOR: It seems to me high time that someone recognized publicly that the Russians are playing a system. Dr. Sargant has named a likely suspect and suggested astutely how to combat it.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6 -- The Hollyhocks Restoration Fund will gain from the Friday night formal benefit showing for invited guests of an exhibition of the paintings of Jean de Botton. The show, which will mark the opening of the new Southampton Art Gallery-East, will continue for two weeks.

BEGINNING early next year, television viewers in West Germany will find an added attraction in their daily video fare. The country, which has had seven noncommercial television networks operating over one channel in the past, will join England and several other European countries in the opening of a second channel, whose programs will partially be maintained and paid for by commercial sponsors.

AT a little after 9 o'clock, on a warm summer evening just thirty years ago yesterday, a tall, heavy-set gentleman wearing a brown double-breasted suit and a Panama hat stepped into a taxi in front of a restaurant at 332 West Forty-fifth Street, waved good-by to the two friends with whom he had just had dinner and, smiling, settled back comfortably as the cab pulled out into traffic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of "somewhat hysterical efforts" to inflame public opinion in advance of the espionage trial of Francis Gary Powers, pilot of the U-2 reconnaissance plane shot down over the Soviet Union on May 1.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 6 -- The eighth annual Forget Me Not Ball for the benefit of the Nassau Cerebral Palsy Association will take place Oct. 8 in the Georgian Room of the Garden City Hotel. Many dinner parties at the hotel will precede the event, with dancing afterwards.
CONAKRY, Guinea, Aug. 6 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba said last night that the Congo wanted technical and economic help from individual countries rather than from the United Nations.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 6 -- Perked-up California Republicans met in state convention today. They heard Senator Thomas H. Kuchel sound the keynote that Vice President Nixon would win the Presidency, but that the fight would be tough and close.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- David Coggins of Marblehead, Mass.; sailed Oh-No to a one-quarter point lead over another Bay State skipper, Francis Charles of Hull, racing Jester, in the first two races of the Atlantic Coast championship of the International 110 Class on Long Island Sound today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Invitations have gone out to surviving men and women who pioneered the Social Security Act to join a twenty-fifth anniversary celebration at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare on Aug. 15.

SELIG HARRISON, an American who spent three years in India as a foreign correspondent, is a serious student of political affairs; he combines an eye for detail with a perceptive understanding of the landscape. ACCRA, Ghana, Aug. 6 -- President Kwame Nkrumah threatened today to order Ghanaian troops into Katanga Province to fight the Belgian forces if the United Nations failed to compel their withdrawal.

WHEN disaster spread through Germany during the last days of World War II, boys of 12 to 16 were hurriedly stuffed into uniforms and given weapons. Some of them took to the situation with gusto and were recruited into the Volkssturm, a fanatic group which indulged largely in the sport of hunting and gunning down escapees from German camps.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- An outbreak of socalled African horse sickness, spread by a minute insect, already has caused inestimable damage to nine countries in Asia and the Middle East. The carriers, of the culicoides type of sand fly, threaten the equine population of the affected countries, in which these animal constitute the main motive power.

EVVIE, one of the two heroines of Vera Caspary's slick new novel, is a dream girl. She is beautiful, clever, talented. She loves life and abandons herself to living it. THE design of two stamps, four-cents and 8c, which Washington has added to the 1960 United States philatelic program, was made public yesterday by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield. Yesterday marked the fifteenth anniversary of the dropping of the first atomic bomb over Hiroshima. In that one bomb was concentrated the explosive power of 20,000 tons of TNT. It leveled the city of Hiroshima and brought death to more than 100,000 Japanese.

An elderly mannequin, constructed eighty-eight years ago of wood to stand outside a Manhattan bicycle shop, has found new employment in a modern age. The report of the State Judicial Conference on the cases handled during the year ended June 30 reveals a failure of the New York courts to keep up with their business now become truly alarming. The public is used to stories of justice delayed, but the latest conference statistics show that matters are going from bad to worse at a rate that should penetrate the jaded attention of the public.
Laos is a mountain kingdom in the turbulent Balkans of Southeast Asia known collectively as Indochina.

Decca Records, Inc., posted the highest first six months' earnings in its history in the half-year ended on June 30. The rise in profit reflected primarily the excellent performance of Decca's 87.1 per cent-owned subsidiary, the Universal Pictures Company, which had a record gross of more than $8,000,000 from one film alone in the first six months of this year, a report issued yesterday disclosed.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Carding a 38, 42 -- 80 over the Fenway golf course Mrs. Alfred Slaner of Old Oaks today won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Westchester District gross tournament by three strokes.

In a most remarkable mission to be entrusted to one man, Secretary General Hammarskjold is trying to stamp out the sparks of incipient civil war in the Congo that could set Africa aflame and even precipitate, as he warns, a new world war.
Last week David J. Cogan labeled rumors that he had bought the Biltmore Theatre, 261 West Forty-seventh Street, as premature. Yesterday he confirmed the purchase.

TWO solid weeks of tournament play are coming up, beginning tomorrow: First, a two-day intercity match between teams representing New York and Los Angeles; then eleven or twelve days of the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Senator Barry Goldwater waged a "stand outside" strike against a labor bill today. He lost, for the moment, but does not intend to give up.

A caravan of buses will take dinner guests from the New York Yacht Club to the Winter Garden on Dec. 2 to see "The Unsinkable Molly Brown." The proceeds of the evening will go to the support of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

John Meyer of Locust Valley, L.I., who will be chairman of the interclub championship races at Bridgehampton, Aug. 27 and 28, has, for years, been an outstanding figure in Eastern sports car races and hill climbs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: The curious climate of unreality in which those dwell who insist on believing that We can do business to our advantage with the Soviet Union on disarmament questions is once more exemplified by the letter of Clarence F. Avey in your issue of Aug. 3.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 9, (Reuters) -- Negotiations that seek to indemnify stockholders of the German Gold Discount Bank are expected to start before the end of the year with the West German Government.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 9 -- It was ladies' day at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today. For while the men were going through their paces routinely in the Eastern Grass Court championships, a couple of 17-year-old girls turned in upsets.

A delegation or Soviet civil aviation experts said yesterday they had seen nothing extraordinary so far on their technical exchange visit to the United States. However, they termed the first week of their planned three-week visit pleasant and instructive.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., Aug. 9 -- Within twenty-five years, it was predicted today, the population of suburban Long Island will reach 7,000,000 persons and the area will serve as the key link in a broad interurban belt extending Boston to Richmond.
Governor Rockefeller will make campaign speeches in each of the boroughs in this city for the Nixon-Lodge ticket during September and October.
A class of bright children 11 and 12 years old is taking a free-wheeling course in the Italiian Renaissance at Teachers College, Columbia, this summer.

TILLY FOSTER, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Roxanne Zoubek captured three blues and the horsemanship championship of the thirteenth annual Northern Westchester chapter of the Professional Horsemen's Association Junior Horse Show today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A organized Army so mobile that "nobody walks" is under study by the Department of the Army, officials disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A Budget Bureau report to President Eisenhower said today that Congressional approval of pending legislation coupled with its failure to approve recommended revenue measures "would practically wipe out the $4,200,000,000 surplus estimated in the 1961 budget."

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 9 -- The American Yacht Club crew from Rye, N.Y., with Janet Lethen as helmswoman, held a one-point lead today over the Pequot Y.C. entry, captained by Lyn Cunningham, after two races in the final series for the Long Island Sound girl's championship today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- Curt Simmons beat his former teammates for the third time this season when he tossed a five-hit shut-out as the St. Louis Cardinals swept a double-header from the Philadelphia Phillies, 5 -- 4 and 6 -- 0, tonight.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor, has sold the shopping center and medical building at 224th Street and Linden Boulevard, Queens Village, Queens, to a syndicate of California investors. Norman Katz of Ossip Associates was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter expressed discouragement today over the lack of progress toward an agreement banning atomic tests. He said it might be necessary to impose a time limit on the negotiations.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- When the big Soviet Union team goes to the Olympic Games in Rome this month, it will have two aims. One will be to win medals and the other to demonstrate the superiority of the Kremlin's mass approach to athletics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Federal District Judge George Hart Jr. ordered the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union today to reinstate four officials who were ousted during an insurrection against the union president, James G. Gross.

RARELY will so many foreigners have an opportunity to see American cooking in the making as when the British Food Fair opens in London on Sept. 1. Three hundred thousand persons are expected to visit Olympia Exhibition Hall during the seventeen-day exhibit.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Both Presidential candidates divided their time today between legislative work and campaign plans.
MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- The Soviet Union made public today its official Indictment of Francis Gary Powers as a United States spy.

YESTERDAY Aug. 9, 1960 THE PRESIDENT Had breakfast with Vice President Nixon and Senate Republican leaders; saw Gen. Nathan Twining; met with Joseph S. Farland, new Ambassador to Panama; received a letter from the King of Nepal from Nepalese Ambassador.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Two Soviet officials declared today that juvenile delinquency in the Soviet Union, as in most other countries, was being stimulated by sensational movies and, in some instances, by cheap comic books.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 9 -- In an effort to cut increasing, accidents on the Connecticut Turnpike, state highway officials announced yesterday that electronic warning signs would be installed at six points.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points (30 cents) up to 8 points (40 cents a bale) off yesterday.

The career and capture of Adolf Eichmann, the Nazi commandant of extermination camps, will be told in "Minister of Death," which Viking will issue next month. A survey of two dozen gold stock specialists and monetary exports in New York and Washington shows that not one aniticipates a revaluation of the price of gold -- or devaluation of the dollar -- in the foresseable future.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 9 -- India and Pakistan appeared tonight to be about to cross the last barrier to agreement on the $1,000,000,000 Indus River development program.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made thirty-one loans totaling $658,700,000 in the year ended on June 30, the bank announced yesterday. This compared with $703,000,000 the year before and brought the gross total of the bank's loan commitments on June 30 to $5,181,000,000.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Moving a railroad, demolishing forty-six buildings and shifting major highways in downtown Pleasantville has been increasingly vexatious to merchants and commuters for the last three years.
Magistrate Edward D. Caiazzo took to task yesterday a 28-year-old secretary who appeared in Traffic Court wearing slacks.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- The uncertainties of horse buying are about equivalent to the uncertainties of betting on the beasts. This was brought out with emphasis in today's feature race, which was won by Jimmull of the Harbor View Farm.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Prime Minister Macmillan is going to Bonn tomorrow in the hope that his talks with Chancellor Adenauer will lessen the danger of a political split in Western Europe.
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Modest rises predominated in most sections of the stock market here today under the lead of the top industrials.
A MOVIE actress who once gave the impression that she washed Her face in the Pacific Ocean, brushed her teeth with bark and combed her hair with a scashell, has started a cosmetics concern.
THE chief of the Soviet secret police, who signed the indictment of Francis Gary Powers, the U-2 pilot downed in the Soviet Union May 1, is a prime example of the organization man, Soviet style.

LONG ISLAND game-fish addicts and their allies and sometime opponents, the charter captains, have been living lately in times that test the character of the strong, hardy outdoorsman. Hours of glory follow days of frustration, and only men of iron can maintain steady dignity and restrain the unseemly ebullience of joy and grief.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Antartic Treaty, designed to dedicate the vast south polar area to only peaceful pursuits and researches, went under major debate in the Senate today. The twelve-nation pact, already ratified by five frienly countries, ran into immediate opposition.
Prices of commodity futures moved irregularly on New York markets yesterday after a day of generally dull trading.

The Wyoming Realty Corporation of New York has sold the one-story taxpayer on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 1337-51 Castle Hill Avenue, the Bronx, to Jack Resnick, a realty investor. John J. Reynolds, Inc., was the broker in the sale.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Wilmor (Vinegar Bend). Mizell of the Pittsburgh Pirates, tonight stopped the Chicago Cubs, 7 -- 1, on a five-hitter.

Stanley I. Younger failed to appear yesterday in Federal Court to answer charges by the Securities and Exchange commission that he had engaged in "fraudulent schemes and practices" involving the stock of a non-existent company.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 -- Martyn Green returned to the stage last night for the first time since he had his left leg amputated after an accident in a garage elevator last November. CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Two-run homers by Tito Francona and Vic Power sparked the Cleveland Indians to a 6-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.
The International Paper Company reported yesterday declines in sales and earnings in the second quarter of this year. Profits for the first half fell despite a slight rise in sales.

Greater efforts to integrate the city's public schools were urged yesterday by members of the Board of Education's unofficial advisory commission on integration.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 9 -- A proposal to lease about sixty acres of underwater land to the Long Island Biological Association for Marine Research in Cold Spring Harbor will be discussed at a public hearing next month.

"Live" radio and television debates between Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Nixon are "desirable," spokesmen for the two men and network representatives agreed here yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 10 -- The outcome of Brazil's Presidential elections in eight weeks may hurt her relations with the United States. That is, if the candidate who now seems most likely to win means what he has been saying.

ACCRA, Ghana, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- Parliament voted 55 to 11 tonight to commit Ghanaian troops to fight against Belgian troops in the Congo if the United Nations failed to get the Belgians to move out.
The bond market moved downward again yesterday. Governments were under renewed pressure from speculative selling Corporates eased in light trading. Tax-exempts were firm but less active.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's ill fortune with its Electra jets and Government contracts and the large development costs for its JetStar plane resulted in a net loss of $55,409,000 for the first six months of this year, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The national economy was pictured today by President Eisenhower as stable and prosperous. He found no signs of recession or depression despite lower output in the steel and automotive industries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Executives of variety store chains told Attorney General William P. Rogers today that racial segregation had been ended at lunch counters in their branches in sixty-nine Southern communities, with more progress expected "in the near future."

HONG KONG, Aug. 3 -- Shanghai has won a special status among the cities of Communist China and it is reflected in recent announcements that urban communes will be introduced there only when "conditions have ripened for their establishment."

An arbitrator's award ordering a "runaway" New York clothing manufacturer to reopen his plant here and to pay the Amalgamated Clothing Workers $204,681 in damages was upheld yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 10 -- A motorboat carrying a family of six hit a rock and capsized in Long Island Sound late this afternoon. Four were missing and believed to have drowned. Two teen-aged sisters who had clung to the nearly-submerged bow for four hours were rescued.

An autobiographical narrative by the late Thomas Mann, originally published in a limited edition in 1930, will be reissued Monday by Knopf. In "A Sketch of My Life," Mr. Mann covered his first fifty years, telling of his rise to literary fame, his marriage and family happiness.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and its subsidiaries increased net earnings in the first half this year to $43,902,000 from $38,391,000 in the initial six months of 1959. SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Janet Lethen, representing the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., maintained her lead for the Long Island Sound girls' championship by winning the only race that could be sailed today.

New York City's plan to close Riverside Hospital for youthful narcotics addicts and transfer its patients to other city institutions was strongly opposed yesterday by representatives of many citizens' groups at an open hearing.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 10 -- A reduction of more than $1,000,000 has been granted in the assessed valuation of the Mid-Island Shopping Plaza in Hicksville. The decision by the State Supreme Court here is the first in actions brought by major shopping, centers throughout Nassau County.

M. Michael Meadow and George Schaffer, builders, have bought the property at the southeast corner of Third Avenue and Fifteenth Street for improvement with an airconditioned apartment house.
Commodity futures prices moved irregularly on the New York exchanges yesterday in generally dull trading.

A contraseasonal increase of 452,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies stood 10,166,000 barrels above the level of a year earlier.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 10 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics scored eight runs in the third inning and Dick Hall scattered four hits tonight in a 13-1. victory over the Washington Senators.

With the help of business prosperity whose extent could not be foreseen Governor Rockefeller has not only re-established New York State on a pay-as-you-go basis but has comfortably overshot the mark. DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Jackie Brandt, Dave Nicholson and Jim Gentile hit home runs today to give the Baltimore Orioles a 4-2 triumph over the Tigers and their fifth straight victory.
