The Citizens' Housing and Planning Council of New York, Inc., will benefit from a preview of "Face of a Hero" on the evening of Oct. 19. The Robert L. Joseph play, starring Jack Lemmon, is scheduled to open at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre on Oct. 20.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The advance of industrial shares quickened in the stock market here today. Buying increased appreciably and demand was wider than in recent days.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Willie Jones' bases-filled pinch single in the eighth inning capped a three-run rally tonight and gave the Cincinnati Reds a 5-3 victory that stretched the San Francisco Giants' losing streak to six games.

Stanley I. Younger, reported on Tuesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission as "missing," telephoned the agency yesterday and said he would be available to face criminal indictments charging fraudulent sales of securities.

Iva S.V. Patcevitch, president and chairman of Conde Nast Publications, Inc., sold 82,500 shares of the company's common stock on July 7, according to the insiders' report issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange from reports made available to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The United States Olympic team, which begins assembling here today for the trip to Rome, will receive a rousing public send-off from the city on Monday.

The world's Lutheran churches, largest of the Protestant confessions, showed a net loss of 33,000 members In the last year, primarily because of a big drop in members behind the Iron Curtain, the National Lutheran Council reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Eisenhower said today that "definite action" by the United States would be called for if Cuba or any other country of the American hemisphere fell under the control of international communism.

SAYVILLE, L.I. Aug. 10 -- A change in the order of finish of yesterday's second race, which gave John Fauth's Babylon Yacht Club crew an additional half point, meant the difference as the area semi-finals in the junior sailing championship ended off here today.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 10 -- The army group that occupied the Laotian capital of Vientiane in a coup yesterday, maneuvered today to expand its control in other parts of the country.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Ted Williams hit the 512th and 513th home runs of his career tonight in a 6-1 victory by the Boston Red Sox over the Cleveland Indians.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A late rally raised several grain futures contracts into small gains today on the Board of Trade and wiped out all but small losses in soybeans.

The New York State Banking board yesterday approved applications by six New York City banking institutions for permission to open branches in Nassau County and for one in Westchester County, under the terms of the state's new Omnibus Banking Law.

Antarctica, which became almost a continent-sized laboratory for science during the International Geophysical Year might become a laboratory for international cooperation under the twelve-nation treaty.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 10 -- A 14-year-old boy turned himself in at his mother's urging tonight and admitted killing another boy In a street fight a few hours earlier, the police said.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Although the matches in the Eastern grass court tennis championships were canceled today because of water-logged courts, the grounds crew was seen hosing the playing surfaces early this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today plans to build the first atomic power station in the Antarctic.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 10 -- South Africa's bank rate was raised today from 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

There have been a bushel and a peck of reports and analyses of late that find the state of the economy "disappointing" or "discouraging" or downright "alarming." A somewhat different note is struck by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in its latest monthly survey of business conditions.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP) -- The satellite Discoverer XIII was fired through a fog bank into polar orbit today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- With Vice President Nixon's backing, eight Republican Senators have quietly formed a special committee to counter-attack the heavy Democratic majority, during the current session of Congress.

Tall Tales of Travelers It is the time-honored custom of travelers to bring back tall tales dealing with sights and experiences, as Jona-than Swift recognized when he based his famous satire, "Gulliver's Travels," on this tendency.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee considering an anti-payola bill cut corners today in hope of getting it to the White House by the end of the present session of Congress.

A Brooklyn crime school for youthful apprentices was uncovered yesterday in a large-scale police raid against a "junior Apalachin" syndicate. At least one boy was apparently killed in gangland style by the syndicate as an object lesson for informers.

NAPOLEON III (1808-73) was a rather dull man with an unquenchable thirst for glory. As the nephew of the great Napoleon, he was perhaps the most pretentious of all the pretenders who plagued France. His odd, disastrous career is sketched with authority and considerable interest in G.P. Gooch's "The Second Empire."*

Two new "international" features, by directors known primarily through European film festival prizes, are being planned for English-language production in Italy and Argentina, employing Sidney Poitier and Jo Va Fleet as the American stars.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a leading manufacturer of forest products, has announced plans to merge with a company holding substantial reserves of timber, natural gas and coal.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Making a daring move through the slop under the urging of Manuel Ycaza, C.V. Whitney's Tompion won the $28,350 Bernard Baruch Stakes today. The son of Tom Fool thrilled the crowd of 13,260 by beating Edward Seinfeld's Don Rickles by a neck in the test of a mile and a furlong for 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The State Department has "twisted, tortured and perverted" sugar legislation in a "venomous campaign" against the Dominican Republic, Senator Alien J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, charged today.
FALLS CHURCH, Va., Aug. 10 -- Landon C. Bell, a retired corporation executive and lawyer, died Monday in Arlington Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

LONDON. ALTHOUGH fresh strawberries, large as table tennis balls, luscious black-red plums and juicy blood oranges abound on virtually every London street corner these bright sunny days the transplanted American homemaker continues to long for her frozen orange juice.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Army rebels headed by a young paratroop captain established a politically mixed government today after consolidating their control of Vientiane.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 10 -- Reports that a change was near in the Belgian Government as a result of events in the Congo circulated in Brussels today. A source close to the Government said, however, that any decision had been put off at least until tomorrow.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 10 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba was reported to have been slightly injured tonight by Congolese who surrounded his car and stoned it in the African quarter of Leopoldville.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, Aug. 10 -- Dr. Hastings K. Banda, Nyasaland's nationalist leader, received a tumultuous welcome here today on his return from London.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Aug. 10 -- Divided Alaskans have rejected a proposal to abandon Juneau as the state capital.

A way has been found to put 100,000 pieces of information into a six-ounce "memory" drum that can be held in the palm of the hand. The finding was done by engineers of the International Business Machines Corporation at the company's Federal Systems division laboratory in Washington, D. C.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 10 -- Soviet - Israeli negotiations on the ownership of millions of dollars' worth of disputed real estate in Jerusalem were suspended today. A joint communique said they would be resumed after consultations with the two Governments.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Fallowing is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The Senate Finance Committee went to work today on a controversial bill to provide medical benefits for the aged. Frequent quorum calls cut the meeting short and little was accomplished.

THE Italians have a word for it. They call It gelati, the dish we know as ice cream. Some sources list the Emperor Nero as its originator and it well may be that he was the first to sample. sweetened ice, One historian has it that the emperor fiddled while slaves hot-footed it down mountain slopes with baskets full of snow.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Perhaps the American" public is unaware of the pessimism of bankers in Switzerland, France and West Germany with respect to the future of the American dollar.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- A treaty dedicating the Antarctic. Continent to peaceful pursuits was ratified by the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Eisenhower fired another volley of political rockets at the Democrats today in an effort to force them to act on his legislative program or take the blame for not doing so.
MOSCOW, Aug. 10 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States air attache here today of having engaged in intelligence activities "incompatible with his diplomatic status."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 20 points (10 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday. The far months were weakest.

PARIS, Aug. 10 -- Katanga is preparing to make itself a hard-money bastion of free enterprise in Africa, according to a Frenchman who identified himself today as an economic counselor to the Tshombe government.

ELISABETHVLLE, the Congo Aug. 10 -- President Moist Tshombe of Katanga said today he was ready to negotiate or the admission of United Nation troops to the province, but he refused to accept unconditionally the resolution adopted by the Security Council early Tuesday.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- A wild-cat strike by British seamen opposed to a pay agreement made by their union spread rapidly today.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $22,000,000 to $293,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $6,000,000 to $499,000,000 from a revised figure the week before.

LLOYD HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 11 -- The State Park Commission announced today that it planned to purchase Caumsett, the 1,426-acre estate of the late Marshall Field, for use as a state park, wildlife refuge and arboretum.
KILLINGWORTH, Conn., Aug. 11 -- A two-day bison hunt ended here today when a 1,800-pound bull was slain in a wooded section near the Killingworth reservoir.

THE late Mayor Jimmy Walker once paid glowing tribute to that strange journalistic breed known as the baseball writer. "It is their zeal which holds public interest in this intensely fascinating sport," said Jimmy. "Their writings and statistical records give the game a continuity which will keep its outstanding performances alive as long as baseball is played."

The annual process by which the New York City government decides what it will build with what it can borrow is now beginning. This is the preparation of the Capital Budget, on which basic work is done by the City Planning Commission. First the various city departments and agencies will be heard, for about two weeks beginning Monday.

Hathaway Instruments OMAHA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Dale Elictronics, Inc., Columbus, Neb., has been acquired by Hathaway Instruments, Inc., Denver, in a $6,000,000 transaction, a joint announcement said yesterday.

Councilman Louis Okin, a gray-haired man with a quiet manner and a rather mournful expression, was sitting at a card table on the sidewalk along West Sixty-ninth Street Wednesday evening. He held a large umbrella over his head.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 -- After three rounds of the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Sheraton-Jefferson Hotel tonight, thirteen of the 175 contestants were in a 3-0 tie for the lead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The airlines set aviation records last year in the number of scheduled flights and in the volume of passenger, mail and cargo traffic they carried, the Federal Aviation Agency said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The White House began today to line up a "nonpolitical" speaking tour for President Eisenhower this fall.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The State Department said today that it still recognized the Government of Premier Tiao Somsanith of Laos.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- For some time many students of United States post-war foreign policy have made a common front on two criticisms. One is that this Government merely reacts negatively to Soviet activities in this field instead of initiating them.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- After hitting new highs for the season on a broad opening runup, soybean futures ran into heavy general selling near the close on the Board of Trade today and finished with all contracts off.
HAVANA, Aug. 11 -- Premier Fidel Castro denounced the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Cuba today for what he called its "systematic provocations" against his Government.

City departments and agencies have asked for capital budget allocations amounting to $1,139,359,918, for the calendar year 1961. This includes $16,056,250 for planning and building a 55,000-seat baseball stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.
The New York Yankees, exhilarated by their success over the White Sox and in good physical condition for the first time in two weeks, open a fourgame series against Washington at the Stadium tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Republican national high command today greeted the return of former President Harry S. Truman to the political wars by calling the "truth squad" of 1956 back to work for the party.

The delivery of a cargo of Soviet crude oil to Cuba by the Danish tanker Helene Maersk did not put the ship, her owners or brokers who have handled the ship on a boycott list of major oil refineries, a spokesman for Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) said yesterday.

Seizure of the Cuban Telephone Company by the Castro government will have "no effect on 1960 net income of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation," H.S. Geneen, president of the parent company, said yesterday in releasing the six months report of I.T. T.

OTTAWA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Young Jack Nicklaus and Dr. Frank (Bud) Taylor led the United States back into the running for the Americas Cup today at the halfway point of the amateur golf competition with Canada and Mexico.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Senate Republicans were debating tonight what moves to make tomorrow against the Democratic majority on the civil rights issue.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbilt of the Westchester Country Club scored 42, 40 -- 82 at Woodway today for a one-stroke victory in the weekly tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fair-field Golf Association.

Superintendent of Insurance Thacher's decision on the Blue Cross request for a 37 per cent increase in rates is sound. In denying it for the time being -- and in his analysis of why he did so -- Mr. Thacher has shown exceptional discernment, both of the weaknesses in the Blue Cross case and of the progress it has made in filling the needs of the subscribing public.
LANSING, Mich., Aug. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Financing was completed here last night for a $20,000,000 international bridge linking the Canadian and United States twin cities of Sault Ste. Marie.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- One of these days some astute official of national amateur tennis is going to take a closer look at the record of Donald Dell.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission ordered the New York Central Railroad today to continue all present trains on the Harlem Division until the commission determined how much service was needed.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug 12 -- Yoon Bo Sun, co-leader of the Korean Democratic party, was elected President of South Korea today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled in effect today that a union that violates Federal secondary boycott restrictions loses the right to picket the concern it is striking.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A five-nation investigation committee said today that its evidence directly linked high officials of the Dominican Republic to the attempt June 24 to assassinate President Romulo Betancourt of Venezuela.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Jersey City sent ten men to the plate and scored all their runs in the first inning tonight en route to a 6-4 victory over the Montreal Royals before 1,195 International League fans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- In all the planning now going on for the campaign, nothing is getting more careful attention than the forthcoming face-to-face radio and TV debates and joint news conferences of the two Presidential nominees.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 11 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt charged today that the Rockefeller Administration's pay-as-you-go financing had jeopardized the state's $500,000,000 highway construction program. He called this a major Democratic campaign issue.
Wall Street's smallest bank, the American Trust Company, elected a new slate of directors yesterday, representing, the insurgent faction that recently won a four-year battle for control.
"Come Away With Me," in which Shirley Booth and Kenneth MacKenna were supposed to appear, has struck a snag.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he would stump coast-to-coast for the Republican Presidential ticket.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 2 per cent below the 1959 level. Of the twelve districts surveyed only New York, up 1 per cent, showed a gain.
THE DAY finally has arrived when a women can bribe her youngsters with, "If you're good, I'll take you to the dentist."

BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, Aug. 12 -- Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, strong man in the Laotian Government supplanted in the administrative capital of Vientiane by an army coup Tuesday, was reported acting early today to regain power.
BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 11 -- Loyalist Democrats defeated a move by states' rights forces today to withhold Louisiana's support from Senator John F. Kennedy.

JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 11 -- A pair of 19-year-olds, Howell (Mickey) Van Gerbig and Don Desio, kept pace with the more experienced players in the field by winning two matches in the Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur championship today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- United Air Lines and Capital Airlines filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board late today an agreement to merge, a few hours after directors of both companies approved the plan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Loadings of rail freight were above and truck loadings were slightly below -- levels of the corresponding week of last year, both industries reported today.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo Aug. 11 -- Reports of several arrests of Opposition leaders and "saboteurs" circulated hove today. Only one arrest, that of a local newspaper editor, was confirmed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The New York Times story on Aug. 6 about Vice President Nixon's attendance at a fund-raising dinner in Hawaii and about his brief meeting with Jack Hall, head of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union in the Islands, may have given some readers an incorrect impression of these occurrences.
Steel production in (July declined to 6,343,000 tons from 7,404,873 in June, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Manufacturers of permanent-type swimming pools expect to make a record sales splash this year.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Almost all share groups advanced strongly in the stock market here today. Prices responded to a further increase in demand and some gains were substantial.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Canada's 14,000 Great Lakes sailors will take a strike vote on the 12 per cent wage increase recommended by a Federal concilation board, a spokesman for the Seafarers International Union (Ind.) said today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- Airline stewardesses, whose poise is usually impervious, ran into "slight turbulence" today at an informal union meeting here.

YESTERDAY (Aug. 11, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Saw Immigration and Naturalization Commissioner Swing and Defense Secretary Gates; issued order terminating the Air Coordinating Committee; announced three nonpolitical speeches in Philadelphia and New York on Sept. 26; announced that Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, planned to retire.

Sixty-odd members of the United States Olympic team were whisked through pre-departure processing yesterday. No Detroit assembly line could have functioned more smoothly than the set-up arranged by the Olympic administration staff.

The Westinghouse Electric International Company announced yesterday that it had been awarded a $20,000,000 contract for a power station by the Mexican Government's Comision Federal de Electricidad. J.L. deCubas, executive vice president of the subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, said that it was the largest single export order for steam-electric power equipment ever received by the company.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., announced yesterday it had cleared $4,437,000 for the quarter ended on June 30, with operating revenues of $105,682,000. In the 1959 period, gross revenues amounted to $90,459,000 and net income was $3,151,000.

As the Organization of American States prepares to meet in Costa Rica next Tuesday to consider "the defense of the democratic American institutions against the subversive activities of any organization, government or their agents," President Eisenhower has again defined the position of the United States toward the Caribbean country where that danger has become most acute -- Cuba.
DETROIT, Aug. 11 -- A cargo of 14,000 tons of pelletized iron concentrates produced from low-grade ore in Michlgan's Upper Peninsula arrived today at the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant in Dearborn.
Shields Co., Van Alstyne, Noel Co., and Crowell, Weedon Co. are offering today 300,000 common shares of American Electronics, Inc., at $13.50 a share.
Four breakdowns in the subway system yesterday disrupted homebound rush-hour traffic on the IRT and BMT lines.

There is only one way to describe next month's seasonal premiere of the "Bell Telephone Hour" -- a veritable pot-pourri. The show will include classical music by Van Cliburn, the pianist; jazz by Benny Goodman and a swing band, popular songs by Sally Ann Howes and Howard Keel and ballet by Melissa Hayden and Andre Eglevsky.

Before planting the kind of punches that deprive a man of his reason, Benny Paret likes to let the fellow know there's nothing personal in such punishment. Consequently, the world welterweight champion treated Denny Moyer like an old friend during a luncheon at the Hotel Manhattan yesterday.

LEGS of lamb have been a special buy for so many weeks now that one almost wonders whether a six-legged creature has been produced. The answer to the specials, however, is not a freak animal but merely an attempt to have roast sales keep pace with the seasonally preferred chops.

Freedom has been defined as the opportunity to exercise self-control Teen-agers undoubtedly have gained more freedom than their elders enjoyed at their age. Today's youngsters also have the greatest challenge to their self-control.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that a study of the beleagucred Purchase Department completed since Purchase Commissioner Joseph V. Spagna was suspended in June showed no evidence of wrongdoing in the department.

The bond market, which had refused to take more than passing notice of the Federal Reserve's first credit-easing step this week, reacted promptly yesterday to the latest reduction in the lending (discount) rate.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The Chicago Natural History Museum reported today, the discovery of what it termed "a unique sacred image, the first of its kind ever to be unearthed."
Neither Vice President Nixon nor Senator John F. Kennedy has a strong religious affiliation, an editorial in next week's issue of The Christian Century declares.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent observations of Ira D. Robbing, president of the City Club, proposing that the qualifications of housing inspectors of the Department of Buildings should be eased are not warranted in the light of the magnitude and complexity of the daily job required to be done.

A three-man arbitration board here heard both sides yesterday in a controversy between the Textile Workers Union of America and one of its locals over an issue relating to Southern school integration.

THE whirligig of American interest in Soviet culture is beginning to deposit some strange artifacts on our literary shores. A volume of Yuri Olesha's early satires has turned up in an inexpensive paperback, Leonid Leonov's "The Thief," one of the author's best but earliest productions, has appeared in a handsome translation.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Startled Ridgefield residents are getting a new look at their town in picture postcards being offered for sale here.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The Meadowland Owners Association, consisting of 250 private owners of meadowlands, said today that private capital was prepared to proceed with reclamation and development of the Meadowlands area.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 11 -- It will be Mrs. Joseph Frelinghuysen of Somerset Hills and Mrs. James Whelan of Springdale against Mrs. Alan Sagner of Mountain Ridge and Mrs. Joseph Rudnick of Jumping Brook in tomorrow's final of the Garden State Women's Golf Association four - ball championship at Springdale.
Senator John F. Kennedy flew here yesterday and said that was happy with the progress of his campaign in New York City.

Most landlubbers have not encountered the name of Captain Billopp, but metropolitan area skippers of power cruisers, especially those plying the hobby of predicted-log contests, are well acquainted with one of yachting's patron saints.
QUEBEC, Aug. 11 -- The second stage of the MG Car Club's 1,000-mile rally -- a 337-mile, 8-hour 15-minute run from Concord, N.H. -- ended today.
Two school officials, one from New York City and the other from Monrovia, Liberia, met here yesterday and discovered that they were both confronted with about the same educational problems.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Durban Chief of New Zealand today became the seventh foreign entry in the International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway. Five other foreign horses arrived at the track today for the $50,000 event a week from Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- More textile apparel industry witnesses today urged the United States Government to oppose any reductions in textile tariffs at next year's meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

Indian Head Mills, Inc., has entered into an agreement to purchase all the plants and inventories of the Bachmann Uxbridge division of the Amerace Corporation. The multimillion-dollar transaction would be made by a subsidiary of Indian Head.
Penalty premium charges up to 100 per cent for "bad risks" in the automobile Assigned Risk Plan were approved yesterday by the State Superintendent of Insurance.

POINT MUGU, Calif., Aug. 11 (AP) -- A Navy frogman jumped from a hovering helicopter into the sea 330 miles northwest of Honolulu today -- and became the first man in history to touch a man-made object brought back from an orbit in space.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 11 -- Britain and West Germany agreed today to seek a compromise formula to restore the economic unity of Western Europe.

The four-story store and loft building at 862 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), near Thirtieth Street, has Been purchased by a client of Walter Scott Co., brokers. The buyer owns several adjoining properties. Cohen-Hennig Associates were the brokers in the latest purchase, which was made for cash over mortgages amounting to 35,000.

The Universal Match' Corporation of St. Louis, in a further expansion move, plans to acquire the Glasco Corporation Muncie, Ind., vending machine manufacturer. It was learned yesterday that the transaction would involve more than the $3,973,464 at which Glasco's assets are valued.

Color television has been a long, long time getting off the ground -- and there have been many who have wondered if it ever would. The Radio Corporation of America, which has consistently pushed color TV through the medium of its National Broadcasting Company subsidiary, has no such qualms.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The White House disclosed today that Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, planned to retire. It added that no date had been set.

The construction of a sea-level canal across the Isthmus of Darien in Panama, about 100 miles east of the present lock canal, has been proposed as part of a long-term "solution" to Panama Canal problems.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Sandy Koufax, the Los Angeles Dodger southpaw, shut out the Cincinnati Reds tonight with two hits, 3 -- 0. He struck out thirteen.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- A United Nations spokesman said today that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold had arrrived in Leopoldville, the Congo. He will lead a United Nations force into secessionist Katanga Province tomorrow.

Fred H.Hill, realty investor, announced yesterday that he had contracted to resell the West Side buildings formerly occupied by the De La Salle Institute. The buyer, the Baldwin School of New York, will renovate and occupy the property for junior and senior high school classes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Two Soviet Army colonels in civilian dress walked into a hotel lobby here this week, spent a dollar apiece and picked up reams of reports, pictures and diagrams of the latest United States Army, weapons.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved 1 to 15 points (5 cents to 75 cents a bale) up to a bid reflecting a 7-point drop in the July.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Stan Musial's two-run homer in the twelfth inning powered the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight. Ernie Broglio beat Bob Friend in the pitching duel.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 11 -- president Moise Tshombe of Katani appealed to the world tonight to follow the United Nations' performance In his province with vigilance.
An American labor leader yesterday quoted Soviet Premier Khrushchev as having said that Senator John F. Kennedy "seemed to make sense."

GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- The Soviet Union agreed with the United States today that the projected world-wide control system to ban nuclear tests should be fully operational within six years after a treaty is effective.

Supermarkets are stepping up their advertising sharply, with manufacturers of food and non-food products planning more extensive national and local tie-in advertising. In a driver to retain earnings levels they are scheduling increased efforts to run at least through the year-end.
BEGINNING today and continuing through Sunday, the Greater New York Bridge Association will conduct a Sidney S. Lenz Memorial Tournament at the Statler Hilton Hotel.
POINT O' WOODS, L.I. Aug. 11 -- The preservation of Sunken Forest, an unusual seventy-five-acre sylvan tract along the Fire Island beaches near here, will be celebrated Saturday.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Windsor Castle defeated Snowman on the second jump-off today in the open jumper event of the Sussex County horse show. The bay gelding, owned by W.R. (Bob) Ballard of Toronto, had no faults in the jump-off.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Premier Lumumba tightened security here with rifle-carrying Congolese police and soldiers today, the eve of the United Nations entrance into the secessionist province of Katanga.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Rip Repulski hit a homer in the second inning and singled home another run in a three-run rally in the third, that carried the Boston Red Sox to a 5-2 victory today over the faltering Cleveland Indians.
ALBANY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Five out of seven high-school graduates seeking to enter colleges of the New York State University this fall will be rejected because of a lack of room.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia, chairman of the Senate committee studying such measures, declared his opposition today to any broad new system of medical care for the aged similar to those urged by his party's Presidential ticket.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 11 -- Premier Gaston Eyskens will ask Parliament for a vote of confidence on his Government's policy in the Congo.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Air Force, after months of frustrating failure, succeeded today in returning and recovering the first payload from orbit in space.
Young hoodlums being trained in crime at a Brooklyn gangland school were forbidden to drink heavily or use narcotics, the police reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- A new Center for Research in Security Prices was set up at the University of Chicago today with $50,000 from Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the nation's largest investment house.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Giants snapped a six-game losing streak with a fourteen-hit attack tonight that downed the Milwaukee Braves, 8 -- 7.
Adverse conditions in a number of its best markets resulted in a drop in sales and earnings in the year ended on July 2, Libby, McNeill Libby, Chicago food processing company, reported yesterday.
Steels, drugs, airlines and a dozen or so specialties led the stock market yesterday in a session marked by moderate gains.

Standard-Toch Industries, Inc., manufacturer of paints, varnishes and industrial finishes, with headquarters in Philadelphia, has purchased the Congoleum-Nairn property on Passaic Avenue in Kearny, N.J. Foody Co. of Hackensack were the brokers.

SARAGOTA SPRINGS, Aug. 11 -- Under the sharp handling of Tommy Walsh, F. Eugene Dixon's Cartagena jumped an eight-length victory in the $11,600 North American Steeplechase Handicap today Walsh had to be sharp to win the race, for there was an unscheduled obstacle that required great care to circumvent.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 11 -- Two former officials of the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation were sued today for $3,302,975. The sum represented funds allegedly diverted from the contributions to the foundation from 1951 to 1959.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Olive W. Powers arrived here from New York tonight en route to Moscow, where he will attend the espionage trial of hia son Francis Gary Powers.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- A wildcat seamen's strike prevented the 81,237-ton Queen Mary from sailing from Southampton today for Cherbourg and New York.
DETROIT, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The home-run-happy Baltimore Orioles stretched their winning streak to six games today by routing the Detroit Tigers, 6-1, behind the steady hurling of Jack Fisher.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The New Frontier is co-cd.
SECURITIES, automobiles, even dogs and cats are registered these days. And now so are men's shirts, reports United Press International.
Aviation's "golden triangle," the area in which about a third of the nation's air passenger travel originates and a fourth of all private flights, will get a new telephone service next week.
The Long Island Rail Road asked the Public Service Commission yesterday to approve a new fare schedule, effective Aug. 24, that would cost passengers about 5 cents more for each ride.

This may be the age of space science, but a prominent naturalist said yesterday that there was still plenty of flora and fauna to be explored right here on earth. And he added that if he had it to do over again he'd stick with earth, and happily.

A housewife who got tired of searching for an apartment her family could afford has come up with a solution -- a $38,000,000 cooperative apartment development that would house 2,500 families in Greenwich Village.
GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- Western nuclear diplomacy is frozen in Geneva. It will remain so until a struggle is resolved in Washington.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Once again the New York Central has asked for a fare increase -- the second one in six months. Apparently they aren't happy with one a year.
PAJU, Korea, Aug. 11 -- All indications are for a bumper rice crop this season, but the farmers of the Republic of Korea will be complaining bitterly.

THE story of Barbara Gay Moore Powers was much like that of any woman married to a flier -- until 5:30 o'clock in the morning on May 2. Friends of Francis Gary Powers, the U-2 pilot to be tried soon by the Soviet Union for spying, awakened her in the trailer where she lived with her husband near the airfield outside Adana, Turkey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Soviet Embassy cleared the way today for Mrs. Francis Gary Powers to go to Moscow for her husband's espionage trial in the company of her mother, her physician and two lawyer-consultants.
PORT SAID., United Arab Republic, Aug. 11 -- An African army is to be formed under the United Arab Republic's supreme command, it was reported here today.

LONDON. FURNITURE prices in England, as elsewhere, have been at an unprecedented height. The two top auction room Christie's and Sotheby's, are challenging their own records. Their summer auctions have brought some of the highest prices ever paid.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Republicans and Southern Democrats in the Senate opened an attack today on Senator John F. Kennedy's bill to liberalize the Wage-Hour Law.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Harmon Killebrew hit his sixteenth and seventeenth home runs and accounted for all of the Washington Senators' runs today in a 5-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 11 -- The village of Old Westbury was criticized for Its "provincialism" yesterday ond was ordered to allow Hofstra College to build an experimental branch in the community.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug 11 (AP) -- A Federal judge struck down a state court injunction today and ordered voter registration records in Montgomery County turned over to Federal agents.

A city-owned tenement in which six persons were injured in a fire Saturday had been described as a firetrap in February in a Fire Department report to the Department of Buildings, it was disclosed yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of using tourists as espionage agents and announced it was expelling tourist immediately on spy charges.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City fell $50,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the 1959 week they were up $13,000,000.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Passing will spark the attacks at Soldier Field tomorrow night when the College All-Stars meet the Baltimore Colts, the Champions of the National Football League.

The name of the author of "Nassau Street: A Quarter Century of Stamp Dealing" appeared incorrectly in this space on Wednesday. The author is Herman Herst Jr., a leading stamp dealer, collector and writer. His book will be published Aug. 26 by Duell, Sloan Pearce.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Federal Reserve System, observing a continued relaxation of inflationary pressures, made another move toward "easier money'' today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter gave the Senate Foreign Relations Committee a preliminary outline today of a Latin-American aid plan aimed at "acceleration of social development, and thereby of economic growth."
Commodity futures prices generally declined on New York exchanges yesterday in mostly dull trading.
THE Great Chum Derby, or United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament, will open at Point Judith, R.I., next Wednesday morning and continue for three spectacular days.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- An emergency airlift started tonight to fly home more than 2,000 American tourists stranded by a growing strike of British seamen.
THE merger fever, which has gripped the nation's airlines, railroads and publishing houses this summer, has spread to two Park Avenue flower shops.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, at Southampton, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A thousand stranded passengers, most of them Americans, paced the decks of the strike-bound Queen Mary tonight while Cunard officials organized an airlift to get them home.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today ordered a prehearing conference on Sept. 15 on the merger agreement reached by United Air Lines and Capital Airlines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets for the week ended last Tuesday were unchanged at 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
NEWARK, Aug. 12 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which serves four-fifths of the population of New Jersey, was granted a $10,163,000-a-year rate-increase today.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Industrial share prices bounded ahead in the stock market here today raising The Financial Times index 5.4 points to 329.4. The index has risen for ten consecutive sessions and shows a gain of 13.6 points for the latest week.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The leg of a defunct railroad here has been converted by Westchester County into a twolane highway to be opened next month.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Charlie Maxwell blasted a pair of two-run homers -- the second coming in the tenth inning -- and led the Detroit Tigers to a 6-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

YONKERS, Aug. 12 -- Mrs. Irving Kaufmann of Century and Jack Creavy of Pelham carded a 38, 34 -- 72 at the Hudson River Country Club today and won the Women's Tri-County Golf Association's Lucy Foreman Trophy by one stroke.
Society's obsession with sex has produced little in the way of enlightenment and much in the way of confusion, a book publication of the United Lutheran Church in America declares.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 12 -- The final week-end of the Berkshire Music Festival also brought with it the first touch of autumn. There was a decided chill in the air for tonight's concert, and many women wrapped themselves in sweaters or coats.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- Johnny Unitas and Lenny Moore served notice to the other twelve National Football League teams tonight that the Baltimore Colts are again the team to beat.
YESTERDAY (Aug. 12, 1960) THE PRESIDENT At Camp David for the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The president of the Georgia Automobile Dealers Association has invented a mechanical listener. The sound of the human voice causes its eyes to light up and its eyelids to flutter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that the Cornucopia Gold Mines registration be with-drawn from the American Stock Exchange "for the protection of investors."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Administration, despite increasing impatience over the lack of progress toward a prohibition of tests of nuclear weapons, decided today against making any precipitate move that might break up the negotiations in Geneva.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Britain moved quickly today toward implementing the agreement by Prime Minister Macmillan and Chancellor Adenauer to seek economic unity for Western Europe.

Lionel Rogosin, producer-director of the controversial "Come Back, Africa," will leave in October on a three-month tour of Europe and Asia to prepare his third independent feature, a three-hour semi-documentary on world peace movements.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 12 -- Katanga Province accepted United Nations troops today with a last gesture of defiance. Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold refused to change his plans, however.

The New Haven Clock and Watch Company, maker of electronics equipment, is planning to expand its real-estate activities through the acquisition of Hubbard Estates, Inc., and four affiliated companies.

Robert F. Kennedy, manage of the Presidential campaign for his brother, Senator John F Kennedy, conferred briefly yesterday with Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, at the Biltmore Hotel.
WALNUT, Calif., Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Ralph Boston of Tennessee A. and I. broad jumped 26 feet 11 1/4 inches tonight and broke Jesse Owens' 25-year-old world record, the oldest mark in track.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 12 -- An angry woman sculptor whose prize-winning work was repaired without her knowledge has resigned from the Silvermine Guild of Artists here.
Stocks added about $2,250, 000,000 to aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, responding vigorously to the Federal Reserve's latest reduction in lending (discount) rates.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold assured the Security Council and the leaders of the Congo today that the United Nations force there would maintain a completely neutral role in the new republic's internal quarrels.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The second-place St. Louis Cardinals crushed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9 -- 2, tonight and cut the Pirates, National League lead to three games.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 -- Another American student on tour in the Soviet Union has been accused of hostile and provocative activities and has been ordered to leave the country, the Moscow press reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today times and places at which the Echo I satellite should be visible in the United States as a bright star tomorrow.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Three Chrysler Corporation stockholders filed a petition in Chancery Court today asking for a receivership for the multimillion-dollar automotive company.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 12 -- Officials of West Germany said today that Mr. Macmillan and Dr. Adenauer had brought the free nations of Europe closer "than ever before."
THURMONT, Md., Aug. 12 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's helicopter landed on a baseball field today when bad weather closed in on Camp David, where he plans to spend the week-end.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 12 -- A United States attorney who served on the prosecuting staff at the Nuremberg" war crimes trials has been invited to assist the Israeli Attorney General in the case of Adolf Eichmann.

Religious leaders who recently visited facilities of the United Service Organizations overseas urged yesterday that the public give increased support to the organization to help protect the moral standards of young men in the armed forces.
At 12:05 P.M. yesterday workmen removed barriers from the Long Island Expressway at its interchange with the Clearview Expressway.

A Modern Revolution One of the great social revolutions of modern times is now upon us. It is the growth of suburbia. With the rise of this modern concept of living, the breadwinner finds himself in the throes of an age-old dilemma: how to get to work in the morning while still leaving the family car behind for his wife to do her shopping.
Old-Timers' Day, an annual feature here since 1946, will highlight activities before some 40,000 fans at the Yankee Stadium today.

With the menace of new Communist moves against the free world hanging over their heads while the United States is engaged in a Presidential election campaign, the principal statesmen of Western Europe have launched a new drive for European unity in which hitherto aloof Britain has now joined.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 -- The thirty - first annual summer tournament of the American Contract Bridge League, always the biggest bridge tournament of the year throughout the world, will begin here today and will continue through Aug. 23.

"Economic Atlas of the Soviet Union," said to be the first to deal with Russia as an economic structure of several regions, will be published Sept. 15 by the University of Michigan Press. HAVANA, Aug. 12 -- Cuba acted today to tighten exit regulations for residents who seek to leave the island.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- A rookie first baseman, Gordon Coleman, singled home Frank Robinson for the Cincinnati Reds' winning run in the eighth inning in a two-run rally tonight that beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3 -- 2.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 12 -- Bailey Brown of Bronxville, N. Y., and Jan Hajer of the Netherlands gained the junior division final of the metropolitan junior and boys' tennis championships today at the Cherry Valley Club.

A 21-year-old part-time male model, accused of jilting his financee and holding up a Brooklyn shoemaker, landed in jail yesterday on the latter charge.
JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 12 -- Sub-par golf enabled Bob Gardner, the 1958 titleholder, to gain the semi-final round of the Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur championship today.
The most luxurious and lethal destroyer-leader of the United States Navy steamed into New, York harbor yesterday afternoon to a welcome befitting a battleship.
Leaders in the fields of medicine, journalism, entertainment and government will be honored by the New York Philanthropic League for their aid to the handicapped.
The Air Force capsule' retrieved from orbit on Thursday was scheduled to be flown to Washington on Saturday for a round of ceremonies that probably will end at the White House on Monday.
ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Rockefeller administration said today its highway program remained at a record $1,000,000,000 level and it planned no cutbacks.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa awarded yesterday $65,000,000 of New York City tax anticipation notes to eighteen banks and trust companies.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Aug. 12 -- Five men, one, of them a Suffolk County, police sergeant, were charged today with having conducted a burglary and stolen-goods operation.

"Sunset Boulevard,'' the film about a silent-movie queen living in a world of past glory, is being planned as a Broadway musical by the producing team of Robert E. Griffith and Harold S. Prince.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J, Aug. 12 -- For the most part form held up today in the men's quarter-final matches of the thirty-fourth annual Eastern grass-court tennis championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Ron Hansen's lead-off homer in the ninth inning lifted the Baltimore Orioles to a 4-3 victory over the Boston Red Sax tonight and extended their winning streak to seven games.

Prices for cotton futures or the New York Cotton Exchange moved within a narrow range in quiet trading yesterday. Final prices were 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 14 points (70 cents) up, the latter on a bid for the July, 1961, delivery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today announced it would seek a Supreme Court ruling that the President may prescribe import duties different from those recommended by the Tariff Commission.
ROME, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Plans for a United States airlift to the Olympic rowing site at Lake Albano were greeted, coldly today by Italian officials.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Republicans continued today to block action on a bill to relax picketing controls over the building trades unions. Such a bill had been promised by both parties.

Drug stores, faced with the rapid growth of competition from supermarkets and other sources, are getting bigger, and more diversified, and are using new and improved merchandising methods.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The prospect of major farm legislation at this Congressional session virtually disappeared today.

TORONTO, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs beat the Jersey City Jerseys, 1-0 and 6-1, tonight behind Bob (Riverboat) Smith and Al Cicotte. They set an International League modern record for shutouts.

Parents of some Negro and Puerto Rican junior high school students here may be permitted to send their children to integrated schools outside their neighborhoods. The program is under consideration to further integration and improve school utilization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- An examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission said today that some rail roads had gone too far in of faring novel types of "piggyback" freight service -- involving the hauling of highway trailers on fiat cars.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- A jury of six men and six women, convicted Morgan D. Ryan today of bribing highway officials in Ulster County in the sale of road oil.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Traces of a sleep-inducing drug have been found in blood tests on two little girls whose recurrent comas had puzzled doctors for several months, authorities reported today.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Lyn Cunningham, 15-year-old daughter of the noted yachtsman Briggs Cunningham, captured the Long Island Sound girls' sailing championship today and kept the Founders' Trophy at the Pequot Yacht Club for another year.

THE expense-account society of the old Northwest fur traders was primitive by modern standards, I suppose, but often surprisingly effective. Gentry of the big pelt companies gave the Indians rum, tobacco, beads, scalping knives and such. In return they got beaver fur to make hats for the stylish status-seekers of Paris, London and New York.

An adjournment of Congress before passage of a measure to increase the number of judges on the Federal bench would be an inexcusable dereliction of duty. The record of Congressional inaction to date on this desperately needed legislation would be unbelievable, except that it happens to be true.

Drivers in New York State's Assigned Risk Plan who have gone through a disabling illness or who have been involved in several minor accidents may have to pass driving tests again to keep their licenses, under revisions of the plan effective Oct. 1.

GENOA -- If Hercules were around today, he would cheer at the news that a new extension of the Italian Riviera autostrada is to be opened to traffic this month. Powerful as he was, Hercules ran into trouble navigating the rugged Ligurian coastline on his return from the Garden of the Hesperides.

MONTREAL, Aug. 13 -- The recent appointment of Josaphat Brunet, a retired Royal Canadian Mounted Police officer, to head the Quebec provincial police force marked an unofficial declaration of war by the new Liberal Government on the lawlessness that has been flourishing in the province.

LONDON, Aug. 13 -- It appeared tonight that the wildcat walkout would continue at least until Tuesday, when leaders of the rebel unionist group, which calls itself the Seamen's Reform Movement, have called for mass meetings of striking seamen.

MAICAO, Colombia -- This sand-choked town at the edge of Colombia's Guajira desert does not cover much acreage, but it is one of the world's busiest smuggling centers and the home of one of Latin America's few remaihing pure Indian cultures.

THE 1956 election involved an incident unprecedented in the nation's history: a person of Asian birth -- ineligible a decade before even to become a citizen -- as elected to Congress. A $25,000,000 construction program for high-rise apartments in Manhattan and one-family homes on Long Island has been started by a large real-estate development corporation recently formed through the consolidation of fourteen diversified firms.

THE thirteenth annual American Dance Festival, under the auspices of Connecticut College, will take place next week-end in Palmer Auditorium, on the campus at New London. Its five performances will be on Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings at 8:30 and Saturday and Sunday afternoons at 3.

PORTLAND, Me. -- As vacation country, Maine has almost everything a tourist could want -- sandy beaches, rugged seacoast, silent forests, picturesque lakes and rivers and even an impressive mountain peak, Katahdin, where the Appalachin Trail starts southward for Georgia.

BERNARD Berenson died on Oct. 7, 1959, at the age of 94. He was a many-faceted, complex and fascinating gentleman -- art historian, critic, scholar, connoisseur, expert, taste-maker, writer, philosopher, letter-writer, conversationalist -- above all, a man whose life was shaped by a coherent set of values whereby he hoped to make living itself a work of art.
CLIFTON HEIGHTS, Pa., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Charles H. Elliott, New Jersey State Commissioner of Education from 1927 to 1943, died today at a nursing home after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

THE survivors of the British engagement with the German at Mons are old and few. They are old because the battle lies forty-six years behind us; few because, apart from the natural processes of time, the British Expeditionary Force was mown as with a scythe before the year 1914 was out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Proud Air Force officers displayed briefly today the first man-made object ever placed in orbit around the earth and then recovered. The instrument capsule of the Discoverer XIII satellite, picked up...
HARTFORD, Aug. 13 -- Connecticut is making preparations to abolish its historic county governments on Oct. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (AP) -- John Quinn, the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, said today he had written the baseball commissioner, Ford Frick to pass along a judge's allegation that visiting players had borrowed money from a convicted gambler.
The search for the former owner of a building in which six persons were injured in a fire a week ago led yesterday to a former clerk in the city's old Bureau of Real Estate.

A year ago the 200 boys and girls of varying national and racial origins gathered on the East Harlem ball field could only have been fighting. But yesterday they were able to compete peaceably and to have a day of fun besides in the first East Harlem Olympics.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is my conviction that the Presidential race will be hard-fought and close. THE summer music season in North America has grown up rather like a country cousin that the rest of the family has been unwilling to recognize. It has grown, too, with very little planning as to its development and virtually no supervision.

OPORTO, Portugal, Aug. 13 -- The Grand Prix of Portugal, counting toward the drivers' world championship, will be raced here tomorrow over a 4.6-mile, 110-mile-an-hour circuit on the northern edge of the city.

Nearly a thousand vacation-bound passengers were delayed overnight here by a sudden strike yesterday of crews on the Furness-Bermuda Line ships Queen of Bermuda and Ocean Monarch. They hoped to get started today.
MANILA, Aug 2 -- Negotiations are being conducted for the surrender of the Philippines' top Communist, Dr. Jesus Lava, Defense Secretary Alejo Santos has disclosed.

He declared that it would lessen tensions built up by military alliances, decrease the expenditures for armaments and leave less room for "unintended war."

Fur-trimmed coats and sportswear, along with back-to-school merchandise, shared the spotlight in the fall apparel market last week, according to reports from resident buying offices. WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- There is little similarity between President Eisenhower and Harry S. Truman. Nevertheless, as Congress returned to Washington this week, Mr. Eisenhower was sounding amazingly like his Democratic predecessor.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 13 -- With Cyprus heading in an uncertain mood for independence Tuesday, the police are taking every precaution to prevent violence.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 13 -- The Venezuelan delegation to the Organization of American States foreign ministers conference left for San Jose, Costa Rica, today. Foreign Minister Ignacio Luis Arcaya headed the delegation for the conference, which will begin Tuesday.

FOR THIS WEEK: Abundant rainfall encourages weeds; keep after them. . . . Protect perennial and biennial seedlings from strong sunlight with screening or lath. . . . WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Government geological experts have completed terrain studies of the moon for use by the Army in plans to establish bases there.

Prospects for President Eisenhower's Latin-American aid program appear dim in the present short session of Congress. The program; which ordinarily might win praise as an inspiring advance in foreign-aid policy generally, has been bedeviled by poor timing and cynicism.

BOSTON -- Vacationists desiring to combine a sea excursion, an inspection of a Civil War fort and picnicking will be able to do so soon. Now being put into shape as New England's newest recreational and historical area is Fort Warren on Georges Island in Boston Harbor.

IT was that nineteenth-century wit Thomas Gold Appleton, who said, "Good Americans, when they die, go to Paris." A teen-age Temperance Queen elected in Bristol, England, returned her crown with the statement that she had partaken of alcoholic beverages "several times."

THE trial of Francis Gary Powers, the American pilot of the U-2 reconnaissance plane brought down deep in Russia on May 1, is to begin this Wednesday in Moscow. In all probability the proceedings will be a propaganda exercise the likes of which Moscow has not seen in years.

TO THE EDITOR: Senator Goldwater asks the question: "Why is there such widespread lack of public support for this [conservative] philosophy?" The real answer, it seems to me, is to be found in the defects of Senator Goldwater's philosophy of conservatism.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Jim Brosnan stopped the Dodgers in a relief role and then batted the Reds out of trouble in the eighth inning today to help produce a 6-2 victory over Los Angeles.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 13 -- This city's Dixwell Avenue section, largely populated by Negroes, is going to be redeveloped at a cost of more than $10,500,000 in public funds and millions more in private investments. This project will push the cost of New Haven's redevelopment program beyond $200,000,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs used home runs by Jerry Kindall and Ernie Banks today to defeat the Phillies, 4-2.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The Chicago and North Western Railway will construct a new infrared facility this fall to thaw iron ore. Fitzpatrick, the road's president, said this week.

THIS week in Washington's Lafayette Park, the leafy square across the street from the White House, there will be dedicated a "Bernard Baruch Bench of Inspiration."
