Helen Hayes has agreed to head an overseas repertory company that will perform three plays, representing "the best achievements of the American theatre." The venture, which is part of the President's Special International Program for Cultural Presentations, will travel under the combined auspices of the State Department and the American National Theatre and Academy.

As the new communications satellite swept around the earth about every two hours, the Very Rev. Dr. Lloyd R. Gillmett stressed the need yesterday for man to communicate God's word by an older method -- personal evangelism.
The term "juvenile delinquency" should be eliminated in charging children with offenses against the law, a group studying the Children's and Adolescent Courts recommended yesterday.
This has been a terrible summer for Con Edison, air-conditioner salesmen and Good Humor venders.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 14 -- Four Deputies of the National Assembly left here by plane for Luang Prabang today to report to King Savang Vathana an Assembly vote of no confidence in the Government of Premier Tiao Samsonith.
Yardley of London, Inc., makers of cosmetics and men's toiletries, have announced the start of construction of a $3,000,000 plant in Totowa, N.J.
ROME, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The first United States Olympic plane arrived today carrying a band of talented swimmers hopeful of ending Australia's domination in that sport in the games starting Aug. 25.
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- The airlift to the United States and Canada of passengers stranded here by the wildcat strike of seamen continued today.

THE news department of the National Broadcasting Company continues to demonstrate a laudable sense of responsibility in its coverage of the personalities and events involved in the coming Presidential election.
The Committee of American Steamship Lines, which is going around the country telling the states what the shipping business means to them, has issued a study on Pennsylvania.
The Vick Chemical Company achieved record sales and earnings in its fiscal year ended on June 30, according to the preliminary report of Smith Richardson Jr., president, released today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 14 -- The leading boat this week-end in the Yacht Racing Association competition on Western Long Island Sound was David Meinertz' Finesse, a 110. As a double winner in light air, Finesse beat twenty-four rivals.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 14 -- Souther Whittelsey, with Interlude in the Luders-16 Class, and Donald McClave, with his 110 Class sloop, Derboten, won for the second day in a row today at the Eastern Division of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association regatta.
THE camp season is drawing to a close. Before this month is over, thousands of youngsters, tanned of body and older in experience, will be united with the families they left behind.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 -- Several milestones were passed as the Berkshire Music Festival came to an end this afternoon. It marked the completion of twenty-five years since the Boston Symphony first participated, the tenth year under the direction of Charles Munch and the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the Berkshire Music Center.

Fred Coe, producer, and Arthur Penn, director, are expected to co-produce four special television dramas for the American Broadcasting Company during the 1960-61 season. Mr. Penn also would direct one of the shows, two of which may be taped in London.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 14 -- The discovery of Africa by Africans is one of the most important by-products of the United Nations' intervention in the Congo.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 14 -- Within seconds of his arrival here today for an emergency conference of hemisphere foreign ministers, Dr. Raul Roa of Cuba moved to dash the remaining hopes of his colleagues for a compromise to resolve the crisis in the inter-American system.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Norman Olsen's Red Jacket, one of the new Annapolis-30 Class boats, today won the over-all honors in the thirteenth annual Port Washington Yacht Club's two-day cruise to Huntington Bay and return.

There was a large element of chance in the circumstances that led Philip H. Radel, former United States Olympic wrestler, into the importing business. But it is with considerable design that the six-foot-six New Yorker is working to make the move successful.

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 14 -- The Quincy Challenge Cup for Star Class boats was won today by Joseph Duplin of Cottage Park, Mass. Mead Batchelor of Milford, Conn., was second in the point score and Robert Kirkland, also of Cottage Park, was third.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 14 -- The youngster who gets everything he wants was cited today as an example of what was called the nation's overemphasis on materialism.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Los Angeles turned back Cincinnati, 9 -- 5, in the second game of a double-header today after the Reds had won the opener, 2 -- 0.
The trial of U-2 pilot Francis Gary Powers is scheduled to open Wednesday and already it is clear that the Soviet Government intends to make it one of the great show trials of the century.
OPORTO, Portugal, Aug. 14 -- Smoothly, neatly and without any drama whatsoever, Jack Brabham won the Grand Prix of Portugal here today -- and with it his second straight world driving championship.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 -- Raymond Weinstein recorded a major upset today in the sixth round of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Sheraton-Jefferson.

AMERICANS are known for being well dressed. There is no excuse not to be -- stores and shop windows are filled with the latest fashions and hundreds of magazines offer advice. New fibers continuously are being introduced that eliminate wrinkles, ward off dirt and resist stains, and excellent dry-cleaning methods have kept pace with new developments in fabrics.
A labor union president recently returned from the Soviet Union said last night that Premier Khrushchev dislikes both American Presidential candidates.
Robert Moses charged yesterday that "unreasonable farmers and vituperative politicians" in Oneida County were trying to block completion of the Niagara Power project.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Organized labor served notice today on Congress that it would accept nothing less than a program of medical insurance for the aged under Social Security before adjournment.

IF the National League has its problems with the Pirates and the Cardinals clut- tering up the head of the tracks when, by all pre-season reckoning, they should be plodding at the other end of the line, the American League is being jarred by a couple of stunning surprises too.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: For some time I have been following with attention and sympathy the correct position sustained by your newspaper in Latin-American affairs. Your editorials in difficult times have served as support in the struggle for freedom and democracy by many countries of this continent.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 14 -- In the face of exasperated, occasionally worried criticism from other nations of Europe, the Deutsche Bundesbank here is sticking firmly by a severe tight money policy that has helped build a huge surplus in the West German balance of payments this year.
ALBANY, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Law school professors are the highest paid of all groups of college professors in New York State, the State Education Department reported today.

Some Have, and Some Haven't Our world now, hereabouts, is still divided into two parts: on the one hand, the people who already have taken their vacations and have nothing much to look forward to until Christmas and, on the other, those who have not had their vacations and who are, as August drags on its steamy way, obviously in a highly enviable, even superior, position.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Army will receive a refund of $10,000,000 from the Martin Company of Baltimore because, military officials said, unexpected savings were achieved in the manufacture of the Missile Master.

HONG KONG, Aug. 14 -- Judge William C. Walsh of Maryland said today that his brother, Bishop James E. Walsh, appeared to be in good health and spirits last week after twenty-two months' imprisonment in Communist China.

The Washington Senators sent two Yankees to the hospital and the others to third place while twice upsetting Casey Stengel's Bombers at the Stadium yesterday. By winning, 5 -- 4 and 6 -- 3 -- the second game in fifteen innings -- Cookie Lavagetto's Nats gained a first-division berth in the American League.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 14 -- Soviet experts working in Communist China are returning home, according to the Yugoslav newspaper Borba.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Eddie Mathews hit a three-run homer off Sam Jones in the first inning and Lew Burdette blanked the San Francisco Giants on five hits as the Milwaukee Braves scored a 3-0 triumph before 32,381 fans today.
Law enforcement officials and youth authorities moved yesterday to head off further outbreaks of juvenile violence here.
KYRENIA, Cyprus, Aug. 14 -- There is still no perceptible sense of nationalism in Cyprus, which becomes independent at midnight tomorrow.
The moral climate of the city has disintegrated to a new low ebb because of laxity in the home and the community, three prominent clergymen asserted yesterday.
Roman Catholics in Cuba "are at this moment in danger of having the Iron Curtain fall on their tiny nation," the Rev. Bernard P. Donachie said yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Shore-area sailors won six of the class championships as the twelfth annual National Sweepstakes sailing regatta came to an end on the Navesink River today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- The Chicago Cubs moved out of the National League cellar today when two 20-year-olds paced them to a 2-1 and 7-3 sweep of their double-header with the Philadelphia Phillies.
LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Last week was one of the best the stock market has enjoyed in some months.
The resignation of Ralph J. De Meo as the city's director of purchase was announced yesterday by Roger J. Browne, Acting Commissioner of Purchase.
The Citizens Budget Commission suggested yesterday two emergency steps by which the city could free the bonds for its costly program of water-pollution control from the municipal debt limit.

A lease for 16,000 square feet of space in the eleven-story building at 636 Eleventh Avenue, between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, has been signed by Practical Offset Service, Inc. The George Comfort Company and Henry Baker were the brokers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Two Liberal Democratic Senators predicted today a Senate fight this week over the minimum wage issue and medical care for the aged.
The Air Force plans to test a method for relaying radio messages by means of a reflecting belt made up of billions of tiny metal antennas swarming in orbit around the earth.

Governor Rockefeller's fiscal policies are certain to become a major issue in the campaign this fall for the fifty-eight seats in the State Senate and the 150 in the Assembly. The voter reaction to the issue conceivably could have an impact on the prospects of the Presidential candidates, and, in a close election, be decisive.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The forthcoming reconvening of the United Nations Disarmament Commission raises the question which, under the present circumstances, are the most promising steps to take toward world peace. Real progress can be made only if we learn from the failures of the past.
GENEVA, Aug. 14 -- The Swiss stock markets had a boom during the last week that sent the principal Swiss bank and chemical issues to new highs for the year.

The Federal Reserve Board has just authorized the second reduction in rediscount rates in a little over two months. In June these rates were cut from 4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent; the new cut brings the rate down to 3 per cent. Only four of the twelve regional reserve banks were immediately affected by last week's announced reduction.

TORONTO, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Herb Plews, a pinch hitter, singled in the first extra inning -- the eighth -- today and drove home the winning run as the Toronto Maple Leafs salvaged the second game of a double-header, 3 -- 2, after the Jersey City Jerseys had taken the nine-inning opener, 6 -- 1.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 -- Steel order volume in the last two weeks has been a disappointment to steelmakers. While there has been some improvement with many steel concerns, it has been far from what had been expected.
The task of convincing revenue agents that items on audited tax returns are reasonable and proper should be a little less forbidding in the future.

ONE of the most extraordinary women in the world of food is Elena Zelayeta. She is a motherly woman, and probably the most concise description of her was written by Helen Evans Brown in the preface to "Elena's Secrets of Mexican Cooking" (Prentice-Hall, 1958).
Week Ended Aug. 12, 1960 British pound sterling and Canadian dollar were strong and active in foreign exchange dealings during the past week.
The increased use of flight simulators and other training aids may be the answer -- or a partial one -- to the current issue of Federal-vs.-commercial airlift.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Personal income rose to record levels last year in all but three states, the Commerce "Department's Office of Business Economics reported today.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 14 -- The Belgian Army bade an emotional farewell to this capital of Katanga today and turned over control of of city to Swedish troops of the United Nations.
JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Bob Gardner, a 39-year-old California-born player, regained the amateur championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association today.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 14 -- The Amsterdam Bourse closed the week with an over-all firm tendency. The major factor was the bank rate reduction in the United States. Some brokers were of the opinion that Britain would follow this example next week.
"The man from Madison Avenue may have his faults. But he turns out to be an astonishingly decent fellow and a better citizen of his country than most of the brickbat-throwers."
On opposite sides of the nation stand two houses, one of which will become an American shrine as the birthplace of the man elected President on Nov. 8, 1960.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Lenny Lyles' 92-yard touchdown return of the opening kick-off plus the second-half passing of Y.A. Tittle crushed Washington, 31 -- 7, today as the San Francisco Forty-Niners opened their home exhibition season before a crowd of 13,163.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois was discomfited last week when the Democratic majority of the Senate voted to table his civil rights bill. Later the Republican leader was asked what he thought of the tabling process.

Russellville, Ky., has sold $2,450,000 of industrial building revenue bonds, due from 1962 to 1981, to an investment banking group headed by Graham-Conway Co. The group bid 97.26 with a 4 1/4 per cent coupon to set a net interest cost of 4.47725 per cent, reoffering the bonds at prices to yield from 3.10 to 4.50 per cent.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 -- In this second day of the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament, being played at the Ambassador Hotel here, the four-session pair contests for life masters and senior masters began this afternoon.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for a main dish that is easy to prepare.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates took a six-game grip on first place in the National League today by beating the second-place St. Louis Cardinals, 9 -- 4 and 3 -- 2.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Rocky Colavito hit his twenty-third homer in the opener and then connected for his twenty-fourth in the second game to help the Detroit Tigers sweep a double-header from the Cleveland Indians, 6 -- 1 and 3 -- 2, today.

"This is more than just a igood team. It's a great team!" That was Coach Larry Snyder's enthusiastic appraisal of the sixty-five man United States Olympic track and field squad, which settled down here yesterday for a four-day stay before taking off for the Games in Rome.
The New York Philharmonic will open its own season at the saved and newly decorated Carnegie Hall on Sept. 27.

"The houses to the very roofs were filled with spectators, and to the incessant cheers of the multitude, graceful females signified their welcome by the silent but not less grateful and affecting testimony of the waving of handkerchiefs."
EATON'S NECK, L.I., Aug. 14 -- More than half a million starfish were plucked today from the waters of Huntington Bay where they had been preying on succulent Long Island oysters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Top United States officials are optimistic about prospects for mitigating the effects of the economic breach in Europe.

Joshua Chamberlain, Union general and four times Governor of Maine, is the subject of a biography by Willard M. Wallace. It is called "Soul of the Lion." Chamberlain, as commander of the Twentieth Infantry Regiment of Maine Volunteers, is credited with saving the day for the Federal forces at Gettysburg on July 2, 1863, by attacking from Little Round Top in the face of overwhelming Confederate odds.

Scudder Fund Distributors, Inc., announced last week the filing of a revised prospectus with the Securities and Exchange Commission that would make the company sole distributor for shares of Scudder Fund of Canada, Ltd.
Five Brookryn teen-agers were held yesterday for allegedly seizing an 18-year-old Queens youth and beating him with their fists and torn-off car aerials.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The Congo's badly disrupted health services are compelling the United Nations to recruit hundreds of foreign experts to restore adequate medical care, authorities of the World Health Organization said today.

SACRAMENTO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Oakland Raiders scored twice in the final period to overcome a half-time deficit and defeat the New York Titans, 23 -- 17, last night in an exhibition game between American Football League teams.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $76,878,202,724. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
A satellite in orbit was plugged into the nation's land telephone system early this morning for the first time.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 14 -- A plan for a merger of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists has been rejected by a large majority of the guild's membership.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- A great American tradition died with Will Rogers, according to Walter Blair, of the University of Chicago.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- The president-elect of the American Medical Association said today that most persons over the age of 65 did not want a Government program of health care.

The drastic revision of operating rules for the New York Automobile Assigned Risk Plan announced by the State Superintendent of Insurance, Thomas Thacher, should have several beneficial results. It should somewhat discourage companies from dumping policyholders into the assigned risk pool for inadequate reason, and help the deserving to get out of the pool sooner.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 14 -- Donald Browning steered Vayu across the finish line sixteen seconds in front of Howard Seymour's Mutiny and won Resolute Class honors in today's interclub sailing on Manhasset Bay.

The stanch backers of mutual funds are beginning to get more than a little fed up with critics who sit back and say "I told you so. Those mutual funds are no good. They'll fall, apart in prolonged down market."
The first delegation to go abroad bearing invitations to foreign governments to exhibit at the 1964 New York World's Fair left last night for Ankara, Turkey.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Rod Laver, the quiet red-haired southpaw from Australia, passed another milestone today in a drive he hopes will gain a sweep of the Eastern grass court tennis tournaments.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Senator John F. Kennedy cemented a political peace pact today with Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and pledged to finish the job for social betterment begun by her husband.

ASPEN, Colo This week's Powers trial in Moscow may provide an interesting test of the degree of Russian political reform since Stalin's death. It will be the first internationally advertised Soviet judicial process following the post-Stalin thaw.
Last week's rumors about the sale of the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre, 205 West Forty-sixth Street, to Cy Feuer and Ernest H. Martin, musical comedy producers, have proved to be correct.

THE Cameo Theatre has itself a tired flapdoodle of a picture in "Loves of a Greek in Paris." For reasons best Known to Evets Associates, the distributor, it was imported from Greece, (with English titles) and opened on Saturday.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox snapped the Baltimore Orioles' eight-game winning streak today with a 3-2 victory.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 14 -- Democratic leaders indicated tonight that there would be no attempt by the state party to withhold support from Senator John F. Kennedy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) -- Combining twenty-six hits with route-going pitching performances by Billy Pierce and Early Wynn, the Chicago White Sox beat Kansas City, 9 -- 3 and 7 -- 2, today for a sweep of their four-game series.

Warnings are being sounded in the Soviet Union about the growing problem of technological unemployment. The problem already is causing serious concern in Soviet industry and could become massive in Soviet agriculture, a leading Soviet economist has declared.
Little happened on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume fell to the smallest figure since Aug. 2, more stocks rose than fell and the market averages and indexes closed almost unchanged.

Rockefeller Center yesterday became a partner in two of New York's biggest current, building ventures -- a forty-two-story office building and a thirty-eight-story hotel on the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue).

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 15 -- A band of men who say they are supporters of Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba is living in a state of siege in a house in the center of the working-class district of Consuelo in this capital city.

Even though the stock market has been in the doldrums this spring and summer, dividends have been on the rise. The New York Stock Exchange has added up the payments and announced yesterday that its listed corporations paid out a record $4,804,019,630 in the first half of this year.

Almost two months have passed since Mayor Wagner suspended his Commissioner of Purchase, Joseph V. Spagna, who had been in office almost from the beginning of the first term of the Wagner administration. The Mayor seems to be having difficulty in making up his mind whether to restore Mr. Spagna to his commissionership.

New York University acceded yesterday to demands for separate Graduate School Social Work.
The city is negotiating with T. J. Stevenson Co., Inc., for an amount "substantially in excess" of $176,000 in a settlement involving cheating on rock salt deliveries.

The biggest trend in cosmetics and drugs is toward a marriage of the two. Several cosmetics concerns, after careful experimenting with a cautious toe in the murky waters of government legislation and Federal, state and municipal regulations, have found that the medical approach, handled just so, can be made to sell.

A couple of significant developments concerning the future of "Hail the Conquering Hero" became apparent yesterday. The ANTA Theatre will receive Robert Whitehead's musical entertainment on Jan. 5, 1961.

The Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company were the brokers for two recent real estate deals in the Bronx. One was the sale of a six-story elevator apartment house at 195-06 Woodhull Avenue by Van Dyke Associates to a client of Morris Miller.

Mortgages involving fifty ships and three barges have been insured by the Maritime Administration, the agency reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The United States will press for new arms discussions among the major powers when the United Nations Disarmament Commission meets here tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 -- In the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here, play continued today for the masters' mixed team and the masters' pair championships. This is the third day of the tournament, which will continue through next Tuesday.

Leland Hayward has started negotiations to put "A Thurber Carnival" on television next March. The producer said yesterday that James Stewart wanted to star in the show and would be available if the property could be obtained for television.

ALTHOUGH the successful launching last week of the balloon satellite, Echo I, represented a giant stride forward in the field of communications, it does not mean that international television will become a reality immediately.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Senate turned from its minimum wage debate today to an even more controversial issue, medical care for the aged.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Willie Mays slammed two home runs and led the San Francisco Giants to a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.
Premier Khrushchev has disclosed that Soviet economic plans call for the production of 265,000,000 tons of steel in 1980; more than double the United States' annual production for any year thus far.
Prof. John Kenneth Galbraith, Harvard economist and adviser to Senator John F. Kennedy predicted yesterday a renewed American willingness to spend for public buildings that have beauty and elegance.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The appetite of foreign competitors for the American ceramic tile market is "voracious," the Tariff Commission was told today.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Jersey City swept a double header from Rochester tonight 4-3, 1-0, and cut the Red Wings fourth-place lead to three games.

ROME, Aug. 15 (AP) -- A 7-foot 3-inch woodchopper who plays basketball and 161 other neatly clad athletes from the Soviet Union settled into the Olympic Village today-and forgot to ring down the iron curtain.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Harry Best, in your Aug. 4 issue, seems unduly exercised over the charge by some Republicans that the Democrats "got us into three wars." Does Mr. Best feel equally disturbed by the Democrats' harping on the "Hoover depression"?

Because of yesterday afternoon's rain, last night's chamber music concert in Washington Square had to desert its familiar area in front of the bust of Alexander Lyman Holley. It moved indoors and this time it shifted to a new shelter.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Tony Gonzalez hit a two-out pinch double in the ninth inning tonight to score Hubert Amaro with the run that gave the Philadelphia Phils a 4-3 victory over the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates.
The city announced yesterday that it would prosecute the former owner and agent of a Harlem slum tenement in which six persons were injured in a fire on Aug. 6.
The following letter has come to us through the Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in Washington, which was asked to forward it to us.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Reds swept a double-header from the Milwaukee Braves tonight. Bob Purkey pitched a 4-0 shutout in the second game after Jim Maloney had registered a 5-3 victory.

A PRACTICAL, choice now for shoppers who want to keep the grocery bill down is shoulder of lamb. This cut, which is being offered in many stores, is a kind of two-in-one package. The shoulder includes five or six chops that can be cut off and broiled in the same way as rib or loin chops.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, Aug. 15 -- A 101-gun salute heralded the birth of the Congo Republic as a new nation today. The peaceful transition of the country from its autonomous status in the French Community was accompanied by praise for France.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Stock prices rose here today as persistent demand overcame profit-taking sales.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The merged labor movement set up a special department today to guide affiliates in investing billions of dollars of general funds and welfare funds in Government-backed housing loans.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 15 -- At a former Navy airfield a few miles from the coast, the Federal Aviation Agency is putting on a show as spectacular as anything along the boardwalk.
The present century with its "inventions, arts, skills and aspirations" will be the theme of the 1964-65 World's Fair in Flushing Meadow Park.

Magistrate David L. Malbin caused the afternoon session of Felony Court to run about twenty minutes longer than usual yesterday. But in so doing, he won the approval of twenty-nine probationary patrolmen.
ROME, Aug. 15 -- Hand-picked policemen from, all over Italy started flocking into the capital today as reinforcements for the Olympic Games, which open Aug. 25.

More borrowed money than ever will be available to the city in 1961, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa reported yesterday. As a result, New York will be able to finance a "huge construction and public improvement program," he said.

"I Might Have Got Killed" When a 7-year-old boy survived an accidental plunge over Niagara Falls recently, the ghosts of daredevils who had challenged the mighty cataract, some with lethal results, must have rattled in applause.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Maryland State Athletic Commission lifted Ray Robinson's suspension tonight and opened the way for a proposed National Boxing Association middleweight title fight with Gene Fullmer at Los Angeles Oct. 8.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 -- Four New Yorkers shared the lead with scores of 6-1 each today after the seventh round of the annual open championship of the United States Chess Federation.
A Suffolk County bus line appealed to the Public Commission yesterday for permission to continue its service between Riverhead, L.I., and New York City.
NIAGARA FALLS, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Top musicians and composers from twenty countries, put their ears to Niagara Falls today ut could not agree on the musical qualities of the great roar.
Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley reluctantly rejected yesterday two "meritorious" proposals for easing the city's traffic woes.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 15 -- Shirley Jones rallied in the stretch and overtook Kenneth Thornhill's Brave Pilot in the feature event today. With Sammy Boulmetis in the irons, the Brae Burn Farm's filly captured the mile race by a full length.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 15 -- The second annual $50,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway on Saturday night is shaping up as a race even more exciting than last year's.

The Professional Bowlers Association and the Bowling Proprietors Association of America are in disagreement on a recent B.P.A.A. ruling. As a result, some of the big national tournaments may be conducted without the stars of the game.

SOMERS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Police officials and tavern owners in northern Westchester County moved today to curb outbreaks of violence among youths by banning large gatherings of rival groups after sundown.

SNOWFLAKE, Ariz., Aug. 15 -- Ground-breaking ceremonies were held here over the week-end for a $32,500,000 pulp and paper mill, which will be a major milestone in the industrial boom of the Southwest. The plant, part of a $40,000,000 expansion program of Southwest Forest Industries, Inc., will be the first newsprint producer between Lufkin, Tex., and Portand, Ore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Key Democrats disclosed today why many of President Eisenhower's appointments to high Government posts were being blocked in the Senate. The explanation was that, however the elections turn out, a new Administration will come to town.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications. Commission approved an increase in telegram and money order rates today averaging 8 per cent.

MOONACHIE, N.J., Aug. 15 -- The Port of New York Authority took no action today, the deadline for tax appeals, on the efforts of this borough to make the agency pay taxes on the $890,000 industrial building it has erected for rental to a manufacturing concern.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Judy Rand of Aurora, Ohio the defending champion, and one of her chief challengers, Carol Sorenson of Janesville Wis., tied for the medal today in the junior girls' campionship of the United States Golf Association at Oaks Country Club.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 15 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, who favors a neutralist policy for Laos in the "cold war" conflict between Western and Communist nations, was called upon today to replace Premier Tiao Somsanith who has headed a pro-Western Government.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 15 -- The State Democratic Convention today endorsed a slate of Presidential electors pledged to Senator John F. Kennedy.

Traffic was snarled for more than two hours in the underpass connecting the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive with West Street near the Battery Tunnel in lower Manhattan after a fifteen-ton tractor-trailer caught fire at 10:51) A.M. yesterday.
Mickey Mantle slugged two homers, drove in his team's runs and was clearly the hero of the Yankees 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles at the Stadium last night.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 15 -- Foreign ministers of the Western Hemisphere have gathered in this neat, peaceful Central American capital to seek solutions for emotion-packed problems. These are problems that threaten to undermine the inter-American political system.

Money in the savings bank may soon become as familiar to today's younger generation as a house on the boardwalk was to their parents a quarter century ago. A new game, Savings Bank, has come along to challenge that long-time favorite Monopoly.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 points off to 14 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Greenwich Village civic groups won a big round at City Planning Commission hearings yesterday in their campaign to have an old courthouse, which really looks like a church, converted into a public library.

WINTHROP, Mass., Aug. 15 -- C. Stanley Ogilvy of the Larchmont (L.I.) Yacht Club led all the way and won the opening race of the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship series off the Cottage Park Y.C. today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Bob Bruce, a rookie, limited the Chicago White Sox to two hits tonight as the Detroit Tigers scored a 4-1 victory and dropped the White Sox into a second place tie in the American League.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Small cars are off to a big start in the 1961 model production race.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells, a two-time victor, shot a medal-winning 39, 37--76 today in the qualifying round for the state match-play championship at the Forest Hill Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- The Ryewood Country Club team of Jim Turnesa and Dr. Leonard Newman won the Westchester Professional Golfers Association's pro-amateur best-ball tournament at the Ridgewood C. C. today by one stroke with a 83, 33-66.
Commodity futures moved irregularly lower on New York exchanges yesterday in dull and featureless trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs rose slightly today despite last week's actions by the Federal Reserve System in the direction of easier money.

Sales of the nation's major retail chain companies were 1.6 per cent higher in July than the 1959 month. A survey by The New York Times yesterday showed sales last month for forty-two big chains were $1,561,844,048, against $1,537,578,141 in July, 1959.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Tuesday, Aug. 16 -- With the first stroke of midnight Cyprus received her independence from Britain today. After more than sixteen months of difficult negotiation on the form independence would take, even after independence had been agreed upon, Cyprus became a republic.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The Kabaka of Buganda and Iain Macleod, Colonial Secretary, opened talks today on Buganda's status within the British East African protectorate of Uganda.

INDRANl, a young dancer from India, made her New York debut last night at the Barbizon - Plaza Theatre, assisted by a small company of dancers and musicians. Since her mother, Ragini Devi, was well known here as a dancer a generation ago, the event took on special interest.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 15 -- Western Europe's matchmakers in the business field are convinced that the rival trade communities, the "Inner Six" and the "Outer Seven," were made for each other, and that the nuptials are impending.
OPORTO, Portugal, Aug. 15 -- The Grand Prix of Europe will be raced at Monza, Italy, on Sept. 4. It probably will be one of the emptiest motor rases in history.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 15 -- Western Europe's matchmakers in the business field are convinced that the rival trade communities, the "Inner Six" and the "Outer Seven," were made for each other, and that the nuptials are impending.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 15 -- Dr. B.R. Sen, director general of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, said today that improved techniques of agriculture were the key to higher living standards for under-developed countries.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Congress talked through another day without noticeable progress today.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, Aug. 16 -- President Posun Yun this morning named Do Yun Kim, 66-year-old American-educated economist, as Premier of the second Korean Republic.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The stockholders of the Peoples Bank of Haverstraw voted today to move the main office of the Bank from Haverstraw, the county's oldest village, to New City, the Rockland County seat.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 15 -- The build-up at United Nations forces in Katanga picked up speed today as the first Belgian troops pulled Out of the provincial capital.
NEWPORT, R.I. Aug. 15 -- (AP) -- Eight seeded players stood by today while sixty-six others battled for spots in tomorrow's first round of the seventy-ninth Newport Casino tennis tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Following are the texts of letters exchanged between Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and Premier Patrice Lumumba and Foreign Minister Justin Bomboko of the Congo that were made public here tonight:

Every conference of the foreign ministers of the Organization of American States earns its place in the history of the hemisphere. Such meetings are not often held, and when they are the reasons are compelling. The conference that begins in San Jose, Costa Rica, today shapes up as one of the most important ever held.
MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- The family of Francis Gary Powers was "impressed" today with his Soviet defense lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox cut short Washington's brief visit to the first division tonight, beating the Senators, 11-3, before a crowd of 13,751 that included President Eisenhower.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 15 -- A bitter exchange of letters beween Secretary General Hammarskjold and Premier Lumumba over the meaning of the Security Council's resolutions on the Congo led Mr. Hammarskjold to leave for New York tonight for a Security Council session.

Beckman Instruments, Inc., observed its twenty-fifth anniversary With a report of the highest sales and earnings for any year on record. The electronics producer also reported yesterday a 75 per cent increase in earnings for the year ended on June 30 on a sales gain of 21 per cent.
OTTAWA, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press) -- The drive to narrow Canada's trade gap was slowed sharply during the second quarter of 1960 by a slump in export sales to the United States.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 15 -- President Sukarno appointed sixty-one Indonesians today to serve on a broad-based governing council of the National Front, which he heads.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Department of the Interior today set the allocation of licensed imports of residual fuel oil on the East Coast at 415,000 barrels a day for the quarter beginning Oct. 1. This allocation compares with an average of 395,000 barrels a day imported during the fourth quarter of 1957, the base year under which the oil import program is operated.
GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- United Nations officials met here today with representatives of Belgium and the Congo to try to establish independent banking for the African republic.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Tom Strafaci and Ken Benson of Dyker Beach won the Long Island Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament today by one stroke at the North Hempstead Country club.
The surprising explosion of teen-age gang violence in one of the quietest, most respectable neighborhoods in Queens brought action yesterday from the police and youth authorities.
The body of a Wealthy semi-recluse was found in his litter-choked Yorkville apartment yesterday. He apparently had been dead for more than two weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, Army Chief of Staff, was named by President Eisenhower today to become chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on the retirement soon of Gen. Nathan F. Twining.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Douglas Bruce of the American Yacht Club junior instruction staff at Rye, N.Y., won the Jesse A.B. Smith Trophy in the Long Island Sound Junior Yacht Racing Association's annual instructors' regatta today.
A stackless, yacht-like ship emerged from the harbor fog near the Battery yesterday morning to receive the port's welcome for new ships.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 15 -- The state expects to have eight of its nine passenger railroads, including the four major lines, under contract by Sept. 1 to provide essential commuter services for one year.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 15 -- Costa Rican security forces disarmed today the Cuban delegation here for the conference of foreign ministers of the Americas.

A NEW service that is designed to minimize the busy business executive's (and his secretary's) headaches at Christmas time has just been conceived by Lillian Ross. It is a Christmas gift service department. Gifts are for both men and women. Although selected for "business to business" giving, many are appropriate as personal gifts. All are imported, and not one is more than $25.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- From campuses and corporations, Vice President Nixon has mustered his version of a brain trust to help guide his Presidential campaign.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration released the following timetable today for orbits of the Echo communications satellite over the eastern United States:
Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba, the welterweight champion, will oppose Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore., in a nontitle tenrounder at Madison Square Garden tonight.
TORONTO, Aug. 15 -- The New York Giants got off to an unimpressive start in their opening pre-season football game against the Chicago Bears tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A Republican started right out being beastly to the Democrats as the House of Representatives reconvened today.
New York City paid official tribute to the United states Olympic team yesterday.

High-grade bonds fluctuated narrowly yesterday, giving force to the opinion that the Federal Reserve System's recent moves toward easing credit conditions had been discounted substantially by the market's sharp rise in recent weeks.
'THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 15 -- Invaders from California took three of the top four places in the opening race of the seventeenth International 110 Class championship today under the colors of the Corinthian Yacht Club.

STATE deer-hunting regulations for 1960 have just been issued by the Conservation Department. They are not so complex as last year's, but they are complex enough. There are fewer allowances for the killing of does.
The United States Olympic basketball team will make its farewell appearance tonight when it meets the New York Tapers at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory.
Three Long Island Rail Road commuter trails were delayed up to fifty-seven minutes yesterday morning by an electrical fire on a train in a Brooklyn tunnel.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The grain futures market showed some signs at times today of starting a recovery movement but the small bulges met stiff resistance and prices finished generally steady to weak.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce urged Congress today to vote $1,800,000 to finance the immediate start of a drive to expand this country's export trade.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. Just when the airlines are extending themselves and putting their best foot forward by creating superb public waiting spaces, one way after another, at our major airports, the railroads "cut off their nose to spite their face" by chopping up their great terminals, disfiguring them and cluttering them with advertising and other extraneous internal constructions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Maritime Administrator Ralph E. Wilson appointed today a three-member committee to study possible changes in the organization of the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, N.Y.

HOW much longer than a short story is a novella or a novelette? What is the difference between a long short story and a short novelette? I can't answer these questions, but I have been worrying about them because I think that Edward Loomis' new book, "Heroic Love,"* contains two novelettes and three short stories.
Steel production this week is expected to show a slight increase, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The United States and Britain will hold talks this week to "review" strategy for the twenty-one-month-old Geneva talks seeking to prohibit nuclear tests, the State Department announced today.
Forty-one New York motorists pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of failing to register and insure their cars in New York State while driving with New Jersey license plates.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 16 -- Western and some Communist bloc scientists convened here today to establish an International Academy of Astronautics.

The problem of the aging parent is one faced by more American families every year. The problem's aspects, economic and emotional, will be discussed on this page in two articles. The first appears today; the second tomorrow. A GROWN daughter, who is heading for bankruptcy by maintaining her 80-year-old mother in a medium-priced home for the aged recently voiced the feelings of many adult children in the same position.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The Western Hemisphere is "gravely threatened" by Soviet intervention, Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said tonight as he prepared to depart for a conference of hemisphere foreign ministers.
Two more shows have been announced for Five Enchanted Evenings, eleventh annual series of theatre parties for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund.
LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Striking seamen and officials of the National Union of Seamen prepared tonight for a struggle over the scheduled Thursday sailing of the Queen Elizabeth.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 15 -- Prof, Marcus Nadler predicted today that regardless of the outcome of the Presidential election the Federal Reserve Board's freedom would be left alone.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 -- The Mirisch Company, one of the most important independent movie producing firms announced plans today for large-scale production in Hollywood.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 15 -- The American Federation of Teachers was urged at its annual meeting here today to take stands on two New York State school controversies that have attracted national attention.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold returned the turbulent Congo crisis, to the Security Council tonight beause of grave differences with Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo.

The State of Vermont has designated Aug. 23 as the date of sale for $13,000,000 of highway and other public improvement bonds. The obligations will come due serially from 1961 to 1980. Of the total, $8,000,000 will be highway construction bonds due from 1962 to 1965.
Federal mediation efforts were begun yesterday to end a two-day strike of machinists against the Lockheed Aircraft Service in New York.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Alcoa International, Inc., foreign marketing subsidlary of Aluminum Company of America, has purchased a majority interest in Alukon International, Ltd., a marketer of aluminum building products outside the United Slates.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- George Ball of New York today defeated C. Wesley Michaels of Syracuse, 6-4, 3-8, 6-1, to reach the quarter-final round of the Middle States senior grass court tennis championship at the Germantown Cricket Club.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The 8-year-old son of a lottery winner was found dead today in a Sydney suburb. The child had been kidnapped July 7.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 16 -- A million dollars, more or less, has been pushed into the sellers' windows at the race track here daily. But the people who attended an art auction on Monday evening-Saratoga's first -- balked at betting on a sure thing.

Harry Horwitz, realty investor, announced yesterday he had purchased the blockfront on the west side of Eighth Avenue, between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets. He said he would improve the site with a twenty-story apartment house representing an investment of $6,500,000, including the cost of the land, Mr. Horwitz said the proposed building would contain 400 apartments.

ROME, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A more realistic amateur code, a move to cut down the games more sharply and election of a new president are issues threatening to make a bitter hassle of the International Olympic Committee meeting, which will open Friday.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., had record net sales of $187,508,456 in the quarter ended on July 23, an increase of almost 10 per cent above the $170,612,861 in the 1959 period. Net income was also the highest for any similar period, totaling $2,897,652 against $2,791,589.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Senate Republicans criticized their Democratic colleagues today for withholding approval of renominations of two key Republican officials.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates walloped twenty-seven hits for a twilight-night double victory over the Philadelphia Phils tonight, 11 -- 2, 4 -- 3.
Jean Anouilh's "Time Remembered," a romantic comedy, will be presented by the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" television serie on Feb. 7 (7:30 to 9 P.M.) over the National Broadcasting Company network.

American Machine Foundry At special meeting here yesterday stockholders of American Machine Foundry Company approved the exchange of not more than 152,000 common shares of AMF for the assets and business of the Cuno Engineering Corporation, Meriden, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Eisenhower Administration's proposed $600,000,000 Latin-American aid program gained the unanimous approval of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today. The chairman, Senator J.W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said he believed there would be "a lot of questions" about the program when it got to the floor of the Senate.

In its farewell home appearance, the United States Olympic basketball team defeated the New York Tuck Tapers of the National Industrial League, 83 -- 79, at the Sixty-Ninth Regiment Armory last night.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug 16 (AP) -- A sketchy will written on the back of a dying man's hospital chart was validated today. It changed drastically the beneficiary status of two educational institutions that were to have shared the estate almost equally.

POINT JUDITH, R.I., Aug. 16 -- Gentle charity has a pretty good chance of profiting handsomely from the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament, which opens here tomorrow morning. Or so it seems tonight, since there are plenty of giant tuna around.

A new proposal for transporting the city's commuters with more speed and comfort was offered yesterday by Sidney H. Bingham, former executive director and general manager of the New York City Transit Authority.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell predicted today that the country's unemployed would fall below 4,000,000 in September and October.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : On Aug. 6 President Nkrumah of Ghana, speaking on the situation in the Congo, said, inter alia: "if no United Nations solution is forthcoming, Ghana would lend such armed assistance as the Republic of Congo might request."

We suppose that, like most dreams of passenger transportation cooperation that involve unified action by Connecticut, New York and New Jersey, Sidney H. Bingham's plan for a high-speed tri-state commuter system will be dismissed by some as visionary.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday net earnings of $4,436,000 in June, a record for any month. As a result, the airline was able to show a net profit of $4,000 for the first six months of this year. In the first three months, the company had a net loss of $6,826,000.

Three New York members of Congress lent support yesterday to a move by personnel of the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn to dissuade the Eisonhower Administration from plans to build the next super-aircraft carrier in a private shipyard.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- Intourist, the Soviet travel agency, issued tickets to the Powers trial to the Powers family today. This was the first official confirmation that the family members would be permitted to attend.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 16 -- President Sukarno was expected tonight to order the dissolution of two Opposition anti-Communist political parties as Indonesia prepared to celebrate the fifteenth anniversary tomorrow of the nation's independence.

MONTREAL, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- The aviation industry has spent $50,000,000 in the last five years trying to muffle the roar of jet engines and airlines still are "penalizing" themselves with silencing devices, a spokesman for the world's airlines said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Two leading Western delegates expressed the belief today that the Soviet Union had helped to supply the legal arguments used by Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo in his dispute with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

Whitey Ford, who only last Saturday had blanked the Washington Senators with three hits, 1-0, handed identical treatment to the Baltimore Orioles yesterday at the Stadium. None of Ford's Yankee team-mates complained of the monotony, though, as the Bombers retained first place in the American League.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 -- Eight players are tied for the lead in the United States open chess tournament today with 6 1/2 - 1 1/2 scores at the end of eight rounds of play.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Arab League's oil chief says the league plans to go ahead With a program of expanding pipelines, building refineries and operating a tanker fleet.
Martin Schulman, a trader in Greenwich Village real estate, was acquitted yesterday of a charge of permitting fire hazards in a building from which he is trying to evict tenants.
THE little French dressmaker may be a vanishing species in Paris but her presence is strongly felt in Bloomingdale's new pret-a-porter import collection.
The nation's electric and the gas utilities industries furnished figures yesterday showing the vastness of their continuing expansion.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold returned tonight to seek a clear-cut endorsement of his stand that United Nations forces must not be used to "subdue" Katanga Province.
POINT HOPE, Alaska, Aug. 15 -- Proposed nuclear blasts on the Arctic coast thirty-five miles below this Eskimo village were pronounced safe today from a biological standpoint.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 16 -- Premier Patrice Lumumba decreed martial law today for the next six months.

YESTERDAY (Aug. 16, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Saw Vice President Nixon and Republican Congressional leaders; saw H.E.W. Secretary Flemming, Edward H. Litchfield, chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh, and Robert Bowie, special consultant to Secretary of State; nominated Fraser Wilkins as Ambassador to the new Republic of Cyprus.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Aug. 16 -- Without security guards or police attendants, Dr. Joaquin Balaguer, the new Dominican President, attended church services today -- National Restoration Day.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Rochester Red Wings scored a double victory over Jersey City tonight. The Wings won the opener, 9 -- 6, and then rallied to take the second game, 6 -- 5.
For a time yesterday, just before noon, the stock market gave signs of coming to life. Volume picked up, the tape ran late, and prices rose to their best levels of the day.

YOUNG cabbage, with bright green leaves, is one of the bargains at vegetable counters now. It is being offered for as little as 4 cents a pound. This cabbage, which comes from Long Island and upstate farms, is the freshest and most flavorful New Yorkers will taste all year.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 16 -- A basic prescription for improving the nation's public schools was offered here today. The remedy suggested was more money.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Senate defeated today an attempt to erase the minimum working conditions that farm operators must maintain for migrants recruited for them by the Government. The vote was 56 to 42.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 -- Richard M. Nixon, Republican candidate for President, is the overwhelming favorite of Cleveland's Golden Age Clubs, a poll conducted by The Cleveland Press indicated today.

The nation's aggregate personal income for 1959 came to $381 billion, up $23 billion, or 6 per cent, from the 1958 mark, according to the Department of Commerce. Only three states failed to participate in the improvement. These were North Dakota, South Dakota and Montana, all of which reflected the lower prices of farm products, increased production costs and elimination of the acreage reserve program of the Soil Bank.
"Midgie Purvis," starring Talian Bankhead, has been deferred. A late winter arrival is now scheduled for Mary Chase's farce-comedy, which was to have opened Oct. 12 at the Lyceum.
The New York Civil Liberties Union backed George L. Rockwell, self-styled American Nazi leader, in an appeal yesterday to the State Supreme Court to protect his right to speak in public.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 16 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga expressed his full confidence tonight in the United Nations and Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
LONDON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A surplus of crude oil soon may cut revenues of several Mideast Governments, financial authorities said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The United States offered today to close down gradually its production plants for uranium and plutonium if the Soviet Union would do the same.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Pedro Ramos hit a homer and a run-scoring single as he helped bat and pitch Washington to an 8-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.
United States Government obligations generally declined in price yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Gaining a second place in the first race and winning the second, Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr. of the Larchmont Y.C. took the lead in the competition for the Long Island Sound men's sailing championship today.
BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- The tree flow of traffic between Berlin and the West figures prominently in a new long-term trade pact concluded here today between East and West Germany.
A Brooklyn man was held in $50,000 bail in Kings County Court yesterday as a material witness in an investigation of arson in a $150,000 fire in a Bay Ridge social club.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone began her bid today for a third New Jersey women's match-play championship by beating Mrs. Michael Burke of Cedar Hill, 4 and 3, in the first round at the Forest Hill Field Club.
ROME, Aug. 16 -- Two of the largest groups of American Olympians arrived this evening aboard Pan American World Airways planes.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 16 -- Recent moves by the Roman Catholic Church to initiate discussions on unity among Christians were welcomed today by the executive committee of the World Council of Churches.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Hail to Reason will attempt to carry 126 pounds against a dozen other 2-year-olds in the Saratoga Special tomorrow. The money-making colt who runs in the silks of Patrice Jacobs will seek to add some $20,000 to his already-substantial earnings by winning the fifty-eighth running of the Special.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney said today that the prospect for commercial licensing of live-virus polio vaccine in this country "looks definitely more hopeful."

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- While Al Heist, a rookie center-fielder, lay stunned after crashing into Wrigley Field's vine-covered wall trying to catch a drive by Wally Moon in the eighth inning, Wally rounded the bases today.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Wednesday, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- Representative Keith Thomson won the Republican nomination for Senator in a primary today
THE long, narrow, low-slung stage of the Jan Hus House, which resembles the inside of a trolley car, was the setting last evening for a bumpy revival of Shaw's enchanting "Man and Superman."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Top-seeded Rod Laver of Australia had to rally today to win a first-round match from Miguel Olvera of Ecuador, 1 -- 6, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 1, in the Newport Casino invitation tennis tournament.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 16 -- The Court of Common Pleas today resolved, at least temporarily, a controversy over the establishment of a nonprofit swimming club in a residential area here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Industrial production -- like construction activity, employment conditions and consumer spending -- continued to show little change in July and early August, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 16 -- The State Democratic Convention took steps today to withhold Mississippi's eight electoral votes from Senator John F. Kennedy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- Harry Chiti's wild throw attempting to catch Jimt Landis at third in the eighth inning tonight permitted two unearned runs in score as the Chicago White Sox gained a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers and retained second place in the American League.

Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday he was about to decide whether to dismiss or reinstate Purchase Commissioner Joseph V. Spagna. The Mayor told a press conference at City Hall that he would take action "very shortly."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- California today authorized Pacific Gas and Electric Company to build a multimillion-dollar pipeline from the Oregon border to deliver Canadian natural gas to Antioch in the San Francisco Bay area.

IF there has been a wiser woman in this century than Sidonie Gabrielle Colette her name is unknown to this writer. The emphasis is on "woman," for if any human in our day has deserved that rare title -- surely it is Colette.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points off to 13 points up yesterday with the strength in the far months. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
The Eskay Carpet Company has purchased a plot fronting on Meeker and Varick Avenues and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, in the Greenpoint area of Brooklyn, from Jack and Harry Pine.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 16 -- Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic delighted a strange audience in Vancouver today -- 5,000 in, the Forum Arena, of which 60 per cent were from age 6 to 16. It was the first of two Young People's Concerts that the Philharmonic will give in its three-month tour.
The sudden departure of George Abrams from his post as president of the Hudnut-DuBarry division of Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company has put a question squarely before the advertising industry.
The Fulton Fish Market may be moved from Lower Manhattan and merged with the proposed new Hunts Point whole sale market in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Democrats are far from happy about the current phase of the campaign.

A General Motors Acceptance Corporation issue of $150,000,000 of twenty-two-year debentures was placed on the market yesterday by investment bankers. It carried a 4 5/8 per cent interest coupon and was priced at 99 1/4 to yield 4.68 per cent to maturity.

Mayor Wagner took sharp issue yesterday with any assumption by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa that the city could borrow enough money within its debt limit in the next few years to meet its most essential needs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration released the following timetable today for passes of the Echo communications satellite over the Eastern United States. The "Location" column indicates whether the satellite will appear in the northern or southern half of the sky.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 17 -- The Korean National Assembly rejected today the nomination of Kim Do Yun as Premier of the second Korean Republic.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 16 -- West Germany's Continental Allies have given cautious approval of Chancellor Adenauer's undertaking to bring together Western Europe's rival economic blocs, diplomatic sources said today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 16 -- Cyprus celebrated her independence from Britain today with much pomp and jubilation, with tears of joy for returning heroes and with a display of fireworks that lighted the night sky.

The name of the author of "Fortune's Merry Wheel" was inadvertently misspelled in this space last Thursday. He is John Samuel Ezell, Associate Professor of History at the University of Oklahoma. His book, which Harvard University Press will issue Aug. 29, is a history of the lottery in this country from colonial times throughout the nineteenth century.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- Henry Bassford of Staten Island surprised by defeating third-seeded William (Slew) Hester of Jackson, Miss., 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, and gained the semi-final round of the Middle States senior grass court tennis championship today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 16 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter opened today a round of private talks with his Latin-American colleagues shortly after his arrival for the opening of the conference of Western Hemisphere foreign ministers tomorrow.

BERLIN, Aug. 16 -- The red banners of Stalinstadt, hoisted to mark the city's tenth anniversary, fluttered today in a sharp breeze blowing from the eastern Polish plains across the Oder River into East Germany.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Britain's trade deficit, the excess of imports over exports and re-exports, amounted to u96,100,000 ($269,080,000) last month, the Board of Trade announced today.

HAVANA, Aug. 16 -- Premier Fidel Castro and his brother Raul, the Armed Forces Minister, were reported to have led a raid early today to smash a "counter-revolutionary plot" by Cuban naval officers and men.
NEWARK, Aug. 16 -- Assemblyman Herbert H. Tate, a lawyer here, was named vice chairman of the Republican State Campaign Committee today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Liberal Democrats in the Senate have decided not to try to knock out a bill on medical care for the aged based on Federal-state relief payments.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 -- Captain Kittinger "asked the Lord for help" -- before he plunged earthward at speeds up to 450 miles an hour, he said here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- small band of entertainers and Theatre folk met here today advise ways to give the great American audience that warm feeling about Vice President Nixon.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The Cunard Line remained confident tonight that the Queen Elizabeth would sail on schedule Thursday morning for New York. But striking seamen were still trying to persuade her crew to quit work.
Prices of commodity futures closed generally mixed yesterday on New York exchanges in another day of light and lackluster trading.

THOSE who work with the aged agree that an elderly parent should be encouraged to remain in his own home and apartment until he can no longer maintain it. There seems to be no substitute for the comfort and security an older person feels in familiar surroundings.

Benny (Kid) Paret, the world welterweight champion from Santa Clara, Cuba, got the star billing in the Madison Square Garden ring last night. The accolade of the fans, however, went to Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore., and Gale Kerwin of Canada.

ALAMOGORDO, N.M., Aug. 16 -- An Air Force officer ascended in a balloon to almost nineteen and a half miles today, higher than anyone had risen before in nonpowered flight. Then he stepped out of the open gondola and plummeted sixteen miles before opening his parachute.

The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday a reorganization of its domestic marketing operations and the transfer of the headquarters of this department from Pittsburgh to Houston, Tex., effective about Sept. 1.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- Juan Marichal, a rookie pitcher for the San Francisco Giants, beat the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, 7 -- 3, for his fourth victory without a defeat.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 16 -- The United States and the Soviet Union are at odds over the semantics of soils.

HONG KONG, Aug. 9 -- Steel is the status symbol of Asia today as every young nation sets her sights on industrialization as the quickest means to end underdevelopment. With China and Japan as their examples, the new independent nations of the region aim to change their traditional dependence on agriculture, raise low living standards and accumuate foreign exchange.

YOUNGSTERS interested in music and the exciting evolution of musical instruments are invited to view 202 primitive instruments at the "Lute, Flute and Drum" exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at Seventy-ninth Street.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 (UPI) -- Tito Francona's bases-filled single drove in Johnny Temple in the tenth inning tonight and gave the Cleveland Indians a 4-3 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
Senator John F. Kennedy is moving in fast in his campaign to woo the fans of Adlai E. Stevenson in New York City.
BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Breakdowns marred the opening of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's midget sailing championships off here today.

City school officials rejected yesterday what they called "incompetent accusations" by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa that the Board of Education was requesting more money for school construction than it could spend.
Former Mayor William O'Dwyer said yesterday that he had Joined a new United States motion-picture production concern.

A gala festival such as might once have taken place in the palaces of Italian kings has been arranged for Oct. 14 at Leone's. It will follow a theatre party that evening at the Lyceum for Tallulah Bankhead's performance in "Midgie Purvis."
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 16 -- A record fleet of 248 boats showed up for the opening day of the twelfth annual junior regatta on Manhasset Bay today.
A total of 1,019 persons were hurt in auto accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This compares with 1,073 in the like 1959 week.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- A two-year legal battle between two supermarket chains over ownership of a third has been settled out of court.

Moxie Company In a first step toward diversification, the Moxie Company, Needham Heights, Mass., announced yesterday an agreement to acquire all stock of United Manufacturing and Engineering Corporation, Independence, Mo. Moxie, which has been in business since 1884, has been engaged in manufacture of extract ingredients for the soft drinks Moxie and Ted's Root Beer with franchised dealers principally in the New England area.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 16 -- Premier Souvanna Phouma charted a course of neutrality and unity for Laos today as he presented a Cabinet of eight members to the National Assembly.
A young Bronx leatherworker in cowboy clothes plays the frontier life these days in a spanking new stagecoach, patterned partly after one he saw in a television commercial.

As the Chrysler Corporation's largest creditor, the Prudential Insurance Company of America issued a statement yesterday about its position in the light of a suit against the automobile manufacturer filed on Friday in Delaware by some stockholders.

Just fourteen days after it applied for permission to operate, the National Stock Exchange, Inc., won the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. However, since it has some fixing up to do at its 6 Harrison Street headquarters, trading on the exchange probably will not begin until November, it was said.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Stockmarket prices went into reverse today after their buoyancy of the last few days.
A noontime demonstration of the Neighbor's Rally of Greenwich Village was staged yesterday outside the offices of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission at 280 Broadway

ASPEN, Colo. We and the world customarily think of the United States as a two-party democracy, but, in fact, there will probably be some twenty parties contesting this year's elections. The trouble is that few people ever even hear of most of them.
Mayor Wagner stepped between two city departments yesterday to seek action to end subway fires.

BUYING that first painting or sculpture for a home can make even a strong woman weep. The woman who will select an $800 breakfront or commit her family to a year's payments on a new refrigerator often freezes in terror when asked to decide on a $75 watercolor for her living room wall

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Republican leaders pressed a campaign from the White House steps today to stamp a "do-little" label on the current session of Congress. The party's Congressional chiefs complained that Democrats in charge of the session apparently intended to "jettison" much of President Eisenhower's legislative program.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You carried an AP dispatch from Stockholm quoting "a ranking Western Communist" to the effect that there were stormy scenes at a recent labor conference in Peiping between Soviet and Chinese leaders. At one point the Russians threatened to walk out if the Chinese repeated their criticism of Khrushchev and his policy.

Last week's MG Car Club 1,000-mile rally, its eighth annual, was one of its best. Good roads, interesting navigational and driving problems and pleasant overnight stops in Concord, N.H., Quebec City and Albany gave to the contestants an eyent they will long remember.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 16 -- The U-2 case came up at the International Astronautical Congress here today despite a Swedish attempt to keep it out.
AS the hour nears for the $50,000 International Trot, tension grows out at Westbury. For this, event, which will be held at the Roosevelt Raceway Saturday night is gaining in stature.

THE new Premier of Laos, His Highness Prince Souvanna Phouma, has twice before guided the destinies of the little kingdom of tinkling temple bells. In the minds of most people, Laos has always been a kind of Oriental Graustark remote, nearly mythi cal and full of high deeds.
The capabilities of New York State's ports to cope with atomic-powered shipping and to handle nuclear cargoes will be measured by Ebasco Services, Inc., the state announced yesterday.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 16 -- The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, the largest passenger line in New Jersey, has agreed to expand and improve its commuter services in return for a state subsidy. A year ago it threatened to end passenger service entirely.
SOMERS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Commuters and business-people in this generally quiet suburban town asked today to have armed volunteers deputized for protection from brawling youths.
Bond issues totaling $98,900,000 will be put up for sale in September by the New York State Thruway and municipal housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 -- Two contract bridge masters' championship contests entered their final rounds in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- The Eastern players from the New York area scored a 6-1 victory over the Missouri Valley group today in the first round of the United States Girls' grass court tennis team championship at the Germantown Cricket Club.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Warren Spahn's skill and experience were too much for Jay Hook's youth and strength tonight as the Milwaukee Braves gained a 2-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds after a pitching duel.

A "recovery program" is in the final planning stages for the cranberry industry. That was the word yesterday from Ambrose E. Stevens, executive vice president and general manager of the National Cranberry Association, a cooperative that markets cranberry products under the Ocean Spray brand name.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The lines of battle were formally drawn today in the Senate's coming debate on medical care for the country's 16,000,000 elderly persons.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17 (AP) Clem Labine, making his first appearance in a Pittsburgh Pirate uniform, turned in a fine relief performance tonight and preserved a 5 -- 3 victory for the league leaders over the Philadelphia Phillies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 10:

TRADITIONALLY, there is only one side of criminal law in the Soviet, Union that offers an attorney opportunities for fame, stature and high office. That is the right side, the prosecution side. The growing use of acrylic plastic material in various forms -- the same substance used to make the "bubbles" on a bomber -- has given rise in the last dozen years to mass production of illuminated plastic signs for point-of-purchase and name displays.

Political analysts talk of the labor vote, the farmer vote, the woman's vote, the oldster's vote and others. But is there a saver's vote? Apparently convinced that there is-and that it can work advantageously -- the United States Savings and Loan League is encouraging its member associations to persuade savings-account holders to register and vote.
The completion of a major rebuilding program at LaGuardia Airport was advanced by eighteen months yesterday, in time for the opening of the 1964 World's Fair.

The Transport Workers Union yesterday set a strike against the Pennsylvania Railroad system at the start of the Labor Day week-end.
An expansion of air-cargo facilities at New York International Airport to cope with a tripled volume expected there by 1975 was approved yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Forest Hill, the defending champion, moved into the semi-finals of the Now Jersey women's match-play golf championship with a 3 - and - 2 victory over Mrs. Janet Kern of Orchard Hills at the Forest Hill Shield Club today.
