The bond market mostly marked time yesterday. Prices of Treasury securities fell because of a lack of buying interest. High-grade corporate bonds of recent issue, unable to advance, were generally quoted at Tuesday's levels, With little business transacted.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 17 -- President Sukarno said today that he had ordered the dissolution of two Opposition anti-Communist parties.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was the first executive director of the consolidated Park Association of New York City formed in 1925. The first president was Nathan Straus Jr. The organization was composed of a board of outstanding men and women, among them Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger.
The Cerro de Pasco Corporation reported yesterday an increase of 71.8 per cent in earnings for the first half of this year on a sales gain of 18.6 per cent.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 -- The Chrysler Corporation went to court today to recover profits said to have been made by a business associate of William C. Newberg, former president of Chrysler. Mr. Newberg resigned on June 30 after it was disclosed that he owned a 50 per cent interest in two companies that supplied parts to Chrysler from 1952 to 1958.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 17 -- Archbishop Makarios said today he would not permit Britain to use her bases in Cyprus in any way that would adversely affect the rest of the island.

The exercise of several large stock options was disclosed in the latest insiders' report issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange from reports made available to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 17 -- The Belgian Government defended its Congo policy before Parliament today.

Sporting dog history will be made on Saturday at LaGrangeville, N.Y., where the Eastern English Springer Spaniel Club will hold tests to qualify springers for working certificates. To earn a certificate a dog must demonstrate that he is not gun-shy and that he is willing and able to retrieve from the land and water.

YESTERDAY (Aug. 17, 1060) THE PRESIDENT Held press conference; saw Gordon Gray; Chrisian Ravndal, new Ambassador to Czechoslovakia; Karl Rankin, Ambassador to Yugoslavia; and Postmaster General Summerfield; issued statement on United States' successes in exploration of space; visited his granddaughter Susan, whose tonsils and adenoids were removed at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
America Corporation, formerly Chesapeake Industries, Inc., has acquired Pricemetal Corporation

HAVANA, Aug. 17 -- The Cuban Government continued today its silence on the extent of the "counter-revolutionary" conspiracy in the navy. The plot was reported to have been smashed with a large number of arrests.

God's Weeds in the Garden By the middle of August there can be no doubt as to the true status of the amateur gardener, urban, suburban or completely rural. He is no longer the devoted and admiring slave of nature's ways and nature's wonders that he was a few months ago when his garden and lawn were new toys for a new season.

Two new tenants have signed for space in the News Building, 220 East Forty-second Street, to bring the renting schedule of the structure up to 90 per cent of its 1,000,000 square feet. Matthew J. Stacom, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building, said only three tower floors and 25,000 square feet on a lower floor remain unrented.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Dr. John M. Chang, former Vice President who led a long fight against the policies of President Syngman Rhee, was today nominated for the Premiership of the Republic of Korea.

The final volume of Samuel ETiot Morison's "History of United States Naval Operations In World War II" will be published Oct. 4 by Atlantic-Little, Brown. It will be titled "Victory in the Pacific 1945." The volume begins with the fighting for Iwo Jima and Okinawa and ends with an account of the negotiations that led to Japan's surrender.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee reaffirmed today its intentions to ask contempt of Congress citations for three Port of New York Authority officials.

THE invention of brand new materials may be the goal of many concerns today, but Tiffany's still concentrates on improving the good, old ones. This week, Walter Hoving, president, of the company, announced that Tiffany's had perfected a tarnish-proof finish for sterling silver.
AMONG the varied oddities that have spiced this baseball season there is the matter of individual batting averages. They appear surprisingly low.

Unwilling to cope with the rigors of a short interim booking, Leo Kerz prefers to do the next best thing. He will wait a while before bringing in his production of "Rhinoceros."

Robert Moses, president of the 1964-65 World's Fair Corporation, said last night that Americans were obsessed with equalitarianism.

The prosecution of 10,222 housing cases in the first half of this year resulted in a total of $306,802 in fines, a Department of Buildings report showed yesterday.

HAVANA, Aug. 16 -- Cuba is rapidly becoming a nation in uniform.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In our most recent political convention the talents required to stand up to, talk back to and get tough with the Russians seemed to be tops, and having them the chief qualification of the candidates.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has postponed plans to present Chet Huntley and David Brinkley on "Person to Person."

For fifty-six years the Jamaica Race Track was officially described as "fast," "slow," "good" or "sloppy." The track-condition sign bore no listing yesterday, but it might have been "weedy."

Mrs. Raymond D. O'Brien is chairman for the ball and president of the Manhattanville Alumnae Association, which is sponsoring the event.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- stock-market prices rallied a little today after an uncertain start. Leading industrials sparked the recovery from yesterday's relapse.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- In an amazing show of consistency sixteen of Tuesday's twenty class winners repeated this afternoon in Manhasset Bay's twelfth annual junior regatta.

The years of study that have gone into modernization of the pioneer 1916 zoning resolution governing land use in New York City have their reward in the document made public by the Planning Commission today. It would be difficult to exaggerate the monumental labor that has produced this proposed, comprehensive resolution, or the importance of it to the enlightened planning of our city.
A Queens youth originally ordered held for treason for attempting to organize a Nazi-like movement was sentenced yesterday to an assignment in American history.

Although volume expanded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and more stocks rose than fell for the tenth successive day, prices moved upward with hesitation. The gain was small and came early in the session. After that, prices merely held even.

He also disclosed that negotiations to buy Modern Juniors-Lou Golowitz Co., Inc., a New York sportswear manufacturer, were expected to be completed by the end of this month.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 17 -- New Jersey will offer the New York Central Railroad a subsidy in return for a restoration of limited commuter service on its West Shore Division.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 17 (AP) -- A former soldier whom the Army sent to work in the Michigan copper mines for three years without Army pay found a friend in court today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- "Guilty," said Francis Gary Powers. This confession before the Supreme Military Tribunal switched on a vast Soviet propaganda machine that exploited the sensational espionage trial to the fullest at home and abroad.
The air rights to a two-block area at the Manhattan approach to the George Washington Bridge were sold by the city yesterday for $1,065,000.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr. of the Larchmont Yacht Club won the men's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today.
Senator John F. Kennedy will have as a "firm objective" the ending of the "state of war" against Israel if he is elected President.

A vital phase of New York City zoning concerns the so-called use districts into which the city is divided. These are separated in the proposed zoning resolution into residence, commercial and manufacturing categories.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (UPI) -- Tito Francona's sacrifice fly drove in Harvey Kuenn in the eighth inning tonight and gave a 3-2 victory to the Cleveland Indians over the Chicago White Sox. Johnny Klippstein was the winning pitcher in a relief role.

Commodity futures closed generally down on New York exchanges yesterday in a flurry of sharp price declines. Rubber, cocoa and sugar, which fell under the pressure of brisk selling to many seasonal lows, lead the downward trend.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today that recent United States space achievements "have demonstrated beyond all doubt" American leadership in conquering space.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Moscow radio told the Soviet people today that the facts of Francis Gary Powers' trial "pillory the whole of ruling Washington, which has raised espionage to the level of state policy."
The criminal code of the Soviet Union, under which Francis Gary Powers, the American pilot, is being tried, differs radically from that of democratic countries.
MUKWANAGO, Wis., Aug. 17 -- After ten static years| American Motors has drastically revamped its 100-inch wheelbase Rambler American, the shortest compact car made by a United States manufacturer.

A decline of 1,809,000 barrels on the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. An increase in gasoline production to 30,015,000 barrels from 29,040,000 in the preceding week accounted in part for the relative smallness of the decline.
A proposed city zoning law, extensively revised since the earlier proposals of Dec. 21, 1959, was made public yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- An organization whose purpose is to bring African students to the United States has turned down a State Department offer of $100,000 for their transportation and has accepted a similar offer from the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 17 -- A battle shaped up today between the nation's two major teacher organizations over which one would represent teachers in collective bargaining.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The United States said today that it would scrap "sizable numbers" of its nuclear weapons if the Soviet Union would accept American proposals made yesterday to minimize the dangers of atomic war.
HOUSTON, Aug. 17 -- Representative James Roosevelt was hanged in effigy today after he had told reporters of his proposal to abolish the House UnAmerican Activities Committee.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- The first United States team to salvage ancient monuments endangered by the building of the Aswan High Dam will leave for Egypt from the Oriental Institute here in October.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that it would support Premier Patrice Lumumba in his demand that neutral Asian and African observers be sent to the Congo to supervise the withdrawal of Belgian troops.

POINT JUDITH, R.I., Aug. 17 -- One hundred and thirty-two competing boats in the opening day of the United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament escaped skunk-age today by the comfortable margin of two fish.

New York Deputy Secretary of State Bernard G. Gordon reserved decision yesterday on a motion to reopen a hearing for five Long Island real-estate brokers allegedly involved in bribery to affect zoning.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: In reply to the letter from Prof. David R. Kochery of the University of Buffalo, published Aug. 11, questioning the performance of the President's Committee on Government Contracts, of which Vice President Nixon is chairman, it would appear that Professor Kochery has made only a cursory examination of the facts.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Stuart Brayshaw of the host Babylon Yacht Club successfully defended his Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association midget title today. Brayshaw won the last two events of the seven-race series and nosed out Steve Bedell of the Bellport Bay. Y. C.

The Southern Railway announced yesterday that it had contracted to buy the 71 pelcent stock interest in the Central of Georgia Railway now held by the St. Louis-San Francisco (Frisco) Railway. The purchase price is $22,655,000; payable in cash.
MOSCOW, Aug. 17 -- The members of the family of Francis Gary Powers believe he was behaving quite normally when he testified at his espionag trial today. They do not believe he has been brain-washe.

The U-2 case come to world attention last May 5, when Premier Khrushchev announced that a United States plane on a mission of "aggressive provocation" had been shot down May 1 in the Soviet Union near Sverdlovsk in the eastern foothills of the Ural Mountains.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- United States glass manufacturers, who say they are being driven to the wall by foreign competition, protested today against any further reduction in this nation's tariffs.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Arthur Nardin's Dellmor from Miami Beach, with Billy Haughton at the reins, scored a one-and-one-half-length victory over Yankee Chip in the featured Huntington pace before 23,316 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 -- Because they excelled in three departments -- pitching, fielding and base-running -- the Yankees beat the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 2, in ten innings tonight and added to their lead in the American League race.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Defense Secretary Thomas S. Sates Jr. created today a central planning group to assign nuclear weapons to enemy targets in case of war.

Representatives of California argued yesterday in a Federal hearing here that a proposed Supreme Court decree reallocating the water of the Colorado River could be "nothing short of disastrous" to the industrialized southern area of their state.

California completed yesterday the postponed borrowing of $15,000,000 to finance harbor development. The money was raised by the sale of bonds maturing serially from 1965 to 1990 to a syndicate headed by the Bank of America, National Trust and/Savings Association.

PHILDELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- Florida eliminated the Eastern (New York area) players, 5 -- 2, today in joining Southern California, the defending title holders in the final of the United States girls' grass-court tennis team championship at the Germantown Cricket Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Democrats demanded today to know if the State Department was giving political aid and comfort to Vice President Nixon, the Republican Presidential candidate.

Grant Advertising, Inc., which has offices throughout the world, has absorbed Chambers Wiswell, Shattuck, Clifford McMillan, Inc. a 40-year-old Boston agency, effective Sept. 1. The latter organization's $6,000,000 in billings gives Grant an annual volume in excess of $100,000,000.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Except for one brief flurry in soybeans, grain futures prices churned slowly and within a barely changing range today on the Board of Trade.
Specialties moved up yesterday against the background of a New York Stock Exchange list that was dull and generally down.
New and possibly important biological effects of radio and radar waves were reported at a three-day scientific meeting that concluded here yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- Ben Stone, a Detroit business man, denied today Chrysler Corporation's charge that he profited wrongfully from his association with William C. Newberg, former president of Chrysler.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Lew Burdette of the Milwaukee Braves pitched the first no-hitter of his career tonight, allowing just one runner to reach base for a 1 -- 0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

THE population explosion is affecting the elegant specialty shop. With the official opening on Monday of "Young Bonwit Ninth," Bonwit Teller is doing its bit to promote fashion consciousness from the cradle up.
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- The wife of Francis Gary Powers looked today on the poisoned pin that her husband could have used as a suicide weapon. She walked away without flinching.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 18 -- The satellite Discoverer XIV, crammed with secret gear, was shot into polar orbit today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The state has agreed to the future abandonment of the Pennsylvania Railroad's Exchange Place passenger terminal in Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Defense Secretary Thomas S. Gates Jr. named a senior nuclear expert of the Navy today as deputy director of the new strategic planning group that will assign targets to American retaliatory forces in the event of an all-out war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana will probably become the Senate Democratic leader next year if the Kennedy-Johnson ticket wins in November.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Jersey City Jerseys bunched four hits, a hit batsman and a sacrifice fly for four runs in the first inning tonight and beat the Rochester Red Wings, 4 -- 2. Zach Monroe held Rochester to six hits.
A Touch of Winter At about this time of year there often comes a day that is different from the others. To the casual observer there is little to set it apart.
A broadening of retail demand yesterday carried United States Government securities out of the price slump into which they slipped early this week.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 18 -- Congolese soldiers beat a Canadian captain into unconsciousness and manhandled seven other Canadians today at the Leopoldville airport.
Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy yesterday reaffirmed the right of the community of Roquefort, France, to its exclusive use of the trade-mark "Roquefort" for the cheese cured and ripened in its caves.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 18 -- Schools must do more than just teach the three R's, a national meeting of teachers agreed today.

Some executives of National Airlines, Inc., have been spending more time here in Wall Street in recent weeks than in the system's executive offices in Miami. The visits have but one purpose -- to formulate the best financing program to broaden the company's equity base and to add to its working capital, which at May 31 was down to $1,797,259.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 18 -- Our Jeep came along fast in the closing phase of the $13,500 Promise Stakes today and beat the favored Ambassador by a neck. Flint Schulhofer guided the John Schiff color-bearer in the mile-and-three-quarter hurdle event.

At a special meeting yesterday, the directors of Chrysler Corporation engaged a leading New York law firm to check on the adequacy of a continuing investigation into possible conflicts of interests involving company executives.

Disciplinary trials were scheduled yesterday for three employes of the Department of Real Estate charged with failure to report dangerous conditions in a Harlem building where fire recently caused injury to six persons.

The Amerace Corporation cleared $923,396, or $1.47 a Common share, in the first half of 1960. This is before an $11,000,000 reserve for estimated nonrecurring losses stemming from the recently announced disposal of the textile division.
OMAHA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- President L.G. Barnes of the Omaha Transit Company re-

CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Harvey Kuenn had four straight hits tonight, sparking the Cleveland Indians to an 8-6 victory over the Chicago White Sox. The Indians, rallied to overcome a five run deficit with five runs in the sixth inning and two in the seventh.
IF menu planning seems tedious to Westerners, it can be positively painful to Easterners, particularly if there is a diet factor involved.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $123,000,000 to $416,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $32,000,000 to $534,000,000 from a revised figure of a week ago.
THE PRESIDENT Met with National Security Council. Nominated Gen. George H. Decker to be Army Chief of Staff.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Briggs Cunningham, sailing competitively for the first time since he defended the America's Cup in 1958 as the skipper of Columbia, took an early lead today in the annual Atlantic Class championship.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 18 -- The following is the text of a statement today by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter before the conference of American Foreign Ministers:
The Purchase Department was established as the city's central buying agency twenty-six years ago in recognition of the fact that things are cheaper by the thousands of dozens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Treasury Department today disclosed more of its thinking about refinancing some of its long-term debt well in advance of maturity. Officials said that there has been no decision on the timing of an advance refunding, as this operation is called. It is evidently a live issue.
The Long Island Rail Road's application for fare increases averaging 6.4 per cent next Wednesday was sidetracked yesterday by the state's Public Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent below those in the 1959 week, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A Russian gerontologist who foresees an average lifetime of 150 years was visiting a home for the aged here yesterday when a 72-year-old blind Woman softly asked:
Proceeds from a dance to be held in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza on Oct. 7 will go to the individual scholarship funds of Smith Wellesley and Mount Holyoke Colleges.
THE questions fired at this department most often recently concern the American League race. Who will win it? Where will the Yankees finish ?
POINT JUDITH, R.J., Aug. 18 -- The United States Atlantic Tuna Tournament wallowed along today in fine weather, avoiding disaster by the marking of one fish caught but oddly maintaining interest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Senator John F. Kennedy's press secretary got angry today because the Republicans were saying that the senator had spent too much money to win the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The Zionist Organization of America will open its sixty-third annual convention next Thursday night at the Statler Hilton Hotel and will hear an address by Senator John F. Kennedy, the Democratic nominee for President.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The banners at the State Department look a little glassy-eyed this week, as if they'd been reading Vachel Lindsay's "Congo."

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 18 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru charged today that Communist China had been carrying on a "deliberate campaign" against India that amounted to "interference in the internal affairs of another country."

Joseph Wolf, New York realty investor, announced yesterday he had purchased and taken title to two properties in Cincinnati with a combined value of $5,000,000. Simultaneously he leased the parcels to David Lawrence and associates of New York at rentals aggregating $8,000,000.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 18 -- Indonesia's decision to sever diplomatic relations with the Netherlands may have been partly designed to prod the United States to reappraise its neutrality in the dispute between Jakarta and The Hague over Netherlands New Guinea, some observers speculated todaay.

"Sunrise Semester" will begin its fourth season over Channel 2 on Sept. 26 with courses in sociology and Shakespeare's major tragedies. Both will offer college credit through New York University's Washington Square College of Arts and Science.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Dick Stuart's pinch home run with two on in the eighth inning tonight broke up a pitching duel between Vernon Law and Cal McLish and gave a 3 -- 2 victory to the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates over the Cincinnati Reds.

The Sorkin Corporation, realty operators, has purchased the five-story apartment house for thirty-eight families at 2285 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, for cash over mortgages amounting to $100,000. Leonard, Levites Schiller were the brokers.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 18 -- A compromise solution on the Dominican Republic, reconciling a proposal by the United States for supervised elections there and a project to apply stern sanctions as demanded by Latin America, appeared possible tonight.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 18 -- Premier Pedro G. Beltran's year-old Cabinet faces a test in the current session of Congress over the future status of the International Petroleum Company. It is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Standard Oil (New Jersey).

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Given the setting and the atmosphere, South American business men will reap the same profit and pleasure from a United States business technique as their American counterparts do.

CELEBRATING its fifth birthday, Bergdorf Goodman's Miss Bergdorf introduced its Petite Couture collection for fall this week. The clothes were designed exclusively for Miss Bergdorf by three young Parisians, Carven, Virginie and Louis Feraud, and were made in this country.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The hurly-burly of the Presidential campaign is about to begin. Before it does, Democrats and independents in New York ought to recognize one thing about the Democratic party in this state -- the enormous gap that exists between the so-called leaders of the party and the sentiments of the average voter.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 19 -- Dr. John M. Chang, American-educated former ambassador to the United States, was today named Premier of the Korean Republic.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominioan Republic, Aug. 18 -- Thirteen Dominicans in asylum at the Mexican Embassy were allowed to leave the country today under free-conduct guarantees with passports.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I,. Aug. 18 -- Students studied seashells, sea squirts and seaweed by the seashore today.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored eight runs in the third inning tonight and hung on for a 10-8 victory over the Washington Senators, snapping a four-game losing streak.

Ilya Ehrenburg has protested the "unauthorized" publication in English of his 1929 novel, "The Stormy Life of Lasik Roitschwantz." It was brought out a few days ago by the Polyglot Library of 225 Lafayette Street.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 -- Robert Byrne of Indianapolis, a former intercollegiate champion, took the lead today in the United States open chess tournament with a score of 8 1/2 -- 1 1/2 when he defeated Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, the defender, in a Nimzo-Indian defense lasting thirty-five moves.
The concentration of strontium 90 in the growing bones of infants should reach its maximum this year and thereafter decline, according to a new report from a world-wide survey project,
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- Francis Gary Powers today blamed "the people who sent me" for the major political consequences of his U-2 flight over the Soviet Union May 1.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, Aug. 19 -- Sounthone Pathomvong, the supreme commander of the Royal Laotian armed forces, has escaped from Vientiane and joined the forces of Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, reliable reports from the Thai border indicated last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- A spokesman for the Pennsylvania Railroad said today that a strike of 20,000 non-operating employes, scheduled for midnight Aug. 31, would cause a shutdown of the nation's largest carrier.

The recent decline in the market price of the common stock of American and Foreign Power Company was blamed yesterday for a 19 per cent drop in net assets of Electric Bond and Share Company. Bond and Share owns about 50 per cent of Foreign Power's common stock, which amounts to "no less than 18 per cent" of Bond and Share's assets.

New propulsion systems for small pleasure boats, even revolutionary jet propulsion, are making their appearance. The Sea Jet has been developed by Vanguard Industries of Cincinnati. It cuts fuel consumption by using the thrust of water to propel the boat, providing more speed per gallon of gas.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- The picture that has emerged from two days of testimony by Francis Gary Powers at his espionage trial for the U-2 flight is of a man defending himself solely by pleading political naivete.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Prices moved aimlessly on the stock market today, with demand selective and volume small.

ROME, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The executive committee of the International Olympic Committee will meet tomorrow in a closed session amid growing indications that Avery Brundage of Chicago will be elected to his third four-year term as president.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 -- Play for the masters' team championship and the Nate B. Spingold trophy got under way last night in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Gen. Walter Kreuger, who led the Sixth Army through the jungles of New Guinea in World War II, was known as a tough, sometimes exasperating commander. But his chief of staff earned a grudging Kreuger accolade: "You could set a bomb off under his desk, and he wouldn't turn a hair."

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- Francis Gary Powers challenged the prosecution experts today on a number of technical points that had been-designed to portray him as an invading desperado bent on a murderous spy mission.

PICTON, Ont., Aug. 18 -- Canada's one-boat defense against the United States' three-boat challenge for the Harmsworth Trophy, symbolic of international speed-boat supremacy, has made this little half-hidden Ontario provincial city a boat-racing Mecca.
Fifty politicians are getting cues on how to put their best face forward on TV.

World sugar futures fell for the second consecutive day on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices closed 2 to 8 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) off in active trading of 24,300 tons.
A New York architect of Chinese birth who wants to add "peace" to the esthetics at New York International Airport was chosen yesterday to design a $9,000,000 terminal there.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 10 points up to 5 points off yesterday. The only month to show a decline was May, 1962, and that was a bid price, with no actual sales transacted. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
Mayor Wagner urged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to call a special session of the Legislature to revise the dates for registration in New York City.

Accused in a state inquiry report of "manipulation" of contract procedures, with "favoritism to a long-time personal friend," and in a recent city administration report of presiding over a department riddled with waste and inefficiency, Joseph V. Spagna has resigned as New York's Commissioner of Purchase. The evidence against him has not convinced him.

Despite recent credit-easing moves by the Federal Reserve System, money still remains tight at New York banks. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that daily average borrowings by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in the city rose $98,000,000 to $99,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy disclosed yesterday that he favored a plot in Manhattan's civic center area as the site of a new Police Headquarters building.
Purchase Commissioner Joseph V. Spagna has resigned. Mayor Wagner accepted the resignation yesterday, but refused to say whether he had requested it.
TRENTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The New Jersey State Highway Department disclosed today that its building program for the current fiscal year would be $11,000,000 smaller than last year's.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers battered Kansas City pitchers for fifteen hits, eight of them for extra bases, and gained an 11-6 victory today. The setback was the eighth in a row for the last-place Athletics.

The gold flight from this country reached its most spectacular dimensions in 1958. Under the combined influence of (1) the business recession of 1957-58, (2) the policy of aggressively low money rates, adopted by the Reserve authorities as a contra-Cyclical measure, and (3) the threat of a record peacetime budget deficit, the country's gold loss between February and December of that year totaled roughly $2.8 billion.

The Kratter Corporation, publicly owned real estate investment concern, has entered into an agreement to purchase 400,000 unissued shares of Thorncliffe Park, Ltd., of Toronto, a real estate development company.

Having made himself virtually absolute ruler of Indonesia with its 90,000,000 people, President Sukarno is now reaching out for a new world to conquer. He is stepping up his demands for Netherlands New Guinea as a first move toward a goal that could make him master of Oceania. To that end, he has now severed diplomatic relations with the Netherlands and threatens both a military build-up and the "use of power" to extend his domain.

American Felt Co. A dividend of 15 cents a share, payable on Sept. 15 to holders of record of Sept. 1, was declared yesterday by the American Felt Company. The company paid 25 cents in previous quarters.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- With passengers cheering and sirens hooting, the 83,673-ton Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth sailed from Southampton this morning for Cherbourg and New York.
Arizona's chief spokesman at Federal hearings here on proposed court allocation of Colorado River waters yesterday ridiculed California's cries of disaster as "a lot of nonsense."

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. James R. Hand of Sleepy Hollow shot a 41, 39 -- 80 today to win the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association at the Wee Burn Country Club.

Two more stars, making four in all, will be attached to "The Rape of the Belt," Benn W. Levy's London comedy hit dealing with Hercules and Hippolyte. They are Joyce Redman and John Emery, who will divide billing with Constance Cummings and Peggy Wood.
The Youth Council Bureau of Queens plans to study the causes of last week's gang battle in the usually quiet, respectable neighborhood of Ridgewood and the background of the boys involved.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold told members of the Security Council today that the entire United Nations program in the Congo had been jeopardized by the mistreatment of Canadian signal corps men in Leopoldville.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday an aggregate short interest of 3,251,149 shares as of Aug. 15, an increase of 192,846 shares from the revised total for July 15 of 3,058,303 shares. This gain of about 6.3 per cent coincided with a period when the average daily trading on the exchange dropped by about 13.3 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Vice President Nixon will open his campaign to win the support of the nation's farmers with a speech in Guthrie Center, Iowa, on Sept. 16.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The first official report on East-West trade since the U-2 incident and the collapse of the summit conference indicates that those episodes have had no effect on United States business dealings with the Communist bloc.

Works of fiction and nonfiction by William Michelfelder will be published this season. A novel, "Be Not Angry," will be issued Monday by Atheneum. It is a story about a young priest, troubled with the problem of his calling and his love for a woman, and his pastor, who forces him to face his problem.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 18 -- Capt. Kong Le announced yesterday that he had turned over administrative power in Laos to the new Government of Prince Souvanna Phouma.
Jack McCartan, the star goalie of America's Olympic hockey champions at Squaw Valley, Calif., last winter, yesterday became a full-fledged New York Ranger.
ROME, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The proposed third title bout between the world champion, Floyd Patterson, and Ingemar Johansson of Sweden is running into some roadblocks and may be postponed until spring.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The eighty-two-nation Disarmament Commission voted unanimously today to have the General Assembly call for "the earliest possible continuation" of great-power negotiations like those that broke down at Geneva in June.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Gen. George H. Decker was designated by President Eisenhower today to be Chief of Staff of the Army.
The continued operation of the Government-owned Panama Line was attacked yesterday by Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Sixteen Princeton residents, including three clergymen and a Professor of Humanities, have pledged to tax themselves to help to support the United Nations. In an appeal made public today, they pledged 1 per cent of their declared taxable income for 1959 to the world body.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- "Powers doing fine," The Evening News of London said in a banner headline today on the Moscow trial of the American U-2 pilot.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 18 -- The United Nations force in Katanga reached a strength of more than 3,000 tonight with the arrival of an Irish contingent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- All the fuss over the wage-hour bills boils down to a simple test: who can bring more influence on Congress, employers or wage earners?

ATLANTA, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Gen. Robert E. Lee was "one of the supremely gifted men" produced in this nation, in the opinion of President Eisenhower. For that reason his picture hangs on the wall of the President's office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Truck freight loadings for the week ended last Saturday showed decreases from both the levels of last year and the preceding week of this year. Rail freight loadings were above both last year's and those of the preceding week of this year.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- One could clearly see (and almost hear) old Case in the dugout today urging his league-leading Yankees to "Stay with 'em and we'll catch 'em."

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- A record entry adhered to a dawn-to-dusk schedule in the eighteenth annual Hoffhine memorial tournament today. Forty-six teams from member clubs of the Metropolitan Golf Association were here to play the West course of the Westchester Country Club.

The American Seal-Kap Corporation announced yesterday that it had acquired the Herz Manufacturing Corporation and its affiliates. The Herz companies produce paper drinking cups, food containers and related products under the Hygeia and Sunshine Cup brands.

Knoll Assocites, Inc., and affiliate corporations have leased two floors in the International Telephone and Telegraph Building being constructed by Uris Brothers at 320 Park Avenue, corner of Fiftieth Street. The lease involves about $1,500,000 in rentals and was negotiated by Robert H. Byrne, senior vice president, and Edward H. Rindfleisch, vice president, of the Cross Brown Company, agent for the building.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits deployed today what he called "scurrilous and vicious rumors" that Vice President Nixon was anti-Semitic.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) announced today its second nation-wide increase in the prices it would pay for mortgages. The first nation-wide increase in the six-year life of this particular program was made only last month.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Wally Moon's homer in the thirteenth inning powered the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Forest Hill, the defending champion, and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, a five-time winner, today gained the final round of the women's New Jersey match-play golf championship at Forest Hill.
Production of newsprint continued at a record rate in July, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) -- The Electric Bond and Share Company today asked the U.S. Tax Court to rule out an Internal Revenue Service claim that it owes $4,917,308 additional income tax for the years 1952-53.

Following are excerpts from the transcript of the trial of Francis Gary Powers in Moscow yesterday, as provided in New York by Tass, official Soviet press agency. The paragraphs in parentheses are paraphrased explanatory material provided by Tass.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Senate passed a $1.25 minimum wage bill tonight after the Democratic leadership had yielded some ground on the number of employes and classifications that would come under coverage of the law. The vote on final passage was 62 -- 34.
The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., borrowed $4,000,000 in the public market yesterday, to finance improvements to water supply, sanitary sewer and storm sewer systems.

ROME, Aug. 18 -- A few hours before the United States Olympic track and field and basketball teams left New York by plane for Switzerland, the Stars and Stripes were raised at the Olympic Village tonight, along with the flags of the British West Indies and Malaya.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 18 -- After splitting tacks with the leaders on the final leg of a windward-leeward-windward race, Al Frost of San Diego won the fourth contest of the International 110 Class championship today.

Sales and earnings of the Procter Gamble Company for fiscal 1960 were the largest in its 123-year history, Neil McElroy, chairman, and Howard Morgens, president, reported in the statement for the period that ended on June 30.
Bernard M. Baruch welcomed fifty applauding reporters and photographers to his home yesterday on the eve of his ninetieth birthday and kept the interview on a light note.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 18 -- An ornate opera house is the setting for the Conference of American foreign ministers that opened here yesterday to try to bring stability and understanding to the nations of the Western Hemisphere.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Seaboard Air Line and the Atlantic Coast Line Railroads voted overwhelmingly today in favor of merger of the two companies.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 18 -- Premier Gaston Eyskens won a vote of confidence from the Belgian House of Representatives tonight after a two-day debate on his Congo policy. The vote was 115 to 82, with six abstentions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 18 -- The nine Negro actors who came here from Broadway to make the film version of their hit play, "A Raisin in the Sun," had difficulty finding suitable living accommodations.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- The nation's coastal and intercoastal fleets were described today as the "Achilles heel" in the nation's transportation mobilization plans.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 18 -- Year-round and summer residents of this resort community are cooperating to stage the annual charity revue, "The Village Vanities." It is scheduled at Guild Hall's John Drew Theatre from next Thursday through Aug. 28.

PERSISTENCE apparently pays off. Several weeks of supermarket endeavor have suceeded in persuading large numbers of homemakers to light up their ovens long enough to cook a leg of lamb. ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Aug. 18 -- A Protestant theologian from Czechoslovakia urged the World Council of Churches today to do everything in its power to bring Communist China into the United Nations.

UNION, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Dor O'Connell of Hillman's Driving Range ported a one-over36, 38-74 and won the Francis X. Coakley Memorial Tournament today in a driving rain the Galloping Hill Golf Club.
The American Hellenic Congress, a federation of Greek-American organisations, yesterday called upon Greek shipowners to avoid Soviet Union oil trades.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- A fire at the main Soviet station in Antarctica took the lives of eight men Aug. 3. It was the worst tragedy reported in six years of organized international scientific exploration of the South Polar continent.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Golden One, under Walter Blum, carried the silks of Thurman Harkins to a two-length victory in today's feature at Atlantic City.

MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The world premiere of "I Aim at the Stars," the film telling the life story of Dr. Wernher von Braun, stirred up a storm here tonight.

Chang as the first post-revolutionary Premier. Therewith South Korea enters upon a new chapter of its history for which it has replaced Presidential Government on the American model with Parliamentary Government on the British pattern.

Prices for most commodity futures moved in generally narrow ranges in dull and feature less trading on the New York exchanges yesterday. Prices closed mixed.

CHICAGO. Aug. 19 -- Eleven non-operating railroad unions representing 500,000 off-train employes, and the country's railroads settled their 15-month-old wage dispute today. The agreement provided the workers with a 2 per cent increase pay and a 2 per cent increase in fringe benefits.
